DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 1, or the 22nd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: Amendments to Immigration Law clears legislative floor

TEXT.P: A raft of amendments to the country's Immigration Law cleared the legislative floor Friday, which will offer better protection for new immigrants.
Human rights activists chanted jubilant slogans outside the legislative chamber to celebrate the passage of the Immigration Law amendments.

As the amended law adds provisions to prevent and control human trafficking and offer special protections for foreign citizens and migrant workers falling prey to criminal acts, human rights activists hailed the new legislation as a giant step forward in Taiwan's judicial rights.

Under the new regulations, foreign spouses of local citizens who fall victim to domestic violence and migrant workers who are at odds with their local employers will not be repatriated immediately even if their legal stay period expires. They can stay for a certain period of time to seek justice. Moreover, public hearings or review sessions will be held in addressing those cases. In the past, police have discretion over those disputes.

The amendments also offer easier terms for foreign citizens with advanced high- tech expertise or special contributions to obtain permanent residency in Taiwan. The new amendments will take effect soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Two-step' voting format invalid: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed no compromise Friday over the controversial voting format to be used in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative polls and two referendums to be held alongside, claiming that the "two-step" voting scheme broached by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is invalid.
Chen made the remarks during a tour of Nantou County in central Taiwan.

Chen, who also serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , pledged that he will not give way to or concede over the dispute and cited the Central Election Commission (CEC) as terming the "two-step" voting format as "unconstitutional."

In response to an allegation that the Government Information Office spent more than NT$10 million (US$330,000) to run an advertisement promoting the "one- step" format in print media and on TV, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey argued that doing so was aimed at "correcting a widespread misconception" about the KMT-initiated "two-step" voting scheme.
Shieh strongly criticized the KMT-proposed "two-step" format, saying it would breach the principle of "secret ballots" and make vote-buying and other illegal means to rig elections easier.

Rebutting KMT claims that the CEC-designed "one-step" format will create confusion and chaos in the voting process, Shieh urged the KMT to stop its wrangling with the central government in this regard so as to allow the 18 KMT- led "pan-blue alliance" local governments to put an end to the dispute.

The central government and the 18 localities have been engaged in a verbal battle over which format should be adopted for the legislative elections and the two referendums after the CEC decided Nov. 16 to adopt a "one-step" format for the polls.
No progress has been made in the dispute, with neither camp showing any willingness to soften its position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, Japanese firms to cooperate in online shopping service

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Uni-President Group will cooperate with the Japan-based Rakuten Group to operate an online shopping mall in Taiwan, a company executive said Friday.
Uni-President Group CEO Jason Lin told a news conference that the group's President Chain Store Corp. will form a joint venture with the Rakuten Group to cash in on an online shopping boom in Taiwan.
The first President-Rakuten online shopping mall is slated to be inaugurated in 2008, he added.

President Chain Store Corp. is Taiwan's largest convenience store operator with over 4,600 7-Eleven stores around the country, while the Rakuten Group owns Rakuten Ichiba, Japan's largest online shopping site, with capital totaling NT$174 million (about US$5.4 million).
According to the plan, the Web site is expected to be generating profit by 2009, with 3,000 online stores projected by 2010.

The joint venture is the result of two years of negotiations, President Chain Store Corp. President Hsu Chung-jen said, adding that President will own 49 percent of the joint venture's shares, with Rakuten Ichiba controlling a majority 51 percent.
The new shopping site will offer both Japanese and Taiwanese products, Hsu said, adding that in the future, Taiwanese products might gain access to other overseas markets via Rakuten Ichiba.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity organization calls for home for suspected HIV/AIDS babies

TEXT.P: An executive of the Taipei-based Garden of Mercy Foundation, a charity organization dedicating to offering care and shelter to HIV and AIDS patients, pleaded Friday for aid from the public for "six adorable babies who need a home."

Foundation Chairwoman Chang Su-li made the plea at a press conference to celebrate the second founding anniversary of the Home of Mercy Infant Center, which is now home to the six infants, born to local drug addicts infected with AIDS.

Chang said it cannot be ascertained whether the babies are infected with the AIDS virus directly from the mother until they are 18 months old, but she added that some of them are already being given preventive medicine.

According to pediatrician Lu Chun-yi of National Taiwan University Hospital, the chance of newborns catching AIDS can be lowered from 40 percent to 1 percent or even zero if they are given preventive medicine for six weeks from birth and constant health checks until they are 1 year old.
After three tests, Lu said, they can judge whether or not the babies are infected.
Chang said the AIDS-suspected infants are being cared for by nurses and caregivers working at the center, while two of them are being sent to temporary foster families at the weekend.

Noting that all the people who are fostering or have expressed willingness to adopt babies delivered from AIDS patients are foreign, Chang said with a sigh that so far they have found no local families willing to adopt infants suspected of having AIDS.
She noted that one couple from Changhua County in central Taiwan adopted a baby but "returned" the newborn to social welfare workers after discovering the infant was born to an AIDS-infected mother.
She expressed gratitude to the foreign friends who are either caring for the babies sheltered at the Home of Mercy Infant Center or who have applied to adopt one of them, Chang said.

At the press conference, Paula Perry, a 31-year-old British single woman, and Finnish Tuija Heiskanen, both blondes, caught the media's attention because of the black-haired baby girls lying in their arms.

Perry, who came to Taiwan two years ago, is a researcher in molecular biology in medicine at the Academia Sinica. The devout Christian became the first Home of Mercy foster mother six months ago when she met five-month-old Sarah at the infant center.

Perry told CNA that she takes Sarah to church, shopping and swimming, or just stays at home with her every weekend. She added that she loves the child more and more dearly as the days pass and is considering formally adopting the girl and taking her to the U.K.

For Tuija Heiskanen, a mother of four, there is no likelihood of her adopting the baby girl Mercy she is fostering, although she said she and her husband, both of whom are Christian missionaries serving at the Hsinyi Church in Taipei, very much want to make Mercy their fifth child.
Tuija explained that they are too old to be adoptive parents under Finnish law, which stipulates that only those aged under 45 can adopt children.
Also in the media spotlight at the press conference was a 1-year-old baby boy named Marshall. Chang said Marshall has already been adopted by a U.S. couple and is set to fly there in two months.
The couple told the foundation that they do not care if Marshall has AIDS, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Companies in Tainan County's Orchid Plantation making profit

TEXT.P: The 12 companies that have set up shop in Tainan County's Taiwan Orchid Plantation have seen their business turnover growing up to three times their original investments, Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Friday.

Su told 11 visiting South African parliamentarians of the Democratic Alliance -- a liberal political party -- that the investments made by these companies in the orchid biotechnology park have totaled NT$200 million and that in less than three years, their combined production value has tripled their investment.
Su accompanied the South African delegation on a visit to one of the orchid greenhouses in the plantation and explained how the Tainan county government realized its plans for the plantation.

The plantation, located in Hobi township, has developed 23 hectares in the first stage of the plan. When all five stages of the plan are completed, the total area of the plantation will cover some 170 hectares.

The Tainan county government has indicated that it welcomes orchid breeders, growers and traders, as well as international marketing companies for floral products and related businesses, to set up offices in the plantation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
50 years of Fulbright exchange program celebrated in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) hosted a dinner in Taipei Friday to celebrate 50 years of the Fulbright academic exchange program in Taiwan.

Stephen Young, director of the AIT's Taipei office, who serves as honorary chairman of the Foundation for Scholarly Exchange that administers the program in Taiwan, said that over the past 50 years, the program has created an immeasurable wealth of lasting impressions on over 2,000 participating scholars from Taiwan and the United States.

Young said the program, sponsored by the U.S. Department of State and many partner organizations outside the United States, has for decades increased mutual understanding between the peoples of the United States and the rest of the world.

Last year alone, the program awarded around 6,000 grants to students, teachers, professionals and scholars to study, teach, lecture and conduct research in the United States, and for Americans to pursue similar programs in over 150 countries outside the United States, according to Young.

Many of Taiwan's leaders are Fulbright alumni, including former Minister of Finance Paul Chiu, former Minister of Defense Sun Chen, Cloud Gate Dance Theater founder Lin Hwai-min, National Chengchi University President Wu Se-hwa and former Vice Premier Wu Rong-I, he noted.
Also taking part in the event, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said the Fulbright program represents the longstanding friendship between Taiwan and the United States.
Tu said the program has set a model for the Taiwan-U.S. cooperation partnership and has had a profound influence on Taiwan's development.

In 2006, the number of Taiwanese students going overseas to pursue tertiary education hit a record high, with the number of those going to the United States increasing 59 percent over the 2003 figure, he said, adding that he hopes more American students and academics will study and conduct research in Taiwan through the Fulbright program.

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham unveils recommendations for Taiwan's presidential candidates

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) has published a special report titled Vision 2020 on Taiwan's future to serve as its recommendations for the presidential candidates of the country's two largest political parities.

AmCham said in a news release issued Friday that Taiwan has the potential to enjoy immense business opportunities over the coming decade or more in high-tech industries, financial services and other areas of the economy.

Nevertheless, it pointed out that achieving such success will depend on numerous factors, particularly how well Taiwan overcomes its current reluctance to tap fully into the mega-growth taking place in China's economy.

"It will also be necessary to boost competitiveness through such steps as revamping tax policy, restructuring the financial system, carrying out educational reform, creating a more transparent, consistent and even-handed regulatory regime, and liberalizing rules on work permits for foreign and mainland Chinese professionals," said the AmCham press release.

Even more fundamentally, the news release went on, Taiwan will need to maintain stable cross-Taiwan Strait relations, adopt a more outward-looking and internationalist mindset, strengthen its democratic institutions and build a more collaborative domestic political environment.
These are the major conclusions in Vision 2020, a special issue of Taiwan Business TOPICS that was published this week, the news release said. TOPICS is a monthly magazine published by AmCham.

According to the AmCham news release, Vision 2020 contains 14 articles by prominent Taiwanese and international commentators, attempting to look beyond short-term issues to identify what Taiwan should wish to be like in the year 2020 and what will be required to attain this.
In an accompanying editorial in the issue of Taiwan Business TOPICS, AmCham Taipei states that the necessary progress can only be attained through vigorous, clear-minded and enlightened leadership.
"It is therefore particularly timely that Vision 2020 is being published in the midst of the campaign for the presidential election of next March," notes the editorial.

The editorial further recommends that the presidential and vice presidential nominees and their aides regard the special section as a useful source of reference as they put together the policy objectives that will define their candidacies.

"After the election, the winning team might well give these papers a rereading as a reminder of what needs to be tackled during their term in office to help set the stage for a politically stable, economically flourishing and socially just Taiwan in 2020," it adds.
Following is a list of the 14 contributors and their major themes:

-- Setting the Agenda: A Roadmap to Revitalization by Michael Kurtz, senior managing director at Bear Stearns Asia Ltd. in Hong Kong.With a fuller embrace of mainland Chinese commercial opportunities, radical tax overhaul, financial- sector restructuring, renewed commitment to a strong currency, and educational reform, Taiwan could resuscitate economic growth and preserve its place among the world's most advanced economies through 2020 and beyond. But if political division and inertia continue to prevent policymakers from addressing these vital challenges, future Taiwanese may be left to ponder nostalgically: 'What went wrong?'

-- Economic Development: Moving up the Global Value Chain by Chen Tain-jy, professor of economics, National Taiwan University, and former president of the Chung-Hwa Institute for Economic Research. We should look at industries that will reap rewards beyond our time. To achieve this, we will have to vastly improve the educational system, increase funding for research activities, and provide support for industries that take time to develop.

-- Regional Relations: The Need to Take Advantage of Location by Philip Bowring, columnist for the International Herald Tribune and former editor of the Far Eastern Economic Review.Taiwan has the money, the people skills, the geography, and most of the physical infrastructure. But thus far it lacks the vision, the will, and the level of governance needed to create an identity founded on its role in Asia and the world, transcending debates on who is or is not Chinese.

-- High-tech Industry: Infrastructure in Place for Further Expansion by Peter Kurz, Managing Director and Head of Research, Citigroup Global Markets Taipei.The tech-industry foundation formed over the past two decades provides a uniquely powerful platform from which new industries can develop in the futurein such sectors as materials science, branded products, IC design, and biotech.

-- Service Sector: The Path to Greater Productivity and Higher Income by Peter Sutton, Head of Taiwan Research, CLSA Asia Pacific Markets.Removing restrictions on air travel to China and easing the issuance of business visas to PRC passport-holders are the two changes to government policy that would do the most to return head-office activity to Taiwan.

-- Financial Sector: Opportunities from New Markets and New Products by Schive Chi, Chair Professor of Economics at Shih Hsin University and former president of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance.Some huge opportunities will present themselves to Taiwan's financial institutions in the period before 2020. How well they are able to take advantage of those opportunities will depend both on their own preparedness and on the regulatory approaches adopted by the government.

-- Democratic Consolidation: Inspired Political Reform Requires Effective Leadership by Richard C. Bush, senior fellow and director of the Center for Northeast Asia Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. and former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan. Effective political leadership is neededto offer a sense of vision; to forge a centrist, reformist coalition ... to get politicians to rise above parochial interests and focus on national imperatives ... and to foster public support for change.

-- International Relations: Toward a Win-Win-Win Future by C.J. Chen, former foreign minister and Taiwan representative to the United States and the European Union.To achieve our diplomatic goals -- assuring peace, stability, prosperity, and the dignity of Taiwan in the international community -- we must try to reach greater consensus on our national identity. We must face the reality of an increasingly more powerful China ...

-- U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations: Focus on Forging Positive Dynamics by Bonnie Glaser, senior associate at the Center for Strategic & International Studies, Washington, D.C.Based on an assessment that Taiwan's economic future lies with the mainland and that it has sufficient capability to manage the attendant risks, Taipei could remove barriers to cross-strait flow of people, goods and services, and investment long before 2020.

-- Defense: A Security Challenge of Towering Complexity by Eric A. McVadon, Rear Admiral (Retired) , U.S. Navy.A strategy for the future designed to better ensure U.S. support, develop complementary Taiwan forces, and influence Beijing's thinking offers the prospect of deterring attack and changing these entrenched attitudes so that Taiwan's situation becomes far less dire and complex.

-- Rule of Law: The Urgency of Tackling Judicial Reform C.V. Chen, managing partner and CEO, Lee & Li.The ending of martial law should have removed all the restraints that had held back the development of our legal system. Unfortunately, however, many psychological restraints still remain.

-- Education: Shift the Balance from the Abstract to the Practical by R.C.T. Lee, former president of National Chi Nan University.The biggest problem with our educational system is the huge gap between the best and worst students ... A second major shortcoming is that our engineering courses are too theoretical.

-- Healthcare: How to Assure Both Quality and Affordable Cost? by Chang Ly-yun, Research Fellow and Professor, Academia Sinica, and chair of the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation.The key issue for policymakers is how the government can hold the mass healthcare sector accountable for quality standards despite the incentives given to care provides to cut costs.

-- Infrastructure and Quality of Life: Citizens' Movements Must Take the Lead by Hsia Chu-Joe, director of the Graduate Institute of Building and Planning, National Taiwan University.The state must invest more in urban policies and infrastructure, and it is vital for citizen participation to be a central element in the process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan replaces Korea as 2nd-largest exporter to China in September

TEXT.P: Taiwan surpassed South Korea to become the second-largest exporter to China in September, according to a report released Saturday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Bureau of Foreign Trade.

In September, China imported US$10.13 billion-worth of Taiwanese products, up 21 percent year-on-year and accounting for 11.44 percent of China's total imports for the month, the report said, citing tallies from Chinese customs authorities.
The ratio of 11.4 percent for Taiwanese products -- the highest level so far this year -- compared with 11.18 percent for South Korean products, according to the tallies.
For the first three quarters of this year, however, Taiwan remained the third- largest exporter to China after Japan and South Korea.

China imported US$72.49 billion-worth of Taiwanese products in the January- September period, for an increase of 13.7 percent year-on-year and accounting for 10.5 percent of China's total imports for the period, the tallies show.
For the same period, China imported US$75.51 billion-worth of South Korean products, up 14.8 percent year-on-year and accounting for 10.9 percent of China's total imports for the period.

Meanwhile, tallies compiled by Taiwan's customs authorities show that the trade volume between Taiwan and China amounted to US$74.1 billion in the January- September period, up 15 percent year-on-year, with the trade surplus enjoyed by Taiwan toward China rising 16.9 percent year-on-year to US$33.1 billion.

Taiwan's exports to China amounted to US$53.6 billion during the first three quarters, up 15.6 percent year-on-year and accounting for 30 percent of Taiwan's total exports for the period, the Taiwanese tallies show.
Taiwan imported US$20.5 billion-worth of Chinese products for the same period, up 13.5 percent year-on-year and accounting for 12.7 percent of Taiwan's total imports for the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government begins examining toys sold on local market

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Standard Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has decided to conduct safety examinations of toys being marketed in toy shops, department stores, shopping malls and night markets around the country in the next few days, BSMI officials said Saturday.
The decision was made after the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) recalled 62 toys produced in China from July 19 to Nov. 14 because they were painted with lead-based paint.
The recalled toys include magnetic train sets, toy jewelry sets, accessories for Barbie dolls and stuffed toys, the officials cited CPSC online reports as saying.

The officials explained that their examination will focus on whether the products contain excessive amounts of heavy metals, whether they carry safety instructions, warnings and other useful information written in Mandarin Chinese, and whether there are substandard products listed by the CPSC as recalled items being marketed in Taiwan.
BSMI officials advised consumers to check before buying toys containing small or magnetic parts that could choke toddlers, as well as toys with sharp edges or those that are painted in bright colors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four Taiwanese to attend Asian Young Leader Climate Forum

TEXT.P: A delegation of four young scholars will represent Taiwan in a global young leader forum to share experience and views on climate change.

Wang Ju-han, Chiu Hao-hsi, Lin Ssu-ying and Hsiao Wen-hsuan will participate in the Asian Young Leader Climate Forum (AYLCF) that will take place in Bogor, Indonesia from Dec. 3-10, according to an announcement by the British Council, initiator of the forum.

AYLCF offers 34 young leaders from 13 Asia-Pacific nations and the United Kingdom the opportunity to produce a regional climate action plan that will be presented to the 13th Conference of the Parties (COP 13) of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) to be held in Bali, Indonesia from Dec. 8-11.

"Hopefully, we can learn from participation in the forum and broaden our perspective on climate change as well as our understanding of what other countries are working on, " said Wang, a researcher at the Energy and Environment Research Laboratories of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI)
"Climate change is a global phenomenon. With a little contribution from everyone, we can make a huge impact, " said Lin, who is working on an environmental management master's degree in Germany.
AYLCF is organized by the World Wildlife Fund-Indonesia and the Center for International Forestry Research.

La Repubblica: Veltroni and Berlusconi agree to discuss electoral reforms.
Ruling Democratic Party secretary general Walter Veltroni and former premier Silvio Berlusconi agreed to discuss electoral reforms in a meeting held Friday at the parliament. Berlusconi is concurrently leader of the opposition center- right alliance "the Liberty House" and head of the largest party in opposition Forza Italia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 women to gain basic computer skills before Dec. 31: CEPD

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 women in rural areas are scheduled to complete a course of free computer lessons subsidized by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) by the end of this year, a CEPD official said Saturday.

The CEPD launched the program earlier this year with the aim of narrowing the digital divide between women in urban and rural areas, approving applications from 11 non-profit organizations in June and earmarking subsidies of about NT$14.5 million (US$447,255) from the Executive Yuan's Sino-American Fund for Economic and Social Development to operate the program.

The official pointed out most Taiwanese women, especially those in rural areas, dedicate more time than men to taking care of children and family chores and thus have little time to learn computer skills.

The subsidy program will give them basic computer skills so that they can have better job opportunities, improve their interpersonal relations and create more communication channels with their children. With their computer skills, they can also acquire further education in many fields, the official said.
The 11 organizations have provided 24 hours of basic computer lessons to the course attendees, the official said.

The program has been in practice in more than 100 townships since June, and one of the subsidized organizations, Electronic Commerce Business Association, will hold a students' performance party in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan Dec. 3 to introduce the public to the students' achievements, the official said.
He added that CEPD Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh and Senior Director of Community Affairs of Microsoft Corp. Akhtar Badshah will attend the party to present awards for excellent students.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Korea beats Taiwan in Asian Baseball Championship

TEXT.P: South Korea scored all but one of its runs on homeruns and beat home team Taiwan 5-2 at Taichung's Intercontinental Stadium on the opening day of the 24th Asian Baseball Championship Saturday.
Taiwan will meet the Philippines Sunday before playing Japan Monday in a round robin series of matches.

Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and the Philippines are in Level A of the biennial tournament, which will determine Asia's sole automatic qualifier for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, while the second and third-placed teams will advance to the final Olympic qualifier, to be played next spring.

Lee Jong Wook's three-run homer off Taiwanese starting pitcher Lin En-yu in the fifth innings changed the momentum of the game as South Korea took the lead 3-1. Park Jin Man added a solo homerun in the seventh to make the score 4-2.
The home team outhit the Koreans 8-5 in the game but the advantage was neutralized by three defensive errors. Lin En-yu had 10 strikeouts and gave up four hits in five innings.

Chang Chien-ming and Chang Tai-shan had consecutive hits as Taiwan cut the deficit to 3-2 in the bottom of the sixth. But South Korea added an insurance run in the eighth on Taiwan's two errors and made the final score 5-2.
Japan won the last two titles of the tournament in 2003 and 2005, while Taiwan has finished runner-up both times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to continue efforts to boost ICT development: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Saturday that the government will continue its efforts to boost the development of Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) to sustain the country's competitiveness.

Over the next five years, Chen noted, the government will funnel NT$55.6 billion (US$1.72 billion) into upgrading Taiwan's ICT infrastructure, including NT$11.3 billion on promoting innovative applications related to everyday life, NT$26.5 billion on expanding the country's high-speed broadband network and NT$8.8 billion on promoting digitized services by government agencies.
Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2007 IT Month, which features a theme titled "In Love with Digital Life."
According to Chen, the theme precisely reflects the fact that Taiwan has become an "island of digital life."

Citing a report authored by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission on Taiwan's digital divide situation in 2007, Chen said approximately 13 million people, or 65.5 percent of the country's population, have access to the Internet, with 74.7 percent of Taiwanese households connected to the Internet.
Meanwhile, the penetration rate of mobile phones has reached 103.2 percent, Chen said.

According to the president, these achievements are the results of policies adopted by the government in recent years to improve the country's information technology infrastructure, such as the "M-Taiwan project" aimed at universalizing wireless broadband networking and the "Digital Taiwan project" aimed at turning Taiwan into a hi-tech service-oriented island.
Chen noted that Taiwan's innovative competitiveness has been rated second in Asia and sixth worldwide by the U.K.-based Economist Intelligence Unit.
Meanwhile, 14 Taiwanese businesses were included on the list of the world's top 100 performers in the IT industry released earlier this year by the U.S.-based BusinessWeek, Chen pointed out.

Further pointing to the World Information Society Report 2007 released by the International Communication Union, Chen said Taiwan's digital opportunities are rated seventh best among the 181 economies surveyed worldwide for 2007, up three notches over the previous year's survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N representatives of ROC allies visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: A delegation of permanent representatives to the United Nations from seven of Taiwan's diplomatic allies arrived in Taipei Saturday for a six-day visit, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official announced that same day.
During their stay, they will meet with President Chen Shui-bian to give suggestions on Taiwan's policies with regard to seeking membership of the United Nations.

They will also visit Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong and Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey to exchange views on a variety of issues of mutual interest.
They were accompanied by Liao Kang-min, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, the official said.

The representatives include Tamsir Jallow from The Gambia, Steve D. Matenje from Malawi, Maria Rubiales from Nicaragua, Camillo Gonsalves from Saint Vincent and Grenadines, Afelee Falema Pita from Tuvalu, Janine Coye-Felson from Belize and Luis Lithgow from the Dominican Republic, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Autistic riders complete around-the-island cycling tour

TEXT.P: A group of autistic riders arrived in Taipei Saturday after completing a two- week around-the-island cycling tour, said Yeh Ruey-chu, a member of the Autism Society Taiwan (AST), which organized the event.

Yeh told CNA that the riders experienced blazing sun and typhoon-caused bad weather, as well as rough roads during the trip, but proved themselves courageous and with the ability to face challenges, she said.
Six autistic people completed the tour that started Nov. 18, the youngest of whom is aged 10 and the oldest aged 25.
Before the journey, Yeh said all participants, including the six who completed it, took a three-week training program. In addition, they were all accompanied by their parents during the ride.
Autistic people suffer from autism, sometimes called "classical autism, " which is the most common condition among a group of developmental disorders known as the autism spectrum disorders.

Autism is characterized by impaired social interaction, problems with verbal and nonverbal communication, and unusual, repetitive or severely limited activities and interests. These behaviors can range in impact from mild to disabling.
Yeh said some autistic children can live normal lives with proper education and treatment.

Speaking of the aims behind organizing the cycling tour, Yeh said the AST wants to convey to society the correct information about autism and the autistic, and to inspire other families with members who suffer from the disorder to offer them proper assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's demand for semiconductor equipment on the rise

TEXT.P: Taiwan's demand for semiconductor equipment is expected to break the US$9.5 billion mark this year, with an annual growth of 30 percent or more, officials responsible for industrial services assessed Saturday.

In 2006, the market scale stood at US$7.31 billion, with an annual growth rate of 7.5 percent, said the officials of the Industry and Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) , which is run by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Department of Industrial Technology.

Trading on exposure and drawing equipment, etching devices and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) equipment took the lion's share of the market during the first three quarters of the year, according to ITIS statistics.

The officials said Taiwan is expected to catch up with Japan in 2009 in terms of market scale in semiconductor equipment and could surpass Japan to become the world's largest semiconductor market by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry to follow law in row over hall renovation

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Saturday that the ministry will abide by the law in a dispute with the Taipei city government over a plan to renovate the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly named the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.

Tu made the remarks in response to questions regarding whether the ministry will proceed with a plan Tuesday to remove an inscription alluding to the late President Chiang Kai-shek at the gateway of the memorial hall and replace it with "Liberty Square, " and to also remove a tablet inscribed "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall" on the top of the main monument, after a court ruling.

The Taipei High Administrative Court rejected Friday a Taipei city government injunction request to bar the ministry changing the inscription from "dazhong zhizheng" to "Liberty Square," but it also ruled that the city government, which has listed the memorial hall as a historic relic, has jurisdiction over its protection and "does not need to request an injunction and can arrest anyone caught destroying the historic relic."
The city government's top cultural official reaffirmed that the city government will deal with the matter according to the law.

Lee Yung-ping, director of the city government's Department of Cultural Affairs, urged the ministry not to start the renovation work illegally lest innocent civil servants and construction companies face criminal charges.

She noted that the High Administrative Court has ruled that the city government has jurisdiction over the memorial hall. If the ministry insists on going ahead with its plan without applying for city government approval, related personnel could be prosecuted.
They could face prison terms of up to five years and the civil servants responsible could see their prison term lengthened by one half, she continued.

The renovation work is part of the government's campaign to expunge the last vestiges of the authoritarian Chiang Kai-shek rule. The government renamed Chiang Kai-shek International Airport the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Sept. 6, 2006 and renamed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall July 15, 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteers sell toothbrushes to raise funds for charity

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,000 volunteers for the Eden Social Welfare Foundation sold toothbrushes on the streets of eight counties and cities Saturday with the aim of raising NT$10 million (US$308,452) for vocational training for mentally and physically disabled people, according to a spokesman for the foundation.

The volunteers sold the toothbrushes in various places, including department stores, train stations, hospitals and shopping malls in Keelung City, Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Taichung City, Tainan City, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County.
A total of 150,000 toothbrushes for the charity sale were donated by Hsieh Wei- ta, president of the Taiwan affiliate of the U.S.-based Day and Night Co., an oral hygiene products manufacturer.
The non-government charity organization relies heavily on individual donors to fund its social welfare missions, the Eden spokesman said.
Peng Ying-ying, who started donating to the foundation when it was established in 1982, also volunteered for the sale, the spokesman said.

The foundation held a launch ceremony for the fundraising activity and a party to celebrate its 25th founding anniversary at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei City that featured performances, a handicrafts fair and free dental examinations to attract the public to take part in the fundraising activity, the spokesman said.
Yu Fang-chih, wife of ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, also took part in the launch ceremony and urged the public to support the activity, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: nternational headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Estimate of AIDS Cases In U.S. Rises
New government estimates of the number of Americans who become infected with the AIDS virus each year are 50 percent higher than previous calculations suggested, sources said yesterday.
The Washington Times: Illegals-law challenge rejected
A federal judge yesterday threw out a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Prince William County's [Va.] new ordinance denying services to illegal aliens.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Lawmakers Set Deal on Raising Fuel Efficiency
Congressional negotiators reached a deal late Friday on energy legislation that would force American automakers to improve the fuel efficiency of their cars and light trucks by 40 percent by 2020.
The Wall Street Journal: Rate Plan Has Skeptics, Fans
A government-led plan to freeze interest rates on certain troubled subprime home loans drew criticism both from investors who foresee losses and from some analysts warning that it will merely prolong the pain of the mortgage crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of disabled in Taiwan tops 1 million

TEXT.P: The number of disabled people in Taiwan topped 1 million as of the end of September, with the number of psychiatric patients showing the most rapid increase, Ministry of the Interior officials said Saturday.
The officials made the remarks as the world is preparing to mark International Day of the Disabled on Dec. 3.
They said the number of the disabled in Taiwan had reached 1,010,696 as of the end of September, up 4.28 percent year-on-year.

Among them, the number of people with limb disabilities totaled 402,000, followed by those with impaired hearing at 107,000, those with organ disabilities at 102,000, those with multiple disabilities at 97,000, those with chronic mental illnesses at 95,000 and those with other intellectual disabilities at nearly 90,000.

Compared with the figures at the end of 1999, the number of disabled represented an increase of 55.77 percent. Among all the categories, the number of chronic psychiatric patients showed the biggest increase.

The officials said that as of the end of September, the number of chronic psychiatric patients had reached 95,719, double that of the number in 1999. The number also accounted for 9.5 percent of all the disabled.

They said that out of every 10,000 people, there are 42 chronic psychiatric patients. In terms of gender, men slighter outnumbered women, while in terms of age, those aged between 45 and 64 comprised the bulk.
In terms of level, those suffering from medium-level psychiatric problems accounted for the most at 58 percent, followed by those with mild problems at 22 percent.
The officials also said Taipei City and Taipei County reported the most psychiatric patients, with 12,510 and 12,387, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon to debate proposed cross-strait peace law

TEXT.P: A high-tech tycoon will debate a cross-Taiwan Strait peaceful co-existence legislation he envisions with local politicians Dec. 8.

Robert Tsao, honorary chairman of United Microelectronics Corp., will meet with former legislators Shen Fu-hsiung and Lin Jo-shui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Third Society workshop Convener Chou Yi-cheng, and incumbent Kuomintang legislators Chiang Hsiao-yen and Lai Shyh-bao, in a forum on Taiwan's future that will be held at the Civil Service Development Institute.

Tsao recently ran two front-page advertisements in major local newspapers to elaborate on his suggestion that the two major presidential candidates -- Frank Hsieh of the DPP and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- should work together to draft a law that would provide a legal basis for peaceful co-existence across the Taiwan Strait and safeguard democracy in Taiwan.
Tsao's ads aroused heated debate, with President Chen Shui-bian lambasting the proposal several times, dismissing it as tantamount to capitulation to China.
The ad claims that the law would resolve the cross-strait issue once and for all and end the ceaseless political wrangling over the independence vs. unification issue.

Tsao also said the law should contain several points, including one that ensures that no referendum will be held on independence because that would be contrary to the nation's claim that it is already an independent and sovereign state.

Also, Tsao said the "independence" he mentions, like the DPP's major "resolution on Taiwan's future" of 1999, refers to "de facto independence" and Taiwan's "status quo" -- not the "de jure independence," which he said will cause unnecessary concern and tension, noting that under an anti-secession law enacted by China in March 2005, it is stipulated that "non-peaceful means" will be used if Taiwan moves toward de jure independence.

Tsao also said Taiwan must not instigate a referendum on unification, so as not to polarize the people on the island, but should only do so at the command of China, which would have to explain in detail any substantive measures it would implement to provide a high degree of autonomy to Taiwan, and the rights and obligations of Taiwan people after unification to solicit their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Stanford University forge ties in business talent training
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Nov. 30 (CNA) 12/01/07 21:30:25 (By Josie Chou and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan signed an agreement with the Stanford University School of Medicine Friday for a cooperative program under which Taiwan will get the U.S. academic institution's assistance in training personnel in high value-added therapeutic and medical equipment industries.

The Taipei-based National Applied Research Laboratories (NARL) , run by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) , is representing the government in the cooperative program, titled "Stanford-Taiwan Biomedical Fellowship."

On behalf of the Taiwan government, Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, heading a group of delegates, including NSC Vice Minister Huang Wen-hsiung and NARL President Juang Jer-nan, signed the cooperative pact with Philip A. Pizzo, dean of the Stanford University School of Medicine.

Under the five-year program, the Stanford faculty's first cooperative project with Taiwan, scholarships will be offered to 40 selected Taiwanese individuals in a wide range of professional fields to embark on one-year training programs at Stanford.

The trainees will have to learn to come up with new business ideas by interacting with physicians and surgeons, take courses on intellectual property rights, and undergo practical training at venture capital companies in Silicon Valley.

They are expected to be able to create feasible business formulas for high-tech medical startups in Taiwan, helping the sector develop into one of the star industries in Taiwan like the semiconductor and flat-penal display production sectors whose annual output has surpassed NT$1 trillion (US$31 billion), respectively, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows better care for disadvantaged groups

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reaffirmed the government's resolve Saturday to continuously improve health and welfare services for disadvantaged people, including those with mental and physical disabilities.

Chang made the remarks at the 11th Golden Eagle Award presentation ceremony held at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei. The annual award is instituted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to honor professional accomplishments of those with various kinds of disabilities.

Praising the award winners as "having spawned beautiful pearls" by achieving exemplary success in overcoming their own disability with great fortitude, Chang said the government will never overlook or forget improving care for the mentally or physically disabled.

"All of you are larger-than-life warriors and your determination and perseverance is an inspiration to many others, " Chang said, adding that the government will always stand with the disabled and help them overcome all odds and achieve their life goals.

Speaking on the same occasion, Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said he admires the award recipients' resilience and effectiveness in facing and overcoming adversities. He said the public and private sectors should work in concert to offer fair and reasonable opportunities for the disabled in health care, education and employment.
"The MOI will devote even more efforts to offer more conveniences and respect for those with mental or physical disabilities, " Lee added.

This year's award honors 10 winners with different disabilities, including hearing impairment, visual impairment, limb disabilities, intellectual disabilities, linguistic barriers, facial impairment and multiple disabilities.
Ho Hsin-ju, emcee of the presentation ceremony, said wheelchair dancing has attracted much more attending from local society since she won the Golden Eagle Award last year.

"Over the past year, I have performed wheelchair dances in many schools and prisons around the country. My performances have not only inspired disabled people to adopt a pro-life attitude and overcome their disabilities to stand on their own feet but have also aroused more concern and respect for the disabled," said Ho.

The presentation ceremony also featured a number of dancing and musical performances by disabled artists, including a belly dance by a group of dancers with facial impairments, a flute piece by Lin Ching-yang, a visually impaired musician who has traveled abroad to help promote Taiwan's diplomatic profile, and rock 'n' roll singing performances by visually impaired bands.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate reaffirms no about-face on cross-strait policy

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate reiterated Saturday that if elected, he will not back away from his "open-door" stance on policy toward exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking in an informal meeting with local reporters in the central city of Taichung at the end of a series of grassroots outreach campaign tours in central Taiwann, Frank Hsieh said that if he wins the March 22, 2008 presidential election, he will honor his promise to take active steps to help Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China, known locally as Taishang, cope with their problems and hurdles.

"My cross-strait policy visions and initiatives are based on a Taiwan-centric concept and I fully understand that Taishang face hardships doing business in China. I see no reason for the government to deny them any help," Hsieh said.
Noting that Taiwan's investment in China accounted for 0.5 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in 1999, Hsieh said the ratio already surged to 2.2 percent in 2006.

"The figures indicate that certain problems exist in our China-bound investment management mechanism," Hiseh said, adding that if elected, he will see to it that a thorough review be made and new measures worked out to make amends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 2, or the 23rd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial- level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six- and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.
Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."
