DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: EU, U.S. push rise in green goods trade
The United States and the European Union proposed Friday to make green goods and services exempt from trade tariffs to help foster greater use of climate- friendly technology around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen lauds traditional medicine's contributions

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian recognized Sunday the exceptional contributions that traditional Oriental medicine has made to enhancing the health of all people around the world.

Addressing the opening of the 14th International Congress of Oriental Medicine held at National Taiwan University's International Convention Center, Chen said traditional Oriental medicine has provided a major alternative to Western medicine, particularly in the treatment chronic diseases and senility.

Chen said that owing to the tested efficacy of Oriental medicine, the World Health Organization suggested in 2002 that countries around the world incorporate the research and development of traditional medicine into their national health policy.

He noted that in the three decades since 1976, when the first International Congress of Oriental Medicine was held in Seoul, practitioners and researchers of traditional medicine from Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and many other nations have made groundbreaking achievements and commendable contributions in the struggle to treat the ill and improve the quality of life of all.

In Taiwan, thanks to the concerted efforts of the administration and members from the private sector, the research and development of Chinese traditional medicine and pharmaceuticals has progressed by leaps and bounds in recent years, he said.

The president expressed particular admiration of the Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy under the Cabinet-level Department of Health; the Taichung-based China Medical University; and the Bureau of National Health Insurance for their promotion of Chinese medicine and pharmaceuticals as a major alternative to Western medicine in providing treatment to those in medical need.

Over 2,000 professionals and researchers from Australia, Belgium, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Macau, Malaysia, the Netherlands, Russia and the United Kingdom, the United States and the host Taiwan are taking part in the congress, scheduled to run until Dec. 4.

A total of 38 specialists, including Dr. David Eisenberg, director of the Osher Institute, Harvard Medical School, are expected to deliver speeches during the three-day international meeting, organizers said.

The International Congress of Oriental Medicine -- a major undertaking of the International Society of Oriental Medicine (ISOM) -- has been convened every two or three years in Asia, the United States and Europe.
The aim of ISOM is to facilitate the exchange of academic information and to promote the improvement of human health through research and development.
ISOM also seeks to facilitate cooperation in the field of Oriental medicine; to organize regular scientific conventions; and to translate and publish important works in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Tone on Iran role in Iraq softened
In the last two months, there has been a shift in U.S. military and diplomatic attitudes toward Iran. Officials have backed away from sweeping accusations that the Iranian leadership is orchestrating massive smuggling of arms, agents and ammunition. Instead, they have agreed to a new round of talks with security in Iraq. The meeting is expected to take place this month. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor affairs council launches Web-based occupational guide

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has recently completed its launch of a Web- based career and occupation guide in a bid to provide job seekers with more information in their pursuit of employment, CLA officials said Sunday.
The council has so far completed data entry on 71 job categories in 15 industries and expects those figures to continue to grow in days to come, the officials said.

So far nearly 90,000 people have surfed the CLA job service Web site, the design of which is roughly based on concepts provided by the U.S. Career Guide to Industries and Occupational Outlook Handbook, the officials said.

The Web site carries detailed information and descriptions of the the jobs available, including the nature, content and hours of work; job venue; vocational training, work experience, education background and professional certification required for the position; salary; and future development and prospects, according to CLA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier inspects Taichung Harbor free trade zone

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung inspected the Taichung Harbor free trade zone (FTZ) Saturday and ordered harbor authorities to map out more favorable measures to help businesses stationed in the zone cut operating costs in order to attract further investment.

Chang was warmly welcomed by Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei; Lee Lung-wen, director of Taichung Harbor Bureau; and Jao Ping, director of Taichung Customs Office upon his arrival to Taichung Harbor FTZ for his second visited to the harbor since June 28, 2001.

During the tour, Chang was briefed by Lee on measures employed by the habor to attract investment and operations of the FTZ, plus its advantageous conditions, total import and export trade value and total cargo volume handled at the harbor, as well as its future development given the implementation of several projects under a BOT (Build Operate Transfer) approach.

In addition to praising the zone's achievements since it began operations in 2005, Chang also reiterated the central government's resolve to push forward with the development of the country's FTZs in collaboration with other related government agencies.

Meanwhile, Chang gave instructions for the establishment of an inter-agency coordination mechanism to help remove obsolete regulations and measures that might reduce the willingness of businesses to invest in the FTZ.

Chang also exhorted the harbor bureau to make every effort to implement the Cabinet-approved "Taichung Harbor Overall Planning and Future development Plan" slated for 2007 - 2011, which aims to make Taichung Harbor an international transportation hub at the same time as the Chingchuankang Airport is transformed into an international airport and Taichung City -- in conjunction with Taichung County -- is upgraded to a special municipality, further boosting economic and trade prospects in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet secretary-general to inspect Kinmen

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun, who has been appointed to double as governor of the Taiwan-ruled Fujian Province, which includes the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, is scheduled to visit Kinmen Dec. 4 for an inspection.
Chen, in his capacity as the new Fujian governor, is expected to meet with officials from the Kinmen County Government to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, Executive Yuan officials said.

He will also reach out to the grassroots on Kinmen Island -- which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper -- during his visit to gain a better understanding of the needs of local residents.
Chen's predecessor, Governor Yen Chung-cheng, retired in May with the vacancy being tentatively filled by Yang Cheng-hsi, a section chief of the Taiwan-ruled Fujian Provincial Government.
President Chen Shui-bian appointed Chen Chin-jun Nov. 21 to succeed Yen and swore him in as the new Fujian governor at a changeover ceremony held Nov. 28.

Since then, Chen Chin-jun has reiterated that he is resolved to play an active role improving communication between the central government and the outlying islands. The Executive Yuan will harbor no considerations of electoral or political party affiliation when it comes to affairs or policies concerning Kinmen or Matsu, he stated.
Chen Chin-jun also said that he will see to it that Kinmen and Matsu are developed into "islands of tourism" in the years to come to bring prosperity to these two former anti-communist garrisons.
Chen Chin-jun visited Kinmen Nov. 15 to acquire first-hand information about the offshore county's needs and development programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Alarm of prices, electricity and gas rocketing.
A new round of price increase up to five percent in the next months will have the Italian family to pay more 11 euros for electricity and 45 euros for gas, making the basic burden of a family to surpass 1,000 euros a year beginning from the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supplies secure for first half of 2008: water agency

TEXT.P: Water supplies for both household and industrial use on Taiwan proper in the first half of 2008 have been secured thanks to abundant rainfall brought by several summer typhoons, Water Resources Agency (WRA) officials said Sunday.

According to WRA officials, reservoirs across Taiwan proper still contain considerable volumes of water, including those dedicated to rice irrigation in the coming spring, excepting only Nankan -- the major island of the Matsu island group.

As of the end of November, reservoirs on Nankan Island only retained some 129,000 tons of water, which WRA officials estimate will be sufficient to sustain the use of about 1,600 tons per day until the end of January next year.
If rainfall on Nankan remains scarce during the December-January period, the island will probably face a water shortage in the months ahead, WRA officials warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students rank 4th in int'l scientific literacy assessment

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks fourth in terms of scientific literacy in a student assessment program organized by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) , according to an online preliminary report released by the OECD Sunday.

The OECD's triennial Program for International Student Assessment (PISA) is a school-based survey of 15-year-old students in the principal industrialized countries that assesses young people's reading, mathematical and scientific literacy.

The internationally standardized assessment tests how students near the end of compulsory education have fared in acquiring some of the knowledge and skills that are essential to fully participate in society.

The PISA test asks students to solving a variety of problems in real-world contexts by drawing on a broad range of knowledge and a number of skills and competencies. As a result, the program is thought to effectively evaluate how well young people have been equipped for the world of tomorrow.

The 2006 PISA test was carried out in 57 countries that collectively account for nearly 90 percent of world GDP. Most of these are advanced countries, and include Finland, Switzerland and France, according to Chuang Kuo-jung, chief secretary of Taiwan's Ministry of Education. He added that more than 400,000 students worldwide took part in the extensive two-hour test.

Chuang said the results show that Taiwanese students scored very well in the area of scientific knowledge and understanding, which he said speaks to Taiwan's admirable achievements in scientific education.

Noting that full PISA results will be published worldwide Dec. 4, Chuang urged the media not to violate the stipulations set by the OECD by disclosing in advance the full details and scores of the reading and mathematics sections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workshop hones trainees' negotiation skills in cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: A workshop organized by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to train negotiation talents for cross-Taiwan Strait affairs entered its second day Saturday, with trainees being put through their paces in a simulation in which China presents Taiwan with pandas to encourage negotiations, according to a SEF spokesman.

The SEC, Taiwan's semi-official body dealing with cross-strait affairs, presented a training scenario titled "China offers to give Taiwan two pandas in 2009 to improve cross-strait relations", which presumes that representatives from China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait are the participants' counterparts in the negotiations, the spokesman said.
Participants were asked to coordinate negotiation procedures and apply their skills in two formal negotiation sessions on relevant issues, the spokesman noted.

He added that during the simulation, representatives from the two organizations engaged in discussions on issues related to Taiwan's sovereignty and the effects and consequences of political negotiations.

The three-day workshop, in which a total of 60 people participated, includes lectures by several experts familiar with cross-strait negotiations, including Shi Hwei-you and Chiao Jen-ho, former SEC secretary-generals; Chang Jung-feng, former deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council; and John Deng, chief representative of the Office of Trade Negotiations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: No change in adopting 'one-step' voting format: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Sunday that a "one-step" voting format will definitely be adopted for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative polls and two referendums, and claimed that a draft law by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) regarding the composition of the Central Election Commission (CEC) is "unconstitutional."
Chen made the comments during a campaign rally in Banciao, Taipei County for legislative candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Commenting on a dispute between the DPP and the KMT over the voting format for the coming polls, Chen said that the central government will not change its decision to adopt the CEC-designed "one-step" voting format despite objections from 18 local governments controlled by the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance, " which insist on adopting a "two-step" format.
"There will not be any alteration of the decision because all other countries in the world use a "one-step" voting scheme when holding elections alongside referendums," Chen asserted.
One of the two referendums has been called by the DPP to demand that the KMT return its illegally acquired assets to the state, while the other is a petition by the KMT against government corruption.

The president charged the KMT with refusing to accept the CEC-prescribed "one- step" voting scheme, and accused it of seeking to ram the CEC bill through the "pan-blue" controlled Legislative Yuan as a way of blocking the DPP-proposed referendum and preventing the party's ill-gotten assets from being retrieved.

The KMT-drafted CEC organic law would stipulate that the CEC be formed by members of the various political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the Legislative Yuan -- something which Chen said is "unconstitutional, " citing the composition of the National Communications Commission (NCC) as an example.

The NCC -- currently staffed in line with the principle of proportional representation and an arrangement that the Grand Council of Justices has ruled "unconstitutional" -- will cease its operations in January next year, Chen said, adding that the "pan-blue" alliance's intention to expansively expand the legislature's power will infringe upon the executive and judicial branches.

KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said the same day in central Taiwan city of Taichung that his party will insist on adopting the "two-step" voting format, which is preferred by most local governments and a majority of grass-roots electoral personnel.
The central government should take the majority's opinions into account and smoothly hold the polls, he said.
Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker who also serves as head of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, stressed that his party will not give way to the DPP over the voting format dispute.

Since the KMT began pushing for the CEC bill's passage in January this year, the DPP has repeatedly resorted to physical tussles to block the draft law, Tseng said, adding that the delay in enacting a CEC organic law is shameful in a democratic state like Taiwan.

Despite the fact that the KMT will do its best to negotiate with the DPP over the bill's passage, Tseng stressed that the KMT is poised to call a vote on it before the current session adjourns in late December should the DPP refuse to talk over the issue.
The current CEC is under the supervision of the Executive Yuan, and has its members appointed by the premier and approved by president.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer patient chooses to donate treatment funds to foundation

TEXT.P: A 33-year-old terminally-ill cancer patient from Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, recently decided to cease treatment and donate over NT$1 million -- money budgeted to pay for her medical bills -- to the county government to help build a foundation dedicated to aiding linguistically gifted but poor students.

At Tri-Service General Hospital in Taipei City, Chou Pei-shan, a teacher at Chujen Elementary School in Chubei City of Hsinchu County, told a local media outlet a few days ago that she hopes the planned foundation will be able to help realize her wish -- fanning local students' interest to study the Chinese language and literature despite what she sees as a decline in the literacy of Taiwanese students at the same time as more and more people elsewhere are keen to learn Mandarin.
Chou discovered that she had colorectal cancer some two years ago, shortly after she received her master's degree in language education from National Taichung University.
She was told at the time that she had only six months to live, Chou said. "But my family wouldn't give up on me," she added.
Since then, she has tried every kind of therapeutic treatment, including a "natural killer cell" therapy costing NT$30,000 per treatment.
"I received that therapy three times," Chou said.
In addition, she said, "I have taken more than 900 portions of Chinese herbal medicine, each of which costs NT$300, and over 100 bottles of liquefied nutrients at a cost of NT$3,000 per dose."
"Over the past two years, I underwent 10 major surgical operations, and seemingly endless courses of chemotherapy, constantly checking in-and-out of hospital," Chou sighed weakly.
"I feel heartbroken when I see my father daily drives from Hsinchu to Taipei to bring me three homemade meals, and mother seems to live at the hospital to attend to me," she said.
Lately, Chou said she was advised to cease chemotherapy because she is too weak to endure the cell-damaging treatment.
Until then, she did not know that death was approaching, said the school teacher, who now appears at peace with her fate.
"Now my parents and I are well prepared to face my death."

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet denies plan to replace CPC chairman

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan dismissed Sunday a newspaper report claiming that Wenent Pan, chairman of CPC Corp, Taiwan, will be replaced over the company's failure to take prompt action against a gas station franchise that was found selling diluted fuel.

Cabinet Secretary-General Chen Ching-jun said that the Executive Yuan did not demand that Pan step down to accept responsibility, but tasked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) with looking into the details of the incident to learn whether the state-run company committed any administrative errors.

Chen made remarks in response to an Apple Daily newspaper report that MOEA Minister Steve R.L. Chen lambasted CPC Corp, Taiwan for its handling of the issue and said that he will not cover up the company's wrongdoing.

The report noted that although Chen did not give a clear answer as to whether or not Pan would be replaced, Pan himself offered to resign to take responsibility if any administrative errors were found relating to the company's handling of the event.
The MOEA formed a special task force to investigate who should be held to account for the incident, and a list of those at fault should be available within one week at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwan citizens recognize 'one-step' voting format: DPP poll

TEXT.P: A majority of the Taiwanese public recognizes a "one-step" voting format adopted by the Cabinet-level Central Election Commission (CEC) for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official claimed Sunday.

Chang Yu-feng, director of the DPP Public Opinion Poll Center, quoted results of the latest poll conducted by the DPP, released Sunday, as indicating that 56.2 percent of respondents agree with the CEC decision to adopt a "one-step" ballot distribution and voting format for the next legislative election and two referendums, which are to be held in tandem.

Meanwhile, Chang said, as many as 56.6 percent of respondents said adopting a "two-step" voting format, as proposed by opposition "pan-blue" alliance- controlled cities and counties, would be "inappropriate" -- a figure that is nearly nine percentage points higher than the finding posted in a previous DPP survey conducted Nov. 19 when 47.9 percent of respondents said a "two-step" voting format would be "inappropriate."

According to Chang, as many as 61.3 percent of respondents without political affiliation agree with the "one-step" voting format, while 57.8 percent agree that local governments should recognize CEC decisions.

Among respondents claiming to be "pan-blue" alliance supporters, 31.3 percent support the "one-step" voting format and 42.8 percent think the CEC resolution regarding voting plans for the next legislative poll should be respected and observed, Chang said.

The poll, conducted by telephone between Nov. 28-30, found that as many as 76.4 percent of respondents recognize the CEC as a neutral agency responsible for national electoral affairs and think that seats on the CEC should not be allocated based on the number of seats political parties hold in the Legislature, Chang claimed.
Chang also quoted DPP poll results as indicating that 79 percent of eligible Taiwanese voters will go to polling stations to vote Jan. 12, representing a rough voting rate of between 65-70 percent.
A total of 1,009 valid responses were obtained in the latest DPP survey, which has an error margin of 3 percent, Chang said.

The CEC decided last month to adopt the "one-step" voting scheme for the next legislative poll, under which four ballots -- two for the legislative elections and two for referendums -- will be distributed from separate desks and cast simultaneously into four ballot boxes by voters at every polling station.

On Jan. 12, two referendums will be held alongside the legislative elections: one initiated by the DPP on the reclamation of the KMT's ill-gotten assets and the other initiated by the opposition Kuomintang on wiping out government corruption.

The CEC decided earlier this month to adopt the "one-step" voting format, under which voters will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and two referendum ballots at different desks and then cast them into four different boxes.

"Pan-blue"-controlled localities have insisted that they will use the "two-step" format under which voters will receive and cast referendum ballots only after they have cast their ballots for the legislative elections, claiming that the "one-step" format could cause confusion and chaos during the voting process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing pressure on Taiwan businessmen provokes resentment: MCA

TEXT.P: Beijing's pressuring of China-based Taiwanese business people to make known their political attitudes will only lead to growing resentment among the Taiwanese people, Mainland Affair Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Sunday.

Chen made the comments while offering analysis at a seminar co-sponsored by the Central News Agency, the China affairs studies institute of Tamkang University and Fuhsing Radio on the present situation and challenges of Taiwanese businessmen in China.

According to Chen, Beijing has constantly stepped up its pressure on Taiwanese business people with operations in China, forcing them to make clear their political stance as a means of containing pro-Taiwan independence sentiment.

To deal with those in favor of Taiwan independence, Chinese communists often resort to pretexts such as cracking down on tax evasion or applying extremely stringent customs inspections to make pro-Taiwan independence business people afraid of openly lending support to "Taiwan-centric" polices adopted by the government, Chen said.

Worst yet, China is even leveraging the business interests of Taiwanese enterprises and their workers' personal safety to compel businessmen to pronounce anti-Taiwan independence statements in line with its united front tactics, he went on.

For instance, he added, the chairmen of nine Taiwan business people's associations came out recently with public declarations opposing the government's plan to hold a DPP-backed referendum to pursue U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan and another planned referendum, initiated by the main opposition Kuomintang, to re-join the world body under the official title of the Republic of China.

Taiwan companies are facing great investment risks and uncertainties in China as the two sides have failed to sign an investment guarantee accord, he said, pointing out that the number of trade disputes between Taiwan businessmen and their Chinese partners handled by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation amounted to 201 in the first eight months of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Betel nut chewer of 35 years wins contest by kicking the habit

TEXT.P: A woman who had chewed betel nut for over 35 years recently won the top prize in a contest organized by the Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) under the Executive Yuan's Department of Health to encourage people to give up the harmful habit.
Yu Mei-ling, a member of the aboriginal Bunun tribe, won four round-trip air tickets to Singapore when her name was drawn from among those of over 4,000 other participants in the contest.

"I never thought I'd actually win a prize when I joined the contest, " Yu said, pointing out that she only entered at the urging of a local nurse who suggested that doing so might help her to quit betel nut chewing.

Yu said that she began chewing betel nut when she was only five years old. And at the age of 20, she even opened her own betel nut stand in the rural township of Yenping in Taitung County. "Everyday, Iwould chew betel nut from the time I woke up in morning until the time I went to bed at night."
Yu would eventually close her betel nut stand after getting married at the age of 32, but, in her own words, "I just couldn't break the habit of chewing betel nut."
A turning point for Yu came last year when her dying mother urged her to give up the habit by telling her that "chewing betel nut makes your teeth turn red and your mouth look ugly."
Although Yu cut down on betel nut chewing after listening to her mother's words, she didn't actually quit altogether until she joined the BHP-sponsored contest in August this year.
Yu's story marks a success in the BHP's efforts to end the betel nut culture in Taiwan through the holding of such activities.

According to the bureau's deputy director-general, Chao Kun-yu, major international health organizations around the world now regard betel nut to be a known human carcinogen, and there is strong evidence that betel nut chewers are at higher risk of developing oral cancer.

Chao pointed out that according to official tallies, the number of new mouth cancer cases in Taiwan rose from 1,700 in 2004 to 4,700 in 2006 and that the number of deaths due to oral cancer increased from 1,000 to 2,200 in the same period.

As for Yu, after successfully giving up betel nut chewing, she has now begun working to encourage others to quit the harmful habit. "There are many aboriginal people, both young and old, who chew betel. I try to encourage them to quit the habit by using my mother's words that chewing betel nut makes your teeth turn red and your mouth look ugly." Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Solidarity Union calls for two-step voting format

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) stepped into the dispute between the ruling and opposition parties over the voting format to be employed in the Jan. 12 legislative elections Sunday by calling for distributing the ballots for individual lawmakers and the ballots for specific party separately.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei said while stumping for a party legislative candidate in Taipei that the separation is necessary as the legal qualification for voters to vote for an individual legislative candidate is different from that for voters to vote for a party. Citing the current electoral law, Huang said only voters who took residence in a specific constituency four months before the election are qualified to cast vote for a candidate in that constituency, but any citizen are eligible to cast votes for a party in legislative elections.

Given the difference in the qualification, Huang argued the ballots for individual candidates and ballots for political parties in the legislative election should be given to voters separately to avoid confusion.

His calls complicated the simmering dispute between the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over the voting format to be used on Jan. 12 when the legislative elections will be held together with two referendums--- one over the alleged ill-gotten assets of the KMT and anther over an appeal to clear the government of corruption.
In hopes of boosting the turnout for the referendums, the

DPP administration decided to distribute the two legislative ballots-- one for individual candidates, one for political parties--- and the two referendum ballots at the same time when voters report to the vote stations. The decision is opposed by the 18 local governments headed with a KMT chief which prefer to distribute the referendum ballots to voters only after they had cast legislative ballots in an apparent attempt to curb the turnout of the referendums.
Both sides in the dispute have dug their feet in and there is no indication that the impasse could be broken as the elections is drawing near.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 3, or the 24th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: Police chief visits Kinmen to examine preparations for polls

TEXT.P: National Police Administration Director-General Hou Yu-ih traveled to Kinmen Island Monday to gain a better understanding of the preparations being made in the outlying county for the upcoming legislative elections and to urge police there to clamp down on any irregularities in connection with the polls.

Flanked by Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Huang Mao-sui, Hou met with Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng at Lee's office, where he exchanged views with Lee on the preparations that the Kinmen County government has made for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections.

Noting that competition is expected to be far more intense than in previous legislatives elections as a new "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system will be implemented for the upcoming elections, Hou said six candidates from across the political spectrum are competing for the single legislative seat up for grabs in Kinmen.

Hou said he wants Kinmen law enforcement authorities to spare no efforts in maintaining social order in the island county in the period leading up to the Jan. 12 polls and to crack down on any irregularities in the voting process.

According to the Kinmen police, the number of registered voters in Kinmen stands at around 80,000, but there are some 2,600 residents who have never actually lived on the island. The police said they will closely monitor the situation to make sure that there are no irregularities in the elections, such as ballots being cast by "fictitious voters" or "non-existent residents."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Premier denies report on DPP instructing banks to support candidates

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung denied categorically Monday a newspaper report that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has pushed publicly-run banking institutions to foot the bills for DPP campaigning for the upcoming legislative and presidential elections.
"It's not the DPP's style to do something like that," Chang said.

According to the report carried in the Monday edition of the United Daily News, at least six banks have been instructed to chip in millions of New Taiwan dollars to run propaganda for the DPP on TV talk shows and to host "thanksgiving" dinners and workshops featuring officials from the DPP administration drumming up support for the party's candidates in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative polls and March 22 presidential election.

Discounting the daily's allegations, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said that it is perfectly legitimate for DPP officials to speak at public functions to clarify and defend the DPP administration's policies.
"These public activities should never be distorted as campaigning," Shieh said.

Meanwhile, Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin said at the Legislative Yuan that banks have the right to operate autonomously and that the Ministry of Finance respects the decisions made by banks on their own.

Ho made the remarks in response to questions raised by main opposition Kuomintang Legislators Lo Ming-tsai, Lee Chi-chu, Pan Wei-kang and Fai Hung-tai concerning the allegations involving banks supporting the DPP campaign.

Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen -- who was included on the list of names of ranking officials alleged to have attended business workshops or "thanksgiving" dinners aimed at soliciting support for the DPP's candidates -- said that it is true that he delivered speeches at events sponsored by banks and attended industrial workshops in recent days but that all these functions were related to the development of small- and medium-size enterprises and had nothing to do with the upcoming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Department of Health approves balloon treatment to fight obesity

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) recently approved the use of intragastric balloon treatment in Taiwan, giving new hope to local citizens battling obesity.

Liao Chi-chou, director of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said that use of the non-surgical treatment will be restricted to patients suffering from severe clinical or morbid obesity and patients for whom other treatments for obesity have proven ineffective.

The treatment consists of inserting a soft, expandable balloon made of a pliable silicone material into the stomach through a tube in the mouth. Once inside the stomach, the balloon is immediately filled with a sterile saline solution through a small catheter attached to the balloon. The catheter is then removed by gently pulling on the external end.
The balloon floats in the stomach and gives the patient a feeling of partial fullness, thus reducing their appetite. After six months, the patient returns to have the balloon removed.

According to Dr. Hsiao Tun-jen, who introduced the intragastric balloon treatment into Taiwan in cooperation with Min Shen General Hospital in Taoyuan City, the treatment has been proven effective in helping obese patients lose weight.

Between August 2006 and August of this year, Dr. Hsiao and the hospital conducted clinical trials on 12 patients suffering from morbid obesity or for whom other treatments for obesity had proven inneffecitve. According to their test results, the treatment helped the patients lose an average of 12 percent of their total body weight.

Dr. Hsiao said the treatment offers an alternative to obese patients who may feel too afraid to undergo surgery. He further said that the side effects of the treatment, including, nausea, acid reflux and mild pain in the upper stomach, can be controlled with medication. Furthermore, he added, the treatment is reversible, so patients who find the device unbearable can have it removed without any negative effects.

Although the DOH has approved the intragastric balloon treatment for certain categories of obese patients, the treatment is not covered by national health insurance. So patients opting for the treatment will have to cover the full cost to the tune of approximately NT$120,000 (US$3,714).

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to expand needle-vending machines: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is planning to expand the coverage of vending machines providing clean needles and syringes around the island in its bid to cut HIV/AIDS transmission, a health official said Monday.

Yang Shih-yang, a section chief of the DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC), made the remarks while reporting at a meeting of the Interior Committee of the Legislative Yuan on the feasibility of legislation on alternative treatment for drug abusers. Also in attendance were Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang and officials from the DOH, the Ministry of Justice and the National Police Agency.

Yang noted that since the DOH began a program to cut HIV/AIDS transmission by providing clean needles and syringes as well as alternative treatment -- mainly methadone therapy -- in July 2006, it has borne fruit.
Methadone is a drug used to wean addicts off heroin.
As of October 2008, there were 1,137 outlets providing clean needles and syringes, and 66 medical institutions providing alternative treatment.

Legislator Hou Shui-sheng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested providing clean needles and syringes through additional automatic vending machines, instead of the current channels -- mainly drug stores and convenience stores -- in some cities and counties.
Yang said the CDC is planning to do just that next year, so that addicts can get access to clean needles and syringes even after the drug stores are closed.

On misgivings about giving methadone therapy to drug abusers, a lot of whom are also HIV carriers, Lee said some addicts might have to spend more than NT$3,000 (US$93) per day for drugs, resulting in many to resort to crime to pay for their habits, while methadone costs only NT$18 per day.
Statistics show that robberies were cut by 30 percent last year, he added.

He noted that in the future, drug prevention will move toward the goal of stemming the problem at its roots, adding that the crackdown will focus on illegal drug manufacturing, smuggling and cultivation.
According to DOH tallies, a total of 2,942 new HIV/AIDS cases were reported in 2006, compared with 3,399 cases in the previous year, marking the first time in 22 years that the number has fallen.
Meanwhile, the ratio of drug-addicted HIV carriers has also decreased from 73 percent in 2005 to 60 percent in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCCU develops new anti-virus chip for mobile communication

TEXT.P: Two professors at National Chung Cheng University (NCCU) have developed a new system chip that can detect and remove computer viruses from mobile communication devices with lower power consumption and smaller manufacturing costs, sources at the Chiayi-based university said Monday.

The new chip is capable of recognizing 30,000 viruses, compared to the limited capacity of 1,000 to 3,000 of conventional anti-virus chips, according to Professor Wang Chin- hsien and Chen Tien-fu, who have led the university's research on system-on-a-chip (SOC) technology for several years.

Meanwhile, the chip's power consumption is 48 percent lower than conventional ones, while the design cost for the chip is also 40 percent lower, representing a longer stand-by time for the devices and greater price competitiveness for manufacturers, they said.

Led by Wang and Chen, the members of NCCU's SOC Center have earned international recognition for their achievements, including accreditation from the renowned International Solid-State Circuits Conference (ISSCC) for four consecutive years.
The results of the anti-virus chip have already been accepted by the ISSCC and will be presented at the meeting next February, according to the university.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese baseball hooligans closely watched: mayor

TEXT.P: Police in the central city of Taichung are monitoring closely a group of so- called "baseball hooligans" from Japan and are determined to maintain public order to allow the Asian Baseball Championship to proceed smoothly, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Monday.

Hu confirmed to the media that the Japanese police authorities have informed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the National Police Agency that some Japanese baseball hooligans, who have been denied entry to baseball stadiums in Japan, have made their way to Taiwan to watch the finals of the 24th Asian Baseball Championship, in which teams from Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are competing for a place in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
The mayor said the Taichung police have prepared for the arrival of the thugs and have increased personnel, including plain clothes inspectors, at Taichung's Intercontinental Stadium.
According to Hu, a leader of the hooligans has already been intercepted at the Wuji High-Speed Railway station and was made to return to Taipei City in northern Taiwan.

Some 20 other people who have been identified and targeted by the Taichung police could mingle with other spectators for the crucial game to be held Monday, when Japan meets Taiwan for an Olympic-qualifying battle, Hu added.
Japan now has a 2-0 record, and a victory against the hosts Monday would see them qualify for next year's Olympics.

With Japan beating South Korea in the previous night's thriller 4-3, Taiwan still has a chance to make the Beijing Olympics if it can carry off a victory over Japan by more than two runs Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public advised to call before visiting clinics for flu vaccine shots

TEXT.P: Health authorities advised Monday that citizens who wish to get vaccinated against flu should telephone the clinic before they visit because local clinics have only limited vaccine stocks.

Officials of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health issued the advice after seeing more people visiting local clinics rather than big hospitals for the shots over past two days since the government-funded free flu inoculation program began Dec. 1.
The CDC officials noted that National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) in Taipei City had received only two people seeking the free shots since Saturday.

They said the low vaccination rate at NTUH could result from the hospital's higher registration fee compared to other hospitals and clinics. The registration fee at NTUH is NT$300 while Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) charges just NT$200 and most local clinics charge just NT$150.
On Monday morning, TVGH gave flu shots to around 50 people, they added, while people were seen lining up for the shots at smaller clinics, the CDC officials said.

In light of the limited supply of the vaccines, the CDC advised citizens intending to get the shots to first visit the CDC's Web site at www.cdc.gov.tw or call the CDC's toll-free hotline 1922 to check which medical institutions are still providing the free immunization.
The CDC has procured 2.37 million doses of flu vaccine for adults and 320,000 doses for children aged under 3 for this year's free inoculation program.

Priority inoculation has since Oct. 1 been provided to groups at high risk of infection -- defined as those aged 65 and over, children aged between six months and 2 years, children enrolled in the first or second year of elementary school, health care and quarantine workers, and workers in the poultry and livestock industry.

With Taiwan expected to enter its annual flu season in December, CDC officials urged the public to get immunized as soon as possible as it takes two weeks for the injected form of the vaccine to impart full immunity.

Venezuelan voters delivered a stinging defeat to President Hugo Chavez on Sunday, blocking proposed constitutional changes that would have given him political supremacy and accelerated the transformation of this oil-rich country into a socialist state.

Opposition leaders sounded victorious as last-minute vote counting indicated a sound rejection of President Hugo Chavez's proposals to alter the constitution in order to establish a communist state in Venezuela, despite early predictions of a victory for the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration agency seeks to repatriate Nigerian quickly

TEXT.P: National Immigration Agency officials said Monday that the agency will set up a task force to handle the repatriation of a Nigerian man who has overstayed his visa in Taiwan for more than 11 years.

Agency officials said Nwosu Qgonna Franklin, 43, came to Taiwan on a 30-day entry visa for a business trip with a subsidiary of a Swiss company in 1986, but because he did not pay arrears resulting from the business deal, the contract was terminated and he remained in Taiwan illegally.
He was sent to a detention center of the National Police Agency after a crackdown, the officials said.

They said that during his stay in Taiwan, Taipei police have attempted unsuccessfully to repatriate him five times. The National Police Agency set up a task force in 2001 to coordinate with the Nigeria Trade Office in Taiwan on the issue. Nigeria sent two agents and the NPA and Taipei city police department each sent one police officer to accompany Franklin from Taiwan June 4, 2002. But the repatriation operation failed when the British government refused to issue transit visas in London for the Nigerian.

The officials said Taipei Detention Center officials visited the Nigeria Trade Office in Taiwan Nov. 5 to ask for assistance in repatriating Franklin again, or to help coordinate Nigerian expatriates in Taiwan to shelter him, but no positive response was received.
They also denied reports that he would be given nationality and granted legal stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 13 points to close at 8,596, with 36,220 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 14 points to finish at 8,595, with 222 contracts traded, while March futures lost 35 points to close at 8,585, with eight contract transactions. June futures remained unchanged to close at 8,600, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,609 for December, 8,609 for January, 8,620 for March, 8,600 for June and 8,406 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures lost 2.6 points to close at 355.4, with 2,115 contracts traded, while January TE futures decreased 2.05 points to finish at 355.45, with 32 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures moved down 1.8 points to close at 972.8, with 1,376 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 3.4 points to finish at 970.2, with 14 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June or September.

TEXT.P: The New York Times: Venezuela Hands Narrow Defeat to Chavez Plan

Voters in this country narrowly defeated a proposed overhaul to the constitution in a contentious referendum over granting President Hugo Chavez sweeping new powers, the Election Commission announced early Monday.

One common assumption about the subprime mortgage crisis is that it revolves around borrowers with sketchy credit who couldn't have bought a home without paying punitively high interest rates. But it turns out that plenty of people with seemingly good credit are also caught in the subprime trap.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices close lower on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed slightly lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 2.56 points to close at 8,583.84.
The bourse opened at 8,623.12 and fluctuated between 8,645.62 and 8,565.08 during trading. A total of 3.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.80 billion (US$2.78 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent. Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.

The other three major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent. Cement stocks, as well as banking and financial shares, fell 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 999, with 416 stocks remaining unchanged.
