DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.036 to close at NT$32.304.
A total of US$700 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.268 and fluctuated between NT$32.253 and NT$32.320.

DOC.HEADLINE: Build no-kill shelters for strays: Taipei councilors

TEXT.P: Several Taipei City councilors pleaded Monday on behalf of stray cats and dogs for the establishment of a no-kill policy, replacing euthanasia with sterilization and setting up a regulatory authority to deal with matters, such as registration, medical care and adoption of stray animals.

The short-term goal of such a policy is aimed at cutting down the number of stray animals, providing rescue and medical care, and managing animal adoption and registration, while the long-term goal is to establish a "no-kill homeland, " according to the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health.

Councilors Jian Yu-yan, Li Geng Guo-fang and Yan Sheng-guan, along with representatives of the Animal Protection Association of the Republic of China (APA) , the Garden Homeless Animal Association and the Shibao Animal Protection Association made the plea at a press conference at the Taipei City Council in which they urged the government not to view stray animals as "trash."

"Taiwan does not treat stray animals humanely enough, " said Garden Homeless Animal Association Director-General Rose, who advocated that the government should increase its budget for animal contraception and trap, neuter, release (TNR) , while cutting the amount of money spent on slaughtering unwanted animals.

Councilor Yan Sheng-guan pointed out that contraception and sterilization is regarded among the vast majority of experts as abetter option than euthanasia as it costs less, is far more effective and is far more humane.

Only 36 percent of the stray animals in Taipei City are neutered, which is far less than the 70 percent in the United States, according to Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health Director Yen I-feng. Due to the limited number of shelters and insufficient foster families, there is no choice but keep using euthanasia in the short term, Yen said.

The city government has been trying to speed up the adoption process and has made great efforts in animal rescue as well as registration, Yen went on, adding that it is also taking steps to adopt autonomous regulations to unify policy on solving the problem of animal abandonment and the release of strays after neutering.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers suggest increasing seats for lawmakers-at-large

TEXT.P: Many incumbent lawmakers and legislative candidates suggested Sunday that the government increase the number of legislative seats allocated for lawmakers-at- large to "help improve legislators' performance."
The lawmakers and candidates made the appeal at a forum organized by the Taiwan Vision Forum and Association to generate thoughts on legislative reform and improvement of the quality of lawmakers.

The participants reached consensus that the "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system to be applied to the legislative elections scheduled for January next year will not necessarily improve legislators' performance.

In the new electoral system, voters will cast one vote to elect a legislator for a local constituency and one vote for a party to elect legislators for the national constituency and for citizens residing abroad. A total of 34 seats for lawmakers-at-large will result from the latter vote.

Legislator Justin C. Chou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that electing all legislators through the proportional representation system is the most effective means of preventing legislators from providing personal services to their voters.

Lee Wen-chung, a former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator, agreed with Chou's suggestion, saying that the current political environment, which is unfavorable to legislators who concentrate on law enactment at the legislature, will deteriorate as a result of the new system.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao claimed that the public tends to evaluate lawmakers' achievements according to the frequency of their appearances on TV and how enthusiastic they are in attending weddings and funerals, rather than on their professional performance.
"More seats for lawmakers-at-large will give more opportunities to small political parties, " said Jou Yi-cheng, founder of the newly established Third Society Party.

Tang Fei, the association's president and former premier, expressed hope that the nation's 11 small parties will gain enough votes to let the DPP and the KMT know the public's need for a different voice in politics.

Meanwhile, Lai Hsing-yuan, an opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker, called for the abolishment of the election deposit money required for candidates and prohibit public campaign rallies or campaign advertisements in the media to give small parties an equal footing in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four sunken boat crewmen still missing: fishery officials

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Agency issued a call through fishery radio stations countrywide Monday urging Taiwanese fishing boats operating off the coast of southern Thailand to assist in looking for four missing crewmen of a fishing vessel from Pingtung, southern Taiwan that sank Saturday.
Agency officials said the Pingtung-registered Jychuntsai No.88 with 27 crew was hit by an unknown vessel Saturday 80 nautical miles off the island of Phuket and sank into deep waters.
Twenty-three crewmen were rescued by a foreign merchant boat that passed by while the boat was sinking, but four others were still missing, the officials said.
Taiwan's National Rescue Command Center confirmed the accident several hours later that same day.
The missing are three Taiwanese and one Vietnamese.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been asked to apply for help from the Thai authorities in looking for the missing sailors, Fisheries Agency officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister decorates founder of Taiwan firm in Swaziland

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen decorated Ray Lin, chairman of the Tex-Ray Group, with an Economic Medal Monday in recognition of his contributions to strengthening ties between Taiwan and Swaziland.

Absalom Dlamini, Swaziland's minister of economic planning and development, was among the guests who witnessed the medal-presentation ceremony held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) . The Economic Medal is the top honor bestowed by the MOEA for individuals or organizations who have made outstanding contributions in terms of economic affairs.

Lauding Lin and his business group, Chen said during the ceremony that over the years, Lin has not only invested in Swaziland, helping cement economic and trade exchanges between the two countries, but has also made friends in the African ally by channeling huge amounts of money into Swaziland for social work.
Dlamini is visiting Taiwan for the 11th Economic and Technology Cooperation Conference between Taiwan and Swaziland.

Lin's Tex-Ray Group established Tex-Ray Investment Swaziland in 2001, which now operates eight firms there, employing some 8,000 local people working on integrated production lines -- from growing organic cotton through to operating spinning mills and garment factories.
Tex-Ray Investment Swaziland is also planning to invest in biotech and pharmaceutical research and development in Swaziland.
In recent months, the company has offered aid to more than 2,000 households in Swaziland that have been displaced due to a severe drought.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen activists to form emergency disaster relief association

TEXT.P: Social activists on the outlying island of Kinmen are to form an association dedicated to emergency disaster relief and first aid services across the Taiwan Strait, an organizer said Monday.

Yen Ta-jen, a former Kinmen deputy magistrate, said he came up with the idea of forming the association in view of the increasing travel via direct shipping services between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's Fujian Province.

Hoping to have the association established before the end of this year, Yen said it is expected to provide assistance for people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and has gained support from Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng.
The first preparatory meeting of the Kinmen County Emergency Relief and Medical Service Association was held a day earlier at the Hongbo Ceramics Factory, Yen said.
Addressing the meeting, Lee said that human life is priceless and should be given first priority.

"As the direct shipping services between Kinmen and Fujian have become more and more popular, establishing an emergency disaster relief and medical service system by civic organizations is needed, " Lee said, adding that the proposed association is a good example of cross-strait cooperation.
Noting that the direct shipping services will have been operating for seven years in less than a month, Lee claimed that the government will ease its policy on cross-strait travel.

The number of passengers is expected to increase to between 1 million and 2 million per year, Lee went on, adding that he is looking forward to seeing the Kinmen County Emergency Disaster Relief and Medical Service Association, the Kinmen County Red Cross Organization and the Kinmen-Matsu Cross-Strait Interaction Association working together on providing emergency relief and medical services.
The inaugural meeting of the Kinmen County Emergency Disaster Relief and Medical Service Association is scheduled for the end of December.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB deputy head resigns of own volition

TEXT.P: The deputy head of the Special Service Center under the National Security Bureau (NSB) has decided to resign from his post and retire from public service of his own volition, according to an NSB news release issued late Sunday.
The news release came after media reports claimed that Hsu Li-meng was forced to resign as a result of a recent spate of security incidents.
The reports were incorrect, the NSB news release said.
According to the news release, Chang Kan-ping, incumbent deputy head of the Reserve Command of the Ministry of National Defense, will succeed Hsu.
Noting that the center is aimed at maintaining the security of the head of state, it requires agility, alertness and coordination, the NSB news release said.
The press statement said the center should catch up with the times and that its most crucial mission is to maintain security during next year's presidential election.
The NSB will demand that its personnel focus on security work and image management, the statement added.

Several incidents, such as the suicide of a sergeant while on duty at the presidential residence and protests against the president during his recent grassroots outreach tours, have given rise to the rumor that NSB Director Shi Hwei-yow was dissatisfied with Hsu and ordered his replacement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative meeting to screen 228 Incident bill aborted

TEXT.P: A Legislative Judiciary Committee meeting to screen a bill aimed at bringing to justice those responsible for the 228 Incident and government crimes during the martial law period was aborted Friday after the number of lawmakers attending the meeting failed to meet the quorum.

Although the meeting was dismissed, Wang Hsing-nan, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and one of the 34 DPP lawmakers who endorsed the bill, explained that his party seeks to uncover the facts behind the 1947 tragedy by introducing the legislation.

Wang said that the historic tragedy must be investigated by the judicial authorities to help ease the ethnic confrontation in present-day Taiwan because the incident should not be simplified into a matter about "Chinese mainlanders oppressing Taiwanese natives."

"Such rhetoric will fuel ethnic confrontation and is unfair to Chinese mainlanders, " Wang said, arguing that the 228 Incident bill will not involve innocent family members or relatives as it only seeks to penalize the criminals and return justice to the innocent through legal means.

To serve that end, he said, the Supreme Prosecutors Office should form a task force to probe the 228 Incident and government crimes committed under the martial law rule from 1949 to 1987 imposed by the then-ruling Kuomintang (KMT) . The Supreme Court should also set up a special court to handle relevant cases, he added.

The DPP-drafted law sparked strong criticism from the KMT, which has accused the DPP of "attempting to implicate innocent persons in crimes they did not commit, " as it stipulates that even if the original defendants have died, their spouses, children and third cousins must be held accountable.

DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said later the same day during a tour of Taoyuan County that the 228 Incident draft law "aims to allow their offspring to defend the criminal acts committed by their fathers, grandfathers or relatives or to seek justice from the court."
"It is by no means intended to put their younger generations on trial," Hsieh claimed.

Speaking that same day in a campaign rally for a KMT legislative candidate in Hsinchu City, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou questioned whether enacting such a law is consistent with the so-called "peaceful co-existence" stance broached by Hsieh.
Ma said he suspects that the DPP is trying merely to create hatred and rifts for political gain ahead of the legislative and presidential polls early next year.

Although it is impossible for the KMT to entirely mend the hurt of the families of the 228 Incident victims, Ma claimed that the previous KMT government has "done its utmost" to compensate them by offering an apology and erecting a plaque in commemoration of the victims.

In response to the KMT's attacks, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey blasted the KMT for trying to twist historic facts and shun its responsibility for the 228 Incident of 1947, in which thousands of Taiwanese people were massacred by KMT troops.

The purpose of the DPP-backed draft law is to unearth the truth behind the incident and the white terror conducted by the KMT during the martial law period, according to Shieh. But he added that no persons other than the criminals will be involved.
"There will be no reconciliation or peaceful co-existence if truth is not uncovered and criminals not held accountable, " he argued.
KMT Legislator John Chiang, a grandson of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, warned the DPP not to "maliciously rehash" the 228 Incident because it would stir up a "backlash."

The DPP's scheme to bring the 228 Incident draft law to the Legislative Yuan fully reflects its anti-democratic mindset, he claimed, insisting that "this is not just a personal matter, rather it is a case critically linked to Taiwan's democracy and judiciary."

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun urged the DPP to stop using the 228 Incident to "deceive" voters, on the grounds that the DPP-proposed bill does not take into account the desires of the victims' families.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGWebsites sell secret bank data and PINs
Security breaches that are allowing the financial details of tens of thousands of Britons to be sold on the internet are to be investigated by the countrys information watchdog.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's Lotus Pond being dredged to greet 2009 World Games

TEXT.P: A project to dredge Lotus Pond in Zuoying, a district of Kaohsiung, began Monday, with the aim of making the 42-hectare lake fit for water sports during the 2009 World Games, to be held in Kaohsiung in July 2009.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu presided over a ground-breaking ceremony for the project and entrusted officials of the city government's Public Works Bureau with the work of turning the scenic pond into a world-class arena for water skiing, wakeboarding, canoe polo, and an invitational dragon boat race.

According to bureau officials, the project, scheduled for completion in September 2008 at a cost of NT$155 million, will mean emptying the lake before the dredging process begins. The fish, turtles, shellfish and other water creatures in the lake will be quartered temporarily in other facilities.
The bottom of the lake will be dredged, excavated and leveled to make the water at least three meters deep for the water sports.

The officials said the dredging project will increase the water storage capacity of Lotus Pond by 370,000 cubic meters, and that an added benefit will be greater flood prevention in the area during typhoon seasons.

Lotus Pond, called Lianchihtan in Chinese, is a well-known scenic spot in southern Taiwan. The lake is 1.4-km long and 400-meter wide, drawing its water from the Gaoping River. It used to cover 75 hectares, but has shrunk in area to 42 hectares. The lake is considered a sacred religious place because it is surrounded by quite a few temples.
Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, has been awarded the right to host the next World Games July 16-26, 2009, which are expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of legal Bed and Breakfasts up 36.8% in first 10 months

TEXT.P: The number of legal Bed and Breakfast (B&B) establishments rose 36.8 percent in the first 10 months of this year, compared with the same period last year, to reach 2,223, an official of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.
Citing statistics compiled by the DGBAS, the official said number of rooms provided at legal pensions during the same time was 8,861, up 35.4 percent from the year-earlier level.

Taiwan had a total of 2,737 B&B inns during the same period, an increase of 35.6 percent over last year. Among these, legal rooms for rent accounted for 81 percent, the official said, adding that the government's active counselling on turning illegal pensions into legal ones has contributed to the growth.

Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, Nantou County in central Taiwan and Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan have the greatest number of legal pensions, collectively accounting for 60 percent of the total, the official said.

Meanwhile, the number of Taiwan's first and second class tourist hotels, from January to the end of October, was 89 -- up one on last year's figure -- even as the number of hotel rooms provided during the same period decreased 0.4 percent, and the average room rate increased 3.4 percent to NT$3,243 (US$100), the official said.

The average hotel occupancy rate during the same period decreased 2.6 percent from last year's figure to 66.2 percent, the official said, adding that total room revenue was NT$13.76 billion, down 0.8 percent from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to help bus companies serving remote areas: official

TEXT.P: The government will help private bus companies serving remote regions, the head of Directorate General of Highways (DGH) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Monday.

Chen Ching-yuan made the remarks after five private bus companies in southern Taiwan, including the Chiayi bus company, Kaohsiung bus company and Pingtung bus company, issued a joint statement last week saying that they will be forced to stop bus service in remote areas later this month if the government does not make up for losses incurred plying such routes.
Chen said that the DGH is still communicating with the bus companies, adding that it will adopt a cost-saving approach as well as subsidies to help bus operators tide over the difficulties.

He said that the DGH has appropriated NT$550 million (US$17.02 million) for subsidies to bus companies serving routes in remote regions next year and that the proposed appropriation has been sent to the Legislative Yuan for review. Unless the Legislative Yuan agrees to additional funds, the possibility of further subsidies next year will be minimal.

He noted that some of the costly routes overlap, which he said is also a waste of resources, and the DGH is trying to combine the routes to cut the number of bus services so as to help cut the need for subsidies.
The local governments should also share the responsibility, he said, adding that private bus companies have shouldered the responsibility for serving remote areas for a long time.
"If the local governments can provide subsidies, then it will help solve some of these problems," he added.

The Taiwan provincial bus company association will convene a meeting Dec. 10 to discuss the heavy losses facing private bus companies serving remote routes, an official of the association said Monday.

Association Secretary-General Fang Sheng-teh said that bus companies in central and northern Taiwan could follow the lead of their counterparts in southern Taiwan by cutting unprofitable rural routes.
Fang said that due to soaring gasoline price this year, as well as the rising cost of tires, glasses and batteries, the bus companies have continued to lose money.

He noted that since the government began a mass transportation development project in 1997, it had appropriated NT$800 million a year to subsidize bus companies plying routes in remote region and that bus companies have reluctantly accepted this arrangement.
But he said the DGH cut the subsidies to NT$300 million a few years ago, and after the protests only NT$550 million was granted this year, far less than the actual needs of NT$850 million.

He criticized the government for knowing of the huge losses facing private bus companies but nonetheless being unwilling to make up for their losses, and said the companies think that they have no "obligation to continue to shoulder this responsibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City population aging rapidly

TEXT.P: The population of Taipei City, Taiwan's largest city, is aging rapidly as its annual birth rate is in steady decline, the municipal Department of Health reported Monday.

According to the department's statistics, the city's average annual birth rate of newborns dropped from 13.5 percent in 1997 to 8.1 percent in 2006, while the number of elderly residents increased from some 230,000 to 310,000 during the same period.
Meanwhile, the number of Taiwan's population aged under 14 years dipped from 540,000 in 1997 to 430,000 in 2006 -- marking a 19.7 percent decline, the statistics showed.

Over the past ten years, Taipei City's 12 districts all registered decreases in terms of annual birth rate, with Neihu district posting the largest fall from 15.6 percent to 8.4 percent, the tallies showed.

Taipei City's 8.1 percent newborns birth rate is lower than Taipei County's 8.7 percent but higher than Kaohsiung City's 7.8 percent. Kaohsiung is Taiwan's second-largest city, while Taipei County, which neighbors Taipei City, is Taiwan's most populous administrative district.
As Taiwan's population continues aging steadily, it is set to have a major impact on the nation's social and economic structures which must be prepared for well in advance, department officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recognizes efforts of cancer-fighting charity

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday recognized a local cancer-fighting charity for its years of effort in helping the government raise public awareness of cancer prevention.

Chen made the remarks while addressing a ceremony held to celebrate the Formosa Cancer Foundation's 10th anniversary and to honor 10 cancer fighters selected from a campaign organized by the foundation for the first time.
Chen said that the foundation is one of only a few dedicated to the prevention of cancer and promotion of cancer-related medical treatments.
In 1999, the foundation first started encouraging the public to consume five kinds of fruit and vegetables every day to maintain good health, Chen noted.
In 2004, the foundation collaborated with local supermarkets to further urge locals to follow a healthy diet, Chen went on.
In addition, the foundation established a care and education center for cancer patients, Chen said.
The foundation has also helped the government achieve many private diplomatic missions, Chen said, citing the foundation's membership in the International Union Against Cancer (UICC) as an example.

Chen said he hopes that the foundation will be able to host the World Cancer Congress in the future to share Taiwan's achievements in the field with the world community and to raise Taiwan's international profile.
Meanwhile, Chen also expressed his appreciation to the 10 individual cancer fighters, noting that their passion for life has set a good example for the public.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who also serves as the chairman of the foundation, for his part, thanked Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, and American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Director Stephen Young for attending the ceremony.
Noting that serving as the foundation's chairman is demanding but worthwhile and meaningful, Wang stressed that the foundation will continue to act as a "beacon" for local cancer patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan wins Asian Baseball Championship, clinches Olympic seed

TEXT.P: Japan beat Taiwan 10-2 Monday in the final game of the 24th Asian Baseball Championship at Taichung's Intercontinental Stadium to win the tournament and clinch an automatic seed in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

Undefeated Japan proved itself Asia's dominant baseball power once again by beating Taiwan, South Korea and the Philippines in the round robin tournament, which crowned the Asian champion and determined Asia's lone automatic seed in the eight-team baseball category in Beijing.

According to the tournament's tiebreaking rule, Taiwan not only had to beat Japan but also needed to give up no more than one run to emerge as the tournament winner in a three-way tie. Japan edged South Korea 4-3 and South Korea beat Taiwan 5-2 previously. The tiebreaking rule would kick in if three teams tied at 1-1 in head-to-head match ups.

However, the home team's hope of clinching an Olympic seed was put on hold in the top of the seventh inning, when Japan exploded for six runs to break the game open, 7-2. Arai Takahiro had a two-run homer off Taiwanese closer Tsao Chin-hui as Japan added three more runs in the ninth inning.

Taiwan can still win a berth in Beijing as it and South Korea, Asia's runner-up and the third-place team, will participate in the eight-team Olympic Qualifying tournament next March in Taichung, Taiwan to fight for the last three spots in the 2008 Olympics.

Japanese starter Darvish Yu, a 21-year-old Iranian-Japanese who was named Pacific League MVP in Nippon Professional Baseball last season, dominated Taiwanese hitters in seven strong innings, giving up only three hits and two runs.
Taiwan's starting pitcher Yang Chien-fu gave up seven hits, half of Japan's 14 in the game, in six innings.

Japan quickly jumped on Taiwan with three hits in the first inning as Takahiro's base hit sent third base runner Nishiota Tsuyoshi home for an 1-0 lead. Chen Chin-feng's two-run home run helped Taiwan briefly take the lead 2-1 in the sixth inning.

South Korea defeated the Philippines 13-1 in seven innings earlier in the day. South Korea blasted 16 hits in the game in which the Philippines scored its first and only run in the three-day tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE to obey law over park plaque row: minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will abide by the law in its move to change a plaque on the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park, previously known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Monday.
Tu also urged all sectors to adopt a positive attitude towards Taiwan's freedom and democracy in the plaque dispute with the Taipei city government.

The MOE has been at odds with the city government since the park was renamed May 19 this year. The city government has vowed to arrest and prosecute those who makes any modification to the park as the city government has designated the park as a historic site.

According to an MOE preliminary plan, the hall's current plaque bearing the Chinese characters "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" and alluding to the late President Chiang Kai-shek is set to be replaced by Dec. 8 with a new one carrying the Chinese characters "Tzu You Kwang Chang," which translates as "Liberty Square."

The park was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) a dictator and the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" period of the then-ruling Kuomintang's martial law.

The installment of the plaque will come after the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) publicly announces the amended laws for the designation and abolition of a historic site Dec. 5-7 at the earliest, MOE Secretary-General Chuang Kuo-jung said a day earlier.
Chuang noted that the MOE filed an application with the CCA Nov. 26 in an effort to confirm the national status of the historic site.
The confirmation will invalidate the Taipei city government's designation of the hall as a historic relic, he went on.
Meanwhile, the ministry is also slated to remove a plaque inscribed "Chiang Kai- shek Memorial Hall" and install the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" by Dec. 8, according to the MOE's plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor to head for London for city leadership competitions

TEXT.P: Mayor Jason Hu of Taichung City in central Taiwan will set off for London Tuesday to attend the 2007 World Leadership Forum slated for Dec. 5-6 for the forum-organized city leadership awards competitions, city officials said Monday.

Hu will present a briefing on his city and the efforts made to establish and develop Taichung as a cultural and artistic center in hopes of influencing the judges who will decide the winners of the 2007 World Leadership Awards at a screening committee meeting to be held Dec. 6.
Hu said he attaches great importance to the awards, noting that if Taichung wins, it will help the city's international image.

The World Leadership Awards were first organized in 2005 at the World Leadership Forum in London. According to the organizer, the awards are a means of identifying exceptional leadership in cities around the world and to use that leadership to inspire other cities facing similar challenges.

Each year, over 400 cities around the world are invited to join the competition for awards in 15 different categories through the submission of projects addressing a wide range of activities covering architecture and civil engineering, communication, culture and the arts, economy and employment, education and development of the young, health, housing, environment, law and order, science and technology, sport, town planning, transport, urban renewal and utilities.

The best of those projects will be presented to the judges for screening at a series of symposia in London slated for Dec. 5-6, with the winners to be announced at the Dec. 6 presentation ceremony, according to a message on the forum's Web site.
Taichung is the first Taiwanese city named as a nominee since the awards were inaugurated in 2005.

According to the Taichung city government, Taichung signed up for the award in the category of arts and culture in June. Also nominated in that category are Lima, the capital city of Peru, and Albuquerque in the eastern United States.
The central Taiwan city will also join the "Asia-Pacific City of the Year" competition, city officials said.

Expressing his pride in seeing his city recognized as a nominee for these international awards, Hu said he wants to brief those judging his city in person in order to ensure that Taichung receives the best possible score.

The World Leadership Awards are given to cities whose leaders have shown exceptional imagination, foresight or resilience in a number of key fields -- especially cities that have reversed negative trends, shaken off traditional images, and provided positive examples and inspiration to others, according to the London-based forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president encourages Taiwanese students in science Olympiad

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu encouraged Taiwanese students Monday to set new records at the fourth International Junior Science Olympiad that kicked off in Taipei earlier the same day.

Lu further urged 204 student participants from 39 countries -- including the United Kingdom, Germany, Russia, South Korea, Singapore, the Netherlands, Australia -- to serve the people to make the world a better place in addition to pursuing scientific knowledge.
Lu made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of the three-day event, which is taking place at the Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal University.
Also present at the ceremony were Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng and former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.
Lu said that Taiwanese contestants win five gold medals and one silver every year since Taiwan sent students to take part in the event from 2004.
She said she hopes that Taiwanese students can stage a better performance this year.
In addition, Lu said that nowadays, scientists no longer work individually in laboratories. Rather, she went on, they have begun working together to improve the lives of human beings.
Scientific researches often play a key role in resolving many pressing challenges, such as global warming and renewable energies, Lu said.
If used correctly, scientific knowledge can also bring a ray of hope to those who are living in poverty and suffering from diseases, rather than wars that will cause destruction, Lu said.
According to the event's rules, each team from each country is composed of six students, with each's age being capped at 16. In addition, each team is allowed to have three coaches.
The participants will compete in the fields of mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology, and earth science.
The results of the contest will be announced Dec. 10 at an awarding ceremony that will conclude the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing market of greater Taipei down in November

TEXT.P: The housing market of the greater Taipei area saw a decrease in both the number of transactions and prices in November, an executive with a major real estate company in Taiwan said Monday.

Yeh Ling-chi, president of Evertrust Rehouse Co., said that compared with October, the number of closed deals in greater Taipei last month dropped 10 percent, while the average price of NT$275,000 per ping -- an equivalent of 36 square feet -- also fell by 6 percent.

Yeh attributed the market fall mainly to the uncertainties over the forthcoming legislative and presidential elections in January and March, and the downward trend on Taiwan's stock market that has sapped many people's purchasing power. The stock market's weighted index shed more than 1,600 points, or 15 percent, in November.

He said the number of housing sales in Taichung, central Taiwan, in November also recorded a decrease of 20 percent, although the average price remained at the same level as October at NT$95,000 per ping.

According to Yeh, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the housing market has maintained a moderate growth in the past two months. The number of finalized sales increased 10 percent in October, and the average price remained stable at NT$91,000 per ping.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to promote an aboriginal colonel to rank of general

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has approved the promotion of an army colonel of the Ami tribe to the rank of major general later his month, Legislator Chen Shui-hui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Monday.
Chen Shui-hui said in a press release that the number of the aborigines serving in the military has reached nearly 10,000, but there are currently no active aboriginal generals in the military.
For this reason, Chen said that she has suggested to the president several times that he promote an aboriginal general.

President Chen recently approved to transfer Colonel Chang Wei-ya to serve as general chief of staff at Penghu Defense Command. Chang is expected to be promoted to the rank of major general at the end of the year, according to Legislator Chen.
The legislator said that Chang, 44, was born of an Ami mother, and that his father is a retired sergeant.

The legislator noted that since the government relocated to Taiwan in 1948 after losing the Chinese mainland in a civil war, only two aboriginal military personnel have served as generals -- former Air Force Maj. Gen. Kao Wei-ho of the Ami tribe and former Army Maj. Gen. Tsao Ming-sheng of the Paiwan tribe. Kao has passed away, while Tsao is long retired.

Legislator Chen said that during her meetings with President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, she has suggested repeatedly that the government promote aboriginal military servicemen that have excellent service records.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung to lure more visitors with tourist bus service

TEXT.P: The Keelung city government will spend NT$26.9 million to provide convenient tourist bus services next year in an attempt to attract more visitors to the northern port city.

The Keelung City Council approved the budget proposal submitted by the city government's Transportation and Tourism Bureau to purchase 10 new tourist buses for a service modeled on those of the outlying islands of Penghu and Matsu.
Keelung Mayor Chang Tung-jung said that altogether the city government plans to acquire 30 tourist buses for the service.
Chang said the buses will be used to transport tourist groups from designated hotels in Taipei and the Taipei railway station to the city of Keelung at a low cost.
He added that the buses will have audio-visual equipment to brief visitors about scenic spots and other places of interest in Keelung.
The mayor explained that the tourist buses will not be competing with taxicabs for passengers, because they will only carry tourist groups with fixed travel schedules.

DOC.HEADLINE: International symposium on e-business opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: A three-day international symposium on electronic business kicked off in Taipei Monday, with Vice President Annette Lu delivering an opening address.
The seminar, dubbed "ICEB Taipei 2007, " is aimed at upgrading the quality of e-commerce education in Taiwan, organizers said.

Besides offering a forum for e-commerce experts and academics to exchange views, the seminar will also provide case studies involving local companies seeking service upgrades and innovation, organizers said.
The seminar is co-organized by National Chengchi University (NCCU) , the Institute for Information Industry (III) and the International Consortium for Electronic Business (ICEB).

Dr. James A. Fitzsimmons of the University of Texas at Austin, a service research specialist, and Dr. Fred D. Davis of the University of Arkansas, delivered keynote speeches at the opening session on "service science and the new experience economy" as well as "user acceptance of information technology."
Discussions on service innovation, case study analysis and promotion in operating patterns were also launched.

The ICBC was founded in December 2001 and is comprised of professors from California Polytechnic State University, the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Taiwan's National Chiao Tung University, the National University of Singapore and Tsinghua University of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung county accepts 'one-step' voting format: CEC

TEXT.P: Taitung county has accepted the "one-step" voting format for the Jan. 12 legislative elections and two referendums, an official of the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday.

"The Taitung Election Commission has agreed to accept the 'one-step' voting format, " CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said after the dinner meeting hosted by the CEC in its bid to solve the stalemate over the voting format.

Teng said that agreements were reached on several points during the meeting, including that a poster be placed outside of polls that states that voters can claim one or two ballots for the referendums, and that the ballots cast in the wrong boxes will be counted as "valid."

Taitung was also the only local government of the "pan-blue alliance" led by the Kuomintang (KMT) to send an election official to the dinner, Teng said. The other five cities and counties attending the dinner were controlled by the "pan- green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

In response, a KMT official Monday quoted Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li- cheng as saying that no officials from the county government were authorized to attend the dinner and the Taitung Election Commission is standing by its decision to adopt a "two-step" voting format.
Eighteen cities and counties from the "pan-blue alliance" earlier vowed to follow the "two-step" voting format used in the 2004 presidential election.
The dinner meeting came after the Executive Yuan warned repeatedly that a "two-step" voting format is unlawful, and that the "pan-blue" local governments lack legal basis to defy the CEC's decision.
The cabinet is confident that the 18 'pan-blue"-controlled counties and cities will eventually comply with the "one-step" voting format, a cabinet spokesman said last week.

On Jan. 12, two referendums will be held alongside the legislative elections: one initiated by the DPP on the reclamation of the KMT's ill-gotten assets and the other initiated by the KMT on wiping out government corruption.

The CEC decided earlier this month to adopt the "one-step" voting format, under which voters will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and two referendum ballots at different desks and then cast them into four separate boxes.

The "pan-blue"-controlled localities have insisted that they will use the "two- step" format under which voters will receive and cast referendum ballots only after they have cast their ballots for the legislative elections, claiming that the "one-step" format could cause confusion and chaos during the voting process.

DOC.HEADLINE: National chemical hazard emergency drill to be held in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: A national chemical hazard response drill will take place at the Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan Tuesday, featuring a scenario involving air, land and sea emergency aid and relief operations, a local official said Monday.
Hsiao Yu-cheng, director-general of the Kaohsiung city government's Environmental Protection Bureau, said the drill will involve the participation of over 700 people from 20 units.
An emergency response to a simulated terrorist attack on the World Games, to be held in Kaohsiung City in 2009, will also be included in the drill procedures, Hsiao said.

During the drill, dock workers at the port handling chemical substances are affected by toxic gases released by an unidentified terrorist and a serious fire onboard ship is results in a chemical leak, Hsiao said.

The port's administration center will immediately report the situation to both local and central government emergency response centers for aid and relief. Coast guard patrol corps, army chemical corps and airborne relief personnel will all rush to the port to conduct search and rescue operations, while the police will arrest the unidentified terrorist, Hsiao said.
Hsiao pointed out that the chemical hazard response drill is necessary for the port, for it handles about 70 percent of the nation's shipping of toxic and chemical substances.
He went on that next year's chemical hazard response drill will be conducted on an even larger scale.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister promises to look into misuse of airport pass

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will review the country's exit and entry inspection system and make necessary improvements to prevent irregularities, Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Monday.

Lee made the remarks after a man disguised himself as a legislative aide to secure an "airport protocol pass", which was then used to evade immigration inspection and board a plane bound for Hong Kong Sept. 13.

The man, identified as Yen Jui-yang who had been barred from leaving the country for failing to pay a huge sum of income tax, returned to Taiwan Sept. 19 after reportedly picking up a fake passport abroad. He left the country again Nov. 9 and was caught using a bogus Malaysian passport Nov. 29 when he returned from Macau.

Lee said both the MOI's Aviation Police Office (APO) and the National Immigration Agency (NIA) are at fault in the incident. The APO should had checked and verified the identity of any holder of airport protocol pass in the first place.

"We should take immediate steps to prevent a repetition of this incident in which a man barred from leaving the country used a dubious Legislative Yuan letter to apply for an airport protocol pass and then boarded an outbound plane," Lee said.

As to the NIA's role, Lee said, the incident manifests deficiencies in the existing mechanisms involving commercial airline companies and the NIA's immigration system. For one thing, he said, there should have been a final check to determine whether passengers have undergone immigration inspections before allowing them to board outbound planes.

Noting that the deficiencies have existed for a long time, Lee said immediate steps should be taken to plug the holes. The ministry will discipline relevant personnel after a thorough investigation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 4, or the 25th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan targets 4.8% economic growth for 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan aims to achieve economic growth of 4.8 percent for next year and keep the inflation rate at below 2 percent, according to the economic targets for 2008 unveiled Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
While the government will work to control the unemployment rate at 3.8 percent or below for next year, per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to reach US$18,000, CEPD officials said.

The officials said the government will stick to the objectives of the "mega investment, mega warmth" policy next year to continue encouraging private investment, enhancing the competitiveness of the country's exports and expanding domestic demand.

The CEPD has set the economic growth target at 4.8 percent after taking into account the possible impact of soaring oil prices, which are expected to average US$74 per barrel for next year according to a forecast by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the officials said.
For 2008, the CEPD expects Taiwan's trade surplus in goods and services to reach 7 percent of the country's nominal GDP, contributing 1.6 percentage points to the GDP growth, they said.
Exports in goods and services are expected to increase 5 percent next year, contributing 3.3 percentage points to the GDP growth, the officials said.
Meanwhile, the CEPD has set the target of 3.5 percent growth in the country's private consumption for 2008, which is expected to contribute 1.9 percentage points to the GDP growth, they said.

On the industrial policy for 2008, the government will continue working to boost the development of four emerging industries: the wireless broadband industry, the digital life industry, the health care industry and the eco-friendly industry, CEPD officials said.

In particular, the government will take advantage of Taiwan's information and communications technology edge to work to turn the country into a global research and development hub for household digital products, the officials said.

The government will also work to accelerate industrial upgrading as well as to boost the tourism industry by simplifying visa application procedures and strengthening Taiwan's image as a high-quality travel destination, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: St. Kitts and Nevis foreign minister arrives for visit

TEXT.P: St. Kitts and Nevis Foreign Affairs Minister Timothy Harris and the country's resident minister to the United States, Jasmine E. Huggins, arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
MOFA officials said that Harris, who is also in charge of international trade, industry and commerce, is visiting mainly to organize the opening of his country's new embassy in Taiwan.
The Caribbean country has also appointed Huggins as the charge d'affairs in Taiwan, the officials said.
During their stay in Taiwan, the two officials will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and call on Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang to exchange views on cooperation between the two countries.
They will also ride on the nation's high speed rail, visit the National Palace Museum, and the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung, central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Gambian president arrives in Taiwan for five-day visit

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya Jammeh arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said.
This is Jammeh's seventh visit to Taiwan as head of state, the officials said.

During his visit, Jammeh will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and visit ASUSTek Computer Inc., Motech Industries Inc., Sun Ten Pharmaceutical Co. and the Fisheries Research Institute affiliated to the Council of Agriculture, they said.

The Gambia is an important West African ally of Taiwan which has provided firm support for Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization, according to the MOFA.
