Voters defeated a package of constitutional reforms that could have indefinitely extended President Hugo Chavez's grip on power in Venezuela. It was a shocking electoral loss for the strongman, his first in nine years at the helm. ]By Lu- sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices rise on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher Tuesday on strength in the electronics and IC design sectors, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 67.44 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at 8,651.28.
The bourse opened at 9,557.32 and fluctuated between 8,656.89 and 8557 during trading. A total of 3.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.54 billion (US$2.89 billion).

All six major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent. Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Only banking and financial shares lost ground, decreasing 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 764, with 448 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Speaker of the House of Deputies Fausto Bertinotti said Monday that the ruling center-left Unione had failed because the ambitious programs set prior to the formation of the coalition were not carried out.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N.-bid referendum won't alter cross-strait status quo: MOFA

TEXT.P: A referendum to be held next March as part of the government's efforts to promote the country's quest for U.N. membership will not change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait or Taiwan's status, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press statement released Monday.
The press statement came in the wake of a joint statement issued at a summit held in Beijing Nov. 28 by the European Union and China opposing Taiwan's planned U.N.-bid referendum.

Noting that the EU's comments on the Taiwan issue in the statement did not reflect the facts, the MOFA said that the EU does not fully realize the Taiwan government's many years of efforts in helping its people exercise their democratic rights and that Taiwan understands that the EU may have made the remarks due to pressure from China.
Taiwan will hold the referendum in a peaceful and democratic manner, and the referendum will not constitute any change to Taiwan's status, the ministry said in the press release.
The ministry further said that holding the referendum will not affect the security and stability of Taiwan's neighboring countries in the region.
As an independent, sovereign country, Taiwan is not a part of China, and any issues related to the status of Taiwan must be decided by the 23 million people of Taiwan, the ministry said.

Stressing that the U.N. membership bid is the common wish of political parties across the spectrum in Taiwan, the ministry said that the bid also reflects the determination of the Taiwanese people to take part in the international community.
The people of Taiwan hope to use the referendum -- a democratic process -- to demonstrate their collective will to enter the world body, the ministry said.

In contrast, the Chinese government enacted an "anti-secession law" in March 2005, which provides a legal basis for Beijing to resort to the use of force against Taiwan if it declares independence, the ministry noted.

In addition, Beijing has deployed approximately 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan, threatening the Taiwanese people's basic rights and security, it said, describing such moves as "unacceptable to democratic countries."
Taiwan's government understands that the EU made remarks unfavorable to Taiwan as a concession to China, the ministry said.

Nevertheless, the government hopes that the EU can adopt practical, rational, and cautious attitudes to examine China's untransparent military expansion, poor human rights record, as well as its counterfeit and substandard products exported worldwide.

The EU should also pay heed to imbalances in China's trade with other countries and its undervalued currency, as well as China's excessive energy use and ignorance of environmental issues, the ministry said, noting that all of these will be detrimental to the global economy and regional peace and stability.

The Taiwan government's promotion of the U.N. referendum is a demonstration of democracy, the ministry said, adding that European countries often hold referendums to allow their citizens exercise their power.
If it continues to adopt double standards in its treatment of Taiwan, the EU will hurt the feelings of the Taiwanese people, the ministry said.

Furthermore, adopting double standards will not be beneficial to cross-strait negotiations and dialogue or to efforts to establish mutual trust in the future, the ministry said, adding that on the contrary, it may harm the EU's interests in Asia.

Taiwan's government will continue to communicate with the EU, the ministry said, adding that it hopes that while working to develop relations with China, the EU will not easily make economic and political concessions to Beijing and thus sacrifice Taiwan's national interests and its relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 25 points to close at 8,621 with 42,369 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index Futures for January rose 22 points to finish at 8,615, with 199 contracts traded, while March futures increased 48 points to close at 8,633, with 12 contract transactions. September futures moved up 25 points to finish at 8,430, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,596 for December, 8,593 for January, 8,585 for March, 8,600 for June and 8,405 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures rose 2.45 points to close at 357.85, with 2,233 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 1.95 points to finish at 357.4, with 43 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June or September.

December TF futures lost 6.2 points to close at 965.8, with 2,157 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 5.4 points to finish at 966.4, with 19 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June or September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N.-bid referendum 'neither necessary nor helpful': AIT director

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Director Stephen Young on Monday described a referendum being promoted by Taiwan's government on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan as "neither necessary nor helpful."
The referendum is slated to be held next March alongside Taiwan's presidential election.

Young made the remarks while delivering a speech on "Opportunities and Challenges in U.S.-Taiwan and Cross-Strait Relations" at a conference organized by the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies (FICS).
During his address, Young said the United States views China's sustained military buildup, including its missile deployments, as a destabilizing factor in cross-strait relations.
Speaking of Taiwan's upcoming legislative and presidential elections, Young noted that the U.S. government is observing the elections "with great interest and respect."
"These elections, regardless of who wins, will inevitably open up new possibilities for Taiwan and for U.S.-Taiwan and cross-strait relations," Young said.

Noting that Washington does not and will not take sides in Taiwan's democratic politics, Young said that the United States "looks forward to working closely with whomever the people of Taiwan elect as their next president."

Meanwhile, Young also noted that the United States "has good communications with" Frank Hsieh and Ma Ying-jeou -- presidential candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), respectively.

According to Young, "the solid base of Taiwan's relationship with the United States and other important countries means that Taiwan enjoys international access and support, and is not so isolated as some would argue."

However, Young pointed out that two recent episodes -- namely Taiwan's "ceasing" of the functioning and application of the National Unification Council and Guidelines, and its promotion of the U.N.-bid referendum -- could be "problematic and even risky."
"Unfortunately, these types of episodes tend to have a cumulative effect, damaging trust in U.S.-Taiwan relations over time," he added.
He said the United States hopes and expects that strengthening trust between the two countries will be an important priority for Taiwan's next president.

DOC.HEADLINE: High Court rejects appeal by president's daughter on slander case

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu lost her appeal Tuesday after the Taiwan High Court upheld a lower court ruling that a television commentator's remarks about her engaging in suspected money laundering in New York in September 2005 did not constitute slander.

Chen Hsing-yu filed the appeal after the Taipei District Court ruled on Aug. 28 that TV commentator Hu Chung-hsin had no intention of defaming her when he disclosed in a series of programs in October 2005 that the president's daughter had opened a bank account in New York City to engage in money laundering.

At the time, the president and his family were dogged by a series of corruption scandals. In one of the scandals involving the embezzlement of the Presidential Office's state affairs funds, a public prosecutor listed the president and the first lady as "joint perpetrators."

Cheng Hsing-yu, a dentist, stayed in New York City Sept. 12-16, 2005, to attend a short-term course on dental implant techniques, but Hu quoted unnamed sources as saying that she was seen in the company of friends opening an account with a New York bank.
Hu also alleged that the bank account was opened apparently for the purpose of money laundering.
The district court said in its written statement that two witnesses testified that their Taiwanese friends returning from the United States saw Chen Hsing-yu opening the account.

Although the court asked the Ministry of Justice to verify whether she had opened such an account, the ministry pointed out that it could not request U.S. help for such investigation because opening a bank account is not a criminal act, the statement said.

Another dentist from Taiwan who attended the same course testified that Chen Hsing-yu skipped one afternoon class. The court said it could not be ruled out that she might have used that opportunity to open the account.
Based on these facts, the lower court decided that Hu could not be found guilty of slander unless it could be ascertained that no account was opened.

The high court rejected Chen Hsing-yu's appeal and upheld the lower court's ruling, saying that Hu's remarks did not constitute slander and that he was merely exercising his freedom of speech. The case is now closed as the high court's ruling is final.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese film wins award in India
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/07 18:49:34 (By Paul Kuo and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese film, "The Wall", directed by Lin Chih-ju has won the Golden Peacock Award for the best film among feature films by directors from Asia, Africa and Latin America at the 38th International Film Festival of India (IFFI) , which came to a close Monday.
Lin was granted a medal and US$25,500 in prize money for the honor at the festival, which started Nov. 23 in the Province of Goa, India, and drew over 200 films from 43 countries for the competition.
Lin was also an award winner at Taiwan's 42nd Golden Bell Awards, held in November this year.

"The Wall" was chosen from among a selection of 14 films from 13 countries including Argentina, Bangladesh, Columbia, Israel, Mexico, Morocco, Pakistan, Georgia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. Two Indian films and Hong Kong director Ann Hui's "The Aunt's Postmodern Life" were also enrolled in the competition.

The festival's Web site introduced the Taiwanese work as a "finely crafted film about dreams, hope, betrayal and love that depicts ordinary people coping in politically challenging times, " and that "the filmmaker has created a complete world within the four walls of a simple house"

The five-member jury at the competition was chaired by Hungarian filmmaker Marta Mazaros. Other jury members included leading Turkish actress Meltem Cumbul, noted Argentinean filmmaker Pablo Cesar, New Zealand director Robert Sarkies and one of India's most respected filmmakers, Shaji N Karun.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, rising NT$0.01 to close at NT$32.305.
A total of US$635 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.304 and fluctuated between NT$32.304 and NT$32.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Marshall Islands ties not to be affected by election: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relations with the Marshall Islands will not be affected by the outcome of that country's parliamentary election, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Tuesday.

He said that although China has attempted to manipulate the election outcome through Taiwanese business people, the solid diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the central Pacific nation will not be undermined.

He also said that China will never relax its relentless obstruction and will not "refrain from taking actions ahead of Taiwan's legislative and presidential elections or for any other reasons, " reaffirming that Taiwan must not harbor any false illusions about China.

His remarks came with the outcome of the Marshall Islands' November national election due to be published either Tuesday night or Wednesday morning following the counting of overseas postal ballots. The opposition party Aelon Kein Ad (AKA) has claimed victory, although the ruling United Democratic Party (UDP) also said that they could gain a majority in the 33-member legislature.

Donald Lee, director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, noted that information received by the ministry showed that China pumped a huge amount of money into the election through Taiwanese business people.

Lee noted there are around 25 Taiwanese families in the Marshall Islands, and one or two of them are willing to serve China by helping stump for the opposition party, or providing funds to candidates.

Even though the Marshall Islands parliamentary Speaker Litokwa Tomeing visited China ahead of the national election and said that the AKA will switch diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China, Lee said that Tomeing has since clarified his stance to Taiwan's ambassador to the country.
Tomeing has been the Marshall Islands' parliamentary speaker for the eight years since the UDP of President Kessai Note won the presidential election.

Lee also quoted a senior parliamentarian Tony de Brum, one of the four leading opposition lawmakers who visited China recently, as saying that if the AKA wins the election it will not switch diplomatic relation to China and the country will continue to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
"Whether it is the UDP or the AKA that wins the election, the ministry will keep abreast of the situation and bilateral relations will remain unaffected," he added.

Lee said that a project to generate solar power on an outlying island of the Marshall Islands will be completed in March or April next year, and will be sufficient to provide electricity to 973 households.
Taiwan established diplomatic relations with the Marshall Islands in 1998, and the two nations have since maintained a close and cordial relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan ocean park set to be completed in three years

TEXT.P: The Yilan county government has signed a contract with two private investors Tuesday for the construction of an ocean park under the build-own-operate (BOO) format.

The park, to be located in the county's Wuchieh township, will feature a polar animal zone -- the first of its kind in Taiwan -- and a 118 meter-long transparent, underwater tunnel that is expected to be the world's longest by the time it is completed.

The NT$2.7 billion project is being invested in jointly by the Taiwan-based Turtle Mountain Island Ocean Development Co. and the Malaysia-based KMzone Business Community, which has taken part in the development of several ocean parks in China.
Construction of the park is scheduled to start in March next year, with the park expected to be open to the public in three years, officials said.

In addition to a polar animal zone where polar species such as polar bears, penguins, beluga whales and arctic wolves will be on display, the park will also include a marine animal zone, a scuba diving zone, a river-lake ecology zone, a rain forest ecology zone, an Oceania zone, a Greet Barrier Reef zone, an outdoor performance zone, a 4D theater, water play facilities, a hotel and a restaurant, they said.
Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua said the park is expected to become a new tourist attraction and help increase local people's knowledge of polar animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local researchers improve black pearl cultivation techniques

TEXT.P: Mariculture researchers at National Penghu University (NPU) have successfully improved on techniques to cultivate black pearls, providing a higher yield rate and shorter breeding period, university sources reported Tuesday.

Ueng Jinn-pyng, director of NPU's Netcage Aquaculture Product Technique Research Center, said the university has been developing black-lip oyster cultivation techniques for more than three years and given the latest results black pearls can now be cultivated with much greater ease.
Ueng explained that with the aid of improved techniques 100 black-lipped oysters in the test group produced a total of 20 black pearls -- each worth more than NT$10,000 (US$309).

Meanwhile, Ueng said, the breeding period from seed oyster to pearl harvest has been shorten to three years, a year less than the conventional method typically used in Japan -- a major player in the global pearl business.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: An Assessment Jars a Foreign Policy Debate About Iran
Rarely, if ever, has a single intelligence report so completely, so suddenly, and so surprisingly altered a foreign policy debate here.
An administration that had cited Iranzs pursuit of nuclear weapons as the rationale for an aggressive foreign policyXas an attempt to head off World War III, as President Bush himself put it only weeks agoXnow has in its hands a classified document that undercuts much of the foundation for that approach.
The Wall Street Journal: Economy Moves To Fore as Issue For 2008 Voters
For months, Dale Albright, a 30-year-old Tampa, Fla., bankruptcy lawyer, has watched as his clients buckle under mortgage and credit-card debts. After an expensive recent hospital stay, he's worried that a run of bad luck could leave him in financial straits, too.
"I care about bringing our troops home... and for the most part, I believe as far as domestic terrorism goes, I think we've got that pretty much under control, " Mr. Albright says. " But the economy really scares me." A longtime Republican, this election he says he's voting Democrat.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: A Blow to Bush's Tehran Policy
President Bush got the world's attention this fall when he warned that a nuclear-armed Iran might lead to World War III. But his stark warning came at least a month or two after he had first been told about fresh indications that Iran had actually halted its nuclear weapons program.
The Washington Times: U.S. moves to pre-empt foreclosures
The Bush administration, faced with criticism for doing little to stop a rapidly unfolding mortgage crisis this year, is working feverishly behind the scenes with lenders on a plan that could forestall a tidal wave of foreclosures and defaults next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Securities Association signs MOU with Mongolian counterpart

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Association (TSA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with its Mongolian counterpart, the Mongolian Securities Dealers and Brokers Association (MSDBA) , on cooperating to tap emerging markets, a TSA spokesman said Tuesday.
The MOU was signed by TSA President Huang Min-chu and his MSDBA counterpart in Taipei Monday, according to the spokesman.
It is the second agreement the TSA has signed with a foreign counterpart, following an earlier one signed with the Japan Securities Dealers Association in September 2007.
"The partnership with the Mongolian securities association is expected to help Taiwan move into such emerging markets as Russia and China, " Huang said.
According to Huang, foreign investment has been pouring into Mongolia since its entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1997, bringing enormous economic growth to the nation.
Huang further pointed out that the stock market in Mongolia has been developing steadily since the establishment of the Mongolian Stock Exchange (MSE) in 1991.
"In Mongolia, the growth of share prices in 2006 doubled that of 2005, and stock prices have also grown by a wide margin this year, " Huang added.

The MSDBA, a nationwide organization and the only securities association in Mongolia, was founded by securities dealers and brokers and is comprised of members from MSE, 38 securities brokerage firms and three mutual fund companies.
Taiwan's experiences in personnel training, encouraging market prosperity and risk management provide important references for MSE, Huang said.

Meanwhile, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng encouraged Taiwanese securities firms to be more active in forging bilateral collaborations with their Mongolian counterparts as Mongolia is not only a member of the WTO, IMF and World Bank, but also because its geographic location and rich natural resources make Mongolia an important potential market.

"Taiwan's GreTai Securities Exchange and the Taiwan Futures Exchange have already signed an MOU with the Mongolian Stock Exchange in August, " Hu said, adding that the experiences of TSA in personnel management and market planning will provide great benefits to both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC upbeat about opening of Taiwan visits by Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei expressed optimism Tuesday about opening Taiwan to visits by Chinese tourists next year.

Making the remarks while addressing a celebration for the 51st anniversary of the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) , Tsai said government funds for international publicity promoting Taiwan's tourism will double next year after the passage of a related budget by the Legislative Yuan.

Tourism Bureau officials said the government's budget for international publicity promoting Taiwan as a travel destination amounted to NT$900 million this year and is expected to increase to more than NT$1.5 billion next year.
However, even after the increase, the figure will remain small in comparison with Hong Kong's NT$3 billion per year and Malaysia's NT$5 billion per year, the officials said.
Meanwhile, TVA President Chang Hsueh-lau said the association will make China its main target for its international publicity drive next year.
Taiwan and China have held several rounds of talks on visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists, but a final agreement has yet to be signed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Customs Office seizes 329 kg of illicit drugs this year

TEXT.P: The Taipei Customs Office announced Tuesday that its officials had seized 329 kg of illicit drugs this year as of the end of November.

A spokesman for the office said the narcotics seizures in November totaled 25 kg, including 23.6 kg of ketamine and 1.33 kg of heroin. He added that about 45 percent of the drugs were detected by X-ray scanners at points of entry, while 33 percent were found because of information provided by informers.

The spokesman also said that most of the drugs seized in the 11-month period were shipped via international express parcel services or carried by passengers who hid narcotics in their checked-in luggage or in their carry-on luggage.

In addition to illegal drugs, customs officials also confiscated 185 kg of fresh deer antler velvet -- a material used in oriental medicine to improve sexual stamina -- 170 antelope horns, 276 kg of hairy crabs, 100 counterfeit credit cards and large numbers of pirated video games.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government amends regulations to protect historic plague

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government passed a proposal Tuesday to amend regulations governing city-designated historic relics in an effort to protect a landmark plaque hanging on the gateway of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall from being torn down.

The amendment is an outgrowth of the city government's urgent strategy to respond to the Ministry of Education (MOE) -initiated plan to replace the plaque -- bearing Chinese characters reading "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" -- which is said to allude to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, with another reading "Liberty Square" by Dec. 8.

However, since the MOE's plan was put forward last month it has faced strong resistance from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -administrated Taipei city government, with the city government criticizing the plan to tear down the plaque, which is part of an historic site, as an "autocratic" act aimed at expunging the last vestiges of Chiang's rule.

The late president was also a chairman of the KMT that ruled Taiwan for 50 years until the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in 2000. He has been branded by the DPP as a dictator and fingered as the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during a period of KMT-imposed martial law.

Under the amendment adopted earlier in the day at the local government's administrative meeting, an amendment was passed stipulating that the central government's move to designate or abolish the "national status" of a historic relic located in the city will not affect the relic's status as a city- designated historic site.

The amendment came after the MOE's filing of an application with the Cabinet- level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Nov. 26 to confirm the national status of the historic site, now designated Taiwan Democratic Memorial Park but previously known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park, which was built in 1980 to commemorate the late president.

Confirmation of the landmark's status as a national historical site would invalidate the Taipei city government's designation of the park as a city historic relic under the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law.

With CCA confirmation expected Wednesday, when the council is scheduled to publicize revised regulations governing reviews of the designation and abolition of historic sites, the MOE may soon begin work to "renovate" the memorial hall.

However, under the city government-revised regulations, "the central government's move to manage, maintain, repair or re-use a city-designated historic site should obtain a permit from the city government, " said Yeh Chin- yuan, commissioner of the city's Law and Regulation Commission.
Yeh noted the new rule will take effect Tuesday.

In response to a question posed by reporters as to whether the city government wrote the new regulation on the basis of its own biased political ideology, Lee Yung-ping, director of the City Department of Cultural Affairs, claimed the department was forced to take the action to stop the attempt to replace the plaque, which was itself driven by a contrary political ideology.
The CKS Memorial Hall is a popular tourist attraction in the capital city, Lee said, wondering aloud why the MOE insists on changing its name and the plaque that has become a landmark.

Responding to another question, Yeh admitted that the memorial hall could be a symbol of Taiwan's authoritarian past, but insisted it would be wrong to impose another form of autocratic rule to eliminate its existence, referring to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian's determination to "root out" Chiang's authoritarian legacy.

The central government renamed Chiang Kai-shek International Airport the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Sept. 6, 2006 and renamed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall as National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials, developers learn from U.K. urban regeneration experience

TEXT.P: Local officials and land developers were keen to learn from the experience in the United Kingdom during a conference Tuesday as several major urban regeneration projects are being implemented in various regions throughout Taiwan.

"We don't have enough experience in major urban redevelopment here in Taiwan. That is why we're having this conference to learn from the U.K., which has enjoyed success in this field and developed its expertise, " said Charles Lin, Director-General of Construction and Planning Agency (CPA).

Lin said that the conference, co-organized by the CPA and the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei, would bring valuable knowledge and experience to the participants who are expected to be engaged in many projects in the future.

"Urban regeneration is not easy and it can be expensive. But it's an important task for any modern country, " BTCO Director Michael Reilly said, adding that he was glad that up to 10 regions had been selected to undertake such urban transformation.

With many successful cases in the United States and the U.K., such as the Canary Wharf business district in London and Cardiff in Wales, Taiwan will launch its own multibillion dollar urban regeneration projects at the end of year, including renovation of railway stations in Hsinchu, Keelung, Chiayi and Kaohsiung Port and Taipei's Huakuang Community adjoining the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, Lin said.

During the industrial revolution and after the years of World War II, a lot of large scale and cheap housing projects were built without consideration of the cultural and social context, which is why urban renewal was introduced, said Rupert Robinson, Board Director of the British Urban Regeneration Association (BURA).

Urban regeneration could lead to destruction of buildings, relocation of people, and sometimes expropriation to make available private property. It also involved many parties, including the government, developers and residents, and covered a broad range of social, economical and cultural contexts, Robinson said.
Dialogue with communities and reaching a consensus were extremely important to the process, said Shawn Riley, who also serves as BURA's Board Director.

"Developers and the government had to tell the residents exactly which part of town needed to be regenerated first and what the town would be like in phase one, two and three so they had a clear picture of what the future would be, " Riley said.

The government was also expected to use infrastructure as an enabler and attract investment from private sectors under a well-structured financing plan so all parties could benefit from regeneration plans, Robinson added.
In Taiwan, the government should be very careful with the role it plays during the process because resources are limited, Lin pointed out.
"We have to make it right, not spread it out, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80% of Sports Lottery profits to be used for sports development

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will approve a package of draft amendments to the lottery statute that will see only 20 percent of profits from the Sports Lottery used for social welfare and the other 80 percent on sports development, an Executive Yuan official said Tuesday.

The Executive Yuan is expected to pass the draft amendments at its weekly meeting Wednesday, the official said, adding that law revision is expected to be finished before the Sports Lottery is launched next May.

The amendments were initiated by the Sports Affairs Council, which proposed the issuance of the Sports Lottery to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) last year, the official said, adding that under the amended statute, the MOF will oversee Sports Lottery funds.
The Sports Lottery is scheduled to be formally issued May 2, 2008 by Taipei Fubon Bank.

Under the existing Statute for the Issuance of Welfare Lottery Tickets, lottery issuing institutes have to use profits gained from issuance of lotteries, including the Sports Lottery, for social welfare affairs and government subsidies for pensions and national health insurance, not in the sports field, the official said.

Minister-without-Portfolio Ho Mei-Yueh convened meeting to promote the approval of amendments to the statute in order to establish a legal basis upon which Sports Lottery profits could be spent in the sporting field, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei police vow to crack down on drunken driving

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Police Department indicated Tuesday that its police force will intensify their efforts to combat drunken driving in the winter season when people are drinking more frequently.

A spokesman for the department said the city police force will conduct no less than 10 operations each month to set up road blocks at 122 strategic locations in the city to check driver sobriety, with each operation supported by more than 400 officers.

Noting that many drivers drink and drive just because they feel they might get away with it, the spokesman warned that alcohol and driving do not mix, and that those who ignore the rule could end up paying a heavy price.
The legislature is in the process of amending an existing criminal law to increase the fine for drunken driving from the current NT$30,000 to NT$150,000.

Statistics compiled by the Taipei City Police Department show that in the first 10 months of this year, police took 16,359 drunken drivers into custody. A total of 8,966 offenses occurred between midnight and 6 a.m., with 5,222 happening between 6 p.m. and midnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Din Tai Fung delicacies to be 'diplomatic weapon': Minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is going to employ delicacies created by the celebrated restaurant Din Tai Fung to conduct "soft power diplomacy."
Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang made the announcement Monday while hosting a luncheon at the MOFA reception hall with Din Tai Fung chefs serving the company's trademark dishes on the spot.

Describing the reception hall full of the "luscious aroma of meat" from Din Tai Fung delicacies, Huang said that introducing Taiwan's distinguished culinary culture to international society could be a creative tactic in the nation's attempt to break through China's diplomatic containment.

Renowned in the international culinary world, Din Tai Fung is going to send a group of 17 chefs to the United Kingdom and France to prepare all kinds of savory cuisine for their guests, including its famous steamed pork dumplings, steamed mashed red bean buns, traditional chicken soup along with Taiwanese tea, Huang said.

The event is being organized by the MOFA in cooperation with Din Tai Fung and several other organizations, including the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Government Information Office, the Tourism Bureau, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and the Evergreen Group.

Noted politicians, socialites, media executives, food critics and other celebrities will be invited to attend cookery demonsrations and tastings at Evergreen Group's London headquarters on Dec. 10, and at Evergreen Laurel Hotel in Paris Dec. 12 and Dec. 14, Huang said.

The chefs displayed their culinary skills in advance Monday at the MOFA reception hall, serving tasty dishes and Taiwanese tea so delicious that their efforts were roundly applauded by the guests, including British Trade and Culture Office Director Michael Reilly and French Institute in Taipei Director Jean-Claude Poimboeuf.

Addressing the occasion, Huang said that in the midst of the current hard-fought diplomatic battle, the country can resort to soft tactics, such as "culture diplomacy", adding that the Taipei First Girls High School marching band, which performed in the Edinburgh Military Tattoo this summer, and the Taiwanese symphony black metal band ChthoniC, which performed in many U.S. and European cities earlier this year, are good examples of "soft power diplomacy."

Being rated as one of the top 10 restaurants in the world by the New York Times in 1993 and running successful businesses in America, Japan as well as other places in Southeast Asia, Din Tai Fung has been praised as the pinnacle of Taiwan's culinary world, Huang said, adding that using its image to market Taiwan is a good way of upgrading Taiwan's international profile since fine food knows no borders nor political barriers.
"Din Tia Fung's experienced chefs will devote every effort to promoting Taiwanese delicacies and culture in Europe, " Yan Bing-yi, the group's founder, said at the same occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition commemorates British naturalist's contribution to Taiwan

TEXT.P: An exhibition documenting a 19th Century British naturalist's work in Taiwan was launched Tuesday to pay tribute to his contribution to the ornithology of Taiwan.

The exhibition, which will be held at the National Taiwan Museum (NTM) from Dec. 4 to July 20, commemorates the life and work of Robert Swinhoe (1836-1877) , who documented more than 1,000 species during his 10-year stay in Taiwan from 1856-1866 as Britain's first consular representative to Formosa.

"It's amazing that black-faced spoonbills, which were observed for the first time by Swinhoe in 1863, are still here in Taiwan today, " said Council of Cultural Affairs Vice Chairman Wu Chin-fa in the opening ceremony.
Swinhoe wrote himself into history with his observations and documentation of Taiwan's biological diversity, said museum researcher and exhibition curator Lin Jun-tsun.

Swinhoe was the first naturalist to systematically observe and document birds, mammals, fish and insects in Taiwan and southern China. Swinhoe's blue pheasant, an endangered species endemic to Taiwan, is named after him, Lin noted.
Specimens prepared by Swinhoe have proved to be valuable assets for modern naturalists in Taiwan, he said.
"What Swinhoe did 150 years ago reminds us about what we should do to preserve the environment and co-exist with the nature, " said NTM Director Hsiao Tsun- huang.
Assisted by the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei and the British Council, the exhibition is being organized by the NTM and the National Museum of Natural Science.

DOC.HEADLINE: President dismisses possibility of cross-strait dialogue after March

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Tuesday that even after Taiwan elects a new president next March, it will be "impossible" for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue.
The president made the remarks when he received Richard Bush, a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), at the Presidential Office.

The meeting came one day after Stephen Young, director of the AIT Taipei Office, delivered a speech titled "Opportunities and Challenges in U.S.-Taiwan and Cross-Strait Relations" at a conference organized by the Foundation on the International and Cross-Strait Studies.

Young noted in his speech that Hu Jintao has replaced Jiang Zemin as China's president and that Taiwan will elect a new president next March, making an "opportunity for the two sides to set aside past differences and work to create a new cooperative relationship."

On Young's interpretation that Hu's moderate remarks on Taiwan policy at the recent 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China as an indication Beijing might be looking for ways to open contact with Taiwan's next president, Chen said that "we would rather it is that way, although the reality is otherwise."
This is because Hu said the prerequisite for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to sign a peace agreement will be that "Taiwan must accept the `one-China' principle," Chen said.

He noted that the previous Kuomintang administration passed the National Unification Guidelines in early 1990s in its bid for cross-strait dialogue and even included the guidelines in the party charter.

But he said that even with the National Unification Guidelines, which accepts the "one China" principle and the eventual unification of the two sides, cross- strait dialogue was disrupted from time to time after 1993, when the top negotiators on both sides met for the first time in Singapore after a hiatus of nearly five decades of separation. China even lobbed missiles into waters near Taiwan in 1996 when the island's first popular presidential election was held.

"If the KMT, which accepts the `one China' principle, could not have dialogue with China, how could the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which rejects the principle, embark on dialogue with China?" he asked.
Cross-strait dialogue was completely stalled after former President Lee Teng-hui defined the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as having a "special state-to-state relations" in 1999.
Chen said he has urged China to put aside its differences and embark on peaceful dialogue since he assumed office in 2000, but added that all his goodwill appeal has fallen on deaf ears.

"This is why I say even when a new president is elected in March 2008, it will be impossible for the two sides to resume the dialogue, " he said, unless Hu and the Chinese government are willing to forego its "one-China" principle and its desire for eventual unification as prerequisites for talks.
He responded positively to Young's remarks that "Taiwan's special situation calls for careful, responsible leadership."
He reiterated that the "four noes" pledges he made during his 2000 inaugural speech, and again during his re-election speech in 2004, remain unchanged.

The "four noes" pledges refer to his promise that if China does not use force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change its official name, will not introduce cross-strait "state-to-state" relations into the Constitution and will not hold a referendum on independence or unification.
Taiwan has also strengthened its self-defense capability and the nation's defense budget will be increased to 3 percent of the gross domestic product in 2008, Chen said.

He expressed appreciation for the United States' support for greater Taiwan participation in international organizations, but expressed regret that the United States will not support Taiwan's membership in organizations in its capacity as a state, which he said is "contradictory."

If Taiwan wants greater participation, he said, it should be in the capacity of a nation. Moreover, Taiwan's participation as a state will conform with the content, provision and spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act, he said.

Chen also said that Young said it best when he predicted that "China's democratization may turn out to be the single most important prerequisite for seeking a resolution fo the Taiwan question that is acceptable to both sides."

Chen said China's democratization should include the end of single-party rule, as well as political, religious and assembly freedom, the renunciation of the use of force against Taiwan, as well as peaceful dialogue with Taiwan under the principles of "democracy, sovereignty and equality."

DOC.HEADLINE: Sex workers protest at MOI

TEXT.P: A group of sex workers staged a protest at the Ministry of the Interior Tuesday over the minister's objection to decriminalizing prostitution.

Displaying posters and shouting "prostitutes and patrons are more noble than corrupt politicians, " 20 members of the Collective of Sex Workers and Supporters (COSWAS) gathered in front of the ministry, demanding that Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang deliver on President Chen Shui-bian's promise of no punishment for sex workers.
The protest came after Lee said at a recent meeting called by the Executive Yuan's Human Rights Protection Task Force that both prostitutes and patrons should be prosecuted.

Some human rights activists have been pushing for the decriminalization of prostitution, but Lee was quoted as having said at the meeting that there is not yet broad social support for the decriminalization of prostitution.

Moreover, Lee went on that decriminalizing prostitution will cause more problems, such as disputes over prostitute licensing, human trafficking and social order. Against this backdrop, Lee said he prefers to see the law be revised to have both prostitutes and patrons punished.
Under the current law, only prostitutes are subject to criminal prosecution.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has ordered the Ministry of the Interior to study the feasibility of revising the current law in line with the principle of upholding human rights.

"President Chen Shui-bian promised to amend the law to decriminalize prostitution while running for the presidency in 2004, but nothing has been done so far in this regard, " COSWAS Executive Director Chung Jun-Yun said, adding that the Democratic Progressive Party administration should take immediate steps to deliver on Chen's campaign promise before his presidency expires next May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up for LCD TVs under 46 inches: WitsView

TEXT.P: List prices of all LCD TVs under 46 inches increased worldwide in November according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by WitsView, a market research company.
As for LCD monitors, prices for both 17-inch and 19-inch wide screen models rose, while prices of other models dropped.

Prices of the most popular sizes of LCD TVs fluctuated within a 2.5 percent range in November but those of 26-inch and 40-inch models were more turbulent, with the former falling 3.3 percent to US$646 and the latter climbing 4.2 percent to US$1,507, WitsView's figures show.

Regarding the most common LCD TV models, such as the 32-inch, 37-inch, 42-inch, and 46-inch, these rose 0.7 percent, 0.2 percent, 0.7 percent, and 1.3 percent, respectively, to US$823, US$1,128, US$1,434, and US$2,426.

As for LCD monitors, the cost of a 19-inch wide screen increased for the third consecutive month to US$213 while the cost of most others fell, with the 15-inch model down 0.9 percent, 19-inch down 0.8 percent, 22-inch down 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: New target drug against advanced renal cancer approved in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has recently approved Nexavar tablets, an oral anti-cancer drug containing the active ingredient sorafenib, to be marketed in Taiwan for the treatment of patients with advanced renal cancer, DOH officials said Tuesday.

Nexavar is the second drug approved for the treatment since January, when Sutent capsules were permitted to be imported, the officials added, estimating that Nexavar is expected to help about 500 local patients with advanced renal cancer.

Citing the American Society of Clinical Oncology's clinical trial report on how Nexavar affects patients suffering from end-stage renal cancer whom traditional surgical therapy and immunotheraphy have failed to cure, the officials said the survival period of patients taking Nexavar has been extended from 15.9 months on average to 19.3 months.

National Taiwan University Hospital, Taipei Veterans General Hospital, Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University Hospital have performed clinical trials on Nexavar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think tank adjusts Taiwan's economic growth upward to 5.35 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth this year should be adjusted upward to 5.35 percent from a previous estimate of 4.5 percent, a local think tank said Tuesday.

The Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research (CIER) said in its 2008 global economic outlook seminar that the adjustment was based mainly on an optimistic estimate by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.
The DGBAS forecast in late November that because of brisk exports in the third quarter and stable growth of domestic demand, economic growth will reach 5.46 percent for the whole year.

The DGBAS also predicted that the consumer price index will show an annual increase of 1.7 percent for this year, while economic growth will be 4.53 percent next year and the CPI annual increase for 2008 will be 1.8 percent.
The CIER also said in its forecast that the CPI annual increase will be 1.39 percent and that unemployment will be 3.92 percent for 2007.

Looking ahead to 2008, the institution said there are six uncertain factors, including the ramifications of the subprime crisis in the United States, the fluctuation of the world crude oil and raw material prices, the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar, China's economic situation, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and political changes due to the legislative and presidential elections scheduled for early next year.
The CIER forecast that economic growth for next year will be 4.16 percent, lower than the DGBAS forecast of 4.53 percent and that of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research at 4.39 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan reiterates no change in 'one-step' voting format

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is determined to adopt the "one-step" voting format for the Legislative poll and two accompanying referendums Jan. 12, 2008, and there will be no other alternative, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Tuesday.

Shieh made the remarks in response to reporters' questions after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) voiced strong support for 18 cities and counties controlled by the KMT which are seeking to adopt a "two-step" voting format.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, issued earlier the same day a seven-point statement declaring the party's staunch backing for local authorities adopting the "two-step" voting scheme in a defiance of a Nov. 16 decision by the Central Election Commission (CEC) to apply the "one-step" format.

Turning to a report that Taitung County has agreed to use the "one-step" scheme, Tseng called the report a "twisted fabrication" by local media and reiterated that the 18 local governments will stick to the "two-step" voting format, under which voters will be given and cast their ballots for the legislative poll and referendums in two stages.

CEC branches are responsible for the disposal and management of local polling stations and the central unit is not entitled to meddle in their operations nor to replace their chief officials, Tseng said, adding that the CEC, which has yet to be instituted, is the source of all this chaos.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung met with CEC local unit chiefs Monday evening, with the two sides reaching an agreement that voters will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and two ballots for the referendums at two desks before casting them into four separate boxes -- a departure from the CEC's original decision that voters would take all four ballots from a single desk.

Commenting on the KMT's stance, Shieh made it clear that the CEC-designed "one- step" format will be definitely used for the polls and said that the KMT must be held fully accountable for all possible consequences if it insists on applying the "two-step" format.

In response to the Legislative Yuan Procedural Committee's inclusion of the KMT- drafted CEC organic bill as the first issue of discussion for Friday's legislative session, Ker Chien-ming, legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that it will fully mobilize party lawmakers to kill the bill's passage at "whatever the cost."
The KMT-proposed bill, Ker said, would allow for the establishment of an unconstitutional CEC -- something which the DPP is firmly opposed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan declines to comment on tycoon's ad

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey declined to comment Tuesday on an ad concerning the legislation of a "cross-Taiwan Strait peace law" run by a prominent high-technology tycoon in local newspapers other than blasting it as part of Beijing's united front tactics.

Shieh made the remarks to the CNA after United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) Honorary Chairman Robert Tsao ran a new advertisement earlier that same day in major newspapers appealing for the legislation -- his third since Nov. 20.

According to Shieh, Tsao's advertisement was launched in line with Beijing's united front tactics comprising a legal, psychological and media war. The Executive Yuan has no responsibility to respond to Tsao's move, he said.

In addition to reiterating his claim that Taiwan "needs" to enact such a law to ensure cross-strait peace, Tsao also accused Taiwan's popularly elected presidents of using Taiwan independence as a fake issue to deceive voters.

He urged Beijing to respect the Republic of China and called on it to stop its relentless efforts to squeeze the country in the international community, warning that continuing to do so might eventually lead to a "Republic of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGTemps may get full work rights under EU law
Britain looks likely to lose its fight against the EUs proposed new rights for temporary workers. Employers argue that the change, which would give Britainsestimated 1.3 million agency workers the same pay and workplace conditions as permanent staff, puts 250,000 jobs at risk.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Germans win Taiwan's Tsungming Tu Award

TEXT.P: Two German academics have won the 2007 Tsungming Tu Award instituted by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) to honor outstanding foreign scientists, an NSC official said Tuesday.

NSC Chairman Chen Chien-jen presented the awards to the two Germans -- Peter Jonas, a physiology professor at the Albert-Ludwigs-University of Freiburg and Klaus H. Ploog, a former director of the Graduate Institute of Solid State Electronics of the Max Planck Society -- in a ceremony held in Taipei earlier in the day.
Each recipient was awarded US$75,000 in cash plus a trophy and a citation.
Addressing the ceremony, Chen said the award is the highest academic honor bestowed upon foreign scholars by the Taiwan government.

The Tsungming Tu Award was set up last year by the NSC, which then signed the "Tsungming Tu -- Humboldt Research Award Agreement" with Germany's Alexander von Humboldt (AvH) Foundation to commend outstanding academics and experts from both countries.

After the two winners of the first Tsungming Tu Award were commended, Lee Der- tsai, director of the Institute of Information Science of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious academic institution, was selected as the winner of the Humboldt Research Award and will go to the German city of Bonn next April for the presentation.
Besides working with the AvH, the NSC is also planning to approach academic institutes in Canada, the U.K. and Japan for possible future cooperation in a similar vein.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lanyu's butterflies selected as Taiwan's most beautiful

TEXT.P: The birdwing butterfly native to the Orchid Island, also known as Lanyu, located off Taitung County in eastern Taiwan, has been selected as the country's most beautiful in a recent online poll, an organizer said Tuesday.
The result of the online poll organized by the Shining Culture and Education Foundation is slated to be formally announced Dec. 6.
The month-long poll was aimed at choosing Taiwan's top 10 beautiful butterflies from 23 cities and counties around the island.

Currently, the number of birdwing butterflies -- dubbed "flying pearls" -- is fewer than 2,000 worldwide, with more than 1,500 of them being spotted on the Orchid Island, Taitung County Councilor Chiang Duo-li said.

The butterfly's numbers dropped to below 1,000 a decade ago due habitat loss and reductions of their food supply, Chiang said, adding that massive numbers of the butterflies were also captured for sale by locals in the past.
During the 1960s and 1970s, approximately 5,000 to 10,000 birdwing butterflies were caught and sold annually to butterfly collectors in Taiwan and abroad, Chiang pointed out.

Beginning in 2000, the Council of Agriculture (COA) began collaborating with a local association dedicated to the preservation of the ecosystem on Lanyu to protect the endangered butterflies, said Chiang, who is also the director of the association.
According to Chiang, birdwing butterflies also have been discovered on the Batan Islands of the Philippines, but in very low numbers.
Orchid Island is about 110 km north of the Batan Islands of the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's computer course sponsored by Microsoft concludes

TEXT.P: A course of computer lessons titled "Women Up" financed by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and Microsoft Taiwan to improve the computer skills of women in rural areas in Taiwan has concluded, a CEPD official said Tuesday.

The course, organized by the Electronic Commerce Business Association, was part of a program launched earlier this year by the CEPD with the aim of narrowing the digital disparity between women in urban and rural areas, the official said.
Under the program, the CEPD subsidized 11 non-profit organizations to provide 24 hours of basic computer lessons to the course attendees. The program began in more than 100 townships in June.
Microsoft Taiwan also provided funding for the course as part of a global project started in 2005 to help narrow the digital gap for the underprivileged, the official noted.

A closing ceremony was held in Chiayi County's Tungshih township in southern Taiwan Monday that was attended by 300 of the students and 150 representatives from the program's cooperating organizations around the nation.

Wu Tsai-ai, a 50-year-old student invited to give a speech at the ceremony, said she can now book train tickets and make appointments with doctors online, while Feng Yen-ting, a student suffering from cerebral palsy, said the course allowed her to step out from her limited world to learn computer skills "with familiar people in a familiar place."
CEPD Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh and Senior Director of Community Affairs of Microsoft Corp. Akhtar Badshah also attended the ceremony to exchange views with the students on their studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman to visit Taiwan to meet with presidential hopefuls

TEXT.P: Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , will visit Taipei in the near future to meet with presidential candidates of Taiwan's two major political parties, diplomatic officials said Tuesday.

Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, will meet with Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the March 22, 2008 presidential election, and his electoral rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, during his stay, the officials said.

According to the officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Burghardt expects to get first-hand information about the two hopefuls' policy visions and initiatives. Burghardt, who served as head of the AIT's Taipei Office from 1999-2001, will also exchange views with Hsieh and Ma on the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

The weighted price index was down 24.76 points at 8,626.52 on a turnover of NT$2.12 billion (US$65.62 million) at the open. The index gained 67.44 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at 8,651.28 Tuesday.
