DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 5, or the 26th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary- general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: TPV Technology world's top OEM maker of TFT-LCD flat panels: report

TEXT.P: TPV Technology Ltd., a Taiwan-Indonesian joint venture which operates five manufacturing plants around China, is currently the world's top OEM maker of LCD TV panels, the DisplaySearch reported Wednesday.

According to DisplaySearch -- the world's leader in display market research and consulting -- a total of 20.1 million units of LCD TV panels were produced globally in the third quarter of this year, with 23 percent of the total coming from OEM companies.

In LCD TV Value Chain Report, DisplaySearch said that TPV contributed 19.9 percent of the world's LCD flat panel output in the third quarter of this year, followed by Proview (17 percent), Jabail (14.9 percent), AmTRAN (14.3 percent), Wistron (9.4 percent), Vestel (4.8 percent), Tatung (3.1 percent), Kolin (2.3 percent), Jean (1.7 percent) and Quanta (1 percent).
According to the report, TPV's major client was Netherlands-based Philips, while Proview's top buyer was Polaroid and Jabail's major client was also Philips during Q3.
TPV currently operates five manufacturing plants in Beijing, Wuhan, Suzhou, Dongguan, and Fuching in Fujian Province.

Taiwan's AU Optronics (AUO) -- which became the world's top flat panel supplier in September, delivering 8.18 million large-size flat panels worldwide in that month -- sold 61 percent of its entire products to five major clients, including Sony, Samsung, Philips and LG Electronics, according to DisplaySearch.

Chi Mei Optoelectronics, another major Taiwan flat panel maker and the world's third-largest supplier, delivered about 50 percent of its products to five major clients, namely Samsung, Philips, Funai, LG Electronics and Sony, in Q3.
For the first three quarters of this year, according to DisplaySearch, AUO delivered 57.6 million units of flat panel displays.

Worldwide, output of large-size TFT-LCD panels reached 280 million units in the first three quarters of this year. Of the total, 81 million were for notebook computer screens, 135 million were for desktop computer screens and 58 million were for LCD TV screens, according to DisplaySearch.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students tops in world in mathematics literacy

TEXT.P: Taiwan students have been ranked as the top performers in mathematics among students from a total of 57 countries and regions surveyed worldwide, according to the results of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development's (OECD's) Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) 2006 released Tuesday.

The program, administered by the OECD since 2000, is a triennial worldwide test of 15-year-olds aimed at assessing how far students near the end of compulsory education have come in acquiring the knowledge and skills essential for full participation in society. The assessments cover the students' capabilities in reading literacy, mathematics literacy and science literacy.
This marks the first time that Taiwan has taken part in the assessment, with a total of 8,815 students in the age group from 240 schools around Taiwan being tested.

The results show that Taiwan students topped their peers from other surveyed countries in terms of their performance in mathematics. Students from Finland came in second, followed by those from Hong Kong and South Korea in third place.

In terms of science literacy, Taiwan students ranked fourth, behind only those from Finland, Hong Kong and Canada and ahead of students from Japan and South Korea, which placed fifth and 10th, respectively, according to the results.
Taiwan students' lowest ranking was in the category of reading literacy, in which they placed 16th, behind those from other major Asian economies, including South Korea, Hong Kong and Japan.

Noting that science literacy is the focus of the PISA 2006, Lin Huann-shyang, president of National Hualien University of Education, who acted as Taiwan's project manager, said Taiwan students have demonstrated a strong ability in explaining scientific phenomena
but have performed relative weak in identifying science issues and using science evidence.

However, the overall performance of Taiwan students in the PISA 2006 illustrates the excellent achievements of Taiwan's nine-year integrated compulsory education in terms of mathematics and science, Lin said.

Lin Fou-lai, a professor in mathematics at National Taiwan Normal University, said Taiwan students have much room for improvement in terms of their reading literacy, pointing out that only 4.7 percent of surveyed Taiwan students reached the highest level of proficiency in reading, compared with 21.7 percent of surveyed South Korean students.

The survey was carried out in 43 countries in the first assessment in 2000 which focused on reading literacy, in 41 countries in the second assessment in 2003 which focused on mathematics literacy, and in 57 countries in the third assessment in 2006 which focused on science literacy.
Sixty-two countries have signed up to participate in the fourth assessment in 2009 which will again focus on reading literacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Iran halted nuclear push in 2003 U.S. now says.
U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 and that international pressure has compelled the Islamic Republic to back away from its pursuit of the bomb. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Iran halted its nuclear weapons in 2003 in response to international pressure, and while it contiunes to develop an enriched uranium program, it apparently has not resumed moving toward a nuclear capability, according to a consensus judgment of the U.S. intelligence community released Monday by Director of National Intelligence John McConnell.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 91 points to close at 8,709 with 58,853 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index Futures for January rose 90 points to finish at 8,705, with 220 contracts traded, while March futures increased 73 points to close at 8,706, with 14 contract transactions. June futures moved up 78 points to finish at 8,700, with eight contract transactions, while September futures gained 82 points to close at 8,512, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,618 for December, 8,615 for January, 8,633 for March, 8,622 for June and 8,430 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures rose 6.7 points to close at 364.6, with 3,480 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 5.9 points to finish at 363.3, with 96 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 6.2 points to close at 362.1, with two contract transactions, while June TE futures increased 4.9 points to close at 359, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September.

December TF futures remained unchanged to close at 965.4, with 3,009 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 3.4 points to finish at 963, with 36 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged not to end search for missing fishing boat and crew

TEXT.P: Family members of the skipper of a Suao-based fishing boat missing since Nov. 10 urged the government Wednesday not to cease searching for the crew of the boat.

Accompanied by ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Chin-teh at a news conference, the wife of Chih Yu-hsin, the skipper of the "Chin Hsieh Yi No. 166, " called for governmental agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , to continue their efforts to locate Chih and the other eight crew members.

Chih's uncle, a veteran sailor, said the likelihood that the "Chin Hsieh Yi No. 166" sank or collided with another vessel is extremely low as the boat is equipped with advanced radar, navigation and communications systems.

Chih's wife and uncle said they do not exclude the possibility that Chih was abducted and even murdered by his crew -- made up of six Chinese and two Indonesian citizens -- and that the crew sailed the vessel to China or Indonesia.

Also present at the news conference, Lin Chin-you, an inspector with the CGA Department of Coastal Control, said the "Chin Hsieh Yi No. 166" departed the Suao Port Nov. 8 and made its last radio contact with other Taiwan fishing boats Nov. 10.
Lin said that the CGA began its search on Nov. 12 immediately after being informed that the boat was missing.

He added that although fishing gear belonging to the "Chin Hsieh Yi No. 166" had been spotted some 26 nautical miles south of Tiaoyutai Island and that Japan then dispatched aircraft and patrol boats to help search in adjacent areas for three days, nothing else related to the boat was discovered.
The CGA will continue its search for the "Chin Hsieh Yi No. 166" and its crew, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outlying islands to be allowed to operate duty-free shops

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed an amendment to the Outlying Islands Development Act Wednesday, allowing the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu to operate duty-free shops so that visitors to these areas will not have to pay any tariffs for purchases made there.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said at a news conference held at the Executive Yuan that the amendment is aimed at helping rekindle tourism on Kinmen and Matsu located nearer to China than to Taiwan proper, and Penghu, located in the Taiwan Strait.

Chang said the Outlying Islands Development Act was promulgated in 2000 and that since 2001, the administration has channeled NT$3 billion (US$92.88 million) each year into a foundation to fund infrastructural and sustainable development projects on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.
According to Kuei Hsien-nung, director of the Department of Customs Administration under the Ministry of Finance, the amendment will now be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

Duty-free shop operations on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu are expected to kick off after the Ministry of Finance formally announces their implementation within three months of the Legislative Yuan passing the amendment, Kuei said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.002 to close at NT$32.303.
A total of US$834 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.305 and fluctuated between NT$32.303 and NT$32.345.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's southwest, northeast coasts tsunami-prone: study

TEXT.P: The southwest and northeast coasts of Taiwan are the most vulnerable to tsunami attacks in the event of a strong underwater earthquake occurring in the South China Sea, according to the results of a Taiwan study released Wednesday.
Regions that are considered at high risk include the shoreline between Hengchun and Tainan in southern Taiwan as well as Lotung and Suao in northeastern Yilan County, the study shows.
The study was administered by Wu Tso-ren, an assistant professor at National Central University's Institute of Hydrological Sciences.
Wu reported the results of his study during the South China Sea Tsunami Workshop 2007 held by the Academia Sinica's Institute of Earth Sciences.

Tsunamis are usually caused by undersea earthquakes measuring at least 7.2 in magnitude that have a focal depth no deeper than 30 km. Moderately elevated ground undersea helps the formation of tsunamis.

If the South China Sea experiences an undersea earthquake with a magnitude similar to that of the Dec. 26, 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake centered near the Indonesian island of Sumatra, a tsunami 8-10 meters high is likely to hit Hengchun approximately one hour after the quake, and Lotung and Suao are likely to see a tsunami 6-8 meters high, Wu said.

Referring to a report by the United States Geological Survey assessing the potential risk as a tsunami source along the entire Pacific subduction zones, Wu noted that the Luzon trench has been identified as a high risk zone, while the Ryukyu trench and the North Sulawesi trench have been identified as two medium risk zones.

The report says these subduction zones can rupture and generate large tsunamis that will have significant impacts on the countries in the South China region, including China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines and Taiwan.

In the tsunami triggered by the 2004 earthquake, nearly 300,000 people were killed and more than 1 million others were left homeless in 10 countries surrounding the Indian Ocean, with the total damage estimated at over US$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deities to help promote Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Traditional deities are to be used to help promote Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations, organizers of the activity said Wednesday.

They made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian revealed an "all deities safeguard Taiwan" campaign for the country's U.N. bid during a visit to Tsaotien Temple in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Religious groups will use the opportunity of an annual inspection tour of deities, such as an islandwide tour of a Matsu statue, to promote the U.N. bid, the organizers said. Matsu is the Chinese goddess of the sea.
Similar religious rites will also be performed in New York next year to highlight the nation's U.N. bid, they said.
They noted that the campaign was inspired by a similar deity procession in front of U.N. headquarters in New York prior to the opening of the U.N. Assembly this September.
The deity procession, which is a common sight in Taiwan, drew a lot of publicity for Taiwan.

Religious sources said that during the deity inspection tour around Taiwan and the procession in New York next year, there will be other promotional items available, such as "lucky amulets," to attract attention.
Activity organizers said they will call a news conference in mid-December to publish the details of its activities.
Sources from the Presidential Office said the use of creative innovation to combine tradition with the "new" issue of the U.N. bid is "sure to attract more media attention."
Taiwan has tried without success to re-enter the United Nations since 1993. This year marked the first time the nation had sought entry to the world organization in the name of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teachers to be barred from striking

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed an amendment to the Teachers Act Wednesday prohibiting teachers and teachers' unions from staging boycotts, teaching strikes or from behaving in such a way that would impede normal teaching operations.
Violators of the regulation will be subject to fines ranging from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000 (US$1,858-9,288), according to the amendment.

The amendment also stipulates that government agencies in charge of educational affairs or academic institutions of all levels should not stop hiring teachers, cut their salaries or treat them unfairly if they join teachers unions or take part in related activities.
Offenders of this regulation will be subject to fines ranging from NT$200,000 to NT$1 million, according to the amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate urges people to vote against `authoritarian' power

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou urged the public Wednesday to use their votes to unseat an "authoritarian government" that has arbitrarily planned to tear down what he described as a "historic plaque."

Ma made the call in a statement on a squabble between the KMT-ruled Taipei city government and the central government run by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on a Ministry of Education (MOE) -initiated plan to replace the "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" plaque on the gateway of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, which alludes to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, with another reading "Tzu You Kuang Chang, "which translates as "Liberty Square." The memorial hall was formerly named the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
Ma made the statement after a visit to the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou, Taipei County.

He promised that if elected, he will act based on "public consensus" and through a legal procedure to "restore" the inscription if the DPP government really ignors the city government's opposition and replaces the plaque.

Ma claimed that the government acted to "get around, violate and destroy" the laws with administrative power, referring to an ongoing move to revise the administrative regulations concerning the designation and abolition of a historic relic in its preparation to tear down the plaque.

By designating the memorial park as a historic site with national status, the park's current status as a city-designated historic relic will become null. The change will give the MOE the chance to apply to the Council for Cultural Affairs for permission to renovate the park.

According to Ma, the higher-level laws that the central government attempted to get around in order to carry out its scheme to expunge the last vestiges of Chiang's authoritarian rule include the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law, the Provisions Governing the Organization of the CKS Memorial Hall Administration Office, and the Organization Act of the Central Government.

The DPP has acted to "destroy" a historic relic through designating its status as a historic relic, Ma claimed, adding that the conduct has not only "violated the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law's spirit but also signals the specter of emerging authoritarianism."
The plaque issue was brought up for the purpose of raising conflict, fomenting hatred and seeking election benefits, Ma claimed, calling on the public to be "rational" and stay calm.

The memorial hall was build in 1980 to commemorate Chiang, who the DPP brands as a dictator and accuses of being the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing White Terror of the KMT-imposed martial law.

The DPP government renamed the memorial hall as National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park July 15 after it changed the designation of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Sept. 6, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum to let people refuse unification: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has said Wednesday that a planned referendum on the government's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan will allow the public to express their opposition to unification with China.
Chen made the remarks when he received American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) former Chairman Richard Bush at the Presidential Office Tuesday.
The remarks were in response to a speech delivered a day earlier by Stephen Young, director of the AIT Taipei Office, who said the government's U.N. bid is "unnecessary and unhelpful."

Chen noted that China brought up a new interpretation of its "one China" policy. The new policy sees Taiwan as part of the People's Republic of China, while under the previous interpretation, Taiwan was taken as part of a "cultural China" that does not necessarily equate with the PRC.
Chen said Taiwan's future has to be decided by its people. Asking Taiwan people to accept eventual unification would violate the principle that the nation's power rests with the public, he said.

Joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan does not violate his "four noes" pledges, Chen went on. In addition, it does not involve changing the status quo between two sides of Taiwan Strait or the nation's official name, Chen added, noting that about 80 of the United Nations' 192 member countries joined the world body under unofficial names.
He said the government proposed the bid to join the United Nations to meet the Taiwan people's expectations.

He added that the results of a survey show that 55 percent of Americans support Taiwan's participation in the United Nations and said the percentage will increase to 70 percent if the referendum is successful.
Japanese support will increase from the present 74 percent to 81 percent under the same situation, Chen said, citing other survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers sue KMT candidate for slander

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers filed a charge Wednesday against Ma Ying-jeou, the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate, on charges of slander over a 228 Incident bill that they tried to enact at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang Sing-nan and Kao Chien-chih, among others, submitted the charge to the Taipei Prosecutors Office accusing Ma of "malicious defamation" over the bill, which is aimed at bringing to justice those responsible for the 228 Incident of 1947 and for government crimes during the martial rule imposed by the KMT from 1949-1987.

Wang, who proposed the draft law endorsed by 34 DPP lawmakers, blasted what he described as Ma's "twisted rhetoric" that the bill will involve innocent people because its fourth article stipulates that even if the perpetrators have died, their spouses, sons and even third cousins will also have to stand trial in their places.
Wang accused Ma of seriously distorting the article's "good faith" which he claimed would offer the criminals' offspring "the chance to defend their fathers, grandfathers or relatives."
Ma's claims that the bill is full of hatred and would implicate innocent persons is entirely deviated from the facts, according to Wang.
Ma said a day earlier that the DPP has stepped across the red line for rehashing the 228 Incident because the bill also has hurt the victims' families by failing to take into account their feelings.
Such a draft law is merely a scheme designed by the DPP to cement the "pan-green camp" voter base in the coming legislative and presidential polls, Ma claimed.
Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, turned down an invitation by Wang Tuesday to debate the 228 Incident.
"There is no need to respond to Wang as it would only fuel social confrontation between the two camps," Tseng pointed out.

Thousands of Taiwanese people were massacred by KMT troops in the 228 Incident of 1947 during the party's initial rule of Taiwan shortly after the regime led by late President Chiang Kai-shek relocated from China to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP politicians seek right to hold rallies around memorial park

TEXT.P: Several Taipei city councilors of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have applied to the City Police Department for the right to hold rallies on the sidewalk surrounding the Taiwan Democratic Memorial Park, previously called the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, from Wednesday to Dec. 15, a city police official said Wednesday.
Huang Ching-fu, head of the department's social order maintenance office, confirmed that the application had been approved.
Huang also noted that police will be deployed at the site of the planned public activities to prevent conflicts between political foes.

The DPP city councilors' move to rent the sidewalk space along the memorial park came amid a face-off between the city government and the Ministry of Education (MOE) on the latter's plan to tear down the plaque on the park's gateway, which reads "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" alluding to the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
In protest, various city councilors of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) held a press conference at the party caucus office at the City Council to denounce the MOE plan.

The KMT politicians denounced the DPP's moves to "erase" the name of Chiang Kai- shek and to apply to hold public rallies as an attempt to "raise conflicts" between people with opposing political ideas.

Such conflicts will be used as an excuse for President Chen Shui-bian to impose martial law during the upcoming legislative and presidential elections next year, they claimed, urging KMT supporters to be calm and to avoid conflict with DPP followers.
They also urged city police to stay alert when the DPP organizes rallies at the memorial park or tries to "fake riots" to give Chen a chance to impose a curfew.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to impose restrictions on gravel trucks

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government will enforce a new measure from Jan. 1 banning gravel trucks from other cities and countries from transiting through county roads, while allowing locally based dump trucks to use the roads only during off-peak hours.

The new measure was mapped out after tourism industry workers in Yingge township complained that the large volume of gravel truck traffic through the town every day not only endangers the safety of visitors and local residents but also plagues them with noise and air pollution.

Yingge, one of the townships in Taipei County that relies heavily on tourism for its prosperity, is well-known in Taiwan for its ceramics technology and production. The Yingge Ceramics Museum has an ambitious plan to put Yingge on the world map as a town that produces high-grade ceramics.
Taipei magistrate Chow Hsi-wei visited the town last Sunday to measure the traffic volume of gravel trucks passing through.

At a Dec. 5 meeting with county government officials, police chiefs and leaders of tourism-related industries, Chou adopted the suggestion by Lin Chung-chang, head of the Transportation Bureau of the county government, that sand and gravel trucks from other cities and counties should transit Taipei County only on national roads and that locally based dump trucks should be restricted from using county roads during rush hours and holidays.
The new measure is expected to be sanctioned by the county government's road safety supervisory group before being promulgated by Jan. 1 for implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: November CPI up 4.8% year-on-year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) for November rose 4.8 percent from the same month of last year, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Compared with October, the November CPI dropped 0.59 percent, while for the first 11 months of this year, the CPI increased 1.66 percent over the same period of last year, the officials said.

All seven categories of consumer prices went up in November compared with the same month of last year, with food prices soaring 12.81 percent, medical costs climbing 4.98 percent, transportation and communication costs jumping 4.18 percent, and housing costs rising 0.85 percent, they said.
Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) for November surged 8.23 percent year-on-year, owing to hikes in the prices of energy minerals, oil- and coal- based products and base metals, they said.
Prices of imports increased 13.19 percent year-on-year if calculated in new Taiwan dollars, and 14.91 percent year-on-year if calculated in U.S. dollars, the officials.
Prices of exports rose 2.32 percent year-on-year if calculated in new Taiwan dollars, and 3.86 percent if calculated in U.S. dollars, they said.
Prices of locally produced products intended for domestic consumption jumped 8.16 percent year-on-year, they said.
For the first 11 months of this year, the WPI moved up 6.27 percent year-on- year, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Swaziland build airport, biopark

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian promised a visiting delegation from Swaziland Tuesday that Taiwan will help build an international airport and a biotechnology park in the southern African country to boost bilateral relations.
Chen also encouraged Taiwanese businessmen to invest and set up more factories in Swaziland.
Of the 26 Taiwan-funded companies in Swaziland, Chen said, 17 are garment factories, adding that all those investment projects worth US$84.5 million have provided 19,000 jobs in Swaziland.
Trade between Taiwan and Swaziland increased 21 percent in 2006 over the previous year, Chen said, expressing hope that "both sides will continue to strengthen bilateral trade and cooperation."
Chen further noted that the infection rate of HIV in Swaziland tops 39 percent, one of the highest levels in the world, and he promised to share Taiwan's experience in HIV prevention with Swaziland.

The Swazi delegation was accompanied by Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen and included Swaziland Minister of Economic Planning and Development Absalom Dlamini and deputy ministers of the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare and the Ministry of Enterprise and Employment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 25.67 points to close at 8,676.95.
The bourse opened at 8,626.52 and fluctuated between 8,705.87 and 8,601.13 during trading. A total of 4.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.35 billion (US$3.63 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks and constructcion issues both at 0.6 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent.
Only machinery and electronics shares gained ground, increasing 1.1 percent.
There are more than 1,000 gainers and as many losers with 431 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport ground crew suspected of colluding with smugglers

TEXT.P: Ground crew at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport are suspected of colluding with smugglers in trafficking deer velvet, which carries a tariff of up to 500 percent, an aviation police official said Wednesday.
Customs officials discovered eight suspect cases of fresh deer velvet weighing 185 kg in a van leaving an import warehouse at the airport Nov. 3, the official said.
The velvet did not go through the customs declaration process and lacked the necessary documents to approve its being taken from the warehouse, the official said.
The shipment was from Macau and supposedly did not undergo inspection and quarantine, the official noted.
Aviation police have expanded the investigation to see if smuggling rings are also involved, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nankang exhibition hall ready for inauguration

TEXT.P: The Nankang exhibition hall in suburban Taipei is ready for formal inauguration at any time, the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior said Wednesday.
CPA officials said construction of the exhibition hall was completed at the end of August, and all safety inspections were conducted and passed last month.
The hall's inaugural show -- the Taipei Int'l Cycle Show 2008 -- will be held in March 2008 as scheduled, the officials said.
Following the inaugural show, there will be exhibitions on automobiles, computers, and foods.
The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TETRA) , a semi-official agency promoting Taiwan's external trade, has obtained the right to operate the exhibition hall for the next 10 years.

In view of the fact that Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong have all constructed large exhibition halls, the Ministry of Economic Affairs began to plan for the Nankang exhibition hall in 2003 and completed its construction this August after a number of twists and turns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to spend additional NT$1.46 b. on disadvantaged students

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the government is expected to spend an additional NT$1.46 billion (US$45.2 million) over the next three years to help disadvantaged high school students.

Chang made the remarks after the Cabinet passed a project proposed by the Ministry of Education (MOE) designed to help disadvantaged students economically, culturally and in terms of learning ability.
The premier noted that the MOE has adopted a series of measures aimed at helping these students get equal learning opportunities over
the years and said the project is part of that effort.
The project includes programs on practical skills and courses catering to the needs of certain sectors, as well as supplementary schools.
Under the program, disadvantaged students in senior high schools or vocational schools who are in the "practical skill" program will be exempted from paying tuition fees.
Chang noted that the course will mainly target those students who are not keen on regular learning so that they can obtain practical skills.
The MOE plans to have the tuition fee exemption program cover first, second and third year high school students annually and to have eventually benefited 54,000 students by 2010.
Also, the students who take the courses designed to cater to specific sectors, such as joinery, agriculture and precision machinery, will also be exempted from paying tuition fees.
It is estimated that around 5,100 students will have benefited from the program by 2010, the premier said, helping solve the problem of insufficient workers in some sectors at the same time.
The supplementary school courses will mainly target those who have to work in the daytime, dropouts and other disadvantaged students.

Those students who come from families with an annual household income of less than NT$300,000 will be exempted from paying tuition. It is estimated that 17,000 students will have benefited from the program by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambian president vows firm backing for Taiwan

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya Jammeh vowed Wednesday that he will forever stand by the people of Taiwan and referred to President Chen Shui-bian as "president of the Taiwan republic."

Jammeh, who arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a five-day state visit, made the remarks during a meeting with Chen at the Presidential Office. Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang was also present.
A military salute was held in honor of the Gambian president in the square in front of the Presidential Office earlier that same day. This is Jammeh's seventh visit to Taiwan.

Promising that he will continue speaking up for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations until the world body forswears its Resolution 2758 and allows Taiwan to participate in the international organization, Jammeh said he will "lend his staunch support to Taiwan until the goal is realized."
Resolution 2758 recognizes Beijing as the sole legitimate representative of China and gives the China seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei.
According to Jammeh, excluding Taiwan from the United Nations not only amounts to a violation of its basic principles but also deprives other countries of the opportunity to receive aid from Taiwan.
Jammeh said he is deeply disappointed with Taiwan's absence from the United Nations and that he appreciates the economic assistance the Taiwan government and businessmen have extended to his nation.
For his part, Chen described the Gambia as Taiwan's "close ally" and thanked the West African country for its continued and all-out backing for Taiwan in the international community.
Chen hosted a state banquet for Jammeh in the evening at the Taipei 101 Tower. He will accompany Jammeh Thursday on a tour of Taichung City in central Taiwan aboard the high-speed railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pursues diplomatic goals in eco-friendly way

TEXT.P: The days of strictly political diplomacy and confrontational competition with China in the international arena are long gone, but Taiwan is capable of pursuing its diplomatic initiatives in other ways, such as ecology consultation, a lawmaker versed in the field said Wednesday.

"No one will say no to ecological and environmental protection these days, " said Legislator Tien Chiu-chin, who led an 11-member mission to Saint Lucia, Taiwan's diplomatic ally in the Caribbean, Nov. 25 - Dec. 2 to help develop its Eco Tourism and birding infrastructure.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs-backed mission, comprised of senior birders and ecological photographers, was aimed at helping the Caribbean country establish its Eco Tourism routes and birding Web sites, as well as documenting bird species for the future publication of a birding guide, an essential tool for birders, Tien said.

During the mission's stay, 46 bird species were documented, including St. Lucia's national bird, the Saint Lucia parrot, and 25 were photographed. Two photographers attached to the mission have extended their stays for another month.

"This is a brand new attempt for us to embrace the global trend of environment diplomacy and preservation of bio-diversity and develop our international diplomacy at the same time. There's no better place for such a mission than St. Lucia, which re-established official diplomatic ties with Taiwan Apr. 30, " said MOFA Minister James Huang.

It is the first time the MOFA has worked with a non-government organization (NGO) on an "eco-diplomacy program, " Huang noted. He also thanked Taiwan Sustainable Ecology Society (TSES) and Taiwan International Birding Association (TIBA) for their collaboration.

What Taiwan wanted to do for its allies is drastically different from China's intentions, which will most likely entail throwing a large amount of cash for "monumental projects" at its less-developed allies, Huang said.

"China helped build a large sports stadium in southern St. Lucia although most St. Lucians live in the north, and built a large psychiatric hospital for St. Lucia which has no need of such a facility, " he said.

"We [Taiwan] don't want to do that. Among other things, we are trying to build community centers and help the country to improve its water quality, agriculture and digital education. The idea is to make people's lives better, " Huang stressed.

The St. Lucia mission was a good start, and Taiwan will continue developing its international relations through the application of its expertise in forms of "soft power, " such as Eco-tourism, information technology and cultural innovations, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Citizens urged to get free flu shots early

TEXT.P: People who intend to receive free flu shots should move fast, as supplies are expected to run out in less than three weeks, a Center for Disease Control (CDC) official said Wednesday.

CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said more than 57,000 people had been vaccinated in the first three days since the free vaccinations became available to all citizens Dec. 1, proving the popularity of the government-funded inoculation program.

Of the free shots administered to date, 54,900-plus doses were given to adults and 2,100 to children, Shih said, adding that the majority of the recipients were aged between 50 and 64. Most were residents of Changhua, Taichung, Taipei and Taoyuan counties.
According to laboratory influenza virus surveillance, influenza A is the most common strain in Taiwan, Shih said, adding that this year's vaccine is very effective in combating this type of flu.

Noting that flu epidemics tend to peak between a week before Christmas and the Lunar New Year holiday, Shih said citizens intending to receive free inoculation should hurry up as there are only 490,000 doses left for adults and 150,000 doses for children.

The free flu inoculation program was first launched Nov. 1 for high-risk groups, including children aged between 6 months and 2 years, citizens aged over 65, medical and health care professionals and poultry traders. With doses remaining available, the program became available to all citizens Dec. 1.

On reports that an occupational therapist in central Taiwan was suspected of having developed atypical Parkinsonism after receiving a free flu shot, Shih pointed out that several experts have confirmed it is not atypical Parkinsonism and have ruled out the possibility that her symptoms were induced by the vaccine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Filling station owner selling substandard fuel released on bail

TEXT.P: The owner of a gasoline station in Taipei was released on bail Wednesday after confessing to public prosecutors that he had mixed methanol into gasoline to boost his profits.

Wang Chen-hai, who owns the Heng Chia Gas Station on Wanfang Road, admitted that in less than one month he had netted an extra profit of some NT$500,000 (US$15,425) by selling substandard gasoline mixed with methanol.
Public prosecutors detained him following interrogation, but he was later released after the Taipei District Court granted him bail at NT$200,000.

The scandal blew open more than two weeks ago when a major newspaper reported that car owners patronizing Wang's filling station had begun complaining that their car engines were damaged by substandard fuel.

State-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan, which supplied gasoline to the station, analyzed gas samples from the station and found that its gasoline contained at least 10 percent methanol. CPC canceled its contract with Heng Chia on Oct. 23.

Wang and his daughter at first denied having mixed methanol into gasoline, and accused CPC of proving sub-standard gasoline, but their former employees testified that they had seen Wang pumping methanol into the storage tanks late at night.
The Taipei Public Prosecutors' Office is expected to charge Wang with fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st televised presidential debate to be held after legislative polls

TEXT.P: The first televised debate between ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Ma Ying-jeou, is slated to take place after the Jan. 12 legislative elections, organizers of the debate has said.

The six organizers of the televised debate -- the Public Television Service (PTS) channel, the Central News Agency (CNA), the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily, and the Apple Daily -- made the joint announcement at a news conference held Tuesday.

Also present at the news conference were Hsieh's and Ma's top election campaign aides -- Lee Ying-yuan and Chan Chun-po. Hsieh also attended the news conference to accentuate his support for the planned debate.
At the news conference, the two sides failed to reach an agreement on when the debate should be held.

The organizers originally planned to hold two debates, with the first one being scheduled for Jan. 26 or 27, and the second one for March 1 or 2, said Chen Shen-ching, deputy general manager of the PTS and convener of a preparatory committee for the debate.
Hsieh proposed that the first debate be held on the date chosen by the organizers, while Chan asked the organizers to help negotiate between the DPP and the KMT on selecting a date.
Prior to the news conference, Ma had insisted that the debate be held next February.
According to the organizers' plan, the two presidential candidates will answer questions from 20 selected members of the Taiwanese public and from representatives of local media.
The 20 individuals will be selected from a Web site especially designed by the organizers to invite the public to upload their questions in 30-second video clips, the organizers said.
The Taiwanese citizens can also send their video clips on CD-ROMs to the organizers, they said, adding that the Web site also allows the DPP and the KMT to respond to the posted questions.
In addition, the organizers noted that the 20 selected people will also be invited to the televised debate to raise follow-up questions.

Through the debate, the organizers said they hope that the two candidates can take the opportunity to listen and respond to the voices of grassroots members of society, rather than engaging in a smear campaign against each other.

The presidential candidates should elaborate on their respective platforms to the public in the debate, CNA President Liu Chih-tsung said, urging that such televised presidential debates be institutionalized in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan dumps casino bill

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday a raft of amendments to the Outlying Islands Development Act during its weekly meeting, but a measure permitting the opening of casinos was not included in the package.
Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said that the government has no plans at present to legalize the gambling industry due to a lack of social consensus on the issue.

According to Shieh, the issue is by no means a simple economic affair, rather it also involves legal and moral fronts. The Executive Yuan is not in a hurry to legalize the disputed gambling industry before a national consensus has been forged, he explained.
Shieh also dismissed as sheer speculation that the Executive Yuan's exclusion of the casion provision has something to do with the coming legislative and presidential elections.
The amendment package approved by the Executive Yuan gives the green light to the opening of duty-free shops on Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu islands.

According a United Evening News report, Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa was extremely dissatisfied with the outcome and aggressively criticized the central government for turning a blind eye to the need for economic development on remote islands.

Citing estimates by Penghu authorities, the report said that if casinos were opened on the offshore county, it would generate NT$26 billion in tax revenue per year for the county government, and more than NT$40 billion (US$1.24 billion) worth of foreign and local investment would likely to pour into the county, it added.

Legislator Lin Ping-kun from the Penghu constituency was quoted in the report as voicing a strong suspicion that the Executive Yuan dumped the casino bill to slam the door on outlying islands so as to make an opening possible on Taiwan proper in an effort to lure votes prior to the legislative and presidential polls early next year.

Fielding questions during a question-and-answer session in October at the Legislative Yuan, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh said that the government will temporarily hold back from its plan to promote the gambling industry before relevant regulations and laws have been put in place.

Despite the Executive Yuan's failure to pass the full bill, Lin, a lawmaker of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU), said that he is set to call a vote on a similar NPSU-proposed bill before the Legislative Yuan adjourns its current session in late December, according to the report.

The NPSU-initiated bill to allow casinos on outlying islands has been included on the legislative agenda, and the United Evening News report said that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party is willing to back the measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGSecret trial to let GPs carry out abortions
Family doctors will be allowed to carry out abortions in their surgeries under plans currently being trialled at secret locations by the Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: New Data, New Methods, New Conclusion
How could American intelligence agencies have overstated Iranzs intentions in 2005 so soon after being reprimanded for making similar errors involving Iraq?
The spy agencies had swallowed hard and pledged to do better after a presidential commission in March 2005 issued a blistering accounting of the intelligence failures leading to the Iraq war.
But a National Intelligence Estimate on Iran that was issued two months later said Iranzs leaders were working tirelessly to acquire anuclear weaponXa finding that, like the prewar intelligence on Iraq, has now been acknowledged to have been wrong in one of its chief conclusions.
The Wall Street Journal: Expectations Vary for Fed's Move
With their forecast of economic recovery again endangered by economic turmoil, Federal Reserve officials next week are likely to deliver their third "insurance" interest-rate cut this year.
How big a cut and what to say in the accompanying statement are likely again to be difficult decisions, as they were on Oct. 31 when the Fed cut its short-term interest-rate target to 4.5% and issued a statement suggesting no more rate cuts were likely.

DOC.HEADLINE: Birders optimistic, confident about Taiwan's ecotourism development

TEXT.P: Taiwan has nearly all it takes to develop top quality ecotourism, which is expected to be a niche industry in the future, although there are still some areas requiring work, a senior birder and ecotourism guide said Wednesday.

"Bio-diversity richness; a well-developed transportation system; safety: these three elements explain why Taiwan has been a popular destination for eco- tourists from abroad, " said Simon Liao, Vice Chairman of Taiwan International Birding Association (TIBA) who also works as a guide for eco-tourists.

Liao, freshly back from a mission to Saint Lucia, Taiwan's diplomatic ally in the Caribbean, to help it develop ecotourism and birding infrastructure, took time to reflect on Taiwan's own ecotourism on the sidelines of a press conference.
Not too many people are aware of that Taiwan has been doing well in ecotourism, attracting mostly foreign birders, Liao said.

The average expenses for a foreign birder for a 10-11 day stay in Taiwan are an astonishing NT$ 230,000 (approximately US$7,094), Liao said, adding that he once received a group of British birders who were charged 5,220 pounds (approximately NT$348,000) each for the trip.

"If you knew the business well enough, this would not be a surprise because there are 'three highs' among common ecotourists: an advanced age, a high level of education, and a high consumption capacity, " Liao said.

Hardly anyone he has received in the past has complained about his experience in Taiwan, Liao said, adding that most ecotourists came from the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Japan and the Netherlands.
"Of course, the most impressive thing they found in Taiwan was the extreme friendliness of our people, which has long be known, " he noted.
However, the bilingual services in cheaper hotels did need to be upgraded and more professional guides were needed to develop a stronger ecotourism industry, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA spends over US$11 million annually cleaning train cabins

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is spending NT$370 million (US$11.4 million) a year keeping train cabins clean, TRA Deputy Director-General Chang Ying-huei said Wednesday.

Chang revealed the figure at a press conference TRA held at the Shulin train station in Taipei County to release results of its efforts to keep the new "Taroko" express, commissioned to begin to ply between the capital city of Taipei and Hualien in eastern Taiwan in May, clean and shining.

Chang said improving passengers' satisfaction with TRA trains and services is the administration's key goal this year. With that in mind, TRA has imposed a stricter standards on the cleanness of train cabins, he added.

According to TRA statistics, around 450,000 passengers travel on TRA-operated railway lines every day. A senior official responsible for machine maintenance and repair said it is a great challenge to maintain the cleanness of more than 1,400 TRA express train cabins and numerous other cabins on commuter routes.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Lessons of Iraq Aided Intelligence On Iran
The starkly different view of Iran's nuclear program that emerged from U.S. spy agencies this week was the product of a surge in clandestine intelligence- gathering in Iran as well as radical changes in the way the intelligence community analyzes information.
The Washington Times: Iran still dangerous, Bush says
President Bush yesterday said that Iran is a threat to the rest of the world and must be stopped from obtaining nuclear weapons, one day after a new intelligence report disclosed that Iran had a covert weapons program but shut it down in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Int'l roundtable on Taiwan's capital market to open in Taipei

TEXT.P: An international roundtable conference on the development of Taiwan's capital market will kick off Dec. 10 in Taipei, with 1996 Nobel laureate in economics James Mirrlees and international professionals among its participants.

The conference aims to discuss reform and globalization of the capital market, the integration and efficiency of banking investment, and the government's regulations and supervision of the capital market, according to the organizer -- the Taiwan Securities Association.

Shih Gang, author of the "White Paper on the Development of Taiwan's Capital Market," which is to be unveiled by the association at the conference, and National Taiwan University (NTU) professor Chu Yun-peng will take part in the discussions along with experts from the securities industry and academia, the organizer said in a press release Wednesday.
Through discussions and exchanges of views, the organizer said, it is hoped the expertise of the participants will help in efforts to improve Taiwan's capital market and make it more competitive.
The conclusions reached at the conference will be put in the "White Paper on the Development of Taiwan's Capital Market," the organizer said.

The participants in the conference, to be chaired by former Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, will include delegates from the U.S. Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, Japan Securities Dealers Association, Korea Securities Dealers Association, Australian Financial Markets Association, London Investment Banking Association and the Financial Markets Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan High Speed Rail plans to add three more stations next year

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) is working on plans to add three more stations, including one in Changhua, to its existing eight stations, a task force of the Changhua County government learned Wednesday.

The task force, headed by Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, held a meeting with THSRC executives and officials from the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to discuss whether the plan might be realized at an early date to meet the county's development needs.
THSRC executives said the initial planning of the three stations in Changhua, Yunlin and Miaoli -- all in central Taiwan -- will be completed by the end of June 2007.

Hu Hsiang-lin, deputy director of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail, said the MOTC would like to see the three stations to become operational at the same time, and that the ministry will do its best to provide assistance to the local governments.

Currently the 345-km high speed rail traversing Taiwan's western corridor has eight stations: Taipei, Banciao, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, Tainan and Zuoying. After constructing three more stations next year, the THSRC plans to build two more stations in Kaohsiung, the second largest city of Taiwan, and Nangang, an eastern suburb of Taipei in northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges hard work to win legislative, presidential elections

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asked officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to work hard to win 50 seats in the upcoming legislative elections, DPP officials said Wednesday.

The president also said that there will be no "pendulum effect" in the Jan. 12 legislative and the March 22 presidential elections, referring to the underdog effect in which winning one election handicaps a party in the next election.

Chen said that if the DPP takes 50 seats in the 113-seat legislature, it will build momentum of the party, and Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the DPP in the presidential election, will go on to win the presidency.
The president was speaking in his capacity as DPP chairman during a regular weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, the officials said.

He also went out of his way to ask the heads of DPP chapters in Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties to work hard so as to ensure all DPP candidates in the three counties win the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
"If they work hard enough, the goal of garnering 35 regional seats will be achieved," the president said.

On the at-large seats, Chen predicted that minor parties will be unable to get past the threshold of more than 5 percent of votes cast in the election to ensure a seat, and the at-large seats will end up in the hands of the two major parties -- the DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang.
For this reason, the president stated that the DPP seeking 15 at-large seats is a "reasonable estimate."

The president also said that the DPP has no money to buy votes and will rely on an all-out effort to combat vote-buying after some heads of DPP chapters reported that vote-buying is a serious issue in their cities and counties.

A new "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system will be adopted in the new legislature, with one vote going for individual legislative candidates and the other vote going for a party. The new system is generally considered to favor major political parties.

The number of seats in the legislature will also be halved from the current 225 to 113, with 73 regional seats, six aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for representatives of at-large and overseas expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's forex reserves hit new high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a new high at US$270.09 billion as of the end of November, the Taipei-based Central Bank of Republic of China (CBC) said Wednesday.

The figure represents an increase of NT$4.16 billion over the previous month's level and puts Taiwan in fourth place in the world, behind China with US$1.43 trillion (as of September) , Japan with US$930.3 billion and Russia with US$325.4 billion (both as of October), CBC officials said.
The officials attributed the increase to interest earned on foreign exchange reserves and the appreciation in its reserves, such as the euro, relative to the U.S. dollar.
They also said that the forex reserves of India and South Korea trailed those of Taiwan with US$264 billion (as of Nov. 23) and US$261.5 billion (as of November), respectively.
Singapore had US$160.1 billion and Hong Kong had US$140.6 billion in forex holdings as of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scores of police stationed at park over plaque change dispute

TEXT.P: Scores of police officers from the central government and the Taipei city government have been stationed in the the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park square to prevent supporters and opponents in a park plaque replacement dispute from clashing with one another.

The police deployment came Tuesday in advance of the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) plans to replace the park's front gate plaque bearing the Chinese characters of "Ta Chung Chih Cheng", which allude to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, with a new one carrying the Chinese characters "Tzu You Kwang Chang, " which translates as "Liberty Square," Thursday morning.

The park, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under Kuomintang (KMT) rule.

The Taipei city government has also sent its police officers in preparation to arrest those attempting to make any change to the park, including taking down the plaque, as the park has been temporarily designated by the city government as an historic site.
In addition, the Taipei city government filed a constitutional interpretation of the Council of Grand Justices Tuesday evening in an attempt to safeguard its jurisdiction over the park.

Before the ruling is handed down, the central government has no right to stop or abolish the Taipei city government's designation of the park as a historic site, said Lee Yung-ping, director of Taipei City's Cultural Affairs Department.

Lee made the remarks Tuesday at a press conference shortly after the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) amended its measures for the designation and abolishment of historic sites earlier in the day to deny the city government its right to designate historic sites, including the controversial park.

In response to the CAA's moves, the city government called an emergency meeting to approve an amendment to its regulations, effective immediately, specifying that any national designation or abolishment of the city's historic sites approved by the central government "will not affect" designations made by the city government.

Citing a recent ruling of the Taipei High Administrative Court, Lee said that the Taipei city government has jurisdiction over the park, and has the right to apprehend those caught tampering with the site.
Lee said that the city government "is confident" regarding the future result of the constitutional interpretation ruling unless "there is political interference."
After the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law was amended in 2005, Lee went on, historic sites designated by the central or local governments came to enjoy the same legal status.
Lee said that the city government started a procedure in March to review whether the park can be viewed as an historic site.

During the review process, the park is to be regarded as an historic site, Lee said, adding that the MOE must obtain approval from the Taipei city government's 21-member committee before changing the park's front gate plaque.
However, the MOE has yet to file an application for the approval, according to Lee.
On the contrary, MOE officials said that the ministry will begin to install the new plaque soon after the CCA amendments take effect.
According to CCA officials, the amendments will come into force Dec. 6, three days after the Executive Yuan published the amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-6th Army Corps commander given long prison term for corruption

TEXT.P: A former commander of the 6th Army Corps was sentenced to a prison term of 16 years and six months Wednesday on charges of corruption.
The Military High Court under the Ministry of National Defense convicted Lt. Gen. Cheng Shih-yu of two counts of embezzlement after extensive investigations.

Cheng, who has been in custody since June, was the highest-ranking military officer to have been prosecuted in recent memory. The sentence was also the harshest the military court has ever given in recent years. Cheng can appeal the case.

According to the court verdict, Cheng had ordered his subordinate, Chi Meng- kuan, to falsify procurement documents to embezzle a total of NT$1.31 million in the Army Corps' general administrative fees and additional administrative fees.

Noting that the two counts of embezzlement were separate moves and should be punished separately, military judges gave a 12-year prison sentence for Cheng's embezzlement of general administrative fees and an eight-year prison sentence for the embezzlement of addition administrative fees. But the verdict said Cheng will have to stay behind bar for 16 years and six months for the two counts of embezzlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy memorial hall to be closed for 3 days over plaque dispute

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall and its surrounding park will close to public access from 9 a.m. Thursday through midnight Saturday, the Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Wednesday.

The announcement came after the Taipei city government sent personnel to the hall in an attempt to remove scaffolds. The attempt was foiled after riot police deployed at the park blocked the city government action.
To avoid any further disturbances, MOE officials said the hall and the surrounding park will shut down for three days.
Lee Yung-ping, director of the city government's cultural affairs department, criticized the MOE's closure decision, saying the move indicates the ministry's lack of democratic manner.

The city government and the MOE have been at odds over the MOE's plan to replace the inscription on the gateway to the hall from the Chinese characters of "Ta Chung Chih Cheng", which allude to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, with a new one carrying the Chinese characters "Tzu You Kwang Chang, " which translates as "Liberty Square."

The hall, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under Kuomintang (KMT) rule.

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday.

The weighted price index was up 107.74 points at 8,784.69 on a turnover of NT$4.39 billion (US$135.91 million) at the open. The index gained 25.67 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 8,676.95 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down against New Taiwan dollar in early trading

The greenback was trading at NT$32.300 at 9: 45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.003 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 6, or the 27th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Ex-6th Army Corps commander given long prison term for corruption

TEXT.P: A former commander of the 6th Army Corps was sentenced to 16 years and six months in prison Wednesday on charges of corruption.

Cheng, who has been in custody since June, was the highest-ranking military officer to have been prosecuted in recent memory. The sentence was also the harshest the military court has ever given in recent years. Cheng is eligible to appeal the case.

But the verdict said Cheng will have to stay behind bar for only a total of 16 years and six months for the two counts of embezzlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges hard work to win legislative, presidential elections

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asked officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to work hard to win 50 seats in the upcoming legislative elections, DPP officials said Wednesday.

The president also said that there will be no "pendulum effect" in the Jan. 12 legislative and the March 22 presidential elections, referring to the underdog effect in which winning one election handicaps a party in the next election.

Chen said that if the DPP takes 50 seats in the 113-seat legislature, it will build momentum of the party, and Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the DPP in the presidential election, will go on to win the presidency.
The president was speaking in his capacity as DPP chairman during a regular weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, the officials said.

He also went out of his way to ask the heads of DPP chapters in Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties to work hard so as to ensure all DPP candidates in the three counties win the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
"If they work hard enough, the goal of garnering 35 regional seats will be achieved," the president said.

On the at-large seats, Chen predicted that minor parties will be unable to get past the threshold of more than 5 percent of votes cast in the election to ensure a seat, and the at-large seats will end up in the hands of the two major parties -- the DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang.
For this reason, the president stated that the DPP seeking 15 at-large seats is a "reasonable estimate."

The president also said that the DPP has no money to buy votes and will rely on an all-out effort to combat vote-buying after some heads of DPP chapters reported that vote-buying is a serious issue in their cities and counties.

A new "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system will be adopted in the new legislature, with one vote going for individual legislative candidates and the other vote going for a party. The new system is generally considered to favor major political parties.

The number of seats in the legislature will also be halved from the current 225 to 113, with 73 regional seats, six aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for representatives of at-large and overseas expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy memorial hall to be closed for 3 days over plaque dispute

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall and its surrounding park will be closed to public access from 9 a.m. Thursday through midnight Saturday, the Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Wednesday.

The announcement came after the Taipei city government sent personnel to the hall in an attempt to remove scaffolds erected by MOE contractors in preparation for removal of a plaque referring to the late President Chiang Kai-shek branded by some as dictator.

To avoid any further disturbances, MOE Chief Secretary Chuang Kuo-jung said the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, will be closed to the public for three days. But he added that entry into the National Concert Hall and the National Theater, both of which are within the perimeters of the memorial hall park, would not be affected.
Lee Yung-ping, director of the city government's cultural affairs department, criticized the MOE's closure decision, saying the move indicates the ministry's lack of "democratic process."

The MOE and the city govenrment have been at odds in recent days over the MOE's plan to replace the four-character "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" inscription at the gateway to the hall with another four-character inscription that reads "Tzu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square."

The hall was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under Kuomintang (KMT) rule.

There was shouting, cursing and sporadic shoving between inscription replacement supporters and opponents at the site Wednesday as a face-off between the central government and the KMT-controlled Taipei city govenrment continued over the issue.
According to MOE officials, the plaque replacement will be completed during the three-day closure of the memorial hall.
