DOC.HEADLINE: Photojournalist injured while covering hall plaque replacement news

TEXT.P: A photojournalist and several other people were injured when a pickup van rammed into a crowd gathered in front of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall Thursday.

Wang Jui-chang, a photojournalist with the cable station Eastern Broadcasting Company, was taking pictures of a scuffle between the members of the pro- independence group, World United Formosans for Independence, and the protesters at around 11:10 a.m. when he was hit and dragged by the van for several meters before being rescued.
Wang, who suffered a fractured bone, as well as others injured in the incident were rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital for treatment.

Crowds had gathered in and around the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall immediately after an announcement Wednesday by the Ministry of Education (MOE) that the hall would be closed for three days from Thursday morning to prepare for the replacement of a controversial plaque on the hall's main gateway.
The driver of the van, Peng Sheng-lu, was taken to a police station for questioning.
The hall, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late president. It was renamed early this year.
The MOE intends to replace the plaque bearing the characters "Ta Chung Chih Cheng, " an allusion to the late president, with one which reads "Tzu You Kuang Chang, " or "Liberty Square."

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for end to deification of Chiang Kai-Shek

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday the dispute surrounding his administration's plan to make changes to the main gateway of the former Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall involves the question of whether the country should continue honoring a past dictator as if he were a god.

According to Chen, those who are blocking the plan to remove a plaque and inscription with references to the late President Chiang Kai-shek are not trying to protect historic relics as they have claimed, but instead are trying to safeguard the deified status of Chiang as well as the single party-state system and the "great China" ideology that Chiang's name stands for.

Chen addressed the issue in the latest issue of his online newsletter on the same day the memorial hall -- which was renamed the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall earlier this year -- was shut down for three days for the renovation work amid strong opposition from the Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled Taipei city government which has designated the hall as a historic site.

The renovation work will involve replacing the four-character inscription alluding to Chiang's name located at the top of the main gate with a new inscription that reads "Liberty Square, " as well as replacing a plaque on the hall bearing the Chinese characters for "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall" with a new one that reads "National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall."

Accusing Chiang of being the main perpetrator of the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops, Chen said it would be "anti-democratic, anti-human rights and anti-Taiwan" if the country were to continue maintaining a building honoring Chiang.

Chen said Chiang's 25-year rule of Taiwan never received the consent of the Taiwan people and was based solely on the illusionary "great China" ideology, adding that Chiang viewed himself as the ruler of the whole of China and considered Taiwan as just a part of China.
"To Chiang, Taiwan was only a temporary stop where he could rest in preparation for a return to China to restore a regime defeated by the Chinese communists," Chen said.

"Today, we have renamed the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall as the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall not only to highlight the Taiwan people's sacrifice for and contribution to the pursuit of freedom, democracy and justice over the past five decades, but also to reconstruct the Taiwan consciousness," Chen said.

He further said that while many relatives of the victims of political persecution during the past martial law era are thankful to the government for its efforts to compensate and restore the reputation of the victims, they remain sad and resentful that the truth behind the persecution has yet to come to light.

The president stressed that the Democratic Progressive Party administration's efforts to trace the responsibilities of the past dictatorial rulers are not aimed at seeking revenge but at upholding justice for the victims and their families.
"Asking the victims and their families to look ahead and not back would be like making them victims for a second time," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy hall closes to public for inscription replacement

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall was shut down at 9 a.m. Thursday for three days as ordered by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to facilitate the replacement of a controversial inscription on the hall's main gate.

The MOE intends to replace the inscription bearing the Chinese characters "Ta Chung Chih Cheng," an allusion to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, with one that reads "Tzu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square."

Hundreds of police were deployed to maintain order and keep traffic flowing at the site. Only staff at the hall and ticket-holders to performances at the National Theater and National Concert Hall, which are within the perimeters of the hall, will be granted access to the site during the three-day period, according to police.
In the morning, scores of tourist coaches carrying visitors from Japan, Malaysia and China arrived at the hall, a landmark in Taipei.

Both the MOE and the Taipei city government have designated the hall as a historic site and have jurisdiction over the park. The Taipei city government, which opposes the plan to replace the inscription, has traded barbs with the MOE over the issue over the past several days.
The hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late president. It was renamed early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close slightly higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended slightly higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 17.46 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 8,694.41.
The bourse opened at 8,784.69 and fluctuated between 8,797.61 and
8,654.86 during trading. A total of 4.33 billion shares changed
hands on a market turnover of NT$127.81 billion (US$3.96
billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks and construction issues both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 762, with 445 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 35 points to close at 8,739, with 43,110 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index Futures for January rose 36 points to finish at 8,740, with 455 contracts traded, while March futures increased 14 points to close at 8,720, with 14 contract transactions. September futures moved up 25 points to finish at 8,537, with 16 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,704 for December, 8,704 for January, 8,706 for March, 8,700 for June and 8,512 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures dropped 0.8 points to close at 363.6, with 2,914 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 363.1, with 40 contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 0.9 points to close at 361.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures rose 7.2 points to close at 973, with 3,246 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 6.6 points to finish at 972.4, with 75 contracts traded. March TF futures increased 8.4 points to close at 978, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preferential industrial land rent rate program bearing fruit: MOEA

TEXT.P: Many industrial lands in Taiwan are becoming increasingly popular, with greater numbers of overseas Taiwanese returning to invest in the country and with local enterprises expanding their investment projects, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Thursday.
The official attributed the business boom to the government policy that offers preferential land rent rates in the island's industrial areas to both local and overseas Taiwanese investors.

According to the official, the MOEA launched the preferential land rent rate program in May 2005, with the ministry allocating a total of NT$60 billion (US$1.8 billion) in funds to subsidize rent in the first stage of the program.
MOEA statistics show that in the first stage of the program, 506 companies rented a total of 295.55 hectares of land, generating investment worth NT$203.9 billion and creating 35,000 jobs.
Considering the favorable results of the first stage of the program, the MOEA launched the second stage last year and increased the original budget from NT$30 billion to NT$50 billion.
In the second stage of the program, 345 enterprises rented 295.25 hectares of land in industrial areas, generating investment worth NT$152.01 billion and creating nearly 30,000 jobs.

In light of the favorable results of the program to date and the fact that the funds for the second stage will likely run out by the end of the year, the MOEA does not exclude the possibility of increasing the budget for the second stage or launching a third stage, the official said, adding that Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen is asking related agencies to conduct a thorough evaluation of the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Anti-corruption' roadsigns set up in front of Presidential Office

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government began Thursday to install roadsigns emblazoned with the characters "anti-corruption democracy square" to rename a section of a boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
The new signs appear on the section between Kungyuan Road and Jinfumen on Ketagalan Boulevard.

The move gave rise to speculation that the city government is attempting to confront the central government over its plan to expunge references to the late President Chiang Kai-shek at the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, originally named the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall until the namechange this year. The hall is located adjacent to the Presidential Office.

The city government, which has designated the hall as a historic site and wants it left as it is, has traded barbs with the Ministry of Education (MOE) over the removal of the inscription "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" on the gateway, an allusion to Chiang, and its replacement with one that reads "Tsu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square."
A city government official denied any correlation between the two issues.
Emile Sheng, director of the city government's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, said the street renaming is to mark the International Day against Corruption, which falls on Dec. 9.
In addition, the city government passed a resolution in May to rename the section of Ketagalan Boulevard as "anti-corruption Democracy Square."
"The construction work was set to start on Dec. 6 a long time ago," Sheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Violence outside memorial hall condemned

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed concern Thursday over several journalists and citizens who were injured after being rammed by a van in a scuffle that occurred outside the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall earlier in the day.

Chen condemned the violence and instructed law enforcement authorities to deal with those responsible for the incident in accordance with the law, according to Lee Nan-yang, director-general of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.

Wang Jui-chang, a photojournalist with the Eastern Broadcasting Company, a local cable TV channel, was taking pictures of a scuffle between members of the pro- independence group World United Formosans for Independence and protesters when he was hit and dragged by the pickup van for several meters before being rescued.
Wang, who suffered a broken bone, as well as others injured in the incident, were rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital for treatment.

Reporters for Sanlih TV, Formosa TV and the China Times, as well as various other people, were also reportedly injured in the ram. The driver of the van, surnamed Peng, was taken to a police station for questioning.

Crowds gathered in and around the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall after the Ministry of Education announced a day earlier that it would be closed for three days from Thursday for renovation work amid strong opposition from the Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled Taipei city government, which has designated the hall as a historic site.

The renovation work will involve replacing the four-character inscription alluding to the late President Chiang Kai-shek's name located at the top of the main gate with a new inscription that reads "Liberty Square, " as well as replacing a plaque on the hall bearing the Chinese characters for "Chiang Kai- shek Memorial Hall" with a new one that reads "National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall."
The hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late president. It was renamed early this year.

The KMT issued a statement to condemn the violence. Huang Yu-chen, director of the KMT's Cultural and Communication Affairs Committee, appealed in the statement for calm and urged politicians to stay out of the controversy and refrain from fueling further controversy for their own political gains.

The Satellite Television Broadcasting Association lodged a protest against the violence. Members of the association urged the public to "show respect" for TV reporters, who they said have tried their utmost to "safeguard the public's right to know." They urged the public to stay cool, saying that reporters should also be protected as ordinary people during strife and should not be the targets of attacks.
The Association of Taiwan Journalists (ATJ) also condemned the incident.
ATJ President Chen Hsiao-yi condemned the violence and reiterated that reporters' rights to cover the news should be fully respected.

She added that the law enforcement authorities should have known that the memorial hall could be a flashpoint when the renovation job kicks off and claimed that the police have apparently not done their job in terms of taking precautions.

Meanwhile, Lee Chin-tien, head of the Chungcheng 1st Police Station, said that after preliminary questioning of the van driver, it was found that Peng had "no intention of hurting anyone" and that the case will be referred to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

Lee quoted Peng as saying that he was driving past the memorial hall and was slowed by the crowd when somebody -- identified later as a man surnamed Hsiao -- climbed onto his pickup and began cursing him. Peng said he was terrified and sped up in an attempt to flee from the scene, causing his van to ram the victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kiribati women receive heart surgery in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Three Kiribati women who arrived in Taiwan in November for treatment for rheumatic heart disease have received successful surgery at the Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei City, a doctor at the hospital said Thursday.
The hospital threw a party a day earlier for the patients, heart specialist Lee Chun-yi said.
The three patients have recovered well, Lee said, adding that they will soon return to Kiribati, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the central Pacific Ocean.
Aretitd, one of the three, is a reporter and the only patient who speaks English. "I will write about my experience receiving medical treatment in Taiwan after I return home, " she said.

Nursing personnel at the hospital had drawn up a graphic poster carrying pictures with explanations in both Kiribati and Mandarin in an effort to provide a more friendly environment and to communicate better with the two other patients, Lee said.
Aoniba Roneta, an intern nurse from Kiribati, and Sainimere Vulibeci, a dietician from Fiji, also provided great help, Lee added.

Mackay Memorial Hospital staff have been giving free medical services to Kiribati after signing a sisterhood agreement with the Tungaru Central Hospital of Kiribati through the Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund.
The three patients were the first to be transferred from the Tungaru Central Hospital to Mackay Memorial Hospital for treatment, Lee said.

Riteti Maninraka, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health and Medical Services of Kiribati, expressed his gratitude in a recorded speech at Wednesday's party for Taiwan's assistance and help, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. opposition to Taiwan referendum could suffer backlash: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that U.S. opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan could trigger an emotional backlash from the Taiwan people and could be unfavorable to relations between the two countries.

Chen said he had been informed that during a meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush Oct. 28, Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Jiechi requested that Bush openly voice objections to the referendum initiative or have the U.S. Secretary of State do so to highlight the severity of the issue.

According to Chen, the incident shows that Beijing has learned a lesson from past experience and dare not make enemies of the Taiwan people by openly challenging them, believing that it would be more effective to exert pressure on Taipei through Washington.
Despite U.S. opposition to the plan, Chen claimed that it would be "impossible" for Taiwan to change or scrap the referendum -- slated to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.

The president made the remarks while receiving U.S. Rep. Eni Faleomavaega, who was accompanied by Stephen Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei office, who recently reiterated Washington's objections to the referendum by calling it "neither necessary nor helpful."

During a speech delivered at a conference held by the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies in Taipei Monday, Young said Taiwan's presidential election presents an opportunity for Taiwan and China to set aside past differences and work to create a new cooperative relationship.

Young said Chinese President Hu Jintao's relatively moderate remarks on Taiwan policy at the recent 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China indicates that "Beijing may be looking for ways to open contact with Taiwan's next president."
Therefore, it is imperative that Taiwan's politicians do not carry their actions and rhetoric to the point of closing off future possibilities, according to Young.
Apparently responding to Young's remarks, Chen dismissed as "wishful thinking" the belief that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume dialogue as long as they put aside their differences.

The fact that the government of Taiwan has been calling for the shelving of cross-strait differences over the past seven to eight years shows that the problem lies not with Taiwan, but with China, according to Chen.

"It is impossible to expect the Chinese leaders to set aside major cross-strait differences, especially to renounce the `one China' principle or the ultimate goal of unification, " Chen said, pointing out that even his "five noes" commitments put forth in his 2000 inaugural address failed to make Beijing agree to resuming talks with Taipei.

While the problem already existed during the rule of the Kuomintang, which follows a "one China" principle and pursues ultimate unification of Taiwan and China, the situation has become even more difficult now that Beijing has changed its premise of "one China" from "Taiwan is part of China" to "Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China," he said.
"Not even Ma Ying-jeou (the KMT's presidential candidate) and the KMT dare openly say they accept Taiwan as part of the People's Republic of China," Chen said.

Chen also said Beijing's plan to establish an air defense identification zone in the Taiwan Strait will damage cross-strait peace and stability, and he urged the United States and Japan to pay attention to the unreasonable Chinese move.

DOC.HEADLINE: New earthquake-resistant building component developed

TEXT.P: Researchers at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST) have developed a new earthquake- resistant structure component for buildings, offering an easy-to- install solution with improved protective capabilities, NTUST sources reported Thursday.

Chen Sheng-jin, a professor at NTUST's Department of Construction Engineering, explained that the new component -- dubbed "low yield strength, energy dissipation steel structure for seismic shear force" -- has proved better than conventional ones in terms of seismic wave absorption and building structure protection.

Chen noted that the new component can endure a shear deformation angle of more that 16 degrees, far greater than architecture safety requirements, making building structures secure during even great earthquakes.

The NTUST research team is at present studying how to integrate the component in shear walls, Chen said, adding that based on a prototype experiment, when combined with high-strength beams, the earthquake-resistant design can hold a building intact under a lateral displacement of six degrees, a figure also better than the requirement of two to four degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.006 to close at NT$32.309.
A total of US$874 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.303 and fluctuated between NT$32.285 and NT$32.328.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Marshall Islands ties will not be affected by election: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the Republic of the Marshall Islands will not be affected by the result of a parliamentary election in the Pacific state, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said at a press conference Thursday.
MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said ties will remain unchanged no matter whether the ruling United Democratic Party or the opposition Ailin Kein Ad wins.
Vote counting was originally scheduled to finish a day earlier but different ways of counting postal ballots and tight races in some constituencies caused a delay, Yeh added.

The Washington Times:Rise a surprise to all but Huckabee

DOC.HEADLINE: Climate change needs more effective news coverage: symposium

TEXT.P: Effective reporting and propaganda on climate change can help the general public fight the battle against global warming, experts said Thursday at the Climate Change Symposium held by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei.

The BTCO organized the seminar with regards to the COP13 of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) &the COP/MOP 3 of the Kyoto Protocol currently being held in Bali, Indonesia, a BTCO spokesman said, adding that the office would like to take the opportunity to establish a network with the Taiwanese Environmental Protection Administration and other NGOs since environmental issues play an important role in the British government's public diplomacy campaign.

Addressing the occasion, Alex Palman, the climate change consultant of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, U.K., who developed and implemented the Climate Change Communications Initiative (CCCI) , said that creating fear or providing information alone is not the proper strategy for educating people about climate change, adding that individuals should keep positive attitudes and that everyone can contribute to mitigating global warming by changing their behavior and way of life.

Palman went on to give two successful examples of CCCI campaigns on climate change, including the TV films My CO2 and the Climate Change Champions, both of which he said can serve as models for Taiwan. The former shows that in response to global warming, the general public can simply switch off unused electrical devices or walk instead of driving, while the latter brings together schools, community groups, NGOs as well as central and local governments for competitions in taking anti-global warming action among youngsters.

Speaking on the same occasion, Fiona Harvey, a noted journalist on environmental issues and correspondent for the Financial Times, said that visualizing the problem to the general public -- such as floods occurring more and more frequently in the U.K., or dengue fever spreading toward northern Taiwan due to warmer weather, is a good way of targeting the issue, since climate change is more of a fact than theory.

The media should avoid making its reports "scary reading" because too much pessimism might make people give up making efforts to address the issue or cause them to wonder about its credibility, she said.
"There is optimism as well as gloom, " she said, adding that focusing on reporting possible solutions and empowering people by showing them what they can do is more important.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate calls for calm over monument inscription row

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), called Thursday for calm among supporters over a dispute about an inscription at the top of the main gate of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.

In response to a Ministry of Education (MOE) decision to replace the four- character metal inscription bearing Chiang's second name in the main gate with another meaning "Liberty Square, " Ma urged "pan-blue alliance" backers to stay rational amid what he called a plot by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration to create problems and make political gains in the runup to the legislative and presidential polls of early next year.

Although whether the inscription should be changed is worthy of discussion, Ma blamed the DPP government for attempting to remove it in a "rude and authoritarian manner" without exploring public opinion in advance.

Claiming that it is absurd that the DPP government would tear down the inscription after having appointed the memorial hall as a historic relic with merely an administrative decree, Ma promised that if he wins the March 22 presidential election he will push for the restoration of the inscription through legal and open means.
The sealing of the landmark building for three days of renovation work has sparked strong attacks from the KMT, which said the action fully reflects the DPP's anti-democratic mindset.

Countering the KMT-led Taipei city government, the MOE ordered Wednesday evening that the compound of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall be cordoned off from Thursday to Saturday for the installation of the new inscription, which is slated to be inaugurated Monday.

Citing relevant regulations and laws, both the city government and the central government claimed that each is entitled to oversee the monument's operations, provoking confrontation between supporters of the "pan-green" and "pan-blue" camps.

The "pan-green" camp of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union views the late President Chiang Kai-shek as the main culprit behind the 228 Incident of 1947 and the martial rule that the KMT imposed in Taiwan during the 1949-1987 period.
The DPP has since early this year launched a series of moves to purge the country of all references to Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 Taiwan Orange Festival to be inaugurated Friday

TEXT.P: A 31-day orange festival will be inaugurated Friday in Yunlin County, home to a large proportion of Taiwan's agricultural produce, Yunlin Magistrate Su Chih- fen announced Thursday.
Su made the announcement at a news conference at the Council of Agriculture (COA) in Taipei that was also attended by COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan.
Su Jia-chyuan noted that most of Taiwan's oranges are produced in the southern Yunlin and Chiayi area, but added that prices are low due to the gigantic quantity harvested.

"The COA has been pondering how to increase the profits of orange growers in this area, " Su Jia-chyuan said, adding that this year's orange festival will offer a variety of interesting activities, emulating France's Orange Festival, to attract both buyers and tourists.

In addition, Yunlin County is well known for its coffee, seafood and puppet shows, the COA head said, expressing hope that the combination of orange festival and tourist attractions will bring more benefit to farmers in the county.
For her part, Su Chih-fen urged everyone to eat one orange or drink orange juice daily to not only increase their health but also help orange growers make a profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Influx of new immigrants jacks up housing prices in Taipei

TEXT.P: Housing prices in the Wanhua district of Taipei city rose considerably over the past three years, mainly because many new immigrants settled down there, a property agent in Taipei said Thursday.

Chen Wei-wen, a manager with Eastern Realty's Planning and Research Department, pointed out that the average price of an ordinary apartment in Wanhua soared 25.3 percent to NT$223,000 per ping -- an equivalent of 36 square feet -- over the past three years, while the average price of a housing unit in a high-rise building equipped with elevators also increased by 30.3 percent to NT$241,000 per ping.

Citing statistics provided by the Bureau of Civil Affairs of the Taipei city government, Chen said 30,300 new immigrants settled in Taipei in the first 10 months of this year, with Wanhua being their destination of choice among all city districts.
About 90 percent of the new immigrants in Taipei are Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens, with the remaining 10 percent being immigrants from other Southeast Asian countries.

The real estate agent expressed the belief that further relaxation in the government's policy to allow the three direct links with China in mail, transport and trade will provide a major boost to Taiwan's property market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government has not manipulated indicators: economic planner

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner denied opposition claims Thursday that the government has adjusted the economic monitoring indicators to create a better score sheet for the nation's economic performance.

Ho Mei-yueh, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks at a meeting of the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan. Also attending were Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin and Lu Du-ching, deputy director of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Legislator Lee Jih-chu of the opposition Kuomintang said the government has forecast that economic growth this year will hit 5.46 percent, while the monitoring indicators flashed a yellow-red signal in October, suggesting a transition to a more optimistic economic condition.

In reality, Lee claimed, a survey shows that nearly 80 percent of the people think the distribution of wealth has worsened and that the closure of manufacturers has outnumbered the opening of new ones. Only 20 percent of the enterprises surveyed said they plan to raise salaries.
Lee said she does not think the government has falsified the indicators, but she expressed doubt as to whether the scaling system is effective enough to reflect the real situation.
Ho said the CEPD reviews its economic monitoring indicators every five years and that the present monitoring indicators were only adopted in mid-2007 after careful planning for more than one year.

The CEPD uses a five-level spectrum to gauge domestic economic health, with blue indicating recession, yellow-blue a slowdown, green steady growth, yellow-red a slight overheating and red an absolute overheating.

DOC.HEADLINE: Father of student demonstrator calls for tolerance of diverse voices

TEXT.P: Noted lawyer Y.R. Lee Thursday called for tolerance for diverse voices in Taiwan, which he said should be an open, democratic society.

Lee, founder and partner of Y.R. Lee & Partners Attorneys-At-Law, made the call in a statement issued one day after his son, Lee Ting-chun, was brought in by police for questioning after he gave a speech at the gate of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall concerning a Ministry of Education plan to remove the name of the late President Chiang Kai-shek from the top of the memorial hall's main gate.

Lee Ting-chun was among crowds gathered in and around the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall after the Ministry of Education announced Wednesday that the memorial would be closed for three days from Thursday for renovation work. The announcement came amid strong opposition from the Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled Taipei city government, which has designated the hall as an historic site.

The renovation work will involve replacing the four-character inscription alluding to Chiang's name located at the top of the main gate with a new inscription that reads "Liberty Square, " as well as replacing a plaque on the hall bearing the Chinese characters for "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall" with a new one that reads "National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall."
The hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late president. It was renamed early this year.

Commenting on his son's being nabbed by the police and dismissed later the same day, Lee said his son is a university student and an adult, who, like every citizen in the Republic of China on Taiwan, enjoys a right to freedom of speech according to the Constitution.

Lee said that the people have paid attention to every governmental move and policy. He called for members of all sectors in Taiwan society to be cool-headed and discuss among themselves possible solutions when controversies arise.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mother of Hong Kong student searches for son

TEXT.P: The mother of a Hong Kong student who came to Taiwan 10 years ago but had not contacted his Hong Kong family in recent years, approached the Hong Kong Red Cross Society several days ago seeking help in a search for her son, a source from the Taichung county government said Thursday.

According to Lin Chih-chien, a county government official in charge of social work, the Hong Kong Red Cross Society received a letter from the mother of Ching Chikin recently saying that she received a letter in early October from a Taiwanese individual who claimed that Ching had died Sept. 27 this year of cerebral cancer.

The Hong Kong Red Cross Society then wrote to its Taiwan counterpart, asking for help in a search for Ching. According to the Hong Kong Red Cross Society, Ching's mother said the letter she received in early October was mailed by a social worker named Chia Teh-hsin, supposedly from Taiwan's "Tzi Chin Hospital, " which had cremated Ching, spread his ashes at sea outside the eastern city of Hualien, and donated his corneas to a Taiwanese girl in accordance with his will. Taiwan has no "Tzi Chin" hospital.

Ching's mother told the Hong Kong Red Cross Society that Ching had not contacted her for several years and that she had no idea where he was. She was suspicious about the letter's veracity, which prompted her to approach the Hong Kong Red Cross Society for a search for the truth and her son.

The Taichung county government found out that Ching was born in 1974 and began his residential registration in Linkou, Taipei County in 1994. According to Taiwan's household registration data, Ching began to study at Providence University in Taichung County in 1996. He returned to Hong Kong for a short period in 1998 but returned to Taiwan to work after graduating from the university. He remains on the Taichung County household register.
In addition, the pronunciation of the name of the person who sent the letter to Ching's mother -- "Chia Teh-hsin" -- sounds in Chinese exactly like "a fake letter."
The Taichung county official urged anyone who knows of Ching's whereabouts to contact him on telephone number 04-2526-3100 Ext. 2728.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO minister visits injured reporter

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey headed to National Taiwan University Hospital Thursday afternoon to visit a reporter seriously wounded by a van outside of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall earlier in the day.

Wang Jui-chang, a photojournalist with the Eastern Broadcasting Company, was rammed by a van while taking photos of a scuffle between members of the pro- independence group World United Formosan's for Independence and protesters demonstrating against the imminent replacement of an inscription on the main gate of the hall.
The van also wounded four reporters from Sanlih TV, Formosa TV and the China Times, as well as other citizens. The driver of the van, Peng Sheng-lu, was taken into custody by police for questioning.
Shieh condemned the violence, saying that no one is allowed to employ verbal or physical violence against reporters, and said that the violence done to Wang and others, is "intolerable."

Crowds of people gathered around the hall after the Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Wednesday a temporary closure of the hall, beginning Thursday, for renovations involving the replacement of the four-character inscription reading "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" with another reading "Tzu You Kuang Chang", which translates as "Liberty Square."
The MOE and the Taipei City government have been at odds in recent days over the MOE's plan to replace the inscription.

Shieh said the MOE has followed correct procedures since April this year in preparation for carrying out the replacement, and that the Taipei city government has put up "too much resistance" to the central government's decision.
"The Taipei city government will have to assume its legal and social responsibilities for the incident," Shieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambian president fascinated by Eee PC

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya Jammeh, who is making a five-day state visit to Taiwan, was fascinated Wednesday by an innovative low-cost notebook computer, the Eee PC, during a tour of its manufacturer, ASUSTek Computer Inc.
Jammeh, accompanied by Republic of Cina Ambassador to The Gambia Chang Pei-chi, showed great interest during the visit and was impressed with the innovative product, ASUS said in a press release.
Eee PC, famed for its ease of learning and ease of use, is aimed at creating a user-friendly environment for Internet surfing, work, entertainment, learning and PC operation.

This is Jammeh's seventh state visit to Taiwan since his inauguration in 1996. The Gambia was the first nation President Chen Shui-bian visited following his victory in the presidential election of 2000.
The Gambia is one of Taiwan's firmest African allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yang Ming University establishes platform on epidemic diseases

TEXT.P: A new online information-exchanging platform dealing with epidemic diseases is to open to the public in late December with the aim of reducing the time spent analyzing prevalent virus strains and adjusting vaccines, National Yang Ming University (NYMU) sources said Thursday.

Traditionally, the surces pointed out, World Health Organization would gather virologists each spring to determine which influenza virus strain was likely to be most prevalent in the coming winter; however, analysis of virus characteristics and transmission patterns usually takes a month, reducing the time left for vaccine modification.
However, given this platform and a new analytical system developed by NYMU researchers, the time for that analysis can by reduced to about one week, they added.

The platform, dubbed Epidemiology Net, and the system, are a result of the project on Epidemic Disease Analysis and Virus Strain for Vaccine Selection; they have been constructed by a team led by Yang Ueng-cheng, a biology professor at National Yang Ming University (NYMU) , and technically supported by the service-oriented architecture of International Business Machines (IBM).

Scientists from National Taiwan University, Soochow University, and Veterans General Hospital also contributed to the network, and more universities and hospitals nationwide are expected to join the effort in later stages.

During the present, preliminary phase, most of the entries are coming from Taiwan's Center for Disease Control and the Influenza Virus Bioinformatics System (IVBS) run by another NYMU professor, Yang explained, adding that the information sources will be much more diverse once the platform goes on-line.
Currently, the platform will focus on diseases posing an imminent danger to human health, such as bird flu, dengue fever, HIV-AIDS, and tuberculosis, Yang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign heating up for Taitung area legislative race

TEXT.P: The Taitung County office of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Thursday that the party has revoked the KMT membership of Hsu Chih-hsiung, who is running for a legislative seat as an independent in the Jan. 12 election against a KMT- nominated candidate.

Yanng Yuan-hsun, head of the KMT's Taitung County Office, said his office was merely revoking Hsu's membership, instead of expelling him from the KMT, because Hsu already renounced his KMT membership when he declared his candidacy Nov. 17.
Hsu, 53, a former Taitung County councilor, is running against KMT nominee Justin Huang, an incumbent legislator who is seeking re-election for a third term.

Although Hsu is seen clearly as an underdog, he has managed to get the support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has not fielded its own candidate in the election. He has pledged that he will maintain good relations with the DPP government if elected.

The legislative election for the Taitung area is now a three-way race. The third candidate is a 47-year-old woman, Liu Yun-chu, who is running as a member of the Hakka Party but has not yet appeared in public.

DOC.HEADLINE: European officials urge Taiwan to tackle climate change

TEXT.P: European officials urged the Taiwanese government and businesses to start taking pragmatic measures to tackle the climate change challenge as Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions are drawing international concern.

Taiwanese officials and corporations know very well how serious the emissions are, and understand the linkages between those emissions and climate change, but neither are taking action to meet the challenge, said Frederic Laplanche, deputy head of the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) in Taipei.

"Neither of the two leading candidates in next year's presidential election has put forward specific proposals to reduce Taiwan's high -- and growing -- emissions, " said Michael Reilly, Director of the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei, in a conference discussing media coverage of the climate change issue.

"According to an opinion piece in a local newspaper last Sunday, Taiwan is now the world's third highest per capita emitter of greenhouse gases, behind only the United States and Australia, " Reilly noted, adding that there has been surprisingly little discussion of the impact of global warming on Taiwan.

Taiwan, which is not a Kyoto Protocol signatory and cannot be a signatory to the successor to the Kyoto Treaty because it is not a United Nations member, produces one percent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.

Taiwanese officials, including Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Minister Steve Chen, did not refuse to tackle the issue during discussions with European officials, but some government officials did speak against setting specific targets for cutting emissions, said Edward Dallas, head of BTCO's political and economic section.

The people of Taiwan, especially businessmen and government officials, have to understand that their actions to reduce emissions will have a short-term negative impact on business, but in the long run it is something they must do, Laplanche said.

A possible carbon tax and an import ban on countries which are seen to be "unfriendly to emission mitigation" will impact Taiwanese companies which want to trade in the European market in the future, he said.

According to an European Union (EU) public opinion poll, approximately 87 percent of EU citizens are concerned with climate change, Laplanche said, and that public support is the driving force behind the EU's determination to tackle the climate change issue head-on.

The EU has made a commitment to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 20 percent by 2020 compared to its 1990 levels and a deeper absolute reduction after the Kyoto Protocol expires in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: New employees should show competence after 9 weeks: survey

TEXT.P: The average employer expects new employees to display competence after nine weeks on the jobs, but most of them fall short of the expectation, according to the results of a survey conducted by an online job bank and released Thursday.
The human resources company, 1111.com.tw, conducted the survey of employers to learn their thoughts on the "readiness" of new employees.

The survey found that 28.06 percent of the employers expect new employers to be in top form after three months, compared with 27.71 percent who said they should need one month. On average, the employers think that it should take about 2.21 months, or 8.84 weeks for employees to display their personal best.

The survey also found that 85.44 percent of employers will consider "combat readiness" when hiring new staff. Among the qualifications considered, 43.69 percent said communication ability is important, followed by professional skills (41.74 percent) , language ability (36.41 percent) , problem solving ability (33.39 percent) and ability to work independently (28.77 percent).
On a scale of 1 to 100, new employees averaged 52.88 after nearly one year on the jobs, failing the passing grade of 60 in "readiness," the survey also found.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Details in Military Notes Led to Shift on Iran, U.S. Says
American intelligence agencies reversed their view about the status of Iran's nuclear weapons program after they obtained notes last summer from the deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the weapons development program, senior intelligence and government officials said on Wednesday.
The Wall Street Journal:Big Pharma Faces Grim Prognosis Over the next few years, the pharmaceutical business will hit a wall.
Some of the top-selling drugs in industry history will become history as patent protections expire, allowing generics to rush in at much-lower prices. Generic competition is expected to wipe $67 billion from top companies' annual U.S. sales between 2007 and 2012 as more than three dozen drugs lose patent protection. That is roughly half of the companies' combined 2007 U.S. sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign laborers in Taiwan hits new high

TEXT.P: The number of blue-collar foreign workers in Taiwan reached a new peak of 356,510 at the end of October, an increase of 5.8 percent year-on-year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.
Of that total, 50.8 percent or 181,269 work in Taiwan's industrial manufacturing sector, an increase of 7.2 percent year-on-year, DGBAS officials said.
Of those working in the industrial manufacturing sector, 36,413 work in the electronics industry, while 22,899 work in the textiles and garment industry.
The number of foreign laborers who work in the metal processing industry totaled 22,484 as of the end of October, marking a year-on-year increase of 19.7 percent, the officials said.
A total of 162,240, or 45.5 percent of blue-collar foreign workers have been working in Taiwan's service sector: a year-on-year increase of 6.2 percent.
A majority of that total, 159,713, work as nurses or caregivers. Of these, 97,600 are Indonesians and 36,489 are Vietnamese.
By nationality, Indonesians topped the list of all blue-collar foreign workers in Taiwan, at 112,094, followed by Thais, who number 88,370, and Filipinos at 86,546, according to the DGBAS officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC bill clouds legislative session

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng voiced concern Thursday that a disputed bill on the composition of the Central Election Commission (CEC) might cloud the course of the Legislative Yuan's meeting Friday.

Wang was referring to the draft CEC organic law put forth by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which has been listed by the Legislative Yuan's Procedural Committee as the No. 1 issue for discussion during Friday's session.

As the KMT-drafted law has met fierce opposition from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which form the "pan-green" camp, Wang said that he has asked the ruling and opposition parties to instead negotiate the bill's passage and change the agenda of the Friday meeting out of fear that conflict could erupt between the two sides.

In response to Wang's remarks, Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said that there will be no change to the agenda of Friday's legislative meeting and the CEC bill will be handled as scheduled according to due process.
DPP lawmakers have vowed to do whatever it takes to block the bill's passage.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Touh reiterated later the same day that all-out efforts will be made to kill the "unconstitutional" bill despite the fact the "pan-green" camp is in the minority at the Legislative Yuan.

The draft CEC organic law recently became the focal point of a verbal battle between the DPP and the KMT after the organization decided Nov. 16 to adopt a "one-step" voting format for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative election and two referendums to be held alongside.
Stating that the CEC-designed "one-step" voting format would create procedural chaos, 18 local governments controlled by the KMT said that they will insist on applying a "two-step" format.
Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus is set to call a new vote on the body at the Legislative Yuan.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said in late November that his party would do its best to push the CEC bill through the legislature before its current session adjourns late this month in an effort to maintain what they called "fair elections."
The bill failed to pass the Legislative Yuan during its last session as a result of the aggressive tactics of DPP and TSU lawmakers, including physical tussles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen County chief pessimistic about duty-free shops

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng voiced discontent Thursday with the central government over its failure to help boost local economic development, despite the passage of an amendment by the Executive Yuan to allow the opening of duty-free shops on outlying islands.

The Executive Yuan approved a measure Wednesday during its weekly meeting, authorizing the establishment of duty-free shops on Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu island, but failed to give the green light to a revision allowing for the opening of casinos on the three outlying islands.

According to Lee, the amendment is merely an electoral gambit to deceive voters ahead of the legislative and presidential polls early next year -- something he argued is a far cry from a genuine program to address the needs of local residents.

Lee said the central government has been slow to live up to its election promises, including President Chen Shui-bian's pledge to permit the opening of duty-free shops on Kinmen more than seven years ago when he first campaigned for the presidency.

To effectively improve Kinmen's economy, Lee contended, the best way is to expand the existing mini-links -- direct shipping and trade services maintained between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands with three ports in China's Fujian Province.
He cited Vice President Annette Lu as proposing that the people from Taiwan proper and China should be allowed to travel freely between the two sides via Kinmen Island.
Only crowds of people would bring business opportunities, and duty-free shops without customers are a waste, he said.
Currently, only certain categories of people, including Taiwanese business people based in Fujian province and Kinmen/Matsu residents, are permitted to freely travel across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to establish anti-vote buying centers

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will set up anti-vote buying centers at its headquarters in Taipei and party branches around the country to develop a systematic anti-vote buying mechanism, a DPP official said Thursday.
The announcement came one day after the DPP passed a resolution to set up the anti-vote buying centers at the weekly meeting of its Central Standing Committee.
The resolution is part of the party's effort to ensure fair and just legislative and presidential elections slated for Jan. 12, 2008 and March 22, 2008, respectively, the DPP official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert finds no need to prefer imported drinking water

TEXT.P: There is no need to prefer imported, bottled drinking water as local and imported products are almost identical, Consumers' Foundation Chairman Cheng Hung-jen said Thursday.

Cheng made the remarks after the foundation conducted a survey of 37 bottles of drinking water, both locally produced and imported, sold in Taipei's convenience stores, supermarkets and department stores in October and November.

According to the results of the survey, the price of one liter of bottled drinking water ranges between NT$20 and NT$160, with imports reaching an average of NT$92, while locally produced bottles cost NT$34.
The results also showed that there is no significant difference between the contents and nutrients of locally produced or imported water, Cheng added.

Some deep-sea drinking water enterprises claim that their products contain micro-nutrients, and therefore cost almost twice that of normal bottles, Cheng said, while adding that the micro-nutrients cited by entrepreneurs may be either unnecessary or present in only trace amounts.
In terms of the pH value of water, Cheng said the standard range for pH in drinking water is 6.0 to 8.5, as suggested by Environmental Protection Administration.
However, the survey found eight examples of bottled water with a pH lower than 6.0, with one even reaching 4.9, Cheng said, describing the taste of the latter as like that of vinegar.
Noting that water is only water, Cheng urged the public not to believe the exaggerated marketing claims made for bottled drinking water.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei park to open Dec. 10

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei Park in Taipei will be inaugurated Dec. 10, with local political victims of the country's 38-year martial law period expected to attend the inauguration ceremony, a Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) official said Thursday.

Noting that Dec. 10 also marks the International Human Rights Day, the CCA official said that the park will be open to the public after the inauguration ceremony and will help raise public awareness of human rights in the future.
The park was formerly a detention center holding some 130,000 political dissidents between 1968 and 1987, the official said.

During the 1970s, as human rights movements began to spring up globally, international human rights groups became aware of the detention center and started their long-term efforts to rescue Taiwanese political prisoners, the official went on.
The efforts also helped the international community come to know of Taiwan's authoritarian rule and raise their concerns, the official said.

In order to highlight this key period in Taiwan's transition to democracy, the CCA has decided to transform the detention center into a park marking the country's efforts to win recognition of human rights, the official added.

The CCA will invite local political victims of a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" of the martial law period, and families of the victims, to a series of activities at which Taiwan's government will express its appreciation and recognition of their efforts, the official said.
After the activities, the victims will also be able to meet with their supporters from Japan, Germany, and the United States for the first time over the years, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government will legally accomplish its tasks: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government will abide by the law and accomplish its tasks.

Chen's remarks came amid an ongoing dispute over the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) move to replace the gateway inscription of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late President Chiang Kai-shek.

Despite strong opposition from the opposition Kuomintang-controlled Taipei city government, the MOE closed the memorial hall complex to public access from Thursday through Saturday to facilitate renovation work, including replacing the four-character "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" inscription with another four-character inscription reading "Tzu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square" in English.

The original inscription alludes to Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main perpetrator behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under KMT rule.
After giving a speech to DPP members at a seminar held in the central county of Changhua, Chen told the press that he is gravely concerned about the dispute.
However, he said that the government will absolutely follow the law in accomplishing all it should.

Earlier in the day, a pickup van rammed into a crowd in a scuffle outside the hall, injuring five journalists and several ordinary citizens. One photojournalist was seriously injured and remains hospitalized. Anyone who resorts to violence should be condemned, Chen said.

During a speech given earlier at the seminar, Chen also spoke of the dispute, saying that no one opposed his decision to rename the Presidential Office building, formerly known as the Chieh Shou Hall.
The name "Chieh Shou" was given in celebration of the 60th birthday of Chiang, and has the connotation of "Long live Kai-shek."
Now, the MOE is encountering opposition from those who are trying to defend the "godhood" of Chiang and who are unwilling to see Chiang's divinity defied, Chen said.

Citing another example, Chen said that the government's decision to change the name of Taiwan's international airport in northern Taiwan from the Chiang Kai- shek International Airport to the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport last year also triggered protests.
However, it only took the government eight days to complete the name change of the airport, and the protests subsided, Chen said.

Chen also pointed to Spain's experience as an example and noted that bronze statues of Spain's previous dictator were all pulled down following his death, which he said is what a country often does during its transition to a democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman set to arrive Saturday for brief visit

TEXT.P: Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), is scheduled to arrive in Taipei this weekend for a brief visit, the AIT Kaohsiung branch announced Thursday in a news release.

It will be Burghardt's third visit to Taiwan since he assumed his current post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries in February 2006.

During his stay, Burghardt will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and other key political figures, including presidential candidates of Taiwan's two major political parties, the AIT press release said.

High on the list of political heavyweights Burghardt will meet during his upcoming visit are Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the March 22, 2008 presidential election, and his electoral rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, diplomatic sources said.

According to the sources, Burghardt expects to gain first-hand information about the two presidential hopefuls' policy visions and initiatives. He will also exchange views with Hsieh and Ma on the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.
Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, headed the AIT Taipei Office between 1999 and 2001. He now concurrently serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Honolulu.
The AIT, headquartered in Washington, D.C., is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Posecutors seek detention of motorist on charge of attempted murder

TEXT.P: Prosecutors have applied for court permission to detain a motorist who drove into a crowd of journalists Thursday, injuring six, outside the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall where activists and police had clashed over efforts to delete references to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, according to prosecution sources.

Prosecutors sought to have Peng Sheng-lu detained on charge of attempted murder, the sources said, adding that the Taipei District Court is still reviewing the case and had not yet returned a ruling as of the press time.

One photojournalist, identified as Wang Jui-chang of Eastern Broadcasting Co., was seriously injured in the incident and is still hospitalized, while the five other reporters suffered only minor injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 7, 2007

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday.

The weighted price index was up 80.16 points at 8,774.57 on a turnover of NT$3.77 billion (US$116.69 million) at the open. The index gained 17.46 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 8,694.41 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up against New Taiwan dollar in early trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.315 at 9: 45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.006 from Thursday.
