TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government will abide by the law and accomplish its tasks.

Chen's remarks came amid an ongoing dispute over the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) move to replace the gateway inscription of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate the late President Chiang Kai-shek.

Despite strong opposition from the opposition Kuomintang-controlled Taipei city government, the MOE closed the memorial hall complex to public access from Thursday through Saturday to facilitate renovation work, including replacing the four-character "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" inscription with another four-character inscription reading "Tzu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square" in English.

The original inscription alludes to Chiang, who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main perpetrator behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under KMT rule.
After giving a speech to DPP members at a seminar held in the central county of Changhua, Chen told the press that he is gravely concerned about the dispute.
However, he said that the government will absolutely follow the law in accomplishing all it should.

Earlier in the day, a pickup van rammed into a crowd in a scuffle outside the hall, injuring five journalists and several ordinary citizens. One photojournalist was seriously injured and remains hospitalized. Anyone who resorts to violence should be condemned, Chen said.

During a speech given earlier at the seminar, Chen also spoke of the dispute, saying that no one opposed his decision to rename the Presidential Office building, formerly known as the Chieh Shou Hall.
The name "Chieh Shou" was given in celebration of the 60th birthday of Chiang, and has the connotation of "Long live Kai-shek."
Now, the MOE is encountering opposition from those who are trying to defend the "godhood" of Chiang and who are unwilling to see Chiang's divinity defied, Chen said.

Citing another example, Chen said that the government's decision to change the name of Taiwan's international airport in northern Taiwan from the Chiang Kai- shek International Airport to the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport last year also triggered protests.
However, it only took the government eight days to complete the name change of the airport, and the protests subsided, Chen said.

Chen also pointed to Spain's experience as an example and noted that bronze statues of Spain's previous dictator were all pulled down following his death, which he said is what a country often does during its transition to a democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman set to arrive Saturday for brief visit

TEXT.P: Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), is scheduled to arrive in Taipei this weekend for a brief visit, the AIT Kaohsiung branch announced Thursday in a news release.

It will be Burghardt's third visit to Taiwan since he assumed his current post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries in February 2006.

During his stay, Burghardt will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and other key political figures, including presidential candidates of Taiwan's two major political parties, the AIT press release said.

High on the list of political heavyweights Burghardt will meet during his upcoming visit are Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the March 22, 2008 presidential election, and his electoral rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, diplomatic sources said.

According to the sources, Burghardt expects to gain first-hand information about the two presidential hopefuls' policy visions and initiatives. He will also exchange views with Hsieh and Ma on the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.
Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, headed the AIT Taipei Office between 1999 and 2001. He now concurrently serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Honolulu.
The AIT, headquartered in Washington, D.C., is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 7, or the 28th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should contribute to addressing global warming: Kofi Annan

TEXT.P: Former U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan said Thursday that although Taiwan is outside the U.N. framework, it should still contribute to addressing the problem of global warming.
Annan now heads the Geneva-based non-governmental Global Humanitarian Forum, whose current theme is the humanitarian impact of climate change on the poor and other vulnerable groups.

In an informal meeting with members of the press in Geneva, Annan was asked by a CNA reporter to express his views on the fact that Taiwan, which is the world's 22nd largest emitter of greenhouse gases, is not a member of the United Nations and therefore not a part of global cooperative efforts under the U.N. framework to fight climate change, and whether the forum can facilitate the participation of non-U.N. member states in the global effort.

In response, Annan said that on the political side, Taiwan has been trying very hard to join the United Nations. "You tried almost every year when I was there, and I know the efforts continue with my successor, " adding that this is an issue he would leave for the United Nations to deal with.
"But on the substance of whether a country like Taiwan should become engaged in both mitigation and adaptation, I would say yes, " he added.

He further said that according to reports, there are over 200 countries, more than the total number of U.N. members which stands at 192, participating in the U.N. Climate Change Conference in Bali, Indonesia, because these countries realize whether or not they belong to the United Nations or other world bodies, "we are living in the same world and have the possibility to do something about the environment."
Annan added that in facing climate change, one can take the right actions to deal with the problem without focusing on the issue of participation in certain groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. obliged to make clear its position on referendum: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/07 13:18:48 (By Chiehyu Lin, Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has an obligation to let the Taiwan people clearly understand its position on Taiwan's planned referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, a U.S. State Department official said Thursday.

The United States has been doing so on various public occasions and will continue to do so, said Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, during a press briefing with Taiwanese media in the U.S. capital.
Christensen said he believes the U.S. move has been successful because the Taiwan people have understood the position of the United States and are taking it seriously.

Stressing that the United States honors democracy and has no intention of dictating what Taiwan should or should not do, Christensen said the United States respects the wisdom of the Taiwan people and believes they will choose a policy that is favorable to Taiwan and cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability through the democratic process.

Christensen made the remarks when asked to comment on issues surrounding the planned referendum, including President Chen Shui-bian's latest remarks that U.S. opposition to the referendum could trigger an emotional backlash from the Taiwan people and could be unfavorable to relations between the two countries.

Christensen reiterated that both Taiwan and China should avoid taking any "needlessly provocative actions" so as not to escalate cross-strait tensions and that the referendum is just an example of such actions.

While the United States is opposed to any unilateral actions by either side to change the cross-strait status quo, the U.N. bid referendum is obviously designed to seek changes to the status quo, he said.

According to Christensen, the referendum is inconsistent with Chen's promise that he will not change Taiwan's official name during his term, and by implying that the referendum will provide the Taiwan people a chance to express their opinions on whether Taiwan should unify with China, Chen is also going against his pledge that he will not promote a referendum on the unification versus independence issue during his term.

Calling the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated referendum "unwise, " Christensen said the referendum is not only dangerous and provocative, but it will also scare away potential friends who might help Taiwan, including the United States.

On Chen's claim that it will help prompt the United States to change its "one China" policy if the referendum is passed, Christensen said the U.S. government has no plans to alter the decades-long policy because it has been proven helpful in maintaining cross-strait peace and favorable to Taiwan.

Responding to Christensen's statement, Taiwan's representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, said China's continued isolation of Taiwan in the international community is the main cause behind cross-strait instability.

Wu stressed that Taiwan is a democratic country and that its people have the right to express their opinions through various democratic means, including referendums, adding that the U.N. bid referendum does not involve changing the country's official name or address the unification versus independence issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT Red Line's inauguration to be delayed

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) apologized Friday for failing to deliver on its promise to inaugurate one of the two lines of the mass rapid transit (MRT) system in the southern Taiwan port city by the end of this year.
At a news conference in the city, KRTC President Fan Chen-po and other ranking officials gave a deep bow and explained why they will be unable to meet the public's expectations.
Fan said that the delay is due mainly to the fact that construction work on barrier-free facilities at various stations and renovation work around the stations have not been proceeding fast enough.
As a result, the KRTC was unable to carry out the initial inspection as scheduled on Dec. 7 in order to inaugurate the Red Line before the end of the year, Fan said.
He vowed to pull out all stops to complete the construction work, but he did not say when the line will be inaugurated.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has said repeatedly that the Red Line of the MRT system, on which construction began in October 2001, would be inaugurated in late 2007. But KRTC Chairman Lin Wen-yuan called on the mayor Thursday night to report to her the reasons for the delay in inaugurating the line.
The Kaohsiung MRT system's other line, the Orange Line, is expected to be inaugurated in late 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. to continue to supply Taiwan with defensive weapons: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/07 13:50:10 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States will continue to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons based on the Taiwan Relations Act as well as Taiwan's long-term defense needs, a U.S. State Department official said Thursday.

Speaking during a press conference with members of Taiwan media outlets, Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said that despite China's discontent at the United States' military sales to Taiwan, the United States will continue to carry out this policy, in the belief that maintaining Taiwan's solid defensive capabilities is conducive to maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
As to China's concern, Christensen said that the United States values and listens to China's opinions, but it makes its decisions based on its own assessment and analysis.
Meanwhile, Christensen expressed Washington's expectation that Taiwan's presidential election slated for March 2008 will bring about a new opportunity to improve cross-strait relations.

Noting that the United States supports Taiwan's democratization and shows no favor to any Taiwan presidential candidate, he said the United States respects whatever decision the Taiwan people make and hopes that the March 22, 2008 presidential election will bring about an opportunity for cross-strait dialogue.

Christensen added that he has noted the remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian recently that "cross-strait dialogue would be impossible no matter who is elected in the next presidential election, " but the United States stills attaches great expectations that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue. He further said he encourages both Taiwan and China not to forsake any opportunity that may lead to talks between the two sides.
He also urged the Beijing leadership to engage in dialogue with Taiwan's democratically elected leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four killed in highway accident

TEXT.P: Four people were killed in a car accident on freeway No. 3 near the Chia-yi interchange in southern Taiwan early Friday morning, police officers from the Tainan squad of the National Highway Police Bureau said.
The accident happened when a car traveling southbound swerved into the northbound lane and collided head-on with another car, the officers said.
The body of the driver of the car heading southbound and those of the three people in the other car were all charred by the fire resulting from the accident, the police said.
A preliminary investigation revealed that driver who caused the accident was from Mei-shan township in Chiayi County and the other victims were from Taichung, the officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Minister condemns violence after cameraman injured

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng condemned violence and expressed his condolences Friday to the photojournalist seriously injured by a pickup truck in front of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall on Thursday.

Tu said he feels sorry about the occurrence of the tragic incident, in which ETTV cameraman Wang Jui-chang was run over by a pickup while covering the scuffle between supporters and opponents of the education ministry's decision to replace the inscription on the main gate of the hall.

The minister attributed the accident to the Taipei city government's interference and boycott of the decision to replace the inscription, adding that the city government's provisional designation of the hall as a historic site within a day after the ministry made the decision "is nothing but a political maneuver."

The minister said those who oppose the ministry's decision are people who cannot sever their ties with the past, adding that "we are not asking them to do so, but instead to march toward the boulevard of democracy and freedom."

"We should learn a lesson from Thursday's accident, especially as it happened in a democratic and free land, since opinions do vary in democratic politics, and any view should be expressed in a peaceful way," Tu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA expresses serious concern about China's ADIZ plan in strait

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed serious concern Friday about China's plan to designate an air defense identification zone (ADIZ) within the Taiwan Strait.
MOFA officials said China's plan will undermine the stability in the Taiwan Strait and international aviation safety.

The ministry is closely watching developments related to China's plan and will join hands with major countries to express its stance to the International Civil Aviation Organization and China, the officials said.
The ministry will also solicit support for Taiwan in taking necessary action to safeguard peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, they added.

The officials made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian's meeting with U.S. Rep. Eni Faleomavaega, who serves as the chairman of the House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia, the Pacific and the Global Environment.

The president told Faleomavaega that China's plan to designate an ADIZ within the Taiwan Strait, which will prevent the United States and Japan from gathering military intelligence on China, and to inaugurate a new air route west of the median of the Taiwan Strait, will destabilize the peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen expressed the hope that the United States and Japan will address the serious issue and China's "irrational move."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum unrelated to independence: presidential aide

TEXT.P: The upcoming referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan will be a referendum rejecting unification with China, rather than one pursuing independence for Taiwan, a Presidential Office official said Friday.

Lin Chia-lung, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Taiwan refuses to be downgraded to the status of being a part of China and will continue to push for the referendum despite U.S. opposition.

With 2.72 million people having signed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's referendum petition, Lin said Taiwan expects 10 million people to take part in the referendum -- slated to be held alongside the March 22, 2008 presidential election -- and is confident that the referendum will pass.

Lin made the remarks in response to a statement by Thomas Christensen, U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, that by implying that the referendum will provide the Taiwan people with a chance to express their opinions on whether Taiwan should unify with China, President Chen Shui-bian is going against his promise not to promote a referendum on the unification versus independence issue during his term.
Lin stressed that the referendum is part of Taiwan's democracy and is not to be decided by any foreign government officials.
"This is an internal affair of Taiwan. We will listen to the reaction of our friends but will not waver in our determination to promote Taiwan's democracy," Lin said.
He said Taiwan understands and respects Washington's position on the issue and will continue to communicate with the U.S. government.

Also Friday, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials reiterated that the U.N. bid referendum has not violated President Chen's "four noes" pledges and that the ministry will continue to communicate with the U.S. side to try to sort out their differences.
The officials said China, which has adopted various measures targeting Taiwan in recent years, is the party that is attempting to change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: English-language environment approval rating hits 61.7%: poll

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to create an English-friendly environment have borne some fruit, with more foreign visitors expressing satisfaction with Taiwan's English-language living environment, an official said Friday.

The number of foreign visitors giving a positive review of the government's English-language information services has also increased, the official with the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said.
The official was referring to the results of a RDEC-organized survey of short- term visitors and long-term foreign residents to explore their appraisal of Taiwan's English-language environment.
The survey was conducted between July and October, with a total of 1,068 valid samples being collected from short-term visitors and 1,080 from foreign residents.

Among the short-term visitors, 61.7 percent expressed satisfaction with the local English-language living environment, up 3.8 percentage points from the level recorded in a similar poll conducted last year.

As for foreigners who have lived in Taiwan for six months or longer, only 39.7 percent gave the thumbs-up to the overall local English-language environment, marking a slight increase of 0.5 percentage points from the year-earlier level.

Asked about their assessment of the government's English-language information services, 50.3 percent of the short-term visitors surveyed gave a positive review, up 3.2 percentage points from last year's poll.

According to the RDEC official, all government agencies have made progress in improving their English speaking environment. But he acknowledged that there is still ample room for improvement in the private sector's English speaking environment which foreigners tend to have contact with on a regular basis in their everyday lives, including public transport, retail outlets and tourist site services, to name a few.

Noting that the private-sector English speaking environment has traditionally received a low approval rating, the official said the RDEC will give priority to helping the private business community improve their English literacy and proficiency.

In addition, the RDEC has launched a certification logo program for quality English services. A total of 376 private companies, including therapeutic goods shops, hotels, restaurants, food stores, taxi companies and businesses in other related sectors, have been granted the certification logo to prove the quality of their English services.
Over the next two years, the official said, the RDEC will continue to promote the logo certification program in the hopes that the number of certified companies increases to 1,000.

The RDEC is scheduled to hold an English-friendly environment promotion fair at the Taipei World Trade Center Dec. 11-13. In addition to commending government agencies that have made outstanding progress in creating an English-friendly environment, the official said, a quality English services certification logo presentation ceremony will also be held to honor private shop owners during the fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan rep praises Germany's 'value-based' foreign policy

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Germany, You Ching, has publicly praised Germany's "value-based" foreign policy and expressed the hope that German Chancellor Angela Merkel can meet with President Chen Shui-bian in the near future.
You voiced the hope in an interview with the Berlin Daily which was published in the newspaper's Dec. 4 issue.
You said that as the popularly elected president of Taiwan, Chen keenly hopes to be able to visit Germany and other European countries either in his private capacity or as Taiwan's head of state.

However, Eckart von Klaeden, the foreign affairs spokesman for Germany's ruling party -- the Christin Democratic Union (CDU) -- said Thursday in an interview with "Deutsche Welle" (Voice of Germany) that because of Germany's "one China" policy, a visit by Taiwan's head of state would be impossible at this time.

Touching on Taiwan's upcoming referendum on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Klaedon described it as a move toward independence and urged Taiwan to avoid taking actions that could fuel tensions between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
He also reiterated that cross-strait problems should be solved peacefully.

There has been a noticeable cooling off in relations between China and Germany since Merkel met with the Dalai Lama in Berlin in late September, with China canceling a number of high-level talks with German officials since the visit.

Despite China's objections and criticism from within her own country, Merkel did not regret meeting with the Tibetan spiritual leader, claiming that doing so was in line with Germany's "value-based" foreign policy which includes protecting human rights and safeguarding the country's economic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 27.97 points, or 0.32 percent, to close at 8,722.38.
The bourse opened at 8,774.57 and fluctuated between 8,804.93 and 8,722.38 during trading. A total of 4.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.08 billion (US$3.56 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, and construction issues at 0.5 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down 0.5 percent and cement stocks dropping 0.1 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 872, with 471 stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 32 points to close at 8,706 with 47,784 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 28 points to finish at 8,709, with 542 contracts traded, while March futures rose 41 points to close at 8,761, with 13 contract transactions. June futures moved up 76 points to finish at 8,810, with one contract traded, while September futures gained 13 points to close at 8,550, with 25 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,738 for December, 8,737 for January, 8,720 for March, 8,734 for June and 8,537 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures dropped 2.2 points to close at 361.5, with 2,647 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 2.1 points to finish at 361, with 23 contract transactions. September TE futures increased 1.55 points to close at 364.5, with 26 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures gained 3.6 points to close at 976.8, with 3,142 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 3.6 points to finish at 976, with 83 contracts traded. March TF futures rose 12 points to close at 990, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies Taiwan closing door to interactions with China

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung denied Friday that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has adopted a "closed-door" policy on cross-strait relations, saying that the criticism was absolutely off-base.

Addressing the opening of a symposium on the 20th anniversary of the inauguration of cross-strait exchanges, Chang said the DPP administration has continued to guide the Taiwanese people to engage in bilateral exchanges with their counterparts in China based on the principles of sovereignty, democracy, peace and equality.

Chang said that since 1987, when Taiwan cleared the way for its people to travel to the Chinese mainland to visit relatives, cross-strait exchanges have increased from "dots" to "facets" with massive numbers of people from the two sides engaging in economic, trade, cultural and tourism exchanges over the past 20 years -- a development that has structurally changed cross-strait relations.

Changes in the political climate within Taiwan and China have also resulted in new situations in terms of the development of cross-strait relations, Chang said, adding that in recent years, the DPP administration has continued to promote cross-strait interactions on the premise that Taiwan's distinctive identity should be its top concern.

He quoted government figures as indicating that over the past 20 years, people from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have made 47 million visits to the other side, while two-way trade has topped US$640 billion and investment by Taiwanese companies in China has reached US$62 billion.

Meanwhile, Chang said, Taiwan has continued to extend olive branches to China, hoping that the two sides could resume peaceful dialogue, but the leadership in Beijing has not relented in its persistent political, military and diplomatic suppression of Taiwan.

The Chinese National People's Congress even passed an Anti-Secession Law in 2005 targeting Taiwan, which codifies China's long-standing threat to attack Taiwan if it appears that Taiwan is seeking formal, independent statehood, Chang said, adding that such unfriendly schemes have been major obstacles to the development of cross-strait relations.

Quoting the results of a public opinion poll conducted by the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Chang said that over 60 percent of Taiwan's citizens believe that current exchange activities across the Taiwan Strait might be detrimental to the interests of Taiwan, while 70 percent of respondents have a poor impression of Chinese authorities.

Chang called on both sides to employ "a little more contact and trust and a little less suppression and misconception" to improve bilateral ties, saying that only by engaging in exchanges and dialogue with goodwill and sincerity can a mutually beneficial result be created.
Scores of China hands and geopolitical strategists from the United States, Japan and the host nation, Taiwan, are taking part in the two-day symposium at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Organized by the Straits Exchange Foundation, the symposium is aimed at tackling issues including economic, social and legal relations across the Taiwan Strait; cross-strait negotiations and dialogue; international factors involved in cross- strait relations; cross-strait economic, trade and high-tech exchanges and derivative problems; cross-strait educational and cultural exchanges and derivative problems; as well as the prospectives for cross-strait relations over the next 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recalled Starbucks mugs not marketed in Taiwan: Starbucks Taiwan

TEXT.P: Starbucks coffee mugs marketed in Taiwan are entirely ceramic, and none use plastic handles like those recently recalled in the United States due to a burn hazard, executives of President Starbucks Coffee Corp. said here Friday.

President Starbucks Coffee is a joint venture company between the Seattle- headquartered Starbucks Coffee Co., one of the world's largest coffee companies, and Taiwan's Uni-President Group, created in 1998 to handle operations on the island.

In response to a media inquiry regarding a news release from the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) , which announced Thursday a voluntary recall of Starbucks coffee mugs with plastic handles and a stainless base, Taiwan's Starbucks managers underlined that the problematic China-made mugs have not been imported into Taiwan.
They added that many of Starbucks' products are only marketed on U.S. soil, including the mug recently blamed for several minor burn incidents in the U.S.

According to the CPSC online news release, the white plastic handle of the recalled mugs, printed with "Starbucks" logo, can become detached when the mug is filled with hot liquids, posing a minor burn hazard to consumers.
Starbucks has received 23 reports of handles detaching from the mug, including nine that resulted in minor burns.

The CPSC advised consumers to immediately stop using the mugs and contact Starbucks for instructions on returning the cups for a full refund. Starbucks is also offering a free beverage as an incentive to have consumers return the recalled mugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's public most dissatisfied with economic rights: survey

TEXT.P: The general public in Taiwan is most dissatisfied with the country's economic rights situation, according to the results of an annual human rights survey released Friday.

The survey, conducted by the Taiwan-based Chinese Association for Human Rights, targets 10 aspects of human rights: aboriginal rights, children's rights, cultural and educational rights, disabled persons' rights, economic rights, elders' rights, environmental rights, judicial rights, labor rights, political rights and women's rights.
The survey has two parts: one carried out among the general public and the other among special groups and elites.

The results show that 69.8 percent of the public holds a negative view of Taiwan's economic rights situation, and 64.6 percent of the respondents think the situation is worse this year than last year.
Among all aspects surveyed, only aboriginal rights and elders' rights received positive ratings from more than 50 percent of the public.

On the part of the survey carried out among special groups and elites, which uses a five-point scale, cultural and educational rights received the highest rating, followed by economic rights, women's rights, labor rights and environmental rights.
Children's rights, judicial rights, political rights, disabled persons' rights and the rights of elders received low-to-average ratings, with aboriginal rights performing most poorly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local firms accelerate China-bound investment

TEXT.P: Many Taiwanese companies are accelerating their China-bound investment before the implementation of a new tax system in China next year, under which Taiwanese firms may no longer enjoy preferential tax rates, a government official said Friday.

According to an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , China will equalize the income tax rates of domestic and foreign enterprises starting Jan. 1, 2008, and will only offer preferential tax policies to companies dedicated to high-tech, environmental protection and energy-saving fields.

To cash in on preferential tax rates currently offered to Taiwanese companies with operations in China, many domestic firms are presenting applications in a rush of new investment, or increasing their paid-in capital in their present operations in China.

Only on Thursday, MOEA's Investment Commission approved a total of 15 China- bound investment projects worth more than US$350 million, including those from such information technology (IT) and petrochemical giants as Hon Hai Technology Group, Compal Electronics Inc. and Chang Chun Group.
Among the 15 projects, 12 involve an increase of capital investment by Taiwanese enterprises already operating in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA approves 4 inbound investment projects

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has approved four inbound investment projects by overseas Chinese and foreigners worth a total of US$333.1 million, an MOEA official said Friday.

In the year to date, cumulative investments by overseas Chinese and foreigners has reached US$13.26 billion, and the amount through the entire year is very likely to hit a new high, the official said.
Total investments by overseas Chinese and foreigners in 2006 was US$13.96 billion, the official said.

Among the four inbound projects, Holland's Cooperative Meadowstream Investment W.A. will invest US$143.27 million in Chung Hsi Co., and Cooperative Silverdale United Enterprise W.A. will invest in Hsiung Ho Co. The investments in the two companies will be used to buy private equity in Ta Chong Bank, the official said.
Additionally, Citibank Taiwan's U.S. parent will increase its stake in its Taiwan branch by US$61.73 million, the official added.
The MOEA's Investment Commission also approved another 15 China-bound investment projects, one to invest in Hong Kong and Macau, and another involving investment elsewhere, the official went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-inmates to be allowed to change names

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved the third reading Friday of an amendment to an act governing people's names, allowing ex-inmates to apply to change their names, if desired, three years after they complete serving their prison terms.

The amendment, proposed by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ken-te, reduced the required waiting period for ex-inmates who wish to change their names after they do their time from the current five years to three years.
The reduction will help these people to return to society more easily after they serve their jail terms, Chen said.

Meanwhile, the amendment also stipulates that indigenous people -- whose family names were wrongly registered when their aboriginal family names were rendered into Han Chinese decades ago -- could apply with the Ministry of the Interior to rectify their family names.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous intellectual property rights to be protected

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved the third reading Friday of legislation governing the protection of aboriginal intellectual property rights.

Infringement of the traditional indigenous intellectual property rights, including music pieces, songs, lyrics, and other creative masterpieces, could result in compensation claims of up to NT$6 million (US$185,758), according to the newly-passed act.

Victims of infringement could ask for compensation ranging from NT$50,000 to NT$3 million, but compensation could be as high as NT$6 million if the infringement is found to be "extremely serious, " the act stipulates.

The act also stipulates that if the indigenous intellectual properties are acquired by an aboriginal tribe or community, members of the tribe or community should establish a common foundation to manage the profits generated from those properties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City clinches 2007 World Leadership Award
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/07 17:39:19 (By Jennifer Huang and Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Taichung City clinched the 2007 World Leadership Award in the category of arts and culture in London Thursday, according to the awards organizer.

The World Leadership Awards were first organized in 2005 at the World Leadership Forum in London. The awards are an instrument to identify exceptional leadership in cities around the world and to inspire other cities facing similar challenges, according to the organizer.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, at the head of a delegation of city government officials, personally briefed those judging his city Thursday in an attempt to ensure that Taichung received the best possible score.
Taichung ended up beating Lima, the capital city of Peru, and Albuquerque, in the eastern United States, to win the award in the category of arts and culture.

Taichung captured the award for excellence in providing city citizens with superb art and cultural facilities, as well as coming up with far-sighted blueprints for encouraging such activities. Another reason for the city earning the award is a staggering increase in the number of city citizens taking part in art and culture events over the past five years, the organizer said.

Expressing his pride in seeing the city earn this international award, Hu reaffirmed in an interview with Taiwan's Central News Agency later the same day that he will continue his efforts to promote arts and culture in the central Taiwan city during the last two years of his tenure.
Taichung is the first Taiwanese city to win the award since their inauguration in 2005.

The World Leadership Awards are presented to cities whose leaders have shown phenomenal imagination, foresight or flexibility in a number of key fields -- especially cities that have reversed negative trends, thrown off traditional images, and provided positive examples and inspiration to others, according to the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Senate panel deals blow to Bush on CO2
U.S. negotiators at a climate conference came under mounting pressure Thursday to back mandatory caps on greenhouse gases after legislation to reduce global warming passed a crucial test in the U.S Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow TimesGSiloviki Clash in Storchak Affair
A turf war between rival siloviki factions over the corruption charges against Deputy Finance Minister Sergei Storchak widened Thursday as the Investigative Committee threatened the Prosecutor General's Office with legal action. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC member suggests postponing referendums

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) member Chao Shu-chien proposed Friday postponing two referendums slated to be held alongside with the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative election to avert chaos arising from the combination of the polls.
Chao, a CEC member recommended by the opposition People First Party (PFP) , made the comments in a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

According to Chao, he will propose, in a CEC meeting next Wednesday, postponing the two referendums until Jan. 13 or Jan. 19 as a means of dissolving a fierce dispute regarding the voting format adopted for the polls.

Another CEC member, Liu Kuang-hua, recommended by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , has endorsed his proposal, Chao said, adding that he and Liu are set to boycott the Wednesday meeting if his proposal is again vetoed by other members.
The current 17 CEC members were designated by the premier and approved by president -- a composition which is strongly opposed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP.

As a more complex "single-member constituency, two-vote" system will be implemented for the first time in the coming legislative election, the two referendums should not be called simultaneously so as to avoid additional woes, he argued, explaining that relevant laws do not mandate that referendums be held the same day alongside a national election.
In response to Chao's initiative, the CEC said it fully respects the rights of any individual member to freely air his or her views.

A war over the voting format has being raging between the central government and KMT-controlled local governments since the CEC decided Nov. 16 to adopt a "one- step" format, under which voters will receive two ballots for the legislative election and another two for the referendums from two desks before casting them into four separate boxes.

The 18 KMT-controlled governments insist on applying a "two-step" voting format, which would see voters receiving two legislative ballots and casting them in the first step before proceeding to the second stop to vote in the two referendums.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, closing at NT$32.309.
A total of US$623 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.306 and fluctuated between NT$32.295 and NT$32.348.

DOC.HEADLINE: Let people decide whether to keep the plague: MOE official

TEXT.P: An education official suggested Friday that a referendum be held to determine whether the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall should be renamed the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" and the inscription on the gateway to the hall should be changed from the original Chinese characters "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" to "Tzu You Kuang Chang" which means "Liberty Square".

Chuang Kuo-jung, chief secretary of the Ministry of Education, made the suggestion after he was blasted for directing workers to remove the plagues reading "Ta chung Chih Chen" and "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall."

Chuang mentioned that the previous Kuomintang (KMT) government built the landmark building in commemoration of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, who was also the KMT's top leader, without consulting the people.

"Since Taiwan is now a democratic country, we can hold a referendum to let people express their opinions on the renaming issue, " Chuang said, adding that the referendum can be held either alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections or the March 22 presidential election.

Noting that the Ministry of Education's decision to re-designate the building as the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall'" and the change of the inscription on the gateway to "Liberty Square" is aimed at highlighting the values of democracy and freedom, Chuang said he will fully respect the outcome of the proposed referendum.

DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGInterest cut boosts the mortgage payers
Mortgage payers received a welcome boost to their finances yesterday when the Bank of England cut interest rates for the first time in more than two years, and signalled more cuts early next year.

The Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives in the agency's custody, a step it took in the midst of Congressional and legal scrutiny about its secret detention program, according to current and former government officials.
The Wall Street Journal: Battle Lines Form Over Mortgage Plan
In unveiling a plan to help more than one million struggling homeowners, the Bush administration and the mortgage industry have embarked on a controversial project: picking winners and losers from the rubble of the subprime-mortgage meltdown.
