President Bush should immediately commute the prison sentences of two former U.S. Border Patrol agents convicted in the shooting of a drug- smuggling suspect, says the chairman of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group positive about better protection of new immigrants

TEXT.P: A local human rights watch group praised Friday progress made in providing better protection to new immigrants and HIV-AIDS patients, but criticized the government's inaction on preserving a sanatorium in Taipei county.
The Taiwan Association for Human Rights made the remarks as it unveiled its selection of the top 10 human rights news stories of 2007 ahead of International Human Rights Day, which falls on Dec. 10.

At the top of the list of 10 news stories is the government's foot-dragging in designating the Losheng Sanatorium in Hsinchuang, Taipei County, as an historic site and the preservation of it, despite the sanatorium's having applied for such a designation since 2001.

This is particularly ridiculous in light of the fact that the Council for Cultural Affairs named the 27-year-old National Taiwan Democracy Hall in Taipei City as an historic site after only a few days in order to give the central government the upper hand in its dispute with the Taipei City Government, said the association.

The Losheng Sanatorium, a hospital for lepers, was constructed in the 1930s during the Japanese colonial period. There have been ongoing debates and protests over the government's plans to replace Losheng Sanatorium with a mass rapid transport depot.

Other human rights news stories include the recent passage of an amendment to the immigration law which stipulates better protection for abused foreign spouses and foreign laborers in labor-management disputes.

The passage of regulations on HIV prevention and the protection of HIV patients were also cited. The regulations protect the human rights of HIV patients, expand their access to nursing and protection to ensure the forced relocation of institutions accommodating HIV patients will no longer take place.

Other stories making the top 10 list are the leaks of the personal information of tuberculosis patients barred by the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health from taking long-haul flights due to a flawed computer system and the indictment of several aboriginal people in Smangus in Hsinchu county for picking up windfall wood, which is a tradition of the tribal people.

Other human rights news stories include an immigration official abusing foreign laborers in detention centers, closed-door environmental protection assessments, the retrial of the controversial "Hsichi trio" murder case, and a second year in which the death penalty was not carried out.

Rounding out the top 10 is a "Taiwan Biobank" program launched by Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research institute, in November, which the association criticized for rendering people as genetic "guinea pigs" and infringing on their privacy.

The program targets the residents in Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan in southern Taiwan, and Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli in northern Taiwan, and seeks blood specimens in hopes of unraveling mechanisms responsible for the nation's 10 top causes of death and 20 major diseases.

Meanwhile, in view of the two major elections to be held in early 2008, the association has sent out questionnaires to all candidates taking part in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election to learn about their views on such issues as aboriginal people, gender, immigration, and environment, hoping to collect the information as a reference for voters in making their choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 counterfeit toys seized in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: Law enforcement agents raided a warehouse in Kaohsiung Friday and seized more than 10,000 counterfeit "Doraemon" and "Hello Kitty" toys and collectibles with a retail value of over NT$32 million (US$1 million).

A spokesman for the Special Police Corps in Kaohsiung said a task force formed by its officers and a mobile unit of the Coast Guard Administration in southern Pingtung County stormed the warehouse and confiscated the pirated goods.
They arrested Ku Chi-wen, 39, the owner of the goods, and referred him to the Public Prosecutors Office of the Kaohsiung District Court.

According to the spokesman, the task force had placed Ku under surveillance after receiving tips that he is a wholesale supplier of counterfeit goods to the market in southern Taiwan and owns a large warehouse in the southern port city.
The two Japanese brands are both trademarks that are well-known throughout the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major powers' discord with China over Resolution 2758 'unexpected'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has said that the open opposition of the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Australia to China's misinterpretation of the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 is "unexpected".

Chen made the remarks Wednesday while meeting with permanent representatives to the United Nations from Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including The Gambia, Malawi, Nicaragua, the St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Tuvalu, Belize, and the Dominican Republic.
During the meeting, Chen said that Taiwan's U.N. membership bid under the name Taiwan this year unexpectedly resulted in the public exposure of China's misinterpretation of Resolution No. 2758.
China claimed that under the terms of Resolution No. 2758, Taiwan is a part of China and, as a result, Taiwan has no right to join the U.N.
However, Chen said that the 153-word resolution does not mention "Taiwan" at all.
"The U.N. resolution neither deals with Taiwan's representation in the U.N., nor does it say that Taiwan is a part or province of the PRC," Chen said.

The United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Australia have all openly expressed disagreement with China's misinterpretation of the resolution, Chen said, describing the disagreement as an "unexpected fruit."

The disagreement further encourages the people of Taiwan in their belief that Taiwan is a sovereign country that does not belong to the PRC, Chen said, noting that there is no doubt that Taiwan has the right to join the U.N.

In addition, Chen said that thanks to the allies' efforts to promote Taiwan's U.N.-membership bid this year at a number of U.N. meetings, 140 countries took four hours and 15 minutes to voice their opinions over Taiwan's U.N.-membership application at a General Assembly session that held Sept. 21.
Offering his great appreciation for the allies' staunch support, Chen said that Taiwan will continue to pursue U.N. representation.

DOC.HEADLINE: President `cannot resist' referendum on U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Friday that the nation's planned referendum to apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is a movement from the grassroots and that he cannot buck the trend.

Chen said that 100,000 people initiated the referendum proposal and that a petition to that effect has since collected 2.72 million signatures, which he described as different from a "defensive referendum" he initiated in 2004.
"The president will not be able to resist, deny or overturn the will of the people," Chen said.
He also said that the "U.N. bid referendum will not be retracted or changed," adding that he is confident that it will be passed.
Chen was responding to a U.S. official's remarks a day earlier that reiterated U.S. opposition to Taiwan's planned referendum.

Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, called the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated referendum "unwise." He also said the referendum is not only dangerous and provocative but will also scare away potential friends who might help Taiwan, including the United States.
Chen said he "appreciates" U.S. concern about the planned referendum, which will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.
Addressing concern in the international community about what "comes next after the referendum," he said that it should not worry.
"We only want to express to the world the will of the people of joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan. We hope the world will hear the voice of the Taiwan people," he said.
On widespread international opinion that the U.N. bid might change the status quo, Chen said the status quo is that Taiwan is a sovereign state and that its sovereignty lies with the people.
Taiwan is not part of China or one of its provinces, and the fact is now more clear to the international community, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar hopes plaque dispute opened for public discussion

TEXT.P: The overheated dispute between people with different political stances on a gateway plaque over the past week should be brought up for public discussion, said Kao Yung-kuang, the project leader of a comprehensive survey on human rights in Taiwan.

Kao, who is the dean of the National Chengchi University College of Social Sciences, said he thinks Taiwan's political rights ratings can only be improved through democratic practices dissolving political disputes through public discussion.
Kao made the remarks while releasing the results of the 2007 human rights survey conducted by the Taiwan-based Chinese Association for Human Rights.

The survey targets 11 aspects of human rights: aboriginal rights, children's rights, cultural and educational rights, disabled persons' rights, economic rights, elders' rights, environmental rights, judicial rights, labor rights, political rights and women's rights.

Among the surveyed general public, 42.3 percent of the respondents hold positive views of Taiwan's political rights situation while 36.8 percent thinks the situation negative and 38.1 percent believes the situation has deteriorated over the past year.
Generally speaking, Kao said the survey shows that Taiwanese people recognize the country's achievements in pursuing democracy and freedom and its efforts to protect basic human rights.
However, he noted that the country was seen to perform poorly in terms of equal rights protection, assuming a neutral political stance, and maintaining a separation between party and government.
Kao said he thinks in a country with true democratic practices, a widely- disputed public issue should be publicly discussed in an in-depth and comprehensive manner.

Speaking of the recent scuffle between the central government and the Taipei city government over a controversial plan to renovate the main gate of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park, previously called the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, in Taipei, Kao suggested putting the issue to a series of public discussions as neither the central nor local governments are able to unilaterally impose a solution.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman given 3 years for blackmailing former SEF chairman

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court sentenced a woman to three years in prison Friday on charges of extortion and intimidation against the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Chang Yi-hua was previously sentenced to two and half years by the Shihlin District Court on the same charges and Friday's increased sentence was the result of her appeal to the High Court.

The court ruling noted that Chang, in collaboration with her mother Teng Hsiang- mei, extorted over NT$200 million (US$6.17 million) from Koo and his family between 1994 and 2004 by claiming that Chang was Koo's illegitimate daughter and threatening to expose him.

Teng was previously sentenced to five years by the District Court. Her High Court appeal was suspended because she provided a medical diagnosis showing that she suffers from chronic depression and suicidal tendencies. The court requires further mental status examinations of Teng before resuming proceedings.
Teng and Chang were both indicted last year after DNA tests failed to establish any kinship between Chang and Koo.

Koo was a business tycoon who led the Koos Group of companies from 1940 until his death in January 2005. He also chaired the SEF -- a semi-official organization set up to handle technical and business matters with China in the absence of diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC bill upsets legislative meeting

TEXT.P: A draft law regarding the composition of the Central Election Commission (CEC) failed to be addressed in Friday's legislative session after the ruling and main opposition parties agreed to hold negotiations on it in the future.

According to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) agreed to temporarily put aside the contentious bill drafted by the KMT and negotiate it at some point in the future after spending an entire fruitless morning session on the bill.
As the KMT rejected changing the meeting's agenda, DPP lawmakers occupied the podium and pushed Wang into a corner, totally paralyzing the meeting.
"It is good that the two parties decided to stop fighting, as it is obvious that the DPP will not allow the bill to pass the Legislative Yuan," Wang said.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and director of the party's Policy Coordination Commission, said that the KMT legislative caucus immediately canceled a mobilization order of lawmakers after the decision was made to negotiate the CEC bill another time.

Later that same day, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus whip Lo Chih-ming urged the DPP and KMT legislators to first address the 2008 central government budgetary bill and other issues key to the people's livelihoods instead of wasting energy on the CEC bill.

Lo also described their several rounds of physical squabbling over the bill as merely attempts to make political gains, something he said has seriously hurt Taiwan's democracy and tainted its international image.

The KMT has vowed to push for the CEC bill's passage before the current legislative session adjourns late this month after the body decided Nov. 16 to adopt a "one-step" voting format for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.

Claiming that the current 17-member CEC was packed by supporters of the ruling DPP, the KMT put forward the bill proposing that the organization be composed in proportion of the number of seats that each party holds in the Legislative Yuan in an effort to maintain what they called "fair elections."
The bill has repeatedly failed to clear the Legislative Yuan due to strong opposition from the DPP and the TSU, which say it would allow for the establishment of an "unconstitutional" CEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 lottery winners share jackpot with charities

TEXT.P: Three out of five people who shared the nearly NT$1.3 billion (US$40.24 million) prize in Tuesday's Big Lotto games donated part of their winnings to charity, a Taiwan Lottery Co. official said Friday.

Shan Jui-chiang, chairman of the Taiwan Lottery, said that each of the five winners will receive NT$250 million but will pocket NT$200 million after tax. The high-prize Big Lotto Tuesday had attracted long queues in almost every lottery outlet around the country.
Shan said that one of the winners, a 30-year-old woman, won after spending NT$100 on lottery tickets. She donated NT$3 million to charity.
Another winner, a woman in her 60s, said she prayed for good luck before buying a single NT$50 lottery ticket. She donated NT$100,000.
Another winner is a middle-aged man who spent NT$2,000 on lottery tickets. He donated NT$500,000.
Shan said that four of the winners had their number randomly chosen by the lottery computer and only one chose the numbers.
Shan also said that prize winners had donated NT$81.8 million to charity so far this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major parties claim defects in new legislative election system

TEXT.P: The new "single-member constituency, two-vote" electoral system slated for implementation in the Jan. 22 legislative election next year will squeeze out small political parties and result in other negative impact, representatives of two major political parties said Friday.
The warning came at a seminar organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy earlier in the day to discuss the new legislative electoral system and the future of Taiwan's legislature.
Under the new electoral system, one vote goes to an individual legislative candidate and the other goes to a party. In addition, the number of legislative seats has also been halved from 225 to 113.

Lai Su-ju, director of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT)'s public relations department, said at the seminar that the new system will make each legislator's electoral district smaller than that of a city councilor.
This will result in future legislators focusing only on how to satisfy their voters rather than on reviewing bills and supervising the government, Lai claimed.
By serving their constituents, individual legislators will be very likely to secure these votes, which will dampen the chance of new members being elected to the legislature, according to Lai.
To address what she described as a negative impact on Taiwan's democracy, Lai suggested a limit on legislative terms.
In addition, Lai said that under the new electoral system, it will be easy for those nominated by major political parties to be elected, which will reduce opportunities for diverse voices.
She also expressed concern over whether only a few legislators will be able to control the screening process of legislative bills under the new system.
She also claimed that newly elected legislators next year will have a greater influence in the following presidential election and thus gain greater leverage with their parties.
As a result, these legislators will not need to follow their parties' stances on every issue like legislators at large do, and will enjoy higher autonomy, she speculated.
Echoing Lai, Chang Yu-feng, director of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's public survey center, said it will be difficult for small parties to survive in the new electoral system.
Only those that are very well-known or those that can win support from voters will get elected next year, Chang said.
If small parties want to win legislative seats next year, Chang went on, they will need to work hard to raise their profiles.

Chang further said that the halving of the number of legislative seats has also posed a challenge to political parties, as many incumbent legislators who failed to be nominated by their own parties as regional legislative candidates have decided to run independently.
These legislators, who have won many terms in the past, refuse to follow party rules, adding uncertainty to the outcome of the 2008 legislative elections, Chang claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Newborn baby stuck in train toilet after birth

TEXT.P: A newborn baby, stuck in the toilet of a train Friday morning after being delivered by her 36-year-old mother, was saved after an hour of rescue efforts, according to the police.
The mother, surnamed Shao, boarded the train from Hualien to Taipei on her own Friday morning. Shao unexpectedly went into labor and gave birth to her baby girl in the steel toilet of the train.

Shao was found by train personnel, having fallen onto the floor of the washroom; the baby girl's left leg was stuck in the toilet. The baby could not be safely removed by rescue personnel, who were obliged to call in a train technician to dismantle the toilet.
The baby was finally saved after more than an hour's effort, with the doctors working to sustain her life by giving her oxygen at the same time.

The mother and the 3-kilo baby were sent immediately to a nearby hospital in Yilan County. According to doctors, the baby suffered some fractures to the lower part of her body, but her life is not in danger.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu vaccines available to general public in Kaohsiung County

TEXT.P: The Health Bureau of the Kaohsiung county government announced Friday that it will give free influenza vaccinations to local residents, including healthy adults.

Health officials said that about 51,000 people aged 65 or over and 6,800 children aged between 6 months and 2 years have already been vaccinated and that the city government still has 15,000 doses of vaccine for adults and 8,700 for children under 3.

The Health Bureau will now allow members of the general public to get vaccinated on a first-come, first-served basis, the official said, adding that children older than 3 will be given adult flu shots and those aged 3 or under will be given the child vaccines.

The officials noted that fewer children were vaccinated this year than in previous years, probably because many parents are apprehensive about the controversial mercury-laced preservative thimerosal used in the vaccines.
Doctors, however, still recommend the flu vaccine as the single most effective preventive measure against influenza -- one of the most lethal killers among the elderly and the very young.

Studies have shown that influenza vaccine is 70 percent to 90 percent effective in healthy adults younger than 65. In people aged 65 and over, the vaccine can reduce the severity of the symptoms and the risk of complications by up to 60 percent if they do get sick. And for those living in nursing homes or other long-term care facilities, the vaccine is up to 80 percent effective in preventing death from influenza.

DOC.HEADLINE: Orchid research team in Chiayi wins national innovation award

TEXT.P: An orchid research team at National Chiayi University in southern Taiwan has won this year's national innovation award for its research in phalaenopsis biotechnology, a university spokesman said Friday.

The award was founded by the Institute for Biotechnology and Medicine Industry in 2002 to recognize excellent research results and encourage the transfer of technologies in industrial application, the spokesman noted.

The award is divided into three categories -- enterprises, academic institutes and students -- the spokesman said, adding that the university's research team has won the award in the category of academic institutes.

Shen Tsai-mu, vice president of the university, and Hsu Shan-te, director of the university's Horticultural Technology Center, will represent the research team to receive the award in Taipei Dec. 20, the spokesman said.
The research team, inaugurated in 2001, is composed of several professors under Shen's leadership, the spokesman said.
The researchers are developing key technologies for the local phalaenopsis biotechnology industry and have won numerous awards in many contests, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County exhibition to feature products by aboriginal tribes

TEXT.P: The Yilan county government will hold an exhibition Dec. 8-9 to demonstrate the county's achievements in implementing a plan to help aboriginal tribes develop production industries.
The exhibition will take place at the Yilan County Cultural Center and an adjoining plaza. It will have more than 30 stalls presenting various aspects of the lives of aboriginal people.
Some of the stalls will display farm products and handicrafts produced by aboriginal people, while others will provide delicacies of the Atayal tribe.

County government officials said the exhibition is also intended to create sales opportunities for aboriginal people and increase the competitiveness of their products in the hope of creating jobs and improving their livelihoods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists to march for foreign workers' vacation rights

TEXT.P: Foreign laborers' advocates are planning to hold a protest march in Taipei Sunday in a drive to seek the right of foreign caregivers to have vacations.

The "I Want a Vacation" march is part of a three-day international conference on globalization and the human rights of migrants being held by the Migrant Empowerment Network in Taiwan (MENT) at National Taiwan Normal University. The conference began Thursday and will run through Saturday.

According to MENT, the march is aimed at urging the government to offer legal protection to foreign caregivers in terms of working conditions, to ban private labor brokers, to enact a state-to-state direct employment system, to allow foreign workers to have the right to choose an employer, and to cancel work period limits.
Taiwan International Workers' Association Secretary-General Ku Yu-ling said the government's labor services have failed to cover the families employing foreign caregivers.
Some families that hire foreign caregivers refuse to give their employees any vacation, claiming that they have no money to cover the cost of hiring a substitute in their absence.

Not every family that employs a foreign caregiver is wealthy, Ku said, suggesting that the labor authorities use its managed employment fund to hire local people as caregivers who can be enrolled to substitute for foreign caregivers when the latter are on vacation.
The proposal would not only boost local employment but would also protect the foreign workers' basic human rights, Ku noted.
Sociology Professor Tseng Yen-fen of National Taiwan University said foreign workers are treated as "machines" in Taiwan and their human rights are neglected.
She pointed out that this is why some foreign workers risk the chance of being repatriated to flee from their employers despite being bound by a contract.
Meanwhile, Nguyen Peter Van Hung, the executive director of the Taoyuan County- based Vietnamese Migrant Workers and Brides Office, urged the government to give migrant workers the right to vote.
Voting rights would give the migrants more power to fight for their rights, he said.
The "I Want a Vacation" march is scheduled to begin at 1:30 p.m. at the Zhungxiao-Fuxing MRT station and end at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hails human rights park as progress

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung described as significant and major progress Friday that a detention center under Taiwan's infamous martial law era will be turned into a human rights park later this year.
Chang made the remarks at a press conference held at the Government Information Office (GIO).

According to Chang, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a plaque-unveiled ceremony Dec. 10, which is also world Human Rights Day, to officially rename the Jingmei military detention center as the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park.
The former detention center, located in suburban Taipei, is where many political prisoners were detained and tried during Taiwan's 38-year martial law era.
Chang recalled that when he served as lawyer for some of these political prisoners, he had visited his clients at the gruesome detention center many times. Chang said he still cannot forget it.

After dedicating himself to promoting Taiwan's democracy for nearly 30 years, Chang said he finally understands that the country's democracy was gained by many people with their lives and their blood.

GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey, who was also present at the press conference, noted that martial law era survivors continue the sparkle of Taiwan's democracy so that their next generations can breathe the air of freedom.

Peng Ming-min, an ex-DPP presidential candidate who now represents the human rights park administration, noted that the Jingmei detention center is a symbol of the KMT's political persecution and has become a taboo for many people.
Peng said he was glad to see that the fear of the center will soon become the "hope" for Taiwanese people.

Klaus Walter, a section chief of Amnesty International Germany, who was also present, said Taiwan has now marched toward democracy, but noted that there is still room for the Taiwan people to do better, for example by abolishing the death penalty and showing more concern for the human rights situation in Myanmar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Resumption of cross-strait negotiations likely: academic

TEXT.P: Although systematic dialogue between Taiwan and China have been suspended for years, an academic said Friday that rekindling cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations is feasible.
the expert made the forecast in a seminar sponsored by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to mark the 20th anniversary of the start of cross- strait exchanges.

Lin Wen-cheng, a professor at National Sun Yet-sen University, predicted that Taiwan and China will eventually restart bilateral negotiations due to strong public demand on both sides thanks to increased cross-strait exchanges over the past 20 years.

The Taiwanese government first allowed veterans to visit their homes in China in 1987 after scrapping martial law that same year, marking the start of cross- strait activities following the civil war that caused the Kuomintang to flee to Taiwan in 1949.

Although the chances of Taiwan and China resuming bilateral talks seem slim at present as a result of their own political concerns, Lin said the two sides have been waiting for an opportune time to do so. As to the question of when the two sides will re-open dialogue or whether they will obtain concrete results, Lin said that this will depend on political considerations.

"A strong public demand arising from growing exchanges across the strait will continue pushing the respective governments to halt political manipulation and re-open institutionalized talks as soon as possible, " Lin said, adding that "this is an irreversible trend" despite the current impasse.

The SEF is responsible for Taiwan's dealings with China in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides over the past decades. Its Chinese counterpart is the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hall inscription replacement project draws mixed reactions

TEXT.P: A construction project to replace the gateway arch inscriptions of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall Friday drew mixed reactions from rival groups who had to be separated by riot police under the archway.

During the replacement process, opponents of the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) move to remove inscriptions reading "Ta Chong Chih Cheng" -- which alludes to the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- continued to sing songs in memory of Chiang and chant "Defend the Republic of China" and "Long live the Republic of China."
In contrast, proponents of the MOE's action gave loud rounds of applause and cheered to celebrate the removal of the inscriptions.
It took the workers seven hours to remove the four Chinese characters that made up the inscription.
The construction workers were expected to erect a new inscription reading "Tzu You Kuang Chang," or "Liberty Square" Saturday.
The hall, formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, was inaugurated in 1980 to commemorate Chiang.

Chiang has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main culprit behind a massacre that occurred Feb. 28, 1947 and the ensuing "White Terror" during the period of martial law under Kuomintang (KMT) rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Old people exercise more than youngsters: survey

TEXT.P: Old Taiwanese people enjoy much higher frequency of exercise than their younger counterparts, with one out of four elderly people enjoying established sports habits, a researcher of the National Health Research Institute said Friday.
Wen Chi-pang said 50 percent of Taiwanese people interviewed for a survey admitted that they do not like to exercise, citing results of a survey on exercise habits that started in 2001.

Wen said 75 percent of the population do not get sufficient exercise, if those who burn less than 500 calories through exercise per week are added to the 50 percent of people who take no exercise at all. "Those who think they take physical exercise are not necessarily burning enough calories," Wen noted.

The survey results show that only one seventh of the males and one tenth of the females surveyed burn more than 750 calories per week during exercise, which is the median amount suggested by the U.S. Center for Disease and Prevention.
Nearly 8 million young people with higher education and high income comprise the group that gets the least exercise, Wen said, citing the survey results.

To reach the standard for calories burned, Wen suggested that people do sports such as cycling, fast walking, hiking, ballroom dancing or swimming for 30 minutes a day until panting and five days a week. About 20 minutes per day and three days a week will be enough for exercise that causes people to pant heavily, Wen said.
For gentler sports such as waitankun, taichi, yuanchi dance, Falun Gong exercise and walking, exercise frequency will have to be increased to meet the standard, Wen said.
The elderly tend to exercise more because they have more free time and realize the benefits of exercise from experience, Wen said. He encouraged young people to engage in more physical activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military guards to be withdrawn from late presidents' mausoleums

TEXT.P: The military guards posted at the mausoleums of the late presidents Chiang Kai- shek and Chiang Ching-kuo will be withdrawn from the beginning of next year, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.

The president, who had just stirred up a policial storm in Taipei by ordering the replacement of an inscription on the gateway arch to the hall formerly dedicated to the memory of Chiang Kai-shek after renaming it the Taiwan Democratic Memorial Hall, made the statement while stumping for a group of legislative candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in Taipei.
Branding Chiang a dictator, the president said there is no reason to use taxpayers' money to guard his mausoleum in Tashi, Taoyuan County.
The mausoleum of Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of Chiang Kai-shek, is also located in Tashi.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for December 8, 2007

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 8, or the 29th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Three hanged and named in ministry first
The Justice Ministry executed three death-row inmates Friday and, in a break with its secrecy policy, released their names and details directly to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ships form world's 11th largest merchant fleet in 2006: UNCTAD
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/07 12:54:44 (By Y.C. Jou and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-owned ships formed the world's 11th largest merchant fleet in terms of deadweight tonnage in 2006, down two notches from the previous year, according to a report released Friday by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).

The Review of Maritime Transport 2007 shows that Taiwan's fleet consisted of 574 merchant vessels totalling 24.858 million deadweight tons (dwt) in 2006, up approximately 470,000 dwt compared with 2005.
The tonnage accounted for 2.54 percent of the world's total, down 0.15 percentage points from 2005.

In 2006, the 10 countries and territories with the largest merchant fleets were Greece, Japan, Germany, China, Norway, the United States, Hong Kong, South Korea, the United Kingdom and Singapore, in that order.
The report indicates that Taiwan ranked fifth in the world in terms of container port traffic in 2006, with the country's ports handling a total of
13.1 million twenty-foot-equivalent units (TEUs) for the year, up 2.43 percent over the year-earlier figure.

Kaohsiung port in southern Taiwan ranked as the world's sixth largest container terminal in terms of container throughput in 2006, with the volume of containers handled by the port rising 3.21 percent to 9.77 million TEUs.
The world's top five container terminals in 2006 were Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Busan, in that order.
The report shows that the container throughput of a number of Chinese ports recorded rapid growth last year, including Shanghai's at 20.05 percent and Shenzhen's at 14.03 percent.

The container throughput of Qingdao, Ningbo and Guangzhou soared 22.12 percent, 35.71 percent and 40.88 percent, respectively, with their world rankings advancing from 13th, 15th and 18th in 2005 to 11th, 13th, and 15th in 2006, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Occupancy rate at elderly care institutions reaches 75%: MOI

TEXT.P: The occupancy rate of long-term elderly care institutions around Taiwan has reached 75 percent as demand continues to increase with the greying of the country's population, according to tallies released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
As of the end of October, people aged 65 and older totalled 2.33 million in Taiwan, MOI officials, adding that the number has been increasing every year.

While there are a total of 1,015 long-term elderly care institutions around the country with the capacity to accommodate a total of 62,000 residents, 46,546 seniors, or 2 percent of the elderly population, are residing in these institutions, the officials said.
Taipei County is home to the largest number of long-term elderly care institutions at 194, followed by Taipei City at 171 and Kaohsiung City at 68, they said.
In terms of occupancy rate, Hsinchu City records the highest level at 91 percent, and Liangchiang County has the lowest level at 25 percent, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung skipper caught with illegal whale shark catch

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers boarded a fishing boat Friday night, discovering a victim of illegal hunting, a whale shark, which had been cut up into several parts, a spokesman for the Eastern Coastal Patrol Office (ECPO) said Saturday in Taitung County.

Although whale sharks are not on the list of protected animals in Taiwan, the Fisheries Agency began in 2001 to control the number of whale sharks that could be caught after discovering that whale shark numbers off the island's eastern coast had dropped dramatically due to overhunting.
In that year, an annual quota was set, which has since undergone review and adjustment by the agency every year. This year, the whale shark hunting quota was set at 30, or half the level for 2006.
The spokesman said that the 2007 quota was reached in July. On Nov. 1, a ban on whale shark hunting took effect, and it will remain in place until the end of the year, he noted.

The skipper of the fishing boat, which operates out of the Fukang fishing port in the eastern county of Taitung, confessed to illegal whale shark hunting, the spokesman said, adding that the case has been handed over to local prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG CIA destroyed secret tapes of interrogations.
The CIA said Thursday that it had destroyed videotapes of its secret interrogations of terrorism suspects, taking the action at a time when the agency's harsh methods were coming under intense congressional and legal scrutiny. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for attention to China's threat against Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the international community Saturday to pay attention to China's military threat against Taiwan, its attempts to diplomatically isolate the country, and its "united front" tactics.

Stressing that Taiwan and China are two separate countries independent of each other, Chen called on the world to support Taiwan's bid to join international organizations so as to allow Taiwan to assume its responsibility as a member of the international community.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a conference on human rights held in Taipei by the Liberal International, a world federation of liberal political parties.

Chen noted that both the Liberal International and the Council of Asian Liberals and Democrats have contributed positively to the deepening of Taiwan's democracy by speaking up for Taiwan whenever the country suffers unreasonable suppression by China.
Also, many members of the Liberal International have openly expressed their concerns over cross-Taiwan Strait security and China's military threat against Taiwan, Chen said.

Noting that China has been intensifying its efforts to suppress Taiwan's international participation in recent years, Chen said Beijing is not only blocking Taiwan's participation in international organizations where statehood is required for membership but is also barring Taiwan's participation in non- governmental organizations.
"Beijing is not only suppressing Taiwan, it is also suppressing Taiwan's friends," Chen said.

In one of the most vivid examples, Chen said, China has attempted through manipulation to revoke the Liberal International's consultative status within the United Nations in retaliation against the group's support for Taiwan's bid to gain membership in the World Health Organization.

In yet another example, U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon denied Taiwan's right to take part in the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women earlier this year based on U.N. Resolution 2758, which Ban claimed recognizes "Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China," Chen noted.
According to Chen, Taiwan, having experienced 38 years of martial law under the Kuomintang regime, deeply realizes the importance of human rights.

Stressing that no country should be allowed to resort to violent or non-peaceful means to crack down on its own people or intimidate other countries in a civilized world, Chen asked the international community to pay more attention to China's dictatorship and notorious human right records.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turnover at FTZs for Jan.-Oct. up 3-fold over last year

TEXT.P: The combined turnover at Taiwan's five free trade port zones reached NT$43.76 billion (US$1.35 billion) for the first 10 months of this year, marking a three- fold increase over the figure for the same period in 2006, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Saturday.

The achievement marks a success in the government's free trade port zone policy, which the government began to carry out in 2005 at the free trade zones located at Keelung Harbor, Taipei Harbor, Taichung Harbor, Kaohsiung Harbor and the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the officials said.

CEPD Vice Minister Thomas M.F. Yeh attributed the success to the government's relaxation of restrictions that he said had been hindering cargo from being freely shipped into and out of the free trade zones.
According to CEPD statistics, a total of 128 companies moved into the free trade zones in the first 10 months of this year, marking an increase of 16 percent over the figure for the whole of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q3 after-tax profits of Taiwan listed, OTC firms top NT$500 b.

TEXT.P: The net profits of listed and over-the-counter (OTC) companies in Taiwan amounted to NT$542.7 billion (US$16.8 billion) before taxes and NT$501.6 billion after taxes for the third quarter of this year, according to tallies released Saturday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The gross profits of listed and OCT companies increased NT$33.9 billion year-on- year for the first quarter and NT$83.1 billion year-on-year for the second quarter, further rising NT$127.6 billion year-on-year to NT$650 billion for the third quarter, DGBAS officials said.

In terms of operating profits, the companies posted year-on-year growth of 7.5 percent and 28.1 percent in the first and second quarters, respectively, with the growth rate registering 40.5 percent year-on-year for the third quarter, the officials said.

DGBAS tallies show that Taiwan's economic growth reached 6.92 percent for the third quarter, with the manufacturing industry recording a growth rate of 11.3 percent and contributing 3.1 percentage points to the overall economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade surplus for first 11 months hits new high: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus for the first 11 months of this year hit a record high for the period, thanks to brisk exports, according to the latest tallies released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Saturday.
In the Jan.-Dec. period, Taiwan's exports amounted to US$223.25 billion, while its imports amounted to US$198.08 billion, for a trade surplus of US$25.17 billion for the period, the tallies show.
The trade surplus for the January-November period this year is already higher than the previous record of US$22.59 billion for the whole of 2003, financial officials said.

The officials attributed the large surplus to brisk exports, coupled with the relatively low annual increase in imports. The annual increase in imports over the past four years averaged around 10 percent, but the increase this year was only 6.8 percent, they noted.
In November, exports amounted to US$21.85 billion, while imports amounted to US$17.59 billion, for a trade surplus of US$4.26 billion for the month, also a record single month high.

November exports and imports increased by 11.8 percent and 2.8 percent, respectively, year-on-year, mainly because exports to six nations of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Vietnam -- increased by 23.3 percent, and exports to mainland China, the United States, and South Korea also increased by 14.2 percent, 6.1 percent, and 19.5 percent, respectively, the officials said.

Meanwhile, although imports from China, the Middle East, Africa an India increased by 5.7 percent, 25.8 percent, 130.6 percent and 189.3 percent, respectively, in November, imports from the United States, Japan and South Korea were down by 6.3 percent, 6.7 percent and 15.2 percent, respectively, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 300 people seek aid via Changhua social welfare hotline

TEXT.P: A total of 291 people phoned social workers at the Changhua county government for urgent aid via the "1957 national welfare care hotline" between November 2006 and November this year, an official at the county's Bureau of Social Affairs said Saturday.
Hsu Fang-yu, head of the bureau's social aid office, said 60 percent of the calls were for emergency aid, and 25 percent were for urgently needed medical treatment subsidies.

The Ministry of the Interior activated the "1957 hotline" service Nov. 17, 2006. People facing dire problems in their life or those confronted with life- challenging accidents can phone county social workers for help via the hotline.
The governmental aid services include emergency relief, short-term accommodation, financial assistance for urgent medical treatment, as well as employment aid.

Hsu said that although the hotline is open to anyone who needs help, most of the people who call ask for cash relief and seem reluctant to receive other kinds of assistance, such as in the area of education and employment.
The hotline service is part of the central government's "Mega Warmth" social welfare program aimed at helping disadvantaged families escape poverty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Date for legislative recess not yet certain: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday that whether the legislature will go into recess Dec. 21 is not yet certain.
Wang noted that except for the caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the legislature, all the other parties have agreed to that date.
"I don't know what the KMT is thinking," Wang said.

The ruling and the opposition parties had agreed that the current session would go into recess Dec. 13, or one month prior to the Jan. 12 legislative elections, but Wang proposed postponing the date to Dec. 21 so that the 2008 budget for the central government could be reviewed and passed early.
KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan said "the party has its own
plan," adding that everything will wait until Dec. 10 when the
ruling and opposition parties meet to coordinate on the 2008 budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign trade, trade surplus both set to hit record high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade and trade surplus are both expected to hit record highs this year, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Saturday.

BOFT officials noted that exports for the January-November period amounted to US$223.25 billion, while imports amounted to US$198.08 billion, for a trade surplus of US$25.17 billion, up 36.8 percent year-on-year and surpassing the trade surplus of US$21.32 billion for the whole of 2006.

The officials predicted that foreign trade will continue to be strong in December and that the figure could hit US$450 billion for the year, adding that the trade surplus for the whole year is expected to hit US$27.5 billion.
They said that Taiwan has enjoyed trade surpluses for 21 straight months, which they noted is an especially good situation at a time of soaring raw material prices worldwide.

The Washington Post: Hill Close To Deal on War Funds
House Democratic leaders could complete work as soon as Monday on a half- trillion-dollar spending package that will include billions of dollars for the war effort in Iraq without the timelines for the withdrawal of combat forces that President Bush has refused to accept, House Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer (D-Md.) said yesterday.
The Washington Times:Agency defends estimate on Iran
The federal agency responsible for national intelligence estimates yesterday defended its report on Iran against charges that it was crafted primarily by former State Department officials who infused their personal politics into the report to undercut the Bush administration.

The New York Times: C.I.A. Was Urged to Keep Interrogation Videotapes
White House and Justice Department officials, along with senior members of Congress, advised the Central Intelligence Agency in 2003 against a plan to destroy hundreds of hours of videotapes showing the interrogations of two operatives of Al Qaeda, government officials said Friday.
The Wall Street Journal:Citigroup Expected to Name New CEO Soon
Citigroup Inc.'s board is expected to pick a new chief executive early in the coming week at a regularly scheduled meeting, wrapping up a five- week search, according to people familiar with the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bone fragments discovered in U.S. beef shipment

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday that two bone fragments were found in a shipment of imported U.S. beef, marking the third such case within the last two weeks.

Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, said that the beef was from Colorado-based Swift Beef Co., which has been banned by the DOH from shipping its products to Taiwan since Nov. 27.
However, he said that beef in question was already on its way to Taiwan in mid- November, so the DOH accepted the application for inspection from the Taipei importer.
The two pieces of bone fragments measure 2.4 centimeters and 4.8 centimeters in size, respectively Hsieh said, adding that the importer will now have to send back or destroy the shipment.
Two bone fragments were also found in a Swift Beef Co. shipment in late November. Earlier, Cargill of Nebraska was also banned from shipping its products to Taiwan for the same reason.
The number of U.S. beef packaging houses allowed to export their products to Taiwan now stands at 44.
Taiwan banned beef imports from the United States in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

In April 2005, Taiwan lifted an import ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age but then suspended American beef imports again on June 25 of the same year after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the United States.

Taiwan lifted the second ban on Jan. 25, 2006, but in April 2006, Taiwan found bone fragments in a shipment of beef from U.S. meat supplier Tyson Fresh Meats, leading Taipei to halve its imports from the packing house.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic gravel prices to remain stable next year: MOEA

TEXT.P: Domestic gravel prices are not expected to drop substantially next year even if China resumes exports of this critical construction material to Taiwan, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Saturday.

According to an MOEA estimate, Taiwan will need 60 million cubic meters of gravel next year, of which 55 million cubic meters can be satisfied with domestic supplies, the official said, adding that the shortfall will be covered by imports from the Philippines, Vietnam and North Korea.

Noting that Taiwan has forged cooperative ties with Philippine, Vietnamese and North Korean gravel suppliers since China suspended pebble exports to Taiwan earlier this year, the official said gravel imports from the three countries are expected to continue next year.
Between May and November, Taiwan imported 167,000 tons of gravel from the Philippines, 340,000 tons from Vietnam and 89,000 tons from North Korea, the official said.

With a view to ensuring steady gravel supply, the government has encouraged local companies to launch investment projects in the Philippines for gravel production, the official said, adding that four or five Taiwan-funded gravel plants in that country are scheduled to begin mass production in January 2008.
If all goes well, the official said, gravel imports from the Philippines alone could reach 5 million tons next year.

Since the government launched a NT$60 per ton freight subsidy program for gravel imports from countries other than China in May, about 600,000 tons of gravel had been imported under the program as of the end of November, the official said, adding that the subsidy program will remain in place next year.

As to gravel prices, the official said, domestic gravel prices saw a 20 percent rise between January and March following China's announcement at the beginning of the year that its gravel exports to Taiwan would be suspended from March.

"The sharp rise during that period was mainly fanned by psychological factors, " the official said, noting that "since the government adopted a number of measures, including offering freight subsidies for gravel imports from markets outside China, domestic gravel supplies have returned to normal and prices have gradually stabilized."
"The average gravel price has been rising by just about 1percent since April. We believe that this stable situation will remain unchanged next year, " he added..
As to reports that China will resume gravel exports to Taiwan soon, the official said the government would be pleased if China were to lift its export ban on a reciprocal basis.

Pointing out that Taiwan has never banned gravel imports from China, the official said no negotiations or consultations are needed for resumption of entry of gravel from China. "So long as China lifts its export ban, its gravel can enter Taiwan accordingly, " the official noted.

Sources close to local gravel traders associations said Chinese authorities have begun tackling certain technical details in preparation for resuming gravel exports to Taiwan, but they added that no definite timetable is available yet.
The MOEA official said that even if China resumes gravel exports to Taiwan, domestic gravel prices will remain almost the same, given the current stable market supply and demand situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP urges public to drink less bottled water to save environment

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the public Saturday to drink less bottled water or stop drinking it altogether as part of efforts to save the planet from global warming.
Lu made the call at a rally organized by environmental protection activists at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei City.

The rally was part of an "Anti-Global Warming" parade launched by environmental protection groups, including the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) and the Society of Wilderness, with the aim of raising public awareness of the pollution crisis threatening the survival of the next generation.

In an address at the rally, the vice president cited the U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's assessment as saying that if global warming continues, average global temperatures are expected to rise by between 1.1 degrees Celsius and 6.4 degrees Celsius and sea levels by between 18 centimeters and 59 centimeters during this century.
If temperatures do rise by that amount, she said, it will result in the extinction of around 20 percent of all species on the planet, which will seriously affect living conditions for humans.
Every year, Lu continued, 27,000 tons of raw plastic material is used in producing plastic bottles for drinking water.

In Taiwan, every person drinks an average of 48 bottles of bottled water per year, meaning that 1.1 billion plastic bottles are produced annually for bottled water consumed in Taiwan. She said that more than 1,700 tons of carbon dioxide are emitted into the air in producing that many bottles.

Lu suggested that people carry a refillable water bottle with them and refrain from buying bottled water. The Taipei march was one of a series of similar rallies held simultaneously in eight cities and counties around the country, according to the organizers.

TEPU Secretary-General Ho Tsung-hsun said the event was organized because of concerns about Taiwan's lack of progress in cutting carbon dioxide emissions, as evidenced by the recent failure of a draft bill on greenhouse gas reduction to pass the first reading at the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reverend recalls efforts to help political prisoners 30 years ago

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese reverend recalled his experience in extending assistance to victims of the Kaohsiung Incident 30 years ago on the eve of the official opening of a human rights memorial park, saying that all the hard work was worthwhile as Taiwan now enjoys full democracy.

"I was so happy to see that Annette Lu was elected as the vice president and Chen Chu as the mayor of Kaohsiung, because, for me, it meant I did something right, " Roger Chao, a Germany-based reverend who offered assistance to Taiwanese political prisoners in the 1970s-1980s, said in a CNA interview.

Chao and his wife Doris were invited to attend the Dec. 10 opening of the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park, a large compound which used to house military courts and a detention center for political prisoners -- including Lu, Chen, Shih Ming-teh and Presbyterian Church Reverend Kao Jun-ming.

Chao said that he learned of the incident from German newspapers and was shocked that many demonstrators were detained. In a biennial Christian conference in 1980, Chao launched a "send-a-postcard" campaign that called for German youngsters to send postcards to Taiwanese political prisoners as a way to pressure Taiwan authorities into releasing the dissidents.

"To my surprise, thousands of Germans bought postcards and stamps with their own money and penned their support for Taiwan's democracy. Some of them didn't even know where Taiwan was but they wanted to voice their disapproval of the injustice, " Chao recalled.
Doris Chao went to Taiwan's representative office in Germany with a friend and members of the local press and asked for the immediate release of the prisoners.

The couple also submitted a list of political prisoners to the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs via local churches and called for the German government to pay more attention to the human rights situation in Taiwan.

Long before the Kaohsiung Incident, Chao had been placed on the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) blacklist in 1972 which prevented him from returning to his motherland. Chao was not able to come back to Taiwan until 1987 when he was invited by then Vice President Lee Teng-hui for a visit.

Chao said the "ill feeling" began when he referred to himself as "a reverend from Taiwan" and a Taiwanese, rather than Chinese, in speeches. Taiwan government officials quickly advised him against doing so and told his mother who lived in Kaohsiung that her son was committing treason.

But Chao was determined to support the Taiwanese movement for democracy and kept collecting and exchanging information on political prisoners by corresponding with friends in Taiwan, Germany, Japan and other countries.

"In those days prior to the Internet, gathering information was extremely difficult. With Taiwan authority's strict information controls and luggage checks at airports, we were forced to use secret codes in letters and telegrams to find out who had been executed and whose Bible had been confiscated, " said Chao, who earned a xxxx in degree in theology from the University of Hamburg in 196x.

He and other Taiwanese reverends announced in a "Formosan Christian for Self Determination" statement in 1974 at the Gemarkerkirche church in Barmen, Germany, the same church where a group of German reverends released a statement against the rule of Adolph Hitler and the Nazis in 1934.

"I'm proud of what I did. We spoke out against the injustice 30 years ago when no one dared to say anything. And I think the Taiwanese people should cherish what they have today because they wouldn't have it without the blood, sweat and tears spent by those freedom fighters who had been unfairly tried, imprisoned or executed," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AI member recalls human rights movement in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Past memories suddenly emerged for Klaus Walter, a key person in rescuing political prisoners in Taiwan back in the 1980s, in the days before the inauguration of the Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei Park Dec. 10.
On Saturday, the German human rights activist recalled his first encounter with a Taiwan political prisoner case immediately after joining Amnesty International's Group 1400 in Bonn in 1975.

"I tried to find out all the facts in political prisoner cases which were not easy to obtain as officials in Taiwan never responded to letters sent by AI, " said Walter, who is now director of Membership Support Department, AI Germany.

After getting more and more acquainted with such cases in Taiwan, he decided to form a Taiwan Coordination group to gather all available information on all Taiwan political prisoners and general information about the country itself, he recalled.
"The Kaohsiung Incident on Human Rights Day in 1979 created many 'new' political prisoners for AI to gather information on," he said.
The most "famous prisoners" were Lu Hsiu-lien, Chen Chu, Shih Ming-the, Kao Chun-ming, and a few others, Walter said.

"We started a kind of small campaign within AI. We invited all the coordinators from Sweden, the United States, Britain, Holland and Germany to get involved, " Walter said, adding that "we told them to try to convince their respective sections to go international and start a campaign for Taiwan."

Talking about his efforts to gather information on political prisoners in Taiwan, Walter said the process was very difficult, because "you rarely got an answer, and if you did, it was usually by the Government Information Office.
"Trying to find out whether the information provided by the GIO was true was the toughest part," he recalled.
"The first real response we got was from the Taipei mayor at the time -- Lee Teng-hui," Walter pointed out.
"He was the first person to write back, saying 'yes there is a case,'" Walter recalled.

Walter said that Lee Shen-hsiung, a barrister at the time who is now the head of AI Taiwan, was also a person who worked courageously in trying to gather information and confirm the arrests of political prisoners.
"He was one of our main contacts in Taiwan at the time, " Walter said, adding that "I am glad he is the chair of AI, Taiwan, because he really deserves it."

Human rights activists from Japan who worked with AI, including Nishikura Kazuyoshi, Watarida Masahiro, Tezuka Toshio, Kinoue Takanobu, Kobayashi Masanari, Okawa Shiro, Ito Midori, are also expected to be present Monday at the opening ceremony for the Jingmei park.
"I'm glad that I'll have the opportunity to meet at this event with those who worked with us in Japan," Walter said.
Asked who impressed him the most in the Taiwan's pro-democracy movement, Walter answered "Chen Chu" without hesitation. Chen Chu currently serves as the mayor of Kaohsiung City.
"She really impressed me a lot, " Walter said, adding that "she proved to be a real person, with personality."
Walter pointed out that Chen Chu had already been involved in human rights work before the Kaohsiung Incident.
"I am very glad that someone like her is now a leading politician," Walter said.

He expressed the hope that he will have the opportunity to meet with Chen Chu again, and noting that the 30th anniversary of the Kaohsiung Incident is two years away, he suggested that Kaohsiung City be named a "human rights city."

The Kaohsiung Incident, also known as the Formosa Incident, was the result of pro-democracy demonstrations that occurred in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung Dec. 10, 1979. It has played a very important role in Taiwan's democratic development.

The time period experienced a rising middle n 1989, Walter came to Taiwan for the first time to help establish the first AI groups in the country and to met with former political prisoners, politicians and dignitaries.

During his second visit in 1995, at the invitation of the Taiwanese Association of Human Rights, Walter even took part in a televised discussion with then Minister of Justice Ma Jing-jeou, mainly on the use of the death penalty.
During that visit, he also toured Kueishan Prison where he met with the "Hsinchi Trio," who at that time were on death row.
Upon seeing the three chained at the feet, Walter recalled that he could not accept the way they were being treated, saying it was "degrading."
On the development of human rights and democracy in Taiwan, Walter said he is happy that "we don't have to torture or mistreat prisoners in prison or in police custody which is good."
Walter further said the concept of human rights is "normal, " adding that there is still a lot of room for Taiwan to improve in terms of human rights education and its overall education system.
He urged the Taiwan people to pay more attention to international issues, such as the human rights issues in Darfur in Sudan, or in Myanmar.
He further said that, prior to the inauguration of the Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei Park, the first of its kind in the world, "I also encourage you to do more and to continue."

During his current visit, Walter is also scheduled to head to Green Island which has played an important role in Taiwan's democratic development as many political prisoners jailed there later turned into pro-democracy activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy memorial hall to be re-opened Dec. 10

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall will not be re-opened to public access until 10 a.m. Monday because of a delay in a renovation project involving replacement of the hall's name plate and the epigraph on the main gateway to the hall, an official said Saturday.
Chuang Kuo-jung, chief secretary of the Ministry of Education, said he feels regret that the renovation work could not be completed on time to allow the hall to reopen as originally scheduled.
The ministry closed the hall, formerly known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, for three days from 9 a.m. Thursday through midnight Saturday to facilitate the renovation project.

The renovation involves replacing a plaque on the hall bearing the Chinese characters for "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall" with a new on that reads "National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" and replacing the four-character inscription alluding to Chiang 's name located at the top of the main gate with a new epigraph that reads "Liberty Square."

Chuang blamed the Taipei city government for the delay in completing the replacement work, saying the work was repeatedly interrupted by city government's safety inspections and other technical interferences.

The original "Ta Chung Chih Cheng" epigraph on the main gateway was removed Friday, but installation of the new one "Tzu You Kuang Chang" meaning "Liberty Square" was not finalized 8 p.m. Saturday, Chuang said.

Meanwhile, the hall's original name plaque was finally removed Saturday afternoon, but the installation of the new one is not expected to be finalized until Sunday noon, Chuang said, adding that for safety concern, the hall will not be re-opened to the public until Monday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st TV presentation on ill-gotten party asset referendum held

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged local voters Saturday to support the party-initiated proposal to force the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers in a referendum to be held alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
Yu made the appeal in a televised presentation organized by the Central Election Commission (CEC).

Under the current Referendum Act, the CEC is obligated to hold a series of TV debates on the DPP-proposed referendum initiative regarding reclamation of the huge public assets allegedly embezzled by the KMT during its five decades of authoritarian rule of Taiwan. As the KMT declined to debate the issue, the session was turned into a presentation by the DPP representative.

In the 30-minute presentation, Yu said Taiwan's democratic politics cannot develop in a healthy direction if the KMT is allowed to continue possession of its huge ill-gotten party assets. He urged local voters to cast affirmative votes in the upcoming referendum.
