DOC.HEADLINE: 'Lust, Caution' biggest Golden Horse Awards winner

TEXT.P: Ang Lee's spy thriller "Lust, Caution" swept the board of the 44th Golden Horse Awards in his native Taiwan Saturday, winning seven awards, including best film, best director and best actor.

It marked the first time that the New York-based director has clinched the best director honor of the Golden Horse Awards, the Taiwan version of Hollywood Oscars designed to commend outstanding Chinese-language films and personalities.
Ang Lee also won the coveted honor of Taiwanese filmmaker of the year.

Tony Leung Chiu-wai won the best actor award for his portrayal of a calm, ruthless Japanese-allied spy chief in World War II-era Shanghai in "Lust, Caution" adapted from a short story of the same name by noted writer Eileen Chang. It was the third time that Leung has captured the Golden Horse best actor award.

The film's leading actress, Tang Wei, however, lost to veteran Joan Chen, who won the best actress award for portraying the struggles of a Hong Kong nightclub singer who moves to Australia in "The Home Song Stories."
Tang Wei instead won the best new performer award for her marvelous protrayal of a young spy who posed as an affluent married woman in "Lust, Caution."
A complete list of winners at the 44th Golden Horse Awards is as follows:
Best film: "Lust, Caution".
Best director: Ang Lee, "Lust, Caution".
Best actor: Tony Leung Chiu-wai, "Lust, Caution".
Best actress: Joan Chen, "The Home Song Stories".
Best supporting actor: Tony Leung Ka-fai, "The Drummer".
Best supporting actress: Fan Bingbing, "The Matrimony".
Lifetime achievement award: Edward Yang.
The International Federation of Film Critics award: "What On Earth Have I Done Wrong?!".
Best original screenplay: Tony Ayres, "The Home Song Stories".
Best screenplay adaptation: James Schamus, Wang Hui-ling, "Lust, Caution".
Best action choreography: Donnie Yen, "Flash Point".
Best art direction: Anuson Pinyopotjanee, "The Detective".
Best editing: Zhang Yifan, Jiang Wen, "The Sun Also Rises".
Best cinematography: Lee Ping-bin, "The Matrimony".
Best visual effects: Victor Wong, Eddy Wong, Clement Cheung, Donnie Lai, "Secret."
Best film score: Alexandre Desplat, "Lust, Caution."
Best original film song: "Secret," composer Jay Chou, lyricist Fang Wen-shan, performer Jay Chou.
Best sound effects: Tu Duu-chih, Kuo Li-chi, Tang Xiangzhu, "The Most Distant Course."
Best makeup and costume design: Pan Lai, Olympic Lau, "Lust, Caution".
Best documentary: "Hollywood Chinese."
Best short film: "Fly Out Blue."
Taiwanese filmmaker of the year: Ang Lee.
Taiwanese film of the year: "Secret".
Best new performer: Tang Wei, "Lust, Caution".
Best film by audience vote: "Getting Home".

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 9, or the 30th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti- communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

"I tried to find out all the facts in political prisoner cases which were not easy to obtain as officials in Taiwan never responded to letters sent by AI, " said Walter, who is now director of Membership Support Department, AI Germany.

After getting more and more acquainted with such cases in Taiwan, he decided to form a Taiwan Coordination group to gather all available information on all Taiwan political prisoners and general information about the country itself, he recalled.
"The Kaohsiung Incident on Human Rights Day in 1979 created many 'new' political prisoners for AI to gather information on," he said.
The most "famous prisoners" were Lu Hsiu-lien, Chen Chu, Shih Ming-the, Kao Chun-ming, and a few others, Walter said.

"We started a kind of small campaign within AI. We invited all the coordinators from Sweden, the United States, Britain, Holland and Germany to get involved, " Walter said, adding that "we told them to try to convince their respective sections to go international and start a campaign for Taiwan."

Talking about his efforts to gather information on political prisoners in Taiwan, Walter said the process was very difficult, because "you rarely got an answer, and if you did, it was usually by the Government Information Office.
"Trying to find out whether the information provided by the GIO was true was the toughest part," he recalled.
"The first real response we got was from the Taipei mayor at the time -- Lee Teng-hui," Walter pointed out.
"He was the first person to write back, saying 'yes there is a case,'" Walter recalled.

Walter said that Lee Shen-hsiung, a barrister at the time who is now the head of AI Taiwan, was also a person who worked courageously in trying to gather information and confirm the arrests of political prisoners.
"He was one of our main contacts in Taiwan at the time, " Walter said, adding that "I am glad he is the chair of AI, Taiwan, because he really deserves it."

Human rights activists from Japan who worked with AI, including Nishikura Kazuyoshi, Watarida Masahiro, Tezuka Toshio, Kinoue Takanobu, Kobayashi Masanari, Okawa Shiro, Ito Midori, are also expected to be present Monday at the opening ceremony for the Jingmei park.
"I'm glad that I'll have the opportunity to meet at this event with those who worked with us in Japan," Walter said.
Asked who impressed him the most in the Taiwan's pro-democracy movement, Walter answered "Chen Chu" without hesitation. Chen Chu currently serves as the mayor of Kaohsiung City.
"She really impressed me a lot, " Walter said, adding that "she proved to be a real person, with personality."
Walter pointed out that Chen Chu had already been involved in human rights work before the Kaohsiung Incident.
"I am very glad that someone like her is now a leading politician," Walter said.

He expressed the hope that he will have the opportunity to meet with Chen Chu again, and noting that the 30th anniversary of the Kaohsiung Incident is two years away, he suggested that Kaohsiung City be named a "human rights city."

The Kaohsiung Incident, also known as the Formosa Incident, was the result of pro-democracy demonstrations that occurred in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung Dec. 10, 1979. It has played a very important role in Taiwan's democratic development.

The time period experienced a rising middle n 1989, Walter came to Taiwan for the first time to help establish the first AI groups in the country and to met with former political prisoners, politicians and dignitaries.

During his second visit in 1995, at the invitation of the Taiwanese Association of Human Rights, Walter even took part in a televised discussion with then Minister of Justice Ma Jing-jeou, mainly on the use of the death penalty.
During that visit, he also toured Kueishan Prison where he met with the "Hsinchi Trio," who at that time were on death row.
Upon seeing the three chained at the feet, Walter recalled that he could not accept the way they were being treated, saying it was "degrading."
On the development of human rights and democracy in Taiwan, Walter said he is happy that "we don't have to torture or mistreat prisoners in prison or in police custody which is good."
Walter further said the concept of human rights is "normal, " adding that there is still a lot of room for Taiwan to improve in terms of human rights education and its overall education system.
He urged the Taiwan people to pay more attention to international issues, such as the human rights issues in Darfur in Sudan, or in Myanmar.
He further said that, prior to the inauguration of the Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei Park, the first of its kind in the world, "I also encourage you to do more and to continue."

During his current visit, Walter is also scheduled to head to Green Island which has played an important role in Taiwan's democratic development as many political prisoners jailed there later turned into pro-democracy activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Ang Lee's 'Lust, Caution' cleans up at Golden Horse film awards

TEXT.P: Ang Lee's steamy, spy thriller "Lust, Caution" romped home with seven awards, including best film, best director and best actor, at the 44th Golden Horse Awards in his home country of Taiwan Saturday.

Although the New York-based director has won popular acclaim in major film festivals worldwide, Ang Lee said during a party held in Taipei after the Golden Horse Award presentation ceremony that he most values the Golden Horse Awards -- the Taiwan version of Hollywood's Academy Awards, designed to recognize outstanding Chinese-language films and personalities -- because they're held in his home country.
Lee said he still has no idea why he made "Lust, Caution." It seemed that there was an urge leading him to produce the movie to "repay debts that had accumulated over many lifetimes," he said.

Admitting that he had undergone great moral struggles during the making of "Lust, Caution", over scenes some people may consider erotic or steamy, Lee expressed his sincere appreciation to his family members for their support.

Tony Leung Chiu-wei won the best actor award for his portrayal of a calm, ruthless Japanese-allied spy chief in World War II-era Shanghai in "Lust, Caution", adapted from a short story of the same name by noted author Eileen Chang. It was the third time that Leung has captured the Golden Horse Award for best actor.

Ang Lee, who also won the coveted honor of Taiwanese filmmaker of the year, boarded a Taiwan High Speed Rail train Sunday morning for his hometown of Tainan City, southern Taiwan, just hours after the celebration party, to attend an alumni gathering marking the 50th founding anniversary of the middle school that he attended decades ago in Tainan.

The Oscar-winner director will also take time to pay his respects to his deceased father at a temple in Tainan. His father was a superintendent of the prestigious National Tainan First Senior High School.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan status key in presidential poll: Examination Yuan head
DOC.DATELINE: Baltimore, Maryland, U. S. Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/09/07 15:55:03 (By C. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national status is the most critical point in the March 22, 2008 presidential poll and so candidates of both the ruling and opposition parties have to come out with a clear stance regarding the issue, Republic of China Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said here Saturday.
Yao made the remarks while giving a speech analyzing the meaning of presidential polls to Taiwan's democratic development at a meeting with Taiwanese expatriates in Baltimore.

Claiming that Taiwan's national status, rather than its economy, is absolutely the core issue in the next presidential election, Yao opined that both ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh and his main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) counterpart Ma Ying-jeou have to provide the public with a clear explanation concerning their views on this point.

"Neither Hsieh nor Ma can shirk the issue," Yao said, urging both to debate the topic, as Ma continuous to maintain that the economy is the central point while Hsieh increasingly leans toward swing voters.

Both Hsieh and Ma have to tell voters clearly whether they are vying for Taiwan's presidency, whether Taiwan's national territory also includes the Chinese mainland, and characterize the nature of Taiwan-China relations as domestic or international, he argued.

Yao said that he strongly doubts that Ma could promote direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, with Beijing insisting that Taiwan-China routes are domestic, although Ma has repeatedly said that he would immediately embark on the task if elected president.

"I doubt that Ma, in his capacity as head of state, dares to sign documents that would downgrade Taiwan's status to that of a province of China to approve direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights, " Yao said, warning that "Taiwan would become an entirely local Chinese government if Taiwan deals with ensuing complex problems, such as labor affairs and academic diploma verification, in a similar way."

The DPP and KMT are not enemies, but both bear the responsibility of making clear their positions to voters how they will deal with China, because this is the critical point in matters concerning Taiwan's safety and development, he said.

He also contended that the United States and international community have to clearly define what is the so-called "status quo" across the strait now that they are constantly calling for maintaining the status quo between the two sides.

The DPP's efforts to hold a referendum on whether the country should push for U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan are effectively aimed at safeguarding the cross-strait status quo so as to make international society realize that "Taiwan is an independent sovereignty which does not form part of the People's Republic of China," he went on.

According to Yao, Taiwan's people should forge a consensus concerning the so- called cross-strait "status quo" on four fronts -- Taiwan is an independent sovereignty, Taiwan and China do not belong to each other, Taiwan must keep its democratic government system and cross-strait peace must be maintained.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers oppose bills benefiting veterans

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators expressed opposition Sunday to "pork barrel" bills proposed by opposition lawmakers that would benefit only military veterans.

DPP legislators Chuang Ho-tzu and Trong Chai warned in a joint statement that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -led "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers have been pushing 11 "pork barrel" bills, including housing subsidies, favoring military veterans and their dependents.

Noting that the majority of people in Taiwan are not responsible for the "feeding" of the handful of military veterans who came to Taiwan from China more than four decades ago, Chuang and Chai urged all "pan-green camp" legislators, led by the DPP, and novice "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers, to block those bills from being passed into law.

Chuang claims that it would cost Taiwan's people some NT$1.8 trillion (US$55.73 billion) if those 11 bills were passed into law, adding that there is no need for the Taiwanese, whose number constitutes more than four-fifths of Taiwan's entire population, to foot the bills to care for the daily needs of military veterans, who number less than one-tenth of the country's total population.
The NT$1.8 trillion, Chuang said, could instead be spent on other more crucial and significant affairs, such as beefing up the country's national defense, education or social work.

For his part, Chai said that more than 10,000 veterans have retained their Taiwan household registrations but live in China on a long-term basis, while the number of veterans who travel from China back to Taiwan only in January and July to pick up their regular payments from the government exceeds 50,000.

Chuang and Chai were mainly referring to an amendment to an act governing the reconstruction of veterans and military dependents' houses that was approved in a first reading by the opposition-dominated legislature Jan. 8, stipulating that some 350,000 veterans who do not live in designated military residential compounds around the country should also be entitled to special housing subsidies.

Approval of the amendment would require a budget over NT$1 trillion to subsidize reconstruction of old military residential compounds that have been built since the 1950s for some 500,000 military veterans.

Chuang and Chai described the amendment as nothing more than a pork barrel bill of the "pan-blue alliance" aimed at using government money to curry favor with veterans -- who side mainly with the KMT -- in forthcoming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help promote human rights: presidential aide

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan said that Taiwan, based on its own struggle for democracy, is working to promote and protect human rights in other countries worldwide.

Yeh made the remarks Saturday at a seminar titled "Witness to Taiwan's History of Struggling for Human Rights During the Martial Law Era", which was part of activities marking the inauguration of the Taiwan Human Rights Jingmei Park slated for Dec. 10.

The seminar was attended by a total of 14 human rights activists from home and abroad who played a role in Taiwan's human rights movement during the country's martial law era during 1949-1987, including Watarida Masahiro, Tezuka Toshio and Kobayshi Masanari, members of Japan's Solidarity Committee for Taiwan's Political Prisoners; Klaus Walter, director of the Membership Support Department, Amnesty International (AI) Germany; overseas Taiwanese Chen Mei-chin and her husband Gerrit van der Wees.
Also present were Chang Fu-mei, minister of Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission, and Wu Chin-fa, vice chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs.

Yeh said that for many people at the forum, the meaning of "human rights" is not only in the words, but also in the goals they have devoted most of their lives to pursuing. She added that thanks to the combined efforts of the Taiwanese people for half a century, the people of Taiwan are now entitled to enjoy human rights after enduring the world's longest period of martial law.

Noting that Taiwan underwent a smooth transfer of power without bloodshed in 2000, which she said symbolizes that human rights are truly safeguarded in Taiwan, Yeh said that it is hoped that Taiwan will help to develop greater respect for human rights in other countries after having received assistance in safeguarding human rights in the past.

On the same occasion, Dutch pro-democracy activist Gerrit van der Wees said that the Kaohsiung Incident, also known as the Formosa Incident, in 1979 was a watershed moment in Taiwan's human right movement, adding that he was then a university student and dedicated himself to promoting Taiwan's human rights by establishing the next year the Taiwan Communique, a bi-monthly journal focused on political developments in and around Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Tezuka Toshio displayed an array of photos to illustrate the efforts made and prices paid in the process of the country's pursuit of human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ang Lee looking for his next movie script

TEXT.P: Ang Lee, the Academy Award-winning director from Taiwan, said Saturday night that he was looking for material for his next movie, and that he might try to direct a "funny movie" if he could find a good script.

Lee made the remarks at the 2007 Golden Horse Film Festival in Taipei after he was invited on stage to announce and present the best actor award, together with light-hearted Hong Kong actress Sandra Ng.

Ng, winner of the Best Actress Award at the 2003 Golden Horse Film Festival for her role as a prostitute in the film Golden Chicken, tried to make Lee perform a series of facial antics which he might use in dealing with his wife's various moods.
Lee' response, drawing a big laugh from the audience, proved that the Oscar- winning director of "Brokeback Mountain" and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" is also good at making fun.

On his plans for what comes next, he said he will travel to Spain, France, the United Kingdom, northern Europe and Australia to promote his latest film -- "Lust, Caution", an erotic espionage thriller which won seven Golden Horse Awards Saturday, including best feature film, best director, and best actor.

The movie, which also won the Golden Lion for best picture at the Venice Film Festival in September, depicts a group of patriotic Chinese students plotting to kill the head of an espionage network of the Japanese collaborationist government during the Sino-Japanese war years of 1939-1943, using a young woman as a lure.

Asked about his next movie, Lee said he was still looking for the right material, and that if he could not find it, he would rest for a while. He indicated that he might shoot a comedy, if he can find a good script.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nankang Exhibition Hall to be inaugurated in March

TEXT.P: The Nankang Exhibition Hall of the Taipei World Trade Center is slated to open in March next year, with "Taipei Cycle" being the first fair that it will stage to attract buyers from across the world, organizers said Sunday.

According to officials of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which organizes the "Taipei Cycle" -- the largest event of its kind in Asia and second-largest in the world -- the event will be hosted by the Nankang Exhibition Hall from March 13-16.

At the same time, the TaiSPO, an exhibit featuring high-end sporting goods, usually held in April in the past, will be held simultaneously at the First Exhibition Hall of the Taipei World Trade Center in downtown Taipei with the aim of courting an even larger number of buyers to visit Taiwan, TAITRA officials said.
More than 250 companies have applied to take part in this year's TaiSPO -- the 35th of its kind -- with products on display at 1,600 booths, TAITRA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First translation certification exam staged

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) held its first ever certification exam for Chinese-English translators on Dec. 8-9 at the National Taiwan University in Taipei.

The exam, which is comprised of both translations of written materials and consecutive interpretation sections, is the result of an attempt by the MOE to establish a standard translation appraisal system and elevate the professional image of translators, according to the MOE officials.

Among the 881 people registered for the exam, 302 will sit both the translation and interpretation tests, officials said, adding that examinees who pass the translation exam will receive a certificate and will be officially recognized by the Taiwanese government as translators.

Those who pass the first stage of the interpretation exam on Dec. 9 will be eligible for the second stage exam scheduled on Jan. 6, 2008, with those passing it being granted a certificate in consecutive interpreting.

The topics of the questions in the Chinese-English and English-Chinese translation exams vary from economics and science, to social issues, which is good for assessing translation skills, said one examinee.

However, during the listening and written part of the first stage of the interpretation exam, some examinees complained of being confused by how the tape was played, as well as the answering methods, adding these were not in accord with general regulations.
The invigilators stated that they will report the problem to the MOE for further consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker hopeful that Chiangs' tombs will remain in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chiang said Sunday that he and Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun will study means to guard the tombs of late Presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, who are his grandfather and father in the county.

Chiang made the comments while fielding reporters' questions after President Chen Shui-bian said a day earlier that from Jan. 1 next year, military guards protecting the mausoleums of the two late presidents in Tashi, Taoyuan County will be withdrawn as the Chiang family refuses to relocate the remains to a military cemetery in Shichi, Taipei County, on which the government has spent NT$30 million.

Chiang said he will not accept the proposal to relocate the two tombs to the Shichi military cemetery so long as Chen remains in presidency. Allowing a pro- Taiwan independence Chen to preside over the tombs' removal would be a great humiliation to his grandfather and father, he said.

Although Chiang claimed that he will consider the relocation proposal if the KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou succeeds in winning the March 22, 2008 presidential poll, he pointed out that by that time, Ma might also agree to permit the two mausoleums to remain in Tashi.

But since Chen is very likely to rashly withdraw the guards from the two mausoleums as an electoral gambit in the run up to the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative election, Chiang said he will discuss measures with Chu as soon as possible to protect the two mausoleums.

Chiang said that he talked over the relocation issue with Chu more than a year ago, and expressed hope that the Taoyuan County Government would watch over the two mausoleums instead of the central government if the DPP government decides to withdraw the guards.

According to Chiang, Chu responded positively and many local residents are also in favor of the idea, which they said would provide the county with an opportunity to link itself closely with this aspect of the Republic of China's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. calls on people to avoid bottled water

TEXT.P: Vice president Annette Lu called for the Taiwanese people Sunday to drink less bottled wqter, or altogether stop buying it as part of efforts to protect the environment.
Lu called for members of the Taiwanese public to carry with them their own canteens containing boiled water prepared at home when going out to work, school or on a day trip.

Noting that the production of each liter-sized PET bottle requires 17. 5 liters of water, Lu said she has no idea whether the consumers are drinking water, or petroleum, when they are consuming bottled water.

Lu said there are roughly 6.3 billion people in the world, but "we have only one Earth, " which prompted her to advocate a drive to encourage people to "worship heaven, treasure the Earth and love the people"; she went on that this should start with drinking less bottled water, or no longer buying it at all.
She noted that more than 270,000 metric tons of raw materials, and 18,000 barrels of crude oil must be processed each year for worldwide production of plastic water bottles.

In Taiwan, if each citizen consumes 48 PET bottles of drinking water each year, the nation as a whole would be responsible for the production of 1.1 billion PET bottles a year, a number which, if lined up end on end, could circle Taiwan proper 326 times, she said.
Lu jokingly admitted that she might be inviting the wrath of PET producers by advocating this drive, but added that she would not flinch from what should be done.

Lu made the remarks while stumping for ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chao Yung-ching's re-election in the next legislative elections slated for Jan. 12, 2008. She recommended Chao as a good lawmaker who has been devoted to environmental protection and protecting consumers' interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Salaries behind changing jobs: poll

TEXT.P: Good salaries and handsome bonuses are the top concerns of most white-collar workers when planning to change jobs, the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs reported Sunday.

Citing the results of an on-line survey of 5,779 respondents conducted by the bureau from Nov. 1 - 30, bureau officials said that as many as 80 percent of the respondents expressed hope of getting a better salary and more handsome benefits by changing jobs.

When choosing a new position, 37 percent said that they will check whether it is "well paid, near their homes and has a light workload, " while 22 percent and 21 percent pointed to a "comprehensive bonus" and "a good salary" as their top concern, respectively, according to the survey.

Only 8.5 percent of the respondents said that they will prioritize "career development prospects" in their plans to change jobs, ahead of "promotion opportunities" signaled by 4.5 percent and "sharing corporate earnings" by some 3.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to help promote imports of Central American coffee

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) -- Taiwan's foreign trade arm promoting two-way trade worldwide -- is preparing to organize a Taiwanese trade mission to Central America early next year to promote coffee imports from that part of the world.

TAITRA officials said Sunday that the council is organizing a "Central America coffee trade inspection tour, " from Jan. 20-27, aimed at allowing delegates of interested Taiwanese companies to travel to Taiwan's Central American allies of El Salvador and Nicaragua to gain a first-hand understanding of these two countries' coffee industry, including the plantations, crops of Arabica coffee, the processing of coffee beans, as well as their coffee trade norms.

They said that the TAITRA will not only seek governmental subsidies for air tickets for those companies poised to visit El Salvador and Nicaragua, it will also seek governmental subsidies to help fund Taiwan companies' imports of coffee from these two Central American countries.

Coffee has been one of the main products that Taiwan has sought to import from Central America and one of the key products that Central American countries have tried to sell to Taiwan over the past years.
Taiwan has signed free trade agreements (FTA) with El Salvador and Nicaragua for reciprocal benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11th Taipei Cultural Awards go to theatrical workers

TEXT.P: The Performance Workshop theater and Huang Ying-hsiung, a playwright and director, won the 11th Taipei Cultural Awards for their contributions to hand down Taiwan's performing arts to the next generation.

Taipei City's Department of Cultural Affairs held a ceremony to recognize the winners Friday during which Stan Lai, founder of the theater, said that he is delighted to win the award and is willing to contribute the cash prize of NT$200,000 to the cultural agency to encourage more youngsters to engage in artistic creation.
Lee Yong-ping, director of the cultural affairs department, commended the Performance Workshop for its role in leading the development of theatrical performances in Taiwan.

Citing the theater's premier work "The Night We Became Hsiang Sheng Comedians" as an example, Lee said the work became a milestone for Taiwan's theater for its innovative creativity and its powerful performance, which spurred a revival of the dying traditional Chinese comedy form Hsiang-sheng in Taiwan.
Nonetheless, Lee said that the group also made great efforts to cultivate young performing talents by regularly organizing performance camps and other activities on campuses around the country.

As to Huang, who is artistic director of the Tien Experimental Theater, Lee said he was honored for his devotion to training artistic and literary youngsters, and to promoting the performing arts over the past 20 years.

Noting that Huang also paved the way for the disabled to step onto stage through writing plays that are suited for them to perform, Lee said that Huang also designed a special descriptive format for the blind and visually impaired to enjoy movies.

Also attending the ceremony were Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin; the government's Labor Affairs Department Director Su Ying-kuei; Emile Sheng, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; and Lin Cheng-chi, vice chairwoman of the main opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Political prisoners, human rights workers visit ex-detention center

TEXT.P: International human rights workers visiting the Jingmei Military Detention Center Sunday said it was an eye-opening experience while ex-political prisoners described it as a reminder of Taiwan's "bad old days".

Close to 100 former political prisoners, some of whom spent up to 12 years in the center during the 1970s and 1980s, accompanied by the international human rights workers who offered their assistance in rescuing the prisoners, visited the suburb compound -- recently renamed Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park by Taiwan's government.
The site is a vast compound which used to house the military courts of the Taiwan Garrison Command and a detention center for political prisoners.

It was also where eight leaders of the Kaohsiung Incident, including Vice President Annette Lu, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, and former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairmen Shih Ming-deh and Lin Yi-hsiung, stood trial under martial law.

"I was in Room 48. You were in 43, right? " Lin Shu-chi asked his "cell mates" who arrived with him earlier. Memories may fade away, but something you just don't forget, said Lin, who spent a part of his 12 year prison life in Jingmei before being moved to the Green Island.

The only part of the site which has undergone major change was the administration building, which was kept intact but penetrated by several newly- built concrete walls, symbolizing democracy's victory over an authoritative regime, explained architect Chien Hsueh-yi.
The court room of the Kaohsiung Incident trial has been turned into an exhibition room, displaying documents, photographs, relics and articles related to the incident.

Roger and Doris Chao, a Taiwanese-German couple who called on Taiwan's authority to immediate release political prisoners following the incident, were in awe of the atmosphere of the court room. It was there that the Taiwanese prisoners, whom they didn't even know but nonetheless tried to help, stood trial.

A tour of the cells was the highlight of the visit. Former prisoners, most of whom are over 60 years-old, looked for the cells where they stayed 30 years ago. Annette Lu and Chen Chu shared room 59 in the second floor, where female prisoners were kept.

Pointing at a wash-basin on the floor, Huang Hua explained the prisoners had to wash hands, dishes, and bathe in the tiny space. Usually, there were six to seven inmates kept in a 12 square meter room, he said.
Cell mates were allowed to walk around an open space for 20 minutes twice or three times per week; it was our only chance to see the sky and embrace "free air, " he added.

Tsai Tsai-yuan, who was beaten almost to death in the center, showed visitors how he wrote an SOS message and flipped the spitball out of the cracked gap of the window, hoping someone would notice it and bring help.

"I knew that family members of the prisoners would pass by my window on visiting days, so I took the chance, " Tsai said. And he succeeded. His notes was sent out to international human rights organizations and his life was spared.

"This is the real history, " said Gerrit van der Wees, senior political advisor of Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), after listening to stories told by ex-prisoners. He said that Taiwanese should know what really happened during the "White Terror" days.
After the park is inaugurated by President Chen Shui-bian Monday and opened to the public, they will be able to see for themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Symphony orchestra to perform compositions by Ma Shui-long

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra will present three concerts in northern, central and southern Taiwan this month, featuring compositions by Taiwanese composer Ma Shui-long.

The three concerts will take place Dec. 15 at the Kaohsiung Cultural Center, Dec. 16 at the orchestra's Recital Hall in Wufeng Township, Taichung County, and Dec. 17 at the National Concert Hall in Taipei under the wand of conductor Chiu Chun-Chiang.
The works to be performed include Ma's "Liao Tian-ding Suite," "Search," and "The Invisible Temple of God."

"Search" is a piece to be played on the zheng, a Chinese string music instrument, while "The Invisible Temple of God," Ma's latest work, is a piece for orchestra and male chorus, with a Jade Mountain theme incorporating elements of aboriginal music from the Tsou and Bunun tribes, two of Taiwan's 13 indigenous tribes.

Ma, 68, is a professor of music of Taipei National University of the Arts. He graduated from the National Taiwan Academy of the Arts in 1964 and went to Germany for further study in 1972 at the College of Catholic Church Music and Music Education in Regensburg, graduating with distinction in 1975.

His various compositions include those for orchestra, chamber ensemble and chorus. They have been performed in more than 20 countries, including the United States, European and southeast Asian countries.
In 1987, Ma became the first Taiwanese composer to conduct concerts at the Lincoln Center in New York City. He was awarded the National Award for the Arts in the music category in 1999.
In April 2007, the Cabinet presented him with a National Cultural Award in recognition of his life-long contribution and achievements as a composer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dominican Republic deputy foreign minister arrives for visit

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic Subsecretary of External Relations, Sara Guemez Naut, arrives in Taiwan Sunday for a five-day visit, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the same day.

This is Guemez's first visit to Taiwan to acquire a first-hand understanding of Taiwan's political and economic development and its foreign affairs, as well as Taiwan's systems to train personnel in the foreign affairs and taxation sectors, according to the spokesman.
The spokesman added that Guemez will call on the Foreign Ministry, the Ministry of Finance, the Government Information Office, and their affiliated agencies during her stay in Taiwan.

Guemez will also take ride on the high speed rail and the Taipei City mass rapid transit system, and visit the Taipei World Trade Center, Taipei 101 and the National Palace Museum, plus the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in the central city of Taichung, the spokesman said, adding that she is slated to depart Taiwan Dec. 13.

Guemez served as the subsecretary of finance and was chief of the training center for finance and taxation personnel in Dominican Republic and is now in charge of administrative and financial affairs in her current position.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman arrives for visit

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt has arrived in Taipei for a four-day visit, diplomatic sources said Sunday.

Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, was accompanied by Douglas Spelman, chief of the Taiwan desk at the U.S. Department of State, when he arrived Saturday evening.
This is Burghardt's third visit since he assumed his current post in February 2006. He last visited Taipei in mid-June.

The main purpose of his latest visit is to gain first-hand information about the local elections and meet with the presidential candidates of Taiwan's two major political parties -- Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, the sources said.

According to sources, Burghardt will exchanges views with the two presidential hopefuls on a range of issues, including their policy visions and initiatives concerning relations across the Taiwan Strait as well as their views on the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S. -China relations.
Burghardt will review AIT Taipei Office operations Sunday and pay visits to Minister of James Huang Monday morning and to President Chen Shui-bian at 3 p.m. that same day, the sources said.

It remains to be seen whether Burghardt will again attempt to dissuade Chen from holding a referendum on whether the country should seek U.N. membership under the name Taiwan or touch on topics relating to cross-strait relations.
Burghardt is scheduled to wrap up his visit Tuesday.
A retired career diplomat, Burghardt headed the AIT Taipei Office between 1999 and 2001. He now concurrently serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Honolulu.
The AIT, headquartered in Washington, D.C., is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: No improvement in China's human rights situation: experts

TEXT.P: There is no improvement in human rights situation in China in 2007, experts and activists said at a seminar held here on Sunday.

The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) , an independent and non-partisan democracy assistance foundation, organized the seminar, dubbing the 2007 China Human Rights Report: Observation on Political Rights and Judicial Rights, to coincide with the Dec. 10 Human Rights Day and the opening of the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park in Taipei.

Speaking at the seminar, Chen Chun-ju, a research assistant at the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University, said that in 2007 the Communist Party of China (CPC) made no improvement either in political human rights, or in citizen's basic civil rights although it was highly expected that the 2008 Olympic Games will open a window for such change.

Chen said that the CPC stepped up its control of people before and during its 17th National Congress in October, adding thatthe regime has monitored and arrested dissidents, rights activists, petitioners; closed down websites and blogs; and tightened its grip on media since July."

Speaking on the same occasion, Liao Fu-te, an associate research fellow of the Institute of Law, Academia Sinica, said that he is frustrated at seeing no improvement of any kind in people's judicial rights in China, adding that personal liberty and dignity, fair judicial trials, and the proper implementation of laws, are the areas suffering from the most serious infringement.

The conditions of Chinese prisons are condemned world-widely, " Liao said, adding thatalthough the Chinese official media claimed that executions dropped down after the Chinese Peoples Supreme Court took back the power of approving death penalty yet China never provides the number of execution which is regarded as a national secrecy.

Klaus Walter, the German human rights activist and director of Membership Support, Amnesty International Germany (AI), said that AI has urged China to drop death penalty, free imprisoned civil rights activists, and give its people freedom of speech and expression, only to be snubbed by Beijing.

Walter said that he was disturbed too when he tried in vain to rescue Taiwan's political prisoners jailed for the Kaohsiung Incident 30 years ago, and it was beyond his expectation that the jail used to detain those political prisoners has turned into the Jingmei human rights park; therefore, "I try to be optimistic and think that maybe one day the Tiananmen Square in Beijing can become a Liberty Square."

Maysing Yang, vice president of the TFD, concluded the seminar by saying that whether China can really improve human rights and become a democratic country ruled by law has great impact in the stability in Taiwan and human rights in other Asian countries, "We must keep working together and showing concerns about this matter."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 10, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng- hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Democracy memorial hall re-opens

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Democracy Memorial hall re-opened as scheduled at 10 a.m. Monday following its recent renovation.

The renovation involved replacing a plaque on the hall bearing the Chinese characters for "Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall" with a new one that reads "National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall" and replacing the four-character inscription alluding to late president Chiang Kai-shek's name located at the top of the main gate with a new epigraph that reads "Liberty Square."

But Chuang Kuo-jung, secretary-general of the Ministry of Education, said the public still cannot access the second floor of the main hall for safety concerns because the scaffolding has yet to be removed.

He also said that the statute of the late president in the hall will be kept intact, adding that if there are any changes to be made in the future, the ministry will first apply with the Council for Cultural Affairs as stipulated in the historic relic law.
Noting that around 10 million visitors tour the park each year,
Chuang predicted that the number of visitors will increase after
the name change, saying that foreign visitors will be able to see how Taiwan has transformed itself from authoritarian to a free and democratic country.

The memorial hall was built in 1980 by the then-Kuomintang (KMT) government in honor of Chiang who was also the KMT's leader. The current Democratic Progressive Party administration has branded Chiang as a dictator and main perpetrator of the tragic 228 Incident of 1947 and has insisted on renaming the landmark building in downtown Taipei as part of its pursuit of transitional justice, but the re-designation efforts have been met with resistance from the KMT-controlled Taipei city government.
The ministry closed the hall from 9 a.m. Thursday to 10 a.m. Monday to facilitate the renovation work.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSB completes plans on protecting presidential candidates: official

TEXT.P: The National Security Bureau (NSB) has completed planning on protecting candidates' personal safety ahead of the next presidential election slated for March 22, 2008, NSB Director Shi Hwei-yow said Monday.

Responding to reporters' questions at the Legislative Yuan on whether the NSB has obtained intelligence concerning a possible assassination attempt on main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, Shi said his bureau has been constantly monitoring the security of the candidates and their close relatives, irrespective of which party they belong to.

Shi said that the NSB has adopted a "better safe than sorry" policy on protecting the candidates' personal safety and will not ignore any suspicious circumstance in carrying out its task, adding that the bureau will handle all cases concerning the candidates' security after careful assessment of related intelligence.

Noting that it is only natural that spats and bickering intensify as elections approach, Shih urged members of the public to solve differences via rational debate, adding that verbal abuse and violence are not conducive to the development of democracy.

The NSB head stressed that he is confident about maintaining law and order in the period leading up to the presidential election, adding that he will step down if any major accident happens to any of the candidates.

Meanwhile, on the threat letter recently sent to President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsin-yu, Shi said his bureau has been collaborating with the National Police Administration (NPA) to try to track down the sender.
Shi said his bureau has handed the letter to the NPA for examination and has stepped up security measures to protect the personal safety of Chen Hsin-yu and her family.

On rumors that Chen Hsin-yu is planning to leave Taiwan for the United States out of fear for her personal safety after receiving the letter, apparently due to a lack of confidence in the NSB's ability to protect her, Shi said that if the rumors are indeed true, it would represent a failure for the NSB in carrying out its mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Right workers recall effort to help Taiwan political prisoners

TEXT.P: If risking your life for your beliefs and values is honorable, then trying to help those in a country thousands of miles away whom you don't even know and whose names you have a hard time pronouncing is equally appreciated.

That's what the group of international human rights workers invited to attend Monday's inauguration ceremony for the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park did almost 30 years ago through their collective efforts to put pressure on Taiwan authorities to release political prisoners.

Most of the human rights workers, who were based in the United States, Japan, Germany and several other countries, learned of the political prisoner cases in Taiwan by accident and never met the Taiwanese prisoners they helped save until last weekend when they together visited the new park which was once known as the Jingmei Military Detention Center.

Klaus Walter, head of the membership department of Amnesty International German Section, said he wanted to work on South American political prisoner cases at first but was assigned to handle a Taiwan case in 1975 as a 21-year-old student volunteer in Bonn, Germany.
"Maybe my Spanish wasn't good enough, " Walter said half-jokingly, adding that prior to that time, he had no idea where Taiwan was.

However, after starting to work on the case, he began to understand more about the political situation in Taiwan and, one year later, formed a Taiwan Coordination group whose task was to gather all available information on all political prisoners in Taiwan.

It was not easy because Taiwan officials had never answered AI letters, he said, forcing him to gather information via human rights groups in Japan and other countries. In addition, AI regulations required that staff obtain information from at least two different sources to confirm its credibility.

Masahiro Watarida chose a more direct way to gather information and became a victim himself. Watarida, who is now the secretary-general of Globalization Watch Hiroshima, visited Taiwan soon after the Kaohsiung Incident in 1979 to collect information on human rights violations.
When departing from Taiwan Dec. 21, 1979, Watarida was found carrying newspapers and magazines covering the incident. He was arrested, tortured and detained for 84 days.

Overseas Taiwanese also worked hard to seek international help. Roger Chao, a Germany-based Taiwanese reverend and one of the leaders of "Christians for Taiwan's Self-determination, " and his wife Doris worked with AI on extending assistance to victims of the incident.
"And because AI did not allow members to work on cases in their own country, Taiwanese members established a group to seek support from the international community, " Chao said.
International support and assistance were important because the people of Taiwan could not do much living under the authoritarian regime, Chao said.

The Hsieh Tsun-min case showed why the rescue of Taiwanese political prisoners was a global effort. Hsieh, who was imprisoned in 1964 for a public statement titled "A Declaration of Formosan Self-salvation" as a student at National Taiwan University, got acquainted with Japanese Taiwan independence supporter Masanari Kobayashi when both were in a Taiwan Garrison Command detention center in 1971.

Kobayashi had succeeded in distributing leaflets advocating Taiwan independence by flying baloons in Taipei but was later arrested and deported. Later, he helped send Hsieh's messages to international organizations. The messages were printed in the New York Times, which led to Hsieh's death sentence being rescinded later.
On Hsieh's visit to the AI German Section after his release, Rev. Chao recalled, a girl showed Hsieh a letter which had been sent to him seven years earlier but returned by Taiwan authorities.
"The girl was 17 years old when she sent the letter of support. Hsieh was in tears upon reading that letter, " Chao said.

Because Taiwan received so much international help during the period of "White Terror" in the country and because the country now enjoys full democracy, the people of Taiwan should start extending a helping hand to people in regions around the world who are suffering from the same sort of repression, Walter said.

"Think about Darfur, Sudan, where there's a major human rights crisis. Or think about Myanmar, which is closer to you in Asia, " he said, adding that it's time for Taiwan to extend help to those in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: Starkly different treatment for political prisoners: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that comparing special quarters for an imprisoned former Kuomintang (KMT) military intelligence officer and cells for political prisoners of the Kaohsiung Incident was like "heaven versus hell."
Chen made the remarks when he received Lord John Alderdice, president of Liberal International (LI), at the Presidential Office. LI is a world federation of liberal political parties.

He told Alderdice that he visited the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park in Hsintien, Taipei County earlier that same day and noted the stark difference in treatment for Wang Shi-ling, a former director of the Military Intelligence Bureau under the Ministry of the National Defense, and for those who were fighting for the freedom of Taiwan.

Chen was referring to pro-democracy activists who were put behind bars for their parts in the Dec. 10, 1979 Kaohsiung Incident, a peaceful demonstration to mark International Human Rights Day that turned violent after a government crackdown.

In addition to the cells for two of the defendants in the incident -- Vice President Annette Lu and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu -- Chen also visited Wang's "prison accommodation, " which he described as a villa complete with a studio, study and kitchen in which he was allowed to live with his family.

Wang was imprisoned after he instructed gangsters to go to the United States in 1984 to murder Chinese-American writer Henry Liu, better known by his pen-name Jiang Nan, who wrote a critical biography of the late President Chiang Ching- kuo.
The president said the Kaohsiung Incident helped spawn opposition parties in Taiwan, which he noted was a "political taboo" during the martial law era.
He said the incident and the subsequent military court trial turned into the threshold of Taiwan's democracy movement.
He said that he himself, aged under 30 at the time, was the defense lawyer of the top defendant, former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential and vice presidential candidates Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang also served as defense lawyers for the defendants during the trial.
The Jingmei park is a vast compound that used to house the military courts of the now defunct Taiwan Garrison Command and a detention center for political prisoners.
It was there the eight leaders of the Kaohsiung Incident, including Lu, Chen Chu and former DPP Chairmen Shih Ming-teh and Lin Yi-hsiung, stood trial under martial law.

Chen also said he was gratified that the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, a symbol of Chiang's authoritarian rule, has been renamed the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall and that the epigraph that reads "Liberty Square" has replaced an inscription that alluded to the late president above its main gateway.
