DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman meets foreign minister

TEXT.P: U.S-Taiwan relations are healthy overall but regarding the divergence between the two in certain political issues, there is plenty of room for communication, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said after meeting the chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Monday.

AIT Chairman Raymond Burghardt and Huang talked behind closed doors for 45 minutes at the Taipei Guest House, accompanied by AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young, AIT Deputy Director Robert Wang, and Douglas Spelman, the newly appointed director of the U.S. State Department's Office of Taiwan Coordination.
Huang described the timing of Burghardt's visit as "interesting" to which Burghardt responded that it is because recently there have been some "exciting things" going on in Taiwan.

Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of the Department of State for East Asian and Pacific affairs said the previous Friday that the U.S. opposes the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) planned referendum on joining the U.N. under the name of Taiwan, describing it as an attempt to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and a violation of President Chen Shui-bian's promise not to change the nation's title. Therefore, there was widespread anticipation among local political watchers as to whether Burghardt would reiterate the U.S.standpoint.
After the meeting, Huang said that because he and Burghardt are "old friends," they exchanged "candid" opinions.
Burghardt did not reveal details of their discussion, nor did he mention or comment on the DPP's planned referendum.

Burghardt was also scheduled to meet with Chen as well as DPP precidential candidate Frank Hsieh and opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou later in the day. He is scheduled to leave Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Austronesian Forum to be headquartered in Palau in 2008: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan has reached common consensus with Palau, one of its diplomatic allies in the Pacific, on a plan to have the Austronesian Forum headquartered in Palau, the minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) announced Monday.
Icyang Parod made the announcement at a press conference at the CIP to publicize the results of a Dec. 5-7 visit he made to Palau.
He said he also signed a memorandum on the plan with Palau's ministry in charge of national affairs.

The CIP has hosted the forum since 2002. Parod said the forum was formed based on the idea that Taiwan and its six Pacific allies should establish a regional organization dedicated to conducting discussions and exchanges on issues concerning the development of Austronesian culture in the South Pacific.
Other countries in the region, such as the Philippines, are also welcome to join the planned organization, the minister added.
The 2007 Austronesian Forum will take place Dec. 11-12 at the International Convention Center in Taipei, and Dec. 14 at the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung City, southeastern Taiwan.

Government and non-government leaders, academics and researchers, including Tumu te Heuheu, chief of the New Zealand tribe of Ngati Tuwharetoa, have been invited to share their opinions and research findings on traditional indigenous wisdom and indigenous intellectual property rights at the forum.

According to the organizers, the 2007 forum will serve as a platform for understanding Austronesian peoples' political, social, economic and cultural developments, as well as for building a compact and orderly network to enhance the world's awareness of and respect for indigenous people.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'IT Month' Expo in Taipei attracts 750,000 visitors

TEXT.P: This year's "IT Month" Expo attracted a total of 750,000 visitors during its nine-day run, which is similar to the number of visitors to last year's show, an organizer said Monday.

On the last two days of the annual event on Saturday and Sunday, companies with booths set up at the venue offered large discounts on an array of information- technology products and gave away many gifts to boost sales, a spokesman for the Taipei Computer Association said, adding that the show attracted about 120,000 visitors on Saturday and another 150,000 on Sunday.
Despite the high number of visitors to the expo, sales this year were not as good as those at last year's show, the spokesman said.

Describing this year's sales as being "M-shaped," or "polarized," the spokesman noted that prices of some laptop computers with high-class design were at least NT$10,000 (US$308) higher than those of regular laptops.
"However, the laptops with high-class designs were very popular at the show, with some models being sold out," the spokesman said.

Speaking on the overall market situation in Taiwan, the spokesman noted that sales of some Japanese-brand laptops have been strong. However, he continued, for laptop computers of other brands, "many people ask about them, but only a few actually end up buying them."

The expo will also be held in the central city of Taichung Dec. 14-19, in the southern county of Tainan Dec. 28-Jan. 2, and in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Jan. 10-15, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gourmet dumpling chefs to demonstrate skills in London
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/07 17:47:18 (By J.J. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: All 150 seats have been booked long in advance for a demonstration on making juicy pork dumplings that will be offered by chefs from Taipei's Ding Tai Feng Dumpling House at a debut to be held in London Monday.

Yang Chi-hua, owner of Taipei's Ding Tai Feng restaurant, led eight of his chefs to London recently at the invitation of Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to show off the restaurant's traditional Shanghai fare, particularly handmade dumplings, known as pork xiaolongbao and shrimp and crab shiaomai.

Among the 150 guests that are expected to crowd the tasting -- to be held at the Evergreen Group Building in London -- will be Chang Siao-yue, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom, and Lord Richard Faulkner of Worcester, a member of the House of Lords and a co-chairman of the British-Taiwan All-Party Parliamentary Group.
Chang and Faulkner will also try their hands at emulating the chefs in making dumplings.
Fuchsia Dunlop, a prize-winning food writer who writes for publications including Gourmet, Saveur and The Financial Times and who is a fluent Mandarin speaker, will serve as interpreter at the event.
During an interview with CNA, Yang said it is his honor to "do something for Taiwan, " given that the country faces seemingly insurmountable difficulties on its diplomatic front.

Yang, however, declined to affirm that Ding Tai Feng will open a branch operation in London, at least not in the near future, citing the fact that foodstuffs and ingredients in London cost about three times more than in Taipei.

Founded in Taipei's Yungkang Street in 1972, Ding Tai Feng has since made itself a legend with its dumplings, shrimp and crab shiaomai, fried shrimp rice, chicken noodle soup and Shanghai rice cakes. The restaurant was rated as one of the world's top 10 gourmet restaurants by the New York Times in 1993.
In addition to three outlets in Taipei, Ding Tai Feng also runs 41 branch restaurants in Japan, the United States, South Korea, China, Australia, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Professors urge removal of late president's statute from campus

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) urged a leading university Monday to remove a statute of the late President Chiang Kai-shek from its campus to demonstrate its will to remove the vestiges of the martial law era.
TAUP President Tsai Ting-kuei made the appeal after calling on National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) President Kuo Yi-hsiung.

Tsai described Chiang as the main culprit behind the brutal Feb. 28, 1947 incident and the ensuing "White Terror" period during martial law under Kuomintang rule, adding that he is seen as one of the dictators responsible for killing the most innocent citizens in modern Chinese history.
"Chiang was by no means a great man of Taiwan, but a criminal, " Tsai said.

He said the TAUP chose Monday -- International Human Rights Day -- to call on Kuo to suggest that the university remove the statue, saying that the symbol of authoritarian rule could "mislead college students."
If Taiwan wants to pursue freedom and democracy and take the path that enshrines human rights and rule of law, it is best to start with education, Tsai said.

Tsai noted that students of both National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Normal University were victimized during the White Terror, adding that NTU has removed its statue and that NTNU should follow suit.
In response, Kuo expressed appreciation to the TAUP for conveying one viewpoint, but urged respect for the university faculty's authority to handle school affairs independently.

He said the statue was built with donations from the faculty. NTNU Professor and sculptor Chueh Ming-teh then led a team of students who completed the work, which he said "has great artistic value" and "should be viewed as an artistic work, not from an ideological perspective."
Kuo said Taiwan is owned by all the country's people and that bygones should be bygones.

Yang Shu-huang, a professor of NTNU who is in charge of campus beautification, said it is estimated that the statue could fetch NT$100 million given its artistic value, and suggested that the school auction it to replenish school funds.
The TAUP's move followed the government's instruction to remove Chiang's statutes from all military barracks early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.322.
A total of US$561 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.309 and fluctuated between NT$32.270 and NT$32.335.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cannot afford to lose China market: economist

TEXT.P: Taiwan should have more open policies on cross-Taiwan Strait economics because it cannot afford to lose the emerging China market in its pursuit of development, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Jih-chu said Sunday.
Lee, who is also an economist, made the remarks at a forum held by the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER), a private think tank.

Lee was one of the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance's" representatives who attended the forum to give opinions on the China market and national energy policies for the future four to eight years. The forum was presided over by CHIER President Ko Chen-en and also attracted the participation of representatives from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green" camp.

Lee pointed out that due to its political situation, Taiwan cannot sign free trade pacts with other countries and thus has barriers to entering international markets. Under the circumstances, emerging markets with great business potential, such as China's, can serve as a springboard for Taiwan to seek business in the global market, Lee said.
In order to improve its international competitiveness and bring future economic development, Lee said Taiwan will have to upgrade its manufacturing industry and internationalize its service industry.

As to national energy policies, Lee said Taiwan, as a small country that relies heavily on exports, has to fully understand international norms on environmental protection and energy saving in order to cope with changes in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct links with China would boost real estate prices: developer

TEXT.P: Direct transport links with China would boost Taiwan's real estate prices by 30 percent, Chao Teng-hsiung, president of the Farglory Land Development Co., estimated Monday.
Chao predicted that the local real estate market will grow by 5 percent to 10 percent annually in the near future barring political disturbance.

However, the growth would reach 10 percent if the government opened the country to tourists arriving from China, and would hit 20 percent if the government were to ease restrictions on foreigners purchasing real estate in Taiwan.
The developer portrayed a rosy picture for the country's real estate market next year, given the fact that the international economy is predicted to be quite good.

Although the prices of sand and gravel have increased six- to seven-fold this year, Chao said it will decline a little bit after the government allows imports of sand and gravel from Vietnam. However, he went on, this is unlikely to bring down real estate prices, as Taiwan's misery index for real estate and luxury buildings is the lowest in the world.

For the time being, Chao said, foreigners who want to own real property in Taiwan have to navigate through a great deal of government red tape, which he claimed takes "about half a year" and which therefore puts many potential foreign real estate investors off.

Noting that the delivery of new houses in America is rising, Chao said the United States is emerging from the negative impact of the sub-prime mortgage crisis, which bodes well for the economies of other places, including Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most seized smuggled cigarettes fake Japanese brands

TEXT.P: Most of the 6.1 million packs of smuggled cigarettes seized in Taiwan as of Nov. 18 and worth about NT$336 million (US$10.4 million) are fake Japanese brands, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

The figures were unveiled after a report published a day earlier in Japan's Sankei Shimbun that in order to gain foreign currency reserves, North Korea has 10 factories manufacturing counterfeit Japanese cigarettes and is smuggling them into Taiwan.
In the past, a major source of North Korea's foreign reserves came from amphetamine production, according to the report.

However, due to heavy crackdowns on the drug in many countries, two of the three amphetamine factories in North Korea have shut down, the report said, noting that North Korea has switched to producing counterfeit cigarettes.
These cigarette factories help North Korea earn foreign reserves worth between US$500 million and US$700 million annually, according to the report.
Taiwan is the largest market for the North Korean counterfeit cigarettes, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peruvian woman with lymph edema recovering well in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Peruvian woman with a lymph edema that caused a 47 kg swelling on her left leg received successful surgery at the E-Da Hospital in southern Taiwan in November and is recovering well, a hospital spokesman said Sunday.
Maria Rosario Razzeto, 45, came to Taiwan Nov. 9 with her son to receive the operation with the coordination and assistance from Chang Chia-hau, a doctor at the hospital.
Razzeto praised the medical team while being interviewed by a group of journalists from Central and South America who were covering her story.

Razzeto, who began to suffer primary lymphoedema 26 years ago, revealed that her "giant leg" made it difficult for her to move and that she felt too ashamed to go out, not to mention the pain caused by the illness. Primary lymphoedema is often due to an underdeveloped lymphatic system.
After the operation, Razzeto now can walk with the help of a walking frame and she can also now bend her left leg.
Lin Yu-ching, director of E-Da Hospital's rehabilitation center, said Razzeto might be able to walk normally after one or two months of physiotherapy.
Due to Razzeto's poverty, the E-Da Hospital covered her operation costs and is also planning to give her a tooth implant after she comes back to Taiwan next February or March to give her a new smile.

DOC.HEADLINE: New KMT spokeswoman urges ruling party to stop `ugly fight'

TEXT.P: The newly appointed spokeswoman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Monday to stop its "ugly" political fight with the KMT.

Chen Shu-jung, former director of the KMT's Youth Division, replaced Su Jun-pin as the KMT's mouthpiece. Wu was reappointed as spokesman for KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate, Vincent Siew.

At her first press conference, Chen said she was "sickened to death" by foul- mouthed invective spewed by Chuang Kuo-jung, secretary-general of the Ministry of Education, against the KMT's presidential candidate.

Chuang has made a series of unprovoked verbal assaults against Ma over the past few days, ridiculing Ma -- a politician with a public image of civility, good temperament and gentlemanliness -- as being effeminate and lacking masculine qualities. His venomous remarks triggered a backlash from women, mothers and gay groups.
"I, too, could say that Chuang is not man enough, but then what is the meaning in all this?" Chen asked.
Chen urged the DPP leadership and members to do something meaningful for the people instead of indulging themselves in ugly partisan fights.
The KMT spokesman also said the KMT's publicity campaign for the Jan. 12 legislative elections will focus on the theme: "Keep Taiwan Running."

DOC.HEADLINE: Work to relocate historic Taipei Workshop starts

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government began the challenging task Monday of moving the nearly 100-year-old Taipei Workshop -- a train manufacturing and repair facility located near the North Gate in downtown Taipei -- 30 meters to the southeast in an effort to save the historic relic during the construction of a new Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) line.
Taipei City Director of Cultural Affairs Lee Yung-pin praised the relocation as a landmark move in the capital city's efforts to preserve its cultural legacy.

During a ceremony filled with sound of gongs and drums, the old workshop, with a net weight of 1,040 tons, was lifted from the ground by 35 huge oil jacks. Six computer-controlled oil-pressure machines were commissioned to push the building to its new location, according to a local house-moving company contracted to carry out the work.

It will take an estimated nine days to move the building to its new temporary location, where it will remain until 2012, when the construction of the new MRT Songshan Line is completed, Taipei City Department of Rapid Transit Systems officials said.
It will then be moved back to its original location, the officials added.

The Taipei Workshop was constructed in 1909 as the Machine Bureau controlled by the Qing Dynasty. During the Japanese occupation, it was used for maintaining and repairing trains, as well as for making and assembling new trains.

The workshop built 10 wooden trains, each around 14 meters long, in the early part of the 20th Century, according to the Taipei City Department of Cultural Affairs, which also revealed that the rigid frames for the workshop's roof are guessed to be abandoned railway tracks built during the period of Liu Ming-chuan (1836-1896) , Taiwan's governor during the late Qing Dynasty who is acclaimed as the mastermind behind the construction of Taiwan's rail system.

DOC.HEADLINE: President encourages students to have passion for science

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday encouraged participants in the Fourth International Junior Science Olympiad (IJSO) to keep studying science after they graduate, despite what he claimed will be "the loneliness" that awaits them during the exploration process.

Chen made the remarks at the event's closing ceremony. The 10-day international event was held for the first time in Taiwan this year and was organized by National Taiwan Normal University and the Ministry of Education.
The IJSO brought together 220 students from 40 countries to compete in theoretical tests and experimental examinations in the fields of mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology and earth science.

Chen said the students should have learned more from the teamwork during the 10 days than from the competition itself and he encouraged them to make further efforts in their studies in order to contribute their knowledge to the world in the future.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung praised the instructors' enlightenment of the students, quoting Irish poet William Butler Yeats, who wrote: "Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire."

He encouraged students to make breakthroughs in personal growth and expressed the hope that the event has facilitated cultural exchanges among different countries and has enriched the students' learning experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temple receives NT$130 million in donations from followers

TEXT.P: A noted temple in southern Taiwan reported recently that it had received NT$130 million (US$3.9 million) in donations from followers in a single year, which temple officials described as "a phenomenon" in this period of economic slowdown.

Management of the Chaotien Temple in Peikang, in Yunlin County, said the donations between June 1, 2006 and June 30, 2007 represented an increase of NT$50 million when compared with an average annual donation of NT$80 million for previous years.

However, the expenditure during the same period was also huge, at NT$70 million. The management said the expenses mainly went to the maintenance of the temple, salary for the staff and visits to other temples, as well as the sponsoring of various activities.

The management said that the pilgrimage season usually peaks between the first and the third months of the lunar calendar, during which around 1 million followers will donate to the temple, usually accounting for about half of the annual donations.
The management attributed the large increase in donations to the sluggish economy, which has made the public even more keen to pray to Matsu, one of the most popular deities in Taiwan, for good luck.

The other reason is that the directors and supervisors that were elected last October were dedicated to reform and their efforts in making the financial status more transparent and accountable have won the trust of the followers.

For example, the temple began to check gold plates donated by followers over the past decade this April and announced that the total amounted to 2.223 taels, worth a market value of NT$40 million. The temple also announced that donations in the first six months this year totaled NT$86 million. Each tael is about 37.5 grams.

Followers are positive about the new management team, with one follower saying the new measures will show that the donations have not been squandered, which will in turn make people more willing to donate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese peace advocates power of civil society

TEXT.P: A Japanese peace advocate Monday encouraged Taiwanese youth to have the courage to take risks and try to build a peaceful and sustainable Taiwan through their energy and innovative efforts.

The power of civil society in the post-Cold War era has a proven, international track record of making a difference, said Tastuya Yoshioka, Founder and Director of Peace Boat -- a Japan-based non-government organization (NGO) which advocates peace, human rights, sustainable development and environmental protection.

In Japan, young people are taught that risk-taking is wrong, but as we face the ongoing threats such as militarism, nuclear weapons, climate change and global epidemics, all global citizens should step up and do something, he said.

The United Nations framework is important to solving global issues, but it's neither perfect nor able to do it alone. Unfortunately, given the fact that security council member states all make money from wars, world peace is paid little more than lip service, he told more than 100 National Taiwan University students in a lecture.
That's why civil societies can and should come in and make impacts, said Yoshioka, who founded Peace Boat in 1983 as a university student.

Human security, rather than national security, is one of the most important concepts of a civil society, he said, adding that the key is protecting the human being, not the politicians, companies or states.

Yoshioka, 46, established the organization at a time when the issue of Japan's revisionist history high school textbooks was first becoming controversial. He was shocked that neighboring countries in Asia were protesting about the content of the textbooks.

Peace Boat visited Taiwan on its third voyage in 1986 for a meeting with Taiwanese democracy activists. As Taiwan was still under an authoritarian regime, the boat was seized, searched and detained. It is because of that experience that Taiwan has always held a very special place in his heart, Yoshioka said.
Commenting on the cross-Straight issue, Yoshioka said in a media interview Sunday that something along the lines of the European Union format would be an option.
"People can't forget the terrible past, but at the same time they can start reconcile, " he said.
For the past 24 years, Peace Boat has sailed on nearly 60 voyages and visited more than 100 countries, including conflict zones such as Eritrea, Cuba, Sierra Leone and the Balkans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to hold party to celebrate Maokong Gondola's new record

TEXT.P: The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) announced Monday that it will hold a musical party Dec. 21 to celebrate the Maokong Gondola system carrying its 2 millionth passenger.

The cable car system, linking two popular tourist attractions -- the Taipei City Zoo and Maokong, which is famous as a tea growing area -- in the capital city, hosted its 2 millionth passenger Sunday, only five months after its formal inauguration on July 4, TRTC officials said.
The planned musical party will take place at a large parking lot opposite to the zoo, according to the TRTC which operates the gondola system.
Several popular pop singers will join the party, at which there will also be a prize drawing activity and limited free coffee, TRTC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation recognizes those dedicated to Taiwanese language

TEXT.P: A cultural foundation dedicated to the promotion of the Taiwanese language has presented awards to authors and poets writing in local languages and academics conducting relevant research, a spokesman for the foundation said Monday.

The recipients of the "A-Khioh" award are undergraduate and graduate students recognized for using their mother tongues, including the Taiwanese language -- also known as the Holo language -- the Hakka languages, and the indigenous languages.

Tiunn Hok Chu, a board of director of the foundation, said that in recent years, an increasing number of young people have begun to create literary works in the Holo language, and many of them have staged outstanding performances.
However, Tiunn said that he feels greatly disappointed over the government's failure to establish a special council to promote the Holo language and culture.
Tiunn said he hopes that there will be such a council in the future, which will also be on the equal footing with the Council for Hakka Affairs and the Council of Indigenous Peoples.

Liao Ruey-ming, an assistant professor at Chung Shan Medical University's Department of Taiwanese Languages who is also a judge for the award, said that there are approximately 80 literary awards every year in Taiwan.
However, Liao questioned whether these awards have effectively raised the public's awareness of culture in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, he also said he hopes that the "A-Khioh" award will spawn a comprehensive movement to promote Taiwanese languages, to preserve the environment for the languages, and to further encourage research on the cultures of the languages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers, public unhappy with anti-corruption efficacy: survey

TEXT.P: A majority of the respondents to a recent opinion poll have singled out legislators and public functionaries as the most corrupt people in Taiwan, according to the results of the survey released by the Transparency International's Taiwan chapter Monday.

Public functionaries in charge of procurement and public construction projects, legislators and local governmental officials in charge of the gravel industry, in that order, are considered the most corrupt groups in the country, according to the poll, conducted in July.

Up to 68 percent of the respondents said they feel that the administration does not have the teeth to crack down on corruption and embezzlement, while 65 percent said government efforts to stop bribery, graft and vote-buying are insufficient.

A total of 64 percent of the respondents said they feel the administration may never succeed in eradicating graft among public office holders if it only imposes fines without jail terms for those found to have not honestly reported their properties and assets.
The respondents singled out voting-buying, influence-peddling and bribery as the top three irregularities, according to the poll results.
They also consider corruption in state-run enterprises as more rampant than in privately run companies.
On the government's determination to weed out corruption, 41 percent said they are pessimistic, while 36 percent said they are optimistic, according to the results.

Based on a 0-10 scale reflecting the integrity of civil servants, the respondents considered medical professionals working at public health institutions as those with the highest level of integrity, at 6.8 points, while public functionaries in charge of procurement and public construction projects, legislators, and local government officials in charge of the gravel industry are considered to have the lowest levels of integrity, scoring less than 4 points.
The survey of adults randomly selected nationwide was conducted by telephone between July 1-5. It obtained 1,616 valid responses, with a margin of error of 2.5 percent.
Transparency International, a non-government group based in Berlin with branches in more than 90 countries, said leaders can combat corruption only if they made a determined effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to host IAVE regional conference in 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/07 21:53:58 (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will host the 12th Asian and Pacific regional conference of the International Association for Volunteer Effort (IAVE) to be held in 2009 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Taiwan obtained the right to host the event at the 11th Asian and Pacific conference of IAVE, which just concluded after four days in Nagoya, Japan Monday, with the participation of some IAVE 600 members from 11 Asian and Pacific countries.
The IAVE is an international non-governmental organization that promotes, celebrates, and strengthens voluntarism worldwide,

Chiang Kuo-chiang, vice chairman of the NGO Affairs Committee under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), who serves as honorary head of the Taiwan delegation, noted that Taiwan's gaining the right to host the event is a success for Taiwan's diplomacy as it faced a strong rival from South Korea, which sent a 120-member delegation to the event.
Chiang added that it was the long-term contribution of IAVE Taiwan and the determination and professionalism of the Taiwan delegation that won the votes of the IAVE members.

The 30-member Taiwan delegation was arranged by IAVE Taiwan and composed of students from 10 universities, representatives from eight civic organizations and various government agencies including MOFA, Ministry of the Interior, Council for Cultural Affairs and National Youth Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese democracy activists to observe Taiwan's elections

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese democracy activists arrived in Taiwan Monday to observe Taiwan's upcoming elections with the aim of better understanding Taiwan's democratic politics and electoral culture.

The five-member delegation, headed by Xu Wenli, one of the founders of the China Democracy Party (CDP) , which announced its founding in June 1998 with the goal of fighting for fairness and freedom of the Chinese people.

As the CDP also advocates fair popular elections in China, its establishment has not been approved by Chinese authorities. In addition, many of the CDP members have been persecuted by the Chinese government after being accused of trying to sabotage the country. The CDP's headquarters is now located in exile in the United States, with Xu being its convener.

During their stay here, the delegation will visit the campaign offices of candidates of various Taiwanese political parties running in the country's upcoming legislative and presidential elections early next year.

An official of the Taipei-based Chinese Youth Solidarity, which invited the CDP delegation to Taiwan, said the delegation is composed of executives of the CDP, and he believes that they will thoroughly study the procedure of Taiwan's democratization and come to better understand mainstream Taiwanese public opinions.
Xu's delegation was denied entry by the Hong Kong government Dec. 7, where they planned to attend a seminar organized by a civic group there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's largest fitness chain ceases operations

TEXT.P: The owner of Alexander Health Club -- Taiwan's largest fitness chain with a 26-year history -- announced Monday that the cash-strapped company would immediate cease operations.

Candy Tang, chairwoman of the club with more than 20 branches throughout Taiwan, explained that the company could not continue operating in the red, despite an injection of funds from its branches in China into local operations.

Tang's announcement came suddenly, without any prior warning of the company's troubled financial conditions. Many of its more than 200,000 members have annual and long-term contracts, and were stunned and worried that they might not be able to get refunds on their prepaid membership fees.

According to data provided by the Clearing House of the Taiwan Payments Clearing System Development Foundation, 23 checks issued by Alexander, in total worth NT$102.1 million, have bounced as of Dec. 10.

Regulations promulgated by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council in mid- August this year require that health club operators keep a portion of the membership income in reserve to safeguard consumers' contracts within the first year in the event of a club going bankrupt. The regulations, however, do not provide protection for individual membership fees amounting to less than NT$50,000.

Alexander's 23 branches with an annual turnover of NT2 billion are mostly located in the greater Taipei area. To join the club, a member was required to pay an initiation fee of NT$25,000, plus NT$62,500 for a five-year contract and an annual sanitation charge of NT$1,000. The fees could be paid in installments.

Later in the day, Consumers' Foundation workers indicated that they had received 80 requests from Alexander members seeking help to get their money back, and that the foundation is prepared to file a class action on behalf of these consumers.

Meanwhile, the Bankers's Association of the Republic of China urged Alexander members who have been paying their membership fees in installments using their credit cards to ask their banks to cancel further payments immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA explains difficulties of LSA coverage for foreign caregivers

TEXT.P: Offering coverage under the Labor Standards Act (LSA) to foreign caregivers in Taiwan is "technically infeasible, " an official of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The remarks came after an alliance comprised of several foreign labor human rights groups took to the street Sunday to demand that the government include the 160,000 foreign caregivers working in Taiwan in the labor act.
In addition, members of the alliance asked the government to resume providing respite care services to families with foreign caregivers.
In response, CLA Deputy Chairwoman Tsao Ai-lan said that unlike foreign factory workers, it is difficult to separate family caregivers' working time from rest time.
There would be a lot of disputes if the act were extended to include foreign caregivers, Tsao noted.

Tsao also said that foreign caregivers often take care of those who are incapable of moving; as a result, the government cannot require foreign caregivers to take a break after working for certain hours.

On the resumption of respite care services, Tsao said that Taiwan has a serious lack of family caregivers and, as a result, the government should allow those families that are unable to hire foreign caregivers to have priority access to respite care services.

Meanwhile, she also said that local employers of foreign caregivers should not ask their foreign caregivers to do all of the care work, urging the employers to give their foreign employees some days off.
Tsao suggested foreign caregivers negotiate their rights with their employers, noting that if foreign caregivers' rights are trespassed, they can file a complaint with local labor bureaus.
Labor bureau officials will immediately offer assistance and take foreign caregivers to temporary shelters, Tsao noted.

Responding to the alliance's request that the government use the employment security fund to hire local caregivers to provide respite care services to foreign caregivers, Tsao said that local employers of foreign caregivers pay the fund every month for the reduced job opportunities of local disadvantaged workers.
Therefore, the government should use the fund to provide subsidies to local disadvantaged workers, rather than foreign caregivers, Tsao noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. friendship keeping president from taking drastic move

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he has refrained from holding a defensive referendum over China's misinterpretation of U.N. Resolution No. 2758 after taking into consideration U.S. friendship for Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt, who is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Also present at the meeting was Stephen Young, director of the AIT Taipei Office, and other officials.

China, based on its misinterpretation of the U.N. resolution, has repeatedly declared at international gatherings that "Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China (PRC) " or "the PRC includes Taiwan and is the only legitimate government representing China," Chen said.

Noting that such claims have gravely undermined the present cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, Chen said he could hold a referendum to defend Taiwan's sovereignty in line with the country's Referendum Act.
Article 17 of the Referendum Act stipulates that the president is empowered to call a "defensive" referendum on the country's future whenever its sovereign status is endangered.
Chen said he has refrained from doing so out of consideration of the traditionally cordial, friendly relations between Taiwan and the United States.

Referring to a planned referendum on whether Taiwan should apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen said the initiative was proposed by private groups and has received the endorsement of more than 2 million members of the public.

As Taiwan is now a democratic country ruled by law, Chen said he cannot overrule or veto such an initiative. "We must follow our constitutional provision and the stipulations of the Referendum Act," he stressed.

Chen further explained that the U.N. bid referendum has two purposes. "First, we don't like to continually engage in the longstanding battle with China over the right to represent 'one China' and look forward to joining the U.N. in the name of Taiwan; second, we want to have our desire to join the U.N. heard by people around the world through the upcoming referendum," he explained.
The president further accentuated that the referendum has nothing to do with changing Taiwan's official title and does not violate his "four noes" pledge.

"In keeping with custom, we'll hold a flag-raising ceremony on Jan. 1, 2008 to mark the Republic of China's 97th founding anniversary and I'll definitely attend the ceremony, as I did in the past, " Chen told his guests.

He also hailed as a mark of "full respect for Taiwan people's democratic choice" the remarks by Young and Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, that the U.S. government will cooperate with Taiwan's new president no matter who wins the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

As to future cross-strait relations, Chen said: "While I have no idea what my successor will tell our people and the U.S. government and friends, I can guarantee that the 'four noes' promise I made to the U.S. government and President George W. Bush in 2000 and have strictly observed over the past eight years, will remain intact before my term expires next May."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGTailored testing for pupils at primaries
Children are to be taught and tested at their own pace and primary school pupils will study fewer subjects to concentrate more on the basics and a foreign language, under a radical shake-up to be announced tomorrow.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reporters Without Borders stages demonstration in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: The Reporters Without Borders (RWB) , a Paris-based international non- governmental organization dedicated to promoting press freedom, staged a demonstration in Hong Kong Monday -- International Human Rights Day -- to protest against the Chinese government's suppression of human rights.

A large flag showing the Olympic rings transformed into handcuffs was revealed outside the Liaison Office of the Chinese government in Hong Kong by five RWB representatives, including its secretary-general, Robert Menard.

One RWB representative said despite China's promise to improve its human rights situation and press freedom when Beijing was awarded the 2008 Olympics in 2001, its refusal to give visas to RWB members is evidence of its determination to keep critics at a distance, which is what prompted the RWB to call for attention to the situation in China.

Earlier in August, four RWB representatives, including RWB President Fernando Castello and Vice President Rubina Mohring, as well as Menard, were arrested and escorted to the airport for giving an unauthorized news conference outside the building of the Olympic Games Organizing Committee in Beijing.

China is notorious for persecuting journalists, cyber-dissidents and free speech activists, and the situation seems to be worsening, the RWB representatives said, adding that even though the authorities eased the regulations governing the work of foreign journalists in January because of the coming Olympic Games, there have been at least 60 cases of police detaining or obstructing foreign correspondents since then.

The RWB representatives said that although it has written several letters to Jacques Rogge, president of the International Olympic Committee ( IOC), asking for intervention in China's refusal to guarantee freedom of expression and to respect the Olympic Charter's humanistic values, the IOC has remained silent.

"We are not trying to spoil a major sports event, but who will be able to say these games have been a success when thousands of prisoners of conscience languish in Chinese jails, and who will be able to believe in the `One World, One Dream' slogan when Tibetan and Uyghur minorities are subject to serious discrimination? " Menard asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday.
The weighted price index was up 50.85 points at 8,648.88 on a turnover of NT$2 billion (US$61.88 million) at the open. The index plunged 124.35 points, or 1.43 percent, to close at 8,598.03 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: President rules out martial law, deferment of election

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has said he will not use anything as an excuse for imposing martial law.

There will also be no question of deferring the two critical elections scheduled for early next year, Chen noted, adding that the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election will take place as originally slated.

Chen made the remarks Monday in an interview with the Associated Press (AP) . He gave the interview after meeting with visiting American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt, who is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
During the interview, AP reporters asked Chen whether he is likely to declare Taiwan independence before he retires next May to force China to respond before the Beijing Olympic Games.
In reply, Chen said some people in Beijing claim he will do something unexpected during the election season, including declaring independence.
"This is completely not the case, " Chen said, adding that such rhetoric is just an intimidation from China and an excuse by China to pressure the United States to speak against him.
Rebutting China's accusation, Chen said he has assured Burghardt that Taiwan will not backpedal and that he will by no means impose martial law or defer the legislative and presidential elections.

Touching on the planned referendum on the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen reiterated that as the referendum initiative has been proposed by grassroots civic groups, he is unlikely to overrule or veto it. Moreover, he said the referendum is neither a referendum on Taiwan independence nor a step toward de jure independence.

On U.S. concern about the ramifications or impact of the U.N. bid referendum, Chen said he treasures U.S. opinions and is more than willing to communicate frankly with U.S. authorities over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 11, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan- chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

The greenback was trading at NT$32.330 at 10: 00 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.008 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's largest fitness chain ceases operations

TEXT.P: The owner of Alexander Health Club -- Taiwan's largest fitness chain with a 26-year history -- announced Monday that the cash-strapped company would immediate cease operations.

Candy Tang, chairwoman of the club with more than 20 branches throughout Taiwan, explained that the company could not continue operating in the red, despite an injection of funds from its branches in China into local operations.

Tang's announcement came suddenly, without any prior warning of the company's troubled financial conditions. Many of its more than 200,000 members have annual and long-term contracts, and were stunned and worried that they might not be able to get refunds on their prepaid membership fees.

According to data provided by the Clearing House of the Taiwan Payments Clearing System Development Foundation, 23 checks issued by Alexander, in total worth NT$102.1 million, have bounced as of Dec. 10.

Regulations promulgated by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council in mid- August this year require that health club operators keep a portion of the membership income in reserve to safeguard consumers' contracts within the first year in the event of a club going bankrupt. The regulations, however, do not provide protection for individual membership fees amounting to less than NT$50,000.

Alexander's 23 branches with an annual turnover of NT2 billion are mostly located in the greater Taipei area. To join the club, a member was required to pay an initiation fee of NT$25,000, plus NT$62,500 for a five-year contract and an annual sanitation charge of NT$1,000. The fees could be paid in installments.

Later in the day, Consumers' Foundation workers indicated that they had received 80 requests from Alexander members seeking help to get their money back, and that the foundation is prepared to file a class action on behalf of these consumers.

Meanwhile, the Bankers's Association of the Republic of China urged Alexander members who have been paying their membership fees in installments using their credit cards to ask their banks to cancel further payments immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA explains difficulties of LSA coverage for foreign caregivers

TEXT.P: Offering coverage under the Labor Standards Act (LSA) to foreign caregivers in Taiwan is "technically infeasible, " an official of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The remarks came after an alliance comprised of several foreign labor human rights groups took to the street Sunday to demand that the government include the 160,000 foreign caregivers working in Taiwan in the labor act.
In addition, members of the alliance asked the government to resume providing respite care services to families with foreign caregivers.
In response, CLA Deputy Chairwoman Tsao Ai-lan said that unlike foreign factory workers, it is difficult to separate family caregivers' working time from rest time.
There would be a lot of disputes if the act were extended to include foreign caregivers, Tsao noted.

Tsao also said that foreign caregivers often take care of those who are incapable of moving; as a result, the government cannot require foreign caregivers to take a break after working for certain hours.

On the resumption of respite care services, Tsao said that Taiwan has a serious lack of family caregivers and, as a result, the government should allow those families that are unable to hire foreign caregivers to have priority access to respite care services.

Meanwhile, she also said that local employers of foreign caregivers should not ask their foreign caregivers to do all of the care work, urging the employers to give their foreign employees some days off.
Tsao suggested foreign caregivers negotiate their rights with their employers, noting that if foreign caregivers' rights are trespassed, they can file a complaint with local labor bureaus.
Labor bureau officials will immediately offer assistance and take foreign caregivers to temporary shelters, Tsao noted.

Responding to the alliance's request that the government use the employment security fund to hire local caregivers to provide respite care services to foreign caregivers, Tsao said that local employers of foreign caregivers pay the fund every month for the reduced job opportunities of local disadvantaged workers.
Therefore, the government should use the fund to provide subsidies to local disadvantaged workers, rather than foreign caregivers, Tsao noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. friendship keeping president from taking drastic move

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he has refrained from holding a defensive referendum over China's misinterpretation of U.N. Resolution No. 2758 after taking into consideration U.S. friendship for Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt, who is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Also present at the meeting was Stephen Young, director of the AIT Taipei Office, and other officials.

China, based on its misinterpretation of the U.N. resolution, has repeatedly declared at international gatherings that "Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China (PRC) " or "the PRC includes Taiwan and is the only legitimate government representing China," Chen said.

Noting that such claims have gravely undermined the present cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, Chen said he could hold a referendum to defend Taiwan's sovereignty in line with the country's Referendum Act.
Article 17 of the Referendum Act stipulates that the president is empowered to call a "defensive" referendum on the country's future whenever its sovereign status is endangered.
Chen said he has refrained from doing so out of consideration of the traditionally cordial, friendly relations between Taiwan and the United States.

Referring to a planned referendum on whether Taiwan should apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen said the initiative was proposed by grassroots private groups and has received the endorsement of more than 2 million members of the public. "It has nothing to do with the president," he added.

As Taiwan is now a democratic country ruled by law, Chen said the cannot revoke such a referendum initiative. "We must follow our constitutional provision and the stipulations of the Referendum Act," he stressed.

Chen further explained that the U.N. bid referendum has two purposes. "First, we don't like to continually engage in the longstanding battle with China over the right to represent 'one China' and look forward to joining the U.N. in the name of Taiwan; second, we want to have our desire to join the U.N. heard by people around the world through the upcoming referendum," he explained.
The president further accentuated that the referendum has nothing to do with changing Taiwan's official title and does not violate his "four noes" pledge.

"In keeping with custom, we'll hold a flag-raising ceremony on Jan. 1, 2008 to mark the Republic of China's 97th founding anniversary and I'll definitely attend the ceremony, as I did in the past, " Chen told his guests.

He also hailed as a mark of "full respect for Taiwan people's democratic choice" the remarks by Young and Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, that the U.S. government will cooperate with Taiwan's new president no matter who wins the March 22, 2008 presidential election.

As to future cross-strait relations, Chen said he cannot possibly influence what the next Taiwan president may do. "But I here can guarantee that the previous pledge of 'four noes' I made to the U.S. government and President George W. Bush would by no means change before my term ends, " he elaborated, adding that although he was repeatedly nudged by someone to cross the line over the past more than seven years, he has not done so.
The "four noes" pledge is a list of things Taipei will not do that could lead to de jure independence which Beijing has vowed to obstruct by force.
Burghardt's visit comes as the Taipei-Washington ties hit a nadir over the contentious U.N. bid referendum that has angered Beijing.

On the U.S. call for canceling the referendum plan, Chen said he takes seriously the U.S. concerns. While paying homage to Washington's status as "a faithful ally, " Chen said the U.S. is misinterpreting the spirit of the U.N. referendum.
"The U.S. seems to worry excessively, and its understanding of some issues does not match reality," Chen added.

The president further said he expected the U.S. to come to Taiwan's aid in the event China attacked. However, he said Taiwan did not expect Washington to provide a substitute for Taiwan's own armed forces, and pledged to do everything in his power to improve their defense capabilities, including implementing a significant increase in defense spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT not 'troublemaker' party: presidential candidate

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that if elected, he will not unilaterally change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, pointing out that the KMT is not a "troublemaker."

Ma made comments in response to reporters' questions while stumping for KMT legislative candidate Liao Cheng-ching in Yangmei, Taoyuan County when asked about his meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt in Taipei the previous day.

According to Ma, the AIT head expressed concerns about several issues, including cross-strait relations, U.S.-Taiwan ties, Taiwan's upcoming legislative and presidential elections, and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-proposed referendum on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Ma told the reporters that he reassured Burghardt by saying that the KMT has always been a party of peace and that if he is elected, he will not work to unilaterally alter the cross-strait status quo.
When asked about the proposed U.N. bid referendum, Ma said that the public's interest in the issue has already receded and that people are focused on issues related to their livelihood.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's U.N. referendum causes trouble: AIT Chairman

TEXT.P: All that Taiwan's United Nations (U.N.) referendum does is cause trouble, and it will box in Taiwan's next president, American Institute in Taipei Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Tuesday, reiterating the United States' opposition to the referendum.

"All it [the referendum] does is cause trouble, " Burghardt said in a round table with members of the local media. The top AIT official is concluding a visit to Taiwan during which he has met with President Chen Shui-bian, presidential candidates Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh, and other political figures.

It is the second harsh criticism of the proposed referendum leveled by a U.S. official within the last two weeks, following Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Thomas Christensen's remarks in a meeting with members of Taiwan's press Dec. 6 in Washington, D.C.
Christensen said that the United States supports Taiwan's having a wholesome democracy but that a bad democracy or a process packaged as democracy is not true democracy.

The referendum on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is a "clever way" of not violating the pledges that President Chen Shui- bian had made by going through the "back door, " but the United States still interprets it as a violation, he said.
Even if it did not go against the "four noes" pledge, it "came pretty close sometimes, " he added.
Taiwanese officials have described the referendum as a vote against unification with China and for sovereignty, which is more than the contents of the referendum itself, he said.

The United States has the highest regard for Taiwan's democracy, but the referendum unnecessarily threatens cross-strait stability, which has been the United States' main concern in the region, he said.

However, he noted that the United States does value Chen's reassurance Monday of keeping his promises and ensuring a peaceful transition of power after the presidential election next year and has asked China to be patient and show self- restraint ahead of the election.

Burghardt said his meeting with Chen could be summarized as making sure the new president, regardless of who it is, has the chance to be his own man to deal with the cross-straight issue and is not "boxed-in."

The referendum is not fair to the next president not only because holding the referendum will make things difficult for him but also because if it is passes, this will make his job even harder, Burghardt said, adding that the intention of holding the referendum is to bind the hands of Chen's successor.
"The referendum also affects the cross-strait atmosphere and the attitude of the region," he said.
The results of the referendum will not change Washington's one-China policy, even though Chen has said passage of the referendum would prove the policy wrong, Burghardt pointed out.

Responding to a question regarding how the United States will react to the results of the referendum, Burghardt said that it will be important to watch and listen carefully to who says what before, during and after the referendum. Remarks and responses from Chen, both presidential candidates and other countries will be closely monitored, he added.

Burghardt did not directly answer the question posed by a reporter about whether China has "outsourced" the work of containing Taiwan to the United States, but he admitted that the Hu Jintao administration has been more adept and sophisticated in dealing with trilateral relations between the United States, Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: RSF founder in Taiwan for four-day visit

TEXT.P: Reporters sans Frontieres (RSF) Secretary-General and founder Robert Menard is in Taiwan for a four-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Tuesday.

The main purpose of Menard's current visit is to attend a news conference scheduled for Wednesday for the release of the China Human Rights Report 2007 by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) and the presentation ceremony of the TFD's Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award 2007 slated for Thursday, MOFA officials said.

Menard, who won the award in 2006, last visited Taiwan in January this year to receive the award. This year's winner is Cynthia Maung, founder of the Mae Sot Clinic serving Burmese refugees on the Thai-Burmese border.

During his visit, Menard will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu and call on Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming- tong, Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey and MOFA Secretary- General Liang Ying-pin. Menard will also visit the Taiwan Association of Taiwan Journalists and the French Institute in Taipei.
The RSF, founded in 1985 in Paris, is an international non-governmental organization advocating for freedom of the press. The organization now has branches and offices on all five continents.
The group issues the Worldwide Press Freedom Index annually to measure the degree of freedom journalists and media have in more than 160 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.3 points, or 0.46 percent, to close at 8,638.33.
The bourse opened at 8,648.88 and fluctuated between 8,659.36 and 8,569.54 during trading. A total of 3.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.23 billion (US$2.67 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Only construction issues lost ground, decreasing 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 721, with 477 stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors demand 18 months for abusive immigration officer

TEXT.P: Prosecutors requested Tuesday a prison term of one year and six months for an immigration officer whom they indicted on charges of abusing detainees.

Taichung Prosecutors' Office said that Ma Yun-chie, while on duty at a provisional detention center in a Taichung city police station in late August, shackled and assaulted a detainee from Vietnam for making too much noise before sending him to solitary confinement.
In early October, Ma again restricted the movement of a Vietnamese detainee and set the air conditioner to a unbearably low temperature in yet another incident of abuse.
Ma denied abusing or assaulting the detainees. But prosecutors, after investigating the complaints, determined that Ma had been abusive.

TAIEX Index futures for January rose 83 points to finish at 8,638, with 495 contracts traded, while March futures gained 14 points to close at 8,612, with seven contract transactions. DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD to subsidize bus companies to retain service in rural areas

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) plans to set up a NT$40 billion mass transit development fund, with its stake estimated at NT$800 million, to subsidize bus companies operating in the red in rural areas in southern Taiwan, an CEPD spokesman said Tuesday.

The decision was made in an attempt to maintain bus operations in rural areas nationwide after five bus companies operating in southern Taiwan announced Dec. 22 that they are considering whether to stop serving 150 routes in those areas.
Those bus companies have officially applied to suspend their services on 89 of the 150 routes, an official of the Highway Bureau said.

According to the official, the bureau has frequently raised the level of subsidies given to bus companies operating on routes in remote areas that incur operational losses because of the small number of passengers using bus services on a regular basis.

The spokesman noted that over the past few years, the bureau has increased the subsidies from an annual NT$500 million to NT$600 million, somewhat less than that demanded by bus operators in rural villages, adding that it is impossible for the government to provide subsidies to cover all of the losses these operators incur.
A CEPD spokesman also said that the government will continue to review its subsidy mechanism to help operators make ends meet at the most reasonable budget level.
The spokesman disclosed the plan to set up a NT$40 billion fund to help bus companies operating at a loss in remote areas by providing them with subsidies from interests derived from the fund.
Contributors to the fund will include government budgets, motor vehicle fuel tax revenues, revenues from vehicle parking, air pollution control fees and the proposed traffic-congestion fees.

Meanwhile, Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said that the Cabinet is striving to tackle these problems by convening meetings between relevant government agencies and bus operators to protect the rights of commuters in rural areas.
