DOC.HEADLINE: DPP referendum not aimed at changing status quo: MOFA

TEXT.P: The referendum called by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration on Taiwan's U. N. cause is not aimed at changing the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) James Huang asserted Tuesday.
Huang made the comments to reporters on a tour of a local temple in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan.

Huang said both he and President Chen Shui-bian had clearly explained a day earlier the government's stance on the issue to visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt to assuage U.S. concerns during a meeting in Taipei.

The government's effort to hold a referendum on whether the country should pursue U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan is merely an attempt to push the country to enter the world body as a full member -- something which Huang said has nothing to do with altering the cross-strait status quo nor what Beijing calls promoting "de jure" Taiwan independence.

According to Huang, he urged Burghardt to listen to the voices of Taiwan's people rather than just the opinions of the nation's leaders. In a democracy, holding a referendum is the best way to explore the views of the people, he said.

Reinforcing Taiwan's democracy and cementing public awareness of a "Taiwan- centric" consciousness are in the common interest of Taiwan and the United States, and also key to safeguarding peace in the Asia-Pacific region, he stressed.

The DPP-initiated referendum on pushing for Taiwan's U.N. membership will be held alongside the March 22, 2008 presidential election. Another KMT-proposed referendum calling for the country's participation at the world body in the name of the Republic of China will be held at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung world trade center project to be completed by 2010

TEXT.P: A project to construct a world trade center in the southern port city of Kaohsiung is slated to be completed by 2010, a city official said Tuesday.
The project will be opened up for public bidding later this month, an official of the Kaohsiung city government's Public Works Bureau said.
The 4.5-hectare center, which is scheduled to be inaugurated by 2011, will include a 1,500-booth exhibition hall, the official noted.
In addition, the center will have a 2,000-seat conference room, two 800-seat conference rooms, four 40-seat conference rooms, and six 20-seat conference rooms, the official added.

Due to a lack of a large conference hall and exhibition center in Kaohsiung, the city's computer and information product exhibitions have had to be held at local hotels or temporary-erected exhibition venues, the official said.
International events cannot be held at these venues because they are not large enough and the traffic access at these sites is limited, the official continued.

For this reason, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has allocated NT$3 billion (US$93 million) for the world trade center construction project and commissioned the bureau to handle the project, which will kick off in late 2008, the official said.
According to the city government's estimates, the world trade center, when completed, will generate NT$9.2 billion in revenue annually and provide 4,000 job opportunities, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should develop own distinctive products: ITRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop its own distinctive products instead of resorting to cut- throat price competition, the head of a non-profit R&D organization said Tuesday.

Lin Hsin-i, chairman of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) of Taiwan, made the remarks after being invited by a high-tech company to speak on innovation and acquiring a competitive edge at the Taipei International Convention Center.
Lin said the value-added rate of Taiwan products is too low. Although many of Taiwan's products have the lion's share of world markets, they generate little profit, he added.

He pointed out features characterizing the manufacturing industry in recent years, which include a great variety, low demand, short life cycles, high R&D costs, high quality, low prices, short time spans for delivery, a shortage of human resources, increased investment in equipment and low profit generation.
But he stressed that even the "worst of times will provide great opportunities," urging Taiwanese businesses to focus on upgrading the value of their products.
He said that South Korean businesses have long heeded this trend and dedicated themselves to the research and development of key materials, parts and components.

In comparison, Taiwan manufacturers continue to engage in cut-throat price competition. Even if manufacturers relocate to China or Vietnam, they nonetheless maintain the same pattern of low-price competition instead of focusing on establishing their own brand name products.
"If the trend continues, even if Taiwan manufacturers relocate to Africa, the chances of them making big profits will be minimal, " he added.
He cited, as an example, the market share of Taiwan's notebook computers, which is as high as 90 percent, while the profit margin continues to be a mere 4 percent.
"If we can't upgrade the value we bring, we can't upgrade our competitive edge," he stressed.
"The declining value-added rate of Taiwan's major manufacturing industry is worrisome," he said.

The value-added rate of Taiwan's electronic parts and components was cut to 17.1 percent in 2005 from 32 percent in 1999; the value-added rate in the parts and components of the textile industry was cut to 22.7 percent from 28.2 percent; in the computer and communication and audio-video electronic products, it was cut from 20 percent to 11.4 percent during the same period.

The value-added rate of Taiwan's overall manufacturing industry fell to 20.8 percent in 2004 from 27.7 percent in 1999. In comparison, the value-added rate was cut from 24.3 percent to 23.7 percent in South Korea, and from 34.5 percent to 32.9 percent in the United States.

He said this shows that key technologies and marketing channels remain in the hands of other countries, and that even if some Taiwanese products retain the greater share of global markets, the profits generate are minimal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four die in single-car drunken driving accident in Taoyuan County

TEXT.P: The four men who died in a single-car accident in Taoyuan County early Tuesday are suspected of being victims of drunken and reckless driving because all had a strong odor of alcohol, said a spokesman for the county police.

The spokesman said the four victims -- Chiang Yen-tai, Chiang Yen-tsung, Chien Chuan-shou and Lin Chih-chung -- died horrific deaths when their car, traveling at a high speed, crashed into four utility poles before coming to a stop.
He said all four occupants in the car were thrown out of the heavily damaged vehicle and died of crushed skulls and other serious injuries on the spot. It was not known who was driving.
The spokesman said the four men had apparently been drinking heavily late Monday night before traveling by car across the Kanchin Bridge in the Dahsi township of Taoyuan County.

He said the car was obviously traveling at an extremely high speed on a downward-sloping stretch of the road when the driver lost control of the car, causing it to veer off the road and crash into the electrical poles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor cites volunteers promoting tobacco-free environment

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bian cited restaurants and volunteers promoting a tobacco- free environment Tuesday.

At a citation-presentation ceremony held at Taipei City Hall, Hau noted that since the country's Tobacco Hazard Control Act was implemented in 1997, Taipei City government has been promoting an indoor tobacco-free environment in many public places, including restaurants, with the assistance of civic organizations, including the John Tung Foundation.

To date, there are more than 2,600 restaurants around Taipei in which smoking is forbidden, and 311 working places in the city with indoor places free of tobacco, Hau said, adding that those results are the best for any city in Taiwan.

Hau stressed that cigarettes contain some 4,000 chemicals, of which more than 40 are carcinogenic in humans, citing the study conducted by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) of the United States as saying that people exposed to second-hand smoking environment will have a 30 percent higher chance of getting cancer.

Noting that there is a world trend towards creating tobacco-free environments, Hau said many places, including California, Minnesota and Hong Kong are even promoting the creation of an outdoor tobacco-free environment. Hau added that there is still much room for improvement in Taipei City in this regard.

According to a survey conducted by Taipei Medical University, more than 70 percent of the public is satisfied with the campaign to promote tobacco-free restaurants, while 85 percent of the people support continuing such campaigns.

At the ceremony, Hau also presented certificates to restaurants which newly joined the list of tobacco-free places and gave citations to volunteers who have promoted a tobacco-free outdoor environment, in places including parks, plazas and zoos.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman's remarks aim at placating China: sources

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taipei Chairman Raymond Burghardt's latest remarks were aimed at placating China, sources at the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

The sources were responding to Burghardt's remarks at a news conference prior to his departure earlier the same day after a short visit to Taiwan during which he said Taiwan's U.N. referendum causes trouble.

The top U.S. liaison official in the absence of diplomatic ties also said the referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is a "clever way" of not violating the pledges that President Chen Shui-bian had made by going through the "backdoor", but the United States still interprets it as a violation of those pledges.
Lee Nan-yang, director of the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office, refused to comment on Burghardt's remarks.
Yang said President Chen exchanged views with Burghardt Monday on issues of mutual concerns, and there is no need to respond to Burghardt's latest remarks.

But Presidential Office sources said that Burghardt's remarks were aimed at placating China, saying that its message is "to ask China to exercise self- restraint" and "to let the United States do the talking.'

Burghardt's remarks were also aimed at letting the people of Taiwan know the stance of the U.S., and "to see if it will drive down the turnout rate, " the sources said, adding that Burghardt said that the results of the referendum will not change Washington's one-China policy, even though Chen has said passage of the referendum would prove the policy wrong.

The sources said that the planned referendum will not be dropped, noting that President Chen, in an interview with the Associated Press Monday, said that holding the referendum is aimed more at "domestic factors, " and that he believes it will galvanize the public to forge a national consensus on pursuing U.N. membership under the name Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICT industry accounts nearly half of overall exports from Jan.-Oct.

TEXT.P: Exports of information and communications technology (ICT) products accounted for 49.5 percent of Taiwan's total exports, worth US$201.4 billion, from January to October, indicating that the industry has become a prime mover of Taiwan's economy, an economic official said Monday.
Ho Mei-yueh, chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the figure shows an obvious increase from the 34 percent of US$224 billion in exports in 2006.
Ho made the remarks at an annual assembly meeting of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) in Taipei City.

The ICT industry had up to 1.3 million employees during the same period, which was about half of personnel in manufacturing industry and 13 percent among the overall number of nationwide employees, Ho said.
She went on that about one-third of gross fixed capital formation of private sector during the entire year was from the same industry.

Moreover, Ho noted that the TCA and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association (TEEMA) have made great contributions to Taiwan's economic development, noting that the two associations' member firms comprise nearly all of the ICT firms in Taiwan.

Closely related to ICT industry's development, the semiconductor and image display industries, heavily promoted by the government have each performed excellently in global markets, with output values in packaging and testing, and large-sized panel sectors both ranking the first in the world, Ho said.

Ho also spoke of her hope that local enterprises will invest more in ICT-related fields showing great potential for future development, such as wireless broadband, digital technologies, healthcare, and green industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: No second voting format permitted in January polls: premier

TEXT.P: No voting format other than the "one-step" procedure designed by the Central Election Commission (CEC) will be permitted in the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections and two accompanying referendums, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday.
Chang made the remarks in a Cabinet meeting on public order while giving a speech thanking police officers nationwide for their hard work.

With only a month left for the legislative elections in which a more complex "single-member constituency, two-vote" system will be implemented alongside the holding of two referendums, Chang said that it is extremely critical to maintain fair and smooth operations in the coming polls and asserted that "no other scheme than the CEC-designed 'one-step' voting format will be allowed."
Chang also demanded that mafia-organized election rigging and vote buying must be wiped out so as to maintain orderly elections and select well qualified lawmakers.

Although the CEC decided in Nov. 16 to adopt a "one-step" voting format for the January polls, 18 local governments controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have declared that they will adopt a "two-step" voting scheme to avoid what they called the "woes" of the "one-step" voting process.
The central and local governments have yet to reach a compromise in the voting format dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18% of TFCF-supported families getting out of poverty: survey

TEXT.P: Approximately 18 percent of disadvantaged families supported by the private Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) have climbed out of poverty over the past two years, according to a report released Tuesday by the TFCF and the Chinatrust Charity Foundation.

That figure includes 9.2 percent of families who are no longer listed as low- income households, 6.3 percent that have stopped receiving TFCF sponsorship and 2.4 percent that have seen their situation improved although they remain on the list of low-income households, the report said.

The Chinatrust Charity Foundation has since 2004 financed the TFCF's poverty- reduction program with donations collected through the foundation's "Light Up the Life" fund-raising campaign. The report, which sums up the achievements of the poverty-reduction program over the past two years, is based on a survey carried out between September and October among 210 families and 446 children receiving help under the program.

TFCF tallies show that 2,148 families and 5,259 children joined the TFCF's poverty-reduction program between January and September this year, meaning that, on average, one impoverished child appeared on the poverty rolls in Taiwan every 75 minutes.

Forty-five percent of the children were elementary students and approximately 80 percent were from single-parent families. More than 50 percent of the parents from these families were from the 36-45 age group, and 31.3 percent were jobless.
Meanwhile, 56.9 percent of these families made less than NT$15,000 (US$464) per month -- barely one-third of the average monthly earnings of NT$52,994 by Taiwanese households, the tallies indicate.

According to TFCF CEO Wang Ming-jen, the poverty-reduction program has successfully increased the employment rate among parents receiving help from 70.3 percent to 83.7 percent over the past two years.

The survey finds that nearly 90 percent of enrolled families have seen their financial status stabilize since joining the program and that more than 60 percent have seen their income increase, by NT$5,026 per month on average.

Meanwhile, 57.2 percent of parents acquired the vocational skills for which they are currently employed through the program, 58.6 percent now have more money to spend on their children, with the increase averaging NT$3,715 per month.
Despite increasing incomes, TFCF-supported families still make only NT$15,878 per month on average, according to the survey.

The 23rd Light Up the Life fund-raising campaign is being held from Dec. 5 to March 4, with the goal of collecting NT$70 million. People intending to make a donation can call the Chinatrust Charity Foundation's hotline at 0800-001-100.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD head dismisses health club closure as 'isolated case'

TEXT.P: The closure of Alexander Health Club -- Taiwan's largest fitness chain with a 26-year history -- is merely an "isolated case, " according to Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh.
Ho said Monday that the closure does not mean that Taiwan's economy is in decline.
She said that the government predicted that this year's economic growth rate would each 5.46 percent and that the government made its prediction based on the real situation.
Ho said that judging from the information available at present, Alexander's financial deficit seems to have resulted from the rapid expansion of its operations.
Local enterprises should adjust business models as they develop and grow, Ho said, adding that the management of cash flows is very critical for chain companies that charge membership fees.
Ho made the remarks after Candy Tang, founder and chairwoman of the club with more than 20 branches throughout Taiwan and five branches in China, announced the closure of the club earlier in the day.

Tang explained that the club had used revenues earned in China to help address the club's financial straits in Taiwan, but the club has had to cease operations as it could no longer sustain further losses.
The health club had generated revenues of some NT$2 billion (US$61.8 million) annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors search closed health club's headquarters

TEXT.P: Prosecutors in Taipei searched the headquarters of Alexander Health Club Tuesday to investigate the club's sudden suspension of operations.
Meanwhile, the Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said the same day that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and other ministers have already expressed grave concerns over the closure.
The government will look into the case to see if the health club has used their profits gained in Taiwan to invest in China illegally, while leaving debts in Taiwan unaddressed, Shieh noted.
Citing media reports, Shieh said that the health club's branches in China are still operating, which has raised concerns in Taiwan.

The remarks came one day after Candy Tang, founder and chairwoman of the Taiwan's largest fitness chain with a 26-year history, said that the company could not continue operating in the red despite an injection of funds from its branches in China into local operations.
The club has more than 20 branches throughout Taiwan and five branches in China.
Many of its more than 200,000 members, who have annual and long-term contracts, were stunned by the news and worried that they might not be able to get refunds on their prepaid membership fees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Divergent responses from DPP, KMT to opinion survey

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) diverged in their responses Tuesday to a public survey about which president has made the greatest contribution to Taiwan's development.

According to the public opinion poll conducted by the United Daily News, 55 percent of the respondents cited late President Chiang Ching-kuo as the one who made the greatest contribution to Taiwan, while 11 percent pointed to former President Lee Teng-hui. Some 6 percent signaled late President Chiang Kai-shek, slightly ahead of 5 percent who mentioned incumbent President Chen Shui-bian.

KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chuan opined that Chen should conduct in- depth self-reflection and urged him to apologize to the public for his constant smears of late President Chiang Kai-shek over the past seven years.
The poll results have proven that the two late Presidents Chiang did more to build up Taiwan than Chen, Kuo said.

Hsieh Hsin-ni, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and director of the party's propaganda department, argued that the poll results might be "untrue" and questioned whether the newspaper published the survey results to pave the way for KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou to link him to late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
The telephone poll was carried out from Dec. 9-10, successfully questioning 869 adults.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bus companies agree to scrap plan to stop serving remote routes

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) announced Tuesday that it had reached agreement with five bus companies in southern Taiwan to scrap plans to end bus services for remote routes in rural areas.
DGH Director Chen Jin-yuan said that after days of talks, bus company operators decided to reverse an earlier decision to stop services on more than 150 routes in rural areas starting Dec. 22.

Chen said the government had originally planned to subsidize bus companies to the tune of NT$550 million (US$17.02 million) for 2008, but the Executive Yuan later agreed to use provisional funds to cover up to 80 percent of the losses incurred by the bus companies that service the routes.
The subsidies will be increased to NT$720 million, or 80 percent of the subsides requested by the bus operators, he added.

In turn, five bus companies in southern Taiwan said they will continue the services despite their losses, out of consideration of the financial difficulties of the government and the needs of the public for the services.
DGH officials also said they would invite local government officials to a meeting the following day to discuss merging various rural routes to help cut costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Tour de Taiwan to take place next March

TEXT.P: The 2008 Tour de Taiwan, Taiwan's most prestigious cycling event, will be held next year from March 9-16, celebrating the 20th anniversary of the event, the Chinese Taipei Cycling Association (CTCA) announced in a press conference Tuesday.

The race will have eight stages and cover a distance of 861.2 kilometers, setting off from the southern city of Kaohsiung and finishing in Taipei City. In between, the route covers the western counties of Pingtung, Changhua, Taichung, Hsinchu, Taipei County and will finish at the Nangang Exhibition Hall in Taipei City.
The Tour de Taiwan was first held in 1987 by CTCA and has been awarded the distinguished level of 2.2 by the Union Cycliste Internationale (UCI).
With a total purse of US$50,000 and important points for cyclists looking to qualify for the cycling event in the 2008 Beijing Olympics, the race will be an important event, the CTCA stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau to bid for Taipei 101 New Year firework show

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau officials said Tuesday that the bureau will bid for the right to stage a New Year firework show on top of Taipei 101, one of the highest skyscrapers in the world.

Tourism Bureau Deputy Director Hsieh Wei-chun said, however, that as the show will cost up to NT$20 million, which is a lot of money for the bureau, it will have to find other sponsors to pay for the show.

On speculation that English wording to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid might be displayed during the show, Hsieh said there are no such plans, pointing out that the theme will be to promote the country's tourism and adding that the wording will be as simple as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turnover in Southern Taiwan Science Park sets record

TEXT.P: Business turnover registered in the September and October in Southern Taiwan Science Park reached NT$111.6 billion (US$3.45 billion) , a record high for a two-month period, an official of the park administration said Tuesday.
That trade volume represents growth of 11.17 percent over the period of July and August, and an increase of 25.96 percent over the same period of last year.
Accumulatively, business turnover for the first ten month totalled NT$440 billion in the park, representing growth of 19.03 percent over last year's total.

According to the official, the optoelectronic industry registered booming business due to the strong demand for LCD televisions, monitors, and note-book computers, with business turnover during the period reaching NT$79.79 billion, accounting for 71.49 percent of the park's total turnover.
The turnover represents a growth of 9.65 percent over the two previous months' level, and an increase of 24.35 percent over the same period of last year.

Meanwhile, trade in the semiconductor industry also has been robust, with turnover reaching NT$27.1 billion, accounting for 24.29 percent of total turnover in the park and an increase of 17.88 percent over the level registered in the July-August period and showing a growth of 34.94 percent over the same period last year.
Both the optoelectronic and the semiconductor industries set record highs for business turnover in this period.

In terms of biotechnology industry, another promising sector in the park, industry turnover totaled NT$752 million, representing a 69.95 percent-growth over the period of July-August and a 112.68 percent-growth over the same period last year due to stable growth in the demand for vaccines and other pharmaceutical products.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. public divided on intervening in cross-strait conflict: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/11/07 21:14:39 (By Michelle Tsai & Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Americans are divided on the question of whether the United States should intervene in the event of a cross-Taiwan Strait military conflict triggered by a declaration of independence by Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey, coordinated by the national non-partisan, non-profit Committee of 100, found that 49 percent of U.S. Congressional staffers agree that the U.S. should intervene in such a conflict, while only 32 percent of ordinary U.S. citizens, 31 percent of opinion leaders, and 23 percent of business leaders agree that it should.

The survey, titled "Hope and Fear: American and Chinese Attitudes Toward Each Other, " was conducted between mid August and mid September in the United States and China and covered a wide range of issues, including bilateral trade and economic relations, product safety, climate change, the rise of China, and the Taiwan issue, to name a few. Those surveyed included members of the general pubic in both countries, as well as business and opinion leaders, and U.S. Congressional staffers.

On the question of whether the United States should play a more active role in cross-strait relations, 64 percent of Congressional staffers said they agree that it should, while 57 percent of U.S. opinion leaders, 54 percent of business leaders and 46 percent of ordinary citizens said that it should. All the figures marked increases over those in a similar survey conducted in 2005, with the ratio of Congressional staffers supporting a more active U.S. role registering the steepest rise at over five percentage points.

As to whether the United States should intervene in a cross-strait military conflict triggered by a Taiwan declaration of independence, the percentages of business leaders and opinion leaders supporting the notion both marked sharp drops of over 20 percentage points from the level in the 2005 survey, while the ratio of Congressional staffers and ordinary citizens supporting the concept remained roughly the same in the two surveys.

Analyzing the results, Li Cheng, a senior researcher at the Brookings Institution who supervised the survey, told CNA that he believes the sharp drop in the percentage of business leaders and opinion leaders supporting U.S. military intervention is related to U.S. and Chinese economic interests as well as to recent provocative moves by Taiwan's government.
He also attributed the high level of support for Taiwan among Congressional staffers to the successful efforts of pro-Taiwan lobby groups in Washington, D.C.

Meanwhile, among Chinese citizens surveyed, 53 percent of business leaders and ordinary citizens said they believe the Taiwan issue is currently moving toward a peaceful resolution, while 32 percent of opinion leaders in the country said they feel the Taiwan issue reaches a deadlock.

Asked how China should work to solve the Taiwan issue, a majority of Chinese, including 66 percent of opinion leaders, 57 percent of business leaders and 52 percent of ordinary citizens, said expanding exchanges with Taiwan is the most appropriate way to reach the aim of eventual unity.

The survey in the United States, which was conducted via telephone interviews with 1,200 American adults nationwide, has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points, while the survey in China, which was carried out through face-to-face interviews with 4,104 Chinese adults around the country, has a margin of error of plus or minus 1.6 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gender equality groups to file complaint against official

TEXT.P: Leaders of gender equality groups in Taiwan said Tuesday that they will file a complaint against an education official who made a series of sexually discriminatory remarks offensive to women and the gay community.

They pointed out at a press conference that they strongly disagreed with the venomous and utterly puerile remarks by Chuang Kuo-jung, secretary-general of the Ministry of Education, against opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

In a series of verbal assaults in the past few days, Chuang ridiculed Ma -- a politician with a public image of civility, good temperament and gentlemanliness -- as being effeminate and lacking masculine qualities. He also said the Taipei mayor "looked very much like a gay." His remarks were televised nationwide.

Tseng Chao-yuan, secretary-general of the Awakening Foundation -- a non-profit organization promoting women's rights -- said she was disappointed that a senior education official had set such a bad example by ignoring the Gender Equality Education Law initiated by his own ministry.
The law, promulgated in 2004, requires schools to devote at least eight hours per semester to gender-equality courses.

Lai You-mei, secretary-general of the Taiwan Gender Equality Education Association, said Chuang's remarks ruined years of efforts by teachers to promote gender equality in accordance with the Gender Equality Education Law.
She added that Chuang's remarks depicting women and gay people as "not behaving themselves" would make female students, as well as gay students, feel uneasy.
Lai deplored that to date, the Ministry of Education has made no response to Chuang's discriminatory remarks.

The Taiwan Tongzhi Hotline Association president, who is known by the pseudonym Gofyy, said Chuang's deep-rooted patriarchal gender bias and his trotting out of sexual stereotypes dealt a heavy blow to front-line gender education workers and to Taiwan's gay rights movement. The association is a gay and lesbian rights group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Compulsory vehicle insurance rates to be lowered: FSC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) has decided to lower compulsory vehicle insurance rates from next March by an average of 3.78 percent, an FSC official said Tuesday.
Premiums for motorcycles will have an average decrease of 1.12 percent, while those for cars will see a 4.49 percent decrease, the official said.

Under the new policy and taking the hypothesis of a new insurance case for an insurant aged between 30-60 without a record of car accidents, a male insurant will have his insurance rate for a private car lowered by 6.21 percent, representing a saving of NT$122 (US$3.8) of the total NT$1,964 premium for one year.
A female insurant under the same hypothesis will save NT$112 from a decrease of 6.1 percent, the official said.
Insured scooters with premium payments of one-year and two-year periods will have a 4.82 percent and 5.27 percent decrease, respectively.

The official said 100 percent of cars and 96 percent of motorcycles have compulsory liability insurance. The slight adjustment of premium rates is to reduce the public's financial burden, although certain cars with high damage rates should have premium rates increased, he said.

The current Compulsory Automobile Liability Insurance Act took effect in 1998 and has gone through five decreases in premium rates from 2001-2006, with a cumulative decrease of 22 percent, the official said.
The new insurance premium policy was proposed by the Taiwan Insurance Institute and approved by an examination committee of impartial individuals, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Globalization of universities attracts foreigners to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Efforts by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to make domestic universities more globalized have borne fruit by attracting an increasing number of foreigners to study in Taiwan, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Tuesday.

At a press conference held at the MOE, Tu said the globalization of local universities is an important policy as it has increased the number of foreign students coming to Taiwan from 1,960 in 2004 to 5,266 in 2007.
Tu encouraged universities to create a bilingual environment so as to attract more foreign students to Taiwan.

He also urged the 12 universities which have obtained huge subsidies from the government to upgrade the level of their foreign student affairs departments to push for educational exchanges with other countries.
One student from the United States who attended the press conference said he is a computer engineer who developed an interest in language learning.

He first learned Dutch and German, but later began to learn Chinese and calligraphy from an artistic angle. Finding the Chinese language to be very interesting, he said he decided to concentrate on studying Chinese and came to Taiwan for this purpose, taking the Chinese name Lee Ai-hsi.
Lee said he chose to come to Taiwan to learn traditional Chinese characters, as the simplified Chinese characters used in China have distorted the meaning of the Chinese characters.
Another student from Burkina Faso who studies in a postgraduate program at Ming Chuan University, said he was grateful to have the chance to study in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Pan-blue alliance' forecast to seize 71 legislative seats
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/11/07 21:56:29 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese academic forecast here Monday that Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" will take 71 legislative seats in the Jan. 12, 2008 elections, ahead of 39 seats taken by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Wu Chung-li, a researcher with Academia Sinica -- the highest research institute in Taiwan -- issued his speculation in a seminar sponsored by the Washington- based Center for Strategic and International Studies.

According to Wu, the "pan-blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party is likely to seize 71 legislative seats in the polls -- 48 regional seats, 18 at-large seats and five aboriginal seats -- accounting for 62.8 percent of the 113-member 7th legislature.
On the other side, he said he expects the DPP to win just 39 seats -- 25 regional seats, 13 at-large seats and one aboriginal seat -- accounting for 34.5 percent of the total.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the DPP in the "pan-green camp," might win 3 regional seats, he added.

Wu based his speculation on the two camps' performances in major elections from 2004-2006, including the 2004 legislative and presidential polls, the 2005 provincial city and county chief elections and the 2006 special municipality mayoral elections.
Judging from this possible outcome, Wu said January's legislative polls will mark a watershed in Taiwan's political spectrum.

First, the "pan-blue alliance" will further cement its power base in northern, central and most eastern regions, while the DPP will prevail in southern Taiwan -- a development Wu claimed indicates "a serious rift in local society."
Secondly, he predicted, small parties such as the TSU, the New Party and the PFP, will all disappear from the domestic political map.
However, Wu declined to predict the outcome of the March 22, 2008 presidential election, saying that "a host of variants" remain.
DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh is competing with his KMT rival, Ma Ying- jeou, in the presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australian helps train seed instructors for firefighting

TEXT.P: A veteran firefighter from Australia is visiting Taiwan to help with the training of seed instructors in using the three-dimensional water fog technique for firefighting.

Damian Eggleston, a state learning and development officer at the New South Wales Rural Fire Service in Sydney, chaired a workshop at the Taipei City Fire Department's training center Tuesday and demonstrated how to suppress a fire with the three-dimensional water fog technique, which is widely used in advanced countries.
The technique is reportedly far more effective in cooling hot gases in a burning structure than the traditional straight-stream method.

Eggleston, an expert in wildland and structural firefighting, also taught Taipei firefighters how to use the "positive pressure" ventilation technique, along with the three dimensional water fog technique, to remove smoke and heat from a burning structure in order to allow firefighters to enter the structure to save lives or attack the source of the fire directly.

Tsai Chia-lung, deputy head of the Taipei City Fire Department, said Taiwan's older generation of firefighters might still be apprehensive about the positive pressure ventilation method because the oxygen in the fresh air pumped into the fire can actually feed the fire.
He added, though, that when used early in a fire, the techniques allow firefighters to enter burning rooms or structures quickly and bring out trapped people to safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum in Taipei County awarded for language efforts

TEXT.P: The Tamsui Historical Museum in the northern county of Taipei received an award Tuesday for its efforts to help establish an English-language environment in Taiwan.
The museum is one of some 100 government agencies and public places to receive such an award from the Cabinet-level Research, Development, Evaluation Commission (RDEC).
The honor came after the RDEC recently conducted a review of the agencies and places as part of the government's efforts to better serve foreigners in Taiwan.

According to the results of a recent survey conducted by the RDEC on foreign tourists to Taiwan, 61.7 percent of the people interviewed -- up 3.8 percentage points from last year -- said that they are satisfied with the country's English-language environment.
The survey also shows that 50.3 percent of the respondents -- up 3.2 percent -- noted that they are pleased with the English services provided by Taiwan's government agencies.

In order to provide a better service to international tourists, the Tamsui Historical Museum has also constructed friendly environments for Japanese and Spanish speakers, said Chang Bao-chuan, an official at the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau who is in charge of establishing the English-language environment for the museum.

At the 2007 English Carnival currently taking place at the Taipei Show Hall Two in downtown Taipei City, the museum has built a special area equipped with English-language multimedia, said Yu Chen-hua, head of the museum.
Within that area, visitors will be able to experience a day in the life of the British consul in his official residence in Tamsui during the 19th century, Yu noted.
The residence has become a popular tourist attraction.
Visitors to the area will also be able to experience British tea culture, sample royal British tea and snacks, and play tennis on a Nintendo Wii, a popular video game console, Yu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Wednesday.

The weighted price index was down 142.74 points at 8,495.59 on a turnover of NT$3.81 billion (US$117.82 million) at the open. The index gained 40.3 points, or 0.46 percent, to close at 8,638.33 Tuesday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.368 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.030 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Pan-blue alliance' forecast to seize 71 legislative seats
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/12/07 10:49:04 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese academic forecast here Monday that Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" will take 71 legislative seats in the Jan. 12, 2008 elections, ahead of 39 seats taken by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Wu Chung-li, a researcher with Academia Sinica -- the highest research institute in Taiwan -- issued his speculation in a seminar sponsored by the Washington- based Center for Strategic and International Studies.

According to Wu, the "pan-blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party is likely to seize 71 legislative seats in the polls -- 48 regional seats, 18 at-large seats and five aboriginal seats -- accounting for 62.8 percent of the 113-member 7th legislature.
On the other side, he said he expects the DPP to win just 39 seats -- 25 regional seats, 13 at-large seats and one aboriginal seat -- accounting for 34.5 percent of the total.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the DPP in the "pan-green camp," might win 3 regional seats, he added.

Wu based his speculation on the two camps' performances in major elections from 2004-2006, including the 2004 legislative and presidential polls, the 2005 provincial city and county chief elections and the 2006 special municipality mayoral elections.
Judging from this possible outcome, Wu said January's legislative polls will mark a watershed in Taiwan's political spectrum.

First, the "pan-blue alliance" will further cement its power base in northern, central and most eastern regions, while the DPP will prevail in southern Taiwan -- a development Wu claimed indicates "a serious rift in local society."
Secondly, he predicted, small parties such as the TSU, the New Party and the PFP, will all disappear from the domestic political map.
However, Wu declined to predict the outcome of the March 22, 2008 presidential election, saying that "a host of variants" remain.
DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh is competing with his KMT rival, Ma Ying- jeou, in the presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australian helps train seed instructors for firefighting

TEXT.P: A veteran firefighter from Australia is visiting Taiwan to help with the training of seed instructors in using the three-dimensional water fog technique for firefighting.

Damian Eggleston, a state learning and development officer at the New South Wales Rural Fire Service in Sydney, chaired a workshop at the Taipei City Fire Department's training center Tuesday and demonstrated how to suppress a fire with the three-dimensional water fog technique, which is widely used in advanced countries.
The technique is reportedly far more effective in cooling hot gases in a burning structure than the traditional straight-stream method.

Eggleston, an expert in wildland and structural firefighting, also taught Taipei firefighters how to use the "positive pressure" ventilation technique, along with the three dimensional water fog technique, to remove smoke and heat from a burning structure in order to allow firefighters to enter the structure to save lives or attack the source of the fire directly.

Tsai Chia-lung, deputy head of the Taipei City Fire Department, said Taiwan's older generation of firefighters might still be apprehensive about the positive pressure ventilation method because the oxygen in the fresh air pumped into the fire can actually feed the fire.
He added, though, that when used early in a fire, the techniques allow firefighters to enter burning rooms or structures quickly and bring out trapped people to safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum in Taipei County awarded for language efforts

TEXT.P: The Tamsui Historical Museum in the northern county of Taipei received an award Tuesday for its efforts to help establish an English-language environment in Taiwan.
The museum is one of some 100 government agencies and public places to receive such an award from the Cabinet-level Research, Development, Evaluation Commission (RDEC).
The honor came after the RDEC recently conducted a review of the agencies and places as part of the government's efforts to better serve foreigners in Taiwan.

According to the results of a recent survey conducted by the RDEC on foreign tourists to Taiwan, 61.7 percent of the people interviewed -- up 3.8 percentage points from last year -- said that they are satisfied with the country's English-language environment.
The survey also shows that 50.3 percent of the respondents -- up 3.2 percent -- noted that they are pleased with the English services provided by Taiwan's government agencies.

In order to provide a better service to international tourists, the Tamsui Historical Museum has also constructed friendly environments for Japanese and Spanish speakers, said Chang Bao-chuan, an official at the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau who is in charge of establishing the English-language environment for the museum.

At the 2007 English Carnival currently taking place at the Taipei Show Hall Two in downtown Taipei City, the museum has built a special area equipped with English-language multimedia, said Yu Chen-hua, head of the museum.
Within that area, visitors will be able to experience a day in the life of the British consul in his official residence in Tamsui during the 19th century, Yu noted.
The residence has become a popular tourist attraction.
Visitors to the area will also be able to experience British tea culture, sample royal British tea and snacks, and play tennis on a Nintendo Wii, a popular video game console, Yu added.

Today is Wednesday, Dec. 12, or the third day of the eleventh month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.

1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign assets of Taiwan's top 18 non-financial firms near US$50 b.

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses have performed brilliantly in terms of globalization, with 18 Taiwan firms ranking among the world's top 100 non-financial transnational corporations from developing economies for 2005, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Wednesday.

Referring to the World Investment Report 2007 released in October by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTD) , the officials noted that the foreign assets of these 18 corporations amounted to US$48.4 billion for 2005, up 55.3 percent from the year-earlier level.

The companies are Formosa Plastics Group, Hon Hai Precision Industries, Benq Corp, Quanta Computer Inc., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Compal Electronics Inc., Acer Inc., United Microelectronics Corp., Delta Electronics Inc., Chunghwa Picture Tubes, Cheng Shin Rubber Industries Co., CMC Magnetics Corp., Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc., Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., Unimicron Technology, Wistron Corp., Mitac International Corp. and Elitegroup Computer System Co.
These corporations had a total of 370,000 foreign employees in 2005, marking an increase of 41 percent over the previous year, the officials said.

While both growth rates -- in terms of foreign asset value and foreign employment -- were the highest among Asia's four little dragons, foreign sales of the 18 Taiwan corporations jumped 28.7 percent for 2005, the second-highest growth rate among Asia's four little dragons after Hong Kong, the officials said.

Meanwhile, two Taiwan companies were ranked among the world's top 100 transnational corporations by the number of host countries and the Geographical Spread Index for 2005, with Acer Inc. ranking 81st and Hon Hai Precision Industries ranking 100th, according to the UNCTD report.

The CEPD officials also pointed out that six Taiwan companies were included on Fortune magazine's list of the world's 500 largest companies for 2007, compared with three for 2006. The six companies are Hon Hai Precision Industry, CPC, Cathay Financial Holdings, Asustek Computer, Quanta Computer and Formosa Petrochemicals.
The number accounted for 8.6 percent of the total number of companies from emerging economies that made Fortune's top 500 list, up from 4.9 percent for 2006, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan financial leader promotes exchanges in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/12/07 13:12:50 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Financial Services Rountable (TFSR) Chairman Kevin Chien, accompanied by TFSR Secretary-General Mark Wei, arrived in Washington, D.C. Tuesday mainly for talks on the prospects of a U.S.-Taiwan conference aimed at boosting financial cooperation and exchanges between the two countries.

Chien and Wei are expected to meet with Steve Bartlett, president and CEO of the U.S. Financial Services Rountable (USFSR) , Wednesday for talks on the prospects of a 2008 U.S.-Taiwan financial cooperation conference to be jointly sponsored by their respective organizations and the ROC-USA Business Council.
The U.S. Financial Services Rountable is a unique and influential trade association which is limited to the 100 largest financial service companies in the United States.

According to Chien, the TFSR signed a memorandum with the USFSR in March this year on bilateral cooperation, with both sides agreeing to take concrete measures, such as convening conferences, to jointly promote financial cooperation and exchanges between the two countries.

During their two-day stay in Washington, D.C., Chien and Wei are also expected to meet with Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council for talks on issues of mutual concern.

Chien and Wei will also take time to meet with officials from George Washington University's School of Business for talks on the signing of a memorandum on academic exchanges between the school and financial service organizations and educational institutes in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier wants more agriculture produce adopting traceability system

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the government hopes agricultural, fishery and poultry products adopting the traceability system will account for 10 percent of all such products produced next year.
The premier made the remarks during a weekly meeting of the Executive Yuan.

He said the government has set 2008 as agriculture produce safety year, hoping that 10 percent of agricultural products will adopt the management system next year and that all products will adopt the system by 2015.

The traceability system of agriculture produce is a high-tech measure that has been adopted by many advanced countries to manage and record product information from production to processing and logistics, which helps trace product responsibility, guarantee food quality and offer consumers clear information on the food they buy.

The premier noted that the government attaches great importance to agricultural development and welfare of the farmers. It has mapped out a draft agriculture basic law to help Taiwan's agricultural sector cope with the impact and challenges posed by globalization, liberalization as well as global warming effect, he added.

Under the draft law, the traditional agricultural industry will be transformed into high value-added industry, and agriculture will serve multiple functions in terms of food production and ecology, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan has Asia's weakest employment outlook for Q1 2008: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's employment outlook for the first quarter of 2008 remains the weakest among major economies in the Asia-Pacific region, according to the results of an international survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by U.S.-based Manpower Inc. on nearly 52,000 public and private employers from 27 countries and territories worldwide, 1,540 of whom are from Taiwan.
In addition to Taiwan, the seven other Asia-Pacific economies surveyed were Australia, China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, New Zealand and Singapore.

The survey revealed that Taiwan's net employment outlook for the first quarter of 2008 stands at a favorable +14 percent, up three percentage points from the current quarter but down one percentage point from the first quarter this year.

The figure compares with Singapore's +43 percent, India's +42 percent, Hong Kong's +25 percent, Australia's +24 percent, New Zealand's +20 percent and Japan's +17 percent. China's net employment outlook for the first quarter of 2008 is similar to Taiwan's, at +14 percent.

While 23 percent of the Taiwan respondents said they plan to increase their staff numbers in the next quarter, 9 percent expect to cut staff, and 60 percent said they have no plans to hire new workers.

Employers from the finance, insurance and real estate industry sector expressed the strongest intention to hire new workers, with the sector's net employment outlook rising nine percentage points quarter-on-quarter and six percentage points year-on-year to +20 percent for the next quarter.

The net employment outlook for the manufacturing sector stands at +14 percent for the first quarter of 2008, up four percentage points year-on-year. The figure is the same as that recorded for the current quarter.

The mining and construction sector's net employment outlook for the next quarter stands at +10 percent, down 13 percentage points year-on-year, while that of the services sector stands at +13 percent, marking a decline of five percentage points from a year earlier.
The net employment outlook of the transportation and utilities sector registers +8 percent for the next quarter, up four percentage points quarter-on-quarter and three percentage points year-on-year.
Meanwhile, the net employment outlook of the wholesale trade and retail trade sector stands at +12 percent, up five percentage points quarter-on-quarter and two percentage points year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan academic hired as chief editor of prestigious U.S. periodical

TEXT.P: A National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) academic has been hired by the prestigious American journal Experimental Biology & Medicine (EBM) to be a leading associate editor in charge of Asian contributions and head of a soon-to- be founded Asia Office of the periodical, academic sources said Wednesday.

Professor H.Y. Lei, director of the Institute of Basic Medical Sciences under NCKU's Graduate School of Medicine, who is internationally known in medical research in the fields of dengue fever and enterovirus, will be the EBM's leading Asian associate editor and chief of the EBM Asia Office beginning January 2008, according to Dr. Da-hsuan Feng, a NCKU senior vice president, and Dr. Lin Chi-ho, president of the NCKU's Graduate School of Medicine, who were instrumental in introducing Lei to the EBM for the post.

The EBM is a major publication of the Society of Experimental Biology and Medicine (SEBM) in the United States. According to Feng and Lin, 33 percent of EBM's manuscript submissions come from the United States and 33 percent come from Asia, prompting the organization to seek an associate editor from Asia who will be the head of the EBM Asian Office to oversee publication contributions from experts and researchers from Asia.

The SEBM, founded in 1903 to promote investigation in the field of biomedical sciences by encouraging and facilitating interchange of scientific information among disciplines, currently has 870 members worldwide.
Lei will be the EBM's associate editor in Asia between Jan. 1, 2008-Dec. 31, 2010. The EMB Asia Office, meanwhile, will be formally inaugurated at the NCKU Jan. 7, 2008.
Meanwhile, Dr. Tsai Shao-cheng, director of the Department of Physiology under the NCKU's College of Medicine, will be an associate editor of the EMB Asia Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 139 points to close at 8,501, with 52,943 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 132 points to finish at 8,507, with 1,369 contracts traded, while March futures lost 112 points to close at 8,500, with 21 contract transactions. June futures moved down 153 points to close at 8,506, with five contract transactions, while September futures decreased 124 points to finish at 8,336, with 10 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,640 for December, 8,639 for January, 8,612 for March, 8,659 for June and 8,460 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures lost 7.3 points to close at 348.65, with 3,710 contracts traded, while January TE futures moved down 7.3 points to finish at 348.5, with 240 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures dropped 11.8 points to close at 964.8, with 2,281 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 12.2 points to finish at 965, with 196 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Xue Xue Institute wins Design for Asia Grand Award

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Xue Xue Institute, a private school dedicated to cultural and creative education, has won the Design for Asia (DFA) Grand Award presented by the Hong Kong Design Center for its contributions to promoting aesthetic education and its influence on Asian lifestyle, a spokesman for the institute said Wednesday.
The DFA award serves to recognize companies around the world that have created business successes out of good designs that are most influential within Asia.

The institute is the country's first private educational institution devoted to people in the fashion, branding, art and cultural industries that has been sanctioned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Xue Xue Institute founder Lin Po-shin and the institute's chairman, Lilin Hsu, are scheduled to attend the award presentation ceremony Wednesday in Hong Kong during which they will share their experiences and views with representatives from design and cultural industries worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slide on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 147.49 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 8,490.84.
The bourse opened at 8,495.59 and fluctuated between 8,554.12 and 8,451.65 during trading. A total of 3.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$109.16 billion (US$3.37 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up 0.6 percent and foodstuff issues increasing 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 468, with 395 stocks remaining unchanged.

La Repubblica: Italy is taken prisoner by truck drivers.
Italian truck drivers who began to stage a five-day strike Tuesday challenged a government's order to limit their protest and to suspend the strike at midnight of the same day. They said that the strike which has paralysed the nation's merchandise transportation would continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative committee approves FTA with two diplomatic allies

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee approved Wednesday a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and two of its Central American diplomatic allies -- El Salvador and Honduras.
The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) agreed to give the green light to the accord to save time, given that an El Salvador-Honduras FTA is to take effect Jan. 1, 2008.

However, it attached an additional resolution to the FTA demanding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs use only the nation's formal title -- the Republic of China -- without adding the name Taiwan when signing similar accords with other diplomatic allies in the future. This requirement is not applicable to countries without formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The Taiwan-El Salvador/Honduras FTA will be referred to the coming legislative plenary meeting for substantial screening.

KMT Legislator Hsieh Wen-ting said that the KMT legislative caucus proposed attaching the additional resolution after the various parties failed to forge a consensus in two meetings called by ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung to discuss whether the designation of the ROC (Taiwan) should be used when clinching FTAs with diplomatic partners.

According to Hsu, adding the word Taiwan to bilateral pacts can provide a good reference for countries with which Taiwan has no diplomatic relations and can also offer a way of "thinking out of the box." Hsu said he has reservations about the KMT-proposed resolution and will continue exchanging views with other lawmakers on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to show more concern for Chinese dissidents

TEXT.P: Reporters Without Borders (RWB) Secretary-General and founder Robert Menard voiced hope Wednesday that Taiwan will show more concern for the plight of Chinese dissidents.
Menard made the call in an interview with CNA after a visit to the Association of Taiwan Journalists for talks with local journalists to gain a better understanding of the state of Taiwan's media.

In the interview, Menard recalled a trip he made to China in January, saying that during that visit, he handed over to the Beijing authorities a list of names of over 80 imprisoned Chinese dissidents and asked the communist regime to release them in time for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games slated for Aug. 8-24.

Menard said Beijing had made some promises and actually released several dissidents. However, they were released only because they had completed their prison terms, he noted, adding that in fact, Beijing had done nothing.
Menard said the RWB has been concerned about the human rights situation in China for a long time.

Speaking of Taiwan, he praised it as one of the few democratic Asian countries and voiced hope that the country, which shares a common cultural background with China, will pay more attention to China's human rights problems.

Menard had planned to hold a demonstration a few days earlier with other RWB members in Beijing in protest China's failure to fulfill its promises to improve human rights and press freedom made while seeking the right to host the Olympics. However, China rejected his visa application, he said.
Menard arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a four-day visit.
RWB, founded in 1985 in Paris, is an international non-governmental organization advocating freedom of the press. The organization now has branches and offices on five continents.
The group issues the Worldwide Press Freedom Index annually to measure the degree of freedom journalists and media have in more than 160 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate heartened by AIT chairman's remarks

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he felt heartened when American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Taiwan's U.N. bid referendum will "box in" Taiwan's next president.
Hsieh said Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations, meant well and was speaking on his behalf.

He was referring to remarks by Burghardt prior to his departure from Taiwan after a brief visit during which he reiterated U.S. opposition to Taiwan's plan to hold a U.N. referendum alongside the March 22 presidential election, saying it causes trouble and could tie the hands of the next president.

Burghardt said that whether Hsieh or his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang, wins the election, "he deserves to be his own man and should not be boxed in by statements made now," referring to the referendum, which could hold the danger of limiting Taiwan's freedom to maneuver with Beijing.

At a news conference to unveil his new book, titled In Pursuit of Victory in Adversity, Hsieh also said the United States is a good friend of Taiwan, and that "one should listen to the advice of a good friend."
He also said that "it will not be the first time the United States has voiced its opposition, and that a series of other expressions toward Taiwan's referendum on U.N. membership will come."
He also distanced himself from President Chen Shui-bian, saying that he has known Chen for 20 years, during which they have competed and cooperated with each other.
"I know clearly that the president decides the direction of the nation prior to May 20, 2008, but it will be my decision after that if I am elected," Hsieh said.
On cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he said that "Taiwan should see the window of opportunity in its adversity."
Hsieh said that Taiwan, being small, has to display wisdom in dealing with China, while China should show tolerance and compromise.
He noted that both sides of the Taiwan Strait "had good communication" in the 1990s, noting that China was not so strong as it is now.
The compromise of the strong demonstrates tolerance, and co-existence is not for the ears of Taiwan, but also for China, he said.

He also said that Taiwan is in chaos due to long-term squabbling between the ruling and opposition parties and that there is a "dearth of trust in society with no long-term optimism and collective sense of happiness among the public."

Taiwan is at a critical juncture in terms of moving toward peace or deteriorating into chaos. If the situation is not handled well, the chaos could turn into crisis, "with the possibility that China could step in to clear up the mess," he said.
Taiwan has to act with caution and wisdom in the adversity, and should build up its strength, as well as combine "soft power" such as freedom, democracy and culture.
He also said that if more international organizations recognize Taiwan, it will help the country's security.
If elected president, he said, he will try to mend fences with the United States over the eroded trust between the two nations due to the contentious referendum plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETS to start giving written, spoken English tests next year

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based Educational Testing Service (ETS) will begin from January 2008 to prepare English skill tests in speaking and writing for enterprises in Taiwan, in a drive to improve English skills, the Taiwan representative of the ETS Taiwan branch said Wednesday.

Wang Hsing-wei held a press conference in Taipei to announce the new tests, which are part of the Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC) targeting working people, alongside tests in listening and reading.
Wang said more and more local people need to speak or write in English at work, so the ETS developed the tests to meet enterprises' need for employees with English fluency, Wang noted.

The new TOEIC tests will be available for group applicants from January and for individual applicants from August, with the examinees required to take the tests on a computer, according to the ETC office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's EPZs attract US$1.37 billion in investment

TEXT.P: Taiwan's eight export processing zones (EPZs) attracted a total of NT$44.4 billion (US$1.37 billion) worth of investment in the first eleven months of this year, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.
Tseng Sheng-ba, director general of the MOEA's Export Processing Zone Administration, said the figure is higher than the administration's original target of NT$35.2 billion for the whole year.

According to Tseng, Taiwan established its first exporting processing zone in 1966 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung. He said that over the years, the country's EPZs have transformed from traditional-industry based to high-tech industry based.
Due to their successful development, Taiwan's EPZs have become a model followed by many developing countries, he said.

Tseng noted that currently, a total of 330 enterprises have established operations in Taiwan's export processing zones, with one-quarter of the companies having increased their paid-in capital in their operations within the zones this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government initiative to reduce business tax welcomed

TEXT.P: The business sector expressed welcome Wednesday to an Executive Yuan motion authorizing relevant public offices to cancel or adjust downward business taxes on four categories of imported basic commodities.

It is hoped that zero or lower levels of business tax imposed on imported basic commodities, including wheat, barley, corn and soybeans, will help alleviate pressure on domestic traders caused by skyrocketing commodity prices on the international market, Executive Yuan officials said.
Soaring prices of wheat, barley, corn and soybeans have caused a direct impact on local traders, particularly those who deal in flour, cooking oil, bread and animal feed.

The Executive Yuan passed in a regular weekly meeting a motion authorizing government agencies to slash or adjust downward the 5 percent business tax on the commodities, based on their prices including cost, insurance and freight.
At present, imports of soybeans, corn and barley are duty free, and only wheat imports have an import tariff of 3.5 percent.
Most of the flour, animal feed and cooking oil traders welcomed the Executive Yuan initiative, saying the policy is a positive move in terms of stabilizing commodity prices and controlling inflation.
Some, however, lamented that there are too many factors causing their costs to surge, with spiraling grain prices on the international market being the main culprit.
They forecast that flour prices will continue to rise in December, after rises in October and November.
