Millions of pounds will be spent on new play and leisure facilities as part of a government plan to reverse the decline of childhood and make sure that children in England are both seen and heard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City takes over management of seven swimming pools

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government took over management of seven heated swimming pools of the city Wednesday after a private company contracted to run the facilities shut them down a day earlier due to financial difficulties.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin told reporters that the city government will safeguard the interests of Taipei residents and their right to use the facilities, based on provisions of the contracts between the city government and Eden Athletics.
Hau said he has asked the Parks and Street Lights Office of the city government's Public Works Bureau to seek legal counsel to resolve the dispute.

Eden Athletics was awarded contracts to run 14 swimming pools owned by the city government, including the seven heated pools which remain open in winter. Some of the well-known heated pools include the Youth Park Swimming Pool in Wanhua District, the Yuquan Park Heated Swimming Pool in Datong District and the Yucheng Swimming Pool in Nangang District.

The company has run into financial difficulties recently and owes NT$20 million (US$617,665) in royalties to the Taipei city government. Its top executive indicated Tuesday that the company is in the process of filing for bankruptcy.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Airlines to buy 20 Airbus planes

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, will purchase 14 Airbus A350XWB-900 jets -- worth a combined US$4.2 billion -- with an option for an additional six, a spokesman for the Taipei-based airline company said Wednesday.
The announcement came one day after China Airlines' board of directors approved a letter of intent signed by the company with Airbus, said CAL President Chao Kuo-shuai.
The mid-sized A350XWB jet is an extra-wide-body aircraft and will be mainly used by CAL on its long-haul routes to Europe, Australia, and the United States, beginning in 2015, according to Chao.
To cope with surging oil prices, CAL needs to opt for advanced, cost-effective planes, Chao said.
The A350XWB series, to be powered by new-generation Rolls-Royce Trent XWB engines, are newer versions of the A350 rolled out as part of Airbus' response to market demands, Chao noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cyber games popular among Taiwan school children: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty-eight percent of school children surveyed recently by the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) identified themselves as cyber game players, with many playing on weekdays, according to the results of the survey released Wednesday.
The survey was carried out between Oct. 16 and Nov. 2 among 1,818 fifth- and sixth-graders and students in the first and second years of junior high school.
The results show that on weekdays, 18.5 percent of the respondents play cyber games for more than three hours per day, while 3.9 percent use the Internet for over eight hours per day.
On weekends, 43.8 percent of the respondents said they spend more than three hours per day playing cyber games, with 13.4 percent playing for more than eight hours per day.
Slightly more than 10 percent said they tend to continue play after midnight.

On the reasons for spending so much time on games, 62 percent of the respondents said they do so to kill time, while 51.6 percent said they just follow what their friends and classmates do, 50 percent said the games relieve stress, 70 percent said they enjoy the fantasy aspect, and 72 percent said they feel the game characters are part of themselves.
The results indicate that many children turn to cyber games for fun and a sense of achievement because their lives are mundane and frustrating, CWLF officials said.

Meanwhile, the CWLF claimed that children who play cyber games face four major potential crises: exposure to violent content, susceptibility to Internet addiction, dangerous contact with strangers and involvement in criminal activities.

While approximately 70 percent of the cyber games popular among children are not rated, the survey results show that 20.14 percent of cyber game players have a preference for games with adult content.

On the risk of Internet addiction, the CWLF said 25.8 percent of the respondents display symptoms of addiction, while the ratio of children with symptoms reaches 47.3 percent among those who play online games.
On the risk of dangerous contact with strangers, the results show that 61.1 percent of those polled said they will chat with unknown partners while playing games online.

Over 22 percent of the respondents will have further interaction, including exchanging phone calls, making friends and developing romantic relationships. In particular, 15.6 percent of the respondents said they meet friends online.

On the risk of involvement in criminal activities, the survey results show that 27.2 percent of the respondents have used illegal plugins to extend their games, 13.9 percent have stolen other people's user names to play online games and 13.5 percent have used false identities to cheat virtual goods out of others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air controllers failed to provide timely information: CAA

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Wednesday that reports of "near mid-air collision" between a commercial aircraft and several military jet fighters were due to a delay in providing flight information to the civil plane.

CAA officials made the remarks after its probe of the incident, saying that Taitung air traffic controllers had not provided timely information to the pilot of a Daily Air plane that six jet fighters were approaching, resulting in the pilot having little time to respond to the unexpected situation.
The officials said the incident showed that coordination between military and civil aviation needs to be reviewed.

At issue is a Nov. 29 incident in which six F-5F and F-5E fighters were returning in formation to Chihhang Airbase in Taitung in eastern Taiwan. The pilot of the Daily Air plane, one minute after taking off from Fengnien Airport in Taitung on way to Green Island, was startled to see the fighters pass nearby.
The pilot protested to the air traffic controllers after arriving at Green Island.
The probe by the CAA officials showed that the six military jets were flying at an altitude of 1,500 feet as they prepared to land, while the Daily Air plane was at 1,000 feet, CAA officials said.
The officials said that air controllers twice informed military jets that a civilian aircraft was to take off, but failed to inform the Daily Air pilot of the incoming military planes.
Meanwhile, air traffic control officials said that the military and civil planes maintained a "safe distance" and that there was no risk of a collision as had been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA completes 'noise maps' on Kaohsiung, Taipei

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has completed "noise maps" on Kaohsiung City and Taipei City, in southern and northern Taiwan, respectively, to help citizens understand the noise situations in their neighborhoods, an EPA official said Wednesday.
The noise levels of main roads in Kaohsiung and Taipei reach between 70 decibels and 85 decibels, the official said.
The noise levels of regular roads in Kaohsiung are between 50 decibels and 65 decibels, which is higher than the 46-60 decibels recorded in Taipei, the official went on.
The official attributed the louder noise in some areas of Kaohsiung to the port city's mix of industrial and residential areas.
In addition, heavy trucks often drive through these areas at night, making certain areas continuously noisy, the official said.
The EPA plans to publish the "noise map" on Kaohsiung City on its Web site and to highlight noise levels of different locations in the southern city with different colors, the official said.
House-buyers will be able to check these "noise maps" before purchasing a house or apartment, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to shorten time for issuing business certificates

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will lift or ease certain restrictions on administrative management to simplify procedures and shorten the time for issuing business certificates to local enterprises, a Cabinet official said Wednesday.
Citing the results of a report released by the World Bank Group, the official said Taiwan ranked 148th among 175 economies in terms of effectiveness of issuing business certificates.
It takes 206 days for a local enterprise to get a business certificate from the government, while the average issuing time among other Asia-Pacific countries is 147 days, the official noted.

The Executive Yuan will listen to a briefing by the Council for Economic Planning and Development before making any decisions on ending certain unnecessary or redundant administrative procedures in applying for and issuing business certificates, the official said.

It will also make adjustments on regulations in need of improvement in an effort to enhance Taiwan's international competitiveness, which has seen several backslides in global rankings, the official said.

He pointed out that Taiwan's ranking dropped one notch from last year's level to 18th among 55 economies in terms of national competitiveness, citing results of the World Competitiveness Yearbook 2007 conducted by the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland.

Moreover, the country's ranking of overall competitiveness also dropped one notch to 114th among 131 countires, as listed in the Global Competitiveness Report 2007-2008 released by the World Economic Forum in Geneva, Switzerland, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sarkozy's opposition to Taiwan's referendum violates French spirit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that French President Nicolas Sarkozy's recent remarks opposing Taiwan's planned referendum on its quest for U.N. representation under the name Taiwan violates France's founding spirit.

Chen made the remarks during the meeting with Robert Menard, secretary-general of the Reporters without Borders, a Paris-based non-governmental organization dedicated to promoting freedom of the press, at the Presidential Office.

Chen told Menard that Taiwan expects to hold a referendum alongside the presidential election next March on whether the country should join the United Nations under the name Taiwan. This move is mainly intended to proclaim to the world the common desire of the 23 million people of Taiwan to join the U.N, the president explained.
That proposal has encountered opposition from several countries, including France, with Sarkozy expressing his opposition during a recent visit to China.

Sarkozy's opposition was stated under pressure from China and in hopes of economic benefits for France, Chen said, stressing that his expression of opposition to Taiwan's referendum clearly violates France's founding spirits of freedom, democracy and human rights.

Noting that the holding of referendums is a basic human right, Chen said the French people also enjoy this right and that many national referendums have been held during the Fifth Republic, including referendums on issues whether or not France should accept or reject the proposed European Union Constitution.

Chen also mentioned that Menard was denied entry by Chinese authorities on Dec. 10, the world's Human Rights Day, before coming to Taiwan. Menard's China visit was originally aimed at protesting against insufficient protection of freedom of the press in China.

Denying Menard entry to China reflects Beijing's widespread and unceasing repression of the press, so it is no wonder that China consistently trails the world in rankings of press freedom, Chen stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: No pay hikes for China-bound employees: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwanese white-collar office workers seeking better pay through China-based employment are likely to be disappointed as 48 percent of local enterprises have no plans to raise salaries for personnel bound for China in the future, an online human resources service reported Wednesday.

According to 104 Job Bank, which conducted a survey on the issue with 684 companies having branches in China and 3,011 workers with work experience in China, some 48 percent of Taiwan-based companies will not increase pay for their workers stationed in China from 2008, narrowing the gap in salaries paid to workers on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to 1.38-fold on average at present, down from an average 1.57-fold during the period from 1991-1994.
In the past three years, about 30 percent of Taiwanese workers operating in China have received the same pay as their counterparts in Taiwan, if not less, results of the survey showed.
In the early 1990s, some 5 percent of China-based Taiwanese employees enjoyed triple the pay of colleagues doing similar work in Taiwan, while over 13 percent received double the income.
As for new workers to be dispatched to China from next year, they would receive an average pay of 1.24-fold that of their colleagues in Taiwan, the poll found.
According to the survey, 38 percent of Taiwan businesses said they will offer more handsome bonuses instead of pay increases to such employees in the future.

Some 82 percent of Taiwan companies said they will provide airplane tickets as a bonus to their China-based workers; 68 percent of companies will make available holidays; 66 percent will provide accommodation subsidies. About 58 percent of companies said they will offer subsidies for employees' insurance premiums and travel expenditures.
However, 11 percent of the enterprises questioned replied that they do not plan to provide either pay hikes or bonuses to their China-based personnel in the coming year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Far Eastern Air Transport to cancel Taipei-Tainan route

TEXT.P: Far Eastern Air Transport Corp. is awaiting a reply from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) regarding its application to terminate air service between Taipei and Tainan.

Executives with the airline company have indicated that the company would like to cease the air service as soon as possible, but MOTC officials have expressed hope that Far Eastern would continue serving the Kaohsiung-Tainan route at least until after the Lunar New Year in early 2008, when all forms of passenger transport will be in great demand.

The company filed the application with the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the MOTC in late November after promotional efforts to attract more passengers for the Taipei-Tainan route proved to be in vain.

On Nov. 12, Far Eastern reduced the price of a one-way ticket for a Taipei- Tainan flight to NT$1,060 (US$32.8), lower than the NT$1,255 for a one-way ride between the two cites on the Taiwan High Speed Rail. Despite that effort, the occupancy rate has remained at about 30 percent, meaning the airline is operating the route at a loss.
A Far Eastern executive said the company will focus on regional routes in the next decade.

In addition to a domestic route between Taipei and Kaohsiung, the Taipei-based airline operates international services to China, South Korea Indonesia, Malaysia, Palau, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia.
Taiwan's domestic air services are in tatters in less than one year after the Taiwan High Speed Rail became operational in January this year.

Mandarin Airlines canceled its Taipei-Taichung route in May, followed by Uni Air's termination of its service on the Taipei-Chiayi route. TransAsia Airways is still hanging on to its Taipei-Tainan route by using a propeller airplane with about 70 seats, with the price set at NT$998 for a one-way flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: First-class disaster response center in Taipei

TEXT.P: Taiwan's most advanced emergency response center, equipped with state-of-the-art information and communication systems and capable of resisting the most severe disasters, was inaugurated in Taipei City Wednesday, a Taipei City official said.

The building, built at a cost of NT$1.2 billion (US$37.07 million), has seven floors above and two floors under the ground. The building was designed to resist floods and earthquakes of up to level seven intensity, the official said.

Moreover, the roof has a helicopter landing pad to facilitate air rescues, while the building can maintain smooth telecommunications and provide an uninterrupted supply of water and electricity for three consecutive days in support of rescue operations.

The Taipei City Urban Search and Rescue Team carried out a 10-minute emergency response drill at the inauguration ceremony, featuring a series of rescue and relief operations involving rescue members and search dogs.
The Taipei City Fire Department also gave a briefing on the center's establishment, management, and operations during the inauguration ceremony.
Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin said the city government established the center to ensure that Taipei City citizens benefit from the most timely disaster rescue and relief assistance.
He also spoke of his hope that the center would minimize the harm done by every kind of potential disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's human rights worsens: TFD report

TEXT.P: There was no progress in the social, economic and cultural human rights situation in China in 2007, while education rights, political rights and freedom of speech were even worse than in 2005, experts said at a seminar held in Taipei Tuesday.

The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) , a non-partisan organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and human rights in Taiwan and abroad and the first democracy assistance foundation in Asia, organized the seminar in which it released its "2007 China Human Rights Report: Observation on Social, Economic, and Educational and Cultural Rights."

TFD Vice President Tung Li-wen said it is appalling that both the educational rights and rights of free speech compared with 2005 have deteriorated in 2007, despite the national guidelines of Chinese President Hu Jin-tao's proposal to build a "harmonious society." He added that the Communist Party of China (CPC) has severely sacrificed its people's rights while putting every effort into holding the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games and its power transition in the 17th National Congress.

Moreover, the so called "black-hearted" substandard products made in China have become the greatest nightmare for the Chinese people as well as the whole world, Tung said, adding that they are evidence of how social rights are ignored in China and how negligent the government can be with regard to its people's health and lives.

Addressing the same occasion, Robert Menard, founder and secretary- general of Reporters Without Borders , a Paris-based international non-governmental organization dedicated to promoting press freedom, said that China's enormous economic development has not brought progress to its human rights situation or its freedom of the press.

Menard said that even though in January the CPC eased the regulations governing the work of foreign journalists because of the Olympics, there have nonetheless been at least 60 cases of police detaining or obstructing foreign correspondents, which proves again that China's promises are merely lip service. Therefore, pressure should be kept on China through the International Olympic Committee to guarantee freedom of expression and respect for the Olympic Charter's humanistic values, Menard said.

Lee Yu-jung, an assistant professor of the Department of Public Affairs and Management at Tainan University, who was also present at the seminar, said the power struggle between Shin Kong Mitsukoshi and Beijing's Hualian Group over the Shin Kong Place in Beijing demonstrates the regression of economic rights in China in 2007, despite the announcement and implementation of the Property Law of the People's Republic of China in March and October.

In short, even though a representative of the Beijing Candidate Committee said in 2001 that "by entrusting the organization of the Olympic Games to Beijing, you will help the development of human rights" after Beijing was awarded the 2008 Olympics, no durable improvements have been seen in human rights, while some rights have been subjected to greater suppression.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City's eco-friendly plan wins global acclaim

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government in southern Taiwan proposed an action plan on the protection of city climates at a recent global meeting, receiving widespread recognition, a city official said Wednesday.

It marked the first time that a plan proposed by a local government in Taiwan to combat global warming had been recognized by the international community, said Hsiao Yu-cheng, head of the port city's Environmental Protection Bureau.

The remarks came after Hsiao led a delegation that attended the 13th Session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) held in Bali, Indonesia, Dec. 8-11.
The Taiwanese officials took part in the conference not as UNFCCC members but as members of the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI), Hsiao noted.
Kaohsiung City joined the ICLEI in 2006, making it Taiwan's first city to become an ICLEI member, Hsiao said.
Established in 1990, the ICLEI is composed of 715 local governments in 67 countries and is aimed at encouraging local governments to engage in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
Over the years, the ICLEI has initiated many campaigns and programs to help local governments seek sustainable development, earning the organization widespread acclaim.
At the conference, Hsiao proposed the port city's action plan to implement the ICLEI's Cities for Climate Protection (CCP) program to the ICLEI Secretariat and the plan was adopted.
While attending an ICLEI pre-meeting, Hsiao also discussed with ICLEI Secretary- General Konrad Otto-Zimmermann and CEO Wayne Wescott the eco-friendly measures taken by Kaohsiung City.
Hsiao told them the Kaohsiung city government has effectively controlled pollution emissions of factories in the area.
In addition, he said the city government is encouraging local citizens to replace old scooters as part of its efforts to minimize scooter emissions.
Hsiao also noted that the city's subway system -- which will be inaugurated soon -- along with a bus transfer system and bicycle lanes, will enhance the use of the city's mass transportation systems.
He described the vision of transforming the port city into a "low carbon city" as "not unattainable."

DOC.HEADLINE: High price affects willingness to travel by bullet train: survey

TEXT.P: High ticket prices as well as the inconvenience of shuttling to bullet train stations have dampened the public's willingness to travel by high speed rail, according to a survey released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Wednesday.

The first survey on the use of the high speed rail system since its inauguration early this year also found that public opinion is split on the ticket price, with 44.7 percent of respondents saying that the price is reasonable, while 48.2 percent said the price is unreasonable.
The MOTC suggested that the Bureau of High Speed Rail urged Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp., the operator of the bullet train, to offer lower ticket rates during off-peak hours.
The survey also found that around 22 percent of people over 20 have traveled on the high speed train.

For those who have traveled on the high speed rail system but say they would not do so again, the most common reason is "an overall exorbitant price, " including the shuttle service fee to downtown, cited by 44.2 percent of respondents.
For those who have yet to travel by the train, over 75 percent said they have no need to do so, while 7.3 percent cited the high price when asked for their reasons.
For those who have taken a single-ride, 22.2 percent said that the price is too high when asked why they were not traveling by bullet train in both directions.
Asked what improvements are required, most people pointed to the ticket price.

The survey also found that most passengers travel to the high speed rail stations in their own vehicles (44. 6 percent), while most leave the stations after being picked up by relatives and friends (28.4 percent).
For those who used to travel by air, 67.2 percent switched to the bullet train after its inauguration; among those used to traveling by rail, 47.6 percent have switched to the bullet train.
In addition, even though air carriers have launched preferential ticket prices to compete with the high speed rail, only 41.8 percent said they would re- consider travel by air.
Even though the express train is cheaper by 20 or 30 percent than high speed rail, over half said they still prefer the high speed train.

MOTC officials said that the biggest edge the high speed train offers is a sharp reduction in travel time, noting that of those who travel both ways using the high speed rail system, over 68.4 percent said they return home the same day.

Eastern Public Relations Co. at the commission of the MOTC, conducted the survey on people over 20 years of age Sept. 17-28. A total of 1,713 valid responses were collected with a margin of error of 2.4 percentage points.

The 345-km high speed rail, which links Taipei in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, cuts the travel time to 90 minutes from the original four and a half hours. Standard fare for a single ride between Taipei and Kaohsiung is NT$1,490 (US$46).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City cracks down on economic crime

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government had pursued 708 cases of economic crime in the first 10 months of this year, up by 14.5 percent year on year, the municipal Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported Wednesday.

According to department officials, as much as NT$560 million (US$17.3 million) worth of illegal earnings from these cases was tracked by municipal law enforcement agents, with 49.5 percent of the total value incurred from 493 infringements on intellectual property rights, such as the illegal downloading of music or films.

The number of criminal cases related to illegal or violent debt collection rose several fold, prompting municipal police authorities to step up their crackdown on underground loan sharks, the officials said, ascribing the phenomenon to excess consumption loans granted by banks to individual clients, who then turn to loan sharks to repay their debts.

DOC.HEADLINE: international headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Pentagon Critical Of NATO Allies
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates sharply criticized NATO countries yesterday for not supplying urgently needed trainers, helicopters and infantry for Afghanistan as violence escalates there, vowing not to let the alliance "off the hook."
The Washington Times:Cuts in prison time for crack approved
The U.S. Sentencing Commission yesterday unanimously voted to give retroactive status to an amendment in the federal sentencing guidelines that reduces penalties for crack-cocaine offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to hold biggest yet combined exhibition next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will hold the annual bicycle and sporting goods shows together March 13-16 next year, forming the country's biggest ever exhibition event, a TAITRA executive said Wednesday.
The two exhibitions will feature a total of 4,300 booths and are expected to draw 65,000 visitors and 7,000 foreign buyers, TAITRA Vice President Walter Yeh said.

The Taipei International Cycle Show 2008 (Taipei Cycle) will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Nangang Exhibition Hall in Nangang District in Taipei City. The grand opening of the newly completed hall is slated for March 13 next year, the first day of the two exhibitions, Yeh said.
Meanwhile, the Taipei International Sporting Goods Show 2008 (TAISPO) will be held at the old TWTC Exhibition Hall in the Hsinyi district of Taipei City.

TAITRA has received over 700 applications from both domestic and foreign firms for Taipei Cycle, which is the largest bicycle show in Asia and the third largest in the world. Booths booked for next year's event already exceeded 2,700, marking an 18 percent year-on-year growth, Yeh said.
The TAISPO has about 1,600 booths from 254 firms, but the event will not be open to general public, Yeh said.

Yeh pointed out the "Tour de Taiwan" tournament--an international bicycle race held annually in Taiwan--will include the two exhibition venues as additional legs in its race next year, which will be held at the time of the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC entitled to draft contingency measures: Executive Yuan

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will fully respect a draft containing a set of measures being drawn up by the Central Election Commission (CEC) to handle contingencies in the run-up to elections or on voting days, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

Shieh made the comments while answering questions from reporters following a weekly Executive Yuan meeting and after the China Times reported in its Tuesday edition that the CEC is crafting a set of contingency measures to deal with "natural catastrophes" or other "unavoidable situations" ahead of elections and on polling days.

According to the report, the CEC will be entitled to set a new polling day for future elections in case of "natural disasters" or "unavoidable situations, " should the CEC members approve the draft measures.

Stressing that the Executive Yuan will respect relevant proposals put forward by the CEC in this regard, Shieh said that it is tremendously important to maintain fair and smooth operations in the legislative and presidential elections slated for early next year.

As the CEC has decided to adopt a "one-step" voting format in the two elections, the central government said it will not allow some local governments to implement a "two-step" voting scheme in defiance of the CEC's decision.

"Two different voting systems would be totally unfair to all candidates, political parties, electoral workers and voters, " he pointed out, adding that "any irregularities prior to or during the elections will not be tolerated, including efforts to rig elections or buy votes."
However, Shieh declined to answer the question of whether the draft bill being worked on by the CEC has something to do with the voting format dispute between the central and local governments.
CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung urged the public not to overreact to the draft, saying that the measures being assessed already form part of the CEC's internal regulations.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated a day earlier in a cross-agency crime- fighting meeting that the government will not allow gangsters, vote-buying or other irregularities to influence the outcomes of the elections and nor will it permit a "two-step" voting format.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to help Taichung create business opportunities in MRT stations

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government signed an agreement with the city government of Taichung Wednesday to offer technical assistance and help Taichung develop eight stations on its mass rapid transit (MRT) system's Wurih-Beitun Line.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu inked the pact at a ceremony in the Taipei MRT system's Zhongxiao-Fuxing Station near the Sogo Department Store's Fuxing Branch.

Speaking at the ceremony, Hau pointed out that the city-owned Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) in charge of operating the Taipei MRT system, is very experienced in creating business opportunities in stations along the MRT lines, and has created many win-win situations for the city government and firms housed in various stations.

Hu said the Taichung city government will pay a reasonable fee for the technical assistance. He added that the development project is expected to create business opportunities worth NT$15 billion (US$46.35 million) and net NT$1.8 billion a year for the Taichung city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessman meets Pope

TEXT.P: Francis Chen, founder and president of the Franz Collection Inc., presented a Chinese porcelain piece modeled on the work of a late Italian horse painter to Pope Benedict XVI during a meeting in the Vatican Tuesday.

Chen said in an interview with the Central News Agency (CNA) prior to his departure for the Vatican for the rare meeting that he was shocked that he would have the honor of meeting with the Pope when he learned of the audience two months ago.

He said he later learned that one of his friends had helped arrange for the meeting after his company failed to organize a painting exhibition with the Taipei-based National Palace Museum in the Vatican.

The Franz Collection and the Palace Museum originally planned to hold an exhibition featuring a painting collection created by well-known Western missionary-painter Giuseppe Castiglione, also known by his Chinese name Lang Shih-ning, who died in 1766, Chen went on.
The exhibition was also to feature a porcelain work produced for the Franz Collection, Chen said, adding that the work reinterprets one of Castiglione's paintings.

Castiglione was born in Milan, Italy, in 1688. At the age of 27, he was sent by the Vatican to preach in China. He later attracted the attention of Emperor Qian Long of the Qing dynasty and served as an artist for the court.
During the three-hour meeting, the Pope presided over a blessing ceremony and engaged in a cultural dialogue with his guest, according to Chen.

As part of its efforts to promote culture, the Franz Collection previously donated NT$10 million (US$308,928) to sponsor an exhibition showcasing 14th- Century paintings from the Vatican and the Museum of Milan, Chen said.
Chen founded the Franz Collection in 2001, and has established branches in Germany, the United States, Japan, and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature acts to relax restrictions on parental leave

TEXT.P: Lawmakers in the legislative committee on sanitation and the environment, and social welfare passed a draft amendment to the "Gender Equality in Employment Act" Wednesday, which would relax restrictions on applications for parental leave.

The draft amendment, which also proposes changing the title of the act to the "Sexual Equality in Employment Act, " stipulates that no matter how small a company in scale and size, it will be required to agree to applications for parently leave without pay from employees who have worked in the company for at least one year.
The proposal would also prolong the period of paternity leave from two days to three.

Legislator Cheng Yun-Peng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who put forth the amendment, explained that national health insurance covers hospital costs for three days following a natural birth, meaning a newborn's mother can stay at hospital for three days.
However, the existing law only offers the father a two-day leave with pay to stay with the mother, Cheng said.
The amended bill is expected to affect about 900,000 enterprises around the country, officials of the Council of Labor Affairs said.

Under the existing law, only a worker in a company with more than 30 employees is eligible to apply for parental leave, which can last for at most two years, so long as he/she has worked at the company for 12 months or more.
The draft amendment also stipulates that the employer cannot reject an application for parental leave without pay, nor can employers punish workers for taking such leave.

Commenting on the draft amendment, an executive of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries complained that the bill has failed to take the current operational challenges facing local enterprises into consideration, warning that the amendment will greatly affect small- and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND denies defense minister gave assurance to U.S. government

TEXT.P: A Ministry of National Defense (MND) official denied Wednesday that Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu's ongoing Latin American visit is to assure the U.S. government that Taiwan will not do anything to disturb cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
Chen Kuo-hsiang, director-general of the MND's General Political Warfare Bureau, issued the denial in response to questions from legislators on the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the main opposition Kuomintang claimed that Lee has disguised the main purpose of his visit to Central and South America, saying that his main purpose is actually to make a transit stop in the United States to assure the American government that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -proposed referendum on whether Taiwan should join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is not aimed at provoking China nor will it cause a conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

The DPP's plan to hold the referendum alongside the presidential election next year has caused deep concern in both the U.S. and China, with American government officials reiterating on many occasions Washington's opposition to such a proposal, while Chinese and U.S. officials are also making frequent contact on the issue. China sees the referendum proposal as a move to march toward de jure independence, while the American government is worried that the movement might affect the cross-strait status quo.

According to Ting, Washington is also concerned that Taiwan's legislative and presidential elections to be held early next year will further complicate cross- strait ties, which are already tense, and Lee was asked by the U.S. government to give an assurance that Taiwan will not do anything provocative.
Chen said he did not know where Ting's sources were from but he assured him that Lee's Latin American visit is purely for military exchanges with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region.
According to Chen, Lee departed Nov. 29 to visit several of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including the Dominican Republic and Paraguay, and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 13, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MND denies defense minister gave assurance to U.S. government

TEXT.P: A Ministry of National Defense (MND) official denied Wednesday that Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu's ongoing Latin American visit is to assure the U.S. government that Taiwan will not do anything to disturb cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
Chen Kuo-hsiang, director-general of the MND's General Political Warfare Bureau, issued the denial in response to questions from legislators on the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the main opposition Kuomintang claimed that Lee has disguised the main purpose of his visit to Central and South America, saying that his main purpose is actually to make a transit stop in the United States to assure the American government that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -proposed referendum on whether Taiwan should join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is not aimed at provoking China nor will it cause a conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

The DPP's plan to hold the referendum alongside the presidential election next year has caused deep concern in both the U.S. and China, with American government officials reiterating on many occasions Washington's opposition to such a proposal, while Chinese and U.S. officials are also making frequent contact on the issue. China sees the referendum proposal as a move to march toward de jure independence, while the American government is worried that the movement might affect the cross-strait status quo.

According to Ting, Washington is also concerned that Taiwan's legislative and presidential elections to be held early next year will further complicate cross- strait ties, which are already tense, and Lee was asked by the U.S. government to give an assurance that Taiwan will not do anything provocative.
Chen said he did not know where Ting's sources were from but he assured him that Lee's Latin American visit is purely for military exchanges with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region.
According to Chen, Lee departed Nov. 29 to visit several of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including the Dominican Republic and Paraguay, and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature acts to relax restrictions on parental leave

TEXT.P: Lawmakers in the legislative committee on sanitation and the environment, and social welfare passed a draft amendment to the "Gender Equality in Employment Act" Wednesday, which would relax restrictions on applications for parental leave.

The draft amendment, which also proposes changing the title of the act to the "Sexual Equality in Employment Act, " stipulates that no matter how small a company in scale and size, it will be required to agree to applications for parently leave without pay from employees who have worked in the company for at least one year.
The proposal would also prolong the period of paternity leave from two days to three.

Legislator Cheng Yun-Peng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who put forth the amendment, explained that national health insurance covers hospital costs for three days following a natural birth, meaning a newborn's mother can stay at hospital for three days.
However, the existing law only offers the father a two-day leave with pay to stay with the mother, Cheng said.
The amended bill is expected to affect about 900,000 enterprises around the country, officials of the Council of Labor Affairs said.

Under the existing law, only a worker in a company with more than 30 employees is eligible to apply for parental leave, which can last for at most two years, so long as he/she has worked at the company for 12 months or more.
The draft amendment also stipulates that the employer cannot reject an application for parental leave without pay, nor can employers punish workers for taking such leave.

Commenting on the draft amendment, an executive of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries complained that the bill has failed to take the current operational challenges facing local enterprises into consideration, warning that the amendment will greatly affect small- and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to help Taichung create business opportunities in MRT stations

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government signed an agreement with the city government of Taichung Wednesday to offer technical assistance and help Taichung develop eight stations on its mass rapid transit (MRT) system's Wurih-Beitun Line.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu inked the pact at a ceremony in the Taipei MRT system's Zhongxiao-Fuxing Station near the Sogo Department Store's Fuxing Branch.

Speaking at the ceremony, Hau pointed out that the city-owned Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) in charge of operating the Taipei MRT system, is very experienced in creating business opportunities in stations along the MRT lines, and has created many win-win situations for the city government and firms housed in various stations.

Hu said the Taichung city government will pay a reasonable fee for the technical assistance. He added that the development project is expected to create business opportunities worth NT$15 billion (US$46.35 million) and net NT$1.8 billion a year for the Taichung city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC entitled to draft contingency measures: Executive Yuan

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will fully respect a draft containing a set of measures being drawn up by the Central Election Commission (CEC) to handle contingencies in the run-up to elections or on voting days, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday.

Shieh made the comments while answering questions from reporters following a weekly Executive Yuan meeting and after the China Times reported in its Tuesday edition that the CEC is crafting a set of contingency measures to deal with "natural catastrophes" or other "unavoidable situations" ahead of elections and on polling days.

According to the report, the CEC will be entitled to set a new polling day for future elections in case of "natural disasters" or "unavoidable situations, " should the CEC members approve the draft measures.

Stressing that the Executive Yuan will respect relevant proposals put forward by the CEC in this regard, Shieh said that it is tremendously important to maintain fair and smooth operations in the legislative and presidential elections slated for early next year.

As the CEC has decided to adopt a "one-step" voting format in the two elections, the central government said it will not allow some local governments to implement a "two-step" voting scheme in defiance of the CEC's decision.

"Two different voting systems would be totally unfair to all candidates, political parties, electoral workers and voters, " he pointed out, adding that "any irregularities prior to or during the elections will not be tolerated, including efforts to rig elections or buy votes."
However, Shieh declined to answer the question of whether the draft bill being worked on by the CEC has something to do with the voting format dispute between the central and local governments.
CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung urged the public not to overreact to the draft, saying that the measures being assessed already form part of the CEC's internal regulations.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated a day earlier in a cross-agency crime- fighting meeting that the government will not allow gangsters, vote-buying or other irregularities to influence the outcomes of the elections and nor will it permit a "two-step" voting format.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision International president visits Taiwan to promote MED

TEXT.P: World Vision International (WVI) President and Chief Executive Officer Dean Hirsch is visiting Taipei to promote the Micro Enterprise Development (MED) program aimed at helping children from impoverished families, a World Vision Taiwan executive said Thursday.

Hirsch attended a seminar with representatives from the local business community shortly after his arrival Wednesday to share with them the MED's achievements in other countries around the world since 1993.

According to Hirsch, the MED program has been launched in 58 of the nearly 100 countries where the WVI maintains operations. Under the program, the WVI has offered US$1 billion in soft loans to help individuals and households to launch businesses and earn a sustainable income.

Noting that the MED currently only has US$250 million in capital, Hirsch said that the WVI, a global partnership committed to helping the world's poor, intends to raise more funds for the program with the aim of helping improve the lives of 8 million children around the globe, creating 4 million jobs and providing loans to 2 million people by 2011.
Hirsch said Taiwanese business groups are welcome to cooperate with the WVI in carrying out the MED program to help more people and households to stand on their own feet and escape poverty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official opposes draft amendment on expanding parental leave

TEXT.P: A ranking economic planning official voiced opposition Thursday to a draft amendment to a law that would expand the right of parental leave to laborers.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, was referring to a draft amendment to the "Gender Equality in Employment Act," which passed the first reading in the legislature a day earlier.

Under the amendment, all companies, regardless of their size, would be required to grant maternity leave for up to two years to all employees who have worked for the company for at least one year. Companies that do not face fines of up to NT$100,000 (US$3,090).
Currently, only companies with more than 30 employees are required to do so.
The proposed amendment would also extend the period of paternity leave from two days to three days.
Yeh said the Legislative Yuan "means well" by passing the first reading of the amendment to encourage more women to have babies at a time of declining birth rates in the country.
However, he added that the enactment of amendment could affect employers' willingness to hire women.

He said that gender is no longer the main issue in Taiwan's workplace, but the enactment of the amendment to give women long periods of maternity leave would make employers think twice before hiring them.
He suggested that the issue be left to employers and employees to work out on their own.

Meanwhile, Lin Ping-pin, president of the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, said that most of the businesses that are members of the association have limited staff numbers and that if the draft amendment is passed into law, it will affect their willingness to hire women, adding that women could suffer before benefiting from the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate to depart for Japan Dec. 16

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh is scheduled to depart Dec. 16 for Japan for a four-day visit, Hsieh's campaign aides said Thursday.

During the visit, Hsieh will meet with former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and Dietnam Takeo Hiranuma, who heads a pro-Taiwan parliamentary sub-group, they said, adding that Hsieh is also expected to meet with former Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.

As opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou also met with Mori and Hiranuma during his Japanese trip last month, it is widely believed that the arrangements of Hsieh's upcoming Japanese tour are intended to demonstrate Hsieh's political influence in Japan.
The first stop of Hsieh's visit will be Kyoto, where he will deliver a speech at the Kyoto University Alumni Club as an alumni on "ways to strengthen Taiwan- Japan relations."
Hsieh will also call on his mentor -- law professor Shigeaki Tanaka -- and the owner of a noodle store where he worked part-time while studying at the university.
In Tokyo, Hsieh will attend a reception hosted by the Taiwanese expatriate community in Japan and address the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan, in addition to meeting with Japanese politicians.

Also during the trip, Hsieh will visit Japanese chip maker Elpida Memory Inc., which has entered into a joint venture with Taiwan's Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. to set up an electronics firm in Taiwan.
Accompanying Hsieh during the Japanese visit will be his wife Yu Fang-chi, Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing and a group of legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 302.89 points, or 3.56 percent, to close at 8,187.95.
The bourse opened at 8,485.56 and fluctuated between 8,522.14 and 8,187.95 during trading. A total of 4.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$140.98 billion (US$4.36 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 6.1 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 5.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 4 percent, construction issues at 3.7 percent, textile stocks at 3.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 3 percent, and banking and financial shares at 2.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 195, with 318 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes foreign banks to help globalization: economist

TEXT.P: Economics expert Schive Chi said at a recent luncheon organized by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei that Taiwan welcomes foreign banks that can help globalize local banks.

When foreign banks enter the market not as a branch but as a subsidiary, "they will have a very positive influence on industry standards, " Schive said in his Wednesday speech, titled "Opportunities for New Markets and New Products."

Touching on the government's role in banking reform, Schive went on that if Taiwan's next president can make the financial sector truly transparent and independent, the outlook for Taiwan's financial market will be much brighter.

Schive, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, further suggested in his speech that local banks can apply what they have learned from their partnerships with foreign banks in Taiwan to tackle problems they might encounter in China because "whatever has happened here is likely to be repeated in China."
Within this framework, Schive suggested that the government improve its supervisory skills and philosophy.
"The regulators should take the regulated as a partner, rather than seeing the relationships as one between superiors and subordinates," Schive added.

In another 10 or 12 years, Schive suggested, this part of the world will be even more integrated economically, with some kind of regional free trade agreement functioning. " Our domestic banks, particularly the larger ones, will presumably go abroad, especially within the region, to acquire local banks, " he predicted.
Schive further said in his speech that "over the next decade, our capital market will play some roles that used to be played by banks."

As to the future competition between banks, Schive accentuated that "it will be focused on who can give the best service to customers" because banking is basically a people business, of which a key element will be hiring or developing the right talent.
"In this next stage of development, success will depend on having more sophisticated, more internationally minded personnel," Schive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New law needed to protect potential indigenous leaders' rights: CIP

TEXT.P: A new law is needed to ensure that only indigenous people can be elected as chiefs of aboriginal autonomous regions, the head of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) said Thursday.

CIP Minister Icyang Parod said during a Legislative Yuan session that since a draft bill governing indigenous residents' autonomous rights stipulates that all Republic of China citizens enjoy equal political rights in indigenous autonomous regions, there is no legal clause to prohibit Han Chinese citizens from participating in elections of local chiefs in indigenous autonomous regions.
Against this backdrop, he said, an article should be added to the draft bill to stipulate that only indigenous people can be elected as chiefs of aboriginal autonomous regions.

Parod made the remarks in response to ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Ying and opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chang Jen-hsiang, who criticized the Executive Yuan-authored indigenous residents' autonomous rights draft bill as allowing all Taiwan citizens to have right to run for seats representing indigenous regions as long as they maintain household registration in those regions.
This stipulation runs seriously counter to the spirit of indigenous autonomy, the legislators pointed out.

Meanwhile, Chang lashed out at the Executive Yuan for referring the indigenous residents' autonomous rights draft bill to the Legislative Yuan for legislation more than four years after the draft bill was hammered out in June 2003 and only at a crucial moment when legislative hearings on the general budget for 2008 are about to begin.
Chang accused the Executive Yuan of "trying to hold hostage" the legislators at a crucial time.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's intimidation won't sway push for U.N. referendum: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that China's intimidation will not sway the Taiwan people's resolve to push for a referendum on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

President Chen said that since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party initiated a referendum on the U.N. membership bid, Beijing has used an array of political and economic means, including outright threats, to pressure China-based Taiwan business people to side with China or speak out against the referendum.

However, the president said, China's crude attempt to obstruct the Taiwan people's legitimate right to deepen their country's democracy by holding the referendum will not sway their resolve to push for the referendum, which is slated to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election. He added that such attempts by Beijing will only antagonize the Taiwan people.
Both China and the United States, Taiwan's staunch supporter, have voiced opposition to the referendum out of concerns that it represents a step toward de jure independence.

The president also said that the government is dedicated to enticing Taiwan business people operating overseas to return to Taiwan, noting that an office to help them return for investment was established in July this year.

He added that by the end of October, overseas Taiwanese have invested NT$8.8 billion (US$271.6 million) in the country in 91 projects, with 43 of the investment projects involving China-based Taiwan business people.
The president made the remarks when he received winners of the National Golden Award for Architecture at the Presidential Office.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 392 points to finish at 8,110, with 3,145 contracts traded, while March futures lost 378 points to close at 8,122, with 76 contract transactions. Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures lost 18.35 points to close at 330.1, with 4,308 contracts traded, while January TE futures moved down 18.5 points to finish at 330, with 587 contract transactions.
