DOC.HEADLINE: Pope meets Taiwanese delegation
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/07 17:12:54 (By Huang Kwang-chun and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Pope Benedict XVI met a three-member delegation from Taiwan Wednesday at the Vatican and received a set of porcelain pieces modeled on the work of a famous 18th-century Italian missionary-painter as a gift.
The meeting was part of the pope's weekly public audience, in which the pope met with some 8,000 people from all over the world.
The gift was presented by Francis Chen, founder and president of the Franz Collection Inc., which was inaugurated in 2001 and now has branches in Germany, the United States, Japan and Russia.
The other members of the Taiwanese delegation were Fu Jen Catholic University President Bernard Li and Shaw-Lan Wang, publisher of the Chinese-language United Daily News based in Taipei.
During the meeting, Li reported the recent developments concerning the Catholic university to the pope and invited him to visit the school, which is located in Taipei County, northern Taiwan.
Wang greeted the pope in French.

Meanwhile, the pope expressed gratification while accepting the gift from Chen who explained to the pope that the set was created based on paintings created by well-known Western missionary-painter Giuseppe Castiglione.

Castiglione, also known by his Chinese name Lang Shining, was born in Milan, Italy, in 1688. At the age of 27, he was sent by the Vatican to preach in China. He later attracted the attention of Emperor Qian Long of the Qing dynasty and served as an artist for the court. He died in 1766.

Chen said in an interview with the Central News Agency prior to his departure for the Vatican for the rare meeting that he was extremely surprised when he learned two months earlier that he would have the honor of meeting with the pope.

He said he later learned that one of his friends had helped arrange for the meeting after his company failed to organize an exhibition with the Taipei-based National Palace Museum in the Vatican to display Castiglione's painting collection.
The exhibition was also to feature a porcelain piece produced by the Franz Collection, Chen said, adding that the work reinterprets one of Castiglione's paintings.

As part of its efforts to promote culture, the Franz Collection, in addition to presenting the gift to the pope, previously donated NT$10 million (US$308,928) to sponsor an exhibition in Taipei showcasing 14th-century paintings from the Vatican and the Museum of Milan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP rebuts KMT speculation about possible election delays

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rebutted Thursday speculation raised by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) about possible delays in the approaching legislative and presidential elections.
Speaking at a Legislative Yuan news conference, DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Tuoh accused the KMT of lacking vision and still harboring the old mindset of its past martial law era.

The KMT accused the DPP a day earlier of seeking to defer the legislative and presidential elections slated for early next year after government spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said that the Executive Yuan will fully respect any proposals put forward by the Central Election Commission (CEC) to deal with possible contingencies such as "natural catastrophes" or "avoidable and irresistible situations" prior to the elections or on the actual polling days.

The Taipei-based China Times reported Tuesday that the CEC was working on a draft containing a set of contingency measures to serve that end. If the CEC members approve the measures, the CEC will be entitled to set new polling days for future elections, according to the report.

The DPP has shown its "true colors" by "attempting to postpone the two key elections" through creating woes and causing conflict in the run-up to the polls so that it can announce postponements of the elections and impose martial law, the KMT said.

According to Wang, the KMT has been possessed with "evil ideas" by making the charges. As Taiwan has evolved into a democratic and diversified society, the president cannot recklessly announce an emergency decree to delay elections or impose martial law, he said, arguing that "only a dictator would do so."
The KMT must not twist the contingency measures being drafted by the CEC and rehash the issue in the face of the two elections, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese emperor's birthday celebrated in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) sponsored a cocktail reception in the southern port city Wednesday to mark the birthday of Japanese Emperor Akihito, a Kaohsiung city government official said Thursday.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu -- accompanied by Deputy Mayor Lin Ren-yi and Hsu Chuan-sheng, director of the city's Social Affairs Bureau -- attended the party to celebrate Akihito's 74th birthday, which falls on Dec. 23, the official went on.

Also present were JIA Chairman Masaji Takahashi, JIA Kaohsiung Office Director Hiromichi Kobe, Yu Hong, chief executive officer of the Southern Taiwan Joint Services Center under the Executive Yuan and Tracy Thiele, director of the Kaohsiung Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, the official said.
The party marked the first local celebration of Akihito's birthday since Japan switched diplomatic allegiance from Taiwan to China in 1975, according to the official.

Chen -- who is slated to pay a four-day visit to Japan at the head of a delegation beginning Sunday -- said it is a pity that only 100,000 out of the 1.1 million visits to Taiwan paid by Japanese tourists each year are to Kaohsiung, Chen said, expressing hope that more Japanese tourists will visit Kaohsiung using the high speed railway.
She also expressed hope that Kaohsiung can have the opportunity to boost ties with Japanese cities by conducting exchanges in various fields.
The JIA is a semi-official organization authorized to handle affairs between Taiwan and Japan in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry mum on admiral's stumping for DPP candidate

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) kept mum on opposition lawmakers' accusations Thursday that Adm. Chi Ling-lien broke the military's position of political neutrality by stumping for a ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative candidate.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Lee Chia-chin and Lu Chia-chen accused Chi of stumping for DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung during a campaign rally held in Taipei County at the beginning of this month. Chi reportedly also delivered a speech during the drive.

The KMT legislators said Chi violated the National Defense Act, which stipulates that military personnel should remain politically neutral and should not express their support for any candidate in public functions, irrespective of whether they are on or off duty.
Lee demanded that the Defense Ministry deal with Chi in accordance with the military code.

Military spokesman Yu Sy-tue declined to comment on the allegation, but reiterated that the MND's stance on military neutrality remains unchanged and that the ministry will continue to require active-duty officers and enlisted men, as well as cadets at military academies, to stay out of political or election activities.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung offered an apology to Chi and to the Defense Ministry for causing trouble for them. Lee said he thought Chi had already retired, which he said would have freed him from military rulings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Austrian BASE jumper to be blacklisted for unlawful jump

TEXT.P: Taiwan will ban Austrian BASE jumper Felix Baumgartner from visiting the country again after he made an unlawful jump from the Taipei 101 skyscraper earlier this week, National Immigration Agency (NIA) officials said Thursday.

Baumgartner parachuted from the 91st floor of the 509 meter building Tuesday, landing on the roof-top car park of the neighboring Taipei World Trade Center building. He departed for Hong Kong that same day soon after finishing the jump -- a promotional event sponsored by the energy drink manufacturer Red Bull.

NIA officials pointed out that Baumgartner, who entered Taiwan on landing visa, violated the Immigration Act by engaging in an activity inconsistent with the purpose of his visit and being involved in an act considered by the authorities to be detrimental to Taiwan's national interests, public security, public order or the good customs of the country.

Meanwhile, Taipei police said that despite his having already left the country, they are planning to refer Baumgartner for prosecution on charges of endangering public security. They also claimed that the management of Taipei 101 can sue him for intruding into the building and damaging the building's tiles during the jump.
An internationally renowned daredevil, Baumgartner has performed a number of dangerous stunts throughout his career.

They include a skydive in 1999 from the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia -- then the world's highest skyscraper -- and a jump from the Christ statue in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, that same year.
In 2003, he became the first person to skydive across the English Channel using a specially made fiber wing, and in 2004, he became the first person to BASE jump from the Milau Viaduct in France.
In 2006, he skydived into and then BASE jumped from the Turning Torso building in Malmo, Sweden.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.360.
A total of US$1.09 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.350 and fluctuated between NT$32.348 and NT$32.385.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned Taiwanese dancer to present new creation next January

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwanese dancer Sheu Fang-yi will present Taiwanese audiences with a new dance next January, a result of her residence at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in New York earlier this year, Sheu said Thursday.

Titled "37 Arts, " the new creation is named after the building in which the arts center is located. Sheu created the dance with her partner Bulareyaung Pagarlava, a Paiwan aboriginal dancer-turned-choreographer, during their eight-week residence at the center from July to September, Sheu said.

Sheu is the first Asian artist invited to the arts center established by Mikhail Baryshnikov, one of the world's best-known dancers and choreographers. Taiwanese play director Lee Chien-chang, traveling dancer in Germany Chiang Pau-shu, and stunt expert Huang Ming-cheng all participated in Sheu's residence project.
The new dance will show the choreographers' contradictory feelings "of being at an execution ground and paradise at the same time" during their stay at the center, Sheu said.

"I felt like an angel in paradise to be invited for a residence at the world- renowned arts center, " Sheu said. Meanwhile, "we spent almost every waking minute practicing and experienced pain and great frustration, " Sheu added.
"A dancer's life can be part of creation, as new dances continue to present themselves," Bulareyaung said.
Taiwanese director Ang Lee and Baryshnikov both viewed rehearsals of Sheu's new work in New York, and gave her great support, Sheu revealed.
"After establishing a connection with the arts center, the most exciting thing for me now is to share with the Taiwanese people what we created there, " Sheu said.
The new dances are scheduled to be shown in Yilan County Jan. 12, Taipei City Jan. 17-19, and Taichung City Jan. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chung Hsing University sets up R&D center in orchid plantation

TEXT.P: National Chung Hsing University (NCHU) and the Tainan county government signed an agreement Thursday to set up a research and development center in the Taiwan Orchid Plantation, located in the southern Taiwan county.
Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih and NCHU President Shaw Jei-fu signed the agreement.

Su noted that Tainan County has the biggest plantation areas in the nation. At this critical juncture of upgrading its agriculture, it must rely on technical support from the academic sector to overcome problems encountered by the agricultural sector.
He said that in addition to the NCHU, National University of Kaohsiung will also sign an agreement with the county government to set up a facility in the plantation Dec. 17.

Coupled with the Biotechnology Experiment Center in Southern Taiwan set up by Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, Tainan County could become a platform for cooperation between the industrial and academic sectors, which he said will help attract national-level projects to the county.

Shaw said that if Taiwan can use its edge in agricultural production, the gross profits could even surpass those of electronic products, adding that Taiwan needs to develop superb agriculture to create more profit.

He also said his university is the leader in agricultural science and that he hopes to make good use of the results of the R&D center so that the output of the county's agriculture can become No. 1 in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says family threatened

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that members of his family, including his daughter and a grandson, have been threatened with violence and abduction.

Chen disclosed while stumping for ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative candidate Tien Hsin in Taipei that he was told by his chief bodyguard that a letter was mailed to him earlier in the day in which the sender threatened to "rape his daughter Hsin-yu and kidnap his eldest grandson An-an."
The president noted that the letter also warned him to "watch out for two bullets."

DOC.HEADLINE: Western leaders lack courage in dealing with China: RWB

TEXT.P: Robert Menard, secretary-general of the Paris-based Reporters Without Borders (RWB), has said that some leaders of Western countries lack courage in dealing with Beijing and added that democracy and human rights are universal and fundamental principles that should not be undermined.
Menard expressed his opinions Wednesday while meeting with President Chen Shui- bian at the Presidential Office.

During the meeting, Chen accused French President Nicolas Sarkozy of "caving in to Chinese pressure" by issuing a statement during a recent visit to China expressing his opposition to Taiwan's upcoming referendum on joining the U.N. under the name Taiwan.

Blasting Sarkozy's expression as compromising the core values of democracy to cater to the demands of China with a view toward economic gains for France, Chen said it violated France's founding spirit of freedom, democracy and human rights.

In response, Menard said that some Western leaders apparently show a lack of courage when touching on political issues regarding the Chinese government. As secretary-general of the international non-governmental RWB, Menard said he will continue to express his attitude toward safeguarding democracy and human rights.

As to the United Nations' refusal to issue press passes to Taiwanese journalists to cover international events, Menard said it is not in line with the non- discrimination principle, as reporters are entitled to cover news and do not represent their countries while doing their jobs on international occasions.
He also promised to do his utmost to help Taiwanese reporters cover the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Two-step' voting format prohibited: government spokesman

TEXT.P: Electoral workers in local governments favoring a "two-step" voting format in the coming legislative polls and two accompanying referendums must be held accountable if irregularities occur during the voting process, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday.

Emphasizing that "there will not be two different voting systems in a country, " Shieh reiterated that the "two-step" voting method favored by the 18 cities and counties controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not be tolerated in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and referendums.

As to what the Central Election Commission (CEC) called "unavoidable and irresistible situations" on polling days that could be a cause for postponing elections, Shieh said that the commission had yet to define the relevant details.

In a bid to clarify a media report that Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, in a meeting the previous day, rejected a proposal to postpone the legislative elections to resolve the voting format dispute, Shieh claimed that no such meeting was held and said that the Executive Yuan had issued a press release to deny the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italian truck drivers agree on truce, but emergency continues.
Italian truck drivers agreed on a truce with the government and to suspend strike and roadblocks Wednesday after three days of protests which had paralysed the food supply around the nation. However, the situation rmains emergent as it is estimated to take three days for being back to the normality, government officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says he has no power to revoke referendum initiative

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated during a recent media interview that a referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan will take place as planned, despite strong opposition from the United States and China.

Making the remarks during an interview with Germany's Die Zeit weekly, Chen said the referendum was "initiated by the people" according to their constitutional rights and that he has no power to reject or revoke the initiative because he is "not an emperor, "according to a transcript of the interview released Thursday by the Presidential Office.
Chen said Taiwan attaches great importance to U.S. concerns over the issue and will continue communicating with Washington to try to sort out their differences.
"But the U.N. bid referendum must be held. It is impossible for us to backpedal and scrap the plan," he said.

Noting that the "four noes" pledge made in his 2000 inaugural address was based on the prerequisite that "China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, " Chen said this prerequisite is non-existent, given that the number of missiles deployed by China targeting Taiwan has increased from 200 in 2000 to 988 at present.
Chen said the world should not expect Taiwan's people to keep quiet just because China is intimidating Taiwan with its military might.
"The most powerful weapon to protect Taiwan is not missiles or armored vehicles but democracy, special direct democracy such as referendums," Chen said.

He said the United States and Europe should not try to restrict Taiwan's democratic development for the sake of their own interests in China and he added that he was deeply impressed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel's insistence on meeting Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, disregarding Chinese pressure.

According to Chen, the greatest problem with the Chinese leadership is its lack of courage to face up to the true public opinion in Taiwan, mistakenly believing that everyone in Taiwan supports the "one China" principle, accepts ultimate unification with China and is not opposed to Taiwan becoming part of the People's Republic of China.
Chen said China's suppression and intimidation of Taiwan are pushing Taiwan farther and farther away from China.
For example, while only 30 percent of the people in Taiwan identified themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese in 2000, the ratio has soared to 70 percent this year, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU releases new 'contact communication system'

TEXT.P: A new "contact communication system" has been developed by researchers at National Taiwan University (NTU) to enable data exchange with a simple handshake by the users, university sources said Thursday.

Invented by a team led by Lu Shey-shi -- a professor at NTU's Department of Electrical Engineering, the system uses the human body as a data transmission medium, so that when equipped with signal units, two users can exchange information such as telephone numbers and e-mail addresses with a handshake, or a person can submit identification information to operate security systems and ATM machines with a touch of the finger.

Lu explained that although scientists have known for a long time that the human body is capable of conducting electricity, real applications in data transmission through body parts have never come into existence before. "But now, human skin has been made to serve as an electrical contact to allow data communication through body contact," he said.

The signal unit, which can be placed in a watch or mobile phone, can store data ranging from ID numbers, entry security codes, credit card numbers, cash card numbers to medical information, saving the trouble of carrying various cards, Lu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: International hotel at Sun Moon Lake to open in 2012

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau officials said Thursday that when an international hotel on the banks of scenic Sun Moon Lake opens in 2012, Chinese tourists will be one of its main targets.
The officials made the remarks during the first presentation of the construction project for the hotel, which will be built on the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

They noted that Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County is one of the most famous scenic spots in Taiwan and is especially popular with Chinese tourists, although existing accommodation facilities cannot meet demand.
The new hotel, to be built on 2.79 hectares of land bought from the state-run Taiwan Power Company, will have around 250 rooms.

The officials predicted that when the hotel opens for business in 2012, it will attract more tourists, with around 3.36 million domestic visitors, 780,000 Chinese tourists and around 260,000 tourists from other countries visiting every year.

Sun Moon Lake Scenic Park Management Director Tseng Kuo-chi said the hotel will be built based on a statue encouraging private sector investment in international hotels in a bid to upgrade tourism at the lake.
Representatives of foreign construction companies were also present at the presentation and expressed keen interest in the project.
The Tourism Bureau is expected to sponsor two more presentations to learn the views of the construction companies before announcing details of an open bid on construction rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: From a Critic of Tribunals to Top Judge
Back in 2002, a master's degree candidate at the Naval War College wrote a paper on the Bush administration's plan to use military commissions to try Guantanamo suspects, concluding that"even a good military tribunal is a bad idea."
The Wall Street Journal: Central Banks Launch Effort to Free Up Credit
In the biggest coordinated show of international financial force since Sept. 11, 2001, the Federal Reserve yesterday joined four other central banks in a plan aimed at coaxing banks to lend more readily at a time when fear has seized up world credit markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Study Faults Charities for Veterans
Americans gave millions of dollars in the past year to veterans charities designed to help troops wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan, but several of the groups spent relatively little money on the wounded, according to a leading watchdog organization and federal tax filings.
The Washington Times:U.S. troops get to know Anbar
From a height of 500 feet, the topographical features of western Anbar province are almost indistinguishableXmile upon mile of hard, flat earthXbroken only by an occasional oasis, canyonlike depression, narrow road or dry riverbed.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBanks offer billions to fend off recession
The Bank of England and four other powerful central banks are to injectG50 billion into global money markets in unprecedented joint action to ease mounting strains that threaten to tip the worlds leading economies into recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cities vow to cut carbon emissions by 60% by 2050

TEXT.P: Taipei City, Taichung City and Kaohsiung City have vowed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent from 1990 levels by 2050 at a global meeting being held in Bali, Indonesia, government sources said Thursday.
According to the sources, the proposed cuts are part of an agreement reached at the 13th Conference of the Parties (COP 13) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
Alongside the conference, which will run though Dec. 14, is the third meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol.

The agreement titled the Climate Protection Agreement was signed by the members of the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI) , the C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group, the World Mayors Council on Climate Change and the United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG).

Taipei City and Kaohsiung City, in northern and southern Taiwan, respectively, attended the conference as ICLEI members, while Taichung City in central Taiwan is a UCLG member. Taichung Mayor Jason Hu was elected to the UCLG board of directors in November.

Kaohsiung City is confident that it will achieve the goal by 2050, a spokesman for the city's Environmental Protection Bureau (EPB) said during an interview with the Central News Agency later in the day.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has already pledged to cut the port city's carbon emissions year by year, the spokesman noted, adding that at present, factory chimneys in the city are monitored by computer.
If any unusual situation occurs, EPB Director Hsiao Yu-cheng will immediately receive a text message and the bureau will send officials to inspect the situation at once, the spokesman went on.

Taiwan is under no obligation to comply with the Kyoto Protocol as was not allowed to sign it due to its lack of U.N. membership, and thus does not need to cut carbon emissions by 2012, when the protocol expires, the spokesman said.
However, the Executive Yuan has submitted a draft act to the legislature aimed at reducing the country's greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent by 2030, the spokesman noted.
The legislature has not yet passed its third and final reading of the draft act, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: People urged to show more concern for children of foreign spouses

TEXT.P: An official of the Pearl S. Buck Foundation called on the public Thursday to show more concern for the children of foreign spouses with local husbands.

The official urged the public to donate money to the foundation to help them to offer assistance and sponsor a banquet for such children, who usually belong to the less privileged groups in Taiwan, to celebrate the New Year.
It will be the third year the Pearl S. Buck Foundation has organized activities to allow the children of these mixed families feel the warmth of the Taiwan people.

The foundation last year sponsored a banquet for 216 children from mixed families and their parents on the eve of the Lunar New Year, and this year it plans to collect enough money to sponsor a banquet for 500 children.
Foundation Chairman Kuo Yao-tung noted that the number of foreign spouses of local citizens totals 400,000, with the number of their children reaching 200,000.
As these families are often economically less privileged, they need more care from the government and the public, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister en route to visit Panama, Dominican Republic

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang has departed Taiwan to visit the country's diplomatic allies, Panama and the Dominican Republic, to consolidate bilateral ties, diplomatic sources said Thursday.
Huang is set to make layover stops in the United States on his way to these Latin American allies, the sources said.
During his stay in the U.S., Huang is expected to take time to meet with Ministry of Foreign Affairs colleagues posted in North America for a working meeting to be held in Atlanta.

He is also expected to meet with experts from the U.S. National Committee on American Foreign Policy in New York to exchange views on issues concerning bilateral relations between Taiwan and the United States, including U.S. perceptions of Taiwan's plans to hold a nationwide referendum on the country's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

Huang said prior to his departure that he will do his utmost to make the Americans understand that Taiwan will not renege on President Chen Shui-bian's "five noes" pledge while pushing for a U.N.-bid referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: President defends U.N. referendum
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/07 20:45:54 (By Lin Yu-li and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has said during an interview with a German weekly that Taiwan's holding of referendums on public policy issues of major concern is an indispensable step toward deepening the country's democratic institutions.
Chen made the remarks in the interview with Germany's Die Zeit weekly to be published Thursday.

In the interview, Chen praised German Chancellor Angela Merkel for her courage in receiving Tibet's exiled spiritual leader the Dalai Lama during the latter's visit to Germany in September, in defiance of China's strong protest.
Merkel's meeting with the Dalai Lama adversely affected Germany-China ties, with Beijing later canceling several high-level talks between the two countries.
According to Chen, her action showed that "common values are more important than vested interests."

Asked about criticism by the European Union and the United States of Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its quest for a seat in the United Nations under the name Taiwan, Chen said Taiwan appreciates these countries' concern, but added that the holding of referendums is an inevitable step for Taiwan on its march toward full democracy.

Chen described democracy as Taiwan's best defensive weapon and said the country should not waver from this cause, adding that he disagrees with China's claim that Taiwan's referendum proposal is a move toward de jure independence, as the island is already independent.

"Taiwan and China do not belong to each other. Each has their different cultures and this is the status quo existing between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, which Taiwan hopes to maintain, " Chen said.
Taiwan's future can only be decided by its people and no-one can declare that Taiwan is part of People's Republic of China, Chen went on.
However, Chen said it is a possibility that the two sides could move toward reconciliation if China were to abandon considering Taiwan as one of its provinces.

"The big problem for China's leaders is that they are not willing to listen to the voices of Taiwan's people, believing that they lack the courage to reject Beijing's `one China' policy, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan will not yield to China's political, military and economic threats.

DOC.HEADLINE: O'seas Taiwanese young men welcome to join alternative conscription
DOC.DATELINE: Davao, the Philippines, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/07 20:52:35 (By Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese official in charge of conscription affairs called for overseas Taiwanese young men Thursday to join Taiwan's well-established alternative conscription system to gain some experience in national service.

Hsueh Ching-yuan, a section chief of the Department of Conscription under the Ministry of the Interior, who is at the head of a Taiwanese delegation currently on a tour of the Philippines, said Taiwan is the first Asian country to adopt alternative conscription programs to allow draft-eligible young men to serve their mandatory military services in non-military alternative programs.

Over the past seven years, Hsueh said, conscripts have performed commendably in non-military alternative conscription programs, serving as social workers, medical professionals and teachers, at home and abroad, as well as on the diplomatic front, in foreign countries.

By joining the non-military alternative conscription programs, Hsueh said, the children of Taiwanese expatriates can serve their home country of Taiwan in their country of residency on the one hand and make a diplomatic contribution on the other.

The Philippines is the first country in the world where Taiwan has sent its alternative conscripts there to work as teachers, Hsueh said, adding that currently 11 Taiwan conscripts are teaching at eight Chinese schools scattered in the Philippine cities of Manila, Davao and Zamboanga.

During a workshop held at Davao Thursday, Hsueh also conferred a prize on behalf of the minister of the interior on conscript Huang Tsung-hsien in recognition of his outstanding performance as a Mandarin teacher at the Davao Chinese School.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Chen condemns violence after threatening letter

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian condemned violence Thursday after receiving a letter threatening himself, his daughter and his grandson.

The president first revealed that he was threatened during a rally in Taipei to drum up support for Tien Hsin, a candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
He said the use of threats and intimidation against his family is "irrational, " and urged the public to join him in condemning violence.
The president also said that not only his daughter Hsin-yu, but also his son, Chih-chung, had received threatening letters.
He asked if "politics has to be this dirty and sordid, " urging people to see clearly who wants democracy and who detests democracy.

"There will be winners and losers in every election, " he said, adding that he didn't win every time. He noted that he lost during Tainan county magistrate election in 1985, and his wife was injured during a controversial car accident after the election, resulting in her being paralyzed from the waist down.
The president also said that he was jailed for more than two years because of his dedication to politics.
Lee Nan-yang, director of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, said that the letter came in the form of a New Year's greeting card addressed to Lee.
The letter read, "Tell Ah-bian (nickname of the president) to be beware of two bullets. An-an (the president's grandson) will be abducted and Hsin-yu (his daughter) raped," according to Lee.

The two bullets refer to the shooting incident on the eve of the 2004 presidential election, when both Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured on campaign trail. The opposition accused Chen of staging the incident to win sympathy votes in the hotly contested election, albeit without substantive evidence.
Lee said that he immediately turned the letter over to the security service, saying that any violence should be condemned.

Security around the president has been strengthened since the incident. When President Chen attended a democracy and human rights award ceremony in the afternoon, all men dressed in suits were asked to take off their suits for security checks.
Cho Jung-tai, secretary general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that the party will never bow to threats.

Cho said that the previous letter threatening Hsin-yu was sent to the editor of a media outlet and did not invite too much discussion at the time, but this time the letter was sent to the Presidential Office, posing a direct challenge to the government's authority.
Cho said that he could only hope that there is no connection between public name calling of the president and threatens on his life.
He said that Taiwan is a "rational society, " and the threat should not exist. There should be "effective ways to counter such threats," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ecstasy mailed from Malaysia nabbed

TEXT.P: A drug mule and four packets of powdered MDMA ecstasy were seized by law enforcement officers Wednesday in Kaohsiung City, the Kaohsiung County Police Department said Thursday.

According to a spokesman for the municipal police department, a 34-year-old man surnamed Chang was arrested Wednesday evening in a building in Kaohsiung City while trying to collect the illicit drugs mailed from Malaysia under the instruction of a drug trafficker. Two packs of the drug were seized along with Chang.

Agents from the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration's Tainan branch and Kaohsiung County policemen launched the raid after receiving a tip provided by an informant in June and conducting months of tracking and investigation, the spokesman said.

Two another packs of the same narcotics were seized Thursday morning at Chang's suite in a building in Jenwu township, Kaohsiung County according a statement in the initial probe by Kaohsiung County police.

Police suspect that the drug traffickers wanted to smuggle the four packs of MDMA ecstasy, weighing nearly one kilogram in total, into Taiwan in time to rake in handsome profits as Christmas approaches.
One MDMA pill could be sold for NT$500 (US$15.5) at local night clubs or pubs, police said, adding that they are trying to apprehend other accomplices.

According to police investigators, smugglers concealed the illegal drugs in books which had their pages cut out. The empty books with drugs hidden inside were wrapped in many layers of plastic, copy paper, and protective wrapping paper to avoid being detected by X-ray when entering Taiwan's customs.

As each hollowed out book held some 0.25 kilograms of powdered MDMA and yet weighed less than 0.3 kilograms, customs agents might easily allow them to pass, police explained, adding that the drug traffickers must be very familiar with the inspection process of postal materials at Taiwan's customs.
According to Chang, who has a criminal record for document forgery and drug abuse, he had run errands for a drug trafficker nicknamed "Boss" for more than three months.

Chang told police that he would be paid from NT$3,000-NT$5,000 for each errand he made for the "Boss" -- transporting or taking delivery of drugs, or accepting money from clients, adding that he succeeded in five such errands, carrying two packets each time.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to promote recreational farms at travel fair in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will set up a special booth to promote Taiwan's recreational farms at the Taipei International Travel Fair 2007 slated to open in Taipei City Friday, a COA official said Thursday.
The booth will introduce 10 operational recreational farms selected by experts representing unique facets of Taiwan's agriculture, the official said.

The Green World Ecological Farm with Asia's largest butterfly ecological park in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, and Peikuan Farm with the world's only crab museum in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, will both be included, the official said.

Similar to tourist farms, recreational farms integrate agricultural production and rural life for the benefit of visitors. In addition, a recreational farm presents local cultural and ecological resources, and encourages visitors to become involved with the natural environment through picnicking, bird watching, and other low-impact activities.

Seeing the great business potential of the recreational agriculture industry in stress-filled modern life, the government has made great efforts to provide assistance and counselling in the development of local recreational farms, with an aim of making the industry a future star in tourism, the official said.

The COA will also set up a booth to exhibit Taiwan's special agricultural products and local dishes, such as sour Chinese cabbage in Kinmen County, dried silver anchovies of Penghu County, and herbal jelly of Hsinchu County, to better introduce visitors to Taiwan's unique features, the official said.

Students at the Kainan University in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan will work with the Japanese traveling expert Segami Tsuyoshi, who has lived in Taiwan for many years, in creating special Taiwanese dishes for visitors at the fair, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Myanmar human rights needs international collaboration: activist

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) Thursday honored Dr. Cynthia Maung with the second Asia Democracy and Human Rights Awards (ADHRA) in Taipei for her outstanding achievements in human rights and her services to Myanmarese refugees.

President Chen Shui-bian conferred the ADHRA on Maung, dubbed "Myanmar's Mother Theresa," the 48-year-old founder of the celebrated refugee Mae Tao Clinic in the Thai border town of Mae Sot, at a presentation ceremony, while Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) Chairman Wang Jin-pyng presented her with a US$100,000 grant to support her work.

ADHRA was created by the TFD, a Taiwan-based and the first national democracy assistance foundation in Asia, in 2006 to honor individuals or groups dedicated to democratic development, the advance of human rights and the building of democracy. Reporters Without Borders Secretary-General Robert Menard won the first ADHRA last year.

Addressing the occasion, Chen said Maung's selfless love magnifies the atrocity and barbarity of the Myanmarese junta and it is therefore meaningful that Maung won the ADHRA, especially when democratic development in Myanmar has encountered great difficulties.
In her acceptance speech, Maung expressed gratitude to the TFD, saying that Taiwans peaceful democratic development is a model for other countries.

Maung is known for her work to help refugees and migrant workers in Myanmar, as well as those suffering from the deteriorating situation there after the ruling juntas bloody crackdown on protesters against rising prices led by Buddhist monks in September.

The Mae Sot clinic not only offers medical care but also occupational training, health education, social services, housing for unaccompanied children and community-building activities. Thanks to Maung and her colleagues efforts, around 200 patients a day receive the care free of charge.

Regarding the human rights situation in Myanmar, Maung said in an interview that even though there was some pressure such as economic sanctions put on the junta for political dialogue or reform, there has been no change or improvement in the past year.

Maung emphasized repeatedly that international humanitarian assistance should be monitored properly and that international organizations shouldwork collaboratively and directlywith the local community and democratic organizations.

As to the September unrest, Maung said that compared with a similar event in 1988, it was good to see that more people got involved this time and supported the movement. However,there is no opportunity for improvement or change under the military regime,she said, because any attempt at democratic change or political dialogue is cracked down upon by the military.

She urged continuous international attention and collaboration on the issue and expressed hope that the U.N. Security Council will take steps to intervene despite obstruction from "certain countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: India government confers award on Taiwanese film director
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/07 21:43:12 (By Paul Kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: India's government bestowed the Golden Peacock award on Taiwanese film director Lin Chih-ju Thursday in recognition of his winning the best film award at the just concluded 38th International Film Festival of India in Goa.

Lin's film, "The Wall", captured the best film award in the Asian, Latin American and African film category at the Goa film festival, the most prestigious Indian film festival, beating 13 other films by directors from the three areas, including the "Postmodern Life of My Aunt" directed by prominent Hong Kong director Xu Anhua.
The jury described "The Wall" as a "can't miss" film, as it depicted everyday people coping with political challenges in a simple story of dreams, hope, betrayal and love.
This year's Goa film festival attracted a total of 200 films from 43 countries for the competition.

The awards ceremony was presided over by Neelam Kapur, director in charge of film festivals of India's Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, with Taiwan's representative in India Hsia Li-yen receiving the award on behalf of Lin, who will also receive a cash award worth US$25,500.

Noting that Taiwanese films enjoy high esteem in the world film community, Kapur expressed hope that Taiwan will send more films and directors to attend India's various film festivals. She added that the Indian government has earmarked sufficient funds to cover all the traveling cost for foreign guests to attend film festivals with the aim of strengthening cultural exchanges with other countries.

Hailing Taiwanese films for winning many prestigious awards in international film festivals, Kapur said India's film festival organizers will sponsor an event focusing on Taiwanese topics if such superior directors as Ang Lee and Hou Hsiao-shien will be able to attend India's festivals.

Hsia said he would like to serve as bridge to boost the mutual understanding and the cultural exchanges between India and Taiwan, inviting Kapur and other Indian film celebrity to participate in Taiwan's Golden Horse Film Festival and other international film festivals held in Taiwan in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP vows not to bow to death threat targeting 1st family

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not bow to threats posed in an anonymous letter promising harm to President Chen Shui-bian and his family members, DPP Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.
Cho made the remarks after Chen revealed earlier in the day a letter in which someone threatens to "rape his daughter Hsin-yu and kidnap his eldest grandson An-an."
The president noted that the letter also warned him to "watch out for two bullets."

Producing a photocopy of the death threat letter at a press conference called later in the day, Cho said that the government's authority should not be challenged and urged the police to deter the person responsible for a series of threats to Chen's family.
Cho said he hopes that the death threat is not related to a series of unexpected protests targeting Chen staged by individuals on a number of occasions recently.
Describing the people of Taiwan as "rational, " Cho said that "there seems to be a force encouraging all these threats and protests."
With the Jan. 12 legislative election approaching, many sensitive disputes will arise, which might result in greater frictions between supporters of different political parties, Cho said.
Cho stressed that local citizens should voice their opinions through legal and democratic channels, and that the DPP will humbly listen to their opinions.
The Presidential Office has activated its security system, Cho noted, adding that the DPP believes greater importance should be attached to the security of the national leader.

Meanwhile, Cho also told the press that a media outlet received a postcard last week, in which the sender, who dubbed himself a "Taiwanese Citizen", threatened to attack the clinic where the first daughter works.

Only a few days ago, the "Taiwan Citizen" sent out another postcard, demanding that Chen and his son, Chen Chi-chung, apologize for the Ministry of Education's move to replace an inscription of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall alluding the late President Chiang Kai-shek with a new one reading "Liberty Square."
The postcard was sent from Chungho in the northern county of Taipei, the police said, adding that further investigation is under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government agencies work on developing English-friendly environment

TEXT.P: Local government agencies have been working hard in the past five years to create an English-friendly environment, though it still needs many adjustments, agency staff members said Thursday on the sideline of the 2007 English Carnival.

The hard work has paid off, however, judging from the latest results of the overall living environment approval rate of 61.5 percent among foreigners, which was the highest in five years. The survey was conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC).

The basic requirement was render every operational item and bulletin bilingual so foreigners could have easy access to information on where they wanted to go, said Meng Yun-tsung, Manager of Hsinchu Post Office. The office also had English courses for its staff to improve their English conversation.

Results of the same survey showed that only a third of foreigners were satisfied with the police service environment. But that was not the case in Nantou County Police Bureau, which started to work on providing a bilingual environment in 2004, said a policeman surnamed Wu.

"I don't know what it's like in metropolitan areas like Taipei City, where there have been more criminal cases. Most of the foreigners in Nantou are tourists rather than businessmen, which was why most of our interaction involves answering questions, giving directions... and let them use our bathrooms," a policeman surnamed Fan said.
Not every policeman was able to speak fluent English, but foreigners could always call Foreign Affairs Sections of every police station for help, Wu said.

In Kaohsiung City, where the 2009 World Games will be held, a bilingual environment is even more important. The city's transportation and tourism bureaus worked with taxi drivers, who are expected to host many foreign visitors during the games.
More than 400 drivers of the Sin Sing Siang Taxi Radio Station started taking free English lessons offered by the bureaus this year to improve their conversation.

"It's impossible to make all of the drivers speak English well in a short period of time, but at least we're supposed to know which hotels, agencies and locations the passengers want to go to, and be able to chat a little bit with them, " said Wu Yi-fong, an executive of the taxi station.
The initiative and effort should be appreciated, said Douglas Habecker, Editor- in-Chief of Compass, which publishes free bilingual magazines in Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung.

"The [English] environment has improved a lot during the last five years. It's easy for people to criticize but Taiwan has made huge steps. The biggest change has to do with the positive attitude of the central and local governments, and the people, towards internationalization, " said Habecker, 40, who were born in the eastern city of Hualien and lives in Taichung.

The basic idea was not make everyone a good English speaker and to make everything bilingual, because that's impossible, Habecker said, adding that the more important thing is to provide user-friendly, high-quality and constantly updated information through guides, maps and Web sites.
"Try to find a solution and ways to make it easier [for foreigners] in important spots such as airports, hotels and transportation hubs, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Myanmar human rights issue too serious to be overlooked: Maung

TEXT.P: Dr. Cynthia Maung, a Burmese physician who has been providing medical services to Burmese refugees for almost 20 years, said Thursday that there are serious human rights issues in Myanmar.

Maung, recipient of the 2007 Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award (ADHRA) , received the award and grant worth US$100,000 from President Chen Shui-bian in a ceremony before participating in a forum on human rights issue in Myanmar.

Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, has been ruled by a military junta since 1988. The junta changed the country's official English name to the "Union of Myanmar" in 1989, a move which is not recognized by many opponents of the regime.

Estimates of the displaced population on the Thai-Myanmarese border range between 500,000 - 600,000, composed mostly of people forced to leave their towns and farms because of civil wars and oppression from the military junta, she said. It has been very difficult for refugees to gain access to everything from health care and education to clean water and accommodation, she added.
In addition, the refugees face threats from land mines, epidemics and drugs. Taken together, the human rights issue in Myanmar is simply too serious to be overlooked, she said.

The 48-year-old doctor, herself a refugee and a member of the ethnic Karen minority, established the Mae Tao Clinic in Mae Sot, Thailand, near the Thai- Burmese border, in 1988. Since then, the clinic has been providing not only medical care, but also job training, social services, health education, child protection, and community-building activities.

Michael Hsiao, Executive Director of Academia Sinica's Center for Asia-Pacific Area Studies, described situation in Myanmar as "a human hell" where civilians have been deprived of the right of stay in their hometowns.

"As a matter of fact, Taiwan might not be able to do much to improve situation in Myanmar. But Taiwanese can offer support simply by focusing more attention on the problems [in Myanmar] and at the same time take that as a warning to ensure that the same does not happen again in Taiwan," he said.
Some Taiwanese have been doing more than just bringing attention to the issue. The Taipei Overseas Peace Service (TOPS), for instance, has been sending humanitarian missions to Myanmar for 10 years.

The human rights situation in Myanmar and conditions in 10 refugee camps along the Thai-Myanmarese border have been deteriorating, said Sam Lai, a TOPS team leader who's been working in Myanmar for five years.
All the refugees were disappointed after the demonstrations in September failed to overthrow the military regime, Lai said, adding that "they thought they could finally go home."
"For the past five years, my mother has always been asking me the same question: When will you come home? I always answer: Maybe next year, " he said.
"Hopefully, all our Myanmarese friends will be able to go back home someday so I can tell my mother that I'm finally coming home, " Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC to set up a technology section in S. Korea for exchanges

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) will set up a technology section in Seoul, South Korea to facilitate bilateral exchanges in basic scientific research, NSC Vice Minister Yang Hung-dun said Thursday.

The division will be under the authority of the country's representative office in Seoul, known as the Taipei Mission in South Korea, and will have Chou Chuan- hsin, a professor at the Institute of Applied Mechanics of National Taiwan University as its first chief, Yang said.

The Ministry of Science and Technology of South Korea, and the Korea Science and Engineering Foundation will be the two cooperative partners for the technology section during its early stages, which will focus on boosting exchanges in basic scientific research, Yang noted.

Director-General of NSC's Department of International Cooperation Lin Kuang-lung said Chou, who was educated in South Korea before attending college, will be well-served by his knowledge of technology, language ability, and thorough understanding of Korean culture.
During the past six years, Taiwan has set up a technology section each year in different countries, including Russia, Australia, Vietnam, India, the Czech Republic, and South Korea.

Lin pointed out that after establishing a section in Vietnam three years ago, Taiwan has shifted from a country seeking help from advanced countries, to a country seeking opportunities to cooperation with,and providing technical assistance to other countries.

A technology section previously set up in Chicago in the United States, in 1991, has been moved to Boston in order to meet the needs of Taiwan's biotechnology industry, Lin said, adding that next target for setting up a new section is Sao Paulo, Brazil.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows no compromise despite death threat

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he will by no means waver in his rejection of the "one China" principle and China's goal of the "eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait" despite death threats leveled against himself and his family.
"Taiwan and China are two separate, unconnected countries," said Chen while stumping for DPP legislative candidate Tien Hsin in Taipei City.

During the remaining half year of his term, Chen said he will stick to his guns no matter how grave China's saber-rattling and military threats and no matter how frightening the attempts to intimidate himself and his family.

Chen's reaffirmation of his resolve came after the unveiling of anonymous threatening letters to his daughter, his son and the Presidential Office. In one of those letters, the sender warned the president to "watch out for two bullets."

The "two bullets" alluded to the shooting incident on the eve of the 2004 presidential election, when both Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured on campaign trail. The opposition accused Chen of staging the incident to win sympathy votes in the hotly contested election, albeit without substantive evidence.

Speaking in Thursday's campaign rally, Chen said he believes that god had blessed him in that adversity because of his magnanimity in providing attentive care to family members of the two late presidents and the late Premier Sun Yun- hsuan who was partially disabled after suffering a stroke.
Chen's own wife is paralyzed from waist down, yet he said he has never used public funds to foot his wife's medical bills nor have doctors and nurses from state-run hospitals take care of his wife.

"My wife, a disabled first lady, receive far worse treatment than did Sun, a former premier, " Chen said, adding that Veterans General Hospital physicians and nurses took turns caring for Sun before his death early last year. Sun also had a state-funded villa in Keelung for his recuperation, about which the DPP government never complained.

The DPP administration has also followed the practice of the previous Kuomintang government in caring for the widows of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son, the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, until they died a few years ago, Chen said.

Recalling that he has endured many challenges and ordeals in his bumpy political careers, Chen said no threat or intimidation could changed his mind and determination to safeguard national interest and dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 14, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: Solomon prime minister's ouster not to affect ties with Taiwan: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the Solomon Islands will not be affected by the ouster of the South Pacific ally's prime minister, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) acting spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said Friday.

Solomon Islands lawmakers ousted Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare in a vote of no-confidence Thursday, as large numbers of police and soldiers patrolled the country's capital to deal with any possible unrest stemming from the decision.
Despite the ouster, Yeh said, the Solomon Islands' general social situation remains stable. The country is expected to pick a new prime minister in two weeks.

Noting that Taiwan has maintained close contacts with both the Solomon Islands' ruling and opposition parties, Yeh said bilateral relations are not expected to change regardless of which party wins the premiership. According to Yeh, various bilateral cooperative programs will also continue to be carried out without any hitch.

Taiwan and the Solomon Islands have maintained cordial relations since forging diplomatic ties were forged 24 years ago, Yeh said, adding she believes that the long-term friendship between the two countries will remain intact following the South Pacific nation's Cabinet reshuffle.

Solomon lawmakers voted 25 to 22 in the 48-member parliament to support a no- confidence motion put forward by the opposition led by lawmaker Fred Fono, who has accused Sogavare of arrogance and sending the Solomons' international reputation plummeting during his 20-month rule.

Sogavare came to power in April last year in the wake of rioting that devastated the country's capital. He has since caused a series of controversies with his abrasive style and verbal attacks on regional power Australia, according to foreign wire service reports.
Sogavare, who abstained from voting without explaining why, said he accepts the outcome with "humility." He told reporters he would remain in parliament until his four-year term ends in 2010.
The Solomon Islands is located some 1,800 kilometers northeast of Australia. With an area of about 28,000 square kilometers, it has a population of slightly more than 530,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin candidate offers different approach to helping disadvantaged

TEXT.P: Legislative candidate Liu Chien-kuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party put forth some different proposals Friday on helping the disadvantaged in his effort to win voter support in Yunlin County.
Emphasizing social welfare as his core campaign theme, Liu stressed that "subsidies" and "relief" are not the most effective approaches in terms of helping the disadvantaged.
Instead, Liu said during a campaign rally in the south-central county, disadvantaged groups should be provided with assistance that allows them to live "independently and sustainably."

He added that the term "disadvantaged" should be replaced with "untapped advantages" in describing members of these groups as "disadvantages can be turned into advantages if the concept of sustainable operations is materialized."

Liu said that if elected, he will see to it that seniors living alone are provided with free meals on a regular basis, that disabled individuals are given the opportunity to have their own careers, that foreign spouses are provided with free language and cultural classes to help them assimilate into Taiwan society quickly, and that children from low-income families are provided with free, regular kindergarten and after-class education.

During the rally, representatives of 20-odd disadvantaged groups jointly expressed their support for Liu, presenting him with a pair of shoes as a symbolic gesture of their hope that he will be able to move forward with solid strides in representing his constituents.
In return, Liu promised his supporters that if elected, he will work tirelessly to take care of "the elderly, the weak, and women and children."
