Panamanian president meets Taiwan's foreign minister

TEXT.P: Panama was the first stop of Huang's diplomatic visit to the Latin America and the Caribbean Sea, which also will take him to Nicaragua.

Accompanied by Panamanian First Vice President & Foreign Affairs Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro and ROC Ambassador to Panama Tomas Ping- fu Hou, Torrijos and Huang reviewed progress in collaborations projects between the two countries, Lewis said.
According to Taiwan's embassy in Panama, Huang will make an inspection visit Friday to a stadium built under a collaboration project between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wintek becomes world's largest mobile phone panel supplier in Q3

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Wintek Corp. replaced South Korea's Samsung SDI as the world's largest supplier of mobile phone displays in the third quarter of 2007 for the first time by contributing 14.2 percent to the world's total shipments, according to a report released Friday by the display market research and consulting firm DislaySearch.

DisplaySearch tallies show that Wintek shipped 47.26 million mobile phone panels in the third quarter of 2007, up 39 percent quarter-on-quarter and 76 percent year-on-year. The growth rates were the highest among the world's top five mobile phone display manufacturers.

The report said Wintek's recent efforts to expand its production line for thin film transistor liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCDs) have significantly boosted the company's TFT-LCD production, with the shipments of TFT-LCD panels for mobile phones as a percentage of the company's total shipments rising seven percentage points quarter-on-quarter to 19 percent for the third quarter.
During the same period, Samsung SDI shipped 39.19 million mobile phone panels, up 6 percent quarter-on-quarter and accounting for 11.8 percent of the world's total shipments, the report said.

Meanwhile, shipments by Sharp, Epson and TPO accounted for 10.2 percent, 9.5 percent and 7.5 percent, respectively, of the world's total for the third quarter of 2007. Shipments by the five manufacturers together accounted for 53.2 percent of the world's total for the quarter.
The report noted that both Sharp and TPO are shifting to low temperature poly- silicon (LTPS) TFT-LCD manufacturing process.
Of the total of 33.9 million TFT-LCD mobile phone panels shipped by Sharp in the third quarter of 2007, 20.7 million were produced using the LTPS technology, according to the report.
TPO shipped 15 million LTPS-based TFT-LCD mobile phone panels in the third quarter, making it the world's second-largest manufacturer of the products, the report said.
It said the world's total shipments for mobile phone displays amounted to 332.8 million for the third quarter of 2007, up 19 percent over the previous quarter to hit a new high for a single quarter.

However, owing to an 18-percent drop in the average unit price of mobile phone panels, the value of the shipments declined 8 percent year-on-year to US$2.77 billion for the third quarter of 2007, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, family threatened again

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and members of his family were threatened again with violence and abduction Friday in a letter sent to the president's e-mail address, the Presidential Office spokesman said at around noon.
Lee Nan-yang, director-general of the Presidential Office Department of Public Affairs, said the letter, signed by an "assassin in black," warned President Chen to "watch out for two bullets."
The author of the letter also threatened to kidnap and sexually assault members of the president's family, Lee said.
The threat letter has already been referred to the law enforcement authorities to deal with, he added.
The spokesman reiterated that Taiwan is a nation of law and order and that all forms of violence are disdained and condemned.

President Chen disclosed Thursday that a letter was mailed to the Presidential Office to him earlier in the day in which the sender threatened to "rape his daughter Chen Hsin-yu and kidnap his eldest grandson An-an." Chen noted that the letter also warned him to "watch out for two bullets."

The "two bullets" alluded to the shooting incident on the eve of the 2004 presidential election, when both Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured on the campaign trail. The opposition accused Chen of staging the incident to win sympathy votes in the hotly contested election, albeit without substantive evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Lead found in toy jewelry.
Stores across California have pulled lead- tainted children's jewelry from their shelves after state investigators found bracelets, ring and necklaces contaminated with as much as 600 times the legal limit of the poisonous element. The discovery, coming after Mattel Inc. and other manufacturers of toys and novelty items recalled millions of lead-laced toys, bibs and lunchboxes made in China, rattled parents and retailers alike. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Plaintiffs snub hepatitis settlement
Thirteen people infected with hepatitis C from tainted blood products who are suing the state and drugmakers rejected an Osaka High Court compromise settlement Thursday apparently because not all the affected parties would be properly compensated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet unveils new incentives to boost tourism

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Friday a series of new government incentives to boost Taiwan's tourism in the coming two years, including relaxing the eligibility standards for subsidies on Taiwan-bound charter flights and offering free credit of up to NT$400,000 (US$12,384) for domestic spending to lucky foreign visitors.

Making the announcement while addressing the opening of the Taipei International Travel Fair 2007, Chang said the Cabinet has designated 2008 and 2009 the "Tour Taiwan Years, " during which the government will take various measures to attract more international visitors to make Taiwan a major travel destination in Asia.

For example, the government will offer free of charge credit worth NT$100,000 to the one millionth visitor, NT$200,000 to the two millionth visitor, NT$300,000 to the three millionth visitor and NT$400,000 to the four millionth visitor, he said.

Also, the government will provide a US$30,000 bonus to any cruise liners with at least 2,000 passengers that makes a mid-journey stop in Taiwan and lower the threshold making Taiwan-bound charter flights eligible for government subsidies, Chang said.

According to officials at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' Tourism Bureau, while subsidies are currently being provided to round-trip charter flights carrying at least 100 passengers, the passenger threshold will be lowered to 50 next year, and one-way charter flights will also be subsidized.
Taiwan sees approximately 15,000 visitors arrive via charter flights per year, with Japanese charter flights accounting for the largest number of arrivals, the officials said.
In a bid to encourage more South Korean citizens to visit Taiwan, the government will also increase the subsidies for South Korean charter flights next year, they said.

While the subsidies will be raised from 5 million won (US$5,384) to 6.25 million won for charter flights heading for Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport or Kaohsiung International Airport, the amount will be increased from 6.25 million won to 7.5 million won for charter flights heading for other Taiwanese airports, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shin Kong Life Tower still king of skyscrapers in land value

TEXT.P: The Taipei 101 tower may hold the title as the tallest skyscraper in the world, but the Shin Kong Life Tower still reigns in Taiwan when it comes to land value.

According to a report released by the Taipei city government's Land Department Friday morning, the plot of land on which the Shin Kong Life Tower stands has an assessed land value of NT$3.36 million (US$103,780) per ping which is about 3.3 square meters, for fiscal 2008, up 3.3 percent over the 2007 level, while the land plot on which the Taipei 101 stands has an announced value of NT$2.97 million per ping.

This marks the 10th consecutive year that the 51-story skyscraper located across from the Taipei Main Station has ranked at the top of the list in Taiwan in terms of land value, according to the Land Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Sing For Freedom' concert to be staged at Liberty Square

TEXT.P: A concert dubbed "Sing For Freedom" will be held Saturday at the newly re-named "Liberty Square" in front of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, previously known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the concert organizer said Friday.
The concert, organized by the National Cultural Association, will be hosted by local entertainer Chu Yueh-hsin and Janet, host of Fun Taiwan, a Discovery Channel television program.
Many foreign and local bands and singers will be invited to play diverse styles of music at the concert which is aimed at expressing humankind's aspiration for peace and freedom, the organizer said.

It has been reported by several local media outlet that the Liberty Square was chosen as the venue with the aim of trying to erase people's illusions about the late President Chiang Kai-shek, a figure who the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has branded as a dictator.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 69.87 points, or 0.85 percent, to close at 8,118.08.
The bourse opened at 8,186.25 and fluctuated between 8,202.94 and 7,922.66 during trading. A total of 5.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$151.72 billion (US$4.68 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.4 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent.

The four other major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 423, with 379 stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGHospitals to pay for harming patients
All hospitals should be fined if patients contract superbug infections or are harmed by medical errors while in their care, the Governments Chief Medical Officer said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.016 to close at NT$32.376.
A total of US$1.01 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.360 and fluctuated between NT$32.333 and NT$32.422.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid has put Taiwan on the map: academics

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's bid over the past year to push for the country to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan has helped put Taiwan on the map, members of the Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) said Friday.

Speaking at a news conference marking the publication of the TAUP observation of Taiwan's political climate in 2007, Hsu Chu-feng, deputy secretary-general of the TAUP, said the unprecedented U.N. bid initiated by the DPP administration has not only helped consolidate the national identity of the people of Taiwan, it also constitutes a successful diplomatic strike.

Hsu claimed that the U.N.-bid efforts have forged a new, nationwide consensus, which in turn has helped consolidate the national identity of the people of Taiwan, and that the international community has for the first time heard the common voice of Taiwan's people, which is making the Beijing leadership unhappy.

Chen Chun-sheng, an honorary professor with National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said that although the maiden bid to seek the country's entry into the U.N. under the name Taiwan did not succeed, the motion was, for the first time, brought up for discussion by the U.N. General Assembly.

The number of international media reports on the bid was also four or five times greater than that given bids made by the ex-Kuomintang administration seeking to return the Republic of China to the U.N., Chen said.
He claimed that the DPP-initiated U.N. bid was a successful diplomatic strike, which has significantly increased Taiwan's visibility in the international community.
On the issue of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chen said that rationally speaking, Taiwan is not the Republic of China.

He suggested that Taiwan return the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which are located closer to the Chinese mainland than to Taiwan proper, to China and then found a Republic of Taiwan under the spirit of the U.N. Chapter.

He also suggested that the Taiwanese authorities bring those Kinmen and Matsu residents who recognize Taiwan to settle in Taiwan and resettle those Taiwanese residents who recognize the ROC to Kinmen and Matsu.
Chen noted that both notions of the signing of a cross-strait peace accord and the draft of an act governing peaceful engagement between Taiwan and China are pitfalls.
He also called on Taiwan's voters to remain alert against Chinese espionage, claiming that Chinese hands have already been in the upcoming presidential race and referendums.

Chuang Han-lin, a lecturer with the Minghsin University of Science and Technology, said that Taiwan's hard-earned democracy will face an "unprecedented crisis" if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its allied parties win the majority seats of the next legislature and the KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou wins the 2008 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Save for emergencies, helicopters still barred from rooftop landings

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) head said Friday that except for emergency medical relief, helicopters will still be barred from making rooftop landings in Taiwan.

CAA Director General Chang Kuo-cheng made the remarks after Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Hsu suggested Thursday that, due to heavy traffic between Taipei and Taoyuan, the government open helicopter routes between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and some high buildings in Taipei whose roofs suit helicopter landings.
Hsu's idea has obtained the support of Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

However, Chang stressed that helicopter rooftop landings are only permitted in cases of emergency medical relief efforts considering that once such service is opened it will negatively affect aviation security in Taipei's air space, which is relatively small.
Chang said any private flying vehicle or charter plane will have to apply the permission from the CAA before flying along already fixed routes.
According to Chang, a helicopter flying from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to Taipei could only land at Taipei Songshan Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Int'l workshop on visual information processing opening in Tainan

TEXT.P: The 2007 Asia-Pacific Workshop on Visual Information Processing is scheduled to open at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, Saturday, with over 50 specialists and academics from 13 countries participating, workshop organizers said Friday.
It will be the first time that the workshop has been held in Taiwan since its inception in 1995, according to the NCKU authorities.

The three-day workshop is expected to bring together high-tech pundits from Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Iran, Japan, Portugal, South Korea, Singapore, Spain, the United Kingdom, the United States, and the host Taiwan.

A total of 36 papers are expected to be presented during the workshop on subjects ranging from visual information processing and multimedia applictions to transmission of visual information and image and video data indexing, retrieval, analysis and identification.
The NCKU has also plans to publish the findings of the workshop, to be named as Proceedings of the 2007 Asia-Pacific Workshop on Visual Information Processing, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 46 points to close at 8,060, with 93,746 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 43 points, finishing at 8,064, with 6,461 contracts traded, while March futures lost 12 points to close at 8,110, with 40 contract transactions. June futures moved down 95 points to close at 8,020, with two contracts traded, while September futures decreased 46 points to finish at 7,884, with 44 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,106 for December, 8,107 for January, 8,122 for March, 8,115 for June and 7,930 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures lost 3.15 points to close at 327.45, with 4,757 contracts traded, while January TE futures moved down 3.2 points to finish at 326.95, with 667 contract transactions. March TE futures dropped 3.95 to finish at 328.9, with one contract traded, while June TE future decreased 1.9 points to close at 323.3, with two contracts traded. September TE futures gained 3.5 points to finish at 329.9, with 14 contract transactions.

December TF futures dropped 0.6 points to close at 933.8, with 2,091 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 1.2 points to finish at 932.8, with 402 contracts traded. March TF futures lost 2.4 points to close at 939, with 22 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan urged not to interfere in legislative affairs

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng held a press conference Friday in a rare move to remind the Executive Yuan that the legislature has the constitutional power to screen budgetary bills and to urge Cabinet officials to refrain from interfering in budget screening by lawmakers.

Wang took the move after he was called on by Minister Lee Yung-teh of the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) the previous day to explain why he endorsed a proposal put forth by Legislator Wong Chung-chun of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to postpone legislative negotiations on the CHA's budget for next year and to freeze the unspent portion of the CHA's 2007 budget.
In addition to Wang, Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, the director of the KMT Policy Coordination Committee, was also named in the CHA's Thursday statement denouncing Wong for his "irrational" proposal.

The CHA statement came after Lee accused Wong of holding Executive Yuan officials hostage by proposing to freeze the council's budget after it failed to subsidize a planned Hakka cultural and biological park construction project in the southern county of Chiayi at Wong's request.
In the CHA statement, the council also asked Wong to explain why he brought up the proposal, and to identify the law on which he based his call to freeze the council's remaining budget.
The statement, however, was regarded by the legislative speaker as an offense against the legislative power to examine budget bills.

At the Friday press conference, Wang released a formal statement, in which he reiterated that lawmakers shoulder the duty and are endowed with the constitutional power to request a budget cut when they discover improper governmental acts in writing or executing a budget.

Wang also stated that any disputed issues at the Legislative Yuan should be dealt with through negotiations among legislative caucuses of the political parties, and that since the 2008 general budget is still being negotiated, he suggested that the CHA and other Executive Yuan agencies refrain from interfering in the budget screening processes of the various legislative committees to avoid affecting general budget negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Steroid Report Names Star Players
A 21-month investigation into use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball concluded Thursday a culture of secrecy and permissiveness gave rise to a " steroids era" in the game that included some of its biggest names, most prominent among them superstar pitcher Roger Clemens.
The Washington Times:MLB probe cites decade of drug use
A 21-month investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball concluded yesterday that cheating has been rampant in the sport for more than a decade and called initial responses by baseball officials to address the issue "slow and inadequate."

DOC.HEADLINE: HSPA, YRP sign MOU to promote exchanges

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park Administration (HSPA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Yokosuka Research Park (YRP) in Japan to promote exchanges and cooperation in technological fields, HSPA Director Huang Te-jui said Friday.
Huang and Shigo Ohmori, a YRP representative, signed the MOU Thursday at the Hsinchu park office in the northern city of Hsinchu on behalf of the two sides.

The signing ceremony, presided over by Huang, was held alongside a celebration marking the HSPA's 27th founding anniversary. Also present were Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, National Science Council Deputy Minister Huang Wen-hsiung and Tung Chao-chin, president of the Association of Industries in Science Parks.
Huang said the MOU is aimed at promoting cooperation and exchanges between the HSPA and the YRP in various fields, including technological research.
The HSPA is now one of the world's most significant areas for semiconductor manufacturing, while the YRP is the world's first ever international hub dedicated to research in mobile communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Supreme Court rebutes Berlusconi's criticism against prosecutors.
The Supreme Court defended prosecutors who were investigating into alleged briberies committed by former premier Silvio Berlusconi and rebutted the opposition leader's criticism against judicial personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Steroid Report Cites" Collective Failure"
Former Senator George J. Mitchell released a blistering report Thursday that tied 89 Major League Baseball players, including Roger Clemens, to the use of illegal, performance-enhancing drugs. The report used informant testimony and supporting documents to provide a richly detailed portrait of what Mr. Mitchell described as " baseball's steroids era."
The Wall Street Journal: Citigroup Alters Course, Bails Out Affiliated Funds Citigroup Inc., bruised by mounting losses, is bailing out seven affiliated investment entities, bringing $49 billion in assets onto its balance sheet and further denting its depleted capital base.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT blamed over threatening letter targeting president

TEXT.P: Responding to main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers' criticisms of President Chen Shui-bian's public revelation of having received a threatening letter, the Presidential Office urged the party Friday not to gloat over others' misfortune as doing so could invite crime.

Presidential Office Public Affairs Department Director Lee Nan-yang issued the call after various KMT lawmakers criticized Chen for making public the letter and questioned his motives in a forum at the Legislative Yuan earlier the same day.

While stumping Thursday in Taipei for a legislative candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen told supporters that the Presidential Office had received a letter earlier that same day threatening his daughter with rape, his eldest grandson with abduction and himself against two bullets.

KMT Legislator Alex Fai questioned why the intelligence and investigative authorities have not conducted a probe if someone really sent a threatening letter to the president, while his KMT counterpart Chang Jen-hsiang blamed Chen for upsetting the social atmosphere by bringing the issue into the limelight.

Stressing that Chen disclosed the incident to remind the public to pay greater attention to violence and threats, Lee asked the KMT not to apply double standards to similar cases because such an attitude would encourage crime and would not help forge social harmony.

"Any intention to exercise violence must be condemned, regardless of one's political stance, " Lee said, adding that "threatening the president is a very serious matter, and the outside world should not politicize Chen's disclosure of the incident."
Despite the threatening letters sent to President Chen, DPP vice presidential candidate Su Tseng-chang said that he has no plans to increase the number of personnel in his security detachment.

Su blasted those who try to create chaos and upset public order in society through violent means and expressed hope that Taiwan's society would maintain its stability and preserve its kindly nature and good faith.

Apart from Chen, political figures from both the ruling and opposition camps also have received threatening letters in recent weeks, including KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his DPP rival Frank Hsieh, as well as Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey and Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng ahead of the legislative and presidential elections slated for early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group protests against proposed early legislature recess

TEXT.P: Members of a civic group, Citizen Congress Watch (CCW) , staged a protest outside the Legislative Yuan Friday against the legislature's plan to wrap up the current session Dec. 21, 10 days earlier than the legally prescribed date.
Under the Constitution, the Legislative Yuan holds two sessions each year, with the first lasting from Feb. 1 to the end of May, and the second from Sept. 1 to Dec. 31.

Since the term of incumbent lawmakers will come to an end Jan. 31 when they will be replaced by those elected in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, legislators who will join the elections have proposed an early end to the current legislative session to allow them to concentrate on their election campaigns.

The early recess plan was given the green light earlier this week but soon drew opposition from activists dedicated to pushing for judicial and legislative system reforms, who denounced the decision to end the legislative session ahead of schedule as a waste of public money.

CCW Chairman Ku Chung-hua claimed Friday that the decision will waste over NT$50 million of the taxpayers' money, the amount 213 incumbent lawmakers will draw in wages reviewing the more than 1,000 backlogged bills at the Legislative Yuan.
Ku urged legislators to either stay in office until the last day of their terms or donate their salaries to charity.

DOC.HEADLINE: More countries look to woo Taiwanese tourists

TEXT.P: More countries are looking to woo Taiwanese tourists as outbound tourism continues to grow, said travel representatives from various countries at an international travel fair Friday.

"The reason is clear. Almost half of your [Taiwan's] population at least made a trip overseas last year, " Robert Young, a staff in Hungarian Trade Office in Taipei, spoke about Taiwan's tourism potential.

Hungary was among seven new presenters at the 2007 Taipei International Travel Fair taking place from Dec. 14-17 with 62 participating countries at the annual event. Other first-timers are Nauru, the Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Tuvalu, the Solomon Islands and Greece.

According to statistics released by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) in November, the number of outbound Taiwanese tourist trips reached 7.68 million between January and October this year.

"Currently 15,000 Taiwanese tourists visit Hungary every year, and we're targeting 25,000," Young said, adding that negotiations on direct flights between Taiwan and Budapest is ongoing and hopefully a deal will be reached next year.

The Czech Republic has been trying to attract not only Taiwanese investment but tourists as well. Of 30,000 visitors last year, most of them were businessmen, CzechTourism representative Lucie Turkova said, adding that as bilateral trade and investment increase, tourism is also expected to boom and that's why they're here.

Travel agencies have also changed with the times and are going with the latest trends. In the past, most Taiwanese tourists wanted to visit as many countries and spots as possible, but that is no longer the case, said Mathias Hultgren, who represents the Swedish travel agency Scandinavian Perspectives Taiwan.

"Travel plans in the past basically excluded young people because only senior citizens were able to enjoy a two to three weeks trip, " Hulgren said. About 50,000 Taiwanese tourists visited Sweden last year, he said.

Agencies are also employing different strategies to attract Taiwanese tourists. Hultgren said their main target was those who have been to Europe but never visited Scandinavia, and people who are interested in seeing a different part of Europe.

"How many [Taiwanese] people visit Toronto every year? " Hultgren said, adding that Taiwanese have had the misconception that Sweden was too far away for an affordable trip, but the distance between Taipei and Stockholm is about the same as that between Taipei and Toronto.
As usual, Japan took up the most booths, 66 in all, although representatives from Hong Kong and Macao also made their presence felt at the fair.
DGBAS statistics showed that Hong Kong, Japan and Macao were the top three destinations for outbound Taiwanese tourists this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ING Taipei International Marathon to take place Sunday

TEXT.P: The 2007 ING Taipei International Marathon sponsored by the Taiwan-based ING Antai Life Insurance Co. will start at the plaza in front of Taipei City Hall Sunday, drawing over 100,000 participants, a spokesman for the organizers said Friday.

The event's full-marathon -- a run of 42.195 km to be completed within five hours and 30 minutes -- has received 22,000 applications, the spokesman said, adding that the number shows a 44 percent growth of the figure in 2004, which was the first year of the event.
Runners who break any records in the full marathon will win NT$1 million (US$30,865), while local runners who break Taiwanese records will win NT$100,000, the spokesman said.

Taiwanese athletes such as Wu Wen-chien and Hsu Yu-fang, both of whom have set previous local records, will compete along with 10 top-class foreign runners, including two from Kenya who are very likely to break records and win the general championship, the spokesman said.

For the past three years, the event's sponsor has donated about NT$5 million as social welfare funds. The amount is decided every year according to the number of runners who complete the race, the spokesman said.

The sponsor has invited the public to join a fundraising activity to be held alongside this year's marathon with the aim of raising more funds for social welfare, in addition to the amount to be decided by the race results, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Documentary film presents foreign spouses' integration into Taiwan

TEXT.P: A documentary film about the education of foreign spouses in Taiwan premiered in Taipei City Thursday, with the aim of encouraging more new immigrants to study Mandarin and local cultures so as to better integrate into Taiwanese society, an education official said Friday.

The film, produced by Taiwanese director Tsai Tsung-lung, was made at the invitation of the Ministry of Education (MOE), which has provided aseries of courses on both local languages and cultures at local schools to help foreign spouses adapt to life in Taiwan, the official said.

The official pointed out that as of October this year, the number of Taiwan's new immigrants through marriage reached nearly 400,000, but only about 70,000 of them have taken Mandarin lessons provided by the MOE.

One of the film's three leading characters, Kao Hsien-hsiang, an immigrant from Vietnam, has lived in Taiwan for over eight years and finished taking lessons at Sihsian Elementary School in Taipei County last year.

Kao told reporters that she was saddened seeing immigrants from her country suffering from communication difficulties and social discrimination. With her husband's support, she later decided to take lessons and now works as a volunteer at a local household registration office in Taipei County.

The film also shows another two characters with different life experiences and difficulties regaining confidence and acquiring local knowledge via a variety of channels as they prepare themselves for future life challenges.

Director Tsai said he discovered during the production of the documentary that discrimination against foreign spouses is a common phenomenon in Taiwanese society. "Many Taiwanese people are reluctant to understand them or give them chances to speak up, " Tsai said.

He expressed hope that the film will prompt more foreign spouses to learn local languages and cultures in order to better communicate with Taiwan's people and, at the same time, help Taiwan's people better understand the difficulties foreign spouses face, their feelings and thoughts as new immigrants.
The film will also be shown around the country at 12 seminars on the MOE's policies on new immigrants from Dec. 14 to Jan. 6, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHA chief apologizes to Legislative Yuan speaker

TEXT.P: The minister of the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) apologized Friday to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng for mistakenly blaming him for a disputed proposal at the Legislative Yuan to freeze the CHA's unspent budget.

Lee Yung-teh visited Wang at the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day to make the apology after the CHA released a statement Thursday asking Wang to explain why he endorsed the proposal put forth by Legislator Wong Chung-chun of the opposition Kuomintang to postpone legislative negotiations on the CH A's budget for next year and to freeze the unspent portion of the council's 2007 budget.
In response, Wang pointed out that no Executive Yuan agencies have the power to interfere in budget screening by lawmakers.
Lee said he mistook the signature Wang wrote on the proposal document to acknowledge his receipt of the paper as Wang's endorsement of the proposal.

Lee continued to denounce Wong for holding the CHA hostage in an attempt to have his request fulfilled, referring to Wong's failure to win the CHA's subsidizing of a planned Hakka cultural park construction project in Shuishang township in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.
Dozens of Shuishang township residents led by Wong protested at the CHA Friday after the council decided not to subsidize the project, the cost of which has been assessed at NT$8.8 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taiwan' to appear in Taipei 101 New Year firework show

TEXT.P: "Taiwan" or "I Love Taiwan" might appear in a New Year firework show at the top of Taipei 101, one of the highest skyscrapers in the world, a spokesman for Taipei Financial Center Corp., which manages the building, said Friday.
The company will choose between the two wordings rather than the government slogan "U.N. for Taiwan," said Michael Liu, assistant vice president of the company's Corporate Public Affairs.
Liu said that the company will avoid using what he described as "politically sensitive" and "controversial" slogans.
"U.N. for Taiwan" is being used by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to promote the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.

The Tourism Bureau under the Cabinet-level Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) had planned to display the slogan in the firework show in an effort to raise the international profile of the country's U.N. membership bid.
However, the bureau's plan drew protests from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled Taipei city government, which approved the company's plan to stage the firework show earlier in the day.

Amid rumors that the Taipei city government had deliberately postponed the screening of the company's firework show plan, DPP Taipei City Councilor Chuang Jui-hsiung called a press conference in which he accused the city government of applying double standards to its screening of the application.
The city government told the company late last year that the screening would not be subject to the Firework and Firecracker Regulation Act, Chuang noted.
However, the city government has changed its stance this year and now requires the company to abide by the act, Chuang claimed.
Noting that the city government is not the sponsor of the firework show, Chuang said it should not have interfered with the wording of the show.

However, an official of the city's Fire Department, who was also present at the press conference, responded that the city government did not change its stance and did not conduct the screening according to the act.

The screening process was delayed because the company's safety plan failed to pass the city government's screening, the city official explained, dismissing rumors that the city government purposefully delayed the screening.
The city government approved the firework show plan soon after the company submitted an improved safety plan, the official went on.
Taipei 101 will set off 12,000 fireworks this year -- 3,000 more than last year -- Liu said, adding that fireworks will also be set off over the skyscraper for the first time.
More than 600,000 people are expected to watch the New Year show, the city official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Death toll from car accidents from Jan.-Nov. lower than last year

TEXT.P: The number of people who died in car accidents from January to November this year shows an obvious decrease compared with the same period of last year, Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Duei said Friday.

Tsai said the death toll -- specifically, death before arrival at hospital -- from accidents involving small vehicles during the 11-month period was 2,329, which was a 17.76 percent decrease over last year's figure and exceeded the projected goal of a 10 percent drop set by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Meanwhile, the death toll from accidents involving large vehicles also decreased about 20 percent from the year-earlier level, reaching the projected goal.

Tsai said the MOTC will present awards to people who have made great contributions to public traffic safety at a commendation ceremony to be held Dec. 17 at the Liu Tuei Hakka Cultural Park located in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan.

A total of 174 groups and individuals will receive the awards, including traffic police, school teachers and volunteers who have played crucial parts in keeping traffic order and maintaining traffic safety, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County violence prevention center cited

TEXT.P: The domestic and sexual violence prevention center of the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung has been cited by the Ministry of the Interior for its outstanding service over the past year, county government officials said Friday.

Citing statistics compiled by the center, officials at the social affairs bureau said that as much as NT$12.1 million (US$370,000) was distributed in the first 10 months of the year to help victims, with the bulk of emergency financial aid going for daily family needs, followed by economic handouts to provide temporary shelter or rent.

During the January-October period, a total of 4,580 cases of domestic violence were reported to the center, up by 216 over the previous year's level, the same tallies showed. The number of teen abuse cases increased most by 170, while there were 31 cases more involving senior citizens.

There were 327 sexual assaults cases in the ten-month period, up by 48 year on year, according to the statistics. In terms of relations between the victims and offenders, the number implicating online friends grew the most by 15, while there were 12 more cases involving husbands and wives, ex-spouses, engaged couples, boyfriends and girlfriends or ex-lovers.
Officials called on the public to swiftly turn to the county's social affairs bureau or police authorities for help if they find relatives or friends have been assaulted.

Although the county government has set up a comprehensive network to protect victims, officials said the public should be aware that the number of abused children, teens, women and elderly persons has been increasing steadily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to stop referring to late presidents' tombs as 'mausoleums'

TEXT.P: The government will stop referring to the tombs of the late Presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo as "mausoleums" and will simply call each a "tomb, grave or cemetery, " Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jyh-wey said Friday.

Shieh made the remarks while commenting on issues concerning the government's plan to withdraw military guards posted at the Chiangs' graves in Tashi, Taoyuan County, where their remains are temporarily interred.

Calling the plan part of the government's efforts to achieve transitional justice, Shieh said the government has been benevolent enough to have dispatched military guards to protect the mausoleums for so many years after the end of martial law in Taiwan.

It would be very unreasonable if anyone were to think the government should continue using taxpayers' money for the purpose, Shieh said, pointing out that the government has prepared new tombs for the permanent burial of the two late presidents at Taipei County's Wuchihshan Military Cemetery.
However, Shieh would not confirm whether the withdrawal will be completed by Jan. 13, 2008 -- the anniversary of Chiang Ching-kuo's passing.
President Chen Shui-bian said last week that the military guards will be withdrawn at the beginning of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ cooperates with foreign law schools in training prosecutors

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has signed memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with law schools at the prestigious Stanford University and Cornell University in the United States, under which the ministry will send several outstanding prosecutors as visiting scholars to receive training at the two institutes, MOJ sources said Friday.

The cooperative agreements aim to cultivate prosecutors' legal knowledge and foreign language competence and offer them an opportunity to broaden their perspectives in hopes that they will be able to better represent Taiwan while attending international conferences and engaging in negotiations with foreign countries, the sources explained.

With a view to raising the standard of prosecutorial services, the MOJ has proactively sought to forge links with prestigious law schools in the United States and Japan and selected excellent prosecutors to visit the educational institutions to learn about the theory and practice of criminal law systems in various countries and the operational advantages and shortcomings of their systems, the sources said.
Since 2002, the MOJ has clinched MoUs with Yale University and Harvard University in the U.S., as well as the University of Tokyo and Waseda University in Japan, the sources noted.

Prosecutors who are selected under the plan will be granted paid study leave, full tuition subsidies, plus round-trip flight tickets, the sources noted, adding that they will be required to serve at the MOJ for a specific period of time after returning to Taiwan.
Since 2003, a cumulative total of 16 prosecutors have returned to Taiwan and worked at various units at the MOJ after finishing their overseas studies, according to the sources.

As the MOJ is Taiwan's representative agency at meetings of the Asia Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APG) , the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering (FATF) , the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), and the World Trade Organization (WTO), there is an imminent need to train prosecutors to improve foreign language proficiency and professional expertise if they are to be involved in negotiations with other countries, the sources went on.

The MOJ has frequently sent prosecutors to attend international negotiations, meetings or training sessions in Belgium, Australia Japan in the past few months of this year, and has recently dispatched prosecutors to join a Taiwan-EU workshop on legal affairs in Belgium, according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar calls for greater humanity for new immigrants

TEXT.P: Academics and social activists called Friday for greater humanity for new immigrants on the part of the government when drafting relevant policies.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the non-profit Awakening Foundation and attended by scores of academics, representatives of civic groups and immigrants, Liao Yuan-hao, an associate professor at National Chengchi University, said the government should work out more humanitarian policies and mechanisms for new immigrants and foreign spouses.

Citing a legally binding requirement that new foreign spouses must have assets of NT$400,000 (US$12,310) as an example, Liao said many groups dedicated to helping new immigrants have sought to have the Legislative Yuan scrap this rule.

According to Liao, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has promised to help push for such a law amendment. Liao added that they will also seek to meet ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and ask for his assistance.

Many laws currently enacted by the government, such as the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area and the Immigration Law, are hostile to immigrants, Liao said.

He urged the government to adjust its mindset when drawing up policies by taking human rights for immigrants into account instead of merely focusing on entry and exit controls or the "quality" of human resources.
The professor also encouraged social service activists to seek breakthroughs and challenges on the legal front and think out of the box in order to better assist new immigrants.
Liao said he is optimistic that several amendment proposals to the Nationality Law will be discussed at the Legislative Yuan before it adjourns its present session late this month.

Chung Chin-ming, chairman of a cross-Taiwan Strait marriage promotion group, said Taiwan's laws and regulations are very unfriendly to Chinese spouses of local citizens, despite the fact that bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and China have rapidly increased over the past 20 years.
Due to a quota management system implemented by the government, it takes some 33 years for Chinese husbands and wives who hope to be naturalized as Taiwanese to get an ID card, according to Chung.

Men and women from Taiwan and China have established at least 250,000 families to date, with the number of their family members and relatives in Taiwan climbing to more than 1 million, Chung said, pointing out that the government's long-term discriminatory treatment of Chinese spouses negatively impacts local society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Director, businessman receives distinguished British alumni award

TEXT.P: Winston Wong, the son of Taiwanese business tycoon Wang Yung-ching, and Yen Lan- chuan, a film director, received the second annual Distinguished Alumni Awards from the British Council Taipei Friday.
The award recognizes outstanding Taiwanese who received higher education in British universities and graduate schools. Taichung Mayor Jason Hu won the award last year.

A Sheffield Hallam University alumni who studied film and documentary making, Yen came back to Taiwan in 1998 and launched a successful career filming documentaries. Among her works, three documentaries about the Sept. 21 earthquake and Happy Rice -- the story of a Taiwanese farmer -- have earned high praise.
Wong, the president of the Grace T.H.W. Group and a graduate of Imperial College of Science and Technology in London, was recognized for his business success in both Taiwan and China.
All alumni who studied in British schools nominated six candidates before a public vote was conducted during the Education U.K. exhibition, which was held in various cities throughout the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pianist wins 2nd place in Beethoven Piano Competition
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/07 21:57:56 (By Lin Yu-li and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A young Taiwanese pianist residing in Berlin won second place and the Audience Choice Award in the first International Beethoven Piano Competition held in Arad, Romania Thursday.
It was Lu Yi-chih's second international award of the year, having already been the runner-up in the Sendai International Music Competition in Japan in June.

Lu impressed the five judges from Austria and Czech Republic with his playing of Haydn's sonata in the preliminary, two of Brahms' rhapsodies in the semi-final, and working with a local symphony orchestra in Arad to play Beethoven's Piano Concertos No. 5 "Emperor" in the final round.

The 25-year-old Lu attributed winning the Audience Choice Award to his outstanding performance of the Concertos No. 5, but admitted that he played a bit under par in the preliminary and semi-final rounds due to a serious cold and therefore lost the grand prize as the final score was based on all three performances. "It is a pity, " he said.

One of the most distinguished young pianists in Taiwan, Lu went to study at University of Music and Performing Arts Vienna in Austria at the age of 17, then transferred to the Berlin University of the Arts last year.

Lu, who has been busy performing across Europe, held a piano recital at the National Concert Hall in Taipei last May and worked with Austria's National Radio Station Orchestra performing Mozart's concerto at Vienna's Grossen Saal Musikverein in October.

Thanks to his efforts, Lu has won many piano prizes over the past three years, including second place at Barcelona's Maria Canals and Slovakia's Hummel International Piano Competition, the grand prize at Austria's Gradus ad Parnassum, and runner-up status at the third Sendai International Music Competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election campaigns will not focus on late presidents: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has no plans to focus its legislative election campaign on removing "the divinity" of the two late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, a DPP official said Friday.

Rather, the DPP will appeal to local citizens about reclaiming the ill-gotten assets obtained by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) during its previous 55 years of rule in Taiwan, said Hsieh Hsin-ni, director of the party's Culture and Information Department.
In addition, the DPP will tell the public how the KMT "irrationally" has blocked a number of important bills at the legislature over the years, Hsieh went on.

Hsieh's remarks came in response to a report in the Chinese-language United Evening News that day claiming that high-ranking DPP officials have decided to run an "anti-Chiang" campaign in the run-up to Jan. 12 legislative elections.

Hsieh, who is also a legislator, said the DPP's election campaign will show local people how the KMT has "irrationally" obstructed the passage of many important draft acts and what "unjustifiable" bills the KMT has proposed in the legislature.
In a recent TV commercial, the DPP said that "however barbarian the KMT is, it should not block bills that are beneficial to the welfare of the people."

According to the DPP, the KMT has blocked several major bills, including a budget bill for flood prevention projects. The KMT has also frozen the appropriation of several of the DPP government's annual budgets, the DPP said.
Lambasting the KMT for hindering the country's progress and slowing the national economy, Hsieh said the DPP will raise funds to produce more TV commercials targeting the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chunghwa Telecom inks MOU with Palau company

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan's largest telecom operator, has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Palau National Communications Corp. (PNCC) in Taipei to help PNCC enhance its technology and services, a spokesman for Chunghwa Telecom said Friday.

Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Ho Chen-tan made the announcement after inking the MOU with his counterpart who came to Taiwan to take part in an international travel fair that opened in Taipei earlier in the day.
Ho said the MOU is a result of a visit he made to Palau's state-run PNCC in November.
During the visit, Ho said he discovered that the PNCC has earned significant revenues from its Internet, mobile phone and cable TV services.
However, there is still a lot of room for growth in the penetration rates within these services, Ho went on.
Under the terms of the MOU, Chunghwa Telecom will help upgrade the quality of PNCC's services and search for opportunities for joint investment, Ho noted.
Palau comprises more than 200 islands in the northern Pacific located southeast of the Philippines.
With a total population of some 20,000, Palau is Taiwan's nearest diplomatic ally.
As one of the best diving locations in the world, Palau is famous for its coral reefs and attracts large numbers of tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malawian ambassador expresses understanding over slight: MOFA

TEXT.P: Malawi Ambassador to the Republic of China Thengo Maloya has expressed understanding of the situation relating to an incident in which he was asked to take off his jacket for security reasons at a local ceremony, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.
The Foreign Ministry repeatedly explained and apologized to Maloya for the incident and assured him that it will not happen again, MOFA deputy spokeswoman Yeh Fei-pi said.
The apologies came after the ambassador was invited to take part in an Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award (ADHRA) presentation ceremony organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy Thursday.

Maloya told the ministry that President Chen Shui-bian's security officials made him feel "uncomfortable" when he was asked to remove his jacket for security checks prior to Chen's arrival at the ADHRA ceremony.
Yeh said that foreign ambassadors and diplomats enjoy special treatment and diplomatic privileges and urged local organizations to notify the MOFA when they invite foreign officials.
Meanwhile, the National Security Bureau (NSB) also sent an official to apologize to Maloya and issued a public apology.

DOC.HEADLINE: Supreme Court confirms president's confidentiality privilege

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court confirmed Friday President Chen Shui-bian's "confidentiality privilege" and revoked a Taiwan High Court ruling that did not positively address Chen's demand to reclaim a collection of documents and articles held by the Taipei District Court in its probe into the "state affairs fund" misuse case.

The Supreme Court told the High Court to make a new ruling on Chen's petition for reclamation of the documents based on whether Chen's explanation of the importance of keeping the documents confidential is justified.

The High Court ruled Oct. 22 that the District Court should first determine whether Chen himself or the Presidential Office secretary-general is authorized to request the return of the collection under the Presidential Office Organization Law.

As the laws to be used in the case depend on the status or identity of the applicant, the High Court ruling said the District Court should not have made a judgment on Chen's request before it had deliberated on whether Chen has the right to make such a request in the first place.

If Chen is not a suitable applicant, the High Court ruling said the District Court just needs to turn down the request and need not bother to check whether Chen is eligible to proclaim the documents as "strictly confidential" in terms of his confidentiality privilege.

Against this backdrop, the High Court revoked the District Court's previous ruling and demanded that the District Court mete out a new judgment. Dissatisfied with the High Court ruling, Chen appealed the case to the Supreme Court.

The Supreme Court said in its verdict that since the Council of Grand Justices has recognized the president's confidentiality privilege in its No. 627 constitutional interpretation, other national agencies should respect or abide by the ruling.

Given such a privilege, the president is eligible to determine whether a document should be kept confidential for national security or national interest concerns, no matter whether such a document is still in his possession or has already been handed to any Presidential Office unit.

If the president is not allowed to determine the document's confidentiality once it has been handed over to another unit for documentation, the Supreme Court said the president's privilege would be undermined.
Moreover, the Supreme Court said the Presidential Office secretary-general is just the president's chief of staff and should not himself enjoy confidentiality privileges.

Based on this understanding, the Supreme Court said the High Court should decide whether the documents should be returned to Chen based on his explanation and need not bother to check who is obliged to apply for the return of the documents.

Chen asked for the return of the collection Sept. 6 on the grounds that the collection were "strictly confidential" information under the protection of the Classified National Security Information Protection Act and should be kept secret permanently.

The president said in his petition that the collection was labeled "strictly confidential" in line with CGJ Ruling No. 627, which confirms the president's constitutional right to decide what constitutes a state secret and his right to refuse disclosure, also known as confidentiality privilege.
The collection consists of invoices, vouchers, magnetic records, written testimony by concerned individuals and data related to six secret diplomatic projects from 2002 to last December.

The District Court obtained the collection of documents and articles from a prosecutorial team that indicted the first lady and three other defendants last November on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund, " a special allowance fund set aside for the president's discretionary use for official purposes. Chen was named as a "joint perpetrator" in the case, but he was not indicted because of his immunity from prosecution as prescribed in the Constitution.

The lawyers of President Chen and four defendants in the case -- first lady Wu Shu-jen and three of Chen's former and incumbent aides -- appealed to the High Court Oct. 15 after the District Court turned down the presidential request for the return of the collection in a ruling issued Oct. 5.

The District Court based its rejection on the grounds that the president's proclamation of the collection fo documents as "strictly confidential" is illegal. According to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Ruling No. 627 issued June 15, President Chen is entitled to appeal to the Taiwan High Court over disputes with the district court or prosecution concerning the exercise of his confidentiality privilege.

As the four defendants in the "state affairs fund" case do not have the right to appeal the District Court ruling on the ownership of the collection of documents, the High Court ruling said they should not appeal again over the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's PPP-converted per capita GDP ranks 21st

TEXT.P: Taiwan's purchasing power parity (PPP) -converted per capita gross domestic product (GDP) amounted to US$28,552 in 2005, ranking it 21st in the world, government officials said Friday.

As Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, the ranking was calculated by the the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) in terms of the U.N.'s Human Development Index (HDI) formula, the officials said.
According to the DGBAS calculation, Taiwan's HDI ranked 23rd in the world in 2005 in comparison with 31st registered in 1990.

DGBAS officials said the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) has since 1990 released the HDI, which measures the average achievements of a country according to three basic aspects of human development -- life expectancy, knowledge and standard of living as measured by per capita GDP.
Among the 177 countries surveyed in the 2005 report, Iceland topped the HDI list, followed by Norway and Australia.
As Taiwan's HDI was ranked 23rd among the countries surveyed, the country belongs in the category of high human development as defined by the United Nations.
Among the various categories measured, the life expectancy of Japanese citizens topped the list at 82.3 years, while that of Taiwanese people was 77.4 years, ranked 34th.
Regarding knowledge and education, Taiwan's literacy rate was ranked 54th, while its combined primary, secondary and tertiary education gross enrollment ranking was fifth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 15, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino- American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: FM presents Taiwan aid donation for Dominican storm victims
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/15/07 15:07:33 (By Ramon Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang donated US$30,000 to the Dominican Republic Friday on behalf of the Republic of China government in aid for areas devastated by tropical storm Olga.

Shortly after his arrival in the Caribbean country from Panama, Huang drove to La Varguita, a storm-affected district near the capital city of Santo Domingo, to see what Taiwan can do to help the area.

Olga killed at least 22 people, left more than 37,000 people homeless and destroyed thousands of houses across the country, according to a Friday news release by the World Food Programme, the U.N. food aid agency.
Following the tour, Huang visited the Presidential Office where he was received by Dominican Vice President Rafael Alburquerque.
During the meeting, they exchanged opinions on issues of mutual concern and Alburquerque expressed gratitude for the Taiwanese donations.
Prior to Huang's visit, Taiwan had donated US$225,000 in aid for post-storm rehabilitation.
During his stay in Panama, Huang visited Panamanian President Martin Torrijos before attending a banquet hosted by First Vice President and Foreign Affairs Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro.

On Friday, Huang visited the Rommel Fernandez soccer stadium, Panama's largest, which is currently under restoration, a project that is one of many ongoing Panama-Taiwan collaboration programs, according to the ROC Embassy in Panama.
Huang was also scheduled to visit Nicaragua.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling party has no `dirty tricks': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is employing no "dirty tricks," but is only "following the right way."

The president was responding to reports by the United Daily News, which reported that same day that minutes of a closed-door meeting between American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt and Vincent Siew, vice presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang, in Taipei Dec. 8 had been leaked.

Burghardt said rumor had it that the DPP has "dirty tricks" up its sleeve and he expressed concern that the president could create a disturbance in the Taiwan Strait to obstruct the upcoming legislative and presidential elections in early 2008, according to the reports.
The president, who doubles as DPP chairman, asked the media not to ask him to comment on such reports, which he described as "hearsay."
"The DPP is in power and I'm the president. We have always followed the right way in doing things, and there are no dirty tricks," he said.

He noted that during the 2004 presidential election, his rival accused him of staging an election-eve assassination attempt in which he and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly injured, to win sympathy votes.
He described his rival's accusation as a 'dirty trick."
He also said reports that he might impose martial law prior to the Jan. 12 legislative elections or postpone the elections are untrue.

In a rally to stump for a DPP legislative candidate in Taipei County Nov. 25, Chen said he was mulling several options proposed by some activists, including the imposition of martial law and the postponement of the legislative elections, to deal with the issue arising from the 18 cities and counties led by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" that have refused to abide by the Central Election Commission's decision to use a "one-step" voting system in the legislative elections and two referendums scheduled for Jan. 12.
But he made a clarification the following day, saying that Taiwan has come a long way from authoritarian to democratic rule and that there is no question of backpedalling and imposing martial law.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP hopes for Hsinchu Science Park to be active in peace cause

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested Saturday that the Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan should be active in efforts to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait by taking advantage of its cooperative ties with 23 other high-tech facilities around the world.

Lu made the remarks during a walking tour and a Hsinchu food festival organized by the Hsinchu city and county governments and the park's administration office to celebrate the science park's 27th founding anniversary and the 25th anniversary of Hsinchu City's upgrading to a provincial municipality.
In her address, Lu described the science park as one of Taiwan's important diplomatic resources, citing the park's close connections with many other similar facilities around the world.

This year, Lu noted, the science park's production value is expected to hit NT$1.25 trillion (US$38.63 billion) , which she said proves that Taiwan's high- tech industry enjoys an influential global position.

If the cross-Taiwan Strait situation becomes even more tense, the world will be tense too, she said, adding that the science park might be able to help build a peace network with its foreign allies if there is a political conflict between the two sides of the strait.

The Hsinchu Science Park, established by the government in 1980, is regarded as one of the world's most significant areas for semiconductor manufacturing. It is home to the world's top two semiconductor foundries -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate dismisses 'dirty trick' reports

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh denied reports Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian could use "dirty tricks" to obstruct the March 22 presidential election.

Hsieh was responding to reports by the United Daily News that said minutes of a Dec. 8 closed-door meeting in Taipei between American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt and Vincent Siew, vice presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), had been leaked.

According to the reports, Burghardt expressed concern in the meeting that Chen could create a disturbance in the Taiwan Strait and announce the postponement of the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, while Siew pointed out that rumor has it Chen does not like Hsieh and could create an incident that would allow Su Tseng-chang, the DPP vice presidential candidate, to replace Hsieh.
Hsieh dismissed that the reports as unfounded, claiming that the minutes could have been leaked by the KMT.

Hsieh also accused Ma Ying-jeou, his KMT rival in the presidential election, of speaking ill of Taiwan in front of foreign dignitaries, claiming that Ma criticized Taiwan during visits to Japan and the United States instead of lashing out at China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan.
Su claimed that the KMT is actually best at "dirty tricks, " citing the smear campaign by his rival during his bid for a second term as Pingtung county magistrate.

He said the KMT, in its bid to regain power, has attempted to use what he claimed is the United States' "lack of full understanding" about Taiwan's development and is "using sensationalism" to intimidate Taiwan people for its own gains.
Ma declined to comment on Siew's meeting with Burghardt, saying however, that the KMT is keeping tabs on possible DPP election gambits.
Siew, for his part, said he met with Burghardt in his capacity as an old friend and that there was a tacit agreement between the two that the content of the meeting would not be divulged.
On reports that the two discussed DPP "dirty tricks, " he said he was not aware of the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: President defends disclosure of threatening mail

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he would not have divulged the content of threatening mail sent to the Presidential Office recently had the letter not leveled a threat against his grandson.
Chen made the remarks while attending a lunch gathering of Tainan First Senior High School alumni at the Legislative Yuan restaurant in Taipei.

In response to criticism that he caused unease among grassroots citizens by playing up the incident, Chen said he made the revelation mainly because the mail described his eldest grandson as a target.

"I'm no stranger to death threats. Actually, I live under various kinds of threat and intimidation every day. At the height of the `red-shirt' campaign against me last year, I received an average of 20 death threats by phone, mail or e-mail every day. I took them in stride and paid them no mind," Chen said.
Noting that Taiwan is now a pluralistic democratic society, Chen said it is not uncommon that a public issue draws a myriad of voices and opinions.

"I respect dissenting views, but I condemn violence. Everyone is free to air his or her opinions via peaceful, non-violent means. Nobody should resort to violent or non-peaceful ways of expression," he said.

Upon his arrival at the Legislative Yuan restaurant, an aide of opposition Kuomintang Legislator Tsai Chin-lung stepped in front of him intending to heckle Chen in a direct encounter, he was immediately bundled away by police officers posted at the legislature.

Recalling that the mob of red-clad protesters spewed streams of invective at him during last year's failed campaign to force him to step down over graft allegations, Chen said he does not mind the expression of opposing views.

"I would rather see excessive democracy than impose any `red line' or roadblocks to undermine our hard-won democracy. This is probably why the reliability of Taiwan's press is usually very low. Nevertheless, Taiwan ranks top among Asian countries in press freedom surveys conducted by major international media watchdogs, including Reporters Without Borders and Freedom House, " Chen said proudly, adding that he will never back away from his commitment to upholding full freedom of the press and freedom of speech.
