DOC.HEADLINE: Beef, beer festival kicks off in Tainan County

TEXT.P: An annual "beef and beer" festival kicked off Saturday at the Shanghua brewery in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, at which Magistrate Su Huan-chih hosted a charity auction of what he described as the best quality beef in the country.

The venue was filled with the luscious aromas from 10 food stands selling paper- thin slices local beef dipped momentarily in boiling broth and served immediately, with the cooks boasting of the quality and flavor of their locally produced meat, particularly when cooked in this way.

At the opening ceremony for the nine-day festival, Su described Tainan beef as the being of the highest quality in the country and claimed that the "only way" to capture this quality is to cook it "shabu shabu-style" in clear broth.

Since the festival was first held four years ago, Su said, the price of locally produced beef has doubled, thanks to the county's "special beef cuisine," which is considered a perfect match for fresh locally brewed beer.
The festival, organized by the Tainan county government and the Taiwan Tabaco and Liquor Corp., will run through Dec. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: President happy about police nabbing threat suspects

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he was happy that police had arrested two people suspected of having sent him death threat e-mails.

While stumping for Lee Kun-tseh, a legislative candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the southern Taiwan port city Kaohsiung, Chen said he had been informed that the suspects -- two brothers surnamed Hsu -- were being questioned by police.
Police said the younger brother of the two, 26, works in a gas station part-time and had admitted that he sent the e-mail via his older brother's computer "on the spur of the moment."
The president expressed appreciation for the efficiency of the police, which he said proves that the death threats he had received over the past few days were not staged.

He claimed that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is best at staging incidents, saying that it is used to buying votes and other irregularities but dares not take responsibility for its actions and even claims that the assassination attempt on him on the eve of the 2004 presidential election was staged by himself to win "sympathy votes."

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC to formulate rules to prevent disputes in vote counting

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) plans to formulate a code of conduct to prevent television stations from "inflating ballots" while reporting vote counts in the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, an official said Saturday.

NCC Vice Chairman Howard S.H. Shyr said some TV stations "inflated ballots" when reporting vote counts for certain previous elections, including the hotly contested 2004 presidential election, causing many disputes.
"We hope to flesh out a raft of guidelines and operational rules to prevent a recurrence of similar disputes in the two critical elections set for early next year," Shyr said.

The NCC will invite academics and executives from relevant civic groups in the coming days to exchange views on the formulation of operational rules TV stations will have to follow when reporting vote counts in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election, Shyr said.

In principle, Shyr said, the NCC looks forward to seeing TV stations exercising self-restraint in reporting vote counts and refraining from "inflating the number of ballots" of any individual candidate or political party.
For offenders, Shyr said he hopes TV station owners and operators can work out mutually acceptable disciplinary measures within existing legal provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice minister wants public to report vote-buying

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin called for the public Saturday to report vote- buying to help ensure clean elections.

Shih made the remarks when he, Vice Justice Minister Chu Nan, State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming and other officials attended a "human domino" activity in suburban Taipei to help promote the ministry's campaign to crack down on election bribery.
Shih noted that accepting bribes from election hopefuls will not only compromise one's dignity but could lead to prosecution.
He said that since regulations on punishment for vote-buying offenses were amended, penalties have been raised dramatically to include prison terms of between three years and 10 years.

He cited as an example that those giving away tea worth NT$500 (US$15) can be sentenced to three years and two months, while giving away cash between NT$200 and NT$500 to residents of a building complex through vote brokers will be subject to prison terms of three years and six months.
Giving away cash, hosting dinners and tours, or buying or selling votes will also be counted as bribery, he reiterated.
He noted that the ministry has presented NT$413 million in rewards to informants giving information leading to vote-buying convictions over the years.

The ministry has also deployed more than 5,000 informants around the country in its bid to crack down on vote-buying, which has borne fruit in Taoyuan, Miaoli, Changhua, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties recently.
There have been 110 cases involving bribery, among which 30 cases have seen the annulment of an election victory.
Taiwan is set to hold legislative elections Jan. 12, 2008 and a presidential election March 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Urban indigenous teachers keeping native languages alive

TEXT.P: A group of indigenous teachers in Taipei has been running a language program since last year to keep native languages alive among indigenous people who live in the cities, with good results so far, the group said Saturday.

"The objectives of the association are to promote the indigenous cultures of all 13 tribes and to teaching native languages to urban students of indigenous descent, " said Pu Cheng-chan, president of the Taipei Indigenous Languages Teachers Association (TILTA) on the sidelines of an indigenous culture festival held at the Songshan Tobacco Factory.
TILTA was established last year and now has 42 teachers who come from 13 Taiwanese tribes, most of whom are teaching native languages in Taipei City, Pu said.

Teachers have two-hour weekly classes in churches, schools, village offices and even apartments. TILTA has had more than 700 students, ranging from elementary school children to university students, participating in the free programs.
Upah Yuki, an Atayal from Jianshih township in Hsinchu County, has been teaching an Atayal class of 15 students in the Neihu and Nangang areas for the past year.
Pu, a Tsuo from Alishan, Chiayi County, said the group launched the initiative to complement the "Language Nest" program run by the Indigenous Peoples Commission of the Taipei city government.
"I'm happy to see that most of the indigenous students in Taipei City are learning their native languages and that most parents are encouraging their children to do so, " Pu said.
In general, Taiwan's indigenous people are happy to see the government's efforts in preserving indigenous cultures, said Upah.

Upah, who has changed his name from his Chinese name back to his traditional tribal name, said it is the right move for Sanmin township in Kaohsiung County to adopt the new indigenous name of Namasiya township last week to honor its Tsou tribal history.

The move, he said, shows that the government is implementing the "New Partnership between the Indigenous Peoples and the Government of Taiwan" treaty that was signed by President Chen Shui-bian in 1999 and reaffirmed in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's ADIZ plan raises concerns: diplomat
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/07 20:34:52 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Countries that are concerned about regional peace and security have voiced their concerns to Beijing about its plan to designate an air defense identification zone (ADIZ) within the Taiwan Strait Republic of China Deputy Representative to the United States Stanley Kao said Friday.

In a meeting with reporters, Kao said that soon after Taiwan obtained intelligence revealing China's attempt to outline its new ADIZ over the strait, it informed concerned nations of the plan and expressed strong opposition, saying that it will undermine stability in the region and international aviation safety.
Kao said Taiwan is still talking with the "concerned countries" on the issues but refused to name the countries in question.

President Chen Shui-bian brought the issue to public attention during an early December meeting with visiting U.S. Congressman Eni Faleomavaega, who serves as chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia, the Pacific and the Global Environment.

Chen said he believes China's plan to designate an ADIZ within the strait will prevent the United States and Japan from gathering military intelligence on China, while inaugurating a new air route west of the median of the Taiwan Strait will destabilize the peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
He expressed hope that the United States and Japan will address the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local financial holding companies face severe challenges

TEXT.P: Local financial holding groups will face increasing competition from their foreign counterparts as the world's four major banking conglomerates have managed to expand their Taiwan networks through acquisitions, market researchers said Saturday.

The warning came after HSBC Holdings PLC, Europe's biggest bank by market value, took over control of the debt-laden Chinese Bank Friday after the government agreed to pay HSBC NT$47.49 billion (US$1.46 billion).

The HSBC deal was the latest in a series of forays by foreign banks into the Taiwan market. On June 8, ABN Amro Holding NV assumed control of Taitung Business Bank while New York-based Citigroup Inc., the most profitable overseas bank in Taiwan, bought the Bank of Overseas Chinese for NT$14.1 billion in April. In September 2006, London-based Standard Chartered PLC acquired Hsinchu International Bank.

Noting that Taiwan's financial market is not very large, market analysts said foreign banking groups mostly set their eyes on the vast Chinese market in their acquisition bid for Taiwanese banks. Given the facts that Taiwan shares same languages and cultural backgrounds with China, foreign banks can employ the experiences they obtain in Taiwan for use in their foray into the Chinese market.

Moreover, the researchers said, the acquisition of Taiwanese banks will offer foreign banks easy access to the immense financial service market for the large number of Taiwan-funded companies in China and other Asian countries to expand their Asian financial map.

In addition, the analysts said, Taiwan's consumer banking and personal financial management markets are also growing steadily. With a limited number of branches, foreign banks used to have difficulties entering those emerging service fields. After buying into Taiwanese banks, foreign banks can now expand their local service networks and the return of their investment will become even more evident in two or three years, the analysts said.

Local financial holding company executives admitted that the entry of foreign banks have posed a tremendous threat to market shares. "If we fail to upgrade service quality and design innovative financial products, we could be overtaken by our foreign counterparts in three years," said a senior executive of a local financial holding company.
Foreign banks are also expected to offer attractive employment terms to lure away outstanding financial managers from local banks, posing yet another challenge for local banks, the executive warned.

In the face of growing competition from foreign banking groups, the executive said local banks must step up manpower training, streamline overall operations, upgrade product design capabilities and seek merger and acquisition opportunities with their local counterparts to expand economies of scale. The most suitable number of domestic branches of a local financial holding group ranges between 180 and 200, the executive noted.

According to a deal reached between HSBC and Taiwan's government-owned Central Deposit Insurance Corp. (CDIC) , HSBC will take over Chinese Bank's sound assets, including its branches, as well as debts and at least half of the bank's' employees, while Taiwan's Financial Reconstruction Fund will pay HSBC NT$47.49 billion.

The Chinese Bank is a unit of the bankrupt Rebar Group. The CDIC assumed control of the bank after a run on its deposits early this year. The CDIC is the only institution in Taiwan exclusively in charge of managing the deposit insurance system and serves as an integral part of the country's financial safety net.

HSBC said in a statement issued Friday that it plans to inject between US$300 million and US$400 million of fresh capital into Chinese Bank to ensure its enlarged operations will have "appropriate" financial ratios.
"Chinese Bank will provide HSBC in Taiwan with significant opportunities in retail, commercial and corporate banking, " HSBC's Taiwan Chief Executive Alistair Currie said in the statement.
HSBC, which has eight bank branches and 2,300 workers in Taiwan, said the acquisition will increase the number of its branches on the island, Asia's fourth-largest banking market, to 47.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUAS cooperating with Merida in developing solar-powered bicycles

TEXT.P: The National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences (KUAS) is collaborating with Taiwan's second largest bicycle company, Merida Industry Co., to develop solar-powered bicycles, which are expected to hit the market in March 2008, a university executive said Sunday.

Approximately 90 percent of the undertaking has been completed and the entire program is likely to be finalized as scheduled after some modifications, according to Ai Ho-chang, director of the KUAS's Graduate Institute of Applied Science and chief executive of the Southern Solar School established by the Ministry of Education at the university.
Ai said that the university is in charge of the design, research and development and trials of the bicycles, and is engaged in negotiations with Merida on matters concerning patent rights.
He added that Merida is planning to set up manufacturing factories in China to pave the way for the mass production and marketing of the new bikes.

Meanwhile, the 2007 National Solar-Powered Model Car Race organized by the Southern Solar School was held Sunday at National Science and Technology Museum in the southern city of Kaohsiung. It had brought together 41 teams from 21 colleges and universities islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 17, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
6.1% of students receiving guidance have used drugs: survey

TEXT.P: A total of 6.1 percent of junior high school students receiving guidance admitted they have used drugs, according to the results of a survey released by the Champions Education Association over the weekend.
The survey also revealed that 7.7 percent of the students smoke, and 7.2 percent have joined a gang.
Also, 15.1 percent of respondents tend to indulge in online friend-making, while another 27.2 percent tend to indulge in cyber games.

The survey was carried out between May and June this year among 17,265 students in the first year of junior high school. They were all participants in guidance programs offered by the association in 24 counties and cities nationwide.

On parent-child relations, 20 percent of respondents said they do not get along well or have communication problems with their parents, and more than 30 percent think their parents discipline their children too strictly, are inconsistent in applying their rules to themselves or are dissatisfied with their children's performance.

The survey further revealed that approximately 50 percent of respondents find going to school to be an unpleasant experience, 8-12 percent have been extorted or threatened in school, and 13-20 percent are often bullied or ostracized by their classmates.

In addition, 30 percent of respondents are dissatisfied with their appearance, 50 percent care very much how others look at them, 30 percent often feel depressed or sad for no reason, and 50 percent often see their emotions influenced by others or fail to get enough sleep, according to the survey.

Commenting on the results, Wang Fu-lin, head of the Ministry of Education's Department of Military Training Education, said the ratio of drug-using students in this survey is clearly higher than those of similar surveys conducted in the past, which he said could be related to the fact that this survey targeted students requiring extra attention and support.
Results of past surveys carried out among teenagers or undergraduates indicate that 1-2 percent of respondents have used drugs, Wang noted.

Noting that there is always a correlation between drug abuse and gang participation and the issue of school dropouts, Wang said the ministry has in recent years taken various measures to prevent students from dropping out and to encourage dropouts to return to school.

Of the more than 6,000 students dropping out of school during the last academic year, over 600 admitted they left school because of the bad influence of their friends, he pointed out, adding that school dropouts can be led astray more easily than others because of their abnormal lifestyles.
Meanwhile, tallies from the National Police Agency show that 420 minors were arrested for drug abuse during the first eight months of this year, compared with 405 during the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-Taiwan ties not affected by elections, referendums: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's upcoming legislative and presidential elections and the referendums to be held alongside them are not affecting the country's bilateral ties with the United States, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Tzu-pao said Monday.

Yang said while delivering a report at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has repeatedly stressed to the U.S. government that the referendum on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations as a full member under the name Taiwan will not alter the political status quo across the Taiwan Strait and is by no means a move toward Taiwan independence as Beijing has claimed.

Yang said to the legislators from across the political spectrum that he would describe 98 percent of the U.S.-Taiwan relationship as "very good" and the remaining two percent as "not that smooth" because the two sides remain divided over Taiwan's upcoming legislative and presidential elections as well as the issues involved in the referendums.

"This two percent is not having any adverse impact on the overall U.S.-Taiwan relationship," Yang said, claiming that bilateral ties have continuously improved and "this year is better than last year."

Yang said the MOFA has repeatedly told Washington that the deepening of Taiwan's democratization and the building of Taiwan's "distinctive identity" are the "common assets" of Taiwan and the United States which also form the bedrock of peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
Meanwhile, he said, the MOFA has also continued its efforts to improve bilateral U.S.-Taiwan ties, including seeking a relaxation of U.S. restrictions on visits of its Cabinet officials to Taiwan.

The MOFA has also made continuous efforts to push for closer military and security dialogue and cooperation between the two countries and has constantly kept the United States informed about the progress in Taiwan's controls on the export of militarily-sensitive products and in the implementation of anti-terrorism policies, Yang said, adding that the MOFA has also expressed Taiwan's willingness to offer humanitarian aid related to anti-terrorism efforts to individuals from around the world and other countries in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Mission not affiliated with any political party: chief
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/07 15:17:31 (By Jorge Liu and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Defense Mission to the United States serves only the country and has no affiliations with any political parties, Maj. Gen. Chen Ching-chon, chief of the mission, said Sunday.
Chen further said that there is no discord within the mission.

Reports quoting Legislator Sandy Yen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said some of Chen's subordinates disagreed with the way he was managing the mission and therefore reported the matter to relevant authorities.

The reports also said that divisions exist within the defense mission between pro-DPP and pro-Kuomintang (KMT) factions due to the nonstop fighting between the ruling and main opposition parties over the arms procurement bill.

Chen said he was appalled to hear about the reports, claiming the defense mission has always striven to serve the country. He added that such divisions do not exist and that the mission simply carries out the orders issued to it by the government.
He added that there is nothing unusual about the fact that he has been transferred back to Taiwan, because his term has ended.

Chen also said that he has not yet received any orders regarding Navy Rear Adm. Tan Chi-lung assuming the post of chief of the defense mission and Air Force Col. Hsu Wei-kuang, who is slated to be promoted to major general this week, assuming the newly-added post of deputy chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dayeh University wins national solar model car race

TEXT.P: Dayeh University in the central county of Changhua won the championship and the best technology award in a national solar model car race that concluded Sunday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, a university spokesman said Monday.
The race event, now in its second year, was organized by the Ministry of Education and attracted 41 teams from 21 local universities and colleges, the spokesman noted.

In each race in the event, two solar model cars competed on a 80-meter, 8-shaped track, the spokesman said, adding that each car was required to carry a raw egg, with the penalty for breaking the egg being disqualification.
Twenty teams were able to enter the second round of the event, the spokesman continued.
During the championship race, the model car designed by Dayeh University outpaced its rival designed by Kao Yuan University in the southern county of Kaohsiung by 14 seconds, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ocean-going fishing boats urged to pay heed to shark catch norms

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deep sea fishing boats were urged Monday to gain a better understanding of the international norms on the catching of sharks on the high seas.

Officials from the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture called for operators of ocean-going fishing boats to keep in mind international regulations governing the catching of sharks before heading to open fishing grounds or other countries' territorial waters based on cooperative contracts.

Tsai Tien-hsiang, a Fisheries Agency department head in charge of deep sea fishery, said that although shark fishing is not banned worldwide, the international community has become increasingly aware of a sharp decline in shark populations and many nations have either developed shark conservation plans or have actually passed laws providing greater protection for the fish.

The United Nations estimates that more than 100 million sharks are killed each year -- whether as a target of commercial shark fisheries or as bycatch from other fisheries, and studies show that shark populations have declined by 90 percent around the world in the last 50 years.

Sharks are regularly killed for their fins to make the Asian delicacy known as shark fin soup. In a gruesome and wasteful practice known as shark finning, a shark is captured, its fins sliced off -- often while its still alive -- and the animal then tossed back into the sea, dead or dying. The rest of the body is not worth nearly as much as the fin, and having to take the whole shark to shore uses up a lot of space on the boat, especially with larger sharks.
Many countries have taken the problem of shark finning and other forms of shark hunting seriously and some countries have even banned shark fishing altogether, Tsai said.

Various countries, including Australia, the United States, Brazil, Canada and the European Union have banned the inhumane practice of shark finning and require that anyone bringing a shark fin to shore must also have the rest of the carcass.

Regional fishery organizations, including the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) , the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) , the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (IOTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) , have also adopted an international ban on shark finning.
Tsai called for Taiwan's deep sea fishing boat operators to observe this finning ban.

Since sharks form some 10 percent-20 percent of bycatch from other deep sea fisheries, deep sea fishing boats should report to the authorities of the ports they visit about the amount of sharks they are carrying and present relevant documentation, Tsai noted.

He added that shark fishing norms vary from country to country. For example, he said, Palau bans shark fishing altogether and prohibits fishing boats carrying sharks or shark fins from calling at its ports or entering its territorial waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 3,600 legislative elections vote-buying cases handled

TEXT.P: Prosecutorial authorities have handled 3,597 vote-buying cases involving a total of 5,948 defendants during the run-up to the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections, Vice Justice Minister Chu Nan said Monday.

The tallies, which cover data available as of Dec. 14, show that the Taichung Prosecutors Office has handled the largest number of cases at 779, while the Tainan Prosecutors Office and the Yunlin Prosecutors Office have handled the second and third-largest number of cases at 351 and 314, respectively, Chu told the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary Committee.
On cases related to the March 22, 2008 presidential election, prosecutorial authorities nationwide have handled 59 cases involving a total of 104 defendants, Chu said.

In light of the novelty and complexity of the vote-buying methods employed, Chu noted, law-enforcement authorities have deployed 4,162 informants to facilitate investigation of vote-buying cases related to the legislative elections as of Dec. 7.
Meanwhile, another 1,247 informants have been deployed for cases related to the presidential election, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened low and ended at the day's lowest Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 287.23 points, or 3.53 percent, to close at 7,830.85.
The bourse opened at 8,041.6 and fluctuated between 8092.96 and 7,830.85 during trading. A total of 4.23 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.81 billion (US$3.58 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper an pulp shares moving down the most at 6.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 6.4 percent, textile shares at 4.0 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 3.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.0 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.9 percent, and cement shares at 2.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 197, with 289 stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to visit Tokyo next February

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Monday that he will visit Tokyo next February to attend a marathon at the invitation of his Tokyo counterpart, Shintaro Ishihara.

Hau revealed the plan during a meeting at City Hall with Tokyo Metropolitan Councilor Takashi Kabayama, who has been in Taiwan since Saturday at the head of a nearly 200-member delegation of a Japan-Taiwan friendship and culture promotion association.
On Sunday the Japanese group took part in the 2007 ING Taipei International Marathon, which drew tens of thousands of local and foreign runners.

At the meeting with Hau, Kabayama said their participation in the Taipei marathon was in preparation for the upcoming Tokyo International Marathon slated for Feb. 14. He invited Hau to take part in the annual race and to visit Tokyo for city exchanges.
In response, Hau said he will make the trip but will not compete as he is not a runner.
The two politicians also discussed Tokyo's bid for the right to host the 2016 Olympic Games, with Takashi expressing hope for the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee's support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity calls for respect for new immigrants' languages

TEXT.P: A local charitable organization in Kaohsiung City called Sunday for the Taiwan public to respect new immigrants' languages, a spokesman for the charity said Monday.
The Shepherd Life Association made the appeal at a Christmas party held by the association in the southern port city for the country's immigrant families.
The association encouraged new immigrant mothers from China and Vietnam to teach their children and husbands how to speak their mother tongues, the spokesman noted.
The party was held as part of the association's efforts to enhance local people's understanding of different cultures, the spokesman continued.
In addition to dances, songs and a magic show, the party featured speeches delivered by new immigrant mothers and their husbands in Vietnamese and Chinese, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restaurant industry popular among career changers: survey

TEXT.P: The leisure, tourism and restaurant industries are the favorite choices among workers seeking a career change after the upcoming Chinese New Year, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey, carried out in October by an employment service Web site run by the Council of Labor Affairs' Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, shows that 29.7 percent of the potential career changers intend to enter the leisure, tourism or restaurant industries.
The second-most popular choice are schools or government agencies, which are favored by 27.7 percent of potential career changers.
While the hi-tech industry is preferred by 10.1 percent of the respondents, 9.7 percent hope to enter the finance and securities industries.
Ko Chin-chang, operations director of the Web site, attributed the popularity of the restaurant industry to the high profit margin and low entry threshold of the industry.
The high pay and flexible work hours of the tourism industry are making jobs such as tour guides very attractive to potential career changers, he added.

Noting that the Web site provides information on 71 occupations in 15 trades, Ko advised workers to do comprehensive research on the companies or industries they plan to enter before actually making the move to change their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's air route plan to affect cross-strait stability: official

TEXT.P: China's plan to inaugurate a new flight route 4.2 nautical miles west of the median of the Taiwan Strait next January could affect cross-strait stability, National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Shi Hwei-yow said Monday.
China's act "should not be seen as an isolated case, as it would involve a change of the status quo in the strait," Shi said.
The action will affect Taiwan's flight safety and will squeeze the maneuvering space of Taiwan's miliary planes in drills and training, he said.
Beijing could also use the designation of the new route to step up monitoring of Taiwan, he said in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.
He noted that if the flight routes of the two sides of the Taiwan are too close to each other, the overlapping routes could undermine flight safety.

He said the bureau has convened a coordination meeting and has conveyed the views to China via the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) . The CAA also conveyed the concerns to the International Civil Aviation Organization.
"We must react strongly to safeguard security," Shi said.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao demanded that the NSB contact China over the matter, to which Shi responded that China refuses to talk to the Taiwanese authorities, including him.

Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-you said the median of the Taiwan Strait helps restrain both sides, but added that China has in the past deviated toward or even crossed the median during inclement weather conditions.

China's new route will be very close to Taiwan, but the ministry will have a standard procedure to deal with the situation, he said, adding that the air force will respond based on the judgment of whether China's planes have bad intentions.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Half Italy covered by snow, better nor to travel.
A snow storm hit central and southern Italy, particularly on the Adriatic coastal area, where many highways were blocked and townships were isolated. The civil protection authorities suggested people stay at home and not to travel unless it is necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGI came to rid Basra of its enemies, I now hand it back to its friends
With the stroke of a pen, Britain yesterday signed away the last of four Iraqi provinces that it has struggled to secure since 2003, heralding a new era for the people of Basra and largely ending the British militaryscombat role in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG U.S. to keep most troops in Baghdad.
In a change of plans, American commanders in Iraq have decided to keep their forces concentrated in Baghdad when the buildup strategy ends next year, removing troops instead from outlying areas of the country. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Belarus Will Pay 19% More for Gas
Belarus will pay 19 percent more for Russian gas beginning next year, Gazprom said Saturday, a day after President Vladimir Putin announced $1.5 billion in loans to help its economy adjust to rising prices. [by Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: Orchid biotech park, university forge cooperative ties

TEXT.P: The National University of Kaohsiung (NUK) forged cooperative ties Monday with the Taiwan Orchid Plantation, an orchid biotech park located in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, in an effort to breed high-quality orchid seedlings and boost the competitiveness of Taiwanese orchids on the international market.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-jhih and NUK President Huang Ying-chung presided over a ceremony to mark the signing of the agreement, under which a greenhouse will be built for the use of academia-industry cooperative research projects.
The NUK will also install a laboratory in the park to engage in virus tests on orchids in a drive to breed healthy and high quality seedlings, according to the agreement.

The cooperation is part of the government's national high-tech development program in agricultural biotechnology being carried out by NUK, National Tsinghua University, National Cheng Kung University, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology and the Taichung-based National Museum of Natural Science.
The plantation, located in Hobi township and inaugurated at the end of 2004, covered 23 hectares in the first stage of its five-stage construction plan, and is now at the third stage.
When all five stages of the plan are completed, the total area of the plantation will cover some 170 hectares.

The Tainan county government welcomes orchid breeders, growers and traders, as well as international marketing companies of floral products and related businesses, to set up offices in the plantation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ING marathon men's winner to buy farm with prize money

TEXT.P: Kenyan runner Hillary Bett, who won the men's contest in the 2007 ING Taipei International Marathon Sunday, said Monday he will use his prize money to buy a farm.
Bett completed the 42.195-km race in 2:17:09, beating Tanzania's Disdery Hombo and his countryman, Elijah Chemwolo, who came second and third with times of 2:17:35 and 2:18:03, respectively.
The winner won NT$666,666 (US$20,000) , which will allow him to buy over 1,200 square meters of land in Nairobi, Kenya's capital.
"I will use part of the money to continue my training in running, and part of it to buy farmland" Bett said.

The 27-year-old farmer was an excellent amateur marathoner who started intensive training last year, decided to turn professional in April this year, and has since won awards in two marathons in Italy.
The ING Taipei International Marathon brought Bett his first championship.

Bett did not break the event's record of 2: 11: 05 set by another Kenyan marathoner, Luke Kibet, and missed the chance of winning NT$1 million for breaking the record. However, he expressed hope that he will break the record next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 310 points to close at 7,748, with 70,678 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 320 points, finishing at 7,742, with 14,497 contracts traded, while March futures lost 310 points to close at 7,800, with 52 contract transactions. June futures moved down 172 points to close at 7,848, with five contracts traded, while September futures decreased 330 points to finish at 7,554, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,058 for December, 8,062 for January, 8,110 for March, 8,020 for June and 7,884 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

December TE futures lost 13.35 points to close at 313.85, with 3,850 contracts traded, while January TE futures moved down 13.85 points to finish at 312.8, with 1,553 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures dropped 38.4 points to close at 894.2, with 2,595 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 40 points to finish at 892.8, with 1,312 contracts traded. March TF futures lost 42 points to close at 897, with five contracts traded, while June TF futures decreased 30.8 points to finish at 908.8, with two contract transactions. September TF futures dropped 38.6 points to close at 900, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.105 to close at NT$32.481.
A total of US$968 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.376 and hit a high of NT$32.498.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's planned air route will pose danger to Taiwanese flights

TEXT.P: China's planned air route through the Taiwan Strait is likely to overlap existing ones between Taiwan and its outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, posing a danger to Taiwanese air traffic safety, a Taiwanese aviation official said Monday.
The remarks came one day after Vice President Annette Lu disclosed China's plan to add an air route close to the median of the strait that separates the airspace between Taiwan and China.
Billy Chang, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), confirmed that Beijing has notified the CAA via Hong Kong aviation officials regarding its new plan.
In addition, China hopes that Hong Kong aviation authorities will represent the Chinese government in negotiations with the CAA over the new air route, Chang said.
The CAA has reported the case to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) as it involves complex political issues, Chang went on.
At present, Chang said, the specific details of China's new route is not yet clear and the CAA is trying to obtain relevant information about the route through available channels.

China's growing economy has resulted in increasing need for flights, Chang noted, adding that the planned route is aimed at addressing the increasingly busy routes between Hong Kong and Shanghai, which Chang said will pose a threat to Taiwanese planes.

Taiwan's current air routes were planned prior to the loss of its United Nations seat to the People's Republic of China in 1971, Chang said, noting that the median of the strait has been tacitly accepted by both Taipei and Beijing for decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mercury detected in skin cream bought online

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Taipei city government cautioned consumers Monday that the Essence brand of "Special Effect Skin Cream" sold online and in a garment store in Taipei contains mercury that could be hazardous to the health.

Chiang Yu-mei, director of the Food and Drug Division of the city government's Department of Health, said the product, marketed as a skin whitening cream, carries only a date of manufacture and provides no information about its manufacturer, ingredients or weight.

The yellow cream might be useful for removing facial blemishes in the initial stage, Chiang said, adding that using the cream for a long period could lead to mercury poisoning, causing damage to the kidneys and the central nervous system.
Taipei health officials began an investigation after several consumers complained that their skin peeled off or became swollen after using the cream.

The officials traced the origin of the products, sold in the kijiji online shopping mall, to a garment and accessories store in the Wanhua district, and suspected that the skin cream might have been brought in from abroad by Taiwanese tourists.
The officials asked the Taipei City Police Bureau to take over the investigation.
Under the Cosmetics Sanitary Control Act, an offender can be subject to a maximum sentence of one year in prison, plus a fine of up to NT$150,000 (US$4,605).

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition legislator rebuts bribery accusation

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chiang rebutted Monday an accusation that he has committed election bribery, claiming that chocolate coins he gave away to potential voters are worth only NT$ 9 each.
Chiang, who is seeking re-election in Taipei, made the remarks after his election rival, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Julian Kuo, made the accusation.
Kuo claimed at a Legislative Yuan Judiciary Committee meeting that the chocolates given out by Chiang are worth NT$ 40 each, which exceeds the NT$30 limit.

In response, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin, who was invited to deliver a report and answer questions about its investigation of election bribery, said he will look into the matter, which was already being investigated by the Taipei Prosecutors Office. Chiang, meanwhile, provided the sales order for his chocolate to prove their cost.
Kuo later claimed to reporters that the tens of thousands of the chocolates handed out by Chiang are the same as those sold in the Starbucks coffee chain at a retail price of NT$40 each.

The Ministry of Justice investigates bribery cases based on the market price rather than wholesale price of gifts, Kuo said, adding that one Taipei city councilor had his election annulled for giving out T-shirts, although he claimed that they were cheap. The point is not how much the gift costs but how much voters think it is worth, Kuo said.

Market price may vary depending on where one buys it, Chiang said, pointing out that the same product might be sold at different prices in convenience stores, Starbucks or department stores. "Kuo should not make this kind of slanderous accusation," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to pay heed to greenhouse gas emissions

TEXT.P: Several environmental groups urged the government Monday to pay heed to Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions, as its high emissions rate has caused concern in the world community.

At a press conference organized by the Taiwan Environmental Action Network (TEAN) and the Green Party Taiwan, Cheng I-ching, a TEAN director, noted that at the just-concluded U.N. Climate Conference held on the Indonesian island of Bali, many newly industrialized countries such as Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan were listed as the next group of countries to be required to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions.
Taiwan's high average per capita greenhouse gas emissions in particular surprised the participants in Bali, Cheng said.

Cheng, who participated in the Bali conference, said the conference had three major developments -- the long-term goal of cutting greenhouse gas emissions for developed countries is gradually being adopted; the 25 top air polluters in the world, including Taiwan, were told to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; and some underdeveloped countries such as Brazil and South Africa are voluntarily setting long-term reduction goals.

Citing statistics released at the conference, Cheng said Taiwan's average greenhouse gas emission per capita rate tops the Asian list, adding that the participating countries said they will not allow Taiwan to become a "loophole" in the network designed to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.

According to Cheng, the representatives and environmental groups of various countries suggested that Taiwan adopt similar policies and measures to other countries to control greenhouse gas emissions so that it does not encounter a boycott facing the United States.

The U.S., one of the top emitters of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping emissions, refused to sign the Kyoto Protocol and said it is not yet ready to commit to mandatory caps on greenhouse gases, causing strong criticism from the rest of the world.

Lin Tze-lun, an assistant professor at National Taiwan University, said that although the U.S. has rejected any specific emission reduction measures, it recognizes the policies and suggestions made by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
In addition, the conference has decided to set up a fund to help developing countries establish an adjustment mechanism to manage climate-change.
Lin added that it is worrisome that in Taiwan, only the Environmental Protection Administration pays any attention to the issue, while other administrative branches simply ignore the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civil servants would not violate law by wiretapping: official

TEXT.P: A security official claimed Monday that civil servants would not dare to violate the law by engaging in illicit wiretapping.

National Security Bureau Director Shi Hwei-yow made the remarks after the main opposition Kuomintang asked if the government had used bugs in the wake of the leaking of the contents of a recent closed-door meeting in Taipei between KMT vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew and Raymond Burghardt, American Institute in Taiwan chairman.
According to media reports, Siew's office in a cross-strait peace foundation initiated by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan was also suspected of being bugged.
Former Vice Legislative Yuan Speaker P.K. Chiang's office and KMT Legislator Su Chi's office in the legislature were also suspected of having been bugged, the reports said.

Shi noted that according to the law regarding communication protection, violators will be subject to up to five years in prison. No civil servants would dare to break the law under such condition, he claimed.
He also expressed regret that legislation on wiretapping has been in practice for years, but the public still have misgivings.
He said he has repeatedly asked for administrative neutrality and expressed hope that "some political figures" will show restraint lest they incite crimes.
Investigation Bureau head Yeh Sheng-mao also said that wiretapping of individuals is carried out based on the law and claimed that the bureau "will not wiretap any political parties."
He reiterated that the bureau mainly targets cases under criminal investigation. If there is substantive evidence, the bureau will request permission from prosecutors to set up wiretaps.
Asked if the Investigation Bureau will investigate the leaking of the Siew- Burghardt meeting, Yeh said the matter does not fall under the bureau's responsibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSBC expects to turn profits with Chinese Bank takeover next year

TEXT.P: HSBC Holdings PLC, Europe's biggest bank in terms of market value, has agreed to buy the Taipei-based Chinese Bank, which has been under government charge since January following a financial fallout involving the bankrupt Rebar Asia Pacific Group, which owns Chinese Bank.
HSBC Holding agreed to take control of the debt-laden Chinese Bank Friday after Taiwan's government agreed to pay it NT$47.49 billion (US$1.46 billion) based on an indemnity clause.

Alistair Currie, Taiwan CEO of the London-based banking giant, said at a news conference Monday that HSBC will complete the acquisition deal in three months, allowing the deal to begin making a profit from next year.
The acquisition, which is still pending approval by relevant governmental agencies, will increase the number of HSBC branches in Taiwan from eight to 47.
Taiwan is Asia's fourth-largest banking market.

Meanwhile, HSBC said in a statement issued Friday that it plans to inject between US$300 million and US$400 million in fresh capital into the Chinese Bank to ensure that its enlarged operations will have "appropriate" financial ratios.

According to the deal that HSBC struck with the government-owned Central Deposit Insurance Corp. -- which was assigned to take over the Chinese Bank in the wake of a bank run crisis triggered by the insolvency of two other companies under the Rebar Group in January -- HSBC must establish its Taiwan subsidiary within three years of the acquisition or within one year after the value of its assets in Taiwan exceeds US$13.9 billion. The subsidiary should have capital of no less than US$309 million.

According to the deal, HSBC will take over Chinese Bank's sound assets, including its branches, as well as its debts and at least half of the bank's employees, or some 1,000 people, while Taiwan's Financial Reconstruction Fund will pay HSBC NT$47.49 billion. HSBC currently has about 2,300 local employees.

Local financial holding groups are seen to face increasing competition from their foreign counterparts as the world's four major banking conglomerates have managed to expand their Taiwan networks through acquisitions, market researchers said.

The researchers said the acquisition of Taiwanese banks will offer foreign banks easy access to the immense financial service market for the large number of Taiwan-funded companies in China and other Asian countries to help them expand their Asian financial maps.

In addition, the analysts said, Taiwan's consumer banking and personal financial management markets are also growing steadily. With a limited number of branches, foreign banks used to have difficulty entering those emerging service fields. After buying into Taiwanese banks, foreign banks can now expand their local service networks and the returns on their investments will become even more evident in two or three years, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars urge government to continue pre-school education reform

TEXT.P: More than 100 scholars, experts and representatives of parental associations recently signed a petition urging the government not to back away from its determination to push for the overhaul of the country's pre-school educational system.

As the nation's kindergarten administration is subject to the Ministry of Education (MOE) , while the day-care system is under the supervision of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), the MOE presented a draft bill on pre-schooler education and care to the legislature in May this year for its approval to integrate the two systems.

The draft legislation also aims to guarantee the quality of pre-school teachers in order to offer the children a healthier and more congenial educational environment and reduce the financial burden on the families in the caring and education of their children.
According to the Association of Early Childhood Education Reform (AECER) , more than 40 percent of Taiwanese families feel that kindergarten tuition imposes a heavy burden on them.

Meanwhile, a pre-school educator, Ou Chi-you, noted that private kindergartens account for nearly 70 percent of Taiwan's pre-school education institutions, but the quality of these private kindergartens is uneven, she added.

To the surprise of all, the MOD decided to withdraw the bill from the legislature after a group of private kindergarten entrepreneurs took to the street early December to protest against the bill, which they believe will negatively affect their businesses.

The petitioners urged the government to continue pursuing its reform project, which, according to the MOE, will make Taiwan's pre-school education environment healthier, less profit-oriented, and friendlier to children, with several scholars calling for the legislature to pass the bill to guarantee the budget to support pre-school education.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD holds seminar on public construction planning

TEXT.P: A three-day seminar on public construction planning and evaluation organized by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) with an aim to prevent wasting of public funds opened Monday, CEPD Deputy Chairman Chang Ching-sen said.
The seminar was attended by over 400 representatives of local and central governments as well as private counselling companies, Chang said.

According to Chang, many public construction projects proceed without thorough pre-evaluation or planning for future operation and management, causing problems associated with plan alterations or insufficient budgets during construction. Some are even left idle after being completed.

To better preclude the possibility of wasting resources, the CEPD introduced concepts of cost-effectiveness evaluation and financial planning to seminar participants, most of whom are public construction project planners with local governments, Chang said.

The CEPD is responsible for planning and examining central government public construction projects, and has approved projects worth NT$131.5 billion (US$4.04 billion) this year, Chang said, adding that most of the budget will be used to construct expressways, rail transportation, agriculture, and flood control systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to work to collect debts from fugitive tycoon: FSC

TEXT.P: The government will work to collect debts owed by a fugitive tycoon after tracking down what could be some of his overseas assets, a spokeswoman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Monday.

FSC Vice Chairwoman Susan Chang was referring to Wang You-theng, founder and owner of the Rebar Group who is now taking refuge in the United States with his wife. Wang was found to have embezzled billions of dollars out of 70-odd subsidiaries owned by the financially distressed Rebar Asia-Pacific Group.
Chang noted that the FSC has since May embarked on efforts to collect debts of several prominent fugitive tycoons via the Bankers Association of the Republic of China and financial institutions.
The top priority targets are Wang, Tuntex Group founder Chen You-hao, and Guang San Group Chairman Tseng Cheng-jen.
Chang said that about one month ago, they tracked down what could be more than US$90 million of Wang's assets in Europe, and creditor banks are now working to collect debts via various channels.
Chang would not divulge further details.

Wang was exposed after the application for insolvency protection by China Rebar and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co., -- two Rebar group subsidiaries -- caused a panicked run on the Chinese Bank -- yet another Rebar subsidiary -- in early January. The bank's customers withdrew more than NT$33 billion (US$1 billion) from the bank, prompting a government takeover to allay public fears.

The two companies became insolvent after suffering losses totaling NT$25.2 billion over the past seven years. However, according to initial estimates, total losses to the national coffers and investors caused by the Wang family's systematic hollowing out of the Rebar Group-owned subsidiaries could amount to NT$300 billion -- about one-fourth of Taiwan's annual tax revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture authorities promise to address cabbage price slump

TEXT.P: Agriculture authorities promised Monday to propose a strategy within three days to curb a continuing drop in cabbage prices.

Secretary-general Hsu Han-chin of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture (COA) voiced the promise in a meeting with over 30 emotional farmers from Changhua County, central Taiwan, at the COA building.
The cabbage growers, led by Legislator Chen Chao-jung of the opposition Kuomintang, petitioned for the COA for relief after cabbage prices slumped in recent days.
Chen indicated that the price for 30 kg of cabbage has dropped to between NT$300 and NT$500 from NT$1,100-NT$1,300 over a week ago in the county's Hsihu fruit and vegetable wholesale market.

The farmers have failed to earn any profit from their harvest, Chen pointed out, blaming the price fall for a news report from Taichung City last week that said a duck died suddenly after being fed cabbage leaves.
The problematic cabbage reportedly came from the Hsihu market.

In a news release last Friday, the COA said tests on samples from the unfortunate duck have begun, noted it is a single case, and urged consumers to refrain from speculating on the cause of the duck's death before the test results are in.

The news release reiterated that the council employs strict measures in screening pesticide residues on agricultural products in local markets. Over 97 percent of 2,191 samples examined from farm fields and wholesale markets around the country during the first 11 months of the year passed the residue tests, COA said.
Hsu said that since the report of the duck's mysterious death, cabbage wholesale prices have not fluctuated as usual.

Hsu explained that the agency has been closely monitoring cabbage price fluctuations since the wholesale price experienced a rise from NT$15 per kg in July to NT$36.7 per kg in October due to the effects of typhoon damage, before dropping to the current level of NT$19.5 per kg.
It is expected that prices will drop further, to NT$8 per kg, by the end of December due to an abundant harvest, the official said.

Hsu said the COA has activated the 95 percent price adjustment mechanism and is set to purchase vegetables in abundance directly from growers for 95 percent of their production cost in an effort to safeguard the farmers' basic economic security.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has estimated 13 million Internet users: study

TEXT.P: Taiwan has an estimated over 13 million Internet users this year, an all-time high, according to the results of a recent government study to be published Tuesday.

The annual study was conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) among 15,007 people aged over 12 via telephone interviews in August and September, an official said Monday.
The RDEC began to conduct the study in 2001 in an effort to understand the digital gap in Taiwan, the RDEC official said.
The study shows that nearly half of the Internet users polled had made online purchases, up 5 percent from last year, the official noted.
Describing blogging as popular among Internet users, the official said 74 percent of the people interviewed browse other people's blogs.
The official further said that 25.4 percent of the Internet users surveyed had created their own blogs.
In addition, 76.4 percent of the respondents use online communication software, the study shows.
According to the study, the Internet penetration rate this year amounts to 65.6 percent, up from last year's 64.4 percent, the official went on.

The study also shows that the government's efforts to bridge the digital divide among local cities and countries have achieved results, the official said, adding that the Internet penetration rate in the southern county of Yunlin and the eastern county of Taitung grew by 4 percent.
The middle-aged and elderly population also saw an Internet use increase of nearly 100,000 people, the study indicates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese good-will mission donates cherry trees to Kinmen

TEXT.P: A good-will mission from Japan donated 100 cherry seedlings to the National Kinmen Institute of Technology Monday in a gesture to alleviate the trauma inflicted by the Japanese military during the Second World War.
The 28-member group, comprised of alumni of Chuo University in Tokyo, was led by Nagata Shigeru, chairman of a pro-Taiwan friendship association.

In a ceremony at the campus of National Kinmen Institute of Technology (NKIT), Shigeru and NKIT President Lee Chin-cheng planted 10 cherries around a pond and erected a stone monument inscribed with the Chinese characters: "Friendly cherries."

The donation was initiated by Chuo University alumni after they learned from Lee during his visit to Japan in June that many residents of Kinmen were drafted to serve the Japanese troops during the war years and never returned home.
The Chuo alumni expressed the hope that the "friendly cherries" would obliterate the trauma of the past and rebuild friendship between Japan and the outlying island group.

The 10 cherry seedlings planted at the ceremony Monday were from a donation three years ago, because the 100 newly presented seedlings have to undergo a one-year quarantine period in the Yangmingshan National Park in suburban Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 New Year firework show to last 188 seconds

TEXT.P: This year's New Year firework show at the top of Taipei 101, one of the tallest skyscrapers in the world, will last for 188 seconds, a spokesman for the Taipei Financial Center Corp., which manages the building, said Monday.
However, Horace Lin, president of the company, declined to reveal the wording that will appear in the firework show, saying only that it will be neutral.
The announcement came following a recent row between the central government and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT)-controlled Taipei city government over the wording.

The Tourism Bureau under the Cabinet-level Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) had planned to display the government slogan "U.N. for Taiwan" in the fireworks show in an effort to raise the international profile of the country's U.N. membership bid.
However, the bureau's plan drew protests from the Taipei city government.
Lin said that the wording, which will include Taiwan, will be acceptable to both sides.
According to Lin, Taipei 101 will set off 12,000 fireworks this year -- 3,000 more than last year.
Fireworks will also be set off over the skyscraper for the first time, Lin said, adding that traffic controls in the area will be expanded this year.
A concert to be held in the square in front of City Hall on New Year's Eve is likely to break the 520,000 visits registered at last year's event, Lin went on.

Speaking on the same occasion, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin encouraged the public to attend the concert and urged them to attend a flag-raising ceremony and fun run to be organized by the city government on New Year's Day.
Meanwhile, Hau said the city government mobilized nearly 400 people last year to clean up the 21 metric tons of garbage left behind by thoughtless litterlouts after the event.
To address the problem, the city government will provide garbage cans this year, Hau said, urging people not to litter.
One day prior to the new year's eve concert, the city government will hold a carnival featuring dance, military bands, and a flower float parade, according to Hau.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate promises casinos for Penghu

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Monday that if elected president, he will make the offshore county of Penghu a special tourism area and allow the opening of casinos on the island.

Ma made the comments while answering questions from lawmaker Lin Pin-kun and local residents during a ceremony marking the establishment of his presidential campaign headquarters on the outlying island.

Ma gave assurances to Lin that he will fully support the opening of casinos on Penghu as long as comprehensive accompanying measures are put in place with a condition that a reasonable portion of the industry's earnings must be used for nationwide social welfare programs.
Lin, elected from Penghu, has been keen on promoting the gambling industry on his home turf.

In addition, Ma stressed that he will designate Makung Airport on Penghu as one of Taiwan's seven hubs plying direct flights across the Taiwan Strait as part of his efforts to help boost tourism on Penghu.
According to Ma, he has asked the KMT's legislative caucus to endorse an amendment Lin called for to permit the opening of casinos on Penghu during Thursday's legislative meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hard to alter polls dates: CEC official

TEXT.P: Responding to a demand that two national elections slated for early next year should not include referendums, Central Election Commission (CEC) Secretary- General Teng Tien-you said Monday that it would be very difficult to change the polling dates, which have been officially promulgated.

Although doing so might help settle a voting method dispute between the central and some local governments, Teng said it would now be "almost impossible" to ask CEC members to hold a meeting and alter the polling dates.

Teng made the comments in response to a call from a group of main oppostion Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers, including Hung Hsiu-chu, Chiu Yi, Pan Wei-kang and Wu Yu-sheng, earlier that day at a Legislative Yuan news conference.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, also issued a written statement endorsing the KMT legislators' call for "peaceful elections."

Wang and the KMT lawmakers contended that the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election should not be held at the same time as the referendums, to avoid what they claimed would be "procedural woes."

According to Wang, in his 32-year political career, this is the first time he has sensed "strong public worries" about whether the elections will be held on time and smoothly. Speculation that the government might put off the elections or impose martial law has sparked grave public concern at home and abroad, he claimed.

Wang ascribed the uncertainties to the CEC's decision to combine the legislative elections with two referendums and the presidential election with another two referendums, and argued that the chaos would disappear if the elections were not held along with the referendums.
For her part, Hung said she "strongly feels" the public is deeply concerned about whether the polls, in particular the March 22 presidential election, will proceed smoothly.

Liu Kuang-hua, a CEC member recommended by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), told CNA that a Dec. 12 CEC meeting failed to hold vote on a proposal that he submitted calling for a postponement of the referendums to be held alongside the legislative polls.

Liu said he was pleased to see Wang and KMT lawmakers share his standpoint and said that only separating the polls would resolve the voting format dispute. He also called for public support for his proposal.

Although the CEC decided Nov. 16 to adopt a "one-step" voting format for the approaching polls, 18 local governments controlled by the KMT have insisted on applying a "two-step" scheme out of concern over "possible woes" arising from the "one-step" voting method.

Taking the legislative elections as example, under the "one-step" voting format, voters will receive two legislative ballots and two referendum ballots from two different desks before casting each of the ballots into four separate boxes.

Under the "two-step" voting method, voters would receive two legislative ballots and cast them into two different boxes in the first stage before proceeding to the second step, in which voters would receive two referendum ballots and cast them into two different boxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Korean university delegation visits local senior high in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: A delegation comprised of professors of the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) from South Korea visited Kaohsiung Municipal Sanmin Senior High School in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan Monday for academic exchanges.

Led by Im Yong-taek, a professor at KAIST's Department of Mechanical Engineering, the delegation listened to a brief introduction of the high school's history and operations, and also viewed many of the school's facilities, including the library, a Sanmin school spokesman said.

Im introduced the KAIST to students at the high school, saying that the KAIST is a top-rank university in South Korea that provides students with a wide range of diverse courses from an international perspective.

The KAIST has enrolled many international students to cultivate local students' international perspectives and to enhance international exchanges in culture, Im said, adding that the exchange with the high school provides a great opportunity for KAIST to better understand Taiwan's high school education system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Details of contingency draft due by legislative polls: CEC

TEXT.P: A five-member task force of the Central Election Commission (CEC) will soon hold a meeting to craft a contingency draft on the "unavoidable or irresistible situations" that could lead to a halt or postponement of two key elections slated for early next year, CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said Monday.

Teng made the comments while fielding questions from main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Hsieh Kuo-liang and Pan Wei-kang and People First Party (PFP) lawmaker Lee Fu-dien during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

The lawmakers of the two parties in the opposition "pan-blue alliance" asked the CEC to submit as soon as possible the draft to the Legislative Yuan clearly defining all sorts of "unavoidable and irresistible situations ahead of and on the polling days" that it claims could stop or put off elections, as the legislative and presidential elections, slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively, approach.

A media report last week about a CEC plan to iron out a contingency plan which would permit the body to scrap or delay elections in case of "unavoidable or irresistible situations" has sparked strong attacks from the "pan-blue alliance" charging the Democratic Progressive Party administration with seeking to use the CEC as a tool to pursue that aim.
According to Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey, legislative elections to be conducted by local governments in a "two-step" voting method will be suspended or put off.

In defiance of the central government's decision that the CEC-designed "one- step" method will be used for both the legislative and presidential elections, 18 KMT-controlled local governments are insisting on applying the "two-step" voting format, with neither side showing any sign of compromise over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Bush Faces Pressure to Shift War Priorities
With violence on the decline in Iraq but on the upswing in Afghanistan, President Bush is facing new pressure from the U.S. military to accelerate a troop drawdown in Iraq and bulk up force levels in Afghanistan, according to senior U.S. officials.
The Washington Times:Violence quelled, Baghdad on spot
President Bush's troop surge will end this month, and although the White House is pressing the Iraqi government to capitalize on the U.S. military's success, it is declining to set hard deadlines for Iraqi lawmakers to pass critical legislation.

The Japan Times: U.S. voices reservations on Bali deal
A hard-sought deal fixing a 2009 deadline for a new treaty to tackle global warming ran straight into trouble Sunday with the United States voicing concerns.
