DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Candidates Scrambling to Cope With Rise of Huckabee
Just one month ago, Mitt Romney's supporters thought that they had Iowa fairly well in hand. But there was Mr. Romney last week, telling several hundred people at a high school cafeteria in Marion that he was the underdog and pleading for their help to keep him from being derailed at the caucuses by the rise of Mike Huckabee.
The Wall Street Journal:Ingersoll-Rand to Acquire Trane
Ingersoll-Rand Co. has agreed to acquire Trane Inc. in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $10.2 billion that would create one of the world's largest makers of air conditioners and other climate-control systems, people familiar with the matter said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's envoy to HK to assume post soon after finally getting visa

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, Yang Chia-chun, will assume his new post in the coming days after finally getting a work visa from the Hong Kong government, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) sources said Monday.

Yang, who originally headed the MAC's Department of Legal Affairs, will replace Pao Cheng-kang as managing director of Chung Hwa Travel Service, the formal title of Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong, the MAC sources said. Pao's service as Taiwan's top representative in Hong Kong ended early this month.

The MAC, a Cabinet-level agency in charge of Taiwan's China policy planning, appointed Yang as Pao's replacement in July, but the Hong Kong government didn't issue a work visa for Yang until very recently, according to MAC sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan Forest Railway to reopen Dec. 21

TEXT.P: The Alishan forest railway is expected to reopen to passenger services Dec. 21 after four months of repair work to remove massive amounts of fallen rocks from successive landslides during the typhoon season, local forestry officials said Monday.

Officials at the Chiayi office of the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said the No. 42 Tunnel of the railway, located 59 kilometers from Chiayi Station, was blocked by a landslide due to torrential rain in July, and that although the railway was reopened briefly after a month- long repair blitz, the line was again disrupted because of four typhoons and tropical storms.
The repair work was made more difficult by a magnitude six earthquake on July 23 in northern Taiwan, and another magnitude five tremor in southern Taiwan on July 29, the officials said.

They pointed out that the end of the No. 42 Tunnel is now shielded by a protective wall, which will guide any falling rocks away from the railway. The Alishan railway is said to be one of the world's three remaining alpine railways. The other two are located in the Himalayas of northern India, and Andes of South America.

Opened in 1912 while Taiwan was under Japanese rule, the narrow-gauge railway was designed to haul timber down the mountain, but is now mainly used to transport the more than 200,000 tourists who annually visit Alishan to take in the area's beauty at an altitude of more than 2,200 meters in Taiwan's Central Mountain Range.

The scenic rail line winds its way up from the subtropical plains to mountainous pine forests in just 72 kilometers, crossing more than 80 bridges and passing through about 50 tunnels. Its route includes a series of dangerous switchbacks.

Although the government has been operating the train at an annual loss of about NT$110 million (US$3.35 million) , it has decided to preserve the line not only for its historic value but as a means to boost local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lashes out at KMT for failing to match words with deeds

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lashed out at the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday for failing to match its words with deeds.

The president noted that the KMT has made "a better economy and the well-being of the public" the theme of its campaign for the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, but he pointed out that the KMT has consistently blocked the budgets for national development and public welfare bills at the legislature.
The KMT even stalled the review of the 2007 central government's budget for six months, he added.

He stated that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (KMT) aims at grabbing 50 seats in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, saying that based on the 40 percent of votes received by the DPP in the past two legislative elections, this will translate to 45 seats in the upcoming elections, which will see the adoption of a new "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system and the number of seats cut by half to 113.

More efforts will result in an additional five seats, and the DPP could easily emerge as the dominant force in the legislature. This, coupled with DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's winning the March 22 presidential election, will help stabilize the political situation, the president said optimistically.

He also said that KMT's resistance to the Central Election Commission's decision to adopt a "one-step" voting format for the upcoming elections aims at blocking the two DPP-initiated referendums from being held alongside the elections.

The president said that the KMT is trying to block a referendum to return the KMT's ill-gotten assets to national coffer alongside the legislative elections, and a bid to join the U.N. under the name Taiwan in tandem with the presidential election.
The president also said that the KMT will never change its ideology, which he claims amounts to "one China, " and "eventual unification with China."
In contrast, the DPP insists on "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait," the president said.

He said that if China's agricultural products inundate Taiwan and Chinese laborers come in droves to Taiwan, the situation of Taiwanese farmers and the employment rights of the Taiwanese people will be affected.
He concluded that if Taiwan is eventually swallowed up by China or Taiwan can only rely on Chinese market, then it will "indeed be a serious situation."

DOC.HEADLINE: China's sand and gravel could come anytime: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday that Taiwan has not banned China's sand and gravel from coming to Taiwan, and that China can resume exports at any time.

MOEA officials made the remarks after China's Ministry of Commerce said earlier the same day that it has started preparations for the resumption of sand and gravel exports to Taiwan, expressing the hope that Taiwan's gravel association would communicate with China to facilitate the exports.

The officials said that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is in charge the cross-strait issues and that the MAC has commissioned the semi- official Taiwan External Trade Development Council to conduct talks with China on the issue.

Any groups that have not been authorized by the government to conduct such talks will be in violation of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, the officials said.
As Taiwan has not banned China's gravel, as long as China is willing to resume exports, the gravel could come at any time.
"This is purely business deal, " they said, and Taiwan welcomes developments which will help diversify the sources of such imports.

Taiwan previously relied heavily on China's gravel, but managed to meet its needs by increasing domestic dredging and seeking exports from other countries after China unilaterally stopped the exports earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 election choice between Taiwan, China identities: DPP candidate
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/07 23:55:10 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's voters will make a choice in the 2008 presidential election between a "Taiwanese identity" and "Chinese identity, " the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) standard bearer in the race said in Tokyo Monday.

Frank Hsieh, who is currently on a four-day visit to Japan, made the remarks in a speech delivered to Japanese politicians, scholars and business executives interested in Taiwan's affairs as well as Taiwanese expatriates in Japan.

As Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) originated in China and has never forsaken its ultimate goal of pursuing eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Hsieh said the 2008 presidential election could be a choice between a Taiwanese and Chinese orientation.

Even though the KMT moved its seat to Taiwan 58 years ago, Hsieh said the party, which ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000, still has its Chinese title bear the word "Chungkuo" meaning "China."
Hsieh said he is convinced that if the Taiwan-rooted DPP manages to win the 2008 presidential election, the KMT will finally change it designation.

Claiming that the KMT has blocked the DPP's major policy initiatives at nearly every turn since it lost power, Hsieh said the pall of a "democratic civil war" has been shadowing Taiwan over the past seven years.
However, Hsieh said he is confident that if elected he will be able to put an end to the current political chaos.
He further said Taiwan's hope lies in a significant rise in the number of Taiwan people who identify themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese.

A decade ago, he said, only 20 percent of Taiwane people perceived themselves as Taiwanese, and the number rose to 30 percent seven years ago when the DPP just came to power, but the number now surges to 70 percent.

If China continues to block Taiwan's participation in major international organizations and squeeze out its international presence, Hsieh said he believes that Taiwan people's national identity and national consciousness will continue to strengthen.
He criticized his electoral rival, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou for failing to speak up against China's sovereignty claim over Taiwan while visiting Japan earlier this year.

Referring to Ma's statement during his earlier Tokyo visit that if elected, he will neither promote unification, independence nor provoke any conflict across the Taiwan Strait, Hsieh said it is rather strange for a presidential candidate to shun defending his own country's sovereign status during an overseas trip.
Stressing that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state, Hsieh said if Ma does not share such a stance, he should not run for Taiwan's presidency.
In his speech, Hsieh also urged the international community to push China to fulfill its international responsibilities now that its has become economically prosperous.

As to whether China's rise would pose a threat to Asian security and stability, Hsieh said Chian's attitude and policy toward Taiwan could serve as a litmus to such a test. "We could tell from its policy toward Taiwan whether China would honor its promise of pursuing a peaceful rise," Hsieh added.

The weighted price index was down 100.06 points at 7730.79 on a turnover of NT$4.74 billion (US$145.93 million) at the open. The index lost 287.23 points, or 3.53 percent, to close at 7830.85 Monday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.559 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.078 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 18, or the ninth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

Stressing that Taiwan is already an independent sovereign state, Hsieh said that if Ma does not share such a stance, he should not run for Taiwan's presidency.
In his speech, Hsieh also urged the international community to push China to fulfill its international responsibilities now that it has become economically prosperous.
As to whether China's rise will pose a threat to Asian security and stability, Hsieh said Chian's attitude and policy toward Taiwan could serve as a litmus test in this regard.
"We will be able to tell from Beijing's policy toward Taiwan whether China will honor its promise of pursuing a peaceful rise, " Hsieh added.
