DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: South Korea to probe election front-runner
South Korea's Parliament voted Monday to launch a new probe into fraud allegations against presidental opposition front-runner Lee Myung bak, two days before the country goes to the polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job-hopping common among fresh graduates: survey

TEXT.P: Many fresh graduates in Taiwan responding to a recent survey give the impression of being job-hoppers, with 48 percent having changed jobs at least once over the past five months since leaving school.
The results of the survey, which were released Monday, also revealed that 57.73 percent of the respondents are preparing to leave their current jobs after the upcoming Chinese New Year.
The survey was carried out Dec. 1-14 by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank among 2,037 workers or job-seekers who graduated from school this past summer.

The survey shows that 23.12 percent of respondents have not found a full-time job since graduation, including 26.77 percent of senior high school graduates, 25.29 percent of college graduates, 25 percent of master's or doctoral degree holders, and 22.24 percent of university graduates.
Among those who have found employment, 23.63 percent have changed jobs once over the past five months, 11.24 percent have done so twice, and 12.84 percent have done so at least three times.

On the reasons for quitting, 30.52 percent mentioned failure of the job to meet their expectations, 26.64 percent mentioned a desire to find another job with higher pay and better benefits, and 24.63 percent mentioned a lack of career advancement prospects.
While 18.71 percent of the successful job-seekers found their first job after sending out three resumes on average, 17.04 percent only found a job after sending out more than 30 resumes.
A total of 19.41 percent of the successful job-seekers found a job even before graduation, compared with 22.67 percent who only did so after searching for more than three months.

As to their financial resources before getting a full-time job, 34.95 percent relied on the support of family or friends, 31.27 percent relied on their own savings, and 14.38 percent made ends meets through part-time employment.
Compared with 51.40 percent of successful job-seekers who found a job that matches their field of study, 48.60 percent were hired for jobs unrelated to their area of expertise.

The survey revealed that the starting salaries of successful job-seekers average NT$17,960 (US$553) among junior high school graduates, NT$23,846 among senior high school graduates, NT$20,024 among senior vocational school graduates, NT$22,085 among college graduates, NT$23,200 among university graduates and NT$34,186 among master's degree holders.

The figures compare with the average expected salary of NT$19,640 among junior high school graduates, NT$24,513 among senior high school graduates, NT$21,419 among senior vocational school graduates, NT$24,990 among college graduates, NT$25,800 among university graduates and NT$36,973 among master's degree holders.

Meanwhile, the survey results showed that those who studiedin the fields of medicine or health enjoy the highest average starting salary at NT$25,733, followed by those who studied science, engineering or information technology at NT$24,683 and those who studied in the fields of law, political science, sociology or psychology at NT$23,829.
The lowest average starting salary was seen among those who studied mass communication, education or physical education at NT$22,183, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military responsible for Taiwan Strait security: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the military Tuesday to shoulder its unshirkable responsibility to protect security in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a celebration marking 20 years of service of two improved Zwaardvis-class submarines held at the Tsoying naval base in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan conveys concerns to U.S. about China's planned air route

TEXT.P: Taiwan has conveyed its deep concerns to the U.S. State Department and relevant agencies regarding China's planned flight route close to the median of the Taiwan Strait, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) acting spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Tuesday.
Speaking at the MOFA's regular news briefing, Yeh said "the U.S. authorities also find this problem to be serious and will do something about it."

"Such a plan can severely affect cross-strait stability and international flight safety, " she said, adding that other countries which would be affected by the new air route have also expressed their concerns to Chinese authorities.

It was disclosed Monday that China is planning to inaugurate a new flight route 4.2 nautical miles west of the median of the Taiwan Strait next January, and Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) have confirmed that Beijing has notified it via Hong Kong aviation officials regarding its new plan.

As to whether the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), of which Taiwan is not a member, has approved China's new air route, Yeh said the government has not received any such message but will keep working along with other countries through every possible channels on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 23.46 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 7,807.39.
The bourse opened at 7,730.79 and fluctuated between 7,913.88 and 7,664.62 during trading. A total of 5.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$143.35 billion (US$4.4 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.8 percent, textile stocks at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Only machinery and electronics shares gained ground, increasing 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 594, with 447 stocks remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP chairman urges KMT to amend Referendum Law or face boycott

TEXT.P: Lin and members of the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association (Nuke-4 RIA) distributed leaflets at the exits of an MRT station in downtown Taipei to underscore their appeal.

Lin said that although the group has written several times to KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou expressing the hope of being able to call on them to discuss the amendment of the Referendum Law, neither of them has responded to any of the letters.
He reaffirmed the main focus of the group's campaign is to "call for the KMT to amend the Referendum Law rather than to boycott the party in elections."

If the KMT amends the Referendum Law before the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election as proof that the party is sincere in answering the calls for greater democracy, the association will end the boycott immediately.

Asked why his group has only been targeting the KMT, Lin said the DPP has proposed an amendment to the Referendum Law that is largely the same as that called for by the association to enable the Taiwan people to exercise their right of referendum more easily.
In contrast, the KMT has continued to block the amendment in the legislature's procedure committee, so the party "should bear greater responsibility," he said.
However, he lashed out at both the DPP and the KMT for formulating a Referendum Law that has in practice stripped the people of their referendum right.
He noted that 880,000 signatures are required for a referendum proposal to become valid, meaning that only major parties are capable of initiating referendum proposals.
The two major parties have not focused on amending the "flawed" referendum and have instead each initiated their own referendum proposals, which is like "putting the cart before the horse," Lin said.

He was referring to the referendums to be held alongside the upcoming elections. The DPP-initiated referendums are on returning the "ill-gotten" assets of the KMT to the national coffers and on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid under the name Taiwan, while the KMT-initiated referendums are on ending government corruption and on the Republic of China applying to return to the United Nations.

Asked if he will express concerns about President Chen Shui-bian's recent deeds and remarks that some alleged as improper, Lin said that a democracy's ability to function normally depends on the people having the ability to monitor the government, adding that the right to referendum strengthens this ability.
"If there is a good referendum law, then it will at least check the politicians in terms of policies or legal matters," he said.

On whether he will stump for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, Lin noted that he withdrew from the party in January 2006 and that he hopes that he will not have to stump for any political parties or candidates.
Lin has devoted himself to the cause of a nuclear-free homeland in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate hopes Taiwan can become 'miracle maker' for world peace
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/07 16:04:44 (By Yang Ming-chu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Visiting ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Tuesday in Tokyo that he hopes Taiwan will capitalize on its "intelligent power" to become a "miracle maker" for world peace.
Hsieh, who is currently on a four-day visit to Japan, made the remarks while delivering a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan.
Describing Taiwan as an independent country, Hsieh noted that Taiwan is seeking to join the international community and hopes to win recognition from the world.
"Taiwan is currently walking on a path to dignity, and seeking dignity does not mean being a troublemaker," Hsieh said.

Noting that Taiwan can make a contribution to world peace, Hsieh stressed that Taiwan created "economic " and "political" miracles in the past and that it can become a "miracle maker" for world peace in the future.
During his speech, Hsieh also explained that his philosophy on relations between Taiwan and China is one of "co-existence and self-survival."
He said that "co-existence" also means co-prosperity and interdependence, describing himself as a "peace supporter."
Meanwhile, Hsieh noted that a very important premise for "co-existence" is "self-survival" -- with respect and protection.

Hsieh said that the people of Taiwan, including himself, would be glad to see China rise peacefully, adding that during the process, Taiwanese people and businesses have made a massive contribution to China's economic growth.
However, he noted that many people also worry about the possibility that the rise of China could turn into a threat to peace.
"How China treats Taiwan will be a litmus test on whether China's rise will be peaceful or whether it will pose a major threat to peace in Asia," he said.
If China does not respect Taiwan at all and deprives Taiwan's 23 million people of their basic human rights, then cross-strait relations will inevitably become strained, Hsieh said.
He also said that if Beijing continues to use force to threaten Taiwan and does not employ peaceful means to resolve cross-strait issues, then China will become a threat in Asia.

By then, Taiwan will not be the only victim, Hsieh said, noting that other countries -- including Japan -- will also face the threat from China. For this reason, he called on the international community to attach greater importance to Taiwan in looking at cross-strait issues.

In addition, Hsieh said that in recent days, the world has been closely watching developments concerning the upcoming presidential election in South Korea because its result will have an impact on the future development of Asia.

Hsieh further said he hopes that the world can also focus its attention on Taiwan's presidential election slated for March 22 as a strong Taiwan will be conducive to peace and stability in the Asia Pacific region and the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 65 points to close at 7,814, with 73,938 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January gained 34 points, finishing at 7,777, with 25,586 contracts traded, while March futures lost 10 points to close at 7,790, with 47 contract transactions. June futures rose 100 points to finish at 7,850, with 12 contract transactions, while September futures increased 66 points to close at 7,620, with 14 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,749 for December, 7,743 for January, 7,800 for March, 7,750 for June and 7,554 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures rose 4.85 points to close at 318, with 4,350 contracts traded, while January TE futures moved up 3.95 points to finish at 316.25, with 2,726 contract transactions. March TE futures gained 4.15 points to close at 319, with 11 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

December TF futures dropped four points to close at 890.2, with 3,186 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 8.2 points to finish at 883, with 2,646 contracts traded. March TF futures lost 3.6 points to close at 893.4, with 14 contract transactions, while September TF futures lost nine points to finish at 891, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP rebuts accusation of election tricks

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) denied Tuesday an accusation that the party would use bird flu as a pretext to prevent China-based Taiwan businessmen from coming home to vote in two key elections slated for early nest year.

Wang Tuoh made the statement at a Legislative Yuan news conference in response to an earlier question from main Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Ting Shou-chung as to whether the DPP would resort to dirty tricks, such as using an epidemic outbreak, as a pretext for banning cross-Taiwan Strait travel and exchanges, thereby preventing many Taiwan business people from returning and voting in the polls, in particular the March 22 presidential election.

Wang accused the KMT of entertaining "wild fantasies" and described Ting's allegation as a reflection of the party's mindset of its past martial rule. The so-called "dirty tricks" cited by the KMT are nothing more than a product of its imagination, he blasted.

In contrast, some of 20 kinds of "dirty tricks " applied by the KMT to rig elections over the years, have actually been ruled unlawful by courts and the persons involved in these cases convicted, he pointed out, adding that vote- buying is the trick most often used by the KMT.

Currently, more than one million Taiwan business people and family members are based in China, and it is estimated that more than half of them are KMT supporters, according to a news report by the Taipei-based English-language China Post.

Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission (CEC) is set to announce, by the Jan. 12 legislative polls, a contingency draft providing clear definitions of what it terms "natural catastrophes" and "unavoidable or irresistible situations" which could lead to a halt or suspension of the coming elections.

That news has sparked grave concern within the KMT that the DPP would use the CEC as a weapon to block the smooth holding of the legislative and presidential elections as public opinion survey results show that the DPP is lagging well behind the KMT in the two approaching elections.
It was reported that some KMT members are worried that a "two-step" voting method to be adopted by 18 KMT-controlled cities and counties in the coming two elections would be annulled by the CEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: President again thanks U.S. for submarine sale

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian again thanked the U.S. government Tuesday for approving the sale of eight diesel-electric submarines to Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a celebration held at the Tsoying naval base in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to mark 20 years of service by two improved Zwaardvis-class submarines.
Chen noted that the two Dutch-made submarines were delivered to Taiwan in 1987 and 1988, respectively, and commissioned at the Tsoying naval base.

However, Taiwan was only able to acquire the vessels after numerous, almost unbelievable hardships, including a financial crisis facing the Dutch shipbuilder that drove it to the brink of bankruptcy and almost forced it to close down its production line, according to Chen.

At the same time, China was using every possible means to obstruct the arms procurement plan, threatening to downgrade its diplomatic relations with the Netherlands to pressure the European country to cancel the sale, Chen continued.
Chen said this episode demonstrates that "many things cannot be bought with money" and that strong combat weapons, such as submarines, are especially difficult for Taiwan to obtain.

With Taiwan's survival and development depending heavily on foreign trade and shipping, the country must establish a reliable naval force to protect regional stability, Taiwan's economy and trade, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD injects US$100 million into program to recruit talent

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has injected NT$3.251 billion (US$100 million) into a project this year aimed at nurturing industrial talent.
The project is designed to attract overseas talent and students in Taiwan to work for the country's economic development.

A Taiwanese delegation organized by the Executive Yuan visited five major cities around the United States, including San Francisco and Los Angeles, between August and September, and had talked with 1,295 people who were interested in working in Taiwan.
Among them, 18 individuals with a high-tech background have been recruited by the government as advisors to Taiwan's enterprises and research organizations.
According to the CEPD, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has asked universities to open postgraduate student courses for the future supply of talent for domestic enterprises.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the MOEA, the National Science Council, and the Ministry of Education have also offered scholarships to 1,300 students this year to facilitate the nurturing of talent for the country's industrial and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, rising NT$0.036 to close at NT$32.517.
A total of US$1.18 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.481 and fluctuated between NT$32.450 and NT$32.589.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local researchers find natural antimicrobial substances in coral

TEXT.P: Marine biologists have discovered several natural antimicrobial substances in a coral species endemic to Taiwan and expect to apply them to various medical treatments, sources at the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium (NMMBA) in Fengkang, Pingtung County said Tuesday.

The project, the result of collaboration between the museum and two universities, spotted six sesquiterpenoid chemical compounds, dubbed rumphellolides A to F, in the coral species Rumphella antipathies, according to Sung Ping-jyun, the project leader and an associate research fellow at the museum.

Sung noted that every coral species is capable of producing 20 to 30 natural chemical compounds, and that there is a long-standing research question concerning how the possible applications of each substance might be identified.

Currently, Sung explained, the six newly-found materials are known to have antimicrobial effects, which can be helpful in terms of disease and cancer treatment, anti-inflammation and pain-killing drug development, the containment of bacteria and viruses, or production of cosmetics.

Meanwhile, Sung said, conventional extraction methods have an excessively negative impact on the ecology of coral habitats and are unable to exclude other disrupting factors in the symbiotic relations between coral, algae, and other species.

To overcome these shortcomings, Sung said, "we have spent years improving the extraction process, as well as establishing the only mass production coral cultivation farm in the world to facilitate future research and compound extraction."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE files suit against China Youth Corps

TEXT.P: The secretary-general of the Ministry of Education (MOE) filed a lawsuit Tuesday at the Taipei District Court against the Taipei-headquartered China Youth Corps (CYC) , claiming that a portion of the CYC-operated Chientan Overseas Youth Activity Center's property rightfully belongs to the country.

Chuang Kuo-jung told media reporters that the CYC, an organization associated with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , had obtained an enormous amount of national resources during the period of KMT rule.
He blasted the financial injection from the state's coffers during the KMT regime as a move "corrosive to the economic order of a normal country."

Chuang indicated that the MOE helped in the construction of the Chientan center, the largest of all 14 CYC-owned activity centers around the country, with subsidies amounting to NT$168 million during the 1988-1990 period.

Given those subsidies, the MOE should have owned 35.3 percent of the center's buildings. However, Chuang pointed out that over the past two decades the CYC has never acted to transfer any part of the buildings to the MOE.
Moreover, the MOE official said the ministry had offered the CYC subsidies totaling more than NT$780 million since 1957, which, calculated on current values, would be worth in excess of NT$3 billion.

Chang complained that no civil groups in Taiwan, except the CYC, could obtain such a large amount of money from the government's coffers and that no other political party, anywhere, "could control such a vast property holdings as the KMT."
According to the MOE, it brought the civil lawsuit to lay claim to the Chientan center buildings and NT$30 million from the CYC.
If the CYC is not willing to handover one-third of the ownership of the Chientan activity center, the MOE claimed that the CYC should pay the country NT$411.15 million.

In response to the MOE complaint, CYC Secretary-General Wang Fu-sheng said it is difficult for the CYC, a civic organization providing recreation, education and social-welfare services to domestic and overseas Taiwanese youths, to segment the Chientan center's property right, but the CYC will want to return the NT$168 million the MOE offered for the center's construction as a subsidy.
He has no idea how the MOE came up with the figure of NT$411.15 million in its property right claim, Wang added.
Underlining that the CYC is not a political organization, Wang stated that after the issue has been brought to the court, the CYC will have its lawyers to clarify its position on the matter.

The Chientan Overseas Youth Activity Center, situated on the west bank of the Keelung River, occupies an area of 50,000 square meters. The center owns accommodation facilities for up to 1,000 people, an auditorium, a conference room, a banquet room, a lecture auditorium and 40 other meeting rooms.

The CYC, formerly called the "China Youth National Anti-Communist National Salvation Corps, " was established in 1952 on the recommendation of then- president Chiang Kai-Shek as a quasi- governmental, quasi-political organization with close ties to the KMT regime.
On Aug. 28, 1989, the CYC became a non-governmental organization, officially severing its ties with the KMT regime. It dropped "Anti-Communist" from its official name officially Oct. 25, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU tops world institutes in number of papers at ICCAD

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) presented nine papers at the 25th International Conference on Computer Aided Design (ICCAD) held in America, ahead of any other participating academic institute, an NTU spokesman said Tuesday.

The ICCAD, the world's premier conference in electronic design technology, is held annually in November and co-organized by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and the Association for Computing Machinery, the spokesman said.

Two of the papers presented by NTU were included on the list of nominees for Best Paper Award, the spokesman said, adding that the theory presented in one nominated paper, by professors Chiang Chieh-hung and Huang Chung-yang at NTU's Graduate Intitute of Electronics Engineering, has already been adopted by the U.S. industry after presentation.

The ICCAD selected 139 papers among the 508 submitted for conference presentation. Among them, 15 presented were from Taiwan's academic institutes, second only to America's 95 papers, the spokesman noted.
The University of California, Los Angeles, and University of Michigan in Ann Arbor both had seven papers presented.

A team led by professor Chang Yao-wen of NTU's Department of Electronic Engineering presented six papers, with one paper winning the Profesor Margarida Jacome Memorial Award at the ICCAD, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maximum fine for drunken driving raised to NT$150,000

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Criminal Code Tuesday to increase the maximum fine for driving under the influence of alcohol, illegal substances or narcotics from NT$30,000 (US$926) to NT$150,000.
The fine is an alternative to imprisonment of up to one year and short-term detention labor, according to the law.

Also amended Tuesday was the Criminal Law of the Armed Forces, with the maximum fine for active military servicemen caught driving under the influence of alcohol, illegal substances or narcotics raised from NT$100,000 to NT$200,000.

Meanwhile, active military servicemen can be sentenced to imprisonment of up to seven years for causing the death of others while driving under the influence of intoxicating substances, and can be jailed for up to five years if the act results in severe injuries to others, according to the amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Theater du Soleil to present Les Ephemeres in Taipei

TEXT.P: Renowned French stage director Ariane Mnouchkine and her 60-member troupe, Theater du Soleil, will give six performances of the marathon show Les Ephemeres (The Ephemerals) in Taipei between Dec. 22 and 29.
The six-and-a-half-hour show was first presented in the 2006 Avignon Art Festival of France and the Taipei performances will be the show's Asian premiere.

The show will be presented in French with Chinese subtitles on a revolving stage under a huge canopy with 600 seats. The canopy, brought in from France, is being set up in the plaza between the National Theater and the National Concert Hall.

Les Ephemeres, described by critics as an elegy to the ephemeral quality of human existence, has two parts, each lasting 3 hours and 15 minutes. The two parts will be presented together Dec. 22-23 and Dec. 29. The first part will also be performed Dec. 26-27, while the second part will be staged Dec. 28.
The show consists of 50 personal stories that work like small threads woven together into a fabric of love, friendship, conflict and farewells in communal life.

Theatre du Soleil was founded by Mnouchkine in 1964. Her productions are often not confined to a typical stage. When audiences enter a Mnouchkine production, they can often see the actors putting on makeup or getting into their costumes. The actors improvise as stage set movers and even share snacks with the audiences during intermissions, making the audience and performer relationship tighter and more direct.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate values identity, security over economy
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/07 19:50:02 (By Yang Ming-chu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) believes that national identity and security issues are more important than economic issues, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said here Tuesday.

While delivering a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan, Hsieh, who is on a four-day visit to Tokyo, explained that the lack of national security and sovereignty will mean no freedom for the people, rendering other issues "meaningless."

Noting that it is wrong to think that Taiwan only has economic problems, like Hong Kong, Hsieh said that Taiwan has its own president, legislature, currency, and judicial system, making the island a de facto independent state.

In addition, Hsieh said that Taiwan's national security faces a threat from China, who has deployed over 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan, as well as launching legal, psychological, and electronic warfare against the island.

Hsieh continued that China has been attempting to isolate Taiwan from the world and deprive the country of its right to participate in the international community, including the World Health Organization (WHO) , which is a serious concern in safeguarding the health of the Taiwanese people.

China's efforts to block Taiwan internationally have harmed Taiwan's national identity, he went on, noting that Taiwan is nonetheless seeking to become a member of international organizations to strengthen its national identity.

Rebutting claims that Taiwan's international efforts have resulted in cross- strait tensions and turned the nation into a "trouble maker", Hsieh said that in face of the missile threat from China, the people of Taiwan need to protect themselves by joining world organizations.

Elaborating on his strategies to safeguard Taiwan's security, Hsieh noted that first of all, he supports purchasing defensive weapons and vows to raise the country's defense budget to over three percent of GDP.
He also said that he supports the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty, which he noted is of great benefit to the peace and stability in Asia.
Secondly, Hsieh said that Taiwan needs to be recognized by the international community and needs endorsements from more countries in order to further common interests and security issues.
Taiwan and the United States differed on several issues in recent years, but Hsieh said that if he is elected next year, he will strive to rebuild trust between both sides.
Hsieh said he also hopes to establish a framework for peace and stability with China and to create a mutually beneficial situation.

If elected, he also hopes to collaborate with the Japanese government in a number of fields, including defense, culture, economics, non-governmental organizations, and environmental protection, Hsieh said.
Thirdly, Hsieh said that he will further enhance the Taiwanese identity if he wins the 2008 election.
If the people of Taiwan do not regard Taiwan as an independent, sovereign country, the country will not enjoy any significant degree of national security, he went on.
Since the DPP took power in 2000, the percentage of people in Taiwan who consider themselves to be "Taiwanese" rather than "Chinese" grew from 30 percent to 70 percent, according to Hsieh.

Speaking of the country's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan this year, Hsieh said that the U.N. membership bid is expressive of a common aspiration of the Taiwanese people, and that the U.N. bid can also effectively enhance their Taiwanese identity.
Explaining that Taiwan's U.N. bid is not the cause of tensions in Asia, Hsieh attributed the real cause to the fact that the world does not accept Taiwan.

The international community's failure to recognize Taiwan gives the People's Republic of China (PRC) an opportunity to claim that Taiwan is a part of China, which Hsieh stressed is the real reason behind tensions in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man held incommunicado for smuggling protected birds into Taiwan

TEXT.P: A man is being held incommunicado for attempting to smuggle protected fowl into Taiwan, Taipei Customs officials reported Tuesday.
This is the first time a passenger has been held incommunicado for bringing animals into Taiwan.

Customs officials said the man, surnamed Yang, was found to have hidden 13 live fowl and 831 live beetles in his carry-on luggage when he arrived at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport from Surabaya, Indonesia Sunday.

The fowl and beetles were handed over to the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine's Hsinchu office while the passenger was turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office by aviation police.

Customs officials said four of the 13 birds were determined to be cicinnurus regius, a small (approximately 16 cm long), passerine bird of the Paradisaeidae family, which is listed as a protected animal.

Under the Wildlife Conservation Act, the passenger is liable to a prison term of between six months and five years, and/or a fine of between NT$300,000 (US$9,260) and NT$1.5 million (US$9,260-US$46, 300).

Although nine other live birds were not protected, the passenger violated the Statute for Prevention and Control of Infectious Animal Disease by bringing them and 831 live beetles of various types in from an area at risk for high pathogenic avian influenza virus.
Violations of the statute will be subject to up to seven years of imprisonment and/or a fine of up to NT$3 million.
Customs officials again called for the public to refrain from importing live animals from areas at risk of high pathogenic avian flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: "Two-step" voting method invalid: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that all local governments must adopt a "one-step" voting format designed by the Central Election Commission (CEC) for the legislative and presidential elections early next year and that the "two- step" method proposed by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will be invalid.
Chen made the comments while touring Hsing Kuo University in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan.

Chen vowed that there will not be two different voting methods in the legislative and presidential elections, slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively, and called for widespread public support for the CEC decision to apply the "one-step" voting method.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung reiterated earlier the same day at an emergency Legislative Yuan news conference that the validity of the two elections, if conducted in a "two-step" voting format by some local governments, will be determined by the CEC within one week of the election.

Chang made the remarks to clarify comments made a day earlier by CEC Secretary- General Teng Tien-you during a legislative intepellation session that elections to be conducted via a "two-step" voting method by 18 KMT-controlled cities and counties in the polls "would be valid" despite the CEC's decision to adopt a "one-step" format.

According to Chang, Teng's Monday remarks at the Legislative Yuan are merely his personal views and his words do not represent the CEC's stance. Chang blamed Teng for "making improper statements at the national parliament."

Chang categorically repeated that there will be no voting format other than the CEC-designed "one-step" method for the polls, asserting that the winners and legality of the elections -- if held in the "two-step" voting format in some localities -- must be determined jointly by CEC members within a week of the poll.

"Only results confirmed by the CEC are valid, " he emphasized, adding that electoral operations conducted by local election units in defiance of the CEC's decisions and regulations will be illegal and local unit chiefs and their delegates prosecuted.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey also attended the news conference and warned that the central government will not tolerate any lawbreaking by local authorities that would invite "catastrophic chaos."
The central government will do whatever necessary to deal with all possible senarios in advance, he stressed.

However, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin told reporters following a municipal council meeting later the same day that the city's election commission has decided to apply a "two-step" voting method for the legislative and presidential elections -- each accompanied by two referendums -- to avoid chaos in the voting process.

Hsiao Chia-chi, deputy mayor of Taichung City in central Taiwan who also serves as head of the city's election commission, said that the city will hold the two elections in line with the "two-step" voting format based on a set of voting rules promulgated in 2004 by the CEC for polling stations.
Brushing aside concerns that doing so will be illegal, Hsiao argued that the local governments are entitled to organize polling stations under the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakkas the most digitalized ethnic group: survey

TEXT.P: A nationwide survey has found that Hakkas are the most digitalized ethnic group and that the "digital divide" phenomenon has been more of a generation issue rather than an urban-rural issue in recent years, an academic said Tuesday in a press conference.

The annual survey, which was conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC), found that 72.1 percent of Hakkas used personal computers while 70.5 percent of Hoklos and 67.2 percent of indigenous peoples did so.
The Hakkas also had the highest percentage of Internet users -- 66.5 percent, compared to Hoklos' 64.9 percent and 60.9 percent of the indigenous peoples.

Hakkas' advanced digitalization may shocked a lot of people, but it's not surprising from the perspective of social studies, said Wu Chyi-in, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Sociology.

"According to our long-term statistics, the Hakkas have had the highest level of education among all ethnic groups in Taiwan. Being a minority group with limited resources, most Hakkas have tried to realize social mobility and better lives through obtaining higher levels of education," Wu said this social context might be one of the hidden reasons for the group's advanced digitalization.
"Some fellow researchers described the Hakkas as 'the Jews in Taiwan's society', " Wu added.

In addition to that interesting finding, the academic also said that the results of this survey showed that the main issue in the "digital divide" has shifted from infrastructure to differing ways of life between the generations.

According to the survey, Internet use rates in all age groups under 30 surpassed 94.4 percent, but the rates decrease dramatically in groups over 31 years of age. The same phenomena could also be found in the percentages of those writing personal blogs, regularly making online comments and participating in discussions and knowledge-sharing online.
"It looks like 30 is the watershed age of this 'digital divide 2.0' phenomenon, " said Vandy Liu, a professor at Chung Yuan Christian University's Department of Management of Information Systems.

Liu said that Taiwan has been successful in recent years in developing its information technology infrastructure, which was why the broadband Internet penetration rate was not an issue in most regions; rather the Taiwanese government should pay more attention in developing a "society of Internet citizens."

"That means encouraging Internet users of all ages, especially those who above age 30, to live a 'Web 2.0 life' by sharing their experiences, communicating, challenging authorities and injustice online, because this is how society works nowadays, " he said.
"The question for Taiwan's government is: what's next after laying down the infrastructure? " Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA donates second-hand computers to students in remote areas

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has donated 3,800 second-hand or recycled computers to students in remote areas this year with the aim of reducing the digital divide between urban and rural areas, an EPA official said Tuesday.

It is the tenth year that the government has offered second-hand or recycled computers to students living in remote areas, donating more than 10,000 to economically less privileged students during that period.

At the computer-donation ceremony, Hsiao Tai-chi, president of Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) , which was commissioned by the EPA to conduct the computer recycling project, noted that for those citizens or groups not capable of buying new computers, the second-hand ones are the best way to march into the e-era.

Hsiao hailed the recycling of second-hand computers as a combination of environmental protection, charity and science, with an aim of arousing awareness of recycling and maintaining the country's sustainable development.
According to Hsiao, this year's second-hand computer donation program has received a warm response from the public, with 356 groups and individuals participating in this project.

Among these, government agencies donated 52 percent of the second-hand computers, with enterprises accounting for 34 percent and schools, civic groups and individuals providing the remaining 14 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic groups want severe penalties for vote buying and selling

TEXT.P: Several local civic groups called for amendments to the Election and Recall Law and Criminal Law so that those who buy and sell votes will be subject to more severe punishments.
Taiwan Society, Taiwan Society North, Taiwan Society South and other groups called a news conference to highlight their campaign to ensure that there be "no condoning of bribery."

Taiwan Society South President Cheng Cheng-yu said the influence of bribery in Taiwan is far-reaching. Noting that the court has in the past been lenient in punishing such violations, he said an amendment to the Election and Recall Law will address that deficiency.
Cheng said the groups hope to raise the penalty for vote-buying from the current prison term of between three and 10 years to at least five years.

Punishment for those who receive bribes should also be increased to between one year and seven years and/or a fine of between NT$50,000 and NT$500,000, up from the existing three years imprisonment and/or a fine of up to NT$5,000.

Cheng said that the groups will send pledges to severely punish bribery to President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, in hopes that they will sign the pledge and commit themselves to no bribery within one week.
If the groups get no response, they will call on those persons to press for their campaign, Cheng said.
He also expressed hope that the DPP and the KMT will ask their candidates for the Jan. 12 legislative elections to sign the pledge within two weeks.
The groups will publish the names of legislative candidates refusing to sign the pledge, and launch a series of follow-up actions, he reaffirmed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE urged to fight drug use among young students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) should enhance local junior high school students' awareness of drug abuse and increase its efforts to protect students from narcotics, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Liao Pen- yen said Tuesday.

Liao made the remarks after a Dec. 17 report of the Taipei-based, Chinese- language China Times published the results of a survey stating that 6.1 percent of the local 13th graders interviewed have used drugs.
Based on that percentage, Liao inferred at a news conference that more than 18,000 young students could have used drugs.
Questioning why the MOE does not attach greater importance to drug hazards, Liao said that the education ministry has only allocated NT$27 million (US$831,536) to anti-drug education in 2008.
That budget is not enough to train specialized teachers who can provide counseling to students concerning drug abuse, Liao went on.
In response to the lawmaker's questions, Lin Hsiao-yin, a MOE official, said that the ministry is very surprised by the results of the survey conducted by the Champions Education Association, R.O.C.

Lin said that another survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) did not find such a high number of drug use among local junior high school students and noted that the association's survey dealt with students who have received counseling for misconduct, which may have resulted in the survey arriving at an higher than warranted percentage.
In an effort to strengthen anti-drug education at local schools, the education ministry will earmark an additional NT$10 million for next year, Lin said.
Furthermore, the ministry plans to require primary and junior school students to attend courses on the prevention of drug abuse within the next three to five years, according to Lin.
The ministry has also begun designing teaching materials to raise students' awareness of drug abuse and will train "seed teachers" to combat narcotics abuse on campus, Lin concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Diplomats 2007 championship goes to senior high in Taipei

TEXT.P: Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School has won the national Young Diplomats 2007 championship, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
The contest, organized by the MOFA, the Ministry of Education, and local Formosa Television (FTV), drew participants from 133 senior high school teams from around the country, the official said.
Second and third places went to the Kaohsiung Municipal Senior High School in southern Taiwan, and National Cingshuei Senior High School in Taichung County, central Taiwan, the official said.

The top three teams will win prize money of NT$50,000 (US$1,540), NT$30,000, and NT$20,000, respectively, and travel abroad to perform their diplomatic missions during winter vacation, the official said.
A total of 18 groups were selected in the preliminary rounds of the contest held in October and November, the official said.

Participants in the final round, held Dec. 15, went through three rounds of competition including a group talent show, impromptu speech, and quiz, with questions ranging from information on international organizations, diplomatic allies, international etiquette, to global political and economic situations, the official said.

The organizers also commended another five teams for their excellent performances in the final round of the contest, the official said, adding that the final round was recorded and will be aired on FTV Dec. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more airlines allowed to offer Japan-destined flight services

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) confirmed Tuesday that two major domestic flight operators -- Far East Air Transport (FEAT) and Trans Asia Airways (TAA) -- have been offered the right to open air routes serving Japan's Hokkaido and Kyushu.

According to a CAA news release, Taiwan's Association of East Asia Relations completed a procedure Nov. 1 with its Japanese counterpart, the Interchange Association to revise the Taiwan-Japan aviation pact with an exchange of letters between the two non-governmental organizations set up by the two countries to handle bilateral affairs in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Under the revised agreement, the number of airlines designated by Taiwan to operate Taiwan-Japan charter services was doubled to four with FEAT and TAA newly appointed alongside Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airways.
CAA officials said FEAT plans to offer charter services serving Hokkaido, with TAA taking the Kyushu route. They are scheduled to begin the new services in March, they added.

Taipei-based China Airlines and EVA Airways Corp. -- Taiwan's two largest carriers -- will maintain regular services destined for Japan, according to the revised agreement, which also increased the number of regular Taiwan-Japan routes from eight to 10, with the inclusion of two new routes -- Taipei-Komatsu and Taipei-Miyazaki.
In addition, the existing Taipei-Osaka route will be extended to Los Angeles or Seattle in the United States, beginning next July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet users surf 2.7 hours daily in Taiwan: survey

TEXT.P: Internet users in Taiwan surf an average of 2.7 hours a day, according to the results of a 2007 survey on the digital divide, released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan between Aug. 1 and Sept. 17 in Taiwan, drawing on 15,007 people above the age of 12. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 0.8 percent.
According to the poll, the number of people in Taiwan habitually using the Internet rose to 13 million this year, an increase of 400,000 people over the previous year.
The 2007 survey also found that 5.6 million households around the country are online.

Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, has the largest percentage of households online, at 75.5 percent, followed by Taichung City at 73.3 percent, and Taipei City at 71.6 percent, according to the poll, which also pointed out that cities and counties where the online population grew by over 3 percent this year include Keelung City, Yulin County, Hsinchu County, Miaoli County, Taitung County, Tainan City and Taichung County.

The survey also showed that over 40 percent of Internet users aged between 12 and 20 have their own blogs, while more than 30 percent of Internet users aged between 21 and 30 have personal blogs; less than 15 percent of the Internet users over 30 are used to posting their thoughts and feelings online.

On cyber-shopping, the survey found that nearly 70 percent of Internet surfers under 30 years old shop online, and that one in four Internet users between the ages of 21 and 30 have sold goods online.

The poll also showed that 78.4 percent of Internet users said they are concerned about having their personal data exposed on the Internet, 77.6 percent said they worried about computer viruses, 73.6 percent said they are beset by spam, and 59.4 percent voiced worries over credit card data exposure.

DOC.HEADLINE: All Taiwanese agricultural products traceable by 2015: COA

TEXT.P: All Taiwanese agricultural products will be traceable by 2015, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday at the launch of the first nationwide agricultural traceability system.

Certified traceability agricultural products will carry certification insignia for quick identification to guarantee the origin of products, COA Minister Su Chia-chuan said, adding that 2008 will be "Safe Agriculture Year."

More than 172 farmers have been granted Traceability Agriculture Product (TAP) certification from the Cabinet-level COA, which has entrusted 17 certifying institutes around the nation as independent certifying systems.
Food safety has been one of the hottest issues in the past year in Taiwan, as many food safety cases regarding domestic and imported products have been reported.

"The day of pushing for mass production is over. Modern-day farmers and consumers will and should pay attention to safety, quality and quantity -- in that order -- of agricultural products, " Su said.

The certification system consists of three criteria -- TAP, Organic Traceability Agricultural Product and Quality Traceability Agricultural Product -- and will integrate all certifying criteria used in the market by 2010, he said.

Consumers can visit the Taiwan Agricultural Food Traceability System at taft.coa.gov.tw to inquire about related information and in the future will also be able to access the information in supermarkets and on their mobile phones, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: pesticide in cabbage might have killed duckling: health officials

TEXT.P: Health officials from the Taichung city government said Tuesday that a duckling that died a week ago after its owner fed it cabbage probably died of poisoning by pesticide residue on the outer leaves of the vegetable.

The officials of the Public Health Bureau confirmed that they conducted tests on cabbage leaves submitted by the owner of the duck farm and detected five different kinds of pesticide residue, including 0.79 parts per million (ppm) of Carbofuran, exceeding the allowed limit of 0.5 ppm.
The cabbage leaves also had 0.05 ppm of Acetamiprid, 0.04 ppm of Indoxacarb and 0.04 ppm of Dimethomorph. Taiwan has a zero tolerance policy for these three pesticides in vegetables.
The officials explained that if the cabbage leaves are not washed with water, the pesticide residues could be fatal to a small duck.

They suggested that for human consumption, consumers should peel off the outer leaves and wash the cabbage with water thoroughly. This, they said, will remove at least 90 percent of any pesticide residue.

The officials also pointed out that under the Food Sanitation and Management Act, those responsible for allowing vegetables with pesticide residues exceeding allowed limits onto the market will be subject to fines of between NT$40,000 and NT$200,000, while vendors who refuse to disclose the origin of such vegetables are liable to fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000.

Cabbage farmers in central Taiwan staged an angry protest a day earlier after prices of the vegetable plunged to less than NT$6 per kilogram as a result of news reports about the suspected pesticide-caused death of the duckling. They urged the government to take immediate action to help them stabilize prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Democracy Party should learn from Taiwan: activist

TEXT.P: Chinese democracy activist Xu Wenli said Tuesday that the China Democracy Party (CDP) he founded should learn from Taiwan's ploitical parties which gain the power from the ballot box in order to end the totalitarian government of Communist Party of China (CPC).

Xu, heading a five-member delegation of exiled Chinese democracy activists, arrived in Taiwan Dec. 10 to observe Taiwan's upcoming elections with the aim of better understanding Taiwan's democratic politics and electoral culture.

Xu claimed in an interview with the CNA that the process of Taiwan's democratization is similar to that of China, as Taiwan went from one-party rule to democracy, adding that Taiwan's successful experience will be the best reference for China to move forward to democracy in the future.

Noting that the maturity of a democracy hinges on the degree of its rule of law, Xu claimed that none of Taiwan's political parties or groups -- even the anti- corruption protests that occurred last year -- have ever crossed the line, which he said reflects the maturity of Taiwan's democracy.
Xu said the people of Taiwan enjoy freedom of speech and noted that even the president can be criticized, a freedom that the Chinese people lack.
He noted that during China's Cultural Revolution, launched by then-CPC leader Mao Zedong in the 1960s, everybody was involved in politics, including children.
In Taiwan, adults who are not interested in politics can live their lives without having to become involved in politics, Xu went on.
Xu, who was sentenced to more than 10 years in prison by the Chinese government, founded the CDP in 1998 with the goal of fighting for fairness and freedom for the Chinese people.

As the CDP also advocates fair popular elections in China, its establishment has not been approved by the Chinese authorities. In addition, many of its members have been persecuted by the government after being accused of sabotage. The CDP's headquarters is now located in exile in the United States.
Xu said that although China's current opening policy focuses on the economic sphere, this economic freedom has made the Chinese people long for political freedom.
Although the Chinese authorities claim to be democracy-minded, Mao's ideology has profoundly affected their behavior, Xu added.
Noting that Chinese President Hu Jintao's efforts to safeguarding one-party rule have been very strong, Xu said it is unlikely that China's leaders will take the initiative in reforms.
He also predicted that if the Chinese leadership continues its authoritarian rule, the regime will collapse just as the former Soviet Union collapsed.
Xu said now is the best time to develop China's democracy and expressed that Taiwan's experience in developing democracy can serve as a reference for China.
He also urged the Chinese authorities to allow the existence of opposition parties and to conduct free elections.
The delegation will visit the campaign offices of various candidates running in the upcoming legislative and presidential elections early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou Flower Festival 2007 to begin Dec. 22

TEXT.P: The Nantou Flower Festival, a major annual event for Nantou County in central Taiwan, will begin Dec. 22, showcasing beautiful flower arrangements alongside a variety of activities for visitors, Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching said Tuesday.
Lee said the activities will include liquor tastings, cookery featuring flowers, and sightseeing.
He said the county government has invited farmers in seven townships, private corporations, communities, the tourist industry and temples to take part in this year's exhibits.
These efforts have led to the show including large-scale flower fields, as well as spectacular flower gardens at various theme parks around the county.

Visitors can see various flowers in the county's townships, including cherry blossoms in Yuchih township, tulips in Shanlin township and plum blossoms in Hsinyi township, as well as farms of roses, sunflowers and cosmos.
According to Lee, Canadian musician Matthew Lien and local dance group Utheatre will perform on the opening day of the festival.
A group from China's Zhejiang Provincial Department of Culture will also present a traditional Chinese drama at the Chung Tai Chan Monastery in Nantou City Jan. 6 as part of the festival, Lee said.

There will also be a lantern show at night during the festival and a New Year's Eve countdown to be held at the Cingjing Veteran's Farm, Lee added. He also guaranteed that visitors at the New Year countdown will see snow.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar on Kinmen to be held without Chinese participants

TEXT.P: A seminar on culture and academia in southern Fujian Province sponsored by the Kinmen county government, looks almost certain to open Dec. 20 without the participation of invited scholars and experts from China.

County government officials deplored Tuesday that the more-than 70 participants they invited from China had not been given permission from the Cabinet's Mainland Affairs Council to enter the outlying island of Kinmen via the "mini three links" route.

Those invited comprise Luo Caifu, head of the Xiamen municipal government's Cultural Bureau, six academics and 66 experts. They are scheduled to take part in the two-day seminar at the Kinmen county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, but it now appears certain that they will be unable to come.
As a result, the 18 papers originally planned to be presented on the second day of the seminar will now be reduced to nine, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate confident of landslide in presidential election
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/07 22:44:35 (By Mike Chang, Yang Ming-chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said here Tuesday that he is confident of a landslide victory in the March 22 election, expressing the hope that he will beat his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT), by 250,000 votes.
Hsieh, who is in Japan for a four-day visit, made the remarks at a news conference after delivering a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan in Tokyo.
On the Jan. 12 legislative elections, he said the DPP estimates it can capture 50 seats in the streamlined 113-seat legislature.

On the widening gap between Taiwan's rich and poor, Hsieh said the KMT encourages manufacturers to invest in China and claimed that this leads to rising unemployment, while his policy is to support small- and medium-sized enterprises, claiming that this means factories will not have to make an exodus overseas too soon.

He also said that both he and President Chen Shui-bian advocate Taiwan's independent sovereignty but that he differs from Chen on economic issues such as relaxing restrictions on locals investing in China.

Addressing the concerns related to constitutional re-engineering, he said that according to the Constitution, constitutional amendments require the consent of three-quarters of the legislators. As the DPP is aiming at 50 seats in the legislature, constitutional amendment will be beyond the means of the DPP and therefore there should be no concern about resultant cross-Taiwan Strait tensions.
He claimed that although China insists on its "one China" principle, if he is elected, China will "have to" respect the will of the Taiwan people, who will never accept the terms of "one China."
He pointed out that China will face a litany of challenges in the coming 20 years, such as the issues of environmental protection, the widening wealth gap and other social and economic woes.

Taiwan went through all these problems and maybe it can be of assistance. It is not good for China to isolate Taiwan, Hsieh said, expressing the hope that China will treat minor countries peacefully in keeping with its "international responsibility."

He also criticized Ma for not speaking up for Taiwan during a visit he made to Japan last month and his description of the DPP as a "troublemaker," which he described as "not fair." Hsieh described his party as "a creator of a cultural and peace miracle."
Hsieh later called on Takeo Hiranuma, president of the Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, and 21 members of the alliance, a pro-Taiwan group of congressmen and senators.
Hiranuma wished Hsieh victory in the election. Former Defense Minister and now congresswoman Yuriko Koike was also on hand to greet Hsieh.

Hsieh said that if he is elected president, he is sure that the DPP will become the dominant force in the legislature, because if the KMT loses, the party will splinter into Chinese Nationalist Party and the Taiwanese Nationalist Party, and Chinese influence will gradually fade from Taiwan politics, leading to the nation moving toward the path of normalization.
Hsieh said the ratio of those who identify themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese was 30 percent in 2000 when President Chen Shui-bian won his first election with 39.5 percent of the votes.
In 2004, the ratio of those of those who identify themselves as Taiwanese rose to 46 percent, and Chen was re-elected with 50.1 percent of the votes.

Although recent public opinion polls on the issue vary, with the figures standing at around 70 percent or at least over 62 percent, Hsieh said he is confident of an overwhelming victory in the election.
Senator Yasuhiro Oe noted that Ma said during his visit that he knows Japan, but Oe said Japan needs a pro-Japan president for Taiwan.
Ma is generally considered to hold a tough stance on such issues as conflicting fishery rights and Japanese claims on the controversial Tiaoyutais Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan.
Hsieh then called on former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori to exchange views on the cross-strait situation.

DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Millions more ID records go missing The records of more than three million British learner drivers have gone missing from a secure facility in the US, an embarrassed Government admitted last night.

DOC.TEXT: The New York Times:Fed Shrugged as Subprime Until the boom in subprime mortgages turned into a national nightmare this summer, the few people who tried to warn federal banking officials might as well have been talking to themselves. The Wall Street Journal:Iran's Actions in Iraq Scrutinized A Pentagon report will accuse Iran of continuing to funnel weapons and training personnel into Iraq, adding fuel to a heated debate among U.S. policy makers about whether Iran deserves any credit for the steep declines in Iraq's once-unrelenting violence.

DOC.TEXT: The administrative council of Italian state-own airliner Alitalia will meet today to evaluate proposals presented by Air France and Air One respectively for buying the Italy's national flag carrier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man nabbed for mailing threatening letter to president

TEXT.P: A former agent of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice was nabbed in Chunghe, Taipei County Tuesday for mailing threatening letters to government leaders, including President Chen Shui-bian.

Hou Yu-ih, chief of the national police, told a hastily called news conference later that day that the man, identified as Yang Ching-hai, had sent at least 31 threatening letters since November 2005 to senior officials, lawmakers from across the political spectrum and TV commentators.

Notable among the people threatened were former Premier Frank Hsieh, first daughter Chen Hsin-yu, the chief of the Public Affairs Division under the Presidential Office Lee Nan-yang, and the secretary-general of the Ministry of Education, Chuang Kuo-jung.
A total of 13 lawmakers from various political parties have received threatening letters from Yang, and maverick lawmaker Lee Ao has received two.
Enclosed in some of the letters, such as one sent to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, was a bullet, according to Hou.
Three TV commentators, including Cheng Hung-yi who acts as host for a political program on SET-TV, as well as local politicians, were also threatened, according to Hou.
Yang, who once served at the Yunlin office of the Investigation Bureau, was referred to prosecutors for further questioning, Hou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes U.S. will not follow China's thinking on U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Taiwan is continuing communications with the United States in the hope that it will not follow China's rhetoric in thinking Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. bid is a step toward de jure Taiwan independence, the acting spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Phoebe Yeh said that after months of discussion and communications, both sides have realized that there is indeed a gap in understanding.

"Taiwan is acutely aware of the U.S. concerns, and the United States knows perfectly Taiwan's stance, " Yeh said, adding that Taiwan has repeatedly expressed the hope that the United States will not follow China's rhetoric in seeing the U.N. bid is a step toward changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait or seeking de jure Taiwan independence.
Yeh said the ministry regrets the differences between the two countries over the referendum.

A close look at remarks by U.S. officials -- from Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Thomas Christensen to American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt -- shows that the U.S. stance is consistent.
However, she said, Taiwan has repeatedly explained to the United States that a deepening democracy will help peace and stability in East Asia.

Yeh also said that Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will arrive in New York Tuesday and will exchange views on issues of mutual concern with the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the resolution of conflicts that threaten U.S. interests.
Yeh admitted that Huang will meet members of the think tank rather than U.S. officials, but she said he "should be able to meet the people he wants to meet." She did not elaborate.

Yeh claimed that if the planned referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid passes a vote held alongside the March 22 presidential election, it will give a "positive message to the international community that Taiwan people are keen on joining the world body."
However, if the referendum fails, then it can be attributed to a lot of factors, including that the threshold for the referendum is too high, as well as a controversial voting format.

But whether the referendum passes or not, more than 2 million people have signed their names to endorse the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated referendum, which Yeh described as " significant in its own way."
She added that whoever takes the helm of the nation after the March 22 presidential election, he will still have to address the issue of Taiwan's maneuvering space.
"It is impossible not to think about soliciting the maneuvering space of Taiwan internationally, Yeh said, adding that this is why the nation needs to forge a consensus by holding the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday.
The weighted price index was up 73.62 points at 7881.01 on a turnover of NT$3.27 billion (US$100.56 million) at the open. The index lost 23.46 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 7808.39 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down against New Taiwan dollar in early trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.507 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.010 from Tuesday.
