DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate confident of landslide in presidential election
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/07 10:58:11 (By Mike Chang, Yang Ming-chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said here Tuesday that he is confident of a landslide victory in the March 22 election, expressing the hope that he will beat his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang (KMT), by 250,000 votes.
Hsieh, who is in Japan for a four-day visit, made the remarks at a news conference after delivering a speech at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan in Tokyo.
On the Jan. 12 legislative elections, he said the DPP estimates it can capture 50 seats in the streamlined 113-seat legislature.

On the widening gap between Taiwan's rich and poor, Hsieh said the KMT encourages manufacturers to invest in China and claimed that this leads to rising unemployment, while his policy is to support small- and medium-sized enterprises, claiming that this means factories will not have to make an exodus overseas too soon.

He also said that both he and President Chen Shui-bian advocate Taiwan's independent sovereignty but that he differs from Chen on economic issues such as relaxing restrictions on locals investing in China.

Addressing the concerns related to constitutional re-engineering, he said that according to the Constitution, constitutional amendments require the consent of three-quarters of the legislators. As the DPP is aiming at 50 seats in the legislature, constitutional amendment will be beyond the means of the DPP and therefore there should be no concern about resultant cross-Taiwan Strait tensions.
He claimed that although China insists on its "one China" principle, if he is elected, China will "have to" respect the will of the Taiwan people, who will never accept the terms of "one China."
He pointed out that China will face a litany of challenges in the coming 20 years, such as the issues of environmental protection, the widening wealth gap and other social and economic woes.

Taiwan went through all these problems and maybe it can be of assistance. It is not good for China to isolate Taiwan, Hsieh said, expressing the hope that China will treat minor countries peacefully in keeping with its "international responsibility."

He also criticized Ma for not speaking up for Taiwan during a visit he made to Japan last month and his description of the DPP as a "troublemaker," which he described as "not fair." Hsieh described his party as "a creator of a cultural and peace miracle."
Hsieh later called on Takeo Hiranuma, president of the Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, and 21 members of the alliance, a pro-Taiwan group of congressmen and senators.
Hiranuma wished Hsieh victory in the election. Former Defense Minister and now congresswoman Yuriko Koike was also on hand to greet Hsieh.

Hsieh said that if he is elected president, he is sure that the DPP will become the dominant force in the legislature, because if the KMT loses, the party will splinter into Chinese Nationalist Party and the Taiwanese Nationalist Party, and Chinese influence will gradually fade from Taiwan politics, leading to the nation moving toward the path of normalization.
Hsieh said the ratio of those who identify themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese was 30 percent in 2000 when President Chen Shui-bian won his first election with 39.5 percent of the votes.
In 2004, the ratio of those of those who identify themselves as Taiwanese rose to 46 percent, and Chen was re-elected with 50.1 percent of the votes.

Although recent public opinion polls on the issue vary, with the figures standing at around 70 percent or at least over 62 percent, Hsieh said he is confident of an overwhelming victory in the election.
Senator Yasuhiro Oe noted that Ma said during his visit that he knows Japan, but Oe said Japan needs a pro-Japan president for Taiwan.
Ma is generally considered to hold a tough stance on such issues as conflicting fishery rights and Japanese claims on the controversial Tiaoyutais Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan.
Hsieh then called on former Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori to exchange views on the cross-strait situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man nabbed for mailing threatening letter to president

TEXT.P: A former agent of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice was nabbed in Chunghe, Taipei County Tuesday for mailing threatening letters to government leaders, including President Chen Shui-bian.

Hou Yu-ih, chief of the national police, told a hastily called news conference later that day that the man, identified as Yang Ching-hai, had sent at least 31 threatening letters since November 2005 to senior officials, lawmakers from across the political spectrum and TV commentators.

Notable among the people threatened were former Premier Frank Hsieh, first daughter Chen Hsin-yu, the chief of the Public Affairs Division under the Presidential Office Lee Nan-yang, and the secretary-general of the Ministry of Education, Chuang Kuo-jung.
A total of 13 lawmakers from various political parties have received threatening letters from Yang, and maverick lawmaker Lee Ao has received two.
Enclosed in some of the letters, such as one sent to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, was a bullet, according to Hou.
Three TV commentators, including Cheng Hung-yi who acts as host for a political program on SET-TV, as well as local politicians, were also threatened, according to Hou.
Yang, who once served at the Yunlin office of the Investigation Bureau, was referred to prosecutors for further questioning, Hou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes U.S. will not follow China's thinking on U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Taiwan is continuing communications with the United States in the hope that it will not follow China's rhetoric in thinking Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. bid is a step toward de jure Taiwan independence, the acting spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Phoebe Yeh said that after months of discussion and communications, both sides have realized that there is indeed a gap in understanding.

"Taiwan is acutely aware of the U.S. concerns, and the United States knows perfectly Taiwan's stance, " Yeh said, adding that Taiwan has repeatedly expressed the hope that the United States will not follow China's rhetoric in seeing the U.N. bid is a step toward changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait or seeking de jure Taiwan independence.
Yeh said the ministry regrets the differences between the two countries over the referendum.

A close look at remarks by U.S. officials -- from Deputy Secretary of State John Negroponte and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Thomas Christensen to American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt -- shows that the U.S. stance is consistent.
However, she said, Taiwan has repeatedly explained to the United States that a deepening democracy will help peace and stability in East Asia.

Yeh also said that Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will arrive in New York Tuesday and will exchange views on issues of mutual concern with the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the resolution of conflicts that threaten U.S. interests.
Yeh admitted that Huang will meet members of the think tank rather than U.S. officials, but she said he "should be able to meet the people he wants to meet." She did not elaborate.

Yeh claimed that if the planned referendum on Taiwan's U.N. bid passes a vote held alongside the March 22 presidential election, it will give a "positive message to the international community that Taiwan people are keen on joining the world body."
However, if the referendum fails, then it can be attributed to a lot of factors, including that the threshold for the referendum is too high, as well as a controversial voting format.

But whether the referendum passes or not, more than 2 million people have signed their names to endorse the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated referendum, which Yeh described as " significant in its own way."
She added that whoever takes the helm of the nation after the March 22 presidential election, he will still have to address the issue of Taiwan's maneuvering space.
"It is impossible not to think about soliciting the maneuvering space of Taiwan internationally, Yeh said, adding that this is why the nation needs to forge a consensus by holding the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar on Kinmen to be held without Chinese participants

TEXT.P: A seminar on culture and academia in southern Fujian Province sponsored by the Kinmen county government, looks almost certain to open Dec. 20 without the participation of invited scholars and experts from China.

County government officials deplored Tuesday that the more-than 70 participants they invited from China had not been given permission from the Cabinet's Mainland Affairs Council to enter the outlying island of Kinmen via the "mini three links" route.

Those invited comprise Luo Caifu, head of the Xiamen municipal government's Cultural Bureau, six academics and 66 experts. They are scheduled to take part in the two-day seminar at the Kinmen county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, but it now appears certain that they will be unable to come.
As a result, the 18 papers originally planned to be presented on the second day of the seminar will now be reduced to nine, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 19, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid referendum not aimed at declaring independence: Taiwan rep
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/07 12:28:18 (By Michelle Tsai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's planned referendum on applying

to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is not intended to declare independence or disrupt the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Wu stressed the referendum will allow the Taiwan people to exercise their democratic rights and that the vote will only address the issue of Taiwan's U.N. membership, rather than changing the country's official name.

Noting that Beijing has been using U.N. Resolution 2758 -- which recognizes the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate representative of China at the United Nations -- to pressure the world body to reject Taiwan, Wu claimed the resolution does not grant China the right to represent the Taiwan people.
Wu said the United Nations' refusal to consider Taiwan's membership application is frustrating to the Taiwan people but has not dampened their desire to join the world body.

In addition to the referendum initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on using the name Taiwan to join the United Nations, the opposition Kuomintang is also pushing a referendum on U.N. membership for Taiwan under a different name, he pointed out.
Wu made the remarks while delivering a keynote speech entitled "Taiwan's United Nations Bid: Domestic Democracy or International Crisis" at the Heritage Foundation in Washington, D.C.

Asked how U.S. concerns over the referendum are being addressed, Wu reiterated that the United States is Taiwan's most important friend and that Taiwan understands Washington's worries about the possible outbreak of cross-strait conflict.

Based on this reason, Taiwan has made it clear since 2000 that the country will not declare independence, change its official name, or hold a referendum on the unification versus independence issue, Wu said, adding that the U.N. bid referendum is designed merely to make the voices of the Taiwan people heard.

Asked if there is any chance the government of Taiwan might cancel the referendum, Wu said both referendums will go ahead as planned as they are promoted by political parties and are not up to any changes by the government.
According to Wu, China's hostility toward Taiwan has made gaining U.N. membership very important for Taiwan.

Besides blocking Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, China is also attempting to bar Taiwan's participation in the world community and is excluding Taiwan from bilateral and regional free trade agreements with neighboring countries in order to increase Taiwan's economic dependency on China.
Wu argued that including Taiwan in the United Nations will help Taiwan's political and economic development and provide Taiwan and China with a new platform for dialogue.
He stressed the separate rule of Taiwan and China has been the status quo across the Taiwan Strait since 1949 and that the Taiwan people are fully entitled to representation in the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.S. don't want differences to benefit China: minister
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/07 13:36:08 (By Jaw Pyng Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said in New York City Tuesday that neither Taiwan nor the United States want to see China benefit from the friction in their relationship.

Speaking at a news conference at LaGuardia Airport upon his arrival from Atlanta following his official visit to Latin America and the Caribbean, Huang said that differences do indeed exist between Taiwan and the United States, including over the issue of the upcoming referendum on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
Noting that neither the United States nor Taiwan would like China to gain advantage from their differences, Huang said that there is room for the two sides to communicate over the referendum issue.

Before arriving in New York, Huang made a stopover in Atlanta where he presided over a working meeting with Ministry of Foreign Affairs colleagues posted in North America, during which they discussed ways to strengthen Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Huang is scheduled to meet with members of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the resolution of conflicts that threaten U.S. interests, Wednesday to exchange views on issues of mutual concern, including Taiwan's referendum plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investigation bureau disavows any relation with arrested former agent

TEXT.P: The Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Justice disavowed Tuesday any relation with one of its former agents who was arrested Tuesday for mailing threatening letters to public figures, including President Chen Shui-bian.

The bureau said in a written statement that Yang Ching-hai left his job at the bureau in March 1988 and that the bureau has no information whatsoever about his activities or the people he has associated with since that time.
A local newspaper reported Tuesday that Yang entered the Investigation Bureau in 1970 and was considered a maverick by his supervisors.

He published two books criticizing the bureau after leaving his job and filed a lawsuit in June 2000 against Wang Kuang-yu, the bureau chief at the time, accusing him of falsifying numbers for the bureau's annual budget.

Yang was arrested on suspicions of involvement in a total of 31 criminal intimidation cases, including sending threatening letters to President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, government officials, legislators and news anchors.
Yang's girlfriend Ting Yi-chih, who admitted to helping type some of the threatening letters, was released by prosecutors on NT$200,000 bail Wednesday after being questioned.

The bourse opened at 7,881.01 and fluctuated between 8,020.39 and 7,865.48 during trading. A total of 4.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.02 billion (US$3.45 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records 2.6 filicide-suicides per month

TEXT.P: Ninety-six cases of parents comitting suicide after attempting to kill their children have been reported in Taiwan over the past three years, leaving a total of 124 children and teenagers killed or injured, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF).

The figure means an average 2.6 filicide-suicides occur per month in the country, with the incidence rate registering 7.5 cases per million people, higher than Japan's seven cases per million people, foundation officials said.

The tallies were compiled by the foundation based on news reports published in the last three years. The latest of these incidents took place Sunday, in which a man in the central city of Taichung stabbed his eight-year-old daughter and 12 -year-old son with a fruit knife before killing himself with the same knife. The girl and the father died, but the boy survived.
The foundation has discovered that although the number of filicide-suicides has dropped slightly this year, the death rate of children and teenagers involved has increased to over 70 percent.
The tallies show that in 2005, 32 cases causing death or injury to a total of 51 children and teenagers were reported, with the death rate standing at 53 percent.
The number of such cases rose to 35 in 2006, with 46 children or teenagers killed, translating into a death rate of 72 percent.
This year, 29 such cases in which 27 children and teenagers were killed or injured had been reported as of Dec. 18, with the death rate registering 70 percent.
The tallies indicate that nearly 70 percent of the victims of filicide-suicides were school children older than six.
On the causes of the incidents, the tallies show that 37.5 percent of the cases reported so far this year were related to marriage or relationship conflicts.

While another 28.1 percent were attributed to the heavy burden of credit card debt or debts owed to a loan shark, 12.5 percent involved a parent suffering from mental illnesses such as bipolar disorder or depression.
Unemployment was to blame in 9.4 percent of the cases, and 6.3 percent involved a parent with poor health or heavy parental duties, according to the tallies.

CWLF officials urged children to ask for help if they detect any unusual or worrisome acts in their parents, adding that the public should also report the situation to the authorities if they notice any dangerous signs in their relatives, friends or neighbors.

Places they can approach include the foundation's help hotline at (02) 25505959 ext. 4, the Ministry of the Interior's welfare and care hotline at 1957 and the Department of Health's suicide prevention hotline at 0800-788-995, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 32.2% of new additions to labor market dissatisfied with jobs: survey

TEXT.P: About 32.2 percent of newcomers to the workforce are not satisfied with their jobs, with a high percentage of them not content with their salaries, according to the results of a recent survey released Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by the online job broker udnjob.com, found that only 31.6 percent of the workers who recently joined the workforce are satisfied with their jobs, while 44.2 percent of those surveyed said their jobs are acceptable.

Among those who are not satisfied with their jobs, 47.4 percent said they are not content with their salaries, while 36.7 percent said they lack promotion opportunities in their workplace and 33.5 percent said they do not like their superiors or colleagues.

The survey also found that 26 percent of the new workers said they will definitely leave their jobs after one year, a growth of just 1.3 percentage points over last year, while 45.6 percent said whether they will change jobs depends on circumstances, an increase of only 1.6 percentage points over last year, a reflection of the fact that this is standard practice in Taiwan every Chinese New Year.
The survey, conducted online between Nov. 1 and Dec. 1 among 1,537 new workers, had a margin of error of 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker, DPP chief divided over election validity

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and ruling Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai were hugely divided Wednesday over the notion that the validity of the upcoming legislative elections will be determined by the Central Election Commission (CEC) if the election is conducted in a "two- step" voting format.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Tuesday that according to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act, electoral operations will be illegal if the Jan. 12 legislative elections are conducted in a "two-step" voting format by some local governments and that the winners and legality of the elections -- if held in such a format -- must be determined by the CEC members within a week of polling.
Apart from the CEC and the courts, no individual in this country should have the right to validate the election results, Chang said.

Chang made the remarks to clarify comments made Monday by CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you during a legislative interpellation session that elections to be conducted via a "two-step" voting method by 18 KMT-controlled cities and counties in the polls "would be valid" despite the CEC's decision to adopt a "one-step" format.
Chang claimed that Teng's remarks at the Legislative Yuan were merely his personal views and that his words do not represent the CEC's stance.

Wang said Chang has apparently "over-defined" the Public Officials Election and Recall Act, adding that the top government agency in charge of elections and electoral affairs should respect voters' decisions and that the votes they cast should be considered valid.

Meanwhile, Cho noted that the CEC decided in November that a "one-step" voting format will be adopted in the forthcoming legislative elections as well as in the presidential election slated for March 22.
Cho quoted Chang as saying that according to the Public Officials Election and Recall Act, the "two-step" method proposed by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will be invalid.
Cho claimed that the KMT is simply trying to cause a social standoff by insisting on the adoption of a "two-step" voting format.

For his part, the legislature speaker, who was formerly a KMT vice chairman, said that while Chang described Teng's remarks made at the Legislative Yuan as "personal views, " the DPP is also putting forward "personal views" by defining the KMT's "two-step" voting format proposal as "invalid."
Even if the CEC has discussed and made a resolution on the voting format, it should still be examined by the public, Wang said.

Wang said the only way to solve the dispute surrounding the voting format for the elections is to separate the legislative elections and presidential race from proposed accompanying referendums, pointing out that four years ago, when the presidential election and referendum were held separately, the voting went smoothly.
He added that although ballot distributions seems to be no problem in the "one- step" voting format, the most important part -- vote counting -- would be time consuming and troublesome.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT industry's revenues expected to grow 20%-30% this year

TEXT.P: Business turnover of the local information technology (IT) industry this year is expected to rise by 20 percent to 30 percent from last year, a spokesman for the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) said Wednesday.

TCA President Wang Jeng-tang made the forecast after saying that local notebook and personal computer manufacturers should be able to maintain stable growth in the fourth quarter of this year and the first quarter of next year.

In addition, speaking on the likely impact of the Labor Contract Act to be implemented by the Chinese government from Jan. 1, Wang cited notebook computer manufacturers as an example when he said that Taiwan produces up to 80 percent of the world's laptops and that no country can compete in that regard.
It is generally believed that the act will increase the cost of employing Chinese laborers, which will be costly for Taiwanese companies that manufacture in China.
However, Wang pointed out that all notebook computer manufacturers will face the same pressure, because they have all set up factories in China.
For this reason, Wang said it is unlikely that these manufacturers will lower product prices while their costs go up.
"Maybe in the future, they will raise their selling prices a little, " Wang predicted, describing the impact of the Chinese action as "limited" and "not necessarily negative."
Asked if computer manufacturers will shift production sites to other countries to cope with rising labor costs, Wang pointed out that infrastructure construction takes time.
Therefore, "it will take these manufactures at least a year or two before they leave China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate to seek dialogue with China if elected president
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/07 18:54:06 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, the presidential hopeful of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said here Wednesday that he is satisfied with his just-concluded visit to Japan and pledged that he will seek dialogue with China if elected president early next year.
Hsieh made the remarks at a news conference prior to his departure for Taiwan after wrapping up a four-day visit to Japan.

Hsieh said that if he achieves victory in the March 22 presidential election, he will do his utmost to help galvanize peace across the Taiwan Strait and hold talks with China based on national sovereignty and dignity.

He said he is poised to conduct negotiations with China but will not do so unconditionally at the cost of Taiwan's democratic values and efforts by yielding to China's unreasonable conditions, such as its "one China" principle.

According to Hsieh, he favors a broader opening of Taiwan to China on the economic front, including allowing direct cross-strait charter flights and Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, while insisting on safeguarding Taiwan's independent sovereignty on the political front.

Such a stance would mark a departure from the position of Ma Ying-jeou, his main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) opponent, who urges a full opening to China without paying heed to Taiwan's independent sovereignty and also from that of some traditional DPP members who focus excessively on national sovereignty and remain reluctant to open up to China, Hsieh said.

Turning to the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty over the Tiaoyutai island group, which is also claimed by Japan and China, Hsieh said he already proclaimed that the island group belongs to Taiwan when he served as premier from 2005-2006.

However, he added that the sovereignty dispute over the island groups should be put aside temporarily to allow fishery development by designating the 12-nautical mile zone around the islands as a conservation area.

In response to Ma's suspicion that Hsieh was afraid of defending Taiwan's sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais in front of the Japanese side, Hsieh argued that Ma is unaware of how the government has been seeking to resolve the Tiaoyutai issue through international negotiations.
Hsieh arrived in Osaka Dec. 16 for a four-day visit and then proceeded to Kyoto and Tokyo, where he gave speeches, visited Japanese politicians and met Taiwanese expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei commuters greeted by bus drivers-turned-Santa Claus

TEXT.P: Some 500 drivers working for a Taipei bus company are dressing up as Santa Claus this month in order to bring seasonal greetings to commuters and to make their usually bland bus rides more colorful and memorable.

The Santa drivers, introduced by Capital Bus, which operates 45 bus routes in the greater Taipei area, also hand out candies and cookies to passengers during the Christmas season. Christmas is not a public holiday in Taiwan.
More and more drivers undergo the voluntary yuletide transformation, which started a few years ago, following growing public demand.

"We had only a few Santa drivers at first, but many passengers would wait at the bus stops for Santa drivers and buses with Christmas decorations," Yang Shu- ting, the station master at Er-chong, Taipei County, told CNA.

The company then asked all its drivers to dress up as Santa Claus on a voluntary basis and most drivers have cooperated, Yang added. Many other staff members also wear Santa costumes, which are provided by the management.
Over the years, many drivers have taken pride in being able to bring Christmas greetings to bus passengers but for at least some of them, taking on this extra role was not easy at first.
"My 10-year-old son was shocked to see me in a Santa costume and asked me what I was doing dressed like a clown," said Wu Chen-sen.
After some explanation, his children had a change in attitude and are now proud to have a dad who is a Santa driver.
"It's going to be December again. Don't forget to become a Santa driver," Wu's children remind him.
Another driver, Chao Er-ge, said: "I was a bit shy at first but now I'm used to it."
"I'm very happy to dress up like a Santa Claus to serve my passengers," he added.
Besides adding color to the journey, Santa drivers make sure passengers do not miss their stops.
"Welcome aboard Capital Bus Route 292 from Er-chong to Lin-Gwang MRT Station. Next stop Zhong-shan MRT Station," a driver announces.
"I was too shy to address the passengers at first," Wu said. "But now, even if there is only one person left on the bus, I still make the announcements."
"It has become a habit," said Wu, who also drives a Route 292 bus.
Reactions from passengers to the Christmas service have been "mostly positive," said Yang.
A passenger, who preferred to remain anonymous, praised the idea and said: "I really like the service they provide."
Capital has been named Taipei's top bus operator 16 times by the city government's Department of Transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another factory shuts down with no prior warning

TEXT.P: Another factory in Taipei County closed down without prior notice or warning Wednesday, leaving 140 employees jobless less than one week before the start of the festive season.

The employees of Wel Champ Industries Co., a company producing computer peripheral products in Shulin City, were stunned when they arrived at work in the morning only to find that the entrance to the factory was locked and the owner of the company, Huang Hung-yuan, and his managers were nowhere to be found.
The workers could hardly believe that the factory, which was operating normally a day earlier, had folded for good.
Other companies with outstanding payments to collect from Wel Cham were also left uncertain as to how to get their money.
While some of Wel Champ's employees were guarding the factory property, others appealed to the Bureau of Labor Affairs of the Taipei County government to intervene on their behalf.
An increasing number of factories in Taiwan have collapsed in 2007 due the economic recession.
Statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economics Ministry show that in the first 10 months of this year, 2,419 factories closed down -- a 60 percent increase over the same period of 2006.

Figures also show that during the first 10 months of this year, 36,788 companies ceased operations, up 38.37 percent compared to the same period in 2006, and surpassing the total number of companies, 36,618, shutting their doors during the whole of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham Taipei renews chairmanship

TEXT.P: Tung Tai-chin, country head of Fidelity International Ltd. Taiwan, has recently been elected by the Board of Governors of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei to head the chamber, an AmCham news release said Wednesday.
Tung will succeed Jane Hwang of the State Street Bank, who will complete her term at the end of the year.

According to the news release, the board also approved a change in nomenclature to bring AmCham Taipei into line with other American Chambers in the greater China area. The elected head will now be known in English as the chairman, while the professional administrator, formerly called executive director, will have the title of president.

After her election as chairman, Tung nominated the other standing officers for the coming year, including Christopher Fay, CEO of Saatchi and Saatchi, as first vice president; Jeffrey Nemeth, president of Ford Liu Ho Motor, as second vice president; Jenny Cheung, managing director of Lots Home Entertainment, as treasurer; and Andy Liu, general manager of UCB (Taiwan) Ltd., as secretary. The board approved all the nominations.
In the news release, Tung was acclaimed for her participation in chamber activities over the past year as treasurer and co-chair of the Capital Markets Committee.

In her address after the election, Tung said she is looking forward to working with the Taiwan government on improving the country's standing on the world stage and seeking to enhance its economic competitiveness.
She also noted that AmCham wishes to contribute to a situation that is beneficial both to the international business community and to the Taiwan public at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to focus on ethanol crop cultivation: COA official

TEXT.P: The government's energy crops policy will focus on planting crops for the production of ethanol gasoline, also known as gashol, after efforts to grow crops for the production of bio-diesel over the past two years have proved inefficient, a senior Agriculture and Food Agency (AFA) official said Wednesday.

AFA Deputy Director Yu Sheng-feng said that as part of the government's efforts to promote the use of biomass energy, the agency began planting energy crops, including soybeans and sunflowers, on 1,721 hectares of fallow land in the southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan in 2006.
This year, the cultivation was further expanded to 24 counties and townships, including Taoyuan and Taipei counties, covering a total of 3,334 hectares of fallow ground.

However, harvests were far less than expected due to damage caused by natural disasters and pests, Yu said, adding that they could only meet the demand from several model governmental bio-energy promotion programs such as the "green government vehicle" program implemented in September.
In this regard, Yu said, future energy crop cultivation will focus on plants like sweet potatoes, which are the major resource for the production of bio- ethanol.
Energy crop cultivation is one of the government's strategies in the face of an international energy crisis resulting from skyrocketing crude oil prices, according to the AFA.

Meanwhile, former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is a 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, suggested that the government speed up efforts to cut Taiwan's emissions of carbon dioxide, one of the factors in global warming.
At a national park/greenland conference held by the Construction and Planning Agency in Taipei earlier in the day, Lee said the country has moved at a snail's pace in the reduction of CO2 emissions.

He said Taiwan can be regarded as an "over-developed" country from the viewpoint of its CO2 emissions. If the nation cannot act to cut the emissions significantly, economic activity in the country will be "meaningless" because the next generation will be faced with a polluted environment unsuitable for living, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei county wetland becomes prize-winning habitat for wildlife

TEXT.P: A wetland area that has been developed into a natural waste water treatment area by ecological engineering methods in Taipei County has also been turned into a natural habitat for wildlife.
The 13-hectare wetland, known as the Da Niao Pi Wetland, has also won the 2007 Ford Motor Company Conservation and Environmental Grant for Excellence.

The wetland, built between November 2005 and December 2006, can treat some 11,000 metric tons of waste water per day discharged into the Tamshui River from communities in Taipei County, with a cleansing rate of 60 percent.

Professor Kuo Jen-hua of National Taiwan University provided technological know- how to the wetland management -- the Taipei County Environmental Protection Bureau -- to nurture Taiwanese endemic wild rice on the wetland, efforts that have already borne fruit over the past year, said Hsiao Tien-kun, a bureau inspector.

In addition to wild rice, Hsiao said, the wetland is now a wildlife conservation habitat with ecological and biological diversity -- visitors and residents include wetland and migrant birds such as the common moorhen, a water bird that inhabits paddy fields, mangroves and wetland areas, the little grebe, the common teal and the rarely seen jacana.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microbiologist discovers bacteria capable of digesting dioxin

TEXT.P: Microbiologists at two universities in the southern port city of Kaohsiung have discovered a bacteria capable of breaking down the poisonous substance dioxin efficiently and are trying to apply the species to a mass purging process to save on the time and cost involved in removing the pollutant, academic sources said Wednesday.

National Sun Yat-sen University (NSYSU) and Cheng Shiu University (CSU) started the project with the aim of remedying the aftermath of dioxin pollution incidents, which at present cost millions of dollars to clean up and require the removal of existing contaminated soil and its replacement with clean soil.

"However, the polluted soil still presents a health threat to humans and animals as there is no effective way of decomposing the substance, " said Chang-Chien Guo-pin, director of the CSU's Super Micro Mass Research and Technology Center.

Dioxin, a general term for a group of hundreds of highly persistent chemicals, is a by-product emitted in the production of herbicides, disinfectants and other agents. Dioxin has proven capable of causing cancer and other diseases in humans.

Chang-Chien noted that the project was first initiated when a CSU team found that hundreds of bacterium species can survive and prosper in dioxin-laced soil, indicating that some of them must have the ability to "digest" and live off the chemical.

Later, Chang-Chien continued, they decided to cooperate with microbiologists from NSYSU to differentiate the various species -- among the several candidate bacteria, only one can break down the chemical with great efficiency, while the others work too slowly to attain economies of scale.

The bacterium -- which Chang-Chien declined to identify as the patent application for the cultivation and purging process is still undergoing review -- is under intense scrutiny by the researchers to determine if it can also work at the same efficacy and efficiency outside the laboratory.
"Once the method proves workable, it will save billions of dollars that would otherwise have to be spent on removing polluted soil," said Chang-Chien.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many products from Honduras, El Salvador to be tariff free

TEXT.P: A number of products imported from El Salvador and Honduras will have import tariffs exempted from early next year or within the next five, 10, or 15 years, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Wednesday.

The Legislative Yuan approved a package of amendments to the General Rules on Customs Import Tariffs a day earlier, regulating tariff exemptions on 10,500 industrial and 1,337 agricultural products from the two countries from next year, the official of the MOF's Department of Customs Administration said.
Items such as T-shirts, men's underwear, catfish slices, frozen shark fins and fish tails, are all included on the exemption list.

Meanwhile, 220 sensitive products with tariff quotas, such as pineapples, mangoes, cigarettes, compact cars, as well as sugar with tariff quotas, have been excluded from the exemption list in order to protect domestic industry, the official said.
Taiwan signed free trade agreements (FTAs) with Honduras and El Salvador, both of which are diplomatic allies of Taiwan, in May this year, the official said.

The amendments also stipulate that 14 imported products, including noni juice from Panama -- which signed an FTA with Taiwan in 2004 -- be exempt from import tariffs from January, while another 38 products from Panama will have import tariffs removed gradually within three or five years, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man charged with forcing Indonesian women to work as prostitutes

TEXT.P: A man in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, and his Indonesian girlfriend were charged Wednesday with forcing four other Indonesian women to work as prostitutes.

Agents from a mobile unit of the Coast Guard Administration in Chiayi County arrested Wang Wen-chin, 39, and his girlfriend, nicknamed "Linlin," at a defunct eatery in Linnei township for luring the Indonesian women into prostitution by offering them work in Taiwan.
Local police who took over the case said Wang closed his eatery of five years in March because of the economic recession and switched to operating a brothel.

Police officers, who declined to disclose the identities of the Indonesian women, said Wang and his girlfriend lured the four Indonesian women into Taiwan with job offers, but forced them to work as prostitutes.
Wang denied that the Indonesian women were working under duress. Police are continuing the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for support for DPP in legislative elections

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called Wednesday for voters to support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its candidates so that the DPP can garner 50 seats in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

The president, who doubles as DPP chairman, made the appeal prior to a weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee. Chen, along with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu-lan, also shouted campaign slogans.

Chen said the next legislature will adopt a "single-member constituency, two- vote" electoral system for the first time, in which voters will cast their first ballot for their preferred regional legislator and a second for their favored political party. The 225-member legislature will also be cut by half to 113 seats.

"Voters are being given an extra privilege and choice to end the chaos in the legislature and stabilize the political situation, " he said, referring to the constant bickering in the opposition-dominated legislature, which has stalled the review of major bills for several years, in some cases.
He urged the voters to endorse the DPP so that it can win at least 35 regional seats. This, coupled with 15 at-large seats, would ensure the party its target of 50 seats.
Should DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh win the March 22 presidential election, he will be able to make the DPP a stable majority in the legislature, Chen said.

The president also said the legislative elections will be a battle between the DPP's "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" stance and the opposition Kuomintang's "eventual unification with China" position.

Each ballot will be crucial, Chen went on, adding that according to the current electoral system, any political parties that fail to receive more than 5 percent of the ballots cast will be ineligible for the distribution of at-large seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to be late bloomer in corporate branding

TEXT.P: Taiwan's corporations have only recently begun branding themselves, but hope to catch up with the strongest brand names around the world, trade officials and corporate leaders said Wednesday.

"While earning meager profits, Taiwanese companies have to upgrade themselves from OEMs (original equipment manufacturers) to OBMs (original brand manufacturers) sooner or later, " Hsu Chun-fang, Deputy Director of Bureau of Foreign Trade, said in a year-end review of the "Branding Taiwan" campaign.
Recognizing that branding will be the next step for Taiwanese businesses, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) launched a seven-year Branding Taiwan campaign in 2006 with a NT$1.6 billion budget.

The campaign focuses on helping SMEs (small and medium enterprises), rather than companies that have already made their mark and possess strong brand names, such as computer hardware manufacturers Acer Inc. and Asustek Computer, which ranked as the top brand name in Taiwan in 2007 with a value of US$1.196 billion.

Nonetheless, the brand value of Taiwan's top-rated Asustek is far less than that of the American car-renting company Hertz, which ranked last on the list of the world's Top 100 brand names this year with a brand value of US$3.3 billion, showing how far Taiwanese companies lag behind in brand development, said Chao Yuan-chuan, chief executive officer of Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
"Taiwan has a long way to go to catch up with the development of international brands. We're latecomers, but at least we're now on our way, " Hsu said.

Most Taiwanese SMEs realized that branding is a road they have to travel if they are serious about staying competitive, but they lack the necessary budget, an essential factor in building up a brand name and expertise, Chao said.

That was where the Branding Taiwan campaign comes in, said Chiu Yi-cheng, General Manager of Kiddie's Paradise Inc., a child educational equipment provider which started to build up its own "Weplay" brand in 1999. The company is now selling its products in 50 countries around the world.

Taiwanese designers and inventors have been doing well in international invention shows and design competitions -- such as the iF and Red Dot competition in Germany -- Chiu said. With its already-strong manufacturing sector, Taiwan will be in an excellent position to develop more international brands if it can integrate the various value chains of different sectors, he added.

Chao encouraged SMEs intending to go into corporate branding to first identify their niche markets and products in order to put their money in the right place. Corporations were also encouraged to develop their brand names in Taiwan before taking them international. Partnerships between several SMEs to develop a brand is also an option, he said.

"For example, A Team, the leading Taiwan cycling industry association, which includes bicycle manufacturers Giant, Merida and others, has been influential and important in the cycling world because of their strong partnership," Chao said.

The combined brand value of this year's top 20 Taiwanese brands exceeds NT$280.5 billion (US$8.443 billion) , representing a 33 percent increase over last year's NT$211 billion (US$6. 464 billion). The brand valuation was organized by the MOEA and conducted by TAITRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business in science park is booming

TEXT.P: Business is booming in the Lungtang section of Hsinchu Science Park, in northern Taiwan, with its output totalling NT$23.1 billion (US$710 million) as of October 2006, according to Hsinchu Science Park Administration.
The Lungtang park, which originally occupied 76 hectares, has been expanded to 106 hectares due to the strong demand from new enterprises looking to establish operations there.
With a current workforce of 3,200, the Lungtang park is expected to attract investment worth NT$300 billion by 2010, generating output worth NT$100 billion and creating more than 10,000 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister suggests president visit Guatemala in January
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/07 21:48:36 (By J. P. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said here Tuesday that he will suggest President Chen Shui-bian attend the Jan. 14, 2008 inauguration of Guatemala's President-elect Alvaro Colom to further Taiwan's overall diplomatic interests.
As Guatemala is an important ally of Taiwan in Central America, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs hopes that a high-level delegation will be sent to the ceremony, Huang said.
However, Huang said that the Presidential Office has yet to confirm whether Chen will attend the inauguration or whether an envoy will take part in the event on his behalf.
Huang confirmed that Chen will also visit some neighboring countries in Central America or the Caribbean if the president decides to visit Guatemala.
But Huang denied speculation that his just-concluded trip to Panama, the Dominican Republic and Haiti was aimed at making arrangements for Chen's possible visits to Panama and the Dominican Republic.

It was reported that Chen might embark on a trip to Central America Jan. 12 -- the day when the elections of the seventh Legislative Yuan are to be held. Chen also serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to earmark NT$1 billion to attract foreign tourists

TEXT.P: The government will earmark NT$1 billion (about US$31 million) within the next two years to attract foreign tourists to Taiwan, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chang made the announcement after the Executive Yuan approved a plan titled "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" at a Cabinet meeting earlier in the day.
The plan is aimed at attracting 4.25 million tourist arrivals to Taiwan by 2009, Chang said, adding that the plan is expected to generate revenues amounting to NT$192.1 billion.

The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications proposed the plan to the Cabinet to capitalize on upcoming sporting events in the area, with the Chinese capital of Beijing hosting the Olympic Games in 2008, while the southern port city of Kaohsiung in Taiwan will host the 2009 World Games, and Taipei hosting the 2009 Summer Deaflympics, Chang said.
Under the plan, the bureau will launch seasonal theme activities to promote Taiwan's festivals and food, Chang noted.
In addition, Chang said that the bureau will also launch a number of tour packages to invite foreign tourists to explore many parts of Taiwan.
Furthermore, the bureau will hire local celebrities to help attract tourists from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Malaysia, Chang went on.
The tourism bureau will also launch hotel packages targeting tourists who make transit stopovers in Taiwan, Chang added.
Chang said that the government will also offer subsidies to foreign cruise ships that stopover at Taiwan's ports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lions Clubs International asked to rectify Taiwan's designation

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday it is regrettable that Taiwan's designation in the Lions Clubs International has been changed to "China Taiwan" simply because China wishes to be a member of this charity-minded organization.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Mahendra Amarasuriya, president of the Lions Clubs International (LCI), accompanied by executives of Taiwan's Lions Clubs at the Presidential Office.

Without the consent of Taiwan's Lions Club, one of the top three non- governmental organizations in Taiwan, the LCI changed its designation in the organization from "ROC Lions Club" to "China Taiwan Lions Club" in 2002 under pressure from China.

Noting that Taiwan is a sovereign country, Chen stressed that Taiwan and China are separate countries that do not belong to each other, and this is the reality of the status quo between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
"It is unacceptable to the 23 million people of Taiwan to arbitrarily change Taiwan's designation in the CLI just because of China's desire to join this world organization," Chen added.

All members of Taiwan's Lions Club hope that Taiwan's designation in the LCI will soon be changed to "Taiwan", with its headquarters having established a task force to push for the rectification of Taiwan's designation in the organization.

Chen stressed that Taiwan also welcomes China's joining the LCI, but the status quo between the two sides of Taiwan Strait should not be altered. He also expressed hope that Amarasuriya and all of the LCI's executives will pay heed to the voices of the 23 million people in Taiwan and acknowledge that the country is not part or a province of China and do not want to be excluded or downgraded.

Responding to Chen's call, Amarasuriya said he recognizes Taiwan is an independent and sovereign country, and as the head of the LCI, promised that he will seriously listen to the opinions of members of Taiwan's Lions Clubs and render assistance in this regard in accordance with the regulations of LCI.
The Lions Clubs International is the world's largest volunteer service organization, with 1.3 million members scattered around 201 countries and geographic areas worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kitchen scraps to net NT$40 million for Tainan city government

TEXT.P: Kitchen wastes collected in the city of Tainan are expected to generate NT$40 million in revenues for the city government over the next two years, officials with the city's Environmental Protection Bureau said Wednesday.

The officials pointed out that the biennial bidding for the rights to have the city's kitchen scraps took place a day earlier, with the contract awarded to the highest bidder, a hog raiser in Rende township, Tainan County, who offered to pay NT$2.6 per kilogram -- nearly five times as much as the previous winning bid two years ago.
They noted that the competition was keen, as the number of bidders increased from three in 2005 to nine this year.
If the quantity of kitchen waste collected in Tainan remains at the same level as in the past two years, the new contract will net NT$40 million for the city government, the officials said.
They attributed the windfall to recent prices hikes, which have made kitchen scraps comparatively cheap as hog feed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elections to end in chaos if alternate voting systems used: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian warned Wednesday that if different voting formats are adopted in the upcoming legislative elections, the outcome will be endless disputes.
The president made the remarks while attending an anti-graft seminar sponsored by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen noted that during past elections, cities and counties adopted the same voting system regardless of which political party was in charge, saying that only by adopting an identical system can the outcome of the elections be accepted by all.
But if the election process and voting system differ from one city to another, then the election is bound to end in chaos and disputes, the president said.
He said that the Central Election Commission (CEC) has decided to adopt a "one- step" voting system for the January 12 legislative elections, and local government should abide by that decision.
He regretted that some cities and counties have insisted on a "two-step" voting system, which he said goes beyond their legal authority and may even violate the Criminal Law.

He said that the election work cannot be completed by the city or county chiefs alone, and it will be "quite irresponsible" if they act rashly and leave the conduct of the election to election staff alone.

He stressed that according to the Constitution, the Election and the Recall Law, and the Referendum Law, the CEC will be in charge of the January 12 legislative elections and the CEC will monitor the conduct of local election commissions in handling the elections."
Since the CEC has decided to adopt the "one-step" voting format in accordance with the law, local governments should abide by its decision, according to Chen.

He cited a recent public opinion poll as showing that 56.2 percent of the people support the CEC's decision to adopt a "one-step" voting system, while 56.6 percent of the people think that the decision of some cities and counties to boycott the "one-step" system is "inappropriate."
Under the "one-step" voting format, voters will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and two referendum ballots at different desks and then cast them into four different boxes.

Eighteen "pan-blue"-controlled localities have insisted that they will use the "two-step" format under which voters will receive and cast referendum ballots only after they have cast their ballots for the legislative elections, claiming that the "one-step" format could cause confusion and chaos during the voting process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Widespread support for teacher sued for searching pupil's backpack

TEXT.P: Education agencies as well as teachers' and parents' groups have thrown their support behind a teacher who was recently acquitted of a privacy infringement charge for inspecting a student's backpack.

The support came after the parents of a student filed a lawsuit against a homeroom teacher, surnamed Lei, at a junior high school in Taipei City for violating their child's privacy rights by searching the student's backpack. They asked for NT$1 million in compensation.
However, the Taipei District Court ruled in favor of Lei on the grounds that searching backpacks is part of a teachers' duty to provide student counseling and guidance.

Yang Yi-fung, a spokesman for the National Teachers' Association asserted that teachers have the right to conduct searches in accordance with a tobacco and drug prevention project formulated by the Ministry of Education, adding that if there is something wrong, the responsibility lies with policy makers, not policy implementers.
The spokesman said that from the perspective of the law, there was nothing wrong with the teacher's actions, and urged the public not to make too much of a simple legal case.

Meanwhile, Lin Wen-hu, deputy director of the National Alliance of Parents organization, said that the court ruling guarantees the scope of teacher's legitimate power to educate students. But he stressed that teachers should be attended by a class representative or a third party while conducting a search of a student's personal property.

An official with the Taipei city government's Department of Education also noted that teachers and instructors are empowered to search students' backpacks in the event of emergency situations or for the sake of campus safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: No option other than 'one-step' voting method: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Wednesday in a weekly Executive Yuan meeting that the decision made by some local units of the Central Election Commission (CEC) to adopt a"two-step" voting method in two elections early next year is invalid.

Chang stressed that the Executive Yuan, in accordance with the law, has no other option but to adopt a CEC-designed "one-step" voting format for the Jan. 12 legislative polls and March 22 presidential election.

In keeping with the basic spirit of the division of power in a democratic nation, the Executive Yuan must fully abide by the decision jointly made by the CEC members, Chang said, expressing his hope that an agreement will soon be reached between the central and some local governments concerning the voting format dispute so as to allow the elections to be held smoothly.

In compliance with the Public Officials Election and Recall Act and the Referendum Law, the CEC is authorized to organize and supervise the two elections in 2008 -- each to be accompanied by two referendums, Chang said, insisting that local CEC branches are not entitled to make their own decisions regarding the voting method.

The Executive Yuan has asked the CEC to do its best to negotiate with its local units to resolve the voting format dispute as soon as possible, he said, adding that "we do not want to see Taiwan's hard-won democracy undermined."

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said following the Cabinet's weekly meeting that the Executive Yuan is set to replace CEC branch chiefs who insist on applying a "two-step" voting scheme in the two approaching polls on charges of breaching Article 153 of the Criminal Code.

Responding to reporters' questions concerning the premier's remark that the central government will seek to talk over the issue with 18 local governments controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) favoring the "two-step" method, Shieh replied that "there is no such plan at present" and asserted that "two different voting methods will not be tolerated in the same election."
Local authorities should comply with the CEC's decision on applying the "one- step" voting format, and there is absolutely no room for compromise on this front, he said.

As to the question of how a task force led by Vice Premier Chiou I-jen would deal with the voting method impasse between central and local authorities, Shieh replied that "an answer is due next Monday."
KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin refused to respond to the Executive Yuan over what he called the central government's flip-flops.
"It is hard for us to respond to an inconsistent Executive Yuan, which said it would negotiate, but later threatened to replace CEC branch chiefs," he said.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Tuesday that local CEC unit chiefs would be prosecuted for "inciting others to defy a superior's orders" under Article 153 of the Criminal Code if they continue to reject the "two-step" voting format.

Chang also said that if the "two-step" format is used in some localities, the winners, and the legality, of the legislative and presidential elections must be determined jointly by the CEC members within one week of the poll. "Only results confirmed by the CEC are valid," he emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes progress in AIDS patients' human rights: civic groups

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made progress in protecting AIDS patients' human rights by allowing patients without household registrations to stay in Taiwan to file appeals to their deportation, a representative of civic groups for AIDS patients' rights said Wednesday.

Lin Yi-huei, secretary-general of the Persons with HIV/AIDS Rights Advocacy Association of Taiwan held a news conference on the same day to announce five top news stories dealing with AIDS issues, as selected by 15 civic groups. Reports on the right of AIDS patients to submit their appeals before deportation were among the five top AIDS-related news events.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Lawmaker Huang Shu-ying pointed out that previous AIDS Prevention and Control Act stipulated that foreign spouses, diplomats or expatriate students without household registrations in Taiwan, if found to have been infected with HIV, were to be deported before submitting an appeal.
Those who have annulled their previous nationalities thereby became stateless persons under the previous regulations, Huang said.

Social worker Yeh Chieh-yu expressed pessimism concerning the amendments, which were passed in July, saying that the association helped two foreign spouses infected with HIV to submit their appeals before being deported, but neither appeal was successful.

"A successful appeal does not necessarily guarantee a patient's long-term stay in Taiwan and the acquiring of Taiwanese nationality," Yeh said. She explained that a foreign spouse affected by HIV has to prove to the Department of Health that the disease came from his or her Taiwanese spouse, and then apply for Taiwanese nationality from the National Immigration Agency.

The other four top news stories dealt with the content of the amendments, the Harmony Home Association that houses AIDS patients being permitted to remain where it is in Taipei City, the launch of an AIDS medical card for AIDS patients' privacy, and an Investigation Bureau trainee with HIV being forced to leave the organization because of his HIV status, Lin said.

These five top news stories reflected the various concerns of a variety of civic groups, Lin said, adding that the association will continue to pay close attention to these stories to further improve the protection of the right of people with AIDS in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seed company wins 2008 Presidential Agriculture Award for innovation

TEXT.P: Local Known-You Seed Co. in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, and Wan Hsiung, a former Agricultural Research Institute director-general, have won the 2008 Presidential Agriculture Awards, for innovation and service, respectively, an agricultural official said Wednesday.
The awards ceremony will be held in February next year, the official said.
The seed company has pursued research and development on fruit, especially melons, and won many awards at international agricultural competitions with it's innovative work, the official said.

For his part, Wan has spent nearly 60 years in agriculture, and has made great contributions to rice production, international exchanges in agriculture, and the nurturing of domestic agricultural personnel.

The Presidential Agricultural Awards, organized by the Council of Agriculture, are designed to recognize individuals and teams that have made outstanding contributions in the field of agriculture, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidates publicize 2nd economic construction blueprint

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, stressed in his second economic construction blueprint Wednesday that if elected, he will work to promote industrial reform and innovation, and push Taiwan to join in the global economic integration.
Ma and his running mate, Vincent Siew, jointly publicized their blueprint earlier in the day after Ma made public elements of his economic platform in late November.

Major topics in the blueprint include promoting traditional industrial reforms, pushing the service sector to become an employment driver in Taiwan, seeking to normalize economic and trade ties with China, seeking to integrate business opportunities in the Taiwan Strait area with those in global markets, and carrying out efforts to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide.

The KMT candidates' plan to pursue cross-strait normalization, which they described as their key strategy to break through the current deadlock blocking regional cooperation, drew the attention of the local and foreign media, and raised questions as to whether the plan might contradict Ma's remarks during his visit to the United States and Europe in 2006, when he said that Taiwan won't conduct talks with Beijing unless the latter dismantles missiles targeting Taiwan.
Questioned on this point, Ma said the normalization of cross-strait economic ties and dismantling of missiles are two different matters which can be dealt with separately.

As the Democratic Progressive Party government has not touched on the missile issue while engaging in talks with Beijing about offering charter flight services between the two sides, Ma said he thinks it is not necessary to bring up the missile problem during cross-strait negotiations on economic issues.

If elected, he will at once begin efforts to normalize Taiwan's economic ties with China, Ma added, noting that he will need more time to address issues concerning means of ending the hostility between the two sides in a drive to seek regional peace.

Ma reiterated that if the KMT regains power next year, it will act to resume cross-strait negotiations based on the 1992 Consensus, which refers to an understanding between the two sides that there is only one China, with both sides free to make their own interpretation of what "one China" actually means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to unveil series of activities in 2008-2009 Tour Taiwan Years

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau will launch a series of activities, including inviting 99 foreign couples to the scenic Mt. Houhuan in central Taiwan and providing foot massages to 1,000 people at the Taipei Arena, to promote tourism, bureau director-general Janice Lai said Wednesday.

She noted that Mt. Houhuan, bordering Hualien and Nantou counties, is one of the major attractions in Taiwan, while providing 1,000-people with foot massages -- a distinctive way of remaining healthy in Taiwan -- will bring publicity and an entry in the Guinness Book of World Records.
Lai made the remarks when reporting on the "2008-2009 Tour Taiwan Years" project. Lai is the executive director of the project.
She expressed hope that through such promotions the number of foreign tourists will grow by 7 percent in the next two years, and tourism revenues will reach NT$390 billion (US$12.03 billion).

Lai said that the bureau is also preparing to increase subsidies, to draw foreign visitors, noting that a subsidies of NT$30 million (US$926,000) have already provided for 100 charter planes bearing 15,000 visitors this year and that subsidies will be raised to NT$50 million next year to bring 20,000 visitors.

Foreign cruise ships will also be given subsidies if they make stopovers in Taiwan, Lai said, adding that the plan, which will be put into practice in next July, will provide US$10,000 in subsidies for cruise ships bear 500 passengers, and US$30,000 for 2,000 passengers.

Meanwhile, to encourage foreign travel agencies to promote tourism in Taiwan, the Tourism Bureau will share some expenses for printing Taiwanese tourism package folders or running Taiwan tourism ads, Lai said.

She also said that the 2009 Deaflympics and the 2009 World Games in Taiwan will help promote tourism in Taiwan. Other international sports events, such as baseball championships, marathons as well as cycling races, will also help to draw visitors.
To develop a broad tourism base, the tourism bureau will also promote winter golfing trips to Taiwan in Japan and South Korean.
Targeting those who enjoy rail travel, the Tourism Bureau will also have high speed rail, Taiwan Railway travel and steam rail package tours.

Noting that Taiwan's popular singing group F4 has a great following in Japan and South Korea, they will ask the group to serve as spokesman for Taiwan's tourism, while popular singer Jolin will serve as the spokeswoman in Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia.

To make use of 2 million visitors making transit stops in Taiwan every year, the tourism bureau will also cooperate with air carriers to offer short-stay packages, for instance a US$97 tour of Taiwan, or half-day tour activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 20, or the 11th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven- member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."
