DOC.HEADLINE: Lions Clubs International asked to rectify Taiwan's designation

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday it is regrettable that Taiwan's designation in the Lions Clubs International has been changed to "China Taiwan" simply because China wishes to be a member of this charity-minded organization.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Mahendra Amarasuriya, president of the Lions Clubs International (LCI), accompanied by executives of Taiwan's Lions Clubs at the Presidential Office.

Without the consent of Taiwan's Lions Club, one of the top three non- governmental organizations in Taiwan, the LCI changed its designation in the organization from "ROC Lions Club" to "China Taiwan Lions Club" in 2002 under pressure from China.

Noting that Taiwan is a sovereign country, Chen stressed that Taiwan and China are separate countries that do not belong to each other, and this is the reality of the status quo between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
"It is unacceptable to the 23 million people of Taiwan to arbitrarily change Taiwan's designation in the CLI just because of China's desire to join this world organization," Chen added.

All members of Taiwan's Lions Club hope that Taiwan's designation in the LCI will soon be changed to "Taiwan", with its headquarters having established a task force to push for the rectification of Taiwan's designation in the organization.

Chen stressed that Taiwan also welcomes China's joining the LCI, but the status quo between the two sides of Taiwan Strait should not be altered. He also expressed hope that Amarasuriya and all of the LCI's executives will pay heed to the voices of the 23 million people in Taiwan and acknowledge that the country is not part or a province of China and do not want to be excluded or downgraded.

Responding to Chen's call, Amarasuriya said he recognizes Taiwan is an independent and sovereign country, and as the head of the LCI, promised that he will seriously listen to the opinions of members of Taiwan's Lions Clubs and render assistance in this regard in accordance with the regulations of LCI.
The Lions Clubs International is the world's largest volunteer service organization, with 1.3 million members scattered around 201 countries and geographic areas worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kitchen scraps to net NT$40 million for Tainan city government

TEXT.P: Kitchen wastes collected in the city of Tainan are expected to generate NT$40 million in revenues for the city government over the next two years, officials with the city's Environmental Protection Bureau said Wednesday.

The officials pointed out that the biennial bidding for the rights to have the city's kitchen scraps took place a day earlier, with the contract awarded to the highest bidder, a hog raiser in Rende township, Tainan County, who offered to pay NT$2.6 per kilogram -- nearly five times as much as the previous winning bid two years ago.
They noted that the competition was keen, as the number of bidders increased from three in 2005 to nine this year.
If the quantity of kitchen waste collected in Tainan remains at the same level as in the past two years, the new contract will net NT$40 million for the city government, the officials said.
They attributed the windfall to recent prices hikes, which have made kitchen scraps comparatively cheap as hog feed.

DOC.HEADLINE: President rebukes opposition for pushing 'money pit' bills

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lambasted the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -led "pan- blue alliance" Thursday for promoting a series of so-called "money pit" bills that favor special, minority groups ahead of the legislative and presidential elections.

Pointing to one bill that would provide more than 350,000 veteran households that do not own a home with a home purchase subsidy of NT$3.2 million (US$98,462) per household, Chen noted that the bill, if passed, would cost NT$1.12 trillion -- a sum equivalent to the central government's total revenue for a whole year.
The amount is sufficient to cover the construction costs of two high-speed railways or the costs of the National Health Insurance program for eight years, according to Chen.

Chen said the move by the opposition goes against the principle of fairness and justice because it creates a "privileged class" formed by veterans and their families -- which have traditionally been supporters of the KMT -- at the expense of the welfare of the vast majority of the country's citizens.
The president made the remarks in an article titled "Welfare for a Minority of the People is Privilege" that appears in the latest issue of his online newsletter.

Chen said that during his recent visits to rural areas in central and southern Taiwan, he often met farmers and workers who raised doubts over the government's policy to provide a living allowance of NT$13,550 per month to veterans and medical subsidies to veterans and their families, while elderly farmers only receive NT$6,000 per month.

He pointed out that over the past seven years, the Democratic Progressive Party administration has been launching various welfare programs targeting senior citizens and workers in an effort to balance such a biased policy, which has existed since the former KMT administration.
Still, the benefits enjoyed by average citizens remain small compared with those enjoyed by military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers, Chen said.

He noted that for decades, retired military personnel, civil servants and public school teachers had enjoyed an unreasonable 18 percent annual interest rate for their deposits, adding that veterans are receiving NT$13,550 per month in living allowance.
Also, even before the National Health Insurance program was launched, veterans and their families already enjoyed government subsidies for their medical bills, he said.
In addition, the former KMT government spent NT$80 billion in compensation for veterans and NT$500 billion on the reconstruction of residential communities for military personnel and their families.

Urging the KMT not to allow an unrestricted continuation of the "privileges" enjoyed by a small minority of people, Chen said every citizen in this country has a responsibility and obligation to contribute to the establishment of a long-lasting, universal social welfare system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slump on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slumped Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 157.23 points, or 1.96 percent, to close at 7,857.08.
The bourse opened at 8,044.17 and fluctuated between 8,048 and 7,840.71 during trading. A total of 3.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.17 billion (US$2.74 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 2.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.8 percent, and textile stocks at 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 284, with 403 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls on NCA to reinforce Taiwan-centric identity

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the National Cultural Association (NCA) Thursday to reinforce national identity and Taiwan-centric consciousness.
Chen, who also serves as chairman of the NCA, made the remarks while presiding over a general assembly of the civic organization.

Noting that the NCA has played its various roles well since its establishment in 1991, Chen urged the organization to continue serving as the bridge between the government and the private sector to deepen the nation's cultural education and exchanges with other countries.
Chen also called on the organization to assist in diversifying Taiwan's cultural industry, expanding the public's world view and building Taiwan's image as a cultural power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official defends decision to sell Chinese Bank to HSBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top financial regulatory official defended Thursday the government's decision to pay NT$47.49 billion (US$1.46 billion) to HSBC Holding PLC for it to take over the debt-ridden Chinese Bank, saying it is a "fair price."

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, made the remarks one day after the government-owned Central Depository Insurance Corp. (CDIC) began the process of selling Chinese Bank, which is part of the Rebar Group. The government assigned the CDIC to take over the struggling bank in the wake of a bank run crisis triggered by the insolvency of two other companies under the Rebar Group in January.
Hu said that he "has done his best to ensure that the government pays less," adding that "it is a fair price judging from the asset quality of Chinese Bank."
Chinese Bank had NT$29.7 billion more debt than assets as of Oct. 31, according to the Financial Supervisory Commission.
Hu pointed out that when the government approved the establishment of 16 new banks in 1990, the fate of some newly established banks "had been sealed."

He said that the FSC will promote an amendment to the Bank Law when the new legislature begins its first session in February so that the government will have a legal basis to step in and monitor potentially problematic banks early.
If the amendment to the law passes, then when a bank's capital adequacy ratio falls below 8 percent, a capital increase will be compulsory, Hu said.

On collecting embezzled funds from fugitive tycoon Wang You-theng, founder and owner of the Rebar Group, Hu said that the government will definitely not allow him to get away with the billions of dollars he allegedly embezzled from the 70-odd companies under his group.
He said the government will offer big rewards or employ other means to retrieve the money from Wang, who is currently hiding in the United States with his wife.
Hu cited the example of second-hand smoke litigation in the United States, saying that a superb legal team can help win a thorny case and help plaintiffs receive a high amount of compensation.
Speaking on reports that foreign banks have frozen Wang's assets to the amount of US$2.96 million, Hu said that Taiwan was informed of the matter through judicial personnel in Europe.

The FSC will work with the Bankers Association of the Republic of China and creditor banks to offer lucrative incentives to attract capable personnel to facilitate the debt collection process, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: With Beijing Olympics approaching, concern grows over human rights

TEXT.P: As the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games approaches, the international community, including the European Union and non-government organizations (NGOs) such as Human Rights Without Frontiers (HRWF) , has organized a series of events to highlight criticism and concerns on China's poor human rights record.

Given that economic and cultural ties between the EU and China have become ever- more closely linked in recent years, the EU confirmed in a recent meeting that it is mulling whether to lift its arms sales embargo against China. However, a resolution unanimously adopted by the European Parliament Dec. 13 clearly states that it will not rashly lift the embargo, as a result of China's poor human rights situation.

The resolution also expresses regret over the European Council and European Commission's lack of success in raising their numerous human rights concerns "in a firm manner" with the Chinese authorities during the 10th EU-China Summit held Nov. 28, and their failure to take opportunity of the approaching Beijing Olympics to pressure China into improving its human rights situation.

In addition, a hearing on the human rights situation in China organized by the Brussels-based HRWF and the political group Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE), was held Dec. 18 in the European Parliament, which concluded that there has been no progress in the country's human rights record since Beijing was awarded the Olympics in 2001.

Addressing the hearing, Hungarian Member of the European Parliament (MEP) and ALDE member Istvan Szent-Ivanyi said that in order to see some real progress in the human rights situation in China "it requires a stronger and more united effort on behalf of the international community to call on China to respect its commitments, " according to the press release from the HRWF.

At the end of the event, the MEPs and 12 NGOs that participated signed a declaration criticizing the "lack of progress" made by China in a number of areas, including Internet censorship and human rights abuses.

According to a report from Agence France Presse, Chinese cyber-dissident Wang To-chia, who criticized the government over human rights abuses ahead of the Olympics, was detained Dec. 19, while Amnesty International reported that property owner Wang Ling was recently given 15 months of "re-education through labor" for signing petitions and preparing banners to protest over the demolition of her property for Olympic construction projects.

These cases, along with many others, not only prove the regression of the human rights situation in China but also underscore the urgent need for action with just eight months to go before the Olympics.

Because of this, the European Union and many NGOs such as the HRWF, Reporters Without Frontiers and Amnesty International have been making this issue the center of their work and hope to induce more pressure and criticism on the Chinese authorities to honor the promises of reform they made in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambling bill fails to clear legislative floor

TEXT.P: A bill on gambling that calls for the opening of casinos on Taiwan's outlying islands if a majority of the residents there consent failed to clear the legislative floor Thursday.

The bill, which is an amendment to an act governing the development of the outlying islands, was not passed at the legislative meeting, with 84 of the 149 legislators present saying nay, 57 saying yea and eight abstaining.

According to the bill, initiated by the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) , if a majority of the residents on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu consent to the opening of casinos in their hometowns, the central government could grant permits to international tourism hotels to operate casinos and other gambling businesses there as part of efforts to rekindle tourism in those areas.
The local government of Penghu has been pushing for the passage of the bill, while the NPSU lawmakers were hoping it could be passed before the Legislative Yuan adjourns its current session Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential election law amended to allow recount

TEXT.P: The Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law was amended Thursday to allow a recount in a presidential election if the difference in the vote shares of the top two candidates falls within 0.3 percent.

The amended law stipulates that in the event of such a situation, the candidate with the smaller number of votes can file a court petition within seven days for a seizure of all or some of the ballots.
The court should finish recounting the seized ballots within 40 days and should then notify the Central Election Commission (CEC) of the result.
The amendment also requires a candidate who petitions for a recount to pay a deposit of NT$3 per vote, which will be forfeit if the results of the recount do not change the election outcome.
The amendment also states that no recount petition will be accepted if any candidate has filed a lawsuit to challenge the election outcome.
The amended law will be implemented as soon as it is promulgated by the president.
At present, a vote recount is only possible through a lawsuit challenging the election outcome, a procedure that can take as long as a year.

The need for the establishment of a rapid procedure for vote recounts received widespread attention after the 2004 presidential election, in which the vote share of President Chen Shui-bian was only 0.24 percent higher than that of his rival, Lien Chan.
Lien filed a lawsuit to seek an annulment of the election, but the court determined Chen as the winner after months of proceedings that included a recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers trade barbs over freezing of 228 foundation budget

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators traded barbs with their opposition Kuomintang (KMT) counterparts Thursday over the opposition-dominated legislature's resolution earlier in the day to freeze funding for the 228 Memorial Foundation.

DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin said at a news conference that she felt "sad, sorry and indignant" that the 228 Memorial Foundation's NT$300 million (US$9.26 million) budget was frozen by the legislature.

Describing the 228 Incident of 1947 -- in which thousands of native Taiwanese were killed in a series of brutal crackdowns conducted by troops of the then- ruling KMT in the name of calming social unrest -- as an incident of "state violence, " Tien said the operations of the 228 Memorial Foundation are necessary and imperative "to prevent similar tragedies from happening again and to educate the people about the historical truth."
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said her colleagues at the Legislative Yuan decided to freeze the fund because they had decided the foundation's operations "lack evident intent."
Hung said the money should not have been allocated by the Ministry of Education and that the few staff of the foundation each receive a monthly salary of NT$50,000 "without doing anything."

Meanwhile, Hung quoted Ministry of Education officials as saying that the foundation is "facilitating ethnic harmony in Taiwanese society." She noted that "enhancing ethnic harmony" is already a policy of the Ministry of Education and said the work has been done with or without the help of the 228 Memorial Foundation.
Hung claimed that the funds will "very likely" be used by the DPP before the next presidential election slated for March 22 to "create more ethnic divisions."
The 228 Incident refers to a series of events in 1947 that led to a brutal crackdown by the then-KMT government against the local population, particularly the intelligentsia.

It took place in a turbulent period of Taiwan's history. In 1945, the China- based KMT government took over Taiwan -- which was at the time a Japanese colony -- when Japan surrendered to the Allied forces. But the KMT's rule was brutal and corrupt, leading to a massive protest Feb. 28, 1947, by the native Taiwanese. More troops were sent from China to crush the demonstrators and in the following months, soldiers arrested and killed thousands of people they claimed were communists or saboteurs trying to overthrow the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan capable of handling planned U.N. referendum properly: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang called for the United States Thursday to "trust in the wisdom" of the Taiwan people, saying they are capable of properly handling a planned referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
Huang, who is visiting the United States, made the remarks in a telephone interview with CNA.

His words came as the Taipei-based China Times reported that a high-ranking U.S. official, possibly Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, might again reiterate U.S. opposition to Taiwan's referendum on U.N. membership on Christmas Eve.
Earlier this month, Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, described the planned referendum as "unwise."

MOFA officials noted that the usually well-informed Nielsen Report recently reported that China has pressured the United States to reiterate its stance on Taiwan's planned referendum again, and that either President George W. Bush or Rice could voice the opposition. But they said Taiwan was informed of similar messages prior to the reports.
Huang, in the CNA interview in New York, refused to comment on "speculative reports."
He said that whether in Taiwan or in the United States, he has conveyed Taiwan's stance and that "no matter what level of U.S. official comments on the issue, the stance will not change."

Huang, who is in New York to meet with members of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, said communications with U.S. opinion leaders on Taiwan's planned referendum will enhance their understanding of Taiwan's stance.
Huang is scheduled to return to Taiwan Friday.

China and the United States have expressed concern that the planned referendum could be a step toward de jure Taiwan independence and a violation of President Chen Shui-bian's "four noes" pledge, which includes no referendum on the nation's status quo.
But Chen has said that the planned referendum is a movement from the grassroots and that he cannot buck the trend.

On widespread international opinion that the U.N. bid might change the cross- Taiwan Strait status quo, Chen said the status quo is that Taiwan is a sovereign state and that its sovereignty lies with the people.
Taiwan is not part of China, nor is it a province of China, and this fact is now more clear to the international community, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Televised legislative election debates slated for Dec. 22-23

TEXT.P: Televised legislative election debates among candidates from nine minor political parties are slated to be held Dec. 22-23, debate organizers said Thursday.

The six main organizers of the debates -- the Public Television Service (PTS) channel, CNA, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News and the Apple Daily -- made the announcement at a news conference held at CNA headquarters.

Candidates from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, the Home Party, the Hakka Party, the Green Party, the Taiwan Farmers' Party, The Third Society Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the Civic Party and the Taiwan Constitution Association will elaborate on their campaign platforms, answer questions raised by civic representatives and debate policies at the two debate sessions expected to take place at the PTS building in Taipei.
All the debates will begin at 5: 30 p.m. and end at 8 p.m., and will be televised live by PTS on Channel 13.
The legislative elections are set for Jan. 12.

The candidates are also expected to answer questions during the debates that were raised during five forums sponsored by PTS and the National Association of Community Universities, as well as other private groups, and held from Nov. 23-Dec. 9 on five issues -- the 12-year compulsory education plan, flood prevention projects and budget plans, policy on the development of local signature products and cultures, farmland development policy and career protection for indigenous people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei records 76 expressway violations by heavy motorbikes

TEXT.P: Riders of motorcycles over 550cc have committed 76 traffic violations while traveling legally on expressways in Taipei City over the past 50 days, according to tallies released Thursday by the city's traffic police.
The tallies, based on data available as of Dec. 16 after expressways were opened to heavy motorcycles Nov. 1, show that speeding accounted for 65 of the violations.

In one of the most extreme cases, a rider was caught riding at 121 kph while traveling on a section near the Huachung Bridge on the Huanhe Expressway, where the speed limit is 60 kph, traffic police said.
During the same period, the number of traffic violations by heavy motorcycles on ordinary roads amounted to 357, including 288 speeding violations, the tallies indicate.

The figures mean there was a total of 353 speeding violations by heavy motorcycles in the city during the period, accounting for 81.5 percent of all traffic violations by this type of vehicle, according to the tallies.
Since Nov. 1, heavy motorcycles have been allowed to travel on a total of 26 expressways around the country, including nine in Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGNew row with Russia over 'threat' to art
Britain was plunged into a fresh dispute with the Kremlin yesterday when Russia cancelled a blockbuster exhibition of paintings due to be held in London next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan national baseball team names new manager

TEXT.P: Hung Yi-chung was named the new manager of Taiwan's national baseball team for the Olympic Qualifying tournament next year, a spokesman for the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA) announced Thursday in a press conference.

Hung will replace Kuo Tai-yuan, who resigned Dec. 14 after Taiwan's subpar performance in the previous tournaments. The pressure to win an Olympic seed will fall on Hung's shoulder next March, when an eight-team qualifying tournament will be held in Taiwan.
Taiwan finished in eighth place in the Baseball World Cup and lost to Japan and South Korea in the Asian Baseball Championship, failing to earn an automatic seed in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

The 46-year-old La New Bears head coach will need to turn in a top three finish in the tournament, which will be held in Taichung and Yunlin from March 3-14, 2008, to earn the right to compete in Beijing.
"We will do whatever it takes [to win a place at the Olympics], " said former national team manager Hsu Sheng-ming, who served as the convener of CTBA's Selection and Training Committee.

Taiwan's roster for the tournament will have to be adjusted, CTBA Secretary- General Lin Tsun-cheng said, adding that it's expected that none of the 40 players on the rosters of U.S. Major League teams next spring will be available for the qualifying games.
Teams participating in the qualifying tournament will include Taiwan, Australia, Mexico, South Korea, Canada, England, Spain and South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF reminds businesses of possible risks to investing in China

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) called for Taiwan's business people to be on guard against the risks they may face when investing in the mainland.

The SEF issued the warning upon its publication of a book on "risks Taiwan business people cannot overlook when investing in China." The SEF is a quasi- official body set up by Taiwan to handle civilian exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal ties.
The book contains the true stories of 36 Taiwanese business people who were cheated, wronged, pressured, or even murdered after investing in China.

SEF Chairman Hung Chi-chang noted that the investment environment in China has undergone tremendous changes in recent years, citing the daunting challenges of water shortages and electricity rationing in eastern and southern China.

China's cut of export rebate rates for certain products, the unification of the income tax system for domestic and foreign businesses, rising wages, as well as the environmental protection policy for new businesses and the Labor Contract Law -- which will come into effect next year -- have all increased operating costs for enterprises and undercut their profit margins, according to Hung.

But despite the dramatic changes in China's investment environment, Hung said that tallies from the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that investment in China has continued to rise in recent years.
Even as the number of investment projects has decreased, the amount of money flowing into any single investment project has continued to rise, showing that the scale of investment has expanded.

Moreover, he said that the ratio of Taiwan's investment in China now constitutes half of Taiwan's outbound investment, surpassing combined investments in Europe, the United States, Japan and Southeast Asia.
Hung said that if the "go west" investment trend is unstoppable, then those who are keen to go must be vigilant as to the possible risks they will face once they get there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Christmas products sold in Taipei contain fluorescent penetrant

TEXT.P: Most of the Christmas products sold in Taipei's stores contain fluorescent penetrant -- a whitening agent that may endanger human health, the Consumers' Foundation warned Thursday.

Cheng Jen-hung, chairman of the Consumers' Foundation, told a press conference that foundation workers conducted tests using ultraviolet light on 21 Christmas products bought randomly from stores in Taipei and found that 20 of the samples showed a fluorescent reaction.

Cheng said that one of the products, a Christmas handbag, contains a "migratory fluorescent substance" -- an even greater hazard to consumers if absorbed into the body. The migratory fluorescent substance is known to be a cause of skin allergies and cancer.

Cheng urged related government agencies to regulate the use of fluorescent penetrants as a whitening agent on a variety of products. He added that if manufacturers are allowed to use fluorescent dyes, their products should carry such discriptions so that consumers can exercise their right to choose safer products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shifts in leadership in allies will not affect ties: MOFA

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday that shifts in the leaderships of two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific are not expected to affect ties between Taiwan and the two countries.

MOFA acting spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh made the remarks after both Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare of the Solomon Islands and President Ludwig Scotty of Nauru were ousted recently in no-confidence votes by their parliaments, with new leaders of the two countries being elected in the last few days.
Sogavare was dismissed in a 25-22 no-confidence vote Dec. 13, and new Prime Minister Derek Sikua was elected earlier Thursday.
President Chen Shui-bian immediately sent a congratulatory message to Sikua, expressing hope that the countries can further strengthen cooperative ties, Yeh said.
According to Yeh, Sikua, who has served as minister of education and training, has maintained a friendly attitude toward Taiwan and last visited Taiwan in August 2006.
Meanwhile, Scotty was ousted by more than half of the lawmakers in the Nauru Parliament in a no-confidence vote Wednesday, with Marcus Stephen elected immediately as the new president.
Stephen has invited Taiwan's Ambassador Fu Cheng-kan to attend his inauguration and has promised to continue strengthening relations with Taiwan, Yeh said.

Stephen is also familiar with Taiwan, having visited the country in March this year. His newly appointed minister of foreign affairs Kieren Keke is the son of Nauru's ambassador to Taiwan. Both of them are friendly toward Taiwan, according to Yeh.

Yeh noted that the political situations in the two countries are quite stable now and that their new leaders have maintained cordial ties with Taiwan, adding that bilateral cooperation projects will continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP invites outstanding Taiwanese to promote Taiwanese cultures

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that the civic group Taiwan Heart, which she established in 2001, is looking for 10,000 outstanding Taiwanese in a variety of professional fields to promote Taiwanese cultures.

Lu made the announcement when she met with winners of the prestigious annual Global Chinese Culture and Arts Award. The award is in recognition of artists who pass traditional arts and crafts down from one generation to the next.
Lu said she is deeply concerned with the positioning of Taiwanese cultures in the international community, especially under the impact of globalization and the magnet effect of China's power.

"After leaving the Presidential Office, I will work harder to integrate people in different areas to better present Taiwanese cultures and encourage the public's identification of Taiwan society, " said Lu, whose vice presidential term will end May 20, 2008.

"Bringing the cohesion of non-governmental power to the promotion of Taiwanese cultures will become my most important job, " Lu said, adding that she has been visiting friends with professional knowledge who have made great contributions in many fields, including industry, education, culture, child care and social welfare.

"The operation of Taiwan Heart is not connected to the elections and will cover a wide range of social and cultural events, " Lu said while inviting the award winners, whom she described as national treasures, to join the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bank sponsors university program for disadvantaged students

TEXT.P: Deutsche Bank A.G. has donated NT$1 million (US$30,760) to sponsor an online reading program initiated by Fu Jen Catholic University (FJU) to help disadvantaged students in central Taiwan, a bank spokesman said Thursday.
The announcement came one day after James Wu, president of the bank, unveiled the donation made through the Deutsche Bank Asia Foundation at a ceremony held in Taipei.

Under the terms of the reading program, 300 FJU students will form online study groups with elementary school students of 47 classes in remote areas of Miaoli County and Miaoli City, said FJU President Bernard Li, who was also present at the ceremony.

Wu said Deutsche Bank attaches great importance to assisting disadvantaged students all over the world and he expressed hope that the donation will help the students read more, while calling on more college students to commit themselves to doing charity work.
Li for his part noted that the university launched the online reading program in 2006.

Describing the collaboration project -- the first of its kind between a university and a bank -- as a good model, Li said he hopes both sides can further establish a virtual interactive learning network between university students and primary students to bridge the digital divide between rural and urban areas.

Yang Te-yuan, principal of an elementary school in Miaoli City, said at the ceremony that over the years, his school has set up Internet communities and online study groups to promote reading among its students.

However, due to insufficient numbers of teachers and books, the school's efforts have failed to achieve results, Yang went on, adding that the Deutsche Bank-FJU collaboration this year will effectively address such problems and arouse students' interest in reading.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV, computer, video games dominate children's pastimes: survey

TEXT.P: Watching television, surfing the Internet and playing video games are the major pastimes of over 90 percent of children living in the greater Taipei area, results of a public opinion poll showed Thursday.
The poll conducted by Kentucky Fried Chicken Taiwan found that 56.2 percent of children living in Taipei City, Taipei County and Keelung City pass their free time by watching television.
The poll, conducted between Dec. 7-16 by telephone, found that 37.6 percent of the children in the area pass their free time by working on computers, surfing the Internet, or playing video games.

Less than 1 percent of the children in the area read, paint, write calligraphy, or play chess -- pastimes that used to be considered as "positive and healthy" -- during their free time, the poll found.

A high 84.8 percent of parents responding to the survey believe that playing with their children is conducive to the child's cognition development, but only 26 percent of parents could afford to keep their children company. A majority of these parents could only lament over the situation, and could not do anything to improve the situation.

Nearly 80 percent of responding parents also believe that reading Chinese classical literature to their children will help in the child's mental development, but only 0.75 percent of the parents responding to the survey have done so, according to the poll results.
The islandwide poll of randomly selected families with children aged between 3 and 10 obtained 450 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to draft 1st technology development guidelines

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will draft Taiwan's first science and technology development guidelines as the country's long-term blueprint for future technological development, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday.
The decision was reached at the Executive Yuan's 27th board meeting of advisers for science and technology held in Taipei City from Monday to Thursday.

The guidelines will adopt a four-year cycle and have a periodic evaluation every two years to serve as references for the new guidelines for the following four years, Chang said, adding that the first guidelines will be effective from 2008-2011.

The Science and Technology Advisory Group (STAG) under the Executive Yuan will work with the National Science Council to design the guidelines and present the content and promotional measures to the Executive Yuan within three months, Chang said.

Comprised of prestigious local and foreign experts and scholars in science and technology, STAG provides counsel to the premier on the country's technological development, and coordinates government agencies, industry and research institutes on technology affairs.

The board meeting also decided to establish a technology decision support office to integrate official and private resources in improving the government's decision-making system related to technological development, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies lack of care for middle, working classes

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that a large proportion of new government policies launched in the past half year are aimed at improving the welfare of the middle and working classes, denying recent claims that the government has failed to attach sufficient importance to these segments of society, many of whom are having difficulty making ends meet.
Chang also said a number of bills proposed by the government to improve people's livelihoods are under review by lawmakers.
Chang's remarks came after a Ministry of the Interior official delivered a report on the results of government measures for the middle and working classes at a regular Cabinet meeting.
He said that in recent years, the government has paid greater attention to the needs of the people by allocating resources for financial aid, increasing the employment rate and improving health care.
In addition, it has made efforts to improve law and order and to offer educational assistance to students from disadvantaged families, he went on.

During his second term as premier from May this year, Chang said, he has striven to develop a sustainable economy and has focused on building a fair and just society for the benefit of the middle and working classes.
Chang previously served as premier from 2000 to 2002.
He noted that several bills and amendments related to the renovation of agricultural villages, insurance for laborers and social assistance have been sent to the legislature for review.

He added that the Cabinet has asked its ministries to step up efforts to negotiate with lawmakers to pass the bills and amendments over the next few days prior to the end of the current legislature's last session.

Chang also said that in order to realize President Chen Shui-bian's new policy declared May 14 to take care of the middle and working classes, the government has raised the minimum wage and has been helping disadvantaged job seekers during the past six months.
The government further proposed plans to extend compulsory education from nine years to 12 years and to implement a national pension scheme, Chang went on.
These measures are part of the government's efforts to build a sound social security network and to bridge the gap between the rich and the poor, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy core issue in presidential election: KMT hopeful

TEXT.P: South Korea's just-concluded presidential poll has proved that the economy was the core issue for voters there, that the public was disgusted with dirty tricks used in the elections and that they keenly hoped for a transfer of power, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.
Ma made the remarks at KMT headquarters, where he and his running mate, Vincent Siew, launched a TV election campaign advertisement.

According to Ma, the three factors that helped former Hyundai CEO and former Seoul Mayor Lee Myung-bak win a landslide victory in Wednesday's presidential election also can be found in Taiwan in the runup to the March 22 presidential election.

Although South Korea has in recent years performed much better than Taiwan in economic terms, Ma said that South Koreans' growing discontent with the economic situation over the past five years under the rule of President Roh Moon-hyun, along with his ideological strife and the dirty tricks used by the ruling party in the election were what led to Lee's electoral victory.
In Taiwan, it is "obvious" that over the past seven years, only rich people have benefited from the country's economic expansion, Ma claimed.

According to Siew, South Koreans chose Lee because of his past achievements, execution and vision, and now he needs to take action to make good on his election promises. The South Korean presidential election should provide Taiwan's people with an opportunity to reflect on their own country's present situation, he added.

In the TV presidential campaign advertisement, Ma and Siew appeal for "a strong Taiwan with a global presence." Hailing the Taiwan people's honesty, diligence and pragmatism, the pair promised that if elected, they will lead Taiwan onto the world stage, as Taiwan cannot afford to further idle away its time and further undermine its competitiveness.

Ma said Taiwan should take advantage of its strategic location at the center of East Asia to sharpen its competitiveness and added that the country must not "remain in seclusion and shut its doors to the rest of the world."
Taiwan should boost cooperation with China to seek breakthroughs in the fierce regional competition -- something Ma described as an essential part of reinvigorating the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges U.S. to heed Taiwan's desire for U.N. representation

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that a planned referendum on applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan is an expression of the collective will of Taiwan's people, and urged China and the United States to heed their voice.

The MAC's appeal was contained in a six-point statement amid reports that a U.S. ranking official may reiterate Washington's opposition to the planned referendum following remarks by Thomas Christensen, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, characterizing the plan as "unwise."

The MAC said that to seek U.N. membership under the name Taiwan is the aspiration and legitimate right of the 23 million people of Taiwan, saying it will show the collective will and resolution of Taiwan to join the international community.

The MAC said that China's hostile approach towards Taiwan has antagonized the people, noting that Beijing has blocked Taiwan's democratic development, obstructed its efforts to join international organizations, and has attempted to mislead the international community by saying that the planned referendum is tantamount to "de jure" independence.
The MAC also said that Washington's tilt toward Beijing in its policy will affect peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and hurt the feelings of Taiwan's people.

Taiwan is a sovereign, independent county and has never been a part of People's Republic of China, the MAC said, and the United States, as the leader of democratic world, should support Taiwan's democracy instead of listening to the rhetoric of an authoritarian country, the MAC said.

The MAC urged China and the United States to stop suppressing Taiwan and listen closely to the will of its people to pursue democracy, saying that their resolution to pursue democracy will not fail under any circumstances.

The MAC concluded by calling for the U.S. to safeguard Taiwan in order to promote change in China, noting that this year marks the 20th anniversary of cross-strait exchanges, that the world has witnessed the tremendous changes taking place in China, and that Taiwan has been one of the driving forces behind China's transformation.
The MAC said that Taiwan's process towards and experience of democracy can serve as references as China moves toward democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential hopeful backs 'two-step' voting method

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou claimed Thursday that according to the law, local city and county governments are responsible for holding and organizing elections.
Ma made the comments in a news conference marking the launch of a TV presidential campaign advertisement at KMT headquarters.

Asserting that in accordance with the law, the local governments' rights to hold elections and prepare the polling stations must be fully respected to ensure a smooth and orderly election, Ma encouraged local election commissions to choose the method they believe best to organize the approaching legislative and presidential elections and polling stations.
Ma gave his assurances that local election commission officials will not be breaking the law by doing so and stressed that it is necessary that elections be held smoothly and orderly.

Ma's comments came amid a fierce dispute between the central and some local governments over the voting procedure in the legislative and presidential elections, slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, 2008, respectively.

The Executive Yuan has repeatedly said that all 25 cities and counties around the country must adopt a "one-step" voting format designed by the Central Election Commission (CEC) for the two elections -- each to be accompanied by two referendums, while 18 KMT-controlled localities, including Taipei City, insist on applying a "two-step" scheme out of concern over chaos in the voting process.

Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday that local election commission chiefs will be replaced if they continue to reject the "one-step" voting method, and claimed that the Executive Yuan is set to act on the matter.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung announced Tuesday that if the coming two polls are held using a "two-step" scheme in some localities, the legitimacy of the results will have to be determined jointly by the CEC members within one week of the polling day. "Only results confirmed by the CEC are valid," he said.
In response to increased pressure from the Executive Yuan, Ma asserted that the courts, not the CEC, have the authority to annul an election.

Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin said later the same day following a meeting with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan that the city will remain firm on its decision to use the "two-step" voting method in the coming polls.

Lien, a political science expert, also backs the municipal election commission's stance to employ the "two-step" format, Hau said, adding that he has not heard of different views in this regard from other KMT-controlled cities and counties.
Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu questioned how the Executive Yuan or GIO could speak for the CEC, an independent organization, concerning electoral affairs.
Hu voiced his grave concerns that if ranking officials continue meddling in CEC affairs, it will seriously affect the normal operations of the approaching polls.

Later the same day, the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution demanding that the CEC not refuse to allocate budgets to its local branches which have decided to hold the two elections in a "two-step" voting method, rather than the CEC- prescribed "one-step" format.
The legislature approved the resolution while screening the 2008 central government budgetary bill.

Lawmakers also adopted another resolution mandating reparations from government agencies which used some of their own budgets to help finance a GIO advertisement promoting Taiwan's bid to push for U. N. membership.

In line with the resolution, government agencies must repay funds they used to help finance GIO ads in local media calling for Taiwan's U.N. membership. If they refuse to do so, they would face prosecution and have to assume relevant responsibilities, the resolution said.

Two referendums aimed at pursuing the country's U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan and seeking to have the country re-enter the world body as the Republic of China will be held along with the March 22 presidential election. They were called by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Two-step' voting format not allowed: Cabinet

TEXT.P: The government will absolutely not tolerate the adoption of a "two-step" voting format proposed by opposition Kuomintang-controlled local governments in defiance of the Central Election Commission's (CEC's) resolution to adopt a "one-step" voting procedure in the upcoming elections, Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey re-affirmed Thursday.

Noting that maintaining the rule of law and social stability is one of the government's basic principles, Shieh said that as the CEC decided to use the "one-step" procedure in accordance with the law, the government will absolutely not allow the use of the illegal "two-step" format in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential poll to avoid causing possible social unrest and election upheaval.

Shieh said that a situation of "one country, two systems" that pits the central government against local governments in elections has never occurred over the past 50 years in Taiwan and that the government will not tolerate the adoption of two different voting formats in the coming elections.

Shieh warned that if electoral officials in opposition-controlled local governments publicly declare that they will adopt the "two-step" voting format for the polls, the CEC can appoint surrogates to replace them according to Articles 7 and 8 of the Public Officials Election and Recall Act, as well as Article 153 of the Criminal Code.

Adding that the CEC is the only legitimate agency in charge of central elections and electoral affairs, Shieh said the government will follow the CEC's "one- step" voting format decision without exception.

He added that an inter-ministerial task force consisting of experts and officials from the CEC, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Justice and the National Police Agency has been formed to study in advance any possible scenarios that could sabotage the elections so as to prevent and deter any illegal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: President congratulates South Korean president-elect

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has sent a congratulatory message to Lee Myung-bak on his victory in South Korea's presidential election Wednesday, the acting spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Thursday.
According to Phoebe Yeh, Chen sent the congratulatory message upon receiving the news of Lee's victory.

Noting that Lee gave an excellent performance when he served as Seoul mayor from 2002-2006, Yeh said MOFA believes Lee will continue to excel in promoting South Korea's economic development and growth.

She expressed hope that Taiwan and South Korea can strengthen cooperation and exchanges in the political, economic, social, tourism and cultural fields in order to contribute to the security, prosperity and development of the Northeast Asian region.

Lee, who belongs to the conservative opposition Grand National Party, garnered 48.6 percent of the votes, beating Liberal Chung Dong-young with a margin of more than 20 percentage points. Lee is scheduled to be inaugurated next February.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV documentary to uncover story of Asian Gibraltar

TEXT.P: A television documentary to premiere Dec. 23 reveal the story of the Kinmen islands, the Taiwanese territory which is only two miles off the coast of China and whose history has been often forgotten or unknown, an official said Thursday.

"Given how many shells Kinmen has taken for Taiwan in the past, it's time for Taiwan and people around the world to better to understand the island, " said Yang Chung-chuan, deputy magistrate of Kinmen County, in a press conference to announce the premiere of "Unknown Kinmen, " a documentary produced by the Discovery Channel.

The documentary attempts to explore the islands, which have been described as the "Asian Gibraltar" because of its unique strategic position, through its culture, architecture and history, said Tommy Lin, vice president and general manager of Discovery Networks Asia's Taiwan Office.

Kinmen experienced extensive shelling from China in 1958, when it was hit by more than 470,000 artillery shells in the span of 44 days. Over the following 20 years, it was hit by another 500,000 non-lethal shells containing propaganda materials, Yang said.

The experience still lingers in the minds of senior citizens, but the former military preserve needs to move forward because development on Kinmen was extremely limited during the period of military rule, Yang said.

People in Kinmen did benefit somewhat from the war as nowadays it is famous for its knives, which are made from artillery shells, Yang said. The return to a civilian government in the 1990s and the launch of the Mini Three Links six years ago, which have brought many Taiwanese business people to the islands, dramatically changed the face of Kinmen's economy, he added.
"Now we thrive on the development of tourism, " he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel to build steel mill in Vietnam

TEXT.P: The China Steel Corp. (CSC) board of directors resolved Thursday to invest some US$293 million to jointly build with foreign counterparts a large steel mill in Vietnam as part of its effort to grab a piece of Vietnam's growing market for steel products.

The CSC board directors decided to channel US$293 million into Vietnam for an investment project that would include other investors, including Japan's Sumitomo Metal, to jointly build a large steel mill that would initially cost US$1.15 billion.

Commercial production at the planned steel mill is scheduled to begin in 2011, with an annual capacity of 1.7 million tons of steel products, including hot- pressed steel rolls, said Chung Lo-min, a CSC deputy CEO.

Noting that the demand for steel products has grown rapidly in Vietnam and other Indochinese countries in recent years, Chung said the investment will not only help CSC expand its exports to these countries, bypassing tariff barriers, but also help CSC gain a niche in the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA).

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU professor recruited as editor for int'l journal of materials

TEXT.P: A professor of National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in southern Taiwan's Tainan City has been appointed to the international journal Asia Materials to edit articles on electro-optical materials in Asia-Pacific area, an NCKU spokesman said Thursday.

Andy Fuh, dean of the NCKU's College of Sciences, was the only Taiwanese academic among the journal's 10 editors, all world renowned scientists, the spokesman said, adding that the journal is slated to be published next February by the publishing group Nature, an international weekly journal of science, the spokesman said.

Fuh got his doctoral degree from the University of Toronto. His research in liquid crystal electro-optical materials has won high praise and recognition in international academic circles. He also made great contribution to the industry with his invention of the world's first Polymer-Dispersed Liquid Crystal (PDLC) laser technique.

The journal will present articles covering a variety of fields including organic, soft, biomedical, electro-optical materials, energy, nano technology, and theories and calculation of materials, the spokesman said.

Target readers for the journal include scientists, engineers, chemists, and physicists, the spokesman said, adding that the journal is very likely to become the leading publication of its kind in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children could become smarter through play

TEXT.P: A childhood education expert said Thursday that children could grow smarter through meaningful play, suggesting parents to spend more time in significant play with their children.

Su Lan made the suggestion after a survey conducted by Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) Taiwan found that most of the children in the greater Taipei metropolitan area focus their entertainment on television, computer and video games.

Noting that many Taiwanese parents do not know how to play, not to mention how to educate their children through play, Su suggested that parents stimulate the potential of their children by spending more time in meaningful play with their children, such as games focused on the continuation of a story told by the other person.
Su once asked some children what is the most important thing in their life, some answered time, the other mentioned wisdom, while one child said loudly "eating and playing."

Taking advantage of this opportunity, Su told the children that it is not easy to have fun while eating and playing in a meaningful way, and encouraged them to dedicate more energy to significant things.

DOC.HEADLINE: Case of imported malaria confirmed in Pingtung County

TEXT.P: Health officials at the Pingtung County government confirmed a case of imported malaria Thursday, saying that the patient is a 35-year-old man who contracted the disease during an overseas trip.

The officials at the county government's Public Health Bureau said the patient, whose name was not disclosed, stayed in New Guinea on business from Nov. 25 to Dec. 15 and developed symptoms of malaria after returning to Taiwan.

Although the patient took some non-prescription medicines, his condition did not improve. He then sought help from a hospital, where a test confirmed that he had contracted vivax malaria, the most common of four human malaria species.
Vivax malaria is caused by Plasmodium vivax that induces paroxysms of chills and fever at 48-hour intervals. Other symptoms include headache, weakness, vomiting and diarrhea.

The disease is rarely fatal, but relapses often occur months to years after treatment because the parasites can remain dormant in the patient's liver cells, evading the body's defence system and the most commonly used drugs.
Health officials pointed out that malaria is most prevalent in Southeast Asia, South Asia, West Africa, North Africa, Central and South America, and Oceania.
They suggested that people who plan to travel to those areas take precautionary measures to avoid mosquito bites or take anti-malarial drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of passengers traveling via domestic flights drops

TEXT.P: The number of passengers traveling on domestic air routes during the January- October period fell 25.3 percent compared with the same period of last year, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The statistics also show that the number of flights on the west coast during the first 10 months of this year decreased 38.1 percent compared with the same period of last year, while the number of passengers dropped 49.6 percent.
MOTC officials attributed the significant drop to the fact that passengers prefer land transport services due to their greater convenience.

The number of domestic flights during the period reached 95,000, down 17.5 percent from the same period of last year, while the number of passengers was 5.44 million, down 25.3 percent, according to the statistics.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration has mapped out measures to help domestic carriers weather the storm of financial difficulties triggered by the air travel recession, according to the MOTC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amended employment act to benefit millions of workers: CLA

TEXT.P: The newly amended Gender Equality Employment Law, extending maternity and parental leave benefits, is expected to benefit more than 5 million local workers, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Thursday.

The announcement came one day after the Legislative Yuan passed the third and final reading of the amendments to the act, making it the first time the legislature has amended the act since its implementation March 8, 2002.

Under the amended act, all employers must allow their employees to take parental leave, without salary, yet retain their positions, which will benefit an estimated 3.14 million workers, the CLA official explained.
Companies hiring over five employees must grant family care leave to their employees, which is expected to help 1.81 million workers, the official noted.

In addition, the amendments increase paternity leave from two days to three days and forbid employers from refusing their employees to take paternity leave, the official said, forecasting that 70,000 workers will benefit from this amendment every year.
The amendments stipulate new penalties for employers who refuse to allow their employees to take menstrual leave, maternity leave, and family care leave, the official said.

Employers will also be fined if they do not allow their employees to hold their positions, without salary, during parental leave, to breast feed at work, or to reduce or adjust working hours, the official noted.

In response to criticisms that previous penalties under the act were insufficient, the amendments have raised the range of penalties from NT$10,000(US$308) -NT$100,000 to NT$100,000-NT$500,000, the official added. Meanwhile, the CLA will soon propose complementary measures to address the concerns of local small and medium-sized enterprises about the possible impact of providing employees with two-year-long parental on company operations, the official said.
The measures will also help address the tendency of local employers to hire fewer women to avoid the possible impact of maternity leave, according to the official.
According to the official, the Ministry of Interior (MOI) has begun to promote babysitting services within local communities, and plans to offer subsidies in the future.

In the future, employees will be able to seek assistance and legal counselling from local labor and social bureaus if they are laid off or unable to retain their positions due to leave taking, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to unveil NCC nomination list by end of January

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will come up with a list of candidates for the National Communications Commission (NCC) by the end of January and refer it to the legislature for confirmation, government spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Thursday.
Shieh made the remarks after the Legislative Yuan finally passed an amendment to Article 4 of the NCC Organic Law earlier in the day regarding the independent media regulatory body's composition.

The original provision stipulated that the NCC should be composed of 13 members recommended by major political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature. The controversial provision, passed in 2005, was later declared unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices on the grounds that it infringed upon the power of the executive branch.
After nearly two years of haggling between ruling and opposition parties, a compromise was finally worked out to end the controversy, with both camps making a concession.

While the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) agreed to drop its partisan "proportional representation" principle concerning the NCC setup, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gave the green light to refer the premier-proposed nomination list to the legislature for sanction.

Under the amended law, the number of NCC commissioners is cut to seven from 13, and their term of office will be extended from three years to four years. The premier will have full power to decide the nomination list, but the appointment is subject to legislative approval. The amended act does not set any ceiling on the number of terms an individual commissioner is allowed to serve.

According to Sheih, requiring legislative confirmation for the NCC nomination still constitutes an infringement upon the power of the executive branch, Nevertheless, he said, the DPP administration is willing to accept such an arrangement now that the opposition no longer insisted on its unconstitutional principle.

The incumbent NCC commissioners reaffirmed Thursday their determination to step down from the post Jan. 31 as they promised after the grand justices ruled that the media watchdog's formation was unconstitutional.

As the new legislators to be elected Jan. 12 will not take office until Feb. 1, the appointment of new NCC commissioners is not expected to be finalized before the departure of their predecessors. Shieh said the Executive Yuan will make every possible efforts to ensure the NCC operates normally during its personnel transition period.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel to build steel mill in Vietnam

TEXT.P: The China Steel Corp. (CSC) board of directors resolved Thursday to invest some US$293 million to jointly build with foreign counterparts a large steel mill in Vietnam as part of its effort to grab a piece of Vietnam's growing market for steel products.

The CSC board directors decided to channel US$293 million into Vietnam for an investment project that would include other investors, including Japan's Sumitomo Metal, to jointly build a large steel mill that would initially cost US$1.15 billion.

Commercial production at the planned steel mill is scheduled to begin in 2011, with an annual capacity of 1.7 million tons of steel products, including hot- pressed steel rolls, said Chung Lo-min, a CSC deputy CEO.

Noting that the demand for steel products has grown rapidly in Vietnam and other Indochinese countries in recent years, Chung said the investment will not only help CSC expand its exports to these countries, bypassing tariff barriers, but also help CSC gain a niche in the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA).

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in hisotry

TEXT.P: Today is Friday, Dec. 21, or the 12th day of the 11th month of Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature clears way for duty-free shops on outlying islands

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Friday the third reading of an amendment that allows duty-free shops to be set up in the country's outlying islands.

The Legislature passed the amendment to the Outlying Islands Development Act on the last day of the current legislative session by an overwhelming margin, allowing the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu to operate duty-free shops so that visitors to these areas will not have to pay any tariffs for purchases made there.

The amendment, first passed by the Executive Yuan in early December, is aimed at helping rekindle tourism on Kinmen and Matsu, which are located nearer to China than to Taiwan proper, and on Penghu, which is located in the Taiwan Strait.

Duty-free shop operations on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu are expected to kick off after the Ministry of Finance formally promulgates the amendment within three months of the Legislative Yuan passing the amendment, ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inbound foreign investment totals US$12.93 b. for first 10 months

TEXT.P: Approved inbound investment by overseas companies amounted to US$12.93 billion for the first 10 months of this year, according to a report on Taiwan's latest economic situation released Thursday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The report noted that inbound foreign investment hit a record high of US$13.97 billion for 2006, with the annual value averaging US$5.69 billion during the 2001-2006 period, twice as much as the average annual value of US$2.85 billion during the 1993-1999 period.

Referring to the World Investment Report 2007 released by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, CEPD officials said Taiwan's inward foreign direct investment ranked 31st among the 218 economies surveyed in 2006, a leap of 31 notches from the previous year.

For the first 10 months of 2007, Taiwan's exports increased 9 percent year-on- year to US$201.4 billion and imports rose 7 percent year-on-year to US$180.5 billion, with the trade surplus soaring US$16 billion year-on-year to US$20.9 billion, according to the CEPD report.
The value of export orders for the January-October period amounted to US$282.9 billion, up 15.1 percent over the year-earlier level.

Citing data from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the report said Taiwan posted economic growth of 6.92 percent in the third quarter of this year, with the growth rate expected to reach 5.43 percent in the final quarter and 5.46 percent for the whole year.

On the economic targets for 2008, the government aims to achieve economic growth of 4.8 percent for next year, control the unemployment rate at 3.8 percent or below, and keep the inflation rate at below 2 percent, the report said.

The report noted that Taiwan's national fixed investment averaged NT$2.46 trillion per annum during the 2004-2006 period, compared with the average of NT$1.93 trillion during the 2001-2003 period and NT$2.12 trillion during the 1997-1999 period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Media, political parties barred from indigenous foundation

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Friday the third reading of an act governing the establishment of an indigenous people's cultural foundation, which bars politicians and media operators from joining as board members.

To avoid political parties and media outlets from intervening in the Indigenous Cultural Foundation's operations, the act stipulates that civil servants, political party members, executives of cable and terrestrial television companies, as well as foreign nationals are prohibited from being members of the foundation's board of directors.
The foundation's CEO and deputy CEO should not be sitting public functionaries or members of any political party, according to the act.

The act stipulates that the Indigenous Cultural Foundation will be established mainly to bolster indigenous education and cultural development, but the foundation could also operate television and radio broadcasting and other related businesses, with the Public Television Service (PTS) being the sole executive partner.

The foundation will be founded with a budget of NT$20 million (US$617,284) to be allocated by the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples and will be able to receive donations from organizations or individuals from all sectors of society, according to the act.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
AUO ships world's most large-area TFT-LCDs during first 11 months

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) shipped a total of 73.44 million large- area thin film transistor liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCDs) during the first 11 months of 2007, making the company the world's largest supplier of the product in terms of unit shipments, according to tallies released Friday by the display market research and consulting firm DisplaySearch.
LG.Philips LCD (LPL) ranked as the second largest supplier, shipping 73.04 million units during the period, followed by Samsung Electronics (SEC) at 71.6 million units.

The tallies show that a total of 360 million units of large-area TFT-LCDs were shipped during the Jan.-Nov. period, including 104 million notebook PC panels, 169 million LCD monitor displays and 77.5 million TV panels.
During November alone, AUO shipped 7.93 million large-area TFT-LCDs, while SEC and LPL shipped 7.81 million units and 7.53 million units, respectively.

By application, AUO shipped the world's largest number of TV panels in November, while SEC was the largest supplier of notebook PC panels and LCD monitor displays for the same month, according to the tallies.
