DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses complain of declining human rights in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals, accompanied by members of a social activists group, lodged their protests Friday against the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration over what they called "declining human rights" in Taiwan.

Several unnamed Chinese spouses said at a news conference held at the National Immigration Agency that they hoped to adapt to their new lives in Taiwan as soon as possible after marrying their Taiwan husbands, but unreasonable policies -- including the interview policy upon arrival, long waiting period for ROC citizenship and restrictions on working in Taiwan -- have made their lives in Taiwan increasingly difficult.

Members of the private Chunghua Cross-Strait Marriage Consultation Association, which sponsored the news conference, called for the DPP administration to respect those basic rights for the Chinese spouses.

Association members said that since the Republic of China government opened the door to cross-strait marriages in 1987, mainland Chinese spouses living in Taiwan have endured extremely unfair treatment in terms of their daily lives and their status in Taiwan.

They said that the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's official China policy planning body -- even proposed in 2002 that the waiting period for Chinese spouses to obtain ROC citizenship being prolonged from eight years to 11 years. The proposal was later dropped under protest from advocacy groups. Nevertheless, the MAC then imposed a quota system for their citizenship application, the Chinese spouses complained.

The DPP administration has also launched an interview policy in recent years to screen inbound Chinese spouses with questions that were considered by objective observers as infringing on their privacy, they noted.

They added that in June this year, the Ministry of the Interior publicized a new demography white paper, in which quotas for Chinese spouses to obtain legal residency were further restricted. As a result, they said, all quotas for Chinese spouses settling in Taiwan, for short or long term stays, were limited substantially.

In addition, they continued to say, Chinese spouses of Taiwanese nationals intending to visit the country for the first time after their marriage have, since Sept. 1, been required to produce properly verified clean bills of health issued by state-run hospitals, legally licensed private hospitals or university- affiliated hospitals and certified by an officially designated Chinese notary agency.
The clean bill of health must also be certified by Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to prove the document's validity, they added.
Currently, according to the association, there are more than 250,000 mainland Chinese spouses living in Taiwan, with only some 30,000 of them having received their ROC IDs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate defends Taiwan's independent sovereignty

TEXT.P: Most of Taiwan's people view Taiwan as an independent nation and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should have no reason to block the country's bid to join world bodies if it agrees with that view, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopeful Frank Hsieh said Friday.
Hsieh made the comments to reporters while presiding over a news conference marking the launch of creative works of art in support of his presidential campaign at his headquarter office.

Stressing that "we should have confidence in pushing the country to enter the international community, and to embark on concrete actions immediately to safeguard our own interests and national dignity, "Hsieh said that "we must not leave these tasks to the next generation."

Commenting on a news report that the United States will again air its objections to the DPP administration's holding a referendum on seeking the country's U.N. membership in the name of Taiwan, Hsieh said that he was not at all surprised to hear the news because U. S. President George W. Bush was reportedly planing to do so during this year's summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in September in Australia.
Bush did not do so on that occasion, but several senior U.S. officials already spoke out against Taiwan's U.N. referendum plan.

"The European Union and the United States oppose Taiwan's U.N. membership bid to further their own interests, which owe much to China's growing might," Hsieh said, adding, however, that he was more astonished to hear opposition from within Taiwan.

Commenting on a reference to Taiwan as "an independent sovereignty" by Vincent Siew, KMT vice presidential candidate, in his new book, Hsieh said that this is the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan and questioned why Siew has failed to recognize the fact in public.

If the KMT really believes that Taiwan is an independent sovereignty, then the party should not drag its feet on the government's efforts to pursue Taiwan's representation at world bodies -- something which Hsieh said is extremely unfair and deterrent to the country.
"Every citizen should speak up for Taiwan, and the country needs more people to speak for it," he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA inspectors describe CAL cabin-door incident as mysterious

TEXT.P: Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) officials described Friday an air traffic incident involving a Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) passenger aircraft as a mystery after completing a probe into the Dec. 9 cabin-door incident.
According to a local newspaper report, the Boeing 747 airplane was found having an unlocked cabin door after taking off from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport on route to Los Angeles.

For safety concern, the plane returned to the airport for an urgent check after the flight staff failed to fix the problem which saw the problematic cabin door remain locked, as the staff have claimed, but continue to make strange noises.
After a security check, the flight again took off from the Taoyuan airport, four hours behind schedule, according to the report.

In response to media inquiries Friday, the CAA officials said CAL informed the CAA of the incident on that same day, and that a check on the problematic plane that day found no signs of mechanical problems with the cabin door, nor electronic problems with devices designed to display mechanical warnings.
CAA technicians asserted that no pilot would let an aircraft take off when they were uncertain as to whether all the cabin doors were tightly locked.
Regarding the Dec. 9 incident, experts said that they have found the airplane's electronic system did give warning of the problem with the cabin door before the plane took off.

Their probe into the actions of CAL air kitchen personnel responsible for the meals on the Dec. 9 Taipei-Los Angeles flight -- those stationed nearest the problematic door -- also found that the door was properly closed, the CAA officials noted, adding the entire incident is mysterious.

CAA officials said the administration has completed the probe and concluded that the case is not an air security-threatening incident and that therefore, there will be no punishment over the incident.
CAL apologized to passengers on the problematic airplane but underlined that the company has addressed the event in a proper manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA to present substantial plan to promote WEO

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will present a substantial plan next month to push for the establishment of a World Environment Organization (WEO), EPA Minister Winston Dang said Friday.

Dang, reacting to a proposal put forth by President Chen Shui-bian in May calling for the formation of the WEO, said the EPA met with environmentalists and academics in November to discuss the issue and held seminars this month to facilitate further discussions.

In addition to promoting the establishment of the WEO, the EPA's policy objectives over the next five years also include reducing the percentage of days with poor air quality to below 1.5 percent by 2011 and improving the water quality of five urban rivers in Taipei County, Keelung City, Tainan County, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County, Dang said.

Also, the EPA will continue encouraging the use of dual-fuel cars, with the goal of seeing the number of this type of vehicle increase to 150,000 and the number of liquefied petroleum gas filling stations rise to 150 over the next five years, he said.
On environmental diplomacy, Dang said an air monitoring station that Taiwan is helping set up in Guatemala is expected to be completed in 2008.
Dang made the remarks while delivering a report at the Presidential Office on Taiwan's efforts to protect the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling, opposition lawmakers trade barbs over voting system

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition legislators traded barbs again Friday over the voting format for legislative and presidential elections after the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution to adopt the "two-step" system in defiance of the Central Election Commission's (CEC's) decision.

The legislature passed a resolution Thursday, 102-92, proposed by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that the "two-step" system should be adopted when voting on the central government's budget for next year. According to the resolution, the CEC, which decided to adopt a "one-step" system last month, cannot refuse to appropriate funds to the local election commissions for conducting the two major elections and referendums in "two-step" voting system.

Tseng Yung-chuan, KMT legislator and the party's executive director of Policy Committee, said that if the CEC ignores the resolution, insists on carrying out "one-stage" voting format for the elections and referendums, or even run ads to intimidate civil servants, then the KMT legislative caucus will file a malfeasance charge against the CEC.

Ker Chien-ming, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus, said that if the legislature forces the CEC to adopt a "two- step" system, it will be a violation of the Constitution.

Ker said that the KMT, which cited the interpretation of the grand justices to say that budget bill passed by the legislature should be considered as a law, but the grand justices are referring to the budget bill itself and not the resolutions attached to it.
He said that the Legislative Yuan should abide by the government's "division of the power" principle, otherwise the Executive Yuan will be reduced to an administrative bureau of the Legislative Yuan.
Ker pointed out that any resolutions passed during the vote on the budget of the central government will be invalid if they violate the Constitution.
"The Executive Yuan can take the view of the legislature as a reference, but the KMT legislative caucus should not necessarily assume that it will be valid," Ker said.
Under the "one-step" voting format, voters will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and the two referendum ballots at different desks, then cast them into four different boxes.

Eighteen KMT-controlled localities have insisted that they will use the "two- step" format under which voters will receive and cast referendum ballots only after they have cast their ballots for the legislative elections, claiming that the "one-step" format could cause confusion and chaos during the voting process.
The CEC and the 18 local election commission have continued to bicker over the voting system despite the fact that the Jan. 12 legislative elections and two referendums are drawing near.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to address grievances of Chinese spouses

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Friday that it will conduct a thorough review after Chinese spouses of Taiwanese nationals complained about their plight in Taiwan, singling out for attention the inefficient interview system among others.

NIA officials pledged to address their grievances to promote the well-being of cross-strait marriages after the private Chunghua Cross-Strait Marriage Consultation Association led a number of Chinese spouses of Taiwanese nationals to the agency to appeal for better treatment.

The officials noted that after the interview mechanism kicked off in Sept. 1, 2003, the locations for conducting the interviews were limited to Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung, Hualien, Kinmen and Matsu, with the waiting period averaging between two and three months.

But after the launch of the agency early this year, the locations at which interviews might be conducted has increased dramatically to 25. Except for Taipei City, Taipei County, and Taoyuan County, where the number of inbound spouses is large (accounting for half of the inbound spouses of the nation) and the waiting period is comparatively longer -- by around one and a half months -- waits for an interview in all other cities and counties are typically less than one month, the officials said.
The reports of "each interviewee having to wait for three months or more" are unfounded, they clarified.

On the regulations requiring the provision of a financial statement, officials also explained that all Chinese spouses of Taiwanese nationals have to be interviewed, but whether they have to provide a financial statement is decided on a case by case basis.

They explained that when Chinese spouses enter Taiwan, they will not have a work permit issued by the Council of Labor Affairs, and will, therefore, be unable to work, meaning that Taiwanese nationals have to shoulder burden of providing their living expenses.

Although the NIA will ask their Taiwanese spouses to provide a financial status statement, that will not be the only basis for approving entry as the statement will "only be one of the references to check the marriage is real and not a marriage of convenience," the officials said.

Moreover, the financial status statement will not be confined to deposits only, officials said, adding that monthly wages, tax returns, real estate and other sources can all serve to prove that Taiwanese nationals are capable of supporting their Chinese spouses in Taiwan.

On a suggestion by association members that the agency revise the regulations on the interview system and the long-stay of Chinese spouses, the agency said that related draft revisions were sent to the Executive Yuan for approval this October.

They also said that revisions to regulations governing long-stays by Chinese spouses have been largely worked out, noting that Chinese spouses who have long- stay certificates in Taiwan could apply to settle down in Taiwan and obtain identification cards if their Taiwanese spouses die during their long-stay and they have not remarried within five years of their deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Total safety reserves of imported oil to be lowered

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Friday the third reading of an amendment to the petroleum management law, allowing the total safety reserve of imported oil held by individual oil import companies to be lowered from the current level of 50,000 kl to 10,000 kl.

The passage of the amendment, which was submitted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will lower the threshold for the organization of new companies participating in this import trade, indirectly undercutting the duopoly enjoyed by the existing CPC Taiwan and Formosa Petrochemical, political observers said.

The amendment stipulates that in case of an acute shortage of crude oil in the country due to certain emergency situations, the Ministry of Economic Affairs could restrict exports of petroleum and other related oil products by private companies.
The amendment pushes for the development and promotion of renewable bio-energy and related technology.
It also stipulates that the country's Petroleum Fund could be used to finance the development and promotion of efficient usage of liquefied gas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung expected to complete WiMax network by 2008

TEXT.P: "Mobile Kaohsiung", an efficient, wireless communication network under construction as part of the southern port city's ongoing urban development program in preparation for hosting the 2009 World Games, is expected to be completed by the end of next year, city officials said Friday.

The program, aimed at building a WiMax network covering the city to facilitate wireless data transmission, was formed in August 2006, with the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Chunghwa Telecom Co. -- Taiwan's largest telecommunication services provider -- offering financial subsidies, according to the city officials.

Under the program, which is assessed to require NT$600 million (US$18.47 million) in construction costs, 25 base transceiver stations will be built in city districts surrounding the main venue for the World Games to turn the city into a barrier-free environment for data transmission, the officials said.
So far, five base stations have been completed, mostly of which are located along the Love River flowing through the port city, the officials said.

In addition, the "M-Kaohsiung" program will also weave a security network by enrolling 1,000 Internet-equipped yellow cabs and installing mobile camera devices on 300 police vehicles in a drive to safeguard all of the athletes and participants in the 2009 games, which will be the largest international sporting event the city has ever hosted, according to the city government.

WiMax, the abbreviation for the "Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, " is a telecommunications technology aimed at providing wireless connectivity over long distances in a variety of ways, from point-to-point links to full mobile cellular-type access.

DOC.HEADLINE: November jobless rate stands at 3.87%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 3.87 percent for November, down 0.05 percentage points month-on-month but up 0.01 percentage points year-on-year, according to tallies released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

For the first 11 months of this year, the average unemployment rate increased 0.01 percentage points year-on-year to 3.92 percent, DGBAS officials said, adding that both the unemployment rate for November and that for the Jan.-Nov. period hit their second-lowest level for the past seven years.
In November, the number of jobless workers totaled 417,000, down 4,000 from October but up 7,000 over the same month last year, the officials said.

While the number of first-time job seekers who failed to find a job dropped by 1,000, the number of people who quit their jobs declined by 3,000. The number of people who lost their jobs because of the termination of seasonal or temporary employment increased by 1,000, they said.

As of November, jobless persons had been unemployed, on average, for 25.4 weeks, 0.5 week less than in October, they said, adding that the average period of unemployment among first-time job seekers was 26 weeks, 0.9 week longer than the previous month.

By educational background, the November unemployment rate was 4.26 percent among senior high school graduates, 3.99 percent among college or university graduates and those with higher education, and 3.15 percent among junior high school graduates and those with lower education.
The November jobless rate was 11.2 percent among the 15-24 age group, 3.77 percent among the 25-44 age group and 2.18 percent among the 45-64 age group.
On the employment situation, the number of employed workers totaled 10.349 million in November, up 29,000 from October and 142,000 from the same month last year.

For the first 11 months of this year, the number of employed workers averaged 10.286 million, up 185,000 year-on-year to hit the highest level for the Jan.-Nov. period over the past three years and the second-highest level over the past 13 years, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli, U.S. officials share anti-terrorism experiences with Taiwan

TEXT.P: Security officers from Israel, the U.S. and Taiwan established Friday a new working pattern for exchange and cooperation, albeit in a very untraditional manner, by watching anti-terrorism movie The Kingdom.

"People here are not aware of terror threats, " Ami Sharon, security officer of the Israeli mission in Taiwan, said at the screening of the film which was aimed at increasing local awareness of terror attacks.
Sharon further said that many people deal with things only after something has happened, adding that "we have to be aware of this important issue."

The event, organized by the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taiwan (ISECO) and supported by the American Institute in Taipei (AIT), showed The Kingdom to officers from the National Police Agency (NPA) , the Homeland Security of the Executive Yuan, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) and the Kaohsiung City Police Bureau.

Besides praising the work the NPA has offered to the Israeli office in Taipei, Sharon expressed hope that through this casual gathering, local authorities could consider terror issues from a different perspective.
"You are already doing well and I just want to increase your awareness," Sharon said to the participants after the screening.
NPA Alien Affairs Section Chief Simon H.C. Hsieh noted that if Taiwan can cooperate better with foreign agencies, "we can keep terrorism from our country."
"But we need more access to information about terrorism, " he added.
The Kingdom, directed by Peter Berg, casts a team of elite FBI agents sent to Saudi Arabia to solve a brutal mass murder and find a killer before he strikes again.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academics analyze South Korean economy, presidential election

TEXT.P: Hope for "a bigger pie" and a better economy was why South Koreans voted for President-elect Lee Myung-bak, who is expected to have little room to adopt a new Taiwan policy, local and South Korean academics said Friday in a forum.

"South Korea's economy has been doing O.K. in general, but the past regimes focused too much on wealth distribution and social welfare in their socialistic economic policies. People tended to see these policies as a failure, " said Taeho Bark, chairman of the Korea International Trade Commission and a professor at Seoul National University.

The annual Taipei-Seoul Forum was held two days after the presidential election in South Korea concluded with a landslide victory for Lee Myung-bak, who garnered 48.7 percent of the votes, putting him 22 percentage points ahead of his closest rival, Chung Dong-young.

Economic issues proved to be the deciding factor in the election, Bark said, as "the rich are not getting richer but the poor are getting poorer in Korea." He said that while the country enjoys substantial economic growth, it's still difficult for university graduates to find jobs, while established corporations such as Samsung have been neglecting the domestic market.
That is why people want a more liberal economy and expect Lee, a former mayor of Seoul and chief executive of Hyundai Construction Co., to "make the pie bigger, " he added.

As Lee is expected to make mending fences with the United States his top diplomatic priority, the forum participants said there will be little room for him to adopt a new policy on Taiwan, given the current Northeast Asian international order, said Lee Ming, a professor at National Chengchi University.

Ron Moo-hyun, the incumbent president, is seen as a leader driven by his ideology, including anti-Americanism, while Lee is seen as more of a pragmatist who can solve problems, said Kim Sunhyuk, director of the Global Leadership Development Center of Korea University.
"Voters chose pragmatism over ideology in this election, " agreed Lee Dong-bak, president of the North Korea Democratization Forum and a former member of South Korea's National Assembly.
"It seems to me that South Korean electorate had already decided two years ago that they would vote for the Grand National Party, " Lee said.

The two-day forum, which was organized by the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University and the Seoul Forum for International Affairs, will continue Saturday with three sessions to discuss the new phase of Taiwan-South Korean relations and regional development in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND to shut down late presidents' mausoleums Monday

TEXT.P: The administration of the mausoleums of the late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo formally notified the Taoyuan county government Friday that it will close the mausoleums from Monday in preparation for management transfer.

The Tashi Mausoleum Administration, which is under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), said the shutdown is to pave the way for the withdrawal of military guards posted at the two mausoleums, located in the county's Tashi township, and a check and inventory of the assets and artifacts before turning them over to the Taoyuan county government.
As droves of people have come to the mausoleums over the past few days in anticipation of the impending closure, Tashi township chief Su Wen-sheng said the decision to shut them down is "rash."

Su said the town has benefited from the mausoleums, noting that visitors and the business opportunities they bring -- such as sales of the town's famous bean curd, amount to an annual revenue of more than NT$400 million (US$12.35 million).
Su said the government's decision to close the mausoleums in such a short time could harm the town's business.

However, Taoyuan county government officials said that after the county government takes over the management of the mausoleums, it will inject more cultural factors to make them even more attractive to visitors.
President Chen Shui-bian said earlier this month that the military guards posted at the mausoleums will be withdrawn from the beginning of next year.
Branding the elder Chiang a dictator, Chen said there is no reason to use taxpayers' money to guard his mausoleum any longer.
The elder Chiang died in 1975, while his son passed away in 1988. Both of them have been interred in Tashi, originally until such time as their bodies could be returned to China for burial.
Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jyh-wey announced last Friday that the government will stop referring to the tombs as mausoleums and will simply call each a "tomb or grave."

DOC.HEADLINE: CO2 emissions standard to be adopted in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Voluntary Carbon Standard (VCS), which aims to be the global benchmark standard for project-based voluntary emission reductions, will be introduced into Taiwan to help local companies comply with international efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, industry sources said Friday.

The announcement came after 38 industrialized countries agreed at the recent United Nations Climate Change Conference in Bali to decrease their carbon dioxide emissions by between 20 percent and 40 percent by 2020.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, Taiwanese companies still need to comply with the protocol if they want to sell products to industrialized countries, said Johnny Shieh, a senior executive of the Taiwan chapter of SGS Group.
Local companies can use the VCS certification as proof of their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Shieh noted.
Dell Inc. -- a U.S.-based computer company -- announced in September that it plans to make its operations carbon neutral by the end of 2008, Shieh went on.
The Geneva-registered SGS Group is the world's leading inspection, verification, testing and certification company.
In addition, Dell has asked its suppliers to report their emissions of greenhouse gases and Dell will help its suppliers cut their emissions, Shieh noted.
Richard Huang, another executive of SGS Taiwan, described the VCS -- which was launched Nov. 19 this year -- as an international standard.
He said Taiwanese companies can use the VCS to obtain quotas for the carbon dioxide emissions they cut.
In addition, Taiwanese companies can buy and sell these quotas on the VCS platform, which will also help them meet their requirements on carbon dioxide emissions, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to reduce CO2 emissions to 2000 levels by 2025

TEXT.P: The government is set to reduce the annual carbon dioxide emissions in Taiwan to year 2000 levels by 2025, according to the Cabinet's chief technology adviser Lee Yuan-tseh.

Lee confirmed Thursday after the conclusion of the 27th meeting of the Executive Yuan Science and Technology Advisory Group that Vice Premier Chiou I-jen has signed the meeting minutes, which will require ministries to meet the C02 emission reduction goal by 2025.

Noting that all the technology advisers are pleased with Chiou's having signed the meeting minutes, Lee said that by 2025, the government is expected to cut current greenhouse gas emissions by approximately 40 percent.
In order to meet that goal, the government needs to make massive adjustments in its policies governing relevant industries, Lee noted.
In 1998, the National Energy Conference reached a temporary agreement under which the government would aim to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the country to year 2000 levels by 2020, Lee said.
However, no consensus was reached on lowering carbon dioxide emissions at the National Energy Conference held in 2005, Lee went on.
According to the white paper on energy policy released at the 2005 National Energy Conference, Taiwan emitted 221 and 276 million metric tons of carbon dioxide in 2000 and 2005, respectively.

Wu Tsung-tsong, deputy minister of the National Science Council (NSC), said during an interview with the Central News Agency that the NSC will include the new goal in the national energy plan at a commissioners' meeting slated for Dec. 25.

Within the next two or three months, the NSC will begin to promote relevant policies and convene a cross-ministerial meeting involving the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Environmental Protection Administration on the formulation of related policies, Wu noted.
If the government does not commit itself to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, then Taiwan will generate an estimated 570 million metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions by 2025, Wu said.

Meanwhile, an official of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau said that as the legislature has yet to pass the draft Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act, the government cannot require local companies to report their emissions of carbon dioxide.
In addition, local companies do not need to collaborate with the government to monitor their greenhouse gas emissions, the official said.
Without such data on companies' carbon dioxide emissions, the government cannot formulate relevant policies on greenhouse gas reduction, the official concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Decision on `one-step' voting method must be obeyed: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has authority over the election commissions in the country's 25 cities and counties, and therefore, all election units must employ a CEC-designed "one-step" voting method in the coming polls, CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Friday.

Chang made the comments during a break in a meeting called by the CEC with election commission chiefs and officials from around the country to settle a deadlock between the central government and 18 cities and counties controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over the voting format for the Jan. 12, 2008 legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.
In accordance with the law, all local election commissions are subordinate to the CEC in terms of electoral affairs, Chang pointed out.

Nevertheless, Wu Shiu-kuang, chairman of Taipei City's election commission, said that the municipal commission has decided to use a "two-step" voting method and that there is no way anyone can alter the decision.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said that the Executive Yuan will do whatever is necessary to prevent the 18 KMT-controlled local governments from using the "two-step" procedure, by either replacing election commission chiefs and workers or even through legal means.
The CEC-prescribed "one-step" voting method is legally binding and the government fully supports its decision to adopt the method to ensure smooth and orderly elections, Shieh said.

Commenting on the CEC meeting, he explained that it was not held to "entice" electoral personnel in the 25 localities but was aimed at encouraging them not to yield to pressure and making them realize that it is their legal obligation to adopt the "one-step" voting scheme.
Shieh denied speculation that the CEC has prepared a compromise package to resolve the voting method dispute and argued that doing so would mean giving way to "evil forces."
"The government must act on a legal foundation and it cannot issue an unlawful response," he said.

The "two-step" voting format being touted by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou is absolutely illegal, he said, adding that the government will not tolerate two different voting systems in the same election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential elections similar in Taiwan, South Korea: academics

TEXT.P: A lot of similarities can be found in the presidential elections of South Korea and Taiwan, academics said Friday on the heels of Lee Myung-bak's landslide victory in South Korea's presidential election.

The first and most obvious similarity is that the economy has become one of the most important issues in both elections, according to academics from Taiwan and South Korea in the annual Taipei-Seoul Forum.

Lee's victory shows voters recognized incumbent President Roh Moo -hyun's economic policy as a failure, said Taeho Bark, chairman of the Korea International Trade Commission and a professor at Seoul National University.

The economy is also a hot topic in Taiwan, although there are other issues, such as national identity and the United Nations referendum, being discussed at the same time, said Lee Ming, a professor at National Chengchi University.

Presidential candidates in both countries are beset by legal cases, as Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou is in the middle of a corruption trial and Lee Myung-bak faces investigation for his involvement in a scandal.

North Korea and China, which have interfered in every major election in South Korea and Taiwan in the past, are surprisingly silent this time, said Lee Ming, president of the North Korea Democratization Forum and a former member of South Korea's National Assembly.

North Korea did not want to see the conservative Grand National Party (GNP) become the ruling party, so it "secretly" collaborated with socialists in South Korea to undermine the GNP in past elections, Lee Dong-bak claimed, adding that South Koreans said "no" to North Korea with their ballots.

Lee also observed a "reversal theory" in elections in South Korea, where GNP and the liberal United New Democratic Party (UNDP) have been exchanged leads in presidential and parliamentary elections during the past few years.

The same theory is also common in local discussions about elections, as political parties that lose in parliamentary or presidential elections will be favored to win the next election because of the voter habit of "helping the weak."
Observers saw the South Korean presidential election as a showdown between Roh and Lee Myung-bak rather than Lee versus UNDP candidate Chung Dong-young, said Lee Ming.

In Taiwan, he continued, some people are also under the impression that President Chen Shui-bian has taken the lead role in the election, making the March election a "Chen vs. Ma" tussle rather the "real" fight, which is between Ma and ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate Frank Hsieh.
"I don't know much about Chen vs. Ma but I do know that in Korea, some people saw this as an election between Lee and former President Kim Dae-jung, rather than Roh Moo-hyun, " Lee Dong-bak said.

The two-day forum, organized by the Institute of International Relations (IIR) of National Chengchi University and the Seoul Forum for International Affairs (SFIA), will proceed Saturday with three sessions to discuss the new phase of Taiwan-South Korean relations and regional development in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not recipient of Chinese investment: MAC official

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not on Beijing's list of overseas areas in which Chinese people are allowed to invest, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Liu Te-hsun said Friday.
Liu made the remarks in response to media inquiries about independent Legislator Lin Wei-chou's recent proposal that Chinese people be allowed to invest in Taiwanese real estate.

Lin cited MAC Chairman Chen Ming-tong as saying a few days ago after a meeting with the Cabinet official that the MAC is considering relaxing restrictions against Chinese people seeking to purchase real estate in Taiwan, to allow Chinese citizens to apply for housing loans at local banks, and to cancel the requirement that Chinese investors in Taiwan real estate must explain the source of their funds.

Liu denied Lin's allegations and explained that China does not allow its people to invest in Taiwan. The issue is not one over which Taiwan has any authority and it is not an issue that can be addressed by revising Taiwanese laws unilaterally, he pointed out.

Liu also noted that Beijing takes strict measures in controlling the outflow of funds overseas, with each outnound remittance limited to US$60,000 at the most. This limitation severely limits the opportunities for Chinese people to buy real estate overseas, he added.
According to MAC statistics, only 10 Chinese citizens have invested in Taiwanese real estate, most of whom are the spouses of Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. Korea's misery index higher than Taiwan's over past decade: CEPD

TEXT.P: South Korea's financial misery index in 2006 was 5.7 percent, higher than Taiwan's 4.5 percent, signifying that the economic pressure on South Koreans is higher than that on the Taiwanese people, according to a report released Friday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Taiwan outperformed South Korea in terms of economic growth and the level of life satisfaction, according to the CEPD report comparing the economic performance of Taiwan and South Korea over the past 10 years.

The report shows that for the period between 1997 and 2006, Taiwan's average economic growth rate reached 4.4 percent, the same level as that of South Korea, while between 2003 and 2006, Taiwan's average economic growth rate stood at 4.6 percent, in comparison with South Korea's 4.3 percent. As for this year, Taiwan's growth rate is estimated at 5.5 percent, while that of South Korea is estimated at 4.8 percent.
Taiwan also reported a higher level of life satisfaction, which is measured by purchasing power parity (PPP), financial misery index and disposable income.

The report shows that Taiwan's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) was US$15,271 in 2005 and US$16,030 in 2006, slightly lower than the US$16,306 and US$18,392 registered by South Korea over the same period.

But Taiwan's PPP-converted per capita GDP reached US$30,687 in 2006, far higher than South Korea's US$24,084. As for 2008, it is predicted to surge to US$32,490 in Taiwan, still ahead of the US$25,840 forecast for South Korea.

As to the financial misery index composed of the unemployment rate and consumer price index (CPI) , over the past decade Taiwan's CPI rose only 0.8 percent, lower than South Korea's 3.4 percent. In terms of unemployment rate, Taiwan's dropped to 3.9 percent in 2006, close to South Korea's 3.5 percent.

The study also shows that although the gap in disposable household income between the richest and poorest families in Taiwan over the past decade increased to 6.01 fold, up from 5.41, the gap in South Korea surged sharply to 7.64 fold, up from 5.4 over the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotel sewage worsens water quality of Feitsui Reservoir: EPA

TEXT.P: Sewage emitted by increasing numbers of hot spring hotels and restaurants in Wulai, Taipei County, has resulted in excessive E. coli counts in the water of the Feitsui Reservoir, according to the results of a survey released Friday.
The survey was conducted by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Taiwan's 20 reservoirs.

Sun Moon Lake in the central county of Nantou has the best water quality, despite substandard sewage disposal from the Lalu, a local five-star hotel, said Leu Horng-guang, director-general of the EPA's Bureau of Water Quality Protection.
From 2004, the Lalu Hotel has been given fines of just NT$60,000 (US$1,847) , NT$150,000 and NT$60,000, for its repeated failure to improve its sewage system, Leu noted.
The Fengshan Reservoir in the southern county of Kaohsiung has the poorest water quality, Leu said.

In accordance with the Water Pollution Control Act, the EPA announced in July that the waste water disposal of over 10,000 hotels, restaurants and hot spring resorts will be subject to EPA control from July 1, 2008, Leu said.
Most of the hotels and restaurants in Wulai wil have to improve their sewage facilities or face penalties, Leu added.
However, in response to the EPA survey results, Li Kung-cheh, head of the Taipei Feitsui Reservoir Administration, said the reservoir water is safe and does not contain high amounts of E. coli.
The waste water produced by hot spring resorts in Wulai drains into the Nanshih River, while the water of the Feitsui Reservoir comes from the Peishih River.

Taipei city government Water Department officials also dismissed the EPA results, saying that the water of the Feitsui Reservoir is monitored by computer and that no unusual situations have been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature OK's FTAs with two Central American allies

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Friday free trade agreements (FTAs) between Taiwan and two Central American diplomatic allies to further advance economic and diplomatic relations.

According to remarks made Nov. 12 by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hsieh Fa- ta in a legislative meeting, El Salvador and Honduras will agree to lower customs duties on 3,151 and 3,451 items of industrial products, respectively, after the free trade pacts take effect.

As industrial goods make up the bulk of Taiwan's exports to both El Salvador and Honduras, the FTAs will give Taiwanese products with preferential import tariffs, allowing them to compete with China, Japan and South Korea and helping Taiwan to better tap the two markets, Hsieh said.

Citing an analysis by the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research, Hsieh said the FTAs will help Taiwan boost its industrial product exports to the two Central American countries by between 4.2 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively, per year.
In terms of agricultural produce, El Salvador and Honduras will also immediately slash customs duty rates for 439 items and 430 items, respectively, from Taiwan, he added.

The FTAs will help Taiwanese companies make inroads into the vast American markets and pursue globalization at a time when other countries in the region are still negotiating the Free Trade Area of the Americas, he said.

According to Hsieh, Taiwanese exports to El Salvador and Honduras in 2006 hit US$71.49 million and US$35.79 million, respectively, while imports from the two countries reached US$8.98 million and US$14.36 million, respectively.
Panama, Guatemala and Nicaragua, all of which are Taiwan's diplomatic partners in Central America, have already signed FTAs with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aboriginal reps return from Japanese fruitful training camp

TEXT.P: Twenty aboriginal representatives have returned to Taiwan from Japan after completing a training program on hotel management, an official of the Cabinet- level Council of Indigenous Peoples said Friday.

The 20 representatives, who returned the previous day, had been selected by the council from among operators of hot spring hotels in aboriginal tribal areas around the country to take part in the 16-day training camp that opened Dec. 5 at a Japanese hot spring hotel, the official went on, adding that the camp was aimed at familiarizing the participants with Japanese-style hospitality, hotel management and administration.

Yang Hui-ying, one of the representatives, who is a member of the Amis tribe from the eastern county of Hualien, said in an interview with CNA that she attended the camp to learn Japanese-style hotel management and culture, which are detail-and-etiquette oriented. She added that Japanese hot spring culture, which can feature a combination of local crafts and dance performances, deserves emulation by Taiwan's aboriginal hot spring operators.
Yang also expressed hope that the council will come up with measures to offer financial aid for aboriginal hot spring operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Confrontation mars just-concluded legislature

TEXT.P: Serious confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties was a principal feature that marred the sixth legislature, which ended its sixth and final session Friday.

The sixth legislature, which concluded a week early to allow incumbent legislators more time to engage in campaign activities for the Jan. 12 legislative elections, set various records over the last three years, including three failed attempts to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

The sixth legislature opened in early 2005 in an atmosphere of extreme mutual distrust, with the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party, convinced of the illegality of the 2004 presidential election result.

Shortly after Chen won re-election by a razor-thin margin, the "pan-blue" presidential ticket of then KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong filed lawsuits to challenge the outcome, claiming that Chen staged an election- eve shooting that slightly injured him and Vice President Annette Lu, to win sympathy votes in the hotly contested election.
Bickering and confrontation stalled business in the legislature from that point on.

One of the most conspicuous was the boycott by the "pan-blue alliance" of the list of Control Yuan members nominated by the president for legislative confirmation, so that the nation's highest watchdog body was left empty after the term of the previous members expired Jan. 31, 2005.

The opposition attempted to recall the president three times in the latter half of 2006, but failed every time because a recall requires the consent of two- thirds of the 225-member legislature, while the "pan-blue" only commanded a slim majority.
Also, the budget law stipulates that the budget for the central government should be passed one month before the start of a new fiscal year, but the 2007 budget did not pass until June 15 that year.

The reason for the unprecedented stalling is attributed to the KMT listing the controversial draft Organic Law of the Central Election Commission at the top of the agenda for discussion Jan. 16, 2007, which triggered even more riotous confrontation between the lawmakers.
After the fourth session of the legislature ended in pandemonium, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng issued a rare written statement to condemn the DPP legislative caucus.

The non-stop conflict took its toll on the smooth operation of the legislature and it became normal for lawmakers to ignore their duties in the regular sessions, making it necessary to organize provisional sessions just to get some work done.

There are 10 provisional sessions in the history of the legislature, and except for the first and second ones in 1951 and 1952, the remaining eight took place during the rule of the DPP administration, with the just-concluded legislature convening three provisional sessions, on par with the record in the fifth legislature.

Compared with the fifth legislature, however, which passed 611 bills, the just- concluded legislature passed only 498 bills, a new low for the past three legislatures. The confrontation between the ruling and the opposition lawmakers is entirely to blame for this dismal performance, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC unveils first colored election ballot

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) unveiled Friday the first colored election ballot, to be used in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
CEC Secretary-General Deng Tien-you noted that the colored logos of 12 political parties vying for at-large seats will be printed on the ballots on a white background. Political parties
will be eligible for at-large seats if they manage to receive more than 5 percent of the ballots cast.

Deng said samples of the colored ballots will be published in election bulletins to help voters in the upcoming elections, which will adopt a new "single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system, meaning that voters will be given two ballots -- one going for their chosen legislator and another for their favored political party.
The new legislature will also see the number of seats halved to 113.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan demands WHO rectify wrong Taiwanese port placement

TEXT.P: Taiwan has ordered its representative office in Geneva to lodge a strong protest with the World Health Organization (WHO) over its wrong placement of several Taiwanese ports on a list of certified ports in China, an official said Friday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs acting spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the WHO has published lists of certified ports of all member countries in accordance with its newly passed International Health Regulations (IHR) , in which the WHO has wrongly included some Taiwanese ports on the Chinese port list.

Noting that such a move will not only affect the Taiwan people's rights but could also cause confusion and difficulty for international merchant shipping and maritime transport operators, Yeh said the MOFA will seek the assistance of major countries around the world to push the WHO to correct the issue as soon as possible.
Because of China's opposition, Taiwan has been shut out of the WHO and its decision-making World Health Assembly, causing a loophole in the world epidemic control and health care network.

Yeh said China has spared no effort to suppress Taiwan, even on public health affairs. In September, she said, China blocked the WHO from directly informing Taiwan of suspected contamination of a shipment of Thai corn on the grounds that all WHO data and information should be passed to Taiwan via Beijing. China did not inform Taiwan until two weeks later.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Jan. 22, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Shah Jahan, the mighty Mogul emperor of India who built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz-i-Mahal, dies at the age of 74.
1771: Spain agrees to cede the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to Britain.
1775: Andre Ampere, the French physicist and discoverer of electromagnets who gave his name to the "amp" as a unit of electricity, is born.
1901: After a 64-year reign, Queen Victoria, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight at the age of 81.
1905: Tsarist troops fire salvo after close-range salvo into a crowd in St. Petersburg, Russia, leaving the snow red with the blood of at least 500 strikers.
1922: Pope Benedict XV, originally Giacomo della Chiesa, who sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace, dies in Rome. He was succeeded by Pope Pius XI.
1924: Ramsay MacDonald becomes Britain's first Labor prime minister, replacing Stanley Baldwin.
1935: After long negotiations, Japan pays 140 million yen for Soviet interests in the Chinese Eastern Railway, the last legal trace of Russian influence in Manchuria.
1944: Allied landings begin at Arizo, Italy, involving an estimated 50,000 U.S. and British troops.
1945: More than 500 U.S. warplanes launch air-raids on Okinawa and Taiwan.
1945: The land route to China -- the Ledo Road across Burma from India to China -- reopens.
1946: U.S. President Harry Truman orders the establishment of the Central Intelligence Agency.
1949: The guerrilla army of China's Mao Tse-tung marches toward Beijing after crossing the Yangtze River to defeat the Nationalist army at Huai Hai north of Beijing.
1955: Adm. Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, says that the United States will help defend Taiwan if attacked following the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Washington on Dec. 3, 1954.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a professor at National Taiwan University, and two students, are charged with subversion against the government by military prosecutors.
1973: Prince Tuipelehake, C.B.E., prime minister of the Kingdom of Tonga, arrives in Taipei for a one-week visit.
1973: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th U.S. president, who succeeded John F. Kennedy, dies of a heart attack in Texas at the age of 64.
1975: Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper and the Fuji Television Corporation of Japan, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1979: Demonstrations are held at Kaohsiung railway station and Chiaotou township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County against the arrest of Yu Teng-fa for sedition.
1980: Dr. Andrei Dimitrievich Sakharov, the Soviet physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, is arrested, stripped of his honor and banished to Gorky from Moscow. An outspoken advocate of human rights and nuclear disarmament, he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the offshore island county of Penghu, killing 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in 20 years, and the Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help the victims.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives the chiefs of administrative branches under the Executive Yuan, and urges them and other government officials to persevere in discharging their duties and to endeavor to promote political reform.
1990: The Yugoslav Communist Party renounces its monopoly on power after 45 years of rule.
1996: The Pentagon announces for the first time the size of the U.S. chemical weapons arsenal, and says all 3.6 million weapons will be destroyed by 2004.
2000: Taiwan's Wei Yun-chieh shoots a five-under-par 67 to win the Chunghua Cup Women's Golf Tournament, the first leg of the 2000 Women's Asian Circuit, with a three-day total of 213.
2001: ROC Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping conveys his congratulations to Ang Lee, a Taiwan-born director whose "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" won the 58th Golden Globe best director and best foreign film awards.
2002: U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance William H. Lash, III arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
2002: Republic of Chad Ambassador to the Republic of China Hissein Brahim Taha presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Those who know it are not as those who love it; those who love it are not as those who find their joy in it."
