DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday.
The weighted price index was up 133 points at 8,074.44 on a turnover of NT$3.72 billion (US$114.85 million) at the open. The index surged 84.36 points, or 1.07 percent, to close at 7,941.44 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was slightly higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Monday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.511 at 10 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.026 from Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 24, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies at the age of 90.
1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.
1999: Taipei's fifth rapid transit line -- the Pangnan Line -- is inaugurated, completing the foundation of the city's rapid transit network.
2000: About 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas take part in a peaceful street march in Taipei to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
2000: Thai Rangsit University confers an honorary doctoral degree on former ROC Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Fukuda vows to aid all hep C victims
Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda said Sunday the ruling coalition parties will craft legislation to pay uniform compensation to everyone who contracted hepatitis C through tainted blood products and submit the bill to the Diet this session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people's voice should not be labeled as 'provocative': rep
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/24/07 12:46:32 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top representative to the United States said Sunday that the Taiwan people's expressing of their desire for membership in the United Nations is a peaceful and rational move which should never be considered as "provocative."

Speaking during a news conference with Taiwan media members, Joseph Wu said that Taiwan is the only country in the world being barred from the United Nations, adding that for decades, Taiwan has not obtained any substantive assistance from the international community.
Against this backdrop, Wu said, the Taiwan people must speak out in a loud voice about their plight in order to prevent the country from being completely isolated.

Wu made the remarks in response to U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's reference Friday to Taiwan's planned referendum on whether the country should apply to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan as a "provocative policy."

Rice reiterated the United States' opposition to Taiwan's referendum plan in a press conference held in Washington, D.C. Calling the referendum a "provocative policy, " she said the referendum "unnecessarily raises tensions in the Taiwan Strait" and "promises no real benefits for the people of Taiwan on the international stage."

Wu stressed that China has been "provocative, " pointing out that it has continued to deploy more and more ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan, as well to try to isolate Taiwan diplomatically and attempt to have Taiwan's designation in international organizations changed to downgrade its status.

Moreover, he said, Beijing unilaterally included Taiwanese ports as certified ports in China on the International Health Regulation-certified port list on the World Health Organization (WHO) Web site recently.

Even worse, he added, China is planning to inaugurate a new flight route 4.2 nautical miles west of the median of the Taiwan Strait next January, which could severely affect cross-strait stability and international flight safety.

Wu noted that Taiwan and the United States have shared many common values and have maintained close and cordial business, trade, cultural and security ties, which he said have helped form the bedrock of a solid relationship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Straits Times: Thaksin-backed party wins Thai elections.
The People Power Party (PPP) - which is linked closely to ousted prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra - yesterday emerged as the largest single party in Thailand's post-coup election and staked a claim to forming a government with leader Samak Sundaravej as premier.
Lianhe Zaobao: Thaksin-backed People Power Party wins Thai elections.
The People Power Party (PPP), which supported ousted prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, had won 228 of the 480 seats in Thailand's Parliament, and this result has shown that Thailand people denied strongly the coup last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Smuggled foreign cigarettes seized at Kaohsiung Port

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Port police in southern Taiwan seized more than 500 cases of smuggled foreign cigarettes, including some rare brands, aboard a local fishing boat at Kaohsiung Port Sunday, local police said Monday.
The police detained the ship captain and four crew members for questioning after discovering that the fishing gear on the boat had not been used during their 20-day fishing journey, the police noted.
In addition, the captain, surnamed Tsai, claimed that all the fish caught over the past 20 days had been sold before they returned home, the police said.
However, the captain could not explain to whom the fish had been sold or where the cigarettes had come from, the police noted, adding that they are still investigating the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: International baseball tournament opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taipei International AA Baseball Invitational Tournament opened here Sunday.

The tournament, the third of its kind, has drawn five teams from Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong, in addition to 11 teams from around the island. They will compete against one another for the title until Dec. 26.

Taipei City Councillor Chen Yu-mei who presided over the opening of the tournament Sunday night as the chief of Taipei Baseball Association said she hopes the tournament will cement the friendship between Taipei and other cities while improving the participants' baseball skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Kaohsiung residents satisfied with mayor's performance

TEXT.P: Slightly over half of Kaohsiung City residents are satisfied with Mayor Chen Chu's performance over the past year, according to the results of a poll released Monday.

In the survey conducted by a pollster company between Dec. 16-19 at the commission of the municipal government's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, 51.3 percent of the respondents expressed satisfaction with Mayor Chen's performance, up from 34.9 percent in a similar poll conducted in March of this year.
Chen was sworn in as mayor of the southern port city Dec. 25 last year.
According to a commission official, 76.5 percent of the respondents surveyed are proud of being a Kaohsiung citizen, while 69.8 percent believe the port city has a bright future.
In addition, 64.7 percent of the respondents said they are pleased with the performance of the city government, up slightly from 61.7 percent in the March survey, the official said.

The Kaohsiung citizens polled said they are most satisfied with the city government's efforts to renovate the city's landscape and to promote tourism, while expressing the most dissatisfaction with the city's law and order, economy, and road conditions, the official continued.

Mayor Chen's performance approval rating has been on a steady rise since March of this year, surpassing the 50-percent for the first time in December, the official said, adding that this indicates that her intensive efforts have won the recognition of the city's residents.

Chen, for her part, said that she pays great attention to the residents' level of satisfaction with the various aspects of the city and her administration, describing any dissatisfaction among residents as a force driving her administration to make progress.

Chen added that she will continue to work to improve the city's law and order, environmental protection, economic development, traffic, cultural development, and overall living conditions during the remainder of her term.

DOC.HEADLINE: No change in Taiwan-Malawi relations: Malawian ambassador

TEXT.P: Bilateral relations between Malawi and Taiwan are firm and solid, Malawian Ambassador to the Republic of China Thengo Maloya reaffirmed Monday.

During a meeting with Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang Monday morning, Maloya denied there has been any change in bilateral Taiwan-Malawi diplomatic relations as rumored recently by a Malawian newspaper.
Maloya made the reassurance amid reports that a delegation of Malawian officials is ready to visit China, which may put Taiwan's formal diplomatic relations with Malawi in jeopardy.

Malawi's Nyasa Times reported on its Web site Dec. 21 that Malawian President Bingu wa Mutharika has agreed that Malawi will sever its formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan and forge formal ties with China.

The Nyasa Times report said that two Malawian ministers, in the company of Malawian foreign ministry officials, are scheduled to depart Malawi Dec. 24 for Beijing. The Malawian official delegation will sign a memorandum of understanding in Beijing to pave the way for the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between Malawi and China, according to the report.

In response to the report, Foreign Minister James Huang met with his Maloya Monday morning to gain a better understanding of the latest development surrounding bilateral relations between Taiwan and Malawi, said Phoebe Yeh, acting spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
It marked the second time that Huang has met with Ambassador Maloya since the Nyasa Times report was posted Saturday, Yeh said.
Meanwhile, Yeh said that Deputy Foreign Minister Yang Tzu-pao has departed Taipei for Malawi to get a better grasp of the situation.
According to Yeh, the Foreign Ministry sought clarification from Maloya and was told that nothing negative has occurred in Taiwan-Malawi diplomatic relations.
The Foreign Ministry was also told Monday that the Malawian officials who were reportedly scheduled to depart from Malawi for China on Dec. 24 "have yet to depart," according to Yeh.

Yeh added that Malawian Foreign Minister Joyce Banda told the Foreign Ministry Sunday that China has attempted many times over the past several years to build better relations with Malawi. Banda said Malawi has maintained formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan over the past 40 years, and it was not the first time that Beijing has tried to undermine Malawi-Taiwan ties, according to Yeh.
Despite Malawi's reassurance, Yeh said, the Foreign Ministry is remaining highly vigilant and closely watching related developments.

Huang had offered to resign to take political responsibility after the country severed formal diplomatic relations with Costa Rica on June 7 this year, but President Chen Shui-bian declined his resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices opened high and ended higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 194.04 points to close at 8,135.48.
The bourse opened at 8,074.44 and fluctuated between 8,135.48 and 8,061.31 during trading. A total of 3.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.93 billion (US$2.52 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 5.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 3.9 percent, paper and pulp shares at 3.1 percent, machinery and electronics stocks at 2.9 percent, textile issues at 2.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.1 percent, construction issues at 1.5 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 1.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,560 to 432, with 443 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Teachers' Association endorses legislative candidates

TEXT.P: The Taipei Teachers' Association has endorsed Kuomintang (KMT) Legislators Diane Lee and Alex Fai for the Jan. 12 legislative elections as their educational platforms won more than 60 percent of some 500 local teachers' support at a voting event held Sunday, a spokesman for the association said Monday.
The announcement came after the association organized the event in an effort to help lawmakers who are really concerned about the country's education system to get elected, the spokesman said.
Approximately 500 teachers from the city's various schools ranging from kindergartens to colleges took part in the event, the spokesman noted.
Before casting their votes, the teachers listened to the platforms of more than 20 legislative candidates, and those of several major and small political parties, the spokesman said.
The association will only endorse those who won over 60 percent of the vote, the spokesman said.

Incumbent KMT Legislator Ting Shou-chung, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidate Tuan Yi-kang, and incumbent KMT Legislator Lai Shyh- bao will not be endorsed, although they garnered over 50 percent of the vote, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 161 points to close at 8,131, with 37,275 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February rose 166 points to finish at 8,136, with 82 contracts traded, while March futures gained 183 points to close at 8,152, with 40 contract transactions. June futures increased 128 points to finish at 8,106, with 20 contract transactions, while September futures moved up 173 points to close at 7,961, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,970 for January, 7,970 for February, 7,969 for March, 7,978 for June and 7,788 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

January TE futures rose 7.95 points to close at 336, with 1,934 contracts traded, while February TE futures moved up 7.35 points to finish at 334.8, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures gained 13.8 points to close at 912.6, with 1,427 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 16.2 points to finish at 912.2, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.498.
A total of US$724 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.485 and fluctuated between NT$32.466 and NT$32.525

DOC.HEADLINE: Fu Jen University gets huge alumni donation

TEXT.P: The Department of Chemistry of Fu Jen Catholic University (FJU) in Taipei County received a donation of US$1.5 million from its alumni earlier this month, the biggest donation ever made by alumni to any privately run university in Taiwan.

Hsu Wen-hsien, director of the FJU Department of Chemistry, expressed appreciation to the donors -- several FJU alumni who preferred to remain anonymous -- and said the donation will be turned into a foundation for the development of the department.
Hsu said the interest from the donation will be used to fund scholarships for students and to meet the costs of improving the department's teaching materials and research facilities.
He added that his department has already received US$300,000 of the donation, which will be paid over five years.
Twelve graduates of the FJU Department of Chemistry have been selected as outstanding alumni for their extraordinary achievements in various fields.
The Chemistry Department is also one of the FJU institutes to boast the highest number of "outstanding alumni."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City Hospital inaugurates respiratory care ward

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Hospital Zhongxing Branch inaugurated a respiratory care ward (RCW) Monday, equipped with 32 beds for ventilator-dependent patients who are not otherwise in critical condition but who need long-term medical care.

Hospital officials said that other branches of the hospital -- which is operated by the city government -- including the Renai, Heping and Yangming branches, will open wards of this kind within the coming six months. By that time, there will be a total of 120 RCW beds in the capital, they added.

According to the Zhongxing branch, the ward is equipped with modern respiratory therapies, surveillance devices, physicians expert in respiratory and other serious diseases, and an independent ward for patients suffering from infection.

The cost for a RCW bed is NT$31,500 (US$969) per month, part of which is covered by National Health Insurance. In addition, a NT$30,000 cash deposit is required upon being admitted to the ward, which will be returned interest-free when the patient is discharged.
Taipei City Director of Health Chiu Wen-hsiang, Taipei City Hospital President Peng Ruei-peng and Zhongxing branch chief Liu Hsiu-wen presided over the inauguration ceremony.

Peng noted that there are around 16,000 patients in intensive-care wards around Taiwan, some 60 percent of whom rely on ventilators to survive. However, he went on, there are also ventilator-independent patients in stable condition who are excluded from intensive-care wards.
It has been estimated that there are around 6,000 ventilator-independent patients who need RCW care around the country, Peng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's highest mountain receives winter's first snowfall

TEXT.P: Yushan in central Taiwan received its first snowfall of this winter Monday when a moist cold front swept the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported later that day.
According to the CWB's Yushan monitoring station's report, the snow began to fall at 2: 05 p.m. on the mountain but lasted only 30 minutes. Less than a centimeter fell, the report said.
With a height of 3,952 meters, Yushan is the country's highest peak and the highest in Northeast Asia.

At 8: 30 a.m., the temperature on the mountain was recorded at minus 3 degrees Celsius, CWB meteorologists said, adding that there was little chance of further snow as the cold front was moving away from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tree planting drive to be launched to help boost Penghu tourism

TEXT.P: The Penghu Clan Association in Taipei City is set to launch a tree-planting drive on the outlying island of Penghu shortly to help boost the island's tourism.

Kao Chien-wen, chairman of the Penghu Clan Association in Taipei, claimed that the "only viable way" of bolstering Penghu's tourism in autumn and winter -- difficult seasons for conventional tourism due to the inclement weather -- is to plant trees to green the islands and make them appeal to visitors.
Kao said that despite Penghu's white sand beaches, emerald sea and beautiful scenery, the island group attracts in winter less than one-fourth of the tourists who visit in spring and summer.

He called for Penghu natives who live on Taiwan proper or people who have visited Penghu before -- Taiwan citizens or foreign nationals -- to each donate NT$2,000 (US$61.73) for each tree to be planted on the islands.
The donated trees, which will carry the donors' names and the date of planting, will be taken care of by caregivers on a daily basis as part of a long-term care project, Kao added.
There are about 1 million Penghu natives who live permanently on Taiwan proper.

Kao, who was scheduled to depart for Penghu the following day to officially launch the tree-planting drive, said the first-stage of the tree planting job is scheduled to be held in the Penghu capital of Makung Jan. 18-19, with ensuing planting to be carried out regularly each year between October and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Slogan of 101 fireworks display still mystery

TEXT.P: The 2008 New Year's Eve countdown will feature a fireworks display of unprecedented scale at Taipei 101, though the slogan to be illuminated on the world's tallest building remains a mystery, according to information released at a press conference Monday.

Addressing the press, Michael Liu, Assistant Vice President of the Taipei Financial Center Corp which owns the skyscrapper, said he does not want to spoil the surprise in advance. The cancellation of the originally planned press release of the Tourism Bureau, of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, which contributed NT$21 million in sponsorship to the project, has added to the suspense surrounding the event.
According to Liu, preparations for the show are taking place under a tight schedule but will be completed Friday for a circuit test.

When the clock strikes midnight Dec. 31, a total of 12,000 rounds of fireworks, 3,000 more than last year, will be launched from sites as high as 500 meters up the building, in 18 to 20 motifs, for a splendid 188 seconds, Liu said.

Noting the economic adversity in 2007, the color of "gold", symbolizing wealth and happiness, has been chosen as the theme color of this year's firework display, signifying a prosperous future and robust economy, he added.

The show will be 80 percent different from the previous ones, with the most up- to-date fireworks to ensure that the festivities outshine all other such events around the world, Liu went on, adding that this grand celebration is bound to be packed with excitement and splendor.

To accommodate people attending the fireworks display and countdown party, the 101 shopping mall, its food court, and all restaurants and cafes on the 4th floor will open until 2 a.m., Liu said, adding that there will also be a car exhibition featuring Italian luxurious automobiles from Ferrari and Maserati, Dec. 28 to Jan. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate to form constitutional reform task force if elected

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that if elected, he will form a task force on constitutional reform after two years in office.

Ma said the task force will study the merits and deficiencies of the existing Constitution, as well as the performance of the new, streamlined legislature that will have the number of its members halved to 113 from the present 225.

He said that if the ruling and the opposition parties can reach a consensus on constitutional reforms, he would be willing to push for further constitutional reforms "to live up to the aspirations of the public." The present Constitution, put into practice in 1947, has been amended seven times since 1991.
Ma made the remarks when he attended a symposium to mark the 60th anniversary of the Republic of China Constitution.
He described democracy as being aimed at the prevention of abuse and corruption, as well as the defense of the people's basic rights.
But he claimed that since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration came to power in 2000, it has dwelled on expanding ethnic division and creating rifts in Taiwan's "harmonious society."
The turbulence that has marred the DPP administration has shown the failings of a democracy "which has elections and no constitution," according to Ma.
He admitted that the present Constitution is far from perfect, but said that in general, it is a reasonable constitution that needs to be cherished.
Instead of "crafting a new constitution, " and "constitutional re-engineering" as advocated by the DPP, he urged the public not to damage or destroy, but to abide by the Constitution.

If elected president, he promised to appoint a candidate endorsed by a majority party or a majority coalition as premier, and said he will establish a mechanism that provides a better system of checks and balances in the spirit of the Constitution.
If the DPP wins a majority in the legislature, Ma said, he will appoint a DPP member to serve as premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: China will not ease suppression because of Taiwan election: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's upcoming presidential election will not cause China to relent in its obstruction of Taiwan internationally, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials predicted Monday.

The officials noted that some analysts have forecast that China will not bash Taiwan in the runup to the presidential election lest it backfires and boosts the campaign of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, although there have been signs recently that China will not relax its Taiwan policy due to the March 22 presidential election.

"The suppression has in fact risen unabated, " they said, adding that Beijing's Taiwan policy includes taking all of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, blocking all channels for Taiwan internationally and crushing all Taiwan's international room for maneuvering, commonly known as the "three all policy."

In addition to the African ally of Malawi, the ministry is also on full alert about possible changes in three Central American allies -- Panama, Dominican Republic and Haiti -- that Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang recently visited, they said.

The officials said this is because the ministry has learned that the three allies have been greatly pressured by China, prompting Huang to make a personal visit to solidify ties. The situation with Panama is especially stark, they noted.

Huang suggested that President Chen Shui-bian should attend the inauguration ceremony of Guatemalan President-elect Alvaro Colom Jan. 14 so as to meet with other national heads of state during the event and contribute to bilateral and multilateral relations between Taiwan and the nations of Central America.
The officials noted that while Huang was visiting Central America, the situation in Malawi gave cause for concern and that Deputy Foreign Minister Yang Tzu-pao was sent there to help shore up ties.
Reports said that a delegation of Malawi officials is ready to visit China, which might put bilateral ties with Taiwan in jeopardy.

Foreign officials have said that China has multiple strategic considerations with regard to Africa and that China knows exactly what it wants from the continent -- its valuable resources as well as Taiwan's allies switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
But they said that when Africa eyes major investment projects promised by China, they often neglect to consider whether China can deliver on its promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer victim enjoys last swim as Christmas gift

TEXT.P: A seven-year colorectal cancer fighter who loves swimming overcame her fatigue and sickness to carry out her last wish Monday -- enjoying a last swim as a Christmas gift from her family and friends.
Shue Yue-chi had been a morning swimmer for over a decade before she was diagnosed with cancer.
She did not give up swimming immediately, but continued her hobby in an effort to increase her strength so that she could better combat the cancer.
Three years ago, she swam across Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan and the following year, swam across South Bay in Kenting, southern Taiwan.
However, as her cancer recently worsened, Shue lost her strength and was unable to swim again, according to her husband, Chang Feng-chuang.

With fewer than six months to live as assessed by her doctors, Shue received encouragement from her swimming friends and decided to swim for the last time on Christmas Eve, although as the day dawned she considered giving up on the plan because she was too weak to walk. However, she later regained enough strength to follow her plan.
Helped by her friends and medical staff, Shue enjoyed 30 minutes of walking slowly in a swimming pool.

Tsai Chen-hua, Shue's doctor at Taipei Medical University Hospital, said that it requires careful preparation -- including forcing the patient to vomit and giving an injection of pain killers -- to allow a serious cancer sufferer to swim.
During Shue's last swim, several medical staff accompanied her in the swimming pool to monitor her situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to invite international heavyweights to Taiwan: lawmaker

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) plans to invite former high- ranking officials from several countries -- including former U.S. presidents and secretaries of state -- to visit Taiwan prior to the country's March 22 presidential election, a DPP lawmaker said Monday.

DPP Legislator Chuang Ho-tzu made the announcement in response to a recent report of the United Evening News claiming that the DPP is working through "international friends" to invite former U.S. presidents to take part in an activity supporting Taiwan's quest for membership in the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
A DPP-sponsored referendum backing the country's U.N. membership bid will be held alongside the presidential election.
Chuang confirmed the news report but declined to specify who will be invited to be members of a foreign delegation to observe Taiwan's presidential election.

Expressing worries that exposure of the details of the plan might trigger obstruction from China, Chuang said that media coverage of the DPP plan would increase the difficulties in inviting the guests.
According to Chuang, the foreign guests may include former Japanese prime ministers, former South Korean presidents, political heavyweights from the Philippines, Indonesia, and Singapore.
Chuang said the DPP will not only invite politicians and Nobel peace award winners, but also other celebrities who are concerned about Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets Tuvaluan prime minister

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thanked visiting Tuvaluan Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia Monday for the country's steadfast support of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization, and for speaking up for Taiwan in the international community.

Chen expressed his gratitude during a meeting with Ielemia and his wife at the Presidential Office, during which he also mentioned that Taiwan has several times dispatched mobile medical missions to Tuvalu this year, and said that he hopes bilateral medical exchanges and cooperation can be further strengthened.

Expressing his admiration for Taiwan's agricultural technical mission in Tuvalu, Chen noted the team has been successful growing more than twenty varieties of fruit and vegetables to help improve local people's diet and health.

Meanwhile, Ielemia also voiced his appreciation for Taiwan's assistance in fields including health care and agriculture, among others, adding that the medical missions were particularly welcome when providing care in his country's capital Funafuti as many of the people receiving medical care were from the country's offshore islands.
Ielemia, accompanied by Minister of Foreign Affairs James, visited the president, who was accompanied by Presidential Office Secretary-General Yeh Chu- lan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Service Center formed for Tainan County's Tree Valley Park

TEXT.P: A preparatory office was set up Monday to organize the establishment of a service center for the Tree Valley Park in Tainan County -- the world's first industrial park specifically serving LCD TV production and supporting industries.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, together with executives of the Linklinear Development Co., an affiliate of the Chi Mei Group, and top officials of the Southern Taiwan Science Park attended a ceremony to inaugurate the office.

Chin Mei plans to invest NT$15 billion (US$461.34 million) in developing the park. Linklinear, which holds an 11 percent stake in Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp. -- Taiwan's second-largest LCD panel manufacturer -- was awarded the build-operate-transfer (BOT) project in 2004.

The county government signed a 30-year contract with Linklinear in November to entrust the company with the management of the Tree Valley Park. The contract will generate NT$1 million in annual royalties in addition to savings of NT$24.7 million a year for the county government.

The 247-hectare industrial zone, located on the west edge of the Southern Taiwan Science Park, is intended to attract LCD TV upstream suppliers of glass, backlights, polarizer, lamps and driver ICs -- a key component of LCD panels -- to build facilities in the park to form an optoelectronics cluster that will dramatically improve LCD TV supply chain performance in Taiwan.
The development project passed an environmental impact assessment by a committee of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration in November.

A total of 150 hectares in the industrial park will be reserved for factory housing, with 50 hectares for a lake and an ecological area. The Tree Valley Park is so named because it will have 100,000 trees planted along a route around the park. To date, 13 LCD-related companies have purchased 60 percent of the land reserved to house factories, with nine of these having set up shop.
When fully operational, the Tree Valley Park is expected to create 20,000 jobs, with a business turnover of NT$300 billion per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Licence for 1st nuclear power plant might be renewed: AEC

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) confirmed Monday that the licence for the country's first nuclear power plant might be renewed for another 20 years.

AEC Chairman Su Hsien-chang said at a year-end news conference that his council has completed a time-limited integrated plant assessment (TLIPA) of the plant in Shihmen, Taipei County, which certifies that the plant can apply to operate for 20 additional years after its original licence of 40 years expires after 2017.

Su noted that if Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), which runs the country's nuclear power plants, applies for extended operation and if the AEC gives it a green light, then it will become the first extended operation nuclear power plant in Asia.
The AEC calculated that carbon dioxide emissions will be cut by 7.3 million tons a year if it can replace the country's thermal power plants powered by coal.
Asked whether more nuclear power plants should be built, Su only said that "Taiwan definitely will not have a fifth nuclear power plant."
Taiwan currently has three nuclear power plants in operation. The fourth, located in Kungliao, Taipei County, is expected to be completed in 2012 after years of controversy.

Because President Chen Shui-bian wanted to deliver on his no-nuclear power campaign promises after his election victory in 2000, the Executive Yuan stopped the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant in October that year. The suspension caused billions of dollars in losses before the government was forced to make an about-face and resume construction early the following year.

But the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan also reached an agreement Feb. 13, 2001 that while the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant should be resumed, the eventual goal would be a nuclear-free Taiwan.
The government thought about decommissioning the aging first and second nuclear power plants at that time, but a policy on the issue was never forged.
Su pointed out that because of soaring crude oil prices, licence renewals for nuclear power plants has become a trend.
He cited examples from the United States, saying that out of 103 nuclear power plants there, half of them have completed the process of licence renewal.

The AEC will send officials to the United States to receive related training, Su said, adding that once Taipower makes an application, the council will start the review process according to relevant regulations.
The review operation is expected to take between a year and 18 months, Su said.
The first of the two generating units of the first nuclear power plant started commercial operation in December 1978 and its licence will expire in 2017.

Asked whether the government will purchase more generating units for its nuclear power plants, Su said the first, second and fourth nuclear power plants could each add two more units. The third nuclear power plant has the room for six more units. Taipower will make its own assessment of the matter, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Too late to change MRT Neihu line train's interior design: officials

TEXT.P: Although the interior space of train cabins to be used on the still under- construction Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Neihu line seems cramped, city officials said Monday that it is too late now to change the cabins' interior design.

Media reporters and other guests were invited by the city's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DRTS) to take a trial run between the Neihu line's Sungshan Airport station and Jiannan station earlier in the day.

The new MRT cabins, manufactured by Bombardier Inc. a Canada-based manufacturer of regional aircraft, business jets, mass transportation equipment, appear to be similar in size to the French-made cabins used on the Muzha line, but the interior design is entirely different.

According to the DRTS, the Neihu line train cabin features an inner space 202 centimeters high -- 2 cm shorter than the Muzha line cabin. However, with LED devices on the ceiling, the new cabin is only 190 cm tall from the ceiling to ground.

In comparison with the inner width of the Muzha cabins, which are between 224 cm and 227 cm wide, those of the Neihu cabin measure 209 cm across. As a result, visitors to the Neihu line Monday were seen bumping against handrails from time to time.

Tsai Tien-ho, the DRTS official responsible for mechanical and electronic engineering affairs, admitted that the inner space of the new MRT cabins is more cramped than that of the Muzha train carriages, but 70 of 101 trains the city government has ordered from Bombardier have been delivered.
"It is too late to change the interior design, " he noted.
One possible means of resolving the space problem, he went on, is to increase operation services on the new line after its inauguration.

The Neihu line, which is still under construction, is a medium capacity system, with most of the line running on an elevated corridor, except for the section near Sungshan Airport. When complete, it will have a total length of 14.8 km and will connect directly to the Muzha Line, providing transfers to Neihu, Nangang and Muzha, according to the city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan issues ultimatum on voting method

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Jin-chun announced Monday that Taiwan's 25 cities and counties must adopt a "one-step" voting method in the coming polls, and that electoral personnel who do not follow the order will be replaced and may even be brought to justice.
According to Chen, the Central Election Commission (CEC) will issue a formal notification to this effect in two days to all local governments, their election commission chiefs and officials.

After the CEC has notified all cities and counties across the country of that demand, local authorities must obey the central government's order to employ the CEC-designed "one-step" voting procedure and will not be allowed to promote any other format in any materials, Chen said, adding that all election bulletins and polling stations must be prepared fully in line with the "one-step" voting method.
Anyone who defies the "one-step" method order will be dealt with strictly in accordance with the law, he asserted.

Chen made the remarks following a cross-agency task force meeting led by Deputy Premier Chiou I-jen to evaluate possible means to deal with 18 local governments controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) which have insisted on applying a "two-step" method.
Chiou called the meeting with officials from the CEC, the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Agency and the Central Personnel Administration.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said earlier the same day that the Executive Yuan might draw up a replacement list of election commission chiefs and personnel in some local governments due to the voting method dispute.

Now that the CEC has decided to employ the "one-step" voting method, the central government will absolutely not compromise on the voting method dispute, Shieh said, reiterating that to ensure smooth and orderly elections the central government will not permit two different voting systems to be applied during the same election.

Answering questions on whether these election commission chiefs and officials will be replaced, Shieh pointed out that the CEC has authority over local governments' election commissions which must abide by the central body's decision.
Shieh acknowledged that the central government has evidence that some local governments have printed materials against the CEC's "one-step" method decision.

In the face of Shieh's warning, Taipei city government spokesman Yang Shiao-tung said the city government will still adopt the "two-step" voting method, but he refused to comment on the Executive Yuan's plan to possibly replace municipal election commission personnel.
Yang said that the Taipei city government will respond to the issue only after it has received a formal written notification from the Executive Yuan.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and head of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, threatened to sue the CEC on charges of "dereliction of duty" if it withdraws election commission chiefs and officials favoring the "two-step" format.

The KMT will absolutely do so, as the Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution last week with a vote 102-92 demanding that the Executive Yuan employ the "two-step" voting method, Tseng said, claiming that the CEC has "shamefully become a dupe" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Localities do not have to obey illegal order: KMT hopeful

TEXT.P: The central government must act in accordance with the law and local governments do not have to follow its orders if they are not issued legally, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential hopeful Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.

Ma made the comments while answering questions from reporters after the Executive Yuan's spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said earlier the same day that it would consider replacing local election commission chiefs and officials who insist on adopting a "two-step" voting format in the coming elections.

The Executive Yuan has repeatedly said that all 25 cities and counties across the country must apply a "one-step" voting procedure designed by the Central Election Commission (CEC) and that the "two-step" scheme being broached by 18 KMT-controlled localities is unlawful.
According to Ma, all government authorities must act based on the law and, if they do not, the parties concerned do not have to follow their illegal and therefore non-binding orders.

As neither side in the dispute has showed any willingness to compromise over the impasse, Ma said that in compliance with the Law on Local Government Systems, such a dispute should be settled by the Legislative Yuan, rather than the Executive Yuan itself.
"It is difficult for the central government to expect others to abide by its orders if it fails to follow due process in issuing them," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA officials seize 7,000 pirated video game DVDs from fishing boat

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials seized 7,000 pirated video game DVDs from a fishing boat in Nanliao Fishing Port in Hsinchu early Monday.
A CGA spokesman said the CGA officials found the pirated DVDs, with an estimated market value of NT$12 million (US$461,340) in polystyrene boxes concealed under 18 tons of fish in the fishing boat.

The spokesman added that Tsai Tsung-ming, the 43-year-old captain of the fishing boat Hsieh Fu, and his two crew members were referred to the Hsinchu Public Prosecutors Office for violations of the nation's Copyright Law and the Customs Anti-smuggling Act.

According to the spokesman, the pirated Wii, Xbox and PS2 games were apparently manufactured in China because the DVDs carry simplified Chinese characters. The captain of the fishing boat admitted that he was asked by a friend to take the fake video games from Pintan, Fujian province, to Taiwan, where they would fetch good prices during the Christmas holiday.

The spokesman said the fishing boat left Nanliao Port Dec. 18 and returned three days later. CGA officials had placed the boat under surveillance and waited until the captain began to unload his catch of fish to confiscate the pirated goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. official's statement has little effect on public opinion: MAC

TEXT.P: As many as 78 percent of Taiwan's people still support holding a referendum on pushing for the country's U.N. membership under the name Taiwan despite a negative response from the United States, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Cheng-yuan said Monday.

According to Tung, only 14.2 percent of the respondents said they would change their attitude due to U.S. opposition to the planned referendum initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Taiwan's U.N. cause.

U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said last Friday in a year-end news conference that the United States supports a one-China policy and opposes Taiwan's referendum to join the United Nations as a provocative move.
"It unnecessarily raises tensions in the Taiwan Strait, and it comes with no real benefits for the people of Taiwan on the international stage. This is why we oppose this referendum, " Rice said.
Tung published the results of the MAC-commissioned public opinion poll at a seminar sponsored by the privately-run Taiwan Thinktank. The MAC will officially make public the survey's results Friday.

In response to Rice's description of the referendum as "provocative," Tung said that the United States might have overlooked China's growing saber-rattling over Taiwan and its relentless attempts to squeeze Taiwan out of the international arena.

Tung gave his assurances that Taiwan's official title, the Republic of China, will be retained even if voters approve the referendum, and pointed out that it is China which is continuously engaged in altering the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and undermining peace in the region.
In addition, he said, China's ambition to swallow up Taiwan has been unmistakable, with the number of its missiles targeting Taiwan increasing to more than 1,000 at present.

The root cause of cross-strait problems lies in China's refusal to recognize Taiwan's independent sovereignty and the fact that Taiwan does not form part of China, he said, stressing that the DPP-initiated referendum merely aims at airing, in a peaceful and democratic manner, the keen desire of Taiwan's people to play a greater international role.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to build tropical botanical garden

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu presided over a ground-breaking ceremony Monday for a tropical botanical garden to be built in the southern Taiwan port city.
The Kaohsiung city government has set aside NT$200 million (US$6.15 million) to develop the 23-hectare garden bordering Kaohsiung County.
Speaking at the ceremony, Chen said the botanical garden project is scheduled for completion in two years: before Kaohsiung hosts the biennial World Games in July 2009.

She added that in the future, the botanical garden will be expanded to link with two plots of land reserved for the No. 6 and No. 7 municipal parks and the Fengshan reservoir, so that these facilities will form a vast ecological area, with its 114-hectare area providing much space for the leisure activities of Kaohsiung's residents.

Chen said the city government has chosen the Hsiaokang district as the location of the botanical garden because the area is bristling with factories that discharge a lot of carbon dioxide into the neighborhood, and that residents in the area deserve something good in return.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan guards against changes in ties with Malawi

TEXT.P: Deputy Foreign Minister Yang Tzu-pao is on his way to Lilongwe, Malawi to cement bilateral ties after a Malawian newspapers said that African state is paving the groundwork for diplomatic ties with Beijing, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

Phoebe Yeh, acting spokeswoman for the ministry said Yang is on a mission to seek clarification from Malawi authorities despite its denial of a Dec. 21 report on Malawian online newspaper Nyasa Times that Malawi President Bingu wa Mutharika has agreed to switch recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The newspaper said President Bingu wa Mutharika has delegated Minister of Presidential Affairs, Davis Katsonga, and Henry Chimunthu Banda, who doubles as the government leader in parliament and minister of energy and mining, to travel to Beijing to open talks leading to diplomatic relations.
Yeh said Taipei is closely monitoring the development in light of the fact that "China is using astronomical figures of money to sabotage our ties with Malawi."
Yeh quoted Malawian Foreign Minister Joyce Banda as telling Taipei on Sunday that China has "attempted many times over the past several years to build better relations with Malawi."

However, she said, Taiwan's Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang summoned Malawian Ambassador in Taipei, Thengo Maloya, earlier that day and was assured by the Malawian envoy that there has been no change in his country's ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential hopeful challenges rival to debates

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential hopeful Frank Hsieh challenged his rival Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang to a series of debates on public policy in an open letter Tuesday.
Hsieh said in the letter that they should hold a debate every two weeks or every month on national policy and issues related to the public.
He sent Lee Ying-yuan, his executive campaign manager, to the KMT headquarters to deliver the letter.

Hsieh has sought an open debate with Ma on the issue of Taiwan's application for U.N. membership since October, but the details of the debate have not been thrashed out. He has therefore taken the initiative to write the letter to speed up the process.

Yeh Chu-lan, one of Hsieh's campaign managers and currently the secretary- general of the Presidential Office, also urged Ma to engage in debates with Hsieh on public policy as soon as possible as there are only 88 days left until the March 22 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: 921 earthquake-related stress adjustment shakes Taichung

TEXT.P: A magnitude 5.1 earthquake jolted Taichung City, central Taiwan, in the early hours of Tuesday, according to a report from the Central Weather Bureau's Seismological Center.

Center Deputy Director Lu Pei-ling indicated that the earthquake was found to have been caused by a stress adjustment subsequent to the massive 7.3-magnitude earthquake that shook the central county of Nantou Sept. 21, 1999, killing some 2,400 people.
The Tuesday earthquake occurred at 2: 28 a.m., 15.2 km southeast of the Seismological Center's Taichung City monitoring station. The epicenter was at 22.9 km underground, the report said.
The quake had an intensity of 5.1 in Changhua, and was followed by an aftershock with a magnitude of 3.7, which shook Nantou at 4:38 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture industry output to hit NT$55 billion by 2011

TEXT.P: The creative culture industry's output is expected to top NT$55 billion (about US$1.7 billion) by 2011 from last year's NT$47.9 billion and to create more than 6,000 job opportunities, an economic official said Tuesday.

The forecast came after the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved a plan proposed by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) to boost the development of arts and culture industry.

Under the terms of the plan, NT$5.64 billion will be invested in the industry over the next four years, a CCA official said, noting that the industry is high value-added and can effectively boost Taiwan's international profile.
The CCA will use the investment to push for the industrialization of the country's culture, crafts, and arts in an effort to transform Taiwan's economy, according to the official.

The plan consists of three programs aimed at improving the the environment for the industry, developing the craft creative industry and establishing a creative and cultural park, the official went on.
The CCA also aims to hold an international symposium demonstrating Taiwan's cultural creativity in 2011, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll shows Yulin County anti-corruption improves greatly

TEXT.P: Yulin County Magistrate Su Chi-fen ranks 11th out of all 23 county chiefs in Taiwan in the Ministry of Justice's (MOJ's) anti-corruption survey, which was revealed Monday.
The survey, dubbed "Research on Indicators and Reform of the National Integrity System, " was conducted by the non-governmental organization, Transparency International Taiwan, for the MOJ.
According to the survey, 54.5 percent of the people in Yulin County approved of Su's integrity, a significant improvement over her predecessors who long found themselves at the bottom of the survey.

At the same time, only 35.1 percent said they were satisfied with the transparency of the Yulin County government, compared to 9.6 percent who considered it average, 28.4 percent had no comment, and 26.8 percent said they were not satisfied.

Overall, people found "illegal influence peddling" to be the most seriously corrupt kind of behavior, followed by outright "bribery" and elaborate "wining and dining" activities, according to the Yulin County Civil Service Ethics Office.

Magistrate Su said the county government needs to reflect on why only 35.1 percent of the people were satisfied with its performance and strive to eliminate the culture of influence peddling, adding that priority should be given to educating people about how to report corruption since nearly 50 percent answered that they were unaware of how to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor vows to create model green city

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu vowed to build the city into a model green city as she celebrated the first anniversary of her four-year term Tuesday.
Chen, speaking of her vision of the port city in southern Taiwan, said that she and the administrative team will devote to the goal of building a "happy Kaohsiung" over the next three years.

"Happy Kaohsiung" will include the development of a healthful economy, provision of a comfortable living environment in its communities, the city's transformation into an international metropolis, and turn the city into a model green city and an urban center in southern Taiwan.
She noted that Kaohsiung is destined to be an industrial city, and that its carbon dioxide emissions are currently one of the highest in the world.
This is why she has set the development of a green economy as the basis of future development, with a focus on cutting carbon dioxide emissions, Chen added.
Chen said she plans to expand park areas and to transform the open spaces of buildings into more ecologically-friendly areas.

In addition, the city government is hoping to cut energy use by 10 percent in the next three years, build 20 kilometers of bicycle lanes each year, adopt low- pollution public transportation vehicles, increase greenery park space by 10 percent each year, push for shuttle bike projects, subsidize 2,000 taxies to switch to a dual-fuel (gasoline and gas) system and increase the ratio of garbage recycling to 30 percent within the next three years, Chen said.
Chen also aims to have the ratio of green industries account for five percent of Kaohsiung's output within three years and increase the recycle ratio of textbooks and stationery by 10 percent.

Chen noted that the city government has solicited nearly 70 billion (US$2.16 billion) from the central government, which she said will be used to finance the underground works of the city's railway system, the construction of the main stadium for the 2009 World Games, an international convention center and a popular music center.

On failing to deliver on her promise to have the MRT system inaugurated by the end of this year, Chen asked for more patience, saying that the residents will be able to enjoy a comfortable and convenient MRT system in the next two or three months.
