TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.59 points, or 0.38 percent, to close at 8,167.07.
The bourse opened at 8,166.18 and fluctuated between 8,181.61 and 8,119.85 during trading. A total of 3.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.78 billion (US$2.3 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.5 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, construction issues at 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.4 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares lost ground, moving down 0.3 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 855, with 510 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amoebic dysentery outbreak suspected in Kaohsiung hospital

TEXT.P: Fourteen patients in a mental institution in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung are suspected to have been infected with amoebic dysentery, health officials of the Kaohsiung county government said Tuesday.

The officials said that they were informed Dec. 19 by Hualien County that nine patients from Kaohsiung's Liang Jen Hospital who were recently transferred to a Yuli sanatorium in the county had a high concentration of amoebic dysentery antibodies in their blood. Further tests showed that three out of the nine have been infected with the disease.

The officials said that they began immediately disinfection work at Liang Jen Hospital and conducted tests on 105 patients. Fourteen of the patients were suspected to have been infected, although they have shown no symptoms of diarrhea.
Stool samples of the fourteen patients will be collected three times within the next week to determine whether they have been infected, the officials said.
Health officials also notified those patients that have been relocated to other institutions and those who have contacted them to adopt precautionary measures.
The officials said that those who live in groups, such as those residing at orphanages, nurseries, detention centers or prisons, are more prone to being infected with amoebic dysentery.

Gays and those who return to Taiwan after touring infected regions are also more prone to the disease, the officials said. Foreign workers and foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals also are infected with the disease from time to time, they added. Those who are infected will recover after taking medicines for one or two weeks, they further said.
Amoebic dysentery is often caused by infection with an ameba. This single-celled parasite is transmitted to humans via contaminated water and food.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traveling U.S. basketball team to visit Taiwan next month

TEXT.P: A traveling basketball team from the United States, known for its "show basketball"-style entertainment, will visit Taiwan next month and stage five exhibition games in five cities around the island, organizers said Tuesday.

The Harlem Wizards will play five exhibition games from Jan. 31-Feb. 4, 2008 in Taipei, Miaoli, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien to showcase their theatrical style and basketball tricks, said Vic Liu of the main organizer Bravo Communications.

The touring basketball team, which was established in 1962 and comprised of street basketball players, is well-known for its basketball show and tricks, rather than playing competition basketball. It has traveled all around the U.S. and five continents over its 46 years and played in more than 6,000 games, Liu said.

The team will be led by Arnold Bernard, nicknamed "A-Train, " the 165 cm tall guard best known for his dribbling skills. Bernard, 38, was also featured in a sneaker manufacturer Nike's "freestyle" theme commercial.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged to take flu vaccine

TEXT.P: Better later than never, a health official said Tuesday in an effort to persuade more members of the general public to get vaccinated against the flu.

Shih Wun-yi, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health, said the vaccine shot becomes fully effective only after three weeks, meaning that those taking it now will be shielded for only part of the peak flu season, which lasts from Christmas to early February. The vaccine is effective in helping to ward off the disease for a year afterward, but is most useful in the first six months.

Noting that the incidence of flu has reached alarming levels in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Hualien, Taitung, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung, Shih said there are still 350,000 doses of the vaccine available in the country.
He urged people who intend to take the government-funded free flu vaccine shots go to nearby hospitals or medical centers.
He estimated that the remaining 260,000 doses for adults and 88,000 doses for children will last through the next two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: No change in status quo despite U.N. bid referendum: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's planned referendum on pursuing U.N. membership under the name Taiwan will not alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Tuesday.
MOFA acting spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh made the comments in a news conference after Singapore's Foreign Ministry aired its objection to Taiwan's referendum plan earlier the same day.
According to Singapore, a referendum on applying for U.N. membership for Taiwan is provocative and would increase Taiwan's isolation in the international community.
Singapore's Foreign Ministry also stressed its "one China" policy and its opposition to either side of the strait taking unilateral move to change the status quo between the two sides.
Expressing regret over Singapore's negative response to the issue, Yeh ascribed the development to pressure from China.

Yeh said that holding the referendum merely aims to transmit the keen desire of Taiwan's people to join the United Nations, and asserted that doing so will neither contribute to a change in Taiwan's official designation, nor alter the cross-strait status quo, or cause instability in the region.
According to a ranking MOFA official, Singapore's negative reaction to Taiwan's planned referendum is a follow-up to explicit opposition from the United States.

The official, who preferred anonymity, criticized the U.S. side for dancing to Beijing's tune and voiced grave concerns that pressure from China and the United States would negatively affect international opinion toward Taiwan.
Nevertheless, he expressed hope that the international community would have faith in Taiwan's ability to adequately hold the referendum and deal with cross-strait relations.

U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said last Friday in a year-end news conference that the United States supports a "one China" policy and opposes Taiwan's referendum to join the United Nations, describing the move as a "provocative policy."
"It unnecessarily raises tensions in the Taiwan Strait, and it comes with no real benefits for the people of Taiwan on the international stage. This is why we oppose this referendum, " Rice said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND to safeguard late presidents' mausoleums before handover

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday that it will continue safeguarding the mausoleums of the late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo before handing over administration of the sites to the Taoyuan county government.

MND spokesman Yu Sy-tue said at a briefing Tuesday that after the shutdown of its mausoleum administration in Taoyuan county, northern Taiwan and the withdrawal of military guards posted at the two mausoleums Dec. 24, security will still be provided.
Yu said the district reserve command is now in charge of taking inventory of the assets and artifacts of the mausoleums to pave the way for transfer operations.
In addition to the reserve command officials and the transfer team, the military police stationed nearby will also provide security, said Yu.
Yu pointed out that the Ministry of the Interior will be in charge of the relocation and interment of the two late presidents, and the MND will act in accordance with its instructions.

Yu said that the ministry had originally planned to complete the relocation of the remains of the two late presidents to Wutzushan military cemetery in Taipei county for burial by September 2005, but family members of the late presidents -- citing the deaths of Faina Chiang, wife of Chiang Ching-kuo, in December 2004, and Nancy Chiang, daughter-in-law of the late president in August 2005, which dealt the family a great blow -- couldn't reach a decision on the time of relocation.

The MND said the ministry wrote to the late president's family members Nov. 29 to inform them that the MND management and the guards of the two mausoleums will be withdrawn and to express the ministry's hope that they would make a decision on interment, but has yet to receive an answer.
MND officials also said that out of security concerns, before the handover of the mausoleums and their re-opening, the military will only consent to visits from Chiang's family members.
The elder Chiang died in 1975, while his son passed away in 1988. Originally, both were temporarily placed in Tashi until such time as their bodies could be returned to China for proper burial.
President Chen Shui-bian, branding the elder Chiang a dictator, said recently that there is no reason to use taxpayers' money to guard his mausoleum any longer.
The Taoyuan county government has said it is willing to take over the administration of the two mausoleums, noting that they bring a great deal of tourism revenue to the county annually. revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Container volume at Kaohsiung harbor sets record

TEXT.P: The number of containers handled at Kaohsiung harbor in southern Taiwan in 2007 is expected to hit a new high of 10.2 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs), officials at the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Tuesday.

The figure would mean an increase of 4.4 percent, or 430,000 TEUs, over 2006 -- the year in which Kaohsiung harbor handled a record 9,774,670 TEUs to retain its status as the sixth largest container port in the world.

According to the officials, the number of containers handled at Kaohsiung harbor this year formally surpassed the 10 million mark Dec. 24 when Ever Ursula, a container ship of Evergreen Marine Corp. -- Taiwan's biggest shipping line -- offloaded over 5,000 containers.

The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau is currently working on an intercontinental container center project within the harbor. When the first stage of the project is completed, the harbor's container handling capacity will increase by 2 million TEUs a year.
Kaohsiung used to be the world's third largest container port in the 1990s, but its ranking has slipped in recent years.

Based on figures from 2006, Containerisation International Magazine, an authoritative source of information about the container industry, has ranked Kaohsiung as the world's sixth largest container port, after five other seaports in east Asia: Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Shenzhen in China's Guangdong province, and Busan in South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former KMT chairman questioned over special funds

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and his wife were summoned early this month for questioning on the use of Lien's "special allowance funds" during his tenures as premier and vice president, a spokesman for the Special Investigation Task Force under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Tuesday.

Noting that the special task force is also engaged in the investigation into the legitimacy of the KMT's sale of its assets, the spokesman for the panel said that the unit has been looking into the party's asset transaction records and relevant materials to learn more about the party's funding sources and cash flow.

The spokesman added the actions came after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus filed a petition with the Supreme Prosecutors Office to probe into suspected misuse of "special allowance funds" of 97 Cabinet chiefs and officials under the previous KMT administration, including former premiers Hau Pei-tsun, Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as well as the KMT's standard bearer for the 2008 presidential election Ma Ying-jeou, who used to be minister of justice, chairman of the Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council.

According to the spokesman, the panel has looked into the original accounting proofs and accounting books and summoned witnesses to give testimony in the cases against Lien, the current KMT's vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew, incumbent KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, former Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh and many other officials.

The spokesman said Lien was allowed to return after answering inquiries from the prosecutors as to how he claimed reimbursement of his "special allowance funds" and "state affairs fund" during his premir and vice presidential terms, respectively.

The spokesman said that to gain a better understanding of progress in the handling of the cases, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Gao Jyh-peng, Hsieh Hsin-ni, Wang Tuoh and Yang Fang-wan paid a visit to Chen Yun- nan, director of the Special Investigation Task Force, Monday.

Claiming that the investigative panel handled special fund cases involving the DPP officials in an extraordinary speedy manner, the DPP lawmakers complained during their meeting with Chen that the cases involving the KMT's Lien, Siew and Wu have progressed in a relative slow manner.

Meanwhile, indicating that Lien allegedly used Pacific Sogo Department Store's uniform invoices to claim reimbursement from his "state affairs fund" totalling NT$1.2 million while serving as the country's vice president, Hsieh questioned why the investigation panel has yet to produce any results concerning the case.

In response, Chen explained that as prosecutors, who were assigned to take charge of cases related to the transfer of KMT assets and special funds, have been concurrently dealing with the special allowance cases involving DPP heavyweights, such as Vice President Annette Lu, they are too busy to handle all the cases at the same time.
Chen added, however, that the prosecutors will ratchet up their efforts on the KMT cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 11 points to close at 8,143, with 30,618 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February rose seven points to finish at 8,143, with 125 contracts traded, while March futures lost one point to close at 8,151, with 19 contract transactions. June futures increased 34 points to finish at 8,140, with six contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,132 for January, 8,136 for February, 8,152 for March, 8,106 for June and 7,961 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

January TE futures rose 0.9 points to close at 336.9, with 1,812 contracts traded, while February TE futures moved up one point to finish at 335.8, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures lost three points to close at 909.2, with 2,079 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved down 2.2 points to finish at 910, with 24 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGIvy League generosity is luring brightest away from Oxbridge
A record number of talented British teenagers are snubbing Oxbridge and applying to Ivy League universities, lured by more substantial American bursaries. Students from families whose household income isG90,000 qualify for financial assistance at Harvard. It also recently raised its threshold for free tuition and board for the poorest students.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidates may be subpoenaed over special allowance fees

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential hopeful Ma Ying-jeou, and his running mate, Vincent Siew, may be summoned for questioning over their use of special allowance funds while serving as ranking appointees in the previous KMT administration, Chen Yun-nan, a spokesman for the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Tuesday.

Chen, director of the Special Investigation Task Force under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said Ma and Siew may be summoned and questioned by prosecutors if necessary, regardless of any possible impact on the approaching March 22, 2008 presidential election.

According to Chen, the special investigation panel has been doing its best to probe the cases involving Ma and Siew following due process of the law after the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) filed a charge May 17 with the Supreme Prosecutors Office accusing 97 former KMT Cabinet chiefs and ranking government officials of embezzling special allowance funds or state affairs funds allocated for their discretionary use.

Ma, who used to be justice minister, chairman of the Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, and Siew, who served as premier and minister of economic affairs, are among those under investigation, as are former Vice President Lien Chan and former Premier Hau Pei-tsun.

According to Chen, the prosecutors in charge have interrogated Lien and his wife as well as secretaries and accounting officials of ex-Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, among many others, for the same purpose.

In response to speculation that Siew might be interrogated in the near term by the special investigation panel over his special allowance funds when serving in the previous KMT administration, Siew declined to comment the issue on the grounds that he has yet to receive a subpoena.
Ma, the KMT presidential candidate, denied knowledge of Lien's affairs. Lien now is the KMT's honorary chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: Power plant investment increases amid raw material price hikes

TEXT.P: The government will boost its investment in a power plant renovation project in the northern county of Taipei to NT$152.4 billion (US$4.7 billion) due to soaring international prices for raw materials and machines, an economic official said Tuesday.

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) originally planned to allocate NT$83 billion for the state-run Taiwan Power Co.'s (Taipower's) Linkou power plant renovation, the CEPD official noted.
The investment plan has been held up for two years due to some environmentalists' concerns about the environmental impact of the plan, the CEPD official noted.

Two years ago, prices of equipment and materials were low, the official went on, adding that now, the approval of the plan comes amid a boom in construction projects in China and India, which has resulted in skyrocketing prices of raw materials and rising demands for equipment and machines.

In addition, an increasing number of professionals with experience working on the plant have begun to retire, which will further delay the completion of the renovation, slated for 2020, and increase costs, according to a Taipower spokesman.
The power plant, which supplies electricity to northern Taiwan, will use more efficient components in the future and produce less air pollution, the spokesman said.
Meanwhile, acquiring the large volume of construction materials needed for the power plant will help boost the local economy, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairman to begin second round of legislative election campaign

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who also serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , will begin the second round of his campaign efforts for DPP legislative candidates Jan. 2, a DPP official said Tuesday.

Chen has already helped raise the profiles of the party's candidates in the entire 73 electoral districts, the official said, adding that during the second round, Chen will focus on 25 hotly contested districts prior to the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
In addition, he is also expected to attend at least 20 campaign rallies in an attempt to boost the popularity of the candidates, the official went on.
Meanwhile, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh will also intensify his efforts to help DPP legislative candidates get elected, beginning Dec. 27, the official said.
He noted that the DPP has established an anti-vote-buying task force, with Vice President Annette Lu, who is also a DPP member, serving as convener.
The task force met Tuesday to discuss strategies for fighting vote-buying, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, Korean museums form sister partnership

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts (NTMFA) and Korea's Gwanju Museum of Art (GMA) officially established a sister partnership to promote art development in the two countries, a Taiwanese official announced Tuesday.

Gwanju is symbolic in the development of Korean culture and democracy, as the city is the site of a civil demonstration and ensuing massacre in the 1980s and has long been a hotbed of Korean popular culture, said Wong Chin-chu, chairwoman of the Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA), at the signing ceremony.
An exhibition of Taiwanese contemporary art will be held alongside the Gwangju Biennale in September 2008, Wong added.
The two sides will collaborate on a wide range of projects, including exhibitions, academic research programs, exchange of curators and exchange of information, she said.
Park Ji-taek, president of the GMA and himself an oil painter, and Lim Jong- young, a GMA curator, also attended the signing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranked top in cluster development in WEF rating

TEXT.P: Taiwan was placed in top position in a rating on the state of cluster development, part of various ratings conducted by the World Economic Forum (WEF) for its 2007-2008 global competitiveness report, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Tuesday.
Taiwan was given 5.7 points out of a possible score of 7 points in the rating, and was acclaimed as a global model in terms of cluster development of innovative industries.

CEPD officials said industrial clusters have been a locomotive of Taiwan's development in terms of innovation and productivity, noting the existing clusters include the high-tech sector and the traditional manufacturing sector, powered by unique local handicraft skills.

In Taipei, for example, the officials said there are industrial clusters in the fields of digital content and ceramic production, while clusters in the production of optical disks automobiles and glass products can be found in Hsinchu.
In central Taiwan, there are industrial clusters of bicycles, precision machinery and musical instruments in Taichung, and clusters of sock-weaving and bicycle production in Changhua.

To sharpen Taiwan's industrial competitive edge in the global and Asian markets, efforts will be reinforced to form and upgrade clusters of local traditional industries to help boost local economic growth and create employment opportunities, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Study shows common yam helpful in repairing liver damage

TEXT.P: A research program conducted by a National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) student has led to the finding that extracts from the roots of rhizoma dioscoreae, also known as the common yam, can help repair damaged livers.
Wei Hsi-ju, a student of the NCKU's Department of Life Sciences, won an award from the Cabinet-level National Science Council for his study on mice.
Wei used carbon tetrachloride to induce liver cirrhosis in the mice and then injected them with doses of rhizoma dioscoreae extract.
Statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Department of Health in 2005 show that liver cirrhosis was the No. 7 cause of death in Taiwan in that year, accounting for 4 percent of the annual death toll.

The experiment found that the extracts increased antioxidant activity in the liver tissue of the mice and reduced liver function abnormalities. It also discovered that the extracts were effective in curbing lipidic overoxidation in the mice and in repairing their damaged liver DNA.
Rhizoma dioscoreae is called shanyao in Chinese. Its chemical composition consists of mainly dioscin and allantoin.
For his research, Wei used a purple variety of the plant that was supplied by the Agricultural Research and Extension Station in Taichung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily news stories most detailed: survey

TEXT.P: The Apple Daily newspaper produces the most detailed news reports and has the greatest influence on society compared with other Chinese-language newspapers in Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey also shows that the United Daily News has the most in-depth news stories, while the Taipei-based China Times has the most widespread coverage of global events.

The survey, now in its fourth year, was conducted by Shih Hsin University's College of Journalism and Communications among 1,100 people aged between 15 and 64 in 25 cities and counties via face-to-face interviews.
The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

The survey -- which also included the interviewees' preferences in terms of local magazines, radio stations, television stations and Web portals in Taiwan -- is part of the college's efforts to understand the public's evaluations of the quality of the media and the media's social influence, said James Hsiung, dean of the college.
Hsiung said the survey respondents are more often exposed to TV than to newspapers and the Internet and that TV news channels are the biggest source of news for the respondents.
However, he described the objectivity of TV news as doubtful, as TV stations often compete to obtain news as fast as possible.
The survey shows that the respondents regard the United Daily News, Apple Daily, and the Liberty Times, in that order, as the top three newspapers in Taiwan.
The respondents believe that Apple Daily, -- followed by the Liberty Times and the United Daily -- has the most detailed and news stories, the survey shows.
The top three newspapers in terms of in-depth news articles are the United Daily News, the China Times and the Liberty Times, in that order, according to the survey results.
In terms of global perspective, the China Times tops the survey, while the United Daily and the Liberty Times are second and third, respectively, according to the survey.
In addition, the top three most-watched TV stations are Formosa TV, Sanlih E-Television, and China Television, the survey shows.
Meanwhile, the respondents said they also watch the HBO movie channel, the Da-Ai Television channel, the CTI news channel, and the Sanlih news channel.
The Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC), the UFO Network, and the Police Radio Station are the most popular radio stations among the respondents.
The most widely read magazines among the respondents are Next Magazine, the China Times Weekly, Business Weekly Magazine, and CommonWealth Magazine, in that order, the survey shows.
In terms of using Web portals, the respondents prefer the Taiwan version of Yahoo to that of MSN and Google, as well as PChome Online, in that order, the survey indicates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier endorses `one-step' voting format

TEXT.P: Chang made clear the Executive Yuan's stance to reporters in YiIan County, northeastern Taiwan, where he attended two ceremonies marking the inauguration of a national highway memorial plaque and a Tourism Bureau administration office in the Northeastern National Scenic Area in the county.

Brushing aside accusations that the Executive Yuan's insistence on applying the "one-step" voting format is merely electoral maneuvering or political infighting, Chang said the central government, based on the principle of rule of law, aims to ensure smooth and orderly polls by choosing the "one-step" procedure legally prescribed by the CEC.

The Executive Yuan announced a day earlier that the "one-step" format must be fully employed throughout Taiwan's 25 cities and counties in the legislative and presidential elections slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively.

Election commission chiefs and officials of some local governments who insist on the adoption of a "two-step" voting procedure in the two elections will be replaced or brought to justice, according to Executive Yuan Secretary- General Chen Jin-chun. Most of those who insist on adopting a "two-step" format are from the main opposition Kuomintang-controlled localities.

DOC.HEADLINE: More than 110 million sleeping pills prescribed in 2006: DOH

TEXT.P: More than 110 million sleeping pills containing zolpidem were prescribed in Taiwan in 2006, marking per capita annual consumption of nearly five pills, Department of Health (DOH) officials said Tuesday.

A subsequent probe, the officials went on, discovered that at least 50 people consumed the drugs -- covered by national health insurance -- in an amount "beyond imagination, " with one consumer getting more than 7,300 pills with doctor's prescriptions in a period of six months.

The DOH has issued 17 marketing certificates for depressants and sleeping pills containing zolpidem, a prescription medication used for the short-term treatment of insomnia. Among these, the most popular in Taiwan is Stilnox, said Hsu Ping- chang, head of the second division of the DOH National Bureau of Controlled Drugs.
Citing bureau statistics, Hsu said that 55.79 million pills of Stilnox were prescribed in Taiwan last year.

In the middle of this year, Hsu went on, the bureau received many reports from hospitals and clinics around the island suggesting that people were being paid to get Stilnox prescriptions at hospitals and clinics.

Since the cost of the medication is covered by the national insurance system, the DOH suspects that many of the people who got prescriptions for large amounts of Stilnox over the past half year were paid to do so by drug traffickers, Hsu said.

The probe found that one woman from Taipei acquired 7,398 Stilnox-containing sleeping pills during the January-June period, making her the largest single consumer. The second-largest Stilnox consumer was found to have acquired 7,137 pills from various medical facilities, Hsu said, noting that such a volume would mean that the person was consuming an average of 40 pills of Stilnox per day.
These two people, along with 15 others, have been blacklisted by the DOH, which has imposed restrictions against their requests for Stilnox, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks 17th in world in number of academic articles

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 17th in the world in terms of the number of articles published by academics during 2006, the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) announced Tuesday.

Data revealed at a council meeting shows that Taiwanese academics published 16,545 articles last year in journals covered by the Science Citation Index Expanded, which provides information on more than 6,400 of the world's leading scholarly science and technical journals covering more than 150 disciplines.
The 2006 performance moved Taiwan up one notch from 2005, with the 16,545 articles being cited 2.87 times each on average, up from the 2.74 times recorded for 2005.

In the area of engineering articles, Taiwan ranks 11 in the world, with 13,076 articles published by its academics in journals covered by the Ei Engineering Village 2 -- a Web-based discovery platform set up by Engineering Information Inc. of the United States to meet the information needs of the engineering community.
The bibliographic database contains over 5 million records and references to more than 5,000 engineering journals and conferences over 30 years.

The statistics compiled by the NSC also show that Taiwanese inventors were granted 6,360 patents in the United States, placing the country in the No. 4 spot globally -- the same ranking it enjoyed in 2005.
According to the figures, for every 1,000 of the employed population in Taiwan, 9.4 people devoted themselves full-time to research and development in 2006, up from the 8.9 individuals in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's R&D spending accounts for 2.58 percent GDP: NSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent NT$307 billion (US$9.5
billion) on research and development in 2006, accounting for 2.58 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for the year, a National Science Council (NSC) official said Tuesday.
NSC Vice Chairman Yang Hung-tun made the remarks after a meeting of NSC commissioners during which the results of a national survey on 2006 R&D were unveiled.
Quoting the survey results, Yang said the country's 2006 R&D expenditure grew by 9.3 percent over the 2005 level.
In terms of the GDP ratio, Yang said, the 2006 figure increased 0.13 percentage points from 2005, when R&D spending accounted for 2.45 percent of that year's GDP.

Of the 2006 R&D funding, the government sector contributed 31.4 percent of the total, the industrial sector accounted for 67.2 percent and the remaining 1.4 percent came from other sectors, according to Yang.

In comparison, the government's share of R&D funds dropped slightly from the 2005 level of 31.5 percent, but the industrial sector's contribution increased from 66.9 percent to 67.2 percent. In terms of the share contributed by other sectors, including higher education institutions, non-profit private organizations and expatriate donors, there was a decrease from 1. 6 percent to 1.4 percent.
Because of legislative cuts, Yang said, the government's R&D investment increased a mere 8.8 percent in 2006 compared with the year-earlier level.
Given the slow growth in the public R&D funds, Yang said the NSC's goal of having the country's total R&D investment reach 3 percent of GDP cannot be realized in 2008.

"Many NSC commissioners expressed hope at Tuesday's meeting that the 3 percent goal can be achieved in 2010, " Yang said, adding that the goal could be attained if the government's annual R&D spending can be increased by 10 percent to 12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu mayor resigns from top city election commission post

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer announced his resignation from the northern city's top election commission post Tuesday, citing as reasons the recent squabbling between central and local governments over the voting format for the upcoming legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.

Lin told a news conference that he feels frustrated by the nagging quarrel over whether the Jan. 12 legislative elections and two referendums to be held alongside should adopt a "one-step" voting format insisted by the Central Election Commission or a "two-step" format adamantly advocated by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

With two experienced officials in the city's election commission tendering their resignations Monday, Lin, a KMT loyalist, said he decided to resign from the chairmanship of the municipal election commission in hopes that the upcoming critical elections can proceed smoothly.

Lin's resignation came as a surprise to KMT authorities. Huang Yu-chen, a KMT spokesman, said Lin had not informed the party central of his decision prior to his announcement. Nevertheless, Huang said he believes that Lin's resignation was just an isolated case and will not have any "domino effect."
According to Huang, the heads of the election commissions of the 18 KMT- controlled localities have long been determined to follow a "two-step" voting procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday.

The weighted price index was down 41.62 points at 8,125.45 on a turnover of NT$2.39 billion (US$73.54 million) at the open. The index gained 31.59 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 8,167.07 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
