DOC.HEADLINE: More than 110 million sleeping pills prescribed in 2006: DOH

TEXT.P: More than 110 million sleeping pills containing zolpidem were prescribed in Taiwan in 2006, marking per capita annual consumption of nearly five pills, Department of Health (DOH) officials said Tuesday.

A subsequent probe, the officials went on, discovered that at least 50 people consumed the drugs -- covered by national health insurance -- in an amount "beyond imagination, " with one consumer getting more than 7,300 pills with doctor's prescriptions in a period of six months.

The DOH has issued 17 marketing certificates for depressants and sleeping pills containing zolpidem, a prescription medication used for the short-term treatment of insomnia. Among these, the most popular in Taiwan is Stilnox, said Hsu Ping- chang, head of the second division of the DOH National Bureau of Controlled Drugs.
Citing bureau statistics, Hsu said that 55.79 million pills of Stilnox were prescribed in Taiwan last year.

In the middle of this year, Hsu went on, the bureau received many reports from hospitals and clinics around the island suggesting that people were being paid to get Stilnox prescriptions at hospitals and clinics.

Since the cost of the medication is covered by the national insurance system, the DOH suspects that many of the people who got prescriptions for large amounts of Stilnox over the past half year were paid to do so by drug traffickers, Hsu said.

The probe found that one woman from Taipei acquired 7,398 Stilnox-containing sleeping pills during the January-June period, making her the largest single consumer. The second-largest Stilnox consumer was found to have acquired 7,137 pills from various medical facilities, Hsu said, noting that such a volume would mean that the person was consuming an average of 40 pills of Stilnox per day.
These two people, along with 15 others, have been blacklisted by the DOH, which has imposed restrictions against their requests for Stilnox, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks 17th in world in number of academic articles

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 17th in the world in terms of the number of articles published by academics during 2006, the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) announced Tuesday.

Data revealed at a council meeting shows that Taiwanese academics published 16,545 articles last year in journals covered by the Science Citation Index Expanded, which provides information on more than 6,400 of the world's leading scholarly science and technical journals covering more than 150 disciplines.
The 2006 performance moved Taiwan up one notch from 2005, with the 16,545 articles being cited 2.87 times each on average, up from the 2.74 times recorded for 2005.

In the area of engineering articles, Taiwan ranks 11 in the world, with 13,076 articles published by its academics in journals covered by the Ei Engineering Village 2 -- a Web-based discovery platform set up by Engineering Information Inc. of the United States to meet the information needs of the engineering community.
The bibliographic database contains over 5 million records and references to more than 5,000 engineering journals and conferences over 30 years.

The statistics compiled by the NSC also show that Taiwanese inventors were granted 6,360 patents in the United States, placing the country in the No. 4 spot globally -- the same ranking it enjoyed in 2005.
According to the figures, for every 1,000 of the employed population in Taiwan, 9.4 people devoted themselves full-time to research and development in 2006, up from the 8.9 individuals in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's R&D spending accounts for 2.58 percent GDP: NSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent NT$307 billion (US$9.5
billion) on research and development in 2006, accounting for 2.58 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for the year, a National Science Council (NSC) official said Tuesday.
NSC Vice Chairman Yang Hung-tun made the remarks after a meeting of NSC commissioners during which the results of a national survey on 2006 R&D were unveiled.
Quoting the survey results, Yang said the country's 2006 R&D expenditure grew by 9.3 percent over the 2005 level.
In terms of the GDP ratio, Yang said, the 2006 figure increased 0.13 percentage points from 2005, when R&D spending accounted for 2.45 percent of that year's GDP.

Of the 2006 R&D funding, the government sector contributed 31.4 percent of the total, the industrial sector accounted for 67.2 percent and the remaining 1.4 percent came from other sectors, according to Yang.

In comparison, the government's share of R&D funds dropped slightly from the 2005 level of 31.5 percent, but the industrial sector's contribution increased from 66.9 percent to 67.2 percent. In terms of the share contributed by other sectors, including higher education institutions, non-profit private organizations and expatriate donors, there was a decrease from 1. 6 percent to 1.4 percent.
Because of legislative cuts, Yang said, the government's R&D investment increased a mere 8.8 percent in 2006 compared with the year-earlier level.
Given the slow growth in the public R&D funds, Yang said the NSC's goal of having the country's total R&D investment reach 3 percent of GDP cannot be realized in 2008.

"Many NSC commissioners expressed hope at Tuesday's meeting that the 3 percent goal can be achieved in 2010, " Yang said, adding that the goal could be attained if the government's annual R&D spending can be increased by 10 percent to 12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu mayor resigns from top city election commission post

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer announced his resignation from the northern city's top election commission post Tuesday, citing as reasons the recent squabbling between central and local governments over the voting format for the upcoming legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.

Lin told a news conference that he feels frustrated by the nagging quarrel over whether the Jan. 12 legislative elections and two referendums to be held alongside should adopt a "one-step" voting format insisted by the Central Election Commission or a "two-step" format adamantly advocated by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

With two experienced officials in the city's election commission tendering their resignations Monday, Lin, a KMT loyalist, said he decided to resign from the chairmanship of the municipal election commission in hopes that the upcoming critical elections can proceed smoothly.

Lin's resignation came as a surprise to KMT authorities. Huang Yu-chen, a KMT spokesman, said Lin had not informed the party central of his decision prior to his announcement. Nevertheless, Huang said he believes that Lin's resignation was just an isolated case and will not have any "domino effect."
According to Huang, the heads of the election commissions of the 18 KMT- controlled localities have long been determined to follow a "two-step" voting procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 26, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: 3.6% of industries, services overstaffed in 2007: survey

TEXT.P: A total of 3.6 percent of businesses in Taiwan's industrial and service sectors were overstaffed this year, down 4.8 percentage points from 8.4 percent in 2005, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

DGBAS officials attributed the improvement in the overstaffing situation to the bettering business climate or corporate mergers in the manufacturing, financial and insurance industries as well as the professional, scientific and technical service industries.

The survey, conducted by the DGBAS in August, revealed that 4.5 percent of businesses in the industrial sector had too many employees, including 5.1 percent of those in the mining and quarrying industries, 4.7 percent in the manufacturing industry, and 3.8 percent in the construction industry.

Meanwhile, 3.1 percent of businesses in the service sector were overstaffed, including 5.5 percent of those in the accommodation and restaurant industries, 5.4 percent in the cultural, sports and leisure service industries, and 5 percent in the medical and healthcare service industries, the results showed.

Among businesses in the Hsinchu Science Park, only 1 percent were overstaffed, marking a drop of 7.3 percentage points from 8.3 percent in the previous survey carried out in June 2005. No overstaffing was reported among businesses in the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

The survey found that sluggish sales were responsible for the overstaffing problem in Taiwan's industrial and service sectors, with 92 percent of the overstaffed businesses coping with the situation by leaving new vacancies unfilled.
While 66.7 percent of overstaffed businesses in the Hsinchu Science Park attributed the problem to corporate reorganization, 33.3 percent blamed it on sluggish sales.

On measures to cope with overstaffing, 66.7 percent of the businesses laid off excess workers or transferred them to other departments or affiliated businesses, compared with 33.3 percent which left new vacancies unfilled, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan economic growth forecast at 4.2% for 2008: think-tank

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Polaris Research Institute forecast Wednesday that Taiwan's economic growth will reach 4.2 percent for 2008, slightly lower than this year's 5.41 percent, mainly as a result of slower growth abroad.

Taiwan's economic growth for 2008 is expected to be lower mainly due to the fact that overseas markets, particularly the United States, Europe and China, which have been driving forces behind Taiwan's economic growth over the last two years, are forecast to be "highly uncertain, " said Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the research think-tank, at a press briefing.
Domestically, Liang said, consumption in the private sector is expected to grow "mildly" for 2008 due to a higher level of per capita income.

On the inflation rate, Liang predicted that the consumer price index (CPI) will reach 1.95 percent for 2008, marking an increase over the level for 2007 which is forecast to top 1.55 percent, mainly as a result of rising prices of crude oil and raw food materials on the international market.

Liang also predicted that the country's currency, the New Taiwan dollar, will not gain much against the U.S. dollar next year -- saying the exchange rate will be around NT$32 to US$1 for the year -- mainly because the NT dollar has not appreciated much while the greenback has depreciated over the past several months and because an end to capital flight from Taiwan is not yet in sight.
Meanwhile, the think-tank revised upward its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 from 4.61 percent to 5.41 percent, with a CPI expansion of 1.55 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bullet train service launch chosen as top domestic news event of 2007

TEXT.P: The Feb. 1 launch of bullet train service which has shortened travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities -- Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south -- to one-and-a-half hours has been selected as the top domestic news event of 2007.
The Central News Agency annually selects the year's top 10 local news stories. For this year, the selection was based on events occurring before Nov. 30.

The inauguration of the 345-km high-speed railway which has emerged as one of Taiwan's most important long-distance transport arteries linking all major cities and counties in western Taiwan has drawn prominent media coverage in Taiwan, leading to its selection by CNA as the top news story of 2007.
Second on the top 10 list is the successive breakouts of financial scandals involving Rebar Asia Pacific Group and Eastern Multimedia Group, led by Wang You-theng and his son Gary Wang, respectively.

The Wangs were accused of having embezzled more than NT$100 billion (US$3.09 billion) in corporate funds and committing a spate of other financial crimes. The senior Wang and his wife remain at large in the United States, while Gary Wang has been detained for investigations. The snowballing Wang family financial scandals led to the resignation of Shih Jun-ji as Financial Supervisory Commission chairman on Jan. 12.
Other news events that made the top 10 list are as follows in order of importance:

-- The 2008 presidential election is poised to be a "final duel" between the country's two bitter rival political camps that will pit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang against the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) team of Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew.

-- Investigations into suspected misuse of "special allowance funds" by incumbent and former senior government officials continue unceasingly. Ma Ying- jeou was indicted on charges of graft over misuse of the public funds allocated for his discretionary use during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006 but was acquitted in the first trial. In the DPP-led "pan-green" camp, Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang were exonerated of any corruption charges with regard to their use of public funds during their respective tenures as premier and local government head, but Vice President Annette Lu and former Premier Yu Shyi-kun were indicted on charges of embezzlement of public funds.

-- Skyrocketing oil and raw material prices, coupled with typhoon damage, have fueled an upward spiral in domestic consumer prices, with the annual growth rate of the Consumer Price Index reaching a 13-year high of 5.34 percent in October.

-- The government applied to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan for the first time. The Executive Yuan has launched an intensive publicity campaign to drum up support for this new policy, with the ruling DPP initiating a referendum on the bid to be held alongside next year's presidential election scheduled for March 22. As a counter move, the KMT initiated a referendum on the country applying to return to the United Nations under its official title, the Republic of China.

-- The Legislative Yuan completed the third reading of the National Pension Act, which is set to take effect Oct. 1, 2008. Under the act, those who are not covered in the existing civil service and labor insurance programs can join the national pension program and will be eligible to receive about NT$9,000 per month until their death so long as they pay a due amount of premium for 40 full years.

-- Taiwan-born New York Yankees star pitcher Chien-Ming Wang made the "2007 Time 100" list, making him the third Taiwanese citizen to be selected by Time Magazine as one of the 100 most influential persons in the world after President Chen Shui-bian and Oscar-winning film director Ang Lee.

-- Ang Lee won the coveted top honor in the 2007 Venice Film Festival with his steamy spy thriller "Lust, Caution." It was the second time that the New York- based director captured the Golden Lion for best film, the Italian film festival's top honor. In 2005, Lee won the award for "Brokeback Mountain, " a gay cowboy romance movie which also earned him a best director Oscar.

-- The government launched a drive to replace the word "China" or "Chinese" in the titles of several state-owned enterprises with the word "Taiwan" to protect them from being mistaken as companies in China. For instance, Chunghua Post was renamed Taiwan Post; Chinese Petroleum Corp. was re-designated CPC Corp., Taiwan; and China Shipbuilding Corp. was renamed Taiwan Shipbuilding Corp. Meanwhile, the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, which was dedicated to the late President Chiang Kai-shek, has been renamed the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall. Chiang was branded by the DPP as a dictator and main perpetrator of the tragic 228 Incident of 1947.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to purchase domestically-grown rice at higher prices

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has decided to offer a higher unit price for the purchase of domestically-grown rice in a bid to help offset rice farmers' higher production costs, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will offer an extra NT$2 for each kilogram of rice that the government purchases from domestic rice farmers, beginning from the first rice harvest next year, Chang said at a regular Cabinet meeting.
Some 230,000 rice farmers around the country are expected to benefit from the policy, with their income increasing by an estimated NT$21,000 for each hectare of rice they grow, Chang said.

Chang said that rice has been the country's most important farm crop, with about 270,000 hectares of rice paddies nationwide. However, he continued, the unit price that the government has offered for the purchase of rice from private rice farmers has remained unchanged for over 14 years.

Rice farmers have suffered from higher production costs and lower profit margins in recent years mainly as a result of higher-priced fertilizers and oil products for their rice-farming machines, Chang said.
Meanwhile, he said, the COA will work to help domestic rice farmers establish a nationwide traceability system to help raise their crop's competitiveness against imported rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investor sentiment hits 2nd-lowest level in 4 years: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investor sentiment for December plunged to the second-lowest level in the past four years as confidence collapsed amid recent fluctuations in global stock markets and domestic political uncertainties, according to the results of a bimonthly survey released Wednesday.

The results showed that Taiwan's investor sentiment index nosedived 102 points from October to stand at -104.7 in December, the second-lowest level since the survey started in December 2003. The lowest level was recorded in October 2005 at -109.4.

Also falling in December were investors' optimism about achieving their investment targets over the next three months, maintaining their present income over the coming year, the stock market outlook over the next three months, the unemployment rate over the next three months, and consumer prices over the next three months.
The survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University in cooperation with Business Today magazine on 1,119 stock investors Dec. 10-20. It has a margin of error of 3 percent.
The survey revealed that the outcome of the March 22, 2008 presidential election will affect the trading decisions of the investors.

Compared with 41 percent of respondents who said they will increase their stock purchases if opposition Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou is elected, 42 percent said they will reduce the number of stocks they own if ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate Frank Hsieh is elected, according to the results.

The survey found that the largest number of respondents believe that the relations between the ruling and opposition parties are the most important factor that will affect the movement of Taiwan's main stock index over the next two months. Other major factors mentioned include the movement of international stock markets, the development of the U.S. subprime mortgage financial crisis, and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Meanwhile, the results showed that 86 percent of respondents will invest in mutual funds in 2008, with over 50 percent preferring those targeting Asian emerging markets. The second-most popular type of mutual funds are those targeting European markets and Latin American markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Almost half of people fail to wash hands at hospitals: polls

TEXT.P: Approximately 48 percent and 47 percent of respondents in two recent surveys in Taiwan often fail to wash their hands after entering or before leaving hospitals, respectively, according to the results of the surveys released Wednesday.

In one survey, the Consumers' Foundation collected 1,541 valid questionnaires from 51 hospitals around the country between Nov. 9-20, while in the other survey, the foundation collected 685 valid questionnaires from its Web site between Nov. 14-Dec. 21.

In the online survey, 58 percent of the respondents said they did not wash their hands after entering a hospital during their last visit, while 22 percent said they did not do so before leaving the hospital.

Most of those who often wash their hands after entering a hospital are students, and citizens aged between 21 and 30 also often do so, while most of those aged between 41 and 50 fail to do so, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan 2007 economy forecast to grow 5.46 percent: premier

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in 2007 is forecast to expand by 5.46 percent, far outpacing the government's original target of 4.6 percent, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chang made the remarks at a regular Executive Yuan weekly meeting in which a 2008 national development program was approved.

Citing the most recent forecasts of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , compiled in November, Chang reported that private sector investment funneled into the domestic market for the whole of this year will hit NT$2.67 trillion (US$82.5 billion) , up by 5.07 percent over the 2006 level, and that the country's annual foreign trade will total NT$529.4 billion, a 24.07 percent increase over the previous year's figure.
Chang attributed the better-than-expected economic growth to an improved domestic investment environment and he thanked all government agencies for their efforts in this regard.

According to Chang, the government's economic theme in 2008 will focus on boosting investment, taking care of the underprivileged, sustainable development of national territory, cracking down on corruption and exploring foreign relations so as to "create jobs and narrow the gap between urban and rural areas and between rich and poor."

The country's economic growth rate for the coming year has been set at 4.8 percent, with a jobless rate of below 3.8 percent and a consumer price index increase of less than 2 percent, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices down slightly on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices ended lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 10.68 points, or 0.13 percent, to close at 8,156.39.
The bourse opened at 8,125.45 and fluctuated between 8,173.9 and 8,071.63 during trading. A total of 2.85 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.52 billion (US$1.98 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both moving up 0.4 percent and construction issues increasing 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,000 to 716, with 526 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening Taiwan as FTZ will be loss-maker: economist

TEXT.P: A local economist criticized Wednesday a proposal by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew to develop Taiwan into a free trade zone (FTZ) as "more a loss than a gain, " claiming that such an opening would harm local manufacturers and workers.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the non-profit policy research organization Taiwan Thinktank, made the comment in a speech titled "The Direction and Strategies of International Cooperation" at a conference held by the Industrial Development Bureau on industrial upgrading and transformation.

Chen, who once served as minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said no country will be willing to open its doors to Taiwan just because Taiwan opens its own for barrier-free trading.

Under World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations in terms of most-favored nation treatment, any WTO member that opens its market and offers privileged trading treatment to another member is obliged to treat all other members in the same way, unless the opening is part of a mutual free trade agreement (FTA), Chen explained.
"Will there be a country willing to open its doors to the whole world only because Taiwan unilaterally opens its own and that country wants to do the same thing for Taiwan?" the economist asked.

Once they get the Taiwan market, the foreign countries will never want to "sacrifice" theirs, which Chen claimed would be the result of an FTZ. He further claimed that Taiwan's opening its market would put the country in a situation in which foreign economies would take advantage of the Taiwan market, while Taiwan would not have access to theirs.

However, Chen said that international cooperation is still a good way for local enterprises to expand their business and profits, and he suggested that the government try to find other kinds of cooperation relations that would pose a lesser threat to local businesses.
He said that signing FTAs with developed countries is the way Taiwan should follow in efforts to boost foreign trade.
Siew, a former premier who also served as minister of economic affairs in the previous KMT administration, proposed the FTZ idea in May in a speech to a gathering of influential entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait opening 'stuck' on sovereignty issue: vice premier

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Chiou I-jen said Wednesday that it is easy to talk about liberalizing business and trade exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, but difficult to really do it.

Noting that the presidential candidates of both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang have vowed to open cross-strait business and trade if elected, Chiou said that actually doing so would be a real challenge, as any opening is "stuck" at the thorny issue of sovereignty.

Elaborating on his opinions at an Executive Yuan year-end news conference, Chiou took the tourism exchange program as an example, saying that Taiwan will never accept the notion of "Taiwan, China" to refer to Taiwan during cross-strait tourism talks. "Such talks will definitely come to a dead end if China refuses to budge on the sovereignty issue," he added.

On the opening of Chinese banking institutions establishing branches or subsidiaries in Taiwan, Chiou said it is an unavoidable trend and that Chinese banks will be allowed into Taiwan sooner or later.

This matter, however, has also been "stuck" and has not make any headway because both sides are firm on their respective insistence on the establishment of a supervisory system over banking operations.

Talking about the surge of activity in sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) on international financial markets, especially in China and the Middle East, Chiou said an SWF -- defined by Investopedia as "a pool of money derived from a country's reserves, set aside for investment purposes that will benefit the country's economy and citizens" -- is a financial product that has advantages and disadvantages. "My stance is that SWFs should be managed vigilantly," he said.

Meanwhile, he noted, most of the partially or wholly state-owned banks in Taiwan are small in size and big in number. He said that two would be enough for Taiwan, adding that the rest should be either merged or sold. "The government would like to help if any foreign financial group is interested in the acquisition of these banks, " he said.

Chiou made the remarks while answering questions from local and foreign reporters on a wide range of topics, including the opening of cross-strait business and trade, the second round of the government's financial reforms and bank mergers.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung also spoke at the news conference to blame Beijing for a "lack of progress" in tourism-opening talks because of China's political considerations.
He added that officials from the two sides must meet to work out a solution to this issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Italian Premier Romano Prodi criticized his predecessor Silvio Berlusconi for claiming frequently to topple his administration. He said that his government has confidence in its objectives and is working for the nation's growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Rapidly, Buffett Secures a Deal for $4.5 Billion
After just two weeks of negotiations, Mr. Buffett, who has been looking for acquisitions on which to spend his companyzs billions of dollars, snagged an industrial conglomerate in a deal announced Tuesday. The Pritzker family of Chicago will sell to Mr. Buffettzs firm, Berkshire Hathaway, a 60 percent stake in Marmon Holdings for $4.5 billion.
The Wall Street Journal: Buffett Makes $4.5 Billion Deal With Pritzkers
Warren Buffett agreed to pay $4.5 billion to buy the majority of an industrial conglomerate from Chicago's Pritzker family, choosing to invest in products like plumbing pipes and railroad tank cars as Asian investors pour billions into U.S. financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Tide Is Shifting On U.S. Exports Companies Finding Markets Overseas
Challenged by a troubled U.S. economy and the steeply falling dollar, a growing number of U. S. manufacturers are making up for slowing domestic sales by expanding them overseas, often with sophisticated products.
The Washington Times: Afghan rebels' arms suppliers assailed Canadian Defense Minister Peter Mackay last night accused Pakistan and Iran of supplying weapons to insurgents, only half an hour before a rocket disrupted his Christmas game of field hockey with the troops here.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Court backs rights of insured.
California health insurers have a duty to check the accuracy of applications for coverage before issuing policies--and should not wait until patients run up big medical bills, a state appeals court ruled Monday. The court also said insurers could not cancel a medical policy unless they showed that the policyholder willfully misrepresented his health or that the company had investigated the application before it issued coverage. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Firm reneges on promised jobs for Nova teachers.
Former Nova Corp. teachers got much sadder tidings than they had hoped for on Christmas Eve, and much of the bad news came long distance.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Straits Times: Thaksin plans return, may advise PPP in elections.
Deposed Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said he plans to return home from exile and might advise the victorious party in last weekend's elections, sparking fears of another year of intense political conflict in Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 40 points to close at 8,187, with 42,687 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February rose 44 points to finish at 8,187, with 150 contracts traded, while March futures gained 26 points to close at 8,186, with 17 contract transactions. June futures increased 40 points to finish at 8,180, with 25 contract transactions, while September futures moved down 62 points to close at 7,914, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,147 for January, 8,143 for February, 8,160 for March, 8,140 for June and 7,976 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

January TE futures rose 0.5 points to close at 337.3, with 2,274 contracts traded, while February TE futures moved up 0.85 points to finish at 336.65, with 10 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures gained 14.4 points to close at 924, with 2,288 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 13.8 points to finish at 923.8, with 13 contracts traded. March TF futures rose 9.8 points to close at 919.6, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hopes for end to controversy surrounding voting system

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung expressed hope Wednesday that controversy surrounding the voting format of the upcoming elections will come to an end now that the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has addressed misgivings about the voting system.

The premier said 18 cities and counties controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang might think local election commissions can decide the setup of polling stations under a provision of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

However, he pointed out that when the MOI -- which is in charge of disputes over election affairs and the application of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law -- makes an interpretation of the law, it is legally binding.

Chang said the setup of the polling stations covers such issues as the location of the stations and the management of election staff, while the voting system is not part of the polling station setup but a "voting procedure."
Chang reaffirmed that the CEC is in charge of the Jan. 12 legislative elections and will command local election commissions.
"Since the MOI has decided on a 'one-step' voting system, the election commissions of Taipei and 17 other local election commissions have no right to make different resolutions," he said.
The ruling and the opposition parties are on a collision course over the Jan. 12 elections with accompanying referendums.

Under the one-step format, each voter will receive two ballots for the legislative elections and two referendum ballots at the same time and then cast them into four different boxes. One of the two legislative ballots is for a candidate, while the other is for a political party.

Voters will also be asked to use the two referendum ballots to indicate whether they support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-initiated proposal to force the KMT to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers, as well as a KMT-backed proposal to wipe out official corruption.

The opposition Kuomintang-controlled 18 cities and counties want to use a "two- step" system, which means that voters will be given two ballots in the first step, after which they will cast these ballots before deciding whether to take part in the referendum votes. Local election officials in these areas claim that the format, used in the 2004 presidential election, will avoid error and confusion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fireworks at Taipei 101 to read `2008 Taiwan'

TEXT.P: Speculation on the words that will appear in a New Year's Eve fireworks display at Taipei 101 -- one of the world's highest skyscrapers -- ended Wednesday with the announcement that "2008 Taiwan" will be spelled out.
The Tourism Bureau made the announcement after keeping the public guessing for several days.
Tourism officials also said there will be a little twist to the word "Taiwan" in that the "i" will be lower case while the dot will be in the shape of a heart to symbolize "I love Taiwan."

When the clock strikes midnight Dec. 31, 12,000 fireworks will be launched from sites as high as 500 meters up the sides of the building for a 188-second show that the tourism officials said will be "spectacular."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.03 to close at NT$32.529.
A total of US$590 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.504 and hit a high of NT$32.542.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP sets up anti-vote buying center

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opened an anti-vote-buying center Wednesday as part of efforts to thwart vote-buying in the approaching legislative and presidential elections.

President Chen Shui-bian, who also serves as DPP chairman, held a news conference at the DPP's Taipei headquarters to announce the establishment of the new facility, urging voters to support clean elections and say no to "black gold" or politicians with shady links to organized crime.

The idea of building an anti-vote-buying mechanism in the party was formed in a resolution by the DPP Central Standing Committee in November, which also instructed that a task force be organized to oversee anti-vote-buying activities. Vice President Annette Lu was appointed as the team's convener.

Chen said he is glad to see the party set up the center within less than a month, calling the new facility a demonstration of the DPP's determination to wipe out vote-buying in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the presidential election slated for March 22.
DPP Central Review Committee Chairwoman Lan Mei-chin, who is also a legislator, serves as director of the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel to collaborate on information technology, biotech

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's National Development Fund (NDF) will invest US$30 million in Israel's GIZA Venture Fund V to facilitate the transfer of information technology and biotechnology from Israeli companies to their Taiwanese counterparts, an NDF spokesman said Wednesday.

Yeh Ming-feng, an executive secretary of the NDF, said GIZA is Israel's third- largest private venture capital company and that the NDF also previously invested NT$450 million (US$14 million) in the GIZA Venture Fund IV.

Israeli companies have first-rate research and development abilities in information technology, biotechnology and security technology, said Yeh, who is also vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
However, Israeli companies lack capital, which Yeh said can be provided by Taiwan.

Since both sides began cooperating in 2005, GIZA Venture Fund has completed seven technology transfer projects involving Taiwanese companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.(TSMC), Yeh went on.
As the Taiwanese government has agreed to make further investment in the Israeli fund, it has also asked GIZA to help assist the development of Taiwan's industries, Yeh noted.

GIZA has agreed to work with the NDF on a large investment project in Taiwan in the near future -- possibly next year at the earliest, Yeh said, adding that the project will greatly boost Taiwan's technology.
GIZA is also discussing with Israeli companies how to invest in Taiwan, according to Yeh, who said Israeli companies will first focus on the information technology and biotechnology sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Playing video games may affect emotional control: study

TEXT.P: People who spend too much time playing video games, especially violent video games, may risk damaging brain functions and affect their learning and emotional control, according to findings of a study released Wednesday.
Chou Yuan-hua, a doctor in the Department of Psychiatry of Taipei Veterans General Hospital, enlisted 30 youngsters -- all aged 25 -- as research subjects.
They were given physical examinations to monitor changes in blood circulation in their brains before and after each played a video game for 30 minutes.
The study found that the act of playing video games obviously causes a decreased blood flow in the brain, and that the effect is even more pronounced in those playing violent video games.

Noting that the study focused on subjects who played video games for only 30 minutes, Chou said many youngsters spend far more time on video games each day, unaware that doing so on a long term basis could damage the frontal lobe of the brain, as well as the anterior cingulate gyrus.

He explained that the frontal lobe of the cerebral cortex, located at the front of the brain, is associated with thinking, speaking, decision-making and impulse control, while the anterior cingulate gyrus, located in the medial wall of the frontal lobe, modulates internal emotional responses.

Although no conclusions as yet have been drawn regarding what might happen if blood flow to these brain areas is diminished frequently, it is already known that frontal lobe damage can leave a person emotionally adrift, opening him or her up to odd mood changes and variations in social behavior and personality.
Chou added that clinical experiences have proven that patients with schizophrenia or depression have significantly lower blood flows in their frontal lobes and anterior cingulate gyruses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier outlines development goals

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the government will continue working on "cementing democracy, reinforcing Taiwan's sovereignty, improving social security and stepping up balanced development in all regions."

Chang made the remarks while presiding over an Executive Yuan year-end news conference. He hailed what he described as the Cabinet's performance in building "prosperity, justice, democracy and sustainable growth" in society over the past seven months since he assumed office.
Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Jin-chun and several ministers without portfolio also attended the press conference.

According to the premier, Taiwan's economy will grow by 5.46 percent for 2007, its jobless rate will drop to a low of 3.81 percent and export levels will achieve a record high. All the Taiwan people are entitled to share the country's economic progress, he said.

Chang promised that the government will wipe out all irregularities that could affect the smooth and orderly holding of the coming legislative and presidential elections, which he said will write a new page in Taiwan's development.

The government's "pragmatic" efforts to advance the country's bid to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan this year has pushed the world to face the reality that Taiwan is not part of China, he went on.
In addition, he said, the government is also engaged in promoting welfare programs for the elderly, the young, the underprivileged and minority groups.

In terms of the industrial upgrading of traditional and small businesses, he added, the government earmarked NT$10 billion in August to help small companies and another NT$10 billion to assist some 150 enterprises in the agricultural sector in innovating expertise.

To reverse a long-term lack of development equilibrium between north and south, the government will allocate NT$100 billion over the coming 10 years to finance a village renovation program aimed at helping farmers overhaul their living environments, he said.

In urban areas, the floor area ratio for new buildings in old districts has been relaxed, he said, adding that six prime urban renovation projects in development are expected to create NT$57 billion in investment returns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Container volume at Keelung harbor sets record

TEXT.P: The number of containers handled at Keelung harbor in northern Taiwan in 2007 hit a record high of 2.17 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) as of Dec. 25, officials at the Keelung Harbor Bureau said Tuesday.
The figure indicates an increase of 4.39 percent, or 91,664 TEUs, over the same period last year, breaking the record of 2.16 million TEUs set in 1995.

Harbor officials said that although the world economy has not been in the best of shape due to the U.S. subprime crisis and soaring crude oil prices, Keelung harbor has performed well for two consecutive years, attributing the reason to a series of preferential measures offered by the harbor.

They said that Israel's ZIM, one of the largest container shipping companies in the world, chose Keelung as its container transshipping center in Asia this year, which has also contributed greatly to the volume increase.
The officials said that looking ahead, the volume handled next year should reach 2.26 million TEUs, based on average growth of 2.43 percent over the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG A nation online
Internet shopping signalled its growing domination of Britains consumer habits yesterday as millions began their annual sales hunt from their armchairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. reverses free train ride plan

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) announced a plan Wednesday to offer free train rides for all people from Dec. 29 to Jan. 1 on the Red Line's southern section, but made an abrupt about-face two hours later.

KRTC president Fan Chen-po explained that the reversal was due to the fact that KRTC needs to devote most of its manpower to inspections of the construction project and test runs on the partially completed Red Line, one of two planned lines of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system.

Officials at the Mass Rapid Transit Bureau under the Kaohsiung city government said they agreed with KRTC's decision because safety inspections and smooth test runs are more important to the Red Line's early opening than free trains rides for the public.
On Dec. 7, Fan and other KRTC executives apologized to Kaohsiung residents for failing to deliver on its promise to inaugurate the Red Line by the end of 2007.
The Red Line has been under construction since October 2001. Fan vowed to complete the construction work as soon as possible, but gave no date for the opening of the line.
The other MRT line, the Orange Line, is scheduled to become operational late next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT denies softening stance regarding voting method

TEXT.P: Amid a voting method dispute between the central and some local governments, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Huang Yu-chen said Wednesday that none of the 18 KMT-controlled localities has softened its stance regarding the issue.

According to Huang, the KMT's insistence on adopting a "two-step" voting format, rather than the "one-step" method prescribed by the Central Election Commission (CEC), is aimed at securing a smooth and orderly holding of next year's legislative and presidential elections slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively.

In compliance with the Constitution, the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, Law on the Local Government Systems, interpretations by Council of Grand Justices or a recent legislative resolution, the 18 cities and counties are legally entitled to employ a "two-step" format, Huang stressed.
The CEC has been manipulated by the Executive Yuan and the Executive Yuan erred severely by meddling in the CEC's operations, he said.

Huang also expressed his belief that Hsinchu City will remain firm in the application of the "two-step" voting format, although its mayor, Lin Junq-tzer, resigned a day earlier from his post as municipal election commission chief due to pressure from the central government.

In a press release issued later the same day, Lin stressed that he decided to quit Hsinchu City's election commission chairmanship to help prevent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and CEC from rigging the elections.

Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Monday that the "one-step" method must be implemented throughout Taiwan's 25 cities and counties in the coming two polls, and electoral personnel who disobey the order will be replaced or brought to justice.

In response to the CEC having added an article to its regulations on replacing electoral officials in localities, Tseng Yun-chuan, a KMT lawmaker and head of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, said such a move seeking to remove electoral personnel through an administrative decree is totally unconstitutional and attacked the Executive Yuan for reducing the CEC to its pawn.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC approves new investment worth NT$6.5 billion

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) approved four new investment projects worth NT$6.51 billion (US$200 million) Wednesday to be launched in Taiwan's various science parks, a NSC official said.

Among these, the investment project presented by Taiwan Polysilicon Corp., which will produce polysilicon, a key upstream material for the photovoltaic industry, accounts for the bulk of new investment.
With its new investment reaching NT$6.33 billion, the Taiwan Polysilicon Corp. will be established in NSC's Southern Taiwan Science Park.

Most of Taiwan's companies involved in the solar energy industry focus on the production of ingots, wafers and solar cells, which are midstream elements for the industry, while most of the upstream materials for Taiwan's photovoltaic industry are imported from the United States, Japan and Germany, the official said.

Noting that polysilicon will be in strong demand over the next three to five years, the official said Taiwan needs urgently to encourage more companies to produce polysilicon for the island's solar energy industry.
Meanwhile, the NCS also approved six companies increasing their paid-in capital, worth NT$3.07 billion in their original operations, within the science parks scattered around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Research institute predicts slower growth for Taiwan in 2008

TEXT.P: The year 2008 is expected to be one of slow economic growth for almost all major economies and Taiwan is no exception with an economic growth rate estimated at 4.23 percent, the head of the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) said Wednesday.

The estimated economic growth rate for Taiwan is slightly lower than the 10-year average of 4.38 percent and more than one percentage point lower than the expected economic growth rate of 5.29 percent for 2007. The growth in domestic consumption and investment are also limited, said TRI President Liu Tai-ying.

A slowing economy in the United States and higher oil prices are the biggest factors expected to impact Taiwan and the rest of the world in 2008, Liu said at a forum looking into the economic prospects for 2008.

Taiwan's already robust export sector is still expected to grow by more than four percent, but the same cannot be said of domestic consumption and investment given the falling consumer confidence, Liu noted.

TRI estimated a 2.92 percent growth rate in domestic consumption next year, which will be higher than the 2.88 percent growth rate of 2007. The slight increase will result from an increasing labor force participation rate and relatively low unemployment rate as well as the short-term impact of the presidential election, said TRI Vice President Wu Tsai-yi.

The growth rate in private sector investment is expected to be 4.12 percent, lower than the 4.99 percent of 2007, Wu said. The rate will be about the same as the economic growth rate, although in the past it was 1.8 times the economic growth rate, Wu said.

A number of instances of pubic investment have not been passed in the Legislature over the past year after becoming ensnared in the process of environmental evaluation and by protests from environment protection groups, which are hurting the national economy, Wu pointed out.

The global economy will be in a period of adjustment in the first quarter of 2008 due to the impact of the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis and high oil prices, but is expected to be more stable starting in the second quarter, said Wu Chung- hsu, a researcher at Academia Sinica.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County magistrate vows to promote economy

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan has vowed to further promote the central county's economic development and improve residents' quality of life.
Cho made the remarks at a news conference held Dec. 18 to celebrate the second anniversary of his assuming office and review the progress made thus far.
Soon after taking up his post, Cho began to implement a blueprint for the development of the county.

According to the blueprint, the county government is to push forward with two major city projects, develop four major industrial areas, establish six major traffic networks, and enhance the quality of life in eight major areas, Cho noted.

The county government has also proactively raised the international profile of the county and engaged in exchanges with many countries, Cho said. He pointed out that in June of this year, the county government sent 100 junior high school and primary school students from disadvantaged families to visit the Nagano Prefecture in Japan, and in August sent another group of elementary school students to visit the Western Australia city of Perth.
Cho added that in November the county government organized the fifth Asian Cup Woodball Championship.

He also noted that his administration has won the bid to host the National Athletic Games in 2011 this year and that the county government plans to set up a bicycle industrial park, a special area for light sport aircraft, and an international-standard racetrack for motorcycles and cars.

In August, the county government hosted a forum attended by chiefs and deputy chiefs of Taichung City, Taichung County, and Nantou County to discuss integrating the tourism resources of central Taiwan, Cho went on.

In 2008, the county government is looking to build a convenient transportation network, create a prosperous economy, market local tourism, and foster a diverse and innovative education system, Cho concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua county begins discussions on bid to become capital city

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government began efforts Wednesday with an academic conference to promote the central Taiwan county becoming the capital city of the country.

The conference on issues concerning the Changhua bid and national development was attended by governmental, industrial and academic representatives, including Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, National Changhua University of Education President Chang Huei-po and Mingdao University President Wang Ta-yung.

In his address, County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan introduced Changhua as enjoying a significant position in Taiwan's history, noting that its Lugang township was once the second largest city on the island, following Tainan in southern Taiwan.
Changhua, the first Taiwanese county to house a population surpassing one million people, is now the fourth largest county in the nation with a population above 1.3 million people.
In geography, Changhua county lies against the central mountain range, which shields the county from typhoons, allowing it to develop stably, Cho indicated.

The magistrate also mentioned that 88.1 percent of the county has not yet undergone urban renewal, meaning that there is ample space in the county for the construction of political and economic establishments.

Topics on Changhua's strengths in history, politics, geography, traffic, population, industry, LOHAS (an abbreviation for Lifestyles of Health and Sustainability) and balanced development were discussed during the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 45% want to maintain status quo: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly 45 percent of the people polled hope to maintain the status quo for the present and decide Taiwan's future later, according to the result of a public opinion poll published by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.
This represents the highest figure since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party took helm of the nation in 2000.

The poll was conducted Dec. 21-23 by the market research company Berkeley BIGC at the MAC's commission. A total of 1,067 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of three percentage points.

Asked about their views on unification with China, declaring Taiwan independence or maintaining the status quo, 44.9 percent said they hope to maintain the status quo and decide on the nation's future later, the highest point since 2000.

One noteworthy finding is that only 11.8 percent of those polled said they hope to maintain the status quo until achieving independence, which is a dramatic decrease from 16.5 percent in August and represents the lowest point of the past four and a half years.

MAC spokesman Liu Teh-hsun said that past public opinion polls conducted by the MAC have shown that voters tend to be more conservative on the eve of major elections and will not give definite views on the future of Taiwan. Taiwan's legislative elections are scheduled for Jan. 12 and presidential election March 22.
Liu attributed the reason to the reality Taiwan faces in the international community as well as China's relentless obstruction, which discourages many of those polled from expressing their views.

Taiwanese perceptions of China's animosity also reflect this point, as the survey shows that 66.8 percent of those polled think that Beijing is hostile to Taiwan's government, a new high in recent years.
The number of those who think Beijing is not friendly to Taiwan's people rose to reach 50.6 percent, according to the poll.

On restrictions imposed on Taiwan business people investing in China, those who believe the government should be stricter fell below 50 percent for the first time with only 44.3 percent saying that the government should be more stringent, the poll showed.

Those who think that the government should ease restrictions rose to 37.7 percent for the first time, and those who think that the government should maintain the current policy also reached double-digit figures for the first time at 11.5 percent.
Liu suggested that this has to do with a litany of regulations governing investment in China unveiled by the government in recent years, making the rules of the game more open and transparent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team completes free service in remote Indian town
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/07 22:31:48 (By Paul Kuo and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese non-governmental medical team has earned public praise and special thank from a Tibetan Buddhism Gyalwang after it completed a seven-day free medical service in a northern Indian town of Bodhgaya in Bihar Province.

The team, consisted of 17 medical doctors, dentists and pharmacists as well as 30 nurses and volunteers, is organized by the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , a private medical charity dedicated to international medical aid service.

Led by TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun, the group arrived in New Delhi early Wednesday to a warm welcome by Andrew Hsia, Taiwan's representative to India. Hsia personally cooked Taiwanese-style breakfast to entertain all team members who have not had hot foods since starting their current charitable medical tour.

Liu told CNA in an interview that witnessing the needs of the poor in the backward area has helped TRMPC members realize how people can contribute to helping others, adding the experience they have learnt from the medical service tour was beneficial to themselves.

According to Liu, many residents in the Indian town are infected with pneumonia due to the filthy living environment. Lack of money to receive regular treatments has even left many patients suffering from multiple drug resistant pneumonia, he noted.
"This in not a good phenomenon," Liu said, adding that the World Health Organization has warned that India could fall victim to a pneumonia epidemic within a decade if no proper efforts are made.
Liu also noticed some cases of malaria during his stay in Bodhgaya, saying the situation is also a result of the dirty environment.

Noting that most of the TRMPC members got cold or had diarrhea during their service mission due to different dining style and sharp temperature differences between day and night in the region, Liu said that if without the TRMPC doctors, team members would have been unable even to take care of themselves.
The TRMPC has been carrying out free medical services in India annually since 2000, and about 5,600 patients received the TRMPC treatments this year, Liu said.
According to Liu, India is a country that badly needs charitable medical aids. "The TRMPC will continue its medical service in other Indian towns next year," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-tech industry benefits, hurts local economy: researcher

TEXT.P: Led by the semiconductor sector, Taiwan's high-tech industry led the way for the national economy, but hurt it at the same time, a researcher said Wednesday in a forum.

"Taiwan's economy is export-driven and most of the contribution came from the high-tech industry. There is no doubt about it. However, Taiwanese citizens did not benefit from the profits made by the industry, " said Liu Tai-ying, President of Taiwan Research Institute (TRI).

Speaking in a forum looking at the prospects for economic growth in 2008, Liu explained that the high-tech industry is a high capital sector, and although it has made huge profits, most companies have to re-invest in themselves as well as increasing capital through public offerings due to the short life-cycle of their equipment and products.
"That means that not only did the money made not go into the people's pockets, but the sector also took money out of the public's pocket," Liu said.

Additionally, the industry created massive output values but failed to create local jobs given the fact that most of their factories have been shifted to China and Southeast Asian countries, he added.
"That is simply the nature and characteristics of the business, " he said matter-of-factly.

The institute predicted robust export growth of more than four percent for Taiwan in 2008. Liu said the high-tech sector is still expected to be the driving force behind the growth. It is estimated that the growth rate for private sector investment will also exceed four percent, with much of it coming from the high-tech industry.

According to the TRI's research, the economic growth rate for Taiwan in 2008 is estimated to hit 4.23 percent, which is slightly lower than the 10-year average of 4.38 percent and more than one percentage point lower than the estimated economic growth rate of 5.29 percent in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's airline companies to cease charging war-risk premiums

TEXT.P: Taiwan's airline companies will no longer ask passengers to pay war-risk premiums beginning Jan. 1, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced Wednesday.
CAA officials said the surcharge will be canceled to reflect reduced war-risk insurance fees paid by airlines to international insurance companies.
The officials added that passengers who have already bought air tickets for the next year can ask for a refund of the pre-paid war-risk premiums.

Currently, a passenger is required to pay a war-risk surcharge of NT$40 when buying a ticket on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route. Taiwan's airline companies also charge each passenger about NT$49 for travel on international routes.

The practice of collecting war-risk surcharges began in October 2001 after insurance consortiums in the United States and other countries significantly increased the war-risk premiums paid by airline companies following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States in that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to stick with 'one-step' voting format: vice premier

TEXT.P: The government will stick with the "one-step" voting format in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential elections, Vice Premier Chiou I-jen said Wednesday.
Chiou made the remarks at a year-end news conference held at the Executive Yuan.
Also present at the news conference were Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun, Cabinet Spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey, and several ministers without portfolios.

Expressing his regret over the voting format dispute, Chiou said that if the government allows local cities and counties controlled by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) mayors to use the "two-step" voting format, there will be even more fierce disputes before and after the elections.
Meanwhile, if the government does not uphold the CEC's decision, there will be a hugely adverse impact on the functioning of the government system, Chiou said.

For this reason, the government will forcibly implement the "one-step" voting format in line with the decision of the Central Election Committee (CEC) regardless of accusations against him or the government, Chiou went on.

Chiou said that the relationship between the CEC and the Cabinet has remained the same as during the KMT's rule in past decades, describing the CEC as an independent institution and an arm of the Executive Yuan.
Chiou noted that the Cabinet must strongly support the CEC's legal decisions and dismissed criticisms from the KMT.
In addition, Chiou denied that the Cabinet has prepared a list of names to replace the chiefs of local election committees, while stressing that whoever violates the CEC's decision will be replaced.
Asked about the recent resignation of Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer of the KMT as a local election commission chief, Chiou said that he "respected" Lin's decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team completes free service in remote Indian town
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/07 22:53:27 (By Paul Kuo and Howard Lin)

According to Liu, many residents in the Indian town are infected with pneumonia due to the filthy living environment. A lack of money to receive regular treatments has even left many patients suffering from multiple drug resistant pneumonia, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC passes amendments to local election commission organic rules

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) passed a raft of legal amendments Wednesday that will empower the CEC to ask the Executive Yuan to replace law- breaking members of city and county election commissions.

CEC members passed the amendments to the organic rules of local election commissions with a vote of 6-3 after more than three hours of debate at a meeting of all commissioners, CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said, adding that the meeting proceeded in a roughly peaceful atmosphere.

Under the revised rules, the CEC can ask the Executive Yuan to replace members of city and county election commissions if they cannot perform their official duties due to disease, or they violate existing laws or are guilty of dereliction of duty, or they have been detained or indicted on criminal charges.
Teng said the revised rules will be referred to the Executive Yuan soon for approval and implementation.
The rule amendment came amid nagging squabbling between central and some local governments over the voting format for the upcoming legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.
While the CEC insists on adopting a "one-step" voting format and the opposition Kuomintang-controlled 18 localities want to follow a "two-step" formula.

Despite the passage of the organic rule amendments to authorize the CEC to replace defiant local election commissioners, KMT authorities said they are not prepared to make any concession on their stance on upholding the "two-step" voting format.

KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen also claimed that the revised rules violate the stipulation of alegislative resolution passed last week that affirms local election commission's rights to decide setup of polling stations and relevant voting format.
