DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 27, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviets. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that the current political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.
2001: The National Taiwan Museum in Taipei represents an exhibition introducing the achievements of the late Dr. Joseph Needham (1900-1995) and the British scholar's contributions to Chinese and world civilization.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan medical team completes free service in remote Indian town
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/27/07 11:21:47 (By Paul Kuo and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese non-governmental medical team has earned public praise and special thanks from a Tibetan Buddhism Gyalwang after it completed a seven-day free medical service in the northern Indian town of Bodhgaya in Bihar Province.

The team, consisting of 17 medical doctors, dentists and pharmacists as well as 30 nurses and volunteers, is organized by the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC), a private medical charity dedicated to international medical aid service.

Led by TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun, the group arrived in New Delhi early Wednesday to a warm welcome by Andrew Hsia, Taiwan's representative to India. Hsia personally cooked a Taiwanese-style breakfast to entertain all team members who have not had a hot meal since starting their current charitable medical tour.

Liu told CNA in an interview that witnessing the needs of the poor in the backward area has helped TRMPC members realize how people can contribute to helping others, adding that the experience they have learnt from the medical service tour was personally beneficial.

According to Liu, many residents in the Indian town are infected with pneumonia due to the filthy living environment. A lack of money to receive regular treatments has even left many patients suffering from multiple drug resistant pneumonia, he noted.
"This is not a good situation," Liu said, adding that the World Health Organization has warned that India could fall victim to a pneumonia epidemic within a decade if proper efforts are not made.
Liu also noticed some cases of malaria during his stay in Bodhgaya, saying the situation is also a result of the dirty environment.

Noting that most of the TRMPC members got colds or had diarrhea during their service mission due to different dining styles and sharp temperature differences between day and night in the region, Liu said, adding that without the TRMPC doctors, team members would have been unable even to care for themselves.
The TRMPC has been offering free medical services in India annually since 2000. About 5,600 patients received TRMPC treatments this year, Liu said.
According to Liu, India is a country that badly needs charitable medical aid. "The TRMPC will continue to offer medical services in other Indian towns next year," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's airline companies to cease charging war-risk premiums

TEXT.P: Taiwan's airline companies will no longer ask passengers to pay war-risk premiums beginning Jan. 1, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced Wednesday.
CAA officials said the surcharge will be canceled to reflect reduced war-risk insurance fees paid by airlines to international insurance companies.
The officials added that passengers who have already bought air tickets for the next year can ask for a refund of the pre-paid war-risk premiums.

Currently, a passenger is required to pay a war-risk surcharge of NT$40 when buying a ticket on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route. Taiwan's airline companies also charge each passenger about NT$49 for travel on international routes.

The practice of collecting war-risk surcharges began in October 2001 after insurance consortiums in the United States and other countries significantly increased the war-risk premiums paid by airline companies following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States in that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 45% want to maintain status quo: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly 45 percent of the people polled hope to maintain the status quo for the present and decide Taiwan's future later, according to the result of a public opinion poll published by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.
This represents the highest figure since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party took helm of the nation in 2000.

The poll was conducted Dec. 21-23 by the market research company Berkeley BIGC at the MAC's commission. A total of 1,067 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of three percentage points.

Asked about their views on unification with China, declaring Taiwan independence or maintaining the status quo, 44.9 percent said they hope to maintain the status quo and decide on the nation's future later, the highest point since 2000.

One noteworthy finding is that only 11.8 percent of those polled said they hope to maintain the status quo until achieving independence, which is a dramatic decrease from 16.5 percent in August and represents the lowest point of the past four and a half years.

MAC spokesman Liu Teh-hsun said that past public opinion polls conducted by the MAC have shown that voters tend to be more conservative on the eve of major elections and will not give definite views on the future of Taiwan. Taiwan's legislative elections are scheduled for Jan. 12 and presidential election March 22.
Liu attributed the reason to the reality Taiwan faces in the international community as well as China's relentless obstruction, which discourages many of those polled from expressing their views.

Taiwanese perceptions of China's animosity also reflect this point, as the survey shows that 66.8 percent of those polled think that Beijing is hostile to Taiwan's government, a new high in recent years.
The number of those who think Beijing is not friendly to Taiwan's people rose to reach 50.6 percent, according to the poll.

On restrictions imposed on Taiwan business people investing in China, those who believe the government should be stricter fell below 50 percent for the first time with only 44.3 percent saying that the government should be more stringent, the poll showed.

Those who think that the government should ease restrictions rose to 37.7 percent for the first time, and those who think that the government should maintain the current policy also reached double-digit figures for the first time at 11.5 percent.
Liu suggested that this has to do with a litany of regulations governing investment in China unveiled by the government in recent years, making the rules of the game more open and transparent.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-tech industry benefits, hurts local economy: researcher

TEXT.P: Led by the semiconductor sector, Taiwan's high-tech industry led the way for the national economy, but hurt it at the same time, a researcher said Wednesday in a forum.

"Taiwan's economy is export-driven and most of the contribution came from the high-tech industry. There is no doubt about it. However, Taiwanese citizens did not benefit from the profits made by the industry, " said Liu Tai-ying, President of Taiwan Research Institute (TRI).

Speaking in a forum looking at the prospects for economic growth in 2008, Liu explained that the high-tech industry is a high capital sector, and although it has made huge profits, most companies have to re-invest in themselves as well as increasing capital through public offerings due to the short life-cycle of their equipment and products.
"That means that not only did the money made not go into the people's pockets, but the sector also took money out of the public's pocket," Liu said.

Additionally, the industry created massive output values but failed to create local jobs given the fact that most of their factories have been shifted to China and Southeast Asian countries, he added.
"That is simply the nature and characteristics of the business, " he said matter-of-factly.

The institute predicted robust export growth of more than four percent for Taiwan in 2008. Liu said the high-tech sector is still expected to be the driving force behind the growth. It is estimated that the growth rate for private sector investment will also exceed four percent, with much of it coming from the high-tech industry.

According to the TRI's research, the economic growth rate for Taiwan in 2008 is estimated to hit 4.23 percent, which is slightly lower than the 10-year average of 4.38 percent and more than one percentage point lower than the estimated economic growth rate of 5.29 percent in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Research institute predicts slower growth for Taiwan in 2008

TEXT.P: The year 2008 is expected to be one of slow economic growth for almost all major economies and Taiwan is no exception with an economic growth rate estimated at 4.23 percent, the head of the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) said Wednesday.

The estimated economic growth rate for Taiwan is slightly lower than the 10-year average of 4.38 percent and more than one percentage point lower than the expected economic growth rate of 5.29 percent for 2007. The growth in domestic consumption and investment are also limited, said TRI President Liu Tai-ying.

A slowing economy in the United States and higher oil prices are the biggest factors expected to impact Taiwan and the rest of the world in 2008, Liu said at a forum looking into the economic prospects for 2008.

Taiwan's already robust export sector is still expected to grow by more than four percent, but the same cannot be said of domestic consumption and investment given the falling consumer confidence, Liu noted.

TRI estimated a 2.92 percent growth rate in domestic consumption next year, which will be higher than the 2.88 percent growth rate of 2007. The slight increase will result from an increasing labor force participation rate and relatively low unemployment rate as well as the short-term impact of the presidential election, said TRI Vice President Wu Tsai-yi.

The growth rate in private sector investment is expected to be 4.12 percent, lower than the 4.99 percent of 2007, Wu said. The rate will be about the same as the economic growth rate, although in the past it was 1.8 times the economic growth rate, Wu said.

A number of instances of pubic investment have not been passed in the Legislature over the past year after becoming ensnared in the process of environmental evaluation and by protests from environment protection groups, which are hurting the national economy, Wu pointed out.

The global economy will be in a period of adjustment in the first quarter of 2008 due to the impact of the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis and high oil prices, but is expected to be more stable starting in the second quarter, said Wu Chung- hsu, a researcher at Academia Sinica.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly half of Taiwan's top 300 business groups see profit growth

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taiwan's top 300 business groups saw their profits grow in 2007, a credit rating service company said Thursday.

Liu Jen, editor-in-chief of the China Credit Information Service, made the remarks as the company published its ranking of Taiwan's top 300 business groups, which showed that around 71 percent of the business groups maintained revenue growth, and nearly 85 percent of them registered a profit.

Liu said that based on the financial statement of the top 300 business groups in 2006, they have set up 9,500 subsidiaries around the world with combined assets of NT$42.949 trillion (US$1.326 trillion) and global revenues of NT$18.263 trillion, surpassing Taiwan's gross national product.
Nine out the top 10 business groups in terms of assets are financial groups, with the exception of Formosa Plastics Group, which ranks sixth.

Cathay Financial Holdings tops the 10 business groups, followed by Taiwan Cooperative Bank, Taishin Holdings, Mega Holdings, Chinatrust Financial Holding, Fubon, Hua Nan Financial Holdings, Shin Kong Financial Holding and First Financial Holding, in that order.
In terms of assets, Formosa Plastics Group ranks first among traditional industries, while the Foxcoon Technology Group sits atop the high-tech industry.
In terms of revenues, the top 10 groups are Formosa Plastics, Foxcoon, ASUS, Kinpo, Quanta, Mitac-Synnex, BanQ, Acer, Inventec, Far Eastern.
In terms of after-tax net profits, the top 10 are Formosa Plastics, TSMC, Foxcoon, UMC, Chuanghwa Telecom, China Steel, Far Eastern, Powerchip Technologies, Fubon, and VIA Technologies.

Liu said that thanks to the effects of a sluggish economy, less than 50 percent of the top 300 business groups were able to maintain profit growth, and some businesses maintaining profit growth may not be included in the top 300.
Chunghwa Telecom is one of the nine business groups making into the top 100 business groups for the first time.

Chunghwa Telecom actually made it into the ranks of the top 20 business groups, Liu pointed out. It set up two overseas holding companies in British Virgin Islands in 2006, showing its ambition in expanding overseas, Liu said, adding that it has an ample room for development in Chinese market.
In terms of business performance, the TSMC was placed at the top of the first 10 groups, followed by Powerchip Semiconductor, which made it into the top 10 for the first time.
The other eight companies rounding out are VIA Technologies, Media Tek, Formosa Plastics, ProMOS, UMC, China Steel, ASUS, and Siliconware Precision Industries, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sales of Taiwan's largest online bookstore rise nearly 40% for 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest online bookstore -- books.com.tw -- has seen its turnover increase nearly 40 percent this year, thanks to its successful alliance with 7-Eleven, officials said Thursday.

Established in 1995, the bookstore posted sales of less than NT$10 million per annum in the beginning and was soon stranded in an operational crisis following the bursting of the dot-com bubble in the early 2000s.

However, an NT$100 million investment in the bookstore in January 2001 by President Chain Store Corp. (PCSC) -- which runs the chain of 7-Eleven convenient stores in Taiwan -- revived the business, and the alliance has since provided customers with a new option -- paying upon delivery at any 7-Eleven outlet nationwide.

The bookstore saw its turnover increased to NT$1.37 billion and its net profit amounted to NT$53 million in 2006, with almost 90 percent of orders being payed upon delivery at 7-Eleven, officials at the bookstore said.
In 2007, the bookstore's turnover has further expanded to NT$1.9 billion, with book sales accounting for NT$1.3 billion, up approximately 40 percent over the year-earlier level, the officials said.
A total of 6 million copies of 229,845 kinds of books have been sold so far this year, with one copy sold every five seconds on average, they said.

According to market research data provided by PCSC, the scale of Taiwan's potential book market is estimated at NT$30 billion per year, with the virtual market accounting for NT$12 billion, or 40 percent.

As the total turnover of online booksellers has amounted to only NT$3 billion to NT$3.5 billion in 2007, the PCSC expects online book sales to increase by up to NT$4.5 billion, or 40 percent, in 2008.
Meanwhile, books.com.tw tallies reveal that the five top-selling categories of books in 2007 are finance and investment, arts, comics, healthcare, and fiction, in that order.

On books providing financial and investment information, the number of buyers for this type of book has risen 119 percent among men and 152 percent among women in 2007, with men preferring those focusing on practical, technical analysis, and women favoring those discussing theories, the tallies show.

Although books on art accounted for only 4 percent of all books available on the Taiwan market, their sales have posted an increase of 130 percent in 2007, owing to the enhancement of Taiwan citizens' beauty awareness, according to the bookstore.

On comics, the sales of the top-10 best-selling comics series have accounted for 14 percent of the total turnover for 2007, and the sales of some of the comics series have been boosted by their adaptation into TV drama series.

Meanwhile, the popularity of books on healthcare has been increasing with the aging of the country's population. Between 2005 and 2007, the quantity of books purchased by buyers in the 41-50 age group has jumped 75 percent. While the number of buyers of books providing healthcare information has climbed 16 percent among men and 21 percent among women in 2007, the number of buyers aged over 40 is 2.5 times as high as that of buyers in the 23-30 age group.

As for works of fiction, the number of new fiction works as a percentage of all fiction works available on the Taiwan market increased from 49 percent in 2006 to 54 percent in 2007, with the number of male buyers rising 9.4 percent -- 4.7 times as high as the growth rate among female buyers, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental bureau not involved in electioneering: official

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san denied categorically Thursday that the city's Bureau of Environmental Protection (BEP) has been involved in electioneering.

Chiu made the remarks after BEP Director Hsiao Yu-cheng was taken into custody early in the morning for allegedly dining and wining city street cleaners in the hopes of winning their support for a specific candidate running in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

Hsiao was accused of having solicited support for a legislative candidate while throwing a lunch party Nov. 24 to entertain 20-plus members of city cleaning staff, including heads of several street cleaning squads in the Sanmin district.

Claiming that entertaining Sanmin district street cleaners was part of Hsiao's efforts to boost the morale of grassroots environmental protection workers after the city's dengue fever outbreak was brought under control, Chiu said the lunch party in question had nothing to do with the legislative elections.
"No legislative candidate appeared at the lunch party, and no campaign literature was handed out during the occasion, " Chiu said, adding that nobody spoke for any candidate during the gathering.

Stressing that Hsiao had not only entertained Sanmin district grassroots street cleaning staff but also those in other city districts, Chiu said he believes that Hsiao was unlikely to campaign for any candidate on such an occasion.

"We are hopeful that judicial authorities can complete relevant investigations and get to the bottom of the case as early as possible, " Chiu said, adding that he is convinced that a thorough probe into the case will clear the names of Hsiao and other grassroots city environment cleaning staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA continuing to assist ROC nationals jailed in Thailand: official

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied Thursday that the ministry has left Taiwan nationals imprisoned in Thailand out in the cold, saying it has provided various forms of assistance to them.

MOFA acting spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said the ministry has continued to help the prisoners apply for amnesty, although she added that Thai judicial authorities will make a ruling based on their investigations and that "we can only do what we can."

Yeh made the remarks after Taipei-based China Times reported that Taiwan lumber businessman Chen Yi-hsiung, currently in a Thai prison for drug trafficking, has repeatedly written to the Taiwan government for assistance "to no avail" over the past six years.

Chen was found to have concealed narcotics in his rental car when he returned to Bangkok from a market survey trip in northern Thailand in September 2001, the reports said. Chen, as well as 118 other Taiwanese nationals in Thai jails, were not included in a royal pardon or commutation program for prisoners to mark Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej's 80th birthday Dec. 5. Chen is now planning to file an extraordinary appeal, the reports added.

Yeh reaffirmed that Taiwan's representative office in Thailand has continued to show concern for the 119 Taiwan nationals scattered in 10 Thai prisons, adding that the office has done many things and that it continues to provide assistance to them.
She said most of the Taiwan nationals are in prison for narcotic offenses, while a few have been convicted of forgery.
To protect the rights of Taiwan prisoners, the office has helped them apply for amnesty, and six of them have been granted amnesty, Yeh said.
Thirty-four Taiwanese nationals are currently applying for amnesty, and the MOFA is keeping tabs on the progress of their applications, she continued.

Thailand also grants pardon on special occasions, such as the Thai King's birthday or other festivities, Yeh said, noting that a Taiwan national who was convicted for injuring others may be released under the royal pardon program to mark the Thai King's birthday.

She said that the country's Thai representative office visits Taiwan nationals in prison regularly to give them daily necessities or books. The office also provides extra assistance if they are sick or being treated unfairly, handling between 50 and 70 such cases a month, she added.
The ministry has continued to provide assistance to Chen, including hiring lawyers, communicating with Thai judicial authorities, and applying for his amnesty, according to Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 157.33 points, or 1.92 percent, to close at 8,313.72.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,169.19 and peaked at 8,355.28 during trading. A total of 4.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.94 billion (US$3.47 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.9 percent, construction issues at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,544 to 450, with 426 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Less chance of steep increases in raw material prices: minister

TEXT.P: An "immediate" end to continuing increases in raw material prices is not possible in the near future, but the range of the increases is expected to become moderate because the prices have already neared their high end, the minister of economic affairs said Thursday.

Steve R.L. Chen made the remarks at the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA's) year-end press conference, during which he announced that bulk commodity marketing service charges will be canceled from the first day of next year.

The cancellation was made in a meeting of the Executive Yuan price stabilization working task force a few days ago. It was also decided during the meeting that the customs testing and quarantine service fees on imports will be cut to a lower level in a drive to help stabilize consumer prices, Chen said.

Asked about possible price fluctuations next year, Chen said that Taiwan has "almost no way" to curb price fluctuations resulting from price hikes of raw materials in the international market, because the country itself relies heavily on raw material imports.

However, Chen continued, the international community has begun efforts to curb raw material price hikes. For example, the U.S. government has launched measures to encourage the planting of more wheat, he said, noting that despite such efforts, there are still many other factors that will play a role in determining prices, including weather, supply and demand, and whether some agricultural raw materials will be used to produce energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 137 points to close at 8,322, with 55,397 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February rose 146 points to finish at 8,330, with 382 contracts traded, while March futures gained 139 points to close at 8,325, with 42 contract transactions. June futures increased 150 points to finish at 8,330, with eight contract transactions, while September futures moved up 95 points to close at 8,100, with 13 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 8,185 for January, 8,184 for February, 8,186 for March, 8,180 for June and 8,005 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

January TE futures rose 6.95 points to close at 344, with 2,932 contracts traded, while February TE futures moved up 6.45 points to finish at 343.1, with 17 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

January TF futures lost one point to close at 924.4, with 4,280 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 2.2 points to finish at 925.8, with 28 contracts traded. March TF futures rose 13 points to close at 932.6, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panama reaffirms sound relations with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/27/07 16:12:00 (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Samuel Lewis Navarro, the first vice president and foreign minister of the Republic of Panama, reaffirmed Wednesday his country's good relations with Taiwan.
Lewis mentioned the issue during a Panamanian Foreign Ministry news conference.

According to a Taiwan media report, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang recently visited three diplomatic allies -- Panama, the Dominican Republic and Haiti -- because the three countries, in particular Panama, have come under strong pressure from China to cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Describing Taiwan-Panama bilateral diplomatic ties as normal and sound, although admitting that Panama has also maintained good commercial ties with China, Lewis denied the Taiwanese report.

DOC.HEADLINE: No change in `one-step' voting method decision: CEC

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Chen-hsiung said Thursday that there has been no change in the CEC's decision that a "one-step" voting method must be implemented throughout Taiwan's 25 localities in the coming legislative and presidential elections.

Chang made the remarks to reporters following a local newspaper claim earlier that same day that the CEC has agreed to allow some local governments to flexibly adopt a "two-step" voting method after CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien- you said Wednesday that a new "two-step" voting procedure proposed by Taitung County is "not unlawful, " although the CEC does not encourage the proposed new scheme.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said later that the "one-step" format legally prescribed by the CEC must be fully implemented in all localities to ensure smooth and orderly legislative and presidential elections, slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively.

Each of the elections will be accompanied by two referendums -- a critical point in a dispute between the central government and 18 cities and counties controlled by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over the voting format.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey reiterated the central government's insistence on employing the "one-step" voting format, emphasizing that the central government remains firm on using it and repeatedly warning that election commission personnel will be dealt with in accordance with the law if they defy the CEC's decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Financial Holding Co. to be inaugurated Jan. 1

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that Taiwan Financial Holding Co. will become the 18th-largest in Asia and the 89th-largest financial institution in the world when it is formally inaugurated Jan. 1.
Chang made the remarks when he attended a party to mark the inauguration of the national-level financial company.

Chang said Taiwan Financial Holding, formed as the result of a merger of the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan and the Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China, has combined assets of NT$5.12 trillion (US$158.02 million).

It has deposits of NT$3.88 trillion and active loans of NT$3.24 trillion, the premier said, adding that it will become the nation's top financial services provider, overtaking Cathay Financial Holding Co., currently the largest financial institute in terms of assets.
The merger of the three state-owned financial institutions was part of the government's efforts to upgrade the overall competitiveness of the country's financial industry.

Taiwan Financial Holding has 308 domestic branches and 16 overseas units in Europe, the United States and Asia. It has also set up footholds in Vietnam and Macau, giving it good globalized deployment.

Chang pointed out recently that following the implementation of the Financial Holding Company Act, various domestic financial institutions have established holding companies as a means of heightening their operating efficiency and competitiveness.

However, they have met with strong challenges from international holding companies, which enjoy the advantages of huge size, international awareness, product development capability and global branch networks. The establishment of a national-class financial holding company in Taiwan, therefore, is an urgent matter, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate vows to reinvigorate local tourism

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, has said that if elected president in 2008, he will put forward a package of measures, including expanding cross-Taiwan Strait chartered flights, to help boost local tourism.
Hsieh made the pledge Wednesday while meeting with representatives from the travel and tourism industry.

Addressing his policy vision on the occasion, Hsieh said that during his tenure as premier from Feb. 1, 2005 through Jan. 25, 2006, he had pushed for direct cross-strait chartered flights to create a win-win situation in relations between the two sides, but the program was later called off by China.

In addition to expanding the number of cross-straight chartered flights, Hsieh also promised to push for multiple-point direct chartered flight services, an arrangement he said that can bypass the controversy over whether the flights should be defined as domestic or international.
However, he said the opening of direct cross-strait transportation should proceed based on the principle of promoting local tourism.
Hsieh also vowed to open Taiwan to Chinese tourists and study the possibility of cutting or even abrogating taxes on all recreational activities, except for golf.

Adding that Taiwan should ease restrictions on visa applications by Chinese tourists, the DPP standard bearer said that if Chinese visitors have already obtained visas from the United States and Japan, Taiwan should approve their visa applications accordingly.

The DPP presidential hopeful added that to realize the government's plan to double the number of tourist arrivals to boost the tourism industry, Taiwan should capitalize on its cutting-edge technologies and abundant resources to develop diversified tourism, including cosmetic surgery tourism and medical tourism.
Hsieh also said that if elected president, he will make efforts to establish marine activity centers by furbishing harbors and piers that now sit idle around the island to develop marine tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.526.
A total of US$734 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.519 and fluctuated between NT$32.514 and NT$32.550.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children's Bureau pledges to enhance protection for preschoolers

TEXT.P: The government will list preschoolers as its main target for child abuse prevention and control next year, as preschoolers have been proven to be the most vulnerable group of victims of child abuse, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Thursday.

Huang Pi-hsia, director-general of the MOI's Children's Bureau, noted that 10,290 cases of child abuse were reported around the country in the first nine months of this year, compared with 10,094 cases recorded for the whole of 2006.
This year's cases include those uncovered in 1,700 of 35,000 families that have been listed by the MOI as high-risk households, Huang said.

Of the 10,290 cases, nine resulted in death, with all the victims being preschoolers aged 6 or younger, she said, adding that the number does not include another 17 children who were killed in 13 filicide-suicides recorded during the Jan.-Sept. period.

To help in the prevention and control of child abuse among preschoolers, the MOI is planning to cooperate with the Bureau of Health Promotion and the Taiwan Pediatric Association to facilitate the gathering of information about possible child abuse cases, in addition to charging chiefs of villages and boroughs with the responsibility of reporting such cases to the authorities, Huang said.

Wang Ming-jen, executive director of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) , said the discovery of child abuse involving preschoolers can be difficult, as many children in that age group are not enrolled in school, adding that the results of a TFCF survey found that only 3.4 percent of child abuse involving preschoolers were reported by preschool educational institutions.

Referring to MOI tallies, Wang noted that 580,000 children aged 3-6 are not sent to daycare institutions or kindergartens and 84,000 children aged 0-2 have not received preventive inoculation provided by health authorities, which he said means more than 660,000 preschoolers are not subject to any extra-familial monitoring or protection.
He suggested that the government set up a more comprehensive child daycare and preventive healthcare system to better protect preschoolers.

For example, he went on, health authorities should trace the causes behind parents' failure to get their children inoculated and transfer the cases to social affairs authorities if any suspicious situations are detected, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Continental polar air mass approaching Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: An approaching continental polar air mass is expected to cover the entire Taiwan area from Dec. 29 to Jan. 2, sending temperatures in parts of Taiwan down to as low as 8 degrees Celsius, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Thursday.
CWB meteorologists predicted fair weather for Taiwan in the next two days, with the exception of a slight chance of showers Friday.
The added that this winter's first cold continental air mass is expected to hit Taiwan Dec. 29 and to remain stationary for five days.
The polar air mass could cause the mercury to drop to as low as 8 degrees Celsius in central and northern Taiwan and to 12 degrees Celsius in southern and eastern Taiwan, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: IMF criticizes Italian government on budget.
The International Monetary Fund criticized the Italian government for lacking courage in cutting public spendings and in reducing public debts in its 2008 budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military personnel not allowed to stump for candidates: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Thursday that military personnel should maintain strict political neutrality and must refrain from stumping for any candidates in the approaching elections.
Chen made the remarks when he presided over a commissioning ceremony for military generals who were promoted to higher ranks.
He pointed out that the military serves the nation and the people and that it should remain neutral in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential election.
"The military should keep out of political activities, and military personnel should not stump for any particular candidates, " he said.
The president's words came in the wake of an incident in which a general stumped for a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate.

General Chi Ling-lien, a strategic adviser at the Presidential Office, appeared at a rally for Lee Wen-chung, a DPP legislative candidate, to drum up support for him. The Ministry of National Defense later recommended to the Presidential Office that he should receive a major demerit as a punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25 films nominated for children's film festival awards

TEXT.P: Twenty-five TV films have been nominated for awards to be presented at the 2008 Taiwan International Children's TV and Film Festival, screening judge Huang Chun-ming said Thursday.

The biennial event, sponsored by the Public Television Service Foundation, is slated to take place April 4-8 at the Taipei Xinyi branch of Eslite Books, the nation's biggest bookstore chain, according to Huang.

The 25 films, selected by five judges from among 365 children's TV films from 41 countries, will compete in the categories of best dramatic feature, best animation, best documentary, best TV program, a Taiwan award and a special jury prize, Huang went on, adding that the winners will each receive a cash prize of US$4,000.
The 25 films will be screened during the festival, Huang said.

The panel of judges will include a Taiwanese jury, Nicole Dresike, founder of the Chicago International Children's Film Festival and Samir Nasr, adviser to the International Center of Films for Children and Young People, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan guards against changes in ties with Malawi

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang admitted Thursday that there are some "unusual signs" in diplomatic relations with Malawi and that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is on "high alert" following reports that China is trying to lure the country away from Taiwan with a promise of US$6 billion in aid.

Speaking to reporters after a swearing-in ceremony for newly appointed Representative to Hungary Stanley Kao and Representative to Jordan Lin Jinn- jong, Huang said that although the US$6 billion is a "fictional, even astronomical figure, " the MOFA "cannot guarantee 100 percent" that relations between Taiwan and Malawi will not waver.

Very few countries can resist such temptation, therefore it is now crucial for Taiwan to keep communicating with the Malawian authorities, he said. Nevertheless, he went on, the government will not raise the stakes for Malawi, as doing so would be "meaningless."

Noting that the 41 years of diplomatic relationship between Taiwan and Malawi is built up on bilateral cooperation and partnership, the MOFA hopes there will not be any changes and is striving to cement diplomatic ties, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: China urged to respect free will of Taiwan businessmen in elections

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Hung Chi-chang called for China Thursday to respect the free will of Taiwan businessmen operating in China and refrain from pressuring them over the approaching elections in Taiwan.
Hung made the appeal in a year-end news conference of the SEF, a quasi-official body set up to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Hung noted that the Taiwanese business group in China titled the All-China Federation of Taiwan Compatriots -- is planning to hold a meeting in Wuhan Jan. 6 in a show of support for the presidential ticket of Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew of the main opposition Kuomintang to which many Taiwan businessmen have been invited.
Hung said the government is concerned about the move as it is believed to be an attempt to try to sway the Jan. 12 legislative and March 22 presidential elections in Taiwan.
He also said that in addition to the meeting in Wuhan, similar activities will be held around China prior to the elections.
Hung protested at China using its political clout to try to sway the free will of Taiwan businessmen in their election choices.
SEF Secretary-General You Ying-lung also said Beijing's interference in Taiwan's elections will be regarded as interference by foreign forces.

"China should address squarely the fact of the separate rule on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and refrain from pressuring Taiwan businessmen there," You said, adding that it is "unjust and unfair" to the Taiwan businessmen who have made great
contributions to China's economic growth.
Meanwhile, You announced that the SEF will inaugurate in March a
service center for Chinese people who find themselves in dire
straits in Taiwan.

You noted that such a mechanism has been in practice for many years, but said that in view of the possible opening of Taiwan to Chinese people for tourism in 2008, cross-strait exchanges will increase unabated, creating a need for the mechanism to be expanded.
It will be the third service center established under the SEF following one set up for Taiwan businessmen operating in China and a document accreditation and verification center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly half of businesses to expand next year: survey

TEXT.P: Forty-five percent of businesses have confirmed that they will hire more staff next year, according to the results of a survey published by an online human resources company Thursday.

Among all sectors, more than 50 percent of companies in the financial, investment, insurance, legal, consultant, research and development, real estate, construction, electronics and information sectors said that they will hire more staff.

Officials of www.104.com.tw. said most businesses will recruit new staff after Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 7, but added that 32.5 percent of them announced their recruitment in late December or plan an announcement for early January, showing that a fierce hunt for qualified personnel has begun.
The company surveyed nearly 2,700 Taiwanese companies between Nov. 22 and Dec. 17. A total of 2,694 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of 1.89 percentage points.

The results show that 45 percent of the businesses said they will need to increase staff numbers next year, 35 percent said that they will maintain their current scale, and 20 percent said they will hire short-term staff, outsource work or cut back in scale.

Company officials said that compared with a similar survey conducted last year, when around 60 percent of the companies said they would hire more staff, businesses this year have adopted a more conservative approach to face the possible economic and political changes expected in 2008.
The financial, investment consulting, and insurance sectors have the highest ratio of recruiting new staff, accounting for 63.5 percent, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan rated world's 5th-largest mega-yacht supplier for 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's yacht builders received orders for 71 mega-yachts with a total length of 6,867 feet (2,093 meters) in 2007, making the country the world's fifth- largest mega yacht supplier, according to tallies released Thursday by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The total length marks a 50 percent jump from 2006 and translates into a global market share of 6 percent, behind only Italy's 43.6 percent, the United States' 11.7 percent, the Netherlands' 9.2 percent and Germany's 8 percent, bureau officials said.

While only one Taiwan yacht builder was included on the list of the world's top 20 yacht builders for 2007, three have been included on the 2008 list -- Horizon (12th) , Ocean Alexander (16th) and Khashing (17th), the officials said.

They noted that the total length of the mega-yachts ordered worldwide have increased from 81,844 feet for 2006 to 113,520 feet for 2008, with the growth rate registering 7.9 percent for 2006, 15.3 percent for 2007 and 20.2 percent for 2008.

Meanwhile, the total number of mega-yachts ordered worldwide has risen from 688 units for 2006 to 916 units for 2008, with the growth rate standing at 6 percent for 2006, 12.9 percent for 2007 and 17.9 percent for 2008, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dioxin-digesting bacterium discovered by high school student

TEXT.P: A new bacterium endemic to Taiwan has been identified by a high school student in Kaohsiung as capable of decomposing dioxin, a group of highly persistent chemicals hazardous to humans and animals, academic sources said Thursday.

The microbial species, identified as pseudomonas mendocina NSYSU, was first spotted by Li Ya-ting, a sophomore at Affiliated Senior High School of National Kaohsiung Normal University, during a laboratory experiment on dioxin-purging substances a year ago, the sources reported.

Li said she decided to find a solution for dioxin-related pollution after an introductory lesson in her freshman year focusing on the case of the Tainan City-based Anshun plant run by the China Petrochemical Development Corp, which emitted large amounts of dioxin into the environment during its 40 years of operation since 1942.

Even after millions of dollars were spent on the site and its surroundings, the dioxin pollutants still exist in the soil at high concentration, leaving the land unusable both in terms of housing and agriculture, according to microbiologists at National Sun Yat- sen University (NSYSU) and Cheng Shiu University (CSU) , who helped Li's work in its later stages.

In the beginning, Li said, she used earthworms as the dioxin- digesting agent, but the worms died quickly in the highly toxic environment. However, Li said she was surprised to find that the worm's body decomposed after a week, indicating there could be bacteria in the contaminated earth.

Seeking assistance from NSYSU and CSU, Li redirected her study to dioxin- resistant microbes that could also decompose the substance, she said, adding that the result was the discovery of pseudomonas mendocina NSYSU, a sub-strain existing only in Taiwan and named after the university.

In the laboratory, the bacterium is capable of digesting 80 percent of a given dioxin in two months, according to the researchers. Meanwhile, the microbe is also effective in breaking down hazardous substances such as PBDD, PBDE, PCB and PAH.
"The bacterium has great potential in field applications, " commented Chang- Chien Guo-pin, director of the CSU's Super Micro Mass Research and Technology Center who participated in the project.

"It exists and evolves in the local environment, therefore it may not disturb the ecology. The cost and time for cultivation is minimal, but it provides a solution with short decomposition time and high dissolution efficiency. And the purging process produces no hazardous byproducts, eliminating the possibility of subsequent pollution," he said.

Even with such benefits, Liu Jong-kang, director of NSYSU's Department of Biological Science and also a project member, cautioned against releasing large amounts of the species into the environment before detailed field experiments have been conducted and suggested that the local government should set aside an area near the Anshun plant for research purposes.
"The impact of mass breeding of this species in the environment is still unknown, " he said, adding that "we have to determine that the species will not disturb or destroy the microbial ecology."

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls for more heed to sovereignty issue

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the public Thursday to devote more energy to studying Taiwan sovereignty issues in the face of China's constant sovereignty claims over Taiwan.
Lu made the appeal while presiding over an award presentation ceremony for the winners of an online competition for essays on the topic of Taiwan's sovereignty issues.

According to Lu, she came up with the idea of organizing a Taiwan sovereignty- themed essay competition after the U.N. Secretariat refused earlier this year to accept Taiwan's instrument of ratification of the multilateral Convention on the Elimination of All forms of Discrimination Against Women.

Upon learning in April that U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon misquoted U.N. Resolution 2758 in rejecting Taiwan's instrument of ratification, Lu said she reported the case to President Chen Shui-bian and asked the president to call for U.S. attention to the gravity of the issue.

Saying that Ban's claim that Resolution 2758 recognizes China's sovereignty over Taiwan was outrageously wrong, Lu said she asked U.S. officials during a transit stop she made in San Francisco in July to attach importance to the issue.

Afterwards, Lu went on, the U.S. authorities decided not to back Ban's interpretation of the U.N. resolution, forcing him to promise not to quote the resolution to back the PRC's sovereignty claim over Taiwan in the future.

Noting that the core value of Taiwan's bid to join the U.N. lies in safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty, Lu said the public should not ignore this key element and should spend more time and energy pondering the issue in a rational manner.

The U.N. Resolution 2758, passed in 1971, only recognized the PRC as the sole legitimate representative of China and gave the "China" seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei. It didn't address Taiwan's representation issue nor did it affirm China's right to represent Taiwan in the U.N. or its sovereignty claim over Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan scientist honored with Humboldt Research Award

TEXT.P: An Academia Sinica researcher has been selected as winner of the Humboldt Research Award and will go to the German city of Bonn next April for the presentation, a spokesman for Taiwan's top research institution said Thursday.

Lee Der-tsai, a distinguished research fellow and the director of the Institute of Information Science at Academia Sinica, received the notice from Germany's Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, indicating that in recognition of his scientific achievements, he is to be presented with the renowned award, the spokesman said.

The Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, established in 1860, has issued the awards every year to up to 100 scientists around the world to commend and encourage their contributions to scientific advancement. Former winners include 42 Nobel laureates, among them Lee Yuan-tseh, the former head of Academia Sinica.

The Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) reached an agreement with the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation last year that a Tsungming Tu-Humboldt Research Award should be established to commend outstanding academics and experts from each other's countries.
After two German scholars were awarded the first such award in early December, Lee Der-tsai was announced as winner of this year's Humboldt Research Award.
Lee Der-tsai said he is extremely happy to receive the prestigious award and delighted to know that he is the third Academia Sinica winner.

He has dedicated years to the study of computational geometry, design and analysis of algorithms, VLSI/CAD systems, parallel and distributed computing, web-based computing, algorithm visualization, digital libraries, bioinformatics, compliant controllers for active suspension/vibration control, and advanced IT for intelligent transportation systems.

In addition, he was selected as Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers in 1992, Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1997, and as a member of Academia Sinica in 2004, according to Academia Sinica.

According to the NSC, he will be granted a scholarship of 60,000 euros (approximately NT$2.82 million) , as well as the post of visiting scholar, which will enable him to visit and stay in Germany for a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Attitudes affect employment chances for highly educated: survey

TEXT.P: Seventy percent of people polled see the high unemployment among Taiwan's highly educated as a serious problem, but 74 percent believe the attitudes of individual university graduates are largely responsible for their failures to land a job.

The telephone poll, conducted by the Educational Policy Research Group of National Taiwan Normal University, collected 1,105 effective samples between Nov. 20 and 22 from interviewees aged between 20 and 65. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent, 19 times out 20. The results of the survey were released Thursday.
Although 70 percent of respondents see the high unemployment among the most educated as a serious phenomenon, they still attach great value to university education.

Results also show that 92 percent of interviewees believe that university students should try to equip themselves with multiple specialties in order to increase their competitiveness in the employment market.

The unemployment problem of the most educated in Taiwan has been worsening over the past five years. According to official statistics, the unemployment rate soared from 3.82 percent in 2003 to 4.45 percent in 2007.

As of late September, of the 429,000 unemployed people in Taiwan, 116,000 had a university or higher educational background, meaning that one out of every four unemployed people was a university graduate.
Taiwan's 163 universities churn out 320,000 graduates each year with bachelor's, master's and Ph. D degrees, who constitute nearly 20 percent of the people looking for jobs.
Statistics provided by the online job search firm 1111 Manpower Bank show that 23 percent the 2007 university graduates are still hunting for jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academics urge Taiwan to develop closer relations with Korea

TEXT.P: Taiwan should take advantage of the opportunities presented by the election of new Korean leadership to develop closer relations with South Korea, especially on the economic front, which will benefit both sides, academics said in a forum Thursday.

"President-elect Lee Myung-bak is the first so-called 'economy president' in South Korean history. Although Taiwan does not enjoy official diplomatic relations with South Korea, it should still seize the opportunity to develop further economic ties with its former ally, " said Lee Tsai-fang, Taiwan's former representative to the Republic of Korea.

"For example, signing a Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) is a realistic and achievable goal, " said Lee, who served as director of the International Relations Center of Ming Chuan University, in a forum discussing Korea's presidential election and the East Asian security.

Taiwan's focus in its relations with Korea should be on economics, not only because the lack of official diplomatic relations, but also because of South Korea needs China to deal with the North Korean issue politically, said Liu To- hai, a political professor at National Chengchi University.
"It [South Korea] will not engage in any serious political talk with Taiwan, " Liu pointed out at the forum, organized by the Taiwan Thinktank, a private policy research organization.
An attempt to expand bilateral exchanges and cooperation is also necessary as bilateral trade reached an unprecedented level of US$22.2 billion in 2006, Lee said.

Taiwan and South Korea can collaborate by exchanging information on investing in China and South Asian countries, said Academia Sinica researcher Lin Cheng-yi, before noting that both sides will have more "maneuvering space" if South Korea manages to improve relations with its northern counterpart during Lee Myung- bak's term.

"If that's the case, in the future it may be possible for Taiwanese businesses to invest in North Korea through partnerships with South Korea. If so, Taiwanese businesses will be able to benefit from cheap labor," Lin said.
Before anything can happen, it's necessary that Taiwan improve its understanding of the two Koreas, said Lee Ming-jun, Deputy Secretary-General of Taiwanese Society of International Law.
"We know too little about South Korea and have to engage in full-scale research and study, " he said.
Most people don't realize that, historically, Taiwan's destiny has been tied up with the events in the Korean Peninsula, Lee said.

He further explained that Taiwan (Formosa) and the Pescadores Islands (Penghu) were ceded to Japan in 1895 after the First Sino-Japanese War, which broke out over control of Korea. Also, upon the escalation of the Korean War in 1950, then President of the United States Harry Truman ordered the Seventh Fleet to protect Taiwan from potential invasion of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Hungarian and Jordanian representatives swear in

TEXT.P: Taiwan's newly-appointed representatives to Hungary and Jordan were sworn in at a ceremony held by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday.

Minister James Huang, who presided over the ceremony at which other MOFA officials participated, congratulated Representative to Hungary Stanley Kao, and Representative to Jordan Lin Jinn-jong on assuming their new posts and expressed gratitude for their tremendous hard work in the past.

Speaking with a CNA reporter after the ceremony, Kao, former deputy representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the U.S., said that Hungary, which experienced atrocities and severe repression under the former Soviet Communist Party until 1989, can well understand the predicament Taiwan faces given China's oppression.

Taiwan set up a representative office in Hungary in 1995 and bilateral relations between Taiwan and Hungary have been solid and sound ever since thanks to the hard work by his predecessors, Kao said, adding that there is still room for further cooperation on economic, educational and cultural fronts, and that he will strive to enhance Taiwan's links to and friendship with Hungary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister low-key about changing nuclear power policy

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen was reserved Thursday about meeting a carbon dioxide emission reduction target set by the Executive Yuan, pointing out that it would be more difficult at present to de-commission nuclear power plants in active service.

According to an Executive Yuan plan to cut Taiwan's CO2 emissions, the country must keep its greenhouse gas emissions for 2025 at the level of some 221 million metric tons -- similar to the 2000 level -- representing a 40 percent cut of the current emissions level.

To serve that end, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has to first explore the plan's effects on different sectors in line with a quota management mechanism that needs to be precisely assessed in advance, he explained.

Asked whether the planned cut will impact Taiwan's economic growth or whether the MOEA should adjust its nuclear power policy, Chen said only that his ministry basically encourages local industry to voluntarily take part in the plan.

As to whether his ministry should adjust its nuclear power policy, Chen admitted that it would be more difficult for the government sector to shut down nuke power plants now despite a promise of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to make Taiwan a nuclear-free country.

But Chen said his ministry will definitely cooperate with the Executive Yuan to meet the CO2 emissions reduction target as long as it has put complementary measures in place, adding that Taiwan is committed to playing a constructive role in the international community, even though it is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol.

DOC.HEADLINE: Staple vegetables may be included in production warning system: COA

TEXT.P: The government is considering including vegetable staples such as cabbages in its production pre-warning system targeting important agricultural products as part of efforts to prevent supply/demand imbalances, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials revealed Thursday.

The COA held a press conference to announce its measures to help vegetable growers adjust their crops to market demand after prices experienced steep drops over past weeks, triggering an outcry among local farmers about the government's incompetence in addressing the problem of market imbalances.

COA Vice Minister Lee Jen-chyuan attributed the price plunges to increased planting after the country sustained a vegetable shortage that led to price hikes in October due to losses caused by Typhoon Krosa.
Moderate winter weather has also helped accelerate plant growth and boost production, Lee noted.
According to Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. tallies, the average wholesale price of vegetables plunged to NT$12.74 per kilo Wednesday from NT$52.3 per kilo registered Oct. 21.
The prices increased Thursday to NT$13 per kilo, the statistics show.

To address price fluctuations caused by supply/demand imbalances, Lee said the COA has activated a "95" mechanism to purchase over-produced vegetable staples, including cabbages and broccoli, at 95 percent of the production cost.

Addressing the COA-operated production pre-warning system, which was put into operation in January this year, Lee said that at present only seven kinds of agricultural products, including bananas, papayas, oranges, pineapples, garlic, onions and peanuts, are included in the system.
Including vegetable staples in the system would be a challenge because the vegetable production period is shorter, Lee noted, explaining it is difficult to control harvests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tensions fall on Korea Peninsula, rise in Taiwan Strait: ex-official

TEXT.P: Tensions on the Korean Peninsula are expected to fall to a more stable level, while those across the Taiwan Strait are expected to rise, said an ex-official in a forum Thursday.

"While the military situation between North and South Korea should be stabilized by the current six party talks, the cross-strait situation is moving in the other direction, " said Lee Tsai-fang, Taiwan's representative to South Korea from 2003 to 2006.

Recent statements from officials of the United States show that cross-strait tensions have risen to a level at which the U.S. feels it is necessary to speak up, Lee said in a Taiwan Thinktank-organized forum discussing South Korea's presidential election and East Asian security.

The "unification versus independence" argument is Taiwan's particular political issue, he said, adding that his personal view was that it would be better to maintain the status quo and let time take care of the problem.

Lee Myung-bak's landslide victory in the presidential election also suggests that South Korea's "North Korea policy" will follow a road map to a peaceful resolution rather than confrontation, he added.

Relations between the two Koreas have been governed by a "top-down" process and handled by government-to-government negotiations in contrast to cross- Taiwan Strait relations, which have been characterized by a "bottom-up" process dominated by civic exchanges and activities, he said.
"But, of course, there is no 'national identity issue' among the Koreans. The problem they have is more of a 'regional complex.' In Taiwan, the situation is just the opposite, " Lee said.

Lee Ming-jun, deputy secretary-general of Taiwanese Society of International Law, agreed with the ex-official's observation, saying that on the Korean Peninsula "politics goes before the economy", while economic considerations take precedence in relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen Group extends helping hand to cabbage farmers

TEXT.P: The Evergreen Group, the Taipei-based shipping and transportation conglomerate, is extending a helping hand to cabbage farmers in central Taiwan hard-hit by a market slump.

Shipping tycoon Chang Yung-fa, chairman of the Evergreen Group, placed two orders Thursday through the Chang Yung-Fa Foundation, a charitable organization, providing timely relief for cabbage farmers in dire need of assistance.

Chang bought 20 metric tons of cabbage from Yunlin County and another 19 metric tons from Changhua County. He agreed to pay NT$10 per kilogram, twice as the going price. The cabbage will be distributed among Evergreen enterprises and employees.

Wholesale cabbage prices in Taiwan have plunged to around NT$5 per kilogram since the beginning of December -- barely enough to cover the production costs -- mainly because cabbage crops at many farms which were devastated by Typhoon Krosa in October are now maturing at the same time.
The market slump caused by overproduction has been further exacerbated by recent news reports that a duckling died of pesticide poisoning after its owner fed it the outer leaves of a cabbage.

Earlier Thursday, farmers staged a protest and dumped a truckload of cabbage in front of the Changhua county government. They urged the county government to work out measures to prevent further losses.

Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan responded by buying 5,000 head of cabbage to give the vegetables to county government employees. He urged the public to buy and eat more cabbage to help the farmers.

The Yunlin County government also announced that farmers can receive subsidies by selling up to 1,500 metric tons of their cabbage crops to the government for refrigeration at NT$5 per kilogram or by turning them into green compost in their fields at a rate of NT$70,000 per hectare.

DOC.HEADLINE: President congratulates new leaders of Nauru, Solomon Islands

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian telephoned new Nauru President Marcus Stephen and new Solomon Islands Prime Minister Derek Sikua, respectively, Thursday to congratulate them on their election victories, according to a Presidential Office news release.

The press statement said Chen invited the new national leaders of Taiwan's two South Pacific diplomatic allies to visit Taiwan in the near future to exchange views on matters of mutual interest, including measures to further expand bilateral cooperation.

In their telephone conversations, the statement said, Chen assured both the Nauruan president and the Solomon Islands' prime minister that his administration will continue with various existing cooperative projects for their mutual benefit. He also called for ongoing support from the two countries for Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations.

For his part, Nauru President Stephen told Chen that he values his country's cordial relations with Taiwan and will work to further upgrade bilateral cooperation in various fields. Stephen also expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's longtime support and aid to his country, the Presidential Office statement said.

Meanwhile, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Sikua expressed hope that President Chen will either attend in person or name a special envoy to attend celebrations of the 40th anniversary of the founding of his country, scheduled for Jan. 31, 2008.

Sikua also told Chen that the Solomon Islands is more than willing to host the 2009 Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit. He further said he will do his utmost to help Taiwan join the U.N. and the World Health Organization.

The third Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit is scheduled to take place in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung next year. Chen invited Sikua and Stephen to attend the meeting and expressed his hope that Taiwan and the Solomon Islands will finalize talks on the signing of a free trade agreement as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Qualified foreign companies welcome to issue IPOs in Taiwan: FSC

TEXT.P: Attracting blue-chip foreign companies to issue their initial public offerings (IPOs) in the local stock market is one of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) major goals for the next year, FSC Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said Thursday.

Speaking at an year-end news conference, Hu said the FSC has overhauled the IPO underwriting system to facilitate attracting foreign companies to apply for listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange or GreTai Securities Market.

In the initial stage, Hu said, the FSC is setting its sights on small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) in Southeast Asian countries, with paid-in capital ranging between NT$50 million (US$1.54 million) and NT$600 million.
The new opening measure also aims at attracting overseas, Taiwan-funded companies, including those in China, to apply to be listed in the local bourse, Hu said.

Although the current requirement that companies listed in the Taiwan securities market should not invest more than 40 percent of their paid-in capital in China may dampen the interest of China-based Taiwanese companies to issue an IPO in Taiwan, Hu said he is confident that the incentives to be adopted will be effective in luring promising startups to seek a listing on the local stock exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate awaits verdict on corruption case

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Thursday that he is a man of integrity and expressed hope that the Taiwan High Court will uphold a lower court's decision and find him not guilty on corruption charges.

Ma made the remarks as the High Court is set to hand down at 10 a.m. Friday its verdict on the high-profile corruption case involving the appropriation of "special allowance funds" set aside for his use during his tenure as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.
Friday's ruling will be closely watched by both Ma's camp and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) because of its critical importance for next March's presidential race.

If the High Court upholds the district court's "not guilty" ruling, Ma's presidential bid will get a significant boost, political analysts said, adding that it could also be a boon to the KMT's standing in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

If Ma is found guilty, he faces a minimum sentence of seven years' imprisonment. A sentence of 10 years or more would force him to drop out of the contest, which could cause political upheaval in the bitterly polarized local society, political analysts said. Ma will be eligible to appeal his case to the Supreme Court if the high court gives a sentence of less than 10 years.
Speaking before supporters Thursday, Ma played down the chances that the lower court's verdict might be overturned.
"I am confident of my integrity and have expectations that justice will prevail," he said.

In August, the Taipei District Court found Ma not guilty of funneling NT$11 million (US$333,000) of public money into his private account while serving as mayor of Taipei. Judges accepted Ma's argument that Taiwanese law recognized the "special allowance funds" as an official subsidy, but prosecutors appealed the decision, sending the case to the High Court.

Ma maintained that one of the main charges against him -- using discretionary funds without providing detailed accounting -- had long been common practice among Taiwanese municipal leaders and other government officials. Rather than pocketing the funds, Ma claimed that he used them to make donations to charity.

Several leading politicians face charges similar to Ma's. Vice President Annette Lu and former Premier Yu Shyi-kun were charged in September of using false receipts to collect reimbursements for their special allowance funds. Bout Lu and Yu have pleaded not guilty.
