DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate cleared of charges (update-1)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou was cleared of all charges by the Taiwan High Court Friday.

The court said the public funds Ma allegedly lined his pockets with during his term as the mayor of Taipei City between 1998 and 2006 are more of an allowance for senior government officials than public funds earmarked for use for official affairs.
Also, the court said Ma had no intention to embezzle the funds or obtain them by fraud, both of which are necessary for conviction on corruption charges.
As to the crime of breach of trust for which Ma was also charged, the court said it did not apply to Ma's case.

Ma was indicted on Feb. 13 on charges of mishandling funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million (US$343,701) from his special allowance fund during his term as Taipei mayor between Dec. 1998 and July 2006. The funds in question are set aside for office-related expenses.

The prosecutor in charge of the case claimed in the indictment that Ma transferred half of those public funds to his personal bank account every month, keeping that portion which was not used as his personal income, with the knowledge that they were public funds.
He was acquitted of the charges by the Taipei District Court on Aug. 14, but the prosecution appealed the decision to the Taiwan Hight Court on Aug. 27. 2 (By Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Evergreen Group extends helping hand to cabbage farmers

TEXT.P: The Evergreen Group, the Taipei-based shipping and transportation conglomerate, is extending a helping hand to cabbage farmers in central Taiwan hard-hit by a market slump.

Shipping tycoon Chang Yung-fa, chairman of the Evergreen Group, placed two orders Thursday through the Chang Yung-Fa Foundation, a charitable organization, providing timely relief for cabbage farmers in dire need of assistance.

Chang bought 20 metric tons of cabbage from Yunlin County and another 19 metric tons from Changhua County. He agreed to pay NT$10 per kilogram, twice as the going price. The cabbage will be distributed among Evergreen enterprises and employees.

Wholesale cabbage prices in Taiwan have plunged to around NT$5 per kilogram since the beginning of December -- barely enough to cover the production costs -- mainly because cabbage crops at many farms which were devastated by Typhoon Krosa in October are now maturing at the same time.
The market slump caused by overproduction has been further exacerbated by recent news reports that a duckling died of pesticide poisoning after its owner fed it the outer leaves of a cabbage.

Earlier Thursday, farmers staged a protest and dumped a truckload of cabbage in front of the Changhua county government. They urged the county government to work out measures to prevent further losses.

Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan responded by buying 5,000 head of cabbage to give the vegetables to county government employees. He urged the public to buy and eat more cabbage to help the farmers.

The Yunlin County government also announced that farmers can receive subsidies by selling up to 1,500 metric tons of their cabbage crops to the government for refrigeration at NT$5 per kilogram or by turning them into green compost in their fields at a rate of NT$70,000 per hectare.

DOC.HEADLINE: President congratulates new leaders of Nauru, Solomon Islands

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian telephoned new Nauru President Marcus Stephen and new Solomon Islands Prime Minister Derek Sikua, respectively, Thursday to congratulate them on their election victories, according to a Presidential Office news release.

The press statement said Chen invited the new national leaders of Taiwan's two South Pacific diplomatic allies to visit Taiwan in the near future to exchange views on matters of mutual interest, including measures to further expand bilateral cooperation.

In their telephone conversations, the statement said, Chen assured both the Nauruan president and the Solomon Islands' prime minister that his administration will continue with various existing cooperative projects for their mutual benefit. He also called for ongoing support from the two countries for Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations.

For his part, Nauru President Stephen told Chen that he values his country's cordial relations with Taiwan and will work to further upgrade bilateral cooperation in various fields. Stephen also expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's longtime support and aid to his country, the Presidential Office statement said.

Meanwhile, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Sikua expressed hope that President Chen will either attend in person or name a special envoy to attend celebrations of the 40th anniversary of the founding of his country, scheduled for Jan. 31, 2008.

Sikua also told Chen that the Solomon Islands is more than willing to host the 2009 Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit. He further said he will do his utmost to help Taiwan join the U.N. and the World Health Organization.

The third Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit is scheduled to take place in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung next year. Chen invited Sikua and Stephen to attend the meeting and expressed his hope that Taiwan and the Solomon Islands will finalize talks on the signing of a free trade agreement as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 28, or the 19th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter- high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non- binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's shipbuilding output expected to top NT$50 b. for 2007

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's shipbuilding industry is expected to amount to NT$52 billion (US$1.6 billion) for 2007, up 21 percent over the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Thursday by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

This will mark the first time the country's shipbuilding output has topped NT$50 billion, IDB officials said, predicting that the production value will further expand to more than NT$60 billion for 2008.

For the first 11 months of this year, Taiwan's state-owned shipbuilder -- CSBS Corp., Taiwan -- saw its revenue amount to NT$26.2 billion and its pre-tax net profit hit a record-high of NT$4 billion, the officials said.

As of the end of November, CSBC had held orders for 60 container vessels worth a total of NT$125.9 billion and 30 fast missile attack boats worth a total of NT$12.62 billion, and the orders will keep the production line of CSBC's Kaohsiung shipyard busy until April 2012 and that of the Keelung shipyard occupied until July 2011, the officials said.

In addition, to prepare for expected changes in the global shipping industry after the completion of the Panama Canal expansion project, CSBS has established a partnership with the American Bureau of Shipping to develop new Panamax-class container vessels with a capacity of 12,500 twenty-foot equivalent units, they noted.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's largest private-owned shipbuilder -- Jong Shyn Shipbuding Co. -- has invested an additional NT$1.75 billion in expanding existing shipyards and building new facilities this year, and the company's annual turnover is expected to increase to NT$4 billion after the completion of the project, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Consumer confidence drops to new low in December: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence has continued to decline in December to hit a new low, according to the results of a monthly survey released Friday.

The survey results, issued by National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan's Economic Development, show that the consumer confidence index for December stands at 62.58, down 0.76 points from the previous month and marking the lowest level since December 2001.

Four out of the six sub-indices fell in December, with the sub-index for stock market investing over the next six months seeing the largest decline, dropping 3.4 points from November's level to stand at 70.90.
The second largest decrease was seen in the sub-index for durable good purchases for the next six months, which lost 1.05 points to stand at 108.95.

The sub-index for domestic economic outlook over the next six months fell 0.2 points to 46.35, while the sub-index for family finances for the next six months slid 0.1 points to 49.00, the lowest level since the survey began in January 2001.
The sub-index for employment opportunities for the next six months leveled off at 72.10.
The only sub-index that increased in December was that for domestic consumer prices for the next six months, which gained 0.15 points to stand at 28.15.
The survey of 2,344 adults around Taiwan was carried out via telephone Dec. 20-22. It has a margin of error of plus or minus two percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TAIEX Index futures for February rose 68 points to finish at 8,395, with 421 contracts traded, while March futures gained 80 points to close at 8,405, with 55 contract transactions. DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan creates new diplomatic stage despite hardship in 2007: minister

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that 2007 was a hard and arduous year for Taiwan, its efforts to expand and maintain its diplomatic ties with other countries in addition to its attempts to join international organizations have created a grand new stage, Minister of the Foreign Affairs James Huang said Friday.

In his opening remarks at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) year-end press conference, Huang said that despite China's expeditious rise over the years which has empowered it with tremendous political and economic clout to exert every conceivable means to repress Taiwan in the international community, his ministry has striven to have Taiwan join the World Health Organization and the United Nations under the name Taiwan as well as to hold three summits with Taiwan's allies in Central America, Africa, and the South Pacific.

Taiwanese people should feel proud of such achievements, he went on, saying that Taiwan has managed to consolidate its democracy further despite its difficult diplomatic situation and without the efforts leading to war with China.

Looking back on the numerous diplomatic battles against China's ruthless oppression in 2007, it is clear that Taiwan should take new initiatives from the strategic high ground in order to fight for the international status it deserves, Huang said.
"If we do not make a step forward, we will end up being squashed," he added.

Moreover, Huang said that Taiwan should also adjust its policies to conform to the international trend of environmental protection and sustainable development not only because that it is an inevitable path for Taiwan to embark on but also because the more Taiwan does in this regard, the more respect it will earn from the international community, adding that such respect is a "precious asset" for Taiwan, which can be transformed into an "asset of the national security".

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Minister reaffirms ties with Malawi unchanged

TEXT.P: Amid news reports that Malawi is to break off diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang stated Friday that links between Taiwan and Malawi remain "unchanged".

Speaking at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) year-end press conference, Huang said the MOFA has received assurances from both Malawian authorities and the Malawian ambassador to Taiwan Thengo Maloya after a series of "close contacts".

However, Huang said the MOFA will not lower its guard as rumors have been swirling that two Malawian ministers have already traveled to China and Malawian authorities will soon announce their decision to establish diplomatic relations with China.

Malawi is an important ally of Taiwan in Africa, Huang went on, saying that it should make a wise choice between China -- a big country with strategic ambitions casting covetous eyes on the natural resources in Malawi -- and Taiwan -- a trustworthy friend that serves as a fine example to the developing country and always takes into consideration the improvement of the living standard and livelihood of Malawi's people in bilateral undertakings.
Huang reiterated that the MOFA will do all it can to maintain the country's friendship with Malawi, but will not compete with China through so-called "money diplomacy".

Huang also said the MOFA has advised the president to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Guatemala president Jan. 14 as Guatemala is a very important friend of Taiwan and the inauguration presents a significant diplomatic occasion at which to cement and solidify bilateral and multi-lateral relations with that and other Central American countries.

However, Huang said the Presidential Office has not yet made a decision on the trip as the coming legislative elections are to be held Jan. 12, just days before the inauguration. The MOFA will continue working on the matter while looking at alternatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD to launch rejuvenation project at industrial parks

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will launch a project early next year to rejuvenate old industrial parks around the country, according to CEPD Minister Ho Mei-yueh.
Ho's remarks came during a year-end news conference in Taipei Thursday to brief members of the media on the CEPD's achievements in boosting the country's economy over the past year.

Due to the fact that facilities at 26 of the nation's 55 industrial parks managed by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs are somewhat time-worn, the CEPD recently decided to establish a task force dedicated to mapping out measures for their rejuvenation, Ho went on.

According to the proposed measures, the CEPD will implement the project in stages, Ho added, noting that the CEPD will select two industrial parks in the earliest stage, beginning sometime in the first quarter of the next year, and those parks will guide the CEPD in designing rejuvenation projects in the second stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport magnate to establish new cancer hospital

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based transport conglomerate Evergreen Group is set to establish a new cancer hospital in Sijhih, Taipei County, utilizing the heavy ion therapy introduced from Japan, group senior officials said Friday.

They noted that the therapy deploys a complicate particle accelerator to expedite carbon and neon ions to treat certain cancers, and that specialists in Japan have concluded that it best cures breast, cervical, and prostate cancer.

"Conventional radiotherapy sometimes provides less-than- necessary radiation dosage to cancers in certain body parts, while surgery sometimes undermines the organ's normal function," they said. "But heavy ion therapy can be a third, non- intrusive alternative when both therapies are inapplicable."

During a press conference Thursday, Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa said that the new heavy ion institute and hospital may require initial funding of US$200 million to acquire the technology and equipment from Japan, as well as to establish a 13.2-hacter building complex to accommodate the facilities.

The institute and hospital will be dedicated to therapy improvement and ensuring the patient's welfare, Chang said, adding that he believes in "no patient should be left unattended, " so even though full course treatment in Japan costs 3 million yen (approximately US$26,600) , medical subsidies will be provided to local patients without financial viability to ensure their right to proper treatment.

In the preparatory stage, Chang said, experts in engineering physics, medical engineering, chemotherapeutics, and medical science will be recruited and sent to Japan for one-year training on the heavy ion therapy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's property market shows signs of slowdown

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real estate market signaled a slowdown with monitoring indicators flashing yellow-blue for the third quarter of 2007: the second consecutive quarter in which a yellow-blue cautionary light has appeared, according to a quarterly report released Friday by the Architecture and Building Research Institute (ABRI).
The overall monitoring score dropped to 10 in the third quarter: the lowest level recorded over the past three years, ABRI officials said.

The composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the market's outlook in the coming two quarters -- stood at 102.46 in the third quarter, down 0.21 percent from the previous quarter, officials said.
Meanwhile, the index of coincident indicators, which represents the current situation, declined 1.85 percent to 101.78.

While the indicators on investment, production and trade all fell in the third quarter, more than 50 percent of businesses surveyed predicted the real estate climate will worsen over the next two quarters, they said.

Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, said the results indicate Taiwan's real estate market is posed for a correction owing to an oversupply of properties.
As past corrections in the real estate market have always lasted six to seven years, Chang said the upcoming correction will definitely continue for some time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four energy producers reduce greenhouse gas emissions

TEXT.P: Three local power plants and one petroleum refinery have obtained verification from the International Standards Organization (ISO) after reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by following the ISO 14064-2 principles and requirements, said Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials Friday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen presented the ISO 14064-2 certificates to the Taoyuan refinery owned by the state-run CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) petroleum company, as well as Taiwan Power Company's (Taipower's) Tunghsiao, Taichung and Hsingta power plants, during a ceremony held by the MOEA to publicize GHG management results in the energy sector.

Chen said the government began helping the CPC, Taipower and another eight private power plants around the country in planning a voluntary GHG emission reduction project long before the legislative committee of sanitation and environment passed a draft bill in May setting concrete targets for the reduction of GHG emissions in Taiwan.

The country, he went on, is expected to cut its total anticipated GHG emissions amount during a 10-year period between 2005 and 2015 by 12 million tons: the equivalent of the amount of carbon dioxide that can only be absorbed by 12,860 forest parks the same size as Daan Park in Taipei.

The MOEA Energy Bureau began operations to help local energy producers calculate, record and cut GHG emissions in 2005. So far, 75 companies in the power generation, oil refinery and gas fuel sectors have received assistance to reduce GHG emissions.
The ISO 14064-2 standard provides guidance at the project level for the quantification, monitoring and reporting of activities intended to reduce GHG emissions.

The system includes requirements for planning a GHG project, identifying and selecting GHG sources, sinks and reservoirs relevant to the project, a baseline scenario, monitoring, quantifying, documenting and reporting GHG project performance, as well as managing data quality, according to the Switzerland- based ISO, a network of the national standards institutes of 157 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBenazir Bhutto assassinated at political rally in Pakistan
Pakistan was plunged into chaos today after the assassination of Benazir Bhutto, the popular opposition leader, just 13 days before a general election that she was well placed to win.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign students in Taiwan rises to 17,742 in 2007

TEXT.P: The number of foreign students studying in universities around Taiwan totals 17,742 for the 2007-2008 academic year, up 3,263 over the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Friday by the Ministry of Education (MOE).
Visiting students include those pursuing academic degrees, exchange students, and language students.

Foreign students pursuing an academic degree in Taiwan come from a total of 117 countries worldwide, with Vietnamese, Malaysians, Indonesians, Japanese and Americans accounting for the greatest number, said officials at the MOE's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.
Among the 109 Taiwan universities with foreign students pursuing a degree, National Taiwan University has the largest number at 438, the officials said.
The tallies show that science, engineering, medicine and agriculture are the most popular areas of study, followed by business management.
Among exchange students, who come from 70 countries, Asians are in the majority at 1,361, the officials said.
By nationality, the five largest groups of exchange students are Japanese, Koreans, Americans, Germans and French, they said.

Meanwhile, among foreign language students learning Mandarin in Taiwan, the majority are from Asia at 5,860, they said, adding that the largest number of these language students -- 2,921 -- are to be found at National Taiwan Normal University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's acquittal will boost housing market: brokers

TEXT.P: The acquittal of main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou by the Taiwan High Court on corruption charges will help boost the local housing market, brokers said Friday.

According to Sinyi Realty Estate Inc. Assistant Manager Wu Ming-hsiung, political uncertainties, including Ma's case and the legislative and presidential elections slated for early next year, are the factors most likely to affect the domestic real estate and property market.

The settlement of Ma's case in a second trial will effectively mitigate potential negative effects on the two approaching elections, providing a reprieve for the domestic housing market which is bound for a turnaround at the end of this year after four years of gains, Wu said.
Wu said that Taiwan's stock market is also closely related to the real estate and property markets.

For instance, he pointed out, the transaction value of Taiwan's housing market in November again contracted as a result of the ongoing U.S. sub-prime mortgage crisis, a weakened U.S. dollar and high-flying oil prices.

The transaction value of the housing market rose by 15.1 percent in October as the local bourse surged to a new high in recent years of over 9,800 points, he said, adding that in September, the transaction value of the housing market grew by 5.6 percent as the Taiwan Stock Exchange climbed.
In August, the transaction value of the domestic housing market shrank by more than 10 percent while the local bourse plunged heavily due to the U.S. credit loan crunch, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate cleared of charges (update-2)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou was found not guilty on all charges by the Taiwan High Court Friday.

The court said the public funds with which Ma allegedly lined his pockets during his term as the mayor of Taipei City between 1998 and 2006 were more of an allowance for senior government officials than public funds earmarked for their use for official affairs.

These public funds constituted half of a special allowance fund set aside by the government for the mayor's use and were usually transferred to Ma's bank account upon receiving a simple receipt from him.
The court said the funds were assumed to have been used by the mayor for job- related purposes as soon as he received them.
The other half of the special allowance fund had to be used for job-related purposes, with the mayor providing proof in the form of invoices. Such funds were not in issue in this case.

The practices governing the use of special allowance funds were established by the government over many years, and Ma followed those practices in his use of the funds; he should not be held to account on that basis, said the court.

Also, the court said Ma had donated to charity NT$51.5 million during his terms as Taipei mayor which is more than the NT$15.34 million special fund he had received in office: a fact which proves that he had no intention of embezzling the funds, nor of obtaining them by fraud, both of which are conditions necessary for conviction on corruption charges, the court said.
As to the charge of breach of trust, the court said it did not apply in this case.
The court's decision is subject to appeal, although one of Ma's lawyers said he hoped the prosecution would not pursue that option.

Ma was indicted on Feb. 13 on charges of mishandling funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million (US$343,701) from his special allowance fund during his terms as Taipei mayor between Dec. 1998 and July 2006.

The prosecutor in charge of the case claimed in the indictment that Ma transferred half of the public funds to his personal bank account each month after handing in his receipts, then kept that portion in full knowledge that these were public funds.
He was acquitted of the charges by the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, but the prosecution appealed the decision to the Taiwan High Court Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate's two troupes to give final performances of 2007

TEXT.P: World-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater's two troupes will give their final performances of the year at two separate locations Saturday.

While Troupe 1 stages "Nine Songs" in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Troup 2 dancers will join other artists for a performance in Kaohsiung County, presenting a series of new works outdoors at the Weiwu Camp Cultural Center in Fengshan City.
Troupe 2's dancers will be joined by Kimbo Hu, a Taiwanese aboriginal singer and legendary blues artist, when they perform founder Lin Hwai-min's latest masterpiece "Dance, Formosa."
Hu and the Punk Hoo band will also entertain the audience with many of their new songs to cap off the evening performance. Entrance to the performance is free.

Cloud Gate Dance Troupe 2 was founded in 1999. Unlike Troupe 1, which specializes mainly in international tours, Troupe 2 aims to cultivate young choreographers by giving performances in Taiwan's communities.

Troupe 1 began its islandwide tour Nov. 23, staging some 70 performances of "Nine Songs," a full-length dance that reinterprets a cycle of ancient ritual songs. The tour will end Dec. 29 in Lin's hometown, Chiayi, with the final performance of the year presented at the Chiayi Performance Arts Center.

Lin choreographed Nine Songs in 1993 to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Cloud Gate. He said he was inspired by an ancient Chinese poem of the same name. The piece has been presented at a number of high-profile events, including the 2000 Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's identity should not be sacrificed: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan-U.S. relations have had their ups and downs over the past seven- and-a-half years and although differences between the two countries have grown greater as a result of Taiwan's U.N. bid under the name of Taiwan, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Friday at a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) year-end press conference that overall, Taiwan-U.S. relations remain "sound, stable, close and friendly."

Describing the differences as "structural problems, " Huang said they emerged under the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) rule rather than that of the preceding Kuomintang regime because while the DPP acknowledges the importance of improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations, it thinks establishing Taiwan's identity is even more significant and will not sacrifice that to improve relations with China.

He said a well-established Taiwan identity and consolidated democracy should be regarded as assets rather than liabilities in Taiwan-U.S. relations, adding that they are also key elements to safeguarding peace, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region, and constitute the best self-defense mechanism against the threat posed by China.

"Although our American friends may not be accustomed to these `structural changes' in the short term, such changes are in fact in line with the interests of both Taiwan and the U.S. in the long run," according to Huang.

He added that despite China's repeated claims to a "peaceful rise, " what China is doing to Taiwan at present completely diverges from the spirit of peace and that of the 2008 Olympic Games. He urged the Chinese authorities to handle bilateral relations prudently and improve the human rights situation in China, as they will be examined closely by the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: High Court ruling on president's son-in-law revoked

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court revoked Friday a Taiwan High Court ruling that gave a seven- year sentence to President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming for his role in an insider trading scandal involving Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock.

The high court sentenced Chao to seven years in prison plus a fine of NT$30 million (US$$915,383) June 26 on insider trading charges, a penalty harsher than a six-year sentence handed down in the first trial by the Taipei District Court Dec. 27 last year. Chao then appealed his case to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court demanded that the High Court retry the case and return a new ruling.
The Supreme Court also revoked the High Court ruling on other defendants in the case, including Chao's father Chao Yu-chu, who was sentenced to nine years and six months plus a fine of NT$30 million.
The High Court sentences for two other defendants in the case - Yu Shi-yi and former TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien -- were also revoked by the Supreme Court.

Yu received a sentence of seven years and two months in prison in addition to a fine of NT$60 million (US$1.83 million) , while Su was given seven years and six months and a fine of NT$30 million, in the second instance.

The case stems from a dinner party attended by the younger Chao and then-TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien July 14, 2005, during which Chao learned that the loss- making TDC was to be bailed out by a syndicated loan from several banks.
He relayed the information to his father, who bid for 5,000,000 shares July 25, 2005 and sold them after the banks approved the loan to TDC.
Su did not engage in insider trading but was found guilty of tipping off the Chaos.
Yu is a friend of the Chaos who was also present at the dinner party and bought TDC stocks along with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to bring HIV-positive blood donor to justice

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) will bring to justice an HIV- positive blood donor responsible for infecting three individuals through transfusions, DOH officials said Friday.
One of the three victims infected with HIV died of an unrelated disease in early December, said Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH.
The DOH will offer assistance to the other two recipients of the tainted blood, Shih noted.
Shih made the remarks after confirming that further test results show that blood donated by the HIV carrier in July of this year contained the deadly virus.
Back in July, the DOH tests did not detect the virus in the donated blood, Shih explained.
The infections were the first of the kind this year, Shih went on.
The HIV-positive blood donor made a total of six donations, most recently in November of this year, Shih said, adding that the donated blood was destroyed soon after being found to be HIV-positive.
The infected individual also donated blood in last March, according to Shih, who added that another two individuals who received blood from this individual have already died due to other diseases.
Shih explained that the blood products made from the HIV-positive blood donors' donation prior to last March should be virus free as the carrier was in the "window period" at that time.
Those who suspect that they might be HIV positive, who have engaged in dangerous sexual behavior, or who have contracted sexual diseases are not allowed to donate blood, Shih said.
Homosexuals, bisexuals, sex workers, or those who have multiple sex partners are also barred from donating blood, Shih noted.
The HIV-positive blood donor was clearly aware that he was not allowed to donate blood and thus faces a maximum jail term of 12 years, Shih said.

As part of its efforts to minimize infection risks as a result of blood transfusions, a DOH official said that the health department has donated NT$20 million (US$614,062) to sponsor a project being conducted by the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation to expand the scope of HIV screening tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO chief defends 'personnel adjustment' on Taipei commission

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy-wey defended Friday the Executive Yuan's decision to adjust the position of Taipei City Election Commission Chairman Samuel Wu, saying that the decision has nothing to do with a replacement.
Shieh made the remarks one day after the Cabinet sent a notice to the Taipei City Election Commission about changing Wu's position to that of a commissioner of the capital's election commission.

Shieh said Wu insists that the Taipei City Election Commission use the "two- step" voting format, which violates the resolution of the Central Election Commission requiring the adoption of the "one-step" voting format in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and two accompanying referendums.

According to the Election and Recall Act, local election commissions are subject to the authority of the CEC and should abide by the CEC's decision, Shieh said, urging Wu not to "create further chaos" and to accept the arrangement.

Responding to criticisms of the Cabinet's appointment of the Taipei City Election Commission member Tsai Tien-chi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to take Wu's position, Shieh explained that the Cabinet selected Tsai through a legal screening process, and declined to make further comment.
Wu said earlier in the day that he does not plan to leave his position and questioned the propriety of the Cabinet's decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold front to hit Taiwan Dec. 29: CWB

TEXT.P: The winter's first cold front will sweep Taiwan Saturday, a Central Weather Bureau (CWB) spokesman said Friday, forecasting that it will intensify Jan. 1, bringing lows of 7 degrees Celsius to central and northern parts of the country.
The spokesman also said showers can be expected in northern, northeastern and eastern Taiwan, while other areas will be sunny or have partly cloudy skies.

The arrival of the front will reduce daytime temperatures to between 7 degrees Celsius and 10 degrees Celsius in central and northern Taiwan, and 12 degrees Celsius to 14 degrees Celsius in the south and east, the spokesman said.
Lows for central and northern regions could remain under 10 degrees Celsius until Jan. 3, he went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman happy about party candidate's acquittal

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung hailed Friday the Taiwan High Court's acquittal of the party's presidential hopeful of corruption charges and urged voters to discard the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in two key elections slated for early this year.

Wu made the call in a written statement after the Taiwan High Court acquitted Ma Ying-jeou earlier in the day of corruption charges in a second trial related to the handling of the special allowance fund allocated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Wu praised the court's independence amid what he called strong pressure from the DPP government and lashed out at the ruling party for attacking Ma with the special allowance fund case.

He also accused the DPP of seeking to rig the legislative and presidential elections, slated for Jan. 12 and March 22, respectively, by pursuing the case against Ma, reminding the public that Su Tseng-chang, the DPP's vice presidential candidate, said while serving as premier that the disputed system governing the special allowance funds is responsible for involving a large number of incumbent and former ranking government officials in similar cases.

Wu said he shares Su's view that the special allowance funds are a remnant of the past which needs to be overhauled and urged the ruling and opposition camps to jointly resolve the issue to protect the dignity and good name of Taiwan's civil servants.

Now that Ma's name has been cleared, Wu urged DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh to walk out of President Chen Shui-bian's shadow and engage in a "gentlemen's race" with Ma in the coming presidential poll by putting forward good policy proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2007 trade with China expected to bring record surplus

TEXT.P: Bilateral trade with China in 2007 is expected to generate a record surplus of US$42 billion for Taiwan, according to statistics released by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Friday.

The trade figures show that two-way trade across the Taiwan Strait in the first 10 months of 2007 amounted to US$83.47 billion. Exports to China totaled US$60.5 billion, while imports were worth US$22.97 billion, resulting in a surplus of US$37.53 billion.
BOFT officials predicted that Taiwan will enjoy a surplus of US$42 billion in its 2007 trade with China, up from the US$38.55 billion for 2006.

Two-way trade in October totaled US$9.36 billion. Exports to China in that month amounted to US$6.9 billion, up 20.4 percent from October 2006 and accounting for 30.4 percent of Taiwan's total exports in October, down slightly from September's 32.5 percent.
Imports from China reached US$2.47 billion in October, representing an increase of 7.6 percent over the same month of 2006 and accounting for 12.8 percent of Taiwan's total imports for that month.
BOFT officials said electrical equipment, optical products, and parts and components were among the major items exported to China in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC warns of social upheaval in China

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned Friday of growing social upheaval in China and said that increased resentment among the Chinese public will lead to social instability.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun issued the warning at a routine news conference.

Citing statistics compiled by China's public security authorities, Liu reported that the number of social unrest cases around China has exploded over the past 13 years -- from some 8,700 in 1993 to more than 32,000 in 1999 and 599,392 last year.

Although China's economy is expanding rapidly at 10 percent per year, Liu said the country's vast underprivileged population has become increasingly disgruntled with the sharp disparity in the social classes and with the increasing wealth gap.

As China is quickly moving toward a polarized society, the Chinese people, mostly farmers, workers and poor citizens, are growing more and more dissatisfied with the imbalance in development and injustice in society, leading to more and more mass protests against the authorities, Liu said.
Although the Chinese authorities are trying hard to maintain social harmony and public order superficially through hardline means, Liu warned that conflict might eventually break out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign trade value, trade surplus hit new records

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total foreign trade value for the year is likely to break the US$450 billion mark, while the trade surplus is expected to amount to US$27.5 billion, both record highs, according to Steve R.L. Chen, Minister of Economic Affairs.

Citing the Ministry of Economic Affair's (MOEA's) latest tallies, Chen made the announcement Thursday at a year-end news conference held to review the country's economic performance over the past year.

Chen said that the country enjoyed booming exports this year with the total value of foreign trade topping US$439.8 billion as of Dec. 15. Total export values reached US$232.7 billion, up 9.6 percent year-on-year.

According to Chen, the economic growth rate for this year is estimated to reach 5.46 percent, surpassing the 4.6 percent target set by the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the 4.89 percent registered last year.

The total value of newly-increased private investment over the first 11 months of this year amounted to NT$977.16 billion (US$30.07 billion), accounting for 97.08 percent of the year's target NT$1.65 trillion, Chen noted, adding that investment in the electronic and information industry amounted to NT$598.21 billion, and the entire year's total is expected to reach NT$1.19 trillion.

Chen added that during the January-November period, approved foreign inbound investment also hit a new high, with investments from foreign or overseas Taiwanese companies amounting to US$14.14 billion, a substantial growth of 18.8 percent over the year-earlier level.

On the outlook for the coming year, Chen said that the total amount of newly- increased private investment has been set at NT$1.08 trillion, with NT$550 billion in the electronic and information sector and NT$296.9 billion in the metal and machinery industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Completed public construction projects to reach 2,091 cases in 2007

TEXT.P: The number of public construction projects completed and to be completed this year is estimated to hit 2,091 cases, with a combined value of NT$130 billion (US$4 billion) , the Public Construction Commission announced in a press release Friday.
In December, 100 public construction projects worth NT$5.5 billion were completed, mostly involving road and drainage construction.
The news release also noted that as of November, the budget for government- controlled public construction projects this year worth above NT$100 million each has been 89.66 percent accounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors to appeal if KMT candidate's acquittal violates law

TEXT.P: Prosecutors will continue to appeal the verdict that acquitted opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou of embezzlement charges against him if the verdict violates the law, a spokesman for the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office said Friday.

The spokesman further said the office respects the ruling of the High Court but added that prosecutors had yet to receive the verdict and will decide whether or not to appeal after reviewing the verdict.
The spokesman made the remarks after the Taiwan High Court upheld earlier in the day the "not guilty" ruling of Ma's first trial.
The spokesman said the High Court and the prosecutors realize that the ruling will have a major impact on the legal interpretation of the special allowances for senior government officials.
For this reason, the prosecutors will follow the law and make the decision that best ensures social justice and equity, according to the spokesman.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of misusing funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million (US$343,701) from his special allowance fund during his terms as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006.

The prosecutors in charge of the case claimed in the indictment that Ma transferred half of those public funds to his personal bank account every month, keeping that portion which was not used as his personal income, with the knowledge that they were public funds.
Ma was exonerated of the charges by the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, but the prosecutors appealed the decision to the Taiwan High Court Aug. 27.

In a related verdict, the Taiwan High Court that same day reduced the graft and forgery jail term of Taipei city government staffer Yu Wen -- who was indicted on charges of using invoices from other people to help Ma claim reimbursement from the special allowance fund -- from 14 months to 12 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT set to dominate legislature after Ma's acquittal: ex-lawmaker

TEXT.P: The next Legislative Yuan is likely to be dominated by a single party after opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou was found not guilty by the Taiwan High Court on all corruption charges against him, a former legislator claimed Friday.

Shen Fu-hsiung, who was a veteran member of the ruling Democratic Party (DPP) before he withdrew from the DPP Oct. 3, made the comment in a conference held by the non-profit Taiwan Competitiveness Forum at the Legislative Yuan.
Former DPP lawmaker Lin Cho-shui and former Premier Tang Fei also attended the conference on the topic of how the Legislative Yuan could be improved.
Shen said Ma's chances of winning the March 22 presidential election increased after he was cleared of the charges earlier in the day.

Based on his observations and statistics he claimed to have collected, Shen went on, the KMT will win a majority in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and that due to the possible "one-party domination" last seen in Lee Teng-hui and Chiang Ching-kuo eras, he expects the Legislative Yuan to be free of notorious backroom negotiations and inter-party conflict.

If DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh wins the election, Shen claimed, Taiwan could plunge into another round of political turmoil expected to last at least four years because the DPP will not win a majority at the legislature in the upcoming elections.
Lin, meanwhile expressed concern that if the KMT wins a legislative majority, Taiwan will have no more political accountability -- a necessity in a democratic country.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Brokered Bhutto's Return to Pakistan White House Would Back Her as Prime Minister While Musharraf Held Presidency
For Benazir Bhutto, the decision to return to Pakistan was sealed during a telephone call from Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice just aweek before Bhutto flew home in October. The call culminated more than a year of secret diplomacy -- and came only when it became clear that the heir to Pakistan's most powerful political dynasty was the only one who could bail out Washington's key ally in the battle against terrorism.
The Washington Times: Opposition leader faced risk of open campaign
The decision to campaign openly was a huge gamble for opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, and she understood the risk.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Bhutto Assassination Ignites Disarray
Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader and twice-serving prime minister, was assassinated Thursday evening as she left a political rally here, a scene of fiery carnage that plunged Pakistan deeper into political turmoil and ignited widespread violence by her enraged supporters.
The Wall Street Journal: Bhutto Killing Inflames Pakistan The world's most unstable nuclear-armed nation is plunging deeper into crisis.
Yesterday's assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has thrown into disarray Pakistan's attempt to restore democracy, eliminating a leading contender for power days before a national election and highlighting the growing reach of extremists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Home Party urging hi-tech leader to vie for presidency

TEXT.P: Although prominent high-tech leaders such as United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) Honorary Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao may have little interest in politics, a Home Party official said Friday that they are seeking to persuade Tsao to vie for the presidency.

Home Party Secretary-General Yao Lee-ming, who is also a university professor and veteran political analyst, made the comments to reporters while answering questions on the eve of a Home Party-hosted dialogue on cross-Taiwan Strait relations scheduled to take place on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

Tsao and former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh have been invited to exchange views and ideas on key cross-strait issues during the dialogue, in order to provide the public with a clear understanding of their respective stances on the issue, Yao said.

Yao confirmed a local media report that his party has been trying to push Tsao and Shih to pair up on a ticket in the March 22 presidential election with the aim of offering the public a third choice apart from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang.

According to Yao, Shih is also encouraging Tsao to solicit widespread public support following the suit of South Korean President-elect Lee Myung Bak, who enjoyed strong voter backing for his pro-business policy line.
Tsao ran two advertisements last month in major local newspapers calling for the legislation of a cross-strait peace law to secure peace in the region and put an end to domestic political infighting.
Shih, a long-time pro-democracy activist, led mass anti-corruption demonstrations against President Chen Shui-bian in autumn last year in downtown Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visa fees for U.S. nationals visiting Taiwan to rise: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/28/07 22:08:40 (By Michelle Tsai and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: Visa fees for U.S. nationals intending to visit Taiwan will be raised to US$131 (NT$4,300) from Jan. 1, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States said Thursday in a press release.

The move is a response to an announcement by the U.S. representative office in Taipei -- the American Institute in Taiwan -- that the visa service charge for Taiwan citizens will be raised to US$131 from US$100 from Jan. 1, the according to the press release.

The press release further said that two working days will be required to process a visa application and added that an additional US$65.50 will be charged for expedited processing requests, which will take approximately three hours to complete.
As part of its efforts to boost tourism, Taiwan offers visa-free privileges for American tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy of Taiwan will worsen before improving: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people who responded to a recent poll believe that Taiwan's economy will deteriorate further before it improves, according to results of the survey released Friday.

Wu Chung-shu, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics, disclosed the results of the survey at a seminar on Taiwan's economic outlook held by the Taiwan Economy and Industry Association.
Wu told the participants that 46.67 percent of the respondents believe the recession will deepen further in the next five years before the trend reverses.

According to Wu, 40 percent of the interviewees are pessimistic, projecting the unemployment rate in 2008 at between 4 percent and 4.4 percent, while predicting that inflation will continue to climb in the next five years.
Another 46 percent expressed fear that Taiwan's property values could fall by up to 9 percent in 2008.

A whopping 80 percent said increasing exchanges with China and lowering political tensions at home should be the government's priorities at present, followed by enhancement of administrative efficiency and improvement of the nation's financial condition.
Wu gave no details about the survey's sampling, the interview method or the respondents.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT urged to publish namelist of party members in judiciary

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should publish a detailed list of its members in the judicial and law enforcement agencies as part of the country's pursuit of transitional justice to consolidate its young democracy, a senior official said Friday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey, who is also Government Information Office minister, made the call after the Taiwan High Court upheld a lower court's not guilty verdict on corruption charges against KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou earlier that same day.

Shieh said he does not trust the judiciary's integrity after learning that the High Court's presiding judge handling Ma's case, Liu Ching-hsing, played a leading role in a high-profile case against pro-independence activists during Taiwan's infamous martial law era.

After the unification of East and West Germany, said Shieh, who is a former Taiwan representative to Germany, all judges and prosecutors of communist East Germany were relieved of their posts on the grounds that it was the only way to win the public's trust in the judiciary following Germany's unification under a democratic system.

Noting that Ma's corruption case was politically sensitive, Shieh said it is very controversial to have a person who once collaborated with the previous authoritarian KMT government to convict pro-independence activists in a highly political case to serve as the presiding judge in Ma's second trial.
"In a normal and reasonable situation, Liu should have been relieved of his judicial post or should have at least made a public apology," Shieh said.

Accusing the KMT of abusing its legislative majority to prevent the passage of legislation to facilitate the handling of some transitional justice cases or problems, Shieh said he could find no peace of mind nor any feeling of justice having prevailed as a result of the High Court verdict on Ma. He further said the KMT should at least make public how many of its members work in the judicial, prosecutorial and investigative organs.

Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of misappropriating public funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million (US$343,701) from his special allowance fund during his terms as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.
He was acquitted of the charges by the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, but the prosecution appealed the decision to the Taiwan High Court Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new envoy vows to expand ties with Hong Kong

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, Yang Chia-chun, said Friday he will do his best to upgrade the breadth and depth of Taiwan-Hong Kong dialogue and boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Yang made the pledge after his arrival in Hong Kong earlier that same day to assume his new post.

In interview with Hong Kong news media at the airport, Yang said that despite a freeze in official ties at the moment, civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong remain brisk and cordial. Taiwan people make an average of more than 2 million visits to Hong Kong annually, while Hong Kong citizens also make 300,000 visits to Taiwan per year, Yang said.

Noting that many Taiwan agencies have opened representative or liaison offices in Hong Kong, Yang said it is hoped that the Hong Kong government can set up a representative office in Taiwan as early as possible to facilitate mutual exchanges and communications.
Yang all expressed hope that an effective dialogue platform can be forged between Taiwan and the Hong Kong government during his term of office.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 29, 2007

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 29, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Home Party urging hi-tech leader to vie for presidency

TEXT.P: Although prominent high-tech leaders such as United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) Honorary Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao may have little interest in politics, a Home Party official said Friday that they are seeking to persuade Tsao to vie for the presidency.

Home Party Secretary-General Yao Lee-ming, who is also a university professor and veteran political analyst, made the comments to reporters while answering questions on the eve of a Home Party-hosted dialogue on cross-Taiwan Strait relations scheduled to take place on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

Tsao and former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh have been invited to exchange views and ideas on key cross-strait issues during the dialogue, in order to provide the public with a clear understanding of their respective stances on the issue, Yao said.

Yao confirmed a local media report that his party has been trying to push Tsao and Shih to pair up on a ticket in the March 22 presidential election with the aim of offering the public a third choice apart from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang.

According to Yao, Shih is also encouraging Tsao to solicit widespread public support following the suit of South Korean President-elect Lee Myung Bak, who enjoyed strong voter backing for his pro-business policy line.
Tsao ran two advertisements last month in major local newspapers calling for the legislation of a cross-strait peace law to secure peace in the region and put an end to domestic political infighting.
Shih, a long-time pro-democracy activist, led mass anti-corruption demonstrations against President Chen Shui-bian in autumn last year in downtown Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visa fees for U.S. nationals visiting Taiwan to rise: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/29/07 11:39:05 (By Michelle Tsai and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: Visa fees for U.S. nationals intending to visit Taiwan will be raised to US$131 (NT$4,300) from Jan. 1, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States said Thursday in a press release.

The move is a response to an announcement by the U.S. representative office in Taipei -- the American Institute in Taiwan -- that the visa service charge for Taiwan citizens will be raised to US$131 from US$100 from Jan. 1, the according to the press release.

The press release further said that two working days will be required to process a visa application and added that an additional US$65.50 will be charged for expedited processing requests, which will take approximately three hours to complete.
As part of its efforts to boost tourism, Taiwan offers visa-free privileges for American tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy of Taiwan will worsen before improving: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people who responded to a recent poll believe that Taiwan's economy will deteriorate further before it improves, according to results of the survey released Friday.

Wu Chung-shu, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics, disclosed the results of the survey at a seminar on Taiwan's economic outlook held by the Taiwan Economy and Industry Association.
Wu told the participants that 46.67 percent of the respondents believe the recession will deepen further in the next five years before the trend reverses.

According to Wu, 40 percent of the interviewees are pessimistic, projecting the unemployment rate in 2008 at between 4 percent and 4.4 percent, while predicting that inflation will continue to climb in the next five years.
Another 46 percent expressed fear that Taiwan's property values could fall by up to 9 percent in 2008.

A whopping 80 percent said increasing exchanges with China and lowering political tensions at home should be the government's priorities at present, followed by enhancement of administrative efficiency and improvement of the nation's financial condition.
Wu gave no details about the survey's sampling, the interview method or the respondents.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT urged to publish namelist of party members in judiciary

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should publish a detailed list of its members in the judicial and law enforcement agencies as part of the country's pursuit of transitional justice to consolidate its young democracy, a senior official said Friday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey, who is also Government Information Office minister, made the call after the Taiwan High Court upheld a lower court's not guilty verdict on corruption charges against KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou earlier that same day.

Shieh said he does not trust the judiciary's integrity after learning that the High Court's presiding judge handling Ma's case, Liu Ching-hsing, played a leading role in a high-profile case against pro-independence activists during Taiwan's infamous martial law era.

After the unification of East and West Germany, said Shieh, who is a former Taiwan representative to Germany, all judges and prosecutors of communist East Germany were relieved of their posts on the grounds that it was the only way to win the public's trust in the judiciary following Germany's unification under a democratic system.

Noting that Ma's corruption case was politically sensitive, Shieh said it is very controversial to have a person who once collaborated with the previous authoritarian KMT government to convict pro-independence activists in a highly political case to serve as the presiding judge in Ma's second trial.
"In a normal and reasonable situation, Liu should have been relieved of his judicial post or should have at least made a public apology," Shieh said.

Accusing the KMT of abusing its legislative majority to prevent the passage of legislation to facilitate the handling of some transitional justice cases or problems, Shieh said he could find no peace of mind nor any feeling of justice having prevailed as a result of the High Court verdict on Ma. He further said the KMT should at least make public how many of its members work in the judicial, prosecutorial and investigative organs.

Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of misappropriating public funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million (US$343,701) from his special allowance fund during his terms as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.
He was acquitted of the charges by the Taipei District Court Aug. 14, but the prosecution appealed the decision to the Taiwan High Court Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new envoy vows to expand ties with Hong Kong

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, Yang Chia-chun, said Friday he will do his best to upgrade the breadth and depth of Taiwan-Hong Kong dialogue and boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Yang made the pledge after his arrival in Hong Kong earlier that same day to assume his new post.

In interview with Hong Kong news media at the airport, Yang said that despite a freeze in official ties at the moment, civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong remain brisk and cordial. Taiwan people make an average of more than 2 million visits to Hong Kong annually, while Hong Kong citizens also make 300,000 visits to Taiwan per year, Yang said.

Noting that many Taiwan agencies have opened representative or liaison offices in Hong Kong, Yang said it is hoped that the Hong Kong government can set up a representative office in Taiwan as early as possible to facilitate mutual exchanges and communications.
Yang all expressed hope that an effective dialogue platform can be forged between Taiwan and the Hong Kong government during his term of office.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11% of children's products contain extractable heavy metals

TEXT.P: Eleven percent of children's products tested recently were found to contain extractable heavy metals, which pose a potential threat to the health of their users, a Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) official said Friday.
The tests targeted 65 items collected by the bureau from hypermarkets, department stores and specialty stores in November.
They included stickers, hanging ornaments, key chains, refrigerator magnets, cheap children's jewelry and children's face or body paints, according to BSMI Deputy Director-General Wang Cheng-hui.

Of the 65 items, seven were detected to contain extractable heavy metals that are potentially harmful to children, Wang said, adding that the bureau has ordered that the responsible manufacturers recall the toxic products.
Meanwhile, 43, or 66 percent, of the products surveyed were not properly labeled, and their manufacturers were ordered to make improvements within a specific time limit, Wang said.

He advised parents shopping for children's products to check that the products come with complete labels that include information such as data of the manufacturers or importers, the main ingredients, volume and manufacture date of the products, instructions on the use and preservation of the products, and any relevant warnings that consumers should consider.
Parents should warn their children not to bite the items or put them in their mouths, and should check regularly that tiny parts such as magnets and buttons have not come loose, he added.
