A suicide attacker shot her then blew himself up on Thursday, plunging the country into turmoil.
Lianhe Zaobao: Teachers' salaries to go up again.
Singapore's teachers will get higher pay packages starting April 2008 under a new initiative called Grow 2.0 announced by Ministry of Education (MOE) yesterday.
Under the new scheme, teachers will be placed on a salary range system with merit increments that are based on one's performance, potential and market wage movements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public warned of dust storm

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) forecast Saturday that a dust storm from northern China would sweep over Taiwan later in the day, brought south by a cold air front from China.
Director-General Chu Yu-chi of the EPA's Department of Environment Monitoring and Information Management noted that East Asia suffers from November to May due to dust storms from northern China.
Chu warned that the air quality would begin deteriorating from 9 p.m. Saturday evening, with the worst expected between 3 a.m. and 7 a.m. the following day.

The air particle density will increase to 50-100 micrograms per cubic meter later in the day, posing a threat to health, Chu said, adding that the dust mass will not begin to leave Taiwan until 3 p.m. Sunday and will not have fully cleared the island until Tuesday.

The Central Weather Bureau released a low temperature warning Saturday, reporting the temperature in the north and northeast would drop to 12 degrees Celsius due to the arrival of this winter's first cold front, with 15 degrees Celsius forecast for southern regions.

The cold front is expected to linger over Taiwan until Jan. 3, a spokesman for the bureau said, noting that people in the north and northeast are expected to experience a low of below 10 degrees Celsius Sunday and 9 degrees Celsius Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City doubles fines for littering

TEXT.P: Fines are to be substantially increased from Jan. 1 for littering recyclable material and garbage bags, the Taipei city government's Department of Environmental Protection (TDEP) announced Saturday.

In order to cut down on such littering, as well as penalizing those who do not use officially issued garbage bags, the TDEP will increase the fines for daytime violations from between twice to five times the present fine of NT$1,200, while nighttime violations from 10 p.m. to 8 a.m. will land fines of up to NT$6,000. The TDEP will also reinforce efforts to obtain evidence of violations and encourage people to report culprits.

TDEP Third Section Chief Li Tzung-tien said that first offenders who litter in the daytime using the official garbage bags will be fined NT$1,200, with cumulative punishments for repeat offenders. Fines will be doubled to NT$2,400 for first offenders who litter using other kinds of garbage bags, he added.

Li said that 150 digital cameras have been procured to collect evidence and added that the public will be educated on proper garbage disposal through posters, bus advertisements, banners, television commercials and in schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer workers planning to change jobs in sluggish economy: survey

TEXT.P: Fewer workers have indicated an intention to change jobs at the end of this year in light of the risk of doing so in a sluggish economy, according to the results of a recent survey released Saturday by an online employment services provider.

The survey by 104 Job Bank revealed that only 28.1 percent of the respondents are certain about leaving their present positions after the Chinese New Year, marking a decrease of 25.8 percentage points compared with the results of a similar survey conducted at the same time last year.

While only 2.4 percent of respondents said they had already found a new job, 37.5 percent said they have no intention of changing jobs immediately but will pay close attention to any new job opportunities.

Another 15.1 percent of respondents said they totally have no intention of quitting their present jobs, with 43.6 percent of these workers believing it would be highly risky to give up their jobs when the economy is sluggish.

Other reasons mentioned by the respondents included that they maintain good partnerships with their present colleagues and that they do not want to give up the benefits and annual leave they enjoy in their present jobs. Only 17.1 percent said they are staying because they are very satisfied with their salary.

On the biggest advantages of changing jobs, 32.9 percent of the respondents who have changed jobs before mentioned that they received higher pay from their new jobs, 21 percent said their new jobs were more interesting and 17.7 percent said the benefits and annual leave offered by their new employers better fitted their needs.
However, 18.3 percent of respondents said they did not benefit from their new jobs because the working conditions were worse than those of their previous jobs.
While job-changers received a 13.6 percent increase in their salaries from each job change on average, approximately 30 percent of job changers saw no change in their salaries.
Among workers born in the 1980s, who are generally considered to display lower employment stability, 44.4 percent saw their salaries level off or decrease after a job change.
The survey was carried out Nov. 21-30 among 5,468 workers. It had a margin of error of 1.33 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic business turnover totals US$729 billion in nine-month period

TEXT.P: The number of domestic business entities had reached over 1.17 million as of the end of September, generating a combined turnover of NT$23.7 trillion (US$729.25 billion) during the first nine months of the year, according to statistics released Saturday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The turnover posed a year-on-year growth of 4.2 percent, the bulk of which was contributed by the manufacturing sector at over NT$8.76 trillion, the tallies show.

The largest portion of domestic business entities were wholesale and retail businesses, with 612,374 units registered as of Sept. 30. The volume recorded showed year-on-year decline of 0.7 percent, according to the DGBAS figures.

Businesses involving cultural, sports and leisure activities fell to 25,819 units, posing a 7.5 percent drop and representing the largest decline in terms of business unit volume in comparison with other business categories, most of which also saw volume drops.
Despite the drops, however, the turnover recorded mostly increases among the different business categories in the first nine months of this year.
According to the DGBAS tallies, the manufacturing sector recorded a year-on-year turnover growth of 8.3 percent, while the wholesale and retail sector registered a 3.6 percent growth.
The largest growth was created in the real estate trading and renting service sector at 15.7 percent, with a combined turnover of NT$574 billion in the nine- month period, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar questioned about drugs, NTU says "misunderstanding"

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) officials said Saturday that an incident in which guest researcher Gallet Sylvain was questioned by the police about a parcel he received from his parents in France and which police suspected of containing hemp seeds was "a misunderstanding."

"Everyone of the Department of Geosciences thinks the whole thing could be just a misunderstanding, " NTU Secretary-General Fu Li-chen said, adding that Sylvain, who has been a researcher in the department for four years, lives a simple life and has a clean record.
Keelung City Police and the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau took him to a police station for questioning over the parcel Thursday.
Sylvain, who was released after being questioned by the Taipei Prosecutors Office, said the package actually contained lentils sent by his parents from France.
Fu said Sylvain cooperated fully with the police investigation, adding that NTU will decide how to handle the incident when the results of a lab test on the package are released.
Hemp seeds are classed as a class B drug in Taiwan. They do not remotely resemble lentils, a very common pulse used in a great many European dishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to inaugurate Sike railway station in Taipei County

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is scheduled to inaugurate Sunday the brand-new Sike railway station -- located in Sijhih, Taipei County -- to offer commuters convenient and fast transport services, a spokesman for the TRA said Saturday.

Sike Station is situated between the Sijhih and Taipei City's Nangang stations and was built by the TRA as a rapid transit station, the third of this kind the administration has constructed in northern Taiwan as part of its policy of turning railroads into rapid transit lines, according to the TRA.

Services at the station will begin at 4: 27 a.m. daily for trains heading north and at 4: 56 a.m. for southbound trains. There will be a total of 137 two-way runs per day through the station, the TRA spokesman said, adding that trains are expected every 10-12 minutes at peak hours.

As the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was laid to rest, the government on Friday recast its version of the events of her assassination and announced that it had obtained an intelligence intercept pinning the attack on a militant linked to Al Qaeda.

DOC.HEADLINE: More local electoral heads to be replaced: Cabinet

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will announce next week more personnel adjustments targeting the heads of local electoral commissions who disagree with the central government over the voting format for the upcoming legislative elections and referendums, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Saturday.
Shieh said the Cabinet cannot delay the matter any further because the problem must be solved before the election gazettes are printed.
He would not identify the targeted localities but said officials subject to replacement will definitely include those have promoted a "two-step" voting format in handbooks for electoral workers.
The Cabinet will also not rule out the possibility of referring these officials for prosecution, he said.

The Cabinet made the move in response to a decision by the 18 counties and cities controlled by the opposition Kuomintang-led "pan blue" alliance to follow the "two-step" voting format, in defiance of the Central Election Commission's decision to adopt a "one-step" voting format.

The measure was only made possible following a recent amendment to the organic rules of local election commissions, according to which the Central Election Commission can ask the Cabinet to replace law-breaking members of city and county election commissions.

Over the past several days, the Cabinet has announced the replacement of the chairmen of the Taipei City Election Commission and the Taichung City Election Commission, and has appointed an official to serve as acting chairman of the Hsinchu City Election Commission, in the wake of Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer's resignation.
The next round of personnel adjustments reportedly will involve Taipei County, Taichung County, Hsinchu County and Penghu County.

Also Saturday, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu accused the Cabinet of abusing its power by revising the organic rules of local election commissions "arbitrarily" in order to interfere in the personnel appointments to local election commissions.
Hu claimed the Cabinet is doing so to influence the outcome of the legislative elections and that the practice has done serious harm to the country's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Language learning programs NIA's primary initiative in 2008

TEXT.P: Subsidization for language learning programs in various localities will be the primary initiative for the National Immigration Agency (NIA) , as the language barrier is the most important factor marring communication between new immigrants and Taiwanese, an NIA official said Saturday.

An annual fund of NT$300 million has been allocated and placed under the administration of the NIA, to which local governments can apply for establishing language learning programs to help new immigrants learn Mandarin and Taiwanese, said NIA Director Wu Cheng-chi.

The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) established the Foreign Spouse Care and Counseling Fund in 2005 with a total budget of NT$3 billion over a 10-year period, Wu said on the sidelines of a seminar discussing care for new immigrants.

The language issue is the biggest challenge for foreign spouses and workers in Taiwan, said Wen Chih-yi, director of a film titled "Nyonya's Taste of Life, which tells the stories of two female Indonesian caretakers and a Thai worker in Taiwan.
"Once we get to understand and befriend them, we will realize that they are no different to us. Most of the cultural differences and misunderstandings come from the language barrier, " she said.

Another important initiative for the coming year will be after-school tutoring for the children of immigrant families because some foreign spouses have difficulties counseling their children, Wu said, adding that this also originates from the language barrier.

Wu denied that the welfare of spouses from China has been ignored by the authorities, saying that the biggest problem for Chinese spouses is obtaining citizenship. Because of "national security issues, " it takes Chinese immigrants eight years to get citizenship, he said.
The NIA will also devote efforts in 2008 to catching runaway foreign workers.
"Unfortunately, runaway workers are a serious problem and we are too short- handed to track all of them, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 140 peace ambassadors certificated in Taipei

TEXT.P: More than 140 representatives of various fields in Taipei city and county received certificates at a ceremony at National Taiwan University in Taipei Saturday allowing them to serve as "ambassadors for peace."

The certification was part of a "peace ambassadors to guard homes" campaign sponsored by the Interreligious and International Federation for World Peace's Taiwan chapter and the Taiwan branch of the Women's Federation for World Peace (WFWP) in support of the U.N.-initiated 2001-2010 Decade for Culture of Peace and Non-Violence.
WFWP Taiwan Chairman Chang King-yuh expressed hope at the ceremony that the peace ambassadors will spread love and peace around the country.
So far, nearly 2,500 Taiwanese people have been certificated to serve as ambassadors for peace, including ultramarathon runner Kevin Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT backs down on CEC voting format

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that it would "compromise" by accepting the Central Election Commission's (CEC's) rules for the voting format in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and simultaneous referendums.

The KMT's policy committee executive director, Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, made the remarks after bitter bickering on the voting format between the Central Election Commission (CEC) and 18 KMT-controlled local election commissions.

Tseng noted that the voting format controversy had been raging for weeks, leaving local election officials in a difficult situation. He claimed that "this is why the KMT-controlled cities and counties are willing to compromise so as to let Taiwan democracy continue to prosper."
The renegade local election officials had been threatened with sacking and prosecution if they went ahead with their unlawful action.
Tseng said that it would accept the "two-step" ballot distribution and "one- step" ballot casting recently offered by the CEC.

This means that voters will claim two ballots for the legislative elections -- one ballot for legislative candidates and another for their favored political party -- at one table. At a second table, they will claim another two ballots for the accompanying referendums. The voters will then cast each ballot in one of four ballot boxes in a "one-step" format.
The CEC had originally planned to have voters claim four ballots at once and cast them at different boxes in a different "one-step" format.

But 18 KMT-controlled cities and counties wanted the "two-step" format that was used in the 2004 presidential election, claiming that this would avoid confusion and maintain the confidentiality of the voters.
Under the "two-step" format, the voters would have claimed two referendum votes after casting their legislative votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will face disaster if KMT wins majority seats: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Saturday that if the pro-unification Kuomintang (KMT) garners more than half of the seats in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, it will mean "the disaster of the nation."
Chen, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ruling pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged voters to support the DPP, which he said represents Taiwan-centric consciousness.

Chen said that the legislative election is no longer the battle for an individual candidate or a party, but a battle to protect Taiwan from being taken by China, predicting that if no DPP candidates win in Taipei's eight constituencies, the party will "surely be ridiculed by China."
The president made the remarks when accompanying DPP legislative candidates Kao Chien-Chih and Wang Shih-chien on a visit to a temple in Shihlin, Taipei to canvass support.

He expressed hope that Taipei City, a stronghold of the KMT and administered by a KMT mayor, will not only support the DPP presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang, but will also support the DPP legislative candidates, saying that every constituency in Taipei counts.

The president also expressed hope that the public will support the DPP when casting their ballots for a political party, saying that this will help the DPP garner its target of 50 seats in the streamlined 113-seat legislature to form a stable majority.
Chen, who was suffering from a cold, said his disabled wife Wu Shu-jen also had a fever of 39 degrees Celsius, and he prayed to the goddess Matsu to seek her blessing for his wife's speedy recovery.
Chen's close aides said that the president will continue to have a full campaign schedule prior to the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady checks into hospital

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-jen was admitted to the National Taiwan University Hospital Saturday suffering from pneumonia, a Presidential Office official said later that day.
Lee Nan-yang, director of the Department of Public Affairs, said that physicians attending her at the presidential official resident suggested that she be admitted.
President Chen Shui-bian had noted while stumping for legislative candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party earlier the same day that his wife was not well and had developed a mild fever.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars form organization to promote transitional justice

TEXT.P: A group of liberal scholars formed a new organization Saturday to pursue the truth about human rights abuses during Taiwan's infamous martial law era as part of their efforts to to promote reconciliation and put the country's authoritarian past to rest.

"The new organization -- Taiwan Truth and Reconciliation Commission or Taiwan TRC -- will dig for the truth of human rights violations and political persecution during the previous authoritarian rule and clarify political and legal responsibilities of those cases, " said Wu Nai-teh, a board director of the non-governmental organization.

Noting that for a country to make a successful transition to democracy, it must make a full accounting of the abuses committed by the previous administration, Wu said pursuing transitional justice requires not only a well-rounded or circumspect discourse but also long-term hard work.

"We need a private truth commission to explore a broad picture of human rights suppression, abuses and violations during the authoritarian period," Wu said, adding that getting to the bottom of truth is the bedrock for national reconciliation.
He further said digging for previous human rights abuses and political persecution should not be aimed at getting a basis for prosecution or punishment of perpetrators.
The findings should mainly be used as teaching materials to inspire self- reflection and prevent recurrence of similar atrocities, Wu said.

Acknowledging that the Taiwan TRC's work agenda might cause misgivings of the country's two bitter rival groups -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green" camp and the main opposition Kuomintang-led "pan-blue alliance, " Wu said the work is not just a political one, but also a cultural movement.

So long as the new organization can push society to gradually face and acknowledge what happened in the past and draw inspirations from past incidents, Wu said he believes that the Taiwan TRC will get sympathy and support.

In addition to looking into the previously classified historical documents, Wu said the organization will launch a publicity campaign to help the public better understand the gist of transitional justice, foster social consensus and push for legislation of relevant laws to pave the way for materialization of transitional justice.
"Seeking transitional justice involves many dimensions of work, " Wu said, adding that common to all forms of justice is official acknowledgement of what happened.
As official disclosure of the truth is a form of justice, Wu said the former ruling party and relevant government organs should offer access to information or archives held by them.

Stressing that seeking transitional justice should go beyond consideration of partisan interests, Wu said exploring cases of human rights abuses or violations during the rule of the two late President Chiangs -- Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- requires extensive and sophisticated investigations and that reconciliation between rival political camps can only be accomplished on the basis of the results of such delicate work.
The Taiwan TRC has some 40 founding members. Wu said he hopes more like-minded academics can join the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Dictator's' statue will stay put: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday the giant bronze statue of "dictator" Chiang Kai-shek in the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei will stay put.

Addressing a campaign rally in Taipei county's Luchou township for a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative candidate in his capacity as DPP chairman, Chen said visitors will find the statue remains intact when the memorial hall reopen to public access on New Year's Day.

The building, known as Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall until earlier this year, was built by the previous Kuomintang government in memory of its late leader and the president of the Republic of China until his death in 1975.

Branding Chiang as a dictator and main perpetrator of the tragic 228 Incident of 1947, the DPP administration re-named the hall as the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall earlier this year and completed replacement of its name plaque and an inscription on its arch gateway early this month amid protests from staunch KMT supporters.

The hall has been shut down for renovation and will reopen Jan. 1. Rumors have it that Chiang's statue would be removed or covered by steel wall. Chen dismissed such speculation, saying that the statue will stay put. But the wall of the hall will be equipped with posters featuring the names, photos and life stories of those who were wrongly killed during Chiang's rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars form organization to promote transitional justice

TEXT.P: A group of liberal scholars formed a new organization Saturday to pursue the truth about human rights abuses during Taiwan's infamous martial law era as part of their efforts to to promote reconciliation and put the country's authoritarian past to rest.

"The new organization -- Taiwan Truth and Reconciliation Commission or Taiwan TRC -- will dig for the truth of human rights violations and political persecution during the previous authoritarian rule and clarify political and legal responsibilities of those cases, " said Wu Nai-teh, a board director of the non-governmental organization.

Noting that for a country to make a successful transition to democracy, it must make a full accounting of the abuses committed by the previous administration, Wu said pursuing transitional justice requires not only a well-rounded or circumspect discourse but also long-term hard work.

"We need a private truth commission to explore a broad picture of human rights suppression, abuses and violations during the authoritarian period," Wu said, adding that getting to the bottom of truth is the bedrock for national reconciliation.
He further said digging for previous human rights abuses and political persecution should not be aimed at getting a basis for prosecution or punishment of perpetrators.
The findings should mainly be used as teaching materials to inspire self- reflection and prevent recurrence of similar atrocities, Wu said.

Acknowledging that the Taiwan TRC's work agenda might cause misgivings of the country's two bitter rival groups -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green" camp and the main opposition Kuomintang-led "pan-blue alliance, " Wu said the work is not just a political one, but also a cultural movement.

So long as the new organization can push society to gradually face and acknowledge what happened in the past and draw inspirations from past incidents, Wu said he believes that the Taiwan TRC will get sympathy and support.

In addition to looking into the previously classified historical documents, Wu said the organization will launch a publicity campaign to help the public better understand the gist of transitional justice, foster social consensus and push for legislation of relevant laws to pave the way for materialization of transitional justice.
"Seeking transitional justice involves many dimensions of work, " Wu said, adding that common to all forms of justice is official acknowledgement of what happened.
As official disclosure of the truth is a form of justice, Wu said the former ruling party and relevant government organs should offer access to information or archives held by them.

Stressing that seeking transitional justice should go beyond consideration of partisan interests, Wu said exploring cases of human rights abuses or violations during the rule of the two late President Chiangs -- Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- requires extensive and sophisticated investigations and that reconciliation between rival political camps can only be accomplished on the basis of the results of such delicate work.
The Taiwan TRC has some 40 founding members. Wu said he hopes more like-minded academics can join the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
There has been only one voting format: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that there has been only one voting format set for adoption in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and referendums and there is no "compromise" version.

Speaking during a campaign rally to stump for ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative candidate Chien Chao-tung in Taichung County, central Taiwan, Chen said there has been only one voting format adopted for the upcoming legislative elections -- the "one step" voting format worked out and promulgated by the Central Election Commission (CEC) more than a month ago.

Chen, however, said he would still like to offer his appreciation to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for its decision the day before to accept a "compromise" version of voting format, thereby helping to put an end to bitter bickering over the voting format between the Cabinet-level CEC and 18 KMT- controlled local governments over the past several weeks.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung also spoke Sunday to express relief and to welcome the KMT's decision to no longer insist on adopting a "two step" voting format. He said the administration needs local governments' cooperation in order to carry out electoral affairs smoothly.

KMT Policy committee executive director and Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan announced at a news conference Saturday that the KMT, taking the interests of the whole country into account, would "compromise" by accepting the CEC's rules for the voting format in the Jan. 12 legislative elections in a bid to ensure that Taiwan's democracy continues to flourish.

Tseng said that the KMT would accept the "two-step" ballot distribution and "one-step" ballot casting option recently offered by the CEC. This means that voters will claim two ballots for the legislative elections -- one ballot for legislative candidates and another for their favored political party -- at one table. At a second table, they will claim another two ballots for the accompanying referendums. The voters will then cast each ballot in one of four ballot boxes in a "one-step" format.

The CEC has planned to have voters claim four ballots at once and cast them at different boxes in a different "one-step" format. But 18 KMT-controlled cities and counties wanted the "two-step" format that was used in the 2004 presidential election, claiming that this would avoid confusion and maintain the confidentiality of the voters. Under the "two-step" format, the voters would have claimed two referendum votes after casting their legislative votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold front drives mercury down

TEXT.P: The mercury is expected to plummet beginning Sunday night as the winter's first cold front sweeps across Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Sunday.

The onslaught of the northern Chinese cold front is forecast to hit Sunday night and will remain for three days before leaving Jan. 3, with lows reaching 7 degrees Celsius in open, coastal areas of central and northeastern parts of Taiwan, CWB forecasters warned.
The forecasters urged the public to watch out for sudden temperature changes and farmers and fishermen to take protective measures to care for their crops.

The arrival of the cold front reduced temperatures to 12.6 degrees Celsius in the northern coastal township of Tamshui Sunday morning. During the daytime, temperatures in northern Taiwan are forecast to reach around 18 degrees Celsius, and 20 degrees Celsius for central and southern Taiwan.
Lows for central and northern regions of the country could remain under 10 degrees Celsius until Jan. 3, the forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady's condition is improving: NTUH

TEXT.P: First lady Wu Shu-jen's condition is improving after being attended by doctors, but she will remain under close observation, a spokesman for National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) said Sunday.
President Chen Shui-bian's wife was admitted to the NTUH Saturday suffering from pneumonia caused by a cold.

NTUH spokesman Tan Ching-ding said that Wu had developed a fever, which reached 39.2 degrees Celsius before she was admitted to the NTUH. Her temperature was still high at around 38 degrees Celsius Sunday.
The first lady has been diagnosed as having an elevated level of white blood cells, low blood pressure and an electrolytic imbalance as a result of high levels of potassium in her blood, Tan added.

Meanwhile, Wong Chao-min, a chief physician with the NTUH's Department of Internal Medicine, said that Wu's fever has been brought under control and the physicians attending her believe that their diagnosis and treatment directions are on the right track.

Wong noted that presently it is still difficult to predict when Wu could be discharged from the hospital, adding that in addition to diagnosis and treatment, other factors, including the patient's condition and body's constitution, could contribute to alter the time of discharge.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Kinmen Marathon to take place Jan. 5

TEXT.P: The 2008 Kinmen Marathon, the first international marathon to be held on the outlying island Kinmen, will take place Jan. 5, with some 10,000 runners taking part.
The event, sponsored by the Kinmen County government, will be divided into four categories: the 42.2-km marathon, the 21.1-km half marathon, the 10-km race and the 3-km leisure run
More than 2,200 runners, including athletes from China's Fujian province and six accomplished runners from Kenya, Zimbabwe and Russia, will compete in the men's and women's marathon groups.
The race will start at 8 a.m. Jan. 5 from National Kinmen Institute Technology, with the marathoners circling Kinmen island along a scenic highway.
The top 10 winners in the men's and women's groups will receive cash awards of between NT$200,000 and NT$2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Small parties woo voters by condemning referendums

TEXT.P: A group of small parties urged the public Sunday to reject the referendums initiated by two major parties in the upcoming legislative elections and cast their ballots for them instead.

Led by Hwang Kwang-kuo, chief of the Democratic Action Alliance, these small parties claim at a news conference in Taipei that both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which initiated a referendum on the country's bid for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, and leading opposition of Kuomintang (KMT) , which initiated the referendum on the country's return to the U.N., are cheating the voters as neither of their proposals is feasible.

Hwang and representatives of New Party, Home Party, Nonpartisan Solidarity Union, Taiwan Citizen Party, Taiwan Hakka Party and Taiwan Farmer's Party told the news conference in Taipei that the two major parties are simply using the referendums to turn out their supporters, in full knowledge that the matters being voted on won't be realized through a referendum.
Hwang said the KMT is contradicting itself by proposing a referendum while urging voters to boycott any referendum after finding public opinion was not in favor of the referendums.

Christina Liu, a legislative candidate of the Nonpartisan Solidarity Union told the news conference that the two major parties, which have been fighting tooth and nail over the voting format, intend to shut small parties out of the legislature and deny minorities a voice in the legislature to detriment of the country's democracy.

She urged voters, who would be given two ballots in the legislative elections -- one for an individual candidate, another for a political party -- to cast their political party ballots for one of the small parties to ensure the healthy development of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Earthquake rocks southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A magnitude 4 earthquake hit the southern county of Chiayi at 1: 47 a.m. Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said later the same day.
No major damage was reported according to the bureau.
The earthquake's epicenter was 18.6 km southeast of Chiayi City, at a depth of 13.2 km, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68 kilograms of ketamine seized at airport in past five months

TEXT.P: Customs officials have seized over 68 kilograms of ketamine from incoming express parcels at the Taoyuan International Airport during the past five months, the Taipei Customs Office said in a news release Sunday.

The office indicated that during the August-December period, officials with its Onsite Clearance Division confiscated a total of 68.72 kilograms of ketamine and 169 grams of heroin from 24 express parcels.

The Taipei Customs Office pledged in the news release that its officials will step up efforts to crack down on drug trafficking via air freight, especially during the festive season when illicit drugs are in great demand.

Ketamine, a fast-acting dissociative anesthetic used on both animals and humans, is being abused by an increasing number of young people as a "club drug." It can produce hallucinogenic effects and impair perceptions. It can also elicit an out-of-body or near-death experience and render the user comatose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP chairman, business tycoon discuss cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: A kbusiness tycoon and the leader of the 2006 anti-corruption movement aimed at President Chen Shui-bian engaged in a dialogue Saturday on Ketagalan Boulevard to elaborate on their views regarding a cross-Taiwan Strait peaceful co- existence law and making Taiwan a nation of freedom.

Microelectronics Corp (UMC) Honorary Chairman Robert Tsao met with Shih Ming- teh, former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman and leader of the anti- Chen campaign, at the open air forum organized by the Home Party during which Tsao dismissed the possibility that he would team up with Shih to run in the 2008 presidential election.

Addressing the forum, Tsao first renewed his call for the passing of a cross- strait peace law, adding that the law will be conducive to the development of cross-strait political and economic relations.

Tsao said that key points of his proposed law include dropping any plan to conduct a referendum on independence for Taiwan, not ruling out the possibility of unification with China, with the proviso that a unification referendum first be put to the people.

He added that the unification referendum will only be held at the request of China and before the referendum is voted on, China must clearly specify all the rights and obligations of Taiwan under which unification would take place to allow the people of Taiwan to make an informed decision.

Should the referendum be adopted, unification could be achieved, if not, China could make a new request for a second unification referendum, Tsao said, adding that there should be no limitation on how many times the referendum would be held.

Echoing Tsao's calls for no referendum on independence, Shih said that as the majority of the 23 million people of Taiwan see Taiwan as an independent and sovereign nation, there is no need to hold a referendum on the issue, adding that only a referendum on unification is needed.

Meanwhile, Shih broached the concept of the division of power and forming a great coalition government to allow more capable and qualified people to manage state affairs, while appealing to national leaders to take the lead in accomodationg differing factions of society and further building Taiwan into a free country.

Touching on the development of cross-strait economics and trade, Tsao attributed Taiwan's lackluster economic performance over the past eight years to rampant anti-China sentiment in the country, deploring that Taiwan has missed a good opportunity to take advantage of access to the greater China market during its economic rise over the past 10 years.
Shih said that although the main opposition Kuomintang has revealed its economic policies, it still needs to work on developing more concrete details for future economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT hands-off on party candidates' boycott of referendum

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will maintain a hands-off policy for the time being regarding calls by party legislative candidates for a boycott of any referendum in the Jan. 12 polls, a KMT official said Sunday.

Huang Yu-cheng, director of KMT Cultural and Communication Department, said his party is still scratching its head for effective ways to turn out supporters for a referendum proposal it initiated on ridding the administration of corruption.

He was asked to comment on criticism from a clutch of small parties earlier the day that the KMT is contradicting itself by proposing an issue for referendum only to call on its voters to boycott altogether referendum in the upcoming legislative elections.

Huang said the KMT is busy canvassing voters to cast a ballot for the political party, which is a separate issue from voting for individual candidates, and has no time to think about how to solicit support for the referendum proposal it initiated.

He said his party fully respects party candidates' calls for a boycott of the referendum, including a proposal initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to authorize the government to retrieve the KMT's ill-gotten assets.
Huang said the KMT would neither encourage, nor hinder party candidates from boycotting the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 trade surplus expected to reach US$30 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total foreign trade for the next year will break the US$500 billion mark, while the trade surplus is expected to expand to US$30 billion, according to the latest forecast released Sunday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The report shows that the country enjoyed booming exports this year and that as of Dec. 15 exports had grown by approximately 9.6 percent, while the cumulative trade surplus reached US$25.56 billion and the total value of foreign trade topped US$439.8 billion.

The latest figures also forecast that the value of total foreign trade for the year is likely to break the US$450 billion mark, while the trade surplus is expected to amount to US$27.5 billion: both record highs.

Meanwhile, according to the forecast published December by Global Insight Inc., an international economic forecasting company, the global economic growth rate for this year would drop to 3.8 percent, down from 4 percent for last year due to slowing economic growth in the United States and Japan.
Global Insight also lowered the global growth forecast for 2008 to 3.4 percent because of the negative effects of the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis.

However, the report of the Bureau of Froeign Trade showed that given increased economic interdependence between China and Taiwan, Taiwan is expected to benefit from China's steady economic growth, which will cushion the impact from falling global markets.

Therefore, Taiwan's growth in exports for 2008 is likely to slow slightly to an estimated 8.52 percent, with total exports reaching an estimated US$265.32 billion. The projected import growth rate will be 8.36 percent, with total imports estimated to reach US$234.83 billion, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls on public to cherish Taiwan's hard-earned democracy

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu reminded the Taiwanese people to cherish the country's hard-won democracy in light of the fact that , people in neighboring Hong Kong will have to wait another 10 years before they can elect their own leaders, and
Lu made the comments Saturday while stumping for Lin Shu-feng, a legislative candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Lu was referring to reports on an announcement issued earlier the same day by Hong Kong's chief executive that China would allow Hong Kong to directly elect its own leader by 2017 and all of its lawmakers by 2020.

Describing Hong Kongers' demand for universal suffrage as a humble wish, Lu lamented that it cannot be fulfilled. She added that despite the fact that Hong Kong is free and rich, it still lacks full democracy.

Mentioning China on the same occasion, Lu said that although the 1.3 billion Chinese people eagerly look forward to becoming a democratic country, nobody could forecast when they will be granted the right to elect their own leaders.

To emphasize the preciousness of democracy, Lu cited Pakistan as an example, claiming that the country's lack of democracy had led to the exile of its former premier Benazir Bhutto and her recent assassination after risking her life to return home earlier this year to run in an upcoming election.
Noting that Taiwan's hard-earned democracy has come about as the result of the sacrifices of an enormous number of people, Lu said that should make the Taiwanese people cherish it even more.
Lu also appealed to Taiwan's people to treasure what they now enjoy, including freedom of speech and economic freedom.

Even though the country is facing a surge in unemployment and a slump in business due to a mass exodus of local traditional industries to China, Lu rebutted reports that South Korea's economic performance outshone Taiwan's, citing to bolster her arguments recent statistics showing that for the first 10 months of this year, Taiwan's exports increased 9percent, the trade surplus reached US$25.7 billion and foreign direct investment stood at US$10.1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong amphibious, special forces form invincible deterrence

TEXT.P: Strong and well-trained amphibious and special operations forces could form an invincible national defense and effective deterrence against invasion, officials from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Sunday.
The officials said the amphibious and army special operations forces completed two important drills late last week, honing their combat prowess.
In modern warfare, amphibious and special operations forces are no less important than advanced jet fighters or missiles, MND officials said.
In a joint drill conducted by members of the Navy, Air force and Marines, the military -- with a combination of aircraft and landing craft -- honed their skills of launching attacks from the sea.

In the drill involving the Army special operations force, members of the highly- trained military units hiked in deep mountains -- the highest peak was 3,000 meters above the sea level -- for 17 consecutive days, honing the skills used in specialized operations such as infiltration and reconnaissance of the mountains, unconventional warfare and airborne logistic operations.

The highly trained and versatile special operations soldiers also surveyed, examined and recorded their findings about roads, bridges, forests and areas that were of potential danger of rock and mudslides during the drill that was concluded in southern Taiwan Friday, according to the MND officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Name-changing of memorial hall dampens DPP's election campaign: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu claimed Sunday that the Ministry of Education's bungle in changing the name of the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall has negative impact on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) campaign for upcoming legislative elections.

Lu said the administration's decision to change the inscription on the gateway of the hall, which was initially built in memory of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, from one honoring Chiang to "Liberty Square" is right, but the Ministry of Education has bungled it by doing it tactlessly and thereby prompted protest from the government of Taipei City which houses the hall and followers of Chiang.
Lu apologized for the ministry's bungle and urged the Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng to follow suit and don't try to shift the blame onto his subordinates.

She made the comment while stumping for DPP legislative candidate Jao Yung-ching in Chunghe, Taipei County, adding that every one in the DPP administration should help the party win the legislative elections by doing their jobs properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 31, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, U.S. Army general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain, and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: U.S. President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-liang, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as the United Nations secretary- general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students present an autographed album to Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-U.S. Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui calls for increased constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits on an equal footing so as to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian calls on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issues operational certificates to seven financial holding companies, the first batch of its kind in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices surge on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 109.33 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 8,506.28.
The bourse opened at 8,450.32 and fluctuated between 8,506.28 and 8,414.79 during trading. A total of 3.6 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.08 billion (US$2.56 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.6 percent, construction issues at 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Only cement stocks lost ground, decreasing 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers more than 1,000 to 842, with 473 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Squatters to hold New Year's party to demonstrate their wish to stay

TEXT.P: A group of squatters living in Shi-jou in Hsintien, Taipei County will hold a New Year's countdown party Monday night amid disputes over their right to continue living in the region.

Showing thanks for the support from different social groups and people, the squatters, who call themselves the Shi-Jou-Tribe Salvation Group, said in a press release that they, however, have no intention of accepting the county government's arrangements for them to move.

According to the Taipei county government Indigenous People Bureau's plan, the Shi-jou tribe is scheduled to be relocated from the area, which is on a flood plain along the Hsintien River, by the start of the high water season on May 1, 2008.

Although the county government has offered alternatives to members of the tribe and invited them to move to the San-xia Indigenous Culture Park, only two of the Shi-jou families have so far accepted the offer, the organizer said.

The Shi-Jou-Tribe Salvation Group, founded Nov. 4 by the Shi-jou aborigines with the aim of protecting their land rights and their autonomy, is now fighting against the local government for their right to stay in the area where they have lived for more than 30 years.
"We don't want to see that the Shi-jou tribe is sacrificed because of political tensions, " the organizer of the party said, adding that the aboriginal people in Shi-jou are unwilling to move.
The organizer further stressed that the Shi-jou people have no intention to accept the county government's plan.

With the hope that the government and society can look into the real needs of the Shi-jou tribe, the people of the tribe call on the presidential candidates to pay more attention to indigenous people's culture and their right to survive, the organizer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County indigenous peoples affairs office to begin operations

TEXT.P: The newly established Indigenous Peoples Affairs Office of the Yilan county government, which aims to promote indigenous people's welfare, will officially begin operations Tuesday, the county's Civil Affairs Bureau (CAB) announced Monday.

In order to raise the service quality for indigenous peoples and to improve their living environment, the county government recently had its organic law revised to allow for the establishment of the Indigenous Peoples Affairs Office and the expansion of staff dealing with relevant affairs.

The new office will be able to carry out the government's welfare policy for indigenous people by diminishing the gap between urban dwellers and members of aboriginal tribes and by helping indigenous tribes to develop a sustainable livelihoods, the CAB explained.

In the beginning, the CAB had a section made up of a handful of staff to handle aboriginal affairs related to forestry, agriculture, social security and education, to name a few. With the newly established Indigenous Peoples Affairs Office, the number of staff members has been expanded to eight.
Moreover, the budget for indigenous affairs has been raised from NT$50 million (US$1.5 million) per year to NT$74 million in order to enhance efficiency and service quality, the CAB said.
The inauguration ceremony will be presided over by Yilan Magistrate Lu Guo-hwa Tuesday morning at Yilan Sports Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 fireworks to be focus of New Year's Eve events

TEXT.P: A fireworks show over the top of Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest skyscrapers, is expected to be the spotlight of activities slated to take place in several parts of Taiwan Monday to celebrate the coming of 2008.

Noting that the midnight temperature is likely to hover around 7 degrees Celsius -- possibly the lowest temperature of this winter, Taipei city government officials said they were still expecting a huge turnout at the fireworks show and a concert in an adjacent area.
Starting from 7 p.m. Monday, the Taipei city government will implement an eight- hour traffic control system in the vicinity of Taipei City Hall and the Hsinyi District.
Meanwhile, several hotels in the capital will also organize parties offering a good view of the fireworks show.

In eastern Taiwan, the Taitung county government will organize two events -- a New Year's Eve countdown celebration at the National Museum of Prehistory and a party at Taimali township, in which a 10-meter airship will fly around the party.
An official of the Taitung county government said free shuttle bus services between the two events will be provided.

In central Taiwan, an official of the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration said that in addition to a New Year's Eve countdown, four local temples will organize a religious event to welcome the arrival of 2008 with 108 bells at midnight.

Also in central Taiwan, the Cingshui service area on the No. 3 National Freeway will hold a concert at 10: 30 p.m. followed by another activity at 11: 15 p.m. in which 10,000 people will hold fireworks to celebrate the coming of the New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for January moved up 87 points to close at 8,481, with 32,943 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February rose 90 points to finish at 8,483, with 298 contracts traded, while March futures gained 93 points to close at 8,498, with 40 contract transactions. June futures increased 102 points to finish at 8,498, with 13 contract transactions, while September futures moved up 78 points to close at 8,289, with 13 contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 8,394 for January, 8,393 for February, 8,405 for March, 8,396 for June and 8,211 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

January TE futures rose 4.75 points to close at 351, with 1,719 contracts traded, while February TE futures moved up 3.95 points to finish at 350, with nine contract exchanges. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

January TF futures rose 0.8 points to close at 939.6, with 1,836 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures moved up 1.8 points to finish at 940.4, with 16 contracts traded. March TF futures increased 3.8 points to close at 943, with six contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan concerned about cross-strait 'status quo': MOFA

TEXT.P: Japan has recently explained that it "does not oppose" Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on its bid for a seat in the United Nations under the name Taiwan, but hopes the referendum will not raise tension in the Taiwan Strait, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.

Japan told the ministry that it will not support the planned referendum "if it leads (Taiwan) to take unilateral action to change the status quo, " noted Huang Ju-hou, chief executive officer of the MOFA Committee on Japanese Affairs.

Huang made the remarks in an interview with CNA in response to questions about Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda's comment on the U.N.-bid referendum during a visit he made to China last week. The comment drew international attention, with Fukuda reported to be opposed to Taiwan's holding of the referendum along with its 2008 presidential election slated for March. 22.
Huang claimed that Fukuda's remarks on the issue were "distorted" by some foreign media outlets.

Citing Japan's mass-circulation Sankei Shimbun, Huang said Fukuda said in a Friday meeting with his Chinese counterpart Wen Jiabao in Beijing that Japan does not support "two Chinas" or "one China and one Taiwan" and neither does it support Taiwan independence.

After the meeting, a Japanese foreign ministry official in charge of Asia- Pacific affairs told reporters covering the meeting that "not supporting" and "opposing" have different meanings, Huang noted.

According to a Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs' publication on Fukuda's statement, Huang went on, the Japanese prime minister underlined that he will not support any attempt to unilaterally change the status quo, and hopes Taiwan's referendum will not increase cross-strait tension.
Judging from this statement, Huang said it is "obvious" that Japan "is not opposed" to the referendum.
What Japan will not support is a referendum that will change the status quo in the strait, Huang went on.

The MOFA official told CNA that after receiving Japan's explanation of Fukuda's remarks, MOFA expressed its understanding and reiterated that joining the U.N. is a common consensus and a common wish of the Taiwanese people.

The planned referendum does not touch the issue of independence and unification and will not change the status quo in the strait, Huang stressed, calling for the Japanese government's trust and respect for the right of the Taiwanese people to exercise their rights as citizens of a democratic country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine exhibitions to be staged at Yingge Ceramics Museum in 2008

TEXT.P: Nine exhibitions will be staged at the Yingge Ceramics Museum in 2008, a spokesman for the museum in Taipei County said Monday.
The nine exhibitions will feature ceramic works created by applicants selected by a five-member jury, the spokesman said.
From next March, the selected works will be displayed in succession at the museum's Sunlight Gallery, Ceramics Hallway and Ceramics Park, the spokesman went on.
Among the successful applicants, two are from Japan and the rest are from Taiwan, including Hung Wei-bin, Kuo Ya-mei, Lin Miao-fang and her spouse Brian Misaveage.
According the spokesman, the selected applicants for this year reveal deeply touching character in their pieces, which have won praise from the jury.

For example, Kuo's work is inspired by the traditional architecture of China's Fujian Province, while Chang describes the "myth of the subconscious and dreams" in her creations and Chen's pieces express nature's vitality.
The Ceramics Museum invites amateur ceramic artists every year to submit their work and the jury then picks out several pieces to be part of the museum's annual program.
This year's jury is made up of five ceramic artists and academics -- Sung Lung- fei, Fan Chen-chin, Li Liang-yi, Chen Kai-huang and Shao Ting-ju.

A total of US$871 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.450 and fluctuated between NT$32.425 and NT$32.528.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to boycott referendum

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided Monday to boycott the referendums to be held alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections and was immediately accused by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration of being "a puppet party of China."

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said his party, which has itself initiated one of the referendum proposals -- to rid the government of corruption -- made the decision "with pain, " claiming that the referendums are being used by the DPP -- which has initiated a referendum proposal on retrieving the KMT's ill-gotten assets -- as a means of bringing out its supporters or triggering conflict.

Wu said the decision was made at a meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee in which almost all its members participated earlier that day and was acknowledged by the party's presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou.
He apologized to the party's supporters for urging them to support the KMT- initiated referendum proposal at first only to later ask them to stay away from it.

Wu said boycotting the referendum is the last resort for his party after it was forced to accept the Central Election Commission's decision to employ a "one- step" voting format in the referendum rather than a "two-step" voting format preferred by the KMT.

Under the "one-step" format, voters will be given two referendum ballots along with two ballots for the legislative elections being held at the same time, while the "two-step" voting format would give voters their referendum ballots only after they have cast their legislative ballots.

Unless the DPP stops using referendums as an electioneering gambit, Wu said, the KMT will also boycott a referendum initiated by the DPP on the country's bid for U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan, which is scheduled to be held March 22 alongside the presidential election.

Government spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey told a news conference that the KMT is cooperating with China to scuttle the country's U.N. bid and said the KMT's decision has "betrayed its scheme to kill referendum via referendum."
He challenged the KMT to establish relations with China outright, and urged voters to punish the party by denying it their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Stock Exchange aims to add 40 listed companies in 2008

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) has set a target of increasing the number of its listed companies by 40 in 2008, TSE Chairman Wu Rong-i said Monday.

Wu told a year-end press conference that the number of companies listed on the TSE stands at 698 at present and that he and other TSE executives hope to add 40 listed companies in 2008, although he added that the Financial Supervisory Commission would be satisfied with 30.

He added that 13 companies have already obtained permission to be listed on the TSE in 2008, including 10 that are currently listed on the over-the-counter market, known as the Gre Tai Securities Market.

The TSE began operations in 1962. Its listed companies reached a record of 700 between February and June of 2005 and then slipped to 688 in 2006. At the end of 2006, the total market capitalization of the 688 companies amounted to US$594 billion, while the average daily trading value totaled US$2.96 billion, representing a market turnover rate of 137.5 percent.
The TSE is said to be among the top 10 stock exchanges in the world in terms of trading value.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opinion poll results barred from release after Jan. 2: CEC

TEXT.P: The results of any opinion polls related to the Jan. 12 legislative elections are barred from being covered, disseminated, commented upon, or cited after Jan. 2, officials of the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Monday.

The CEC made the announcement in line with the Public Officials Election and Recall Act, which forbids local political parties or anyone else from publishing any survey results relating to the election within 10 days of the polling day, the officials said.
Violators will face fines of between NT$500,000 (US$15,384) and NT$5 million, the CEC officials noted.
They said the CEC will also publish the list of qualified legislative candidates Jan. 1, while announcing that election campaigns will officially kick off Jan. 2.
In addition, the CEC will invite indigenous legislative candidates to explain their platforms to the public on the Taiwan Indigenous TV channel at 10 a.m. Jan. 2-3, the officials went on.
The CEC will also air videos aimed at promoting the platforms of 12 political parties on five terrestrial TV stations between 9 p.m. and 10 p.m. Jan. 7-11, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people want third party in legislature: survey

TEXT.P: More than half of the people who responded to a recent survey conducted on behalf of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said there should be other political parties besides the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the Legislative Yuan, according to the survey results released Monday.

Among the 1,070 respondents to the survey, which was conducted by Taipei-based Shih Hsin University Dec. 27-28, 54.6 percent support the existence of a third party in the legislature, while 10.6 percent expressed hope there will be only two parties in the legislature.

Asked which party deserves to stay in the Legislative Yuan as the third party, 17.8 percent of the respondents answered the TSU. This figure, according to TSU officials, means the party is first choice as the third party in the legislature.
In terms of popularity, the poll showed the KMT as having the highest approval rating of 35.3 percent, followed by the TSU at 22.7 percent and the DPP trailing far behind at just 14.8 percent.

On the "single-member constituency, two ballots" electoral system for the Jan. 12 legislative elections, 78.8 percent of the respondents said they know how the voting procedure will work, while 21.1 percent said the new system is not clear to them, according to the survey results.

The poll also shows that 56.1 percent know that their political party ballot will be counted to decide the number of legislator-at-large seats to be appropriated to their favored party, while 43.9 percent said they do not know what this ballot is for.

DOC.HEADLINE: BERI ranks Taiwan 6th lowest-risk country for investment

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) rated Taiwan the sixth lowest-risk country for investment in its third quarterly Business Environment Risk Report of 2007.

In the BERI's report, which evaluates the business environment of over 50 countries, Taiwan has maintained its 6th place ranking among the world's lowest risk countries for investment, behind Switzerland, Singapore, the Netherlands, Japan, and Norway.

Taiwan maintained its scores from the last BERI report, receiving a rating of 1A, and a score of 72 on BERI's profit opportunity recommendation (POR) score. The score indicates that Taiwan is a low-risk country well-suited for investment.
The report predicts that Taiwan's overall investment environment would continue to improve, and that Taiwan's POR score will rise to 73 by 2008, and 74 by 2012, while maintaining its sixth ranking.
Taiwan ranked third among Asian countries for its business environment, behind only Singapore and Japan, but ahead of China, Malaysia, South Korea, Thailand, India and the Philippines, among others.

The Business Environment Risk Report is designed to assess the business environment of various countries based on three main indices: the operations Risk Index, political Risk Index, and remittance and repatriation factor index. In the latest report, Taiwan ranked third worldwide in terms of the Operations Risk Index, with a score of 72, the same ranking and score as in the last report. Only Switzerland and Singapore scored higher.
BERI sees Taiwan's operating risks as stable and predicted that the nation will continue to improve in this regard from 2008 to 2009.

On the Political Risk Index, Taiwan ranked 15th globally, with a score of 59, both the same as in the last report. The report indicated Taiwan's score most likely reflects the uncertainty surrounding the upcoming legislative and presidential elections.
As to the remittance and repatriation factor, Taiwan ranked fifth globally and third in Asia, and its ranking and scores remained unchanged from the last BERI report.

According to the report, Taiwan, with its trade surplus and international payment surplus, will maintain a strong position in the rankings. The report also forecasts that the amount of net foreign direct investment will continue to climb between 2008 and 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA looks forward to prosperous year

TEXT.P: An ambitious goal of upgrading the Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) to a full ministry, the establishment of five cultural parks and the integration of national cultural databases are the CCA's plans for the coming year, a council spokesman said Monday.
"We hope for the establishment of the Ministry of Culture in 2008. This has been a hope of cultural workers for many years, " said CCA Chairwoman Wong Chin-chu at a year-end press conference.

A substantial organizational restructuring within the Executive Yuan has been underway, she said, adding that the CCA could be upgraded to the Ministry of Culture or the Ministry of Culture and Tourism. While the final result is not clear, Wong expressed hope that the council can be upgraded.

Wong said the council has done a lot of work to prepare for the establishment of a cultural assets management organization and an institute that integrates Taiwanese traditional arts, which has helped the council get ready for the upgrade.
Looking ahead to the coming year, the council plans to complete the establishment of five creative culture parks around the nation as the second phase of the Creative Culture Initiative.

The parks will include the Huashan Culture Park in Taipei, the Taiwan Architecture, Design and Art Center in Taichung, the Tainan Creative Culture Park focusing on animation, the Hualien Creative Culture Park focusing on leisure and a creative culture park in Chiayi.
The CCA has been also collaborating with the Ministry of Economic Affairs on an initiative to make 2011 a big year for Taiwan's creative culture industry, she said.

The year will include a world design annual congress, an international craft exposition, the opening of the South Wing of the National Palace Museum and an international creative culture exposition, she said.

In 2007, the council devoted its energy to establishing local cultural subjectivity and exchanges with foreign countries, Wong said, adding that the CCA is planning to set up a third Taiwan Cultural Center in Japan, in addition to ones already established in Paris and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three common weeds proven to be potential cancer fighting agents

TEXT.P: Three common weeds in Taiwan have been found by Academia Sinica researchers to contain cancer fighting ingredients that can be turned into medication after more testing on animals and humans, sources at the institution said Monday.

Scientists at the Agricultural Biotechnology Research Center, Academia Sinica said they found some pure compounds in bidens pilosa, crassocephalum crepidioides, and anoectochilus formosanus hayata are able to inhibit tumor metastasis and angiogenesis on rodents.

Shyur Lie-fen, the center's associate research fellow, explained that the compounds found in bidens pilosa do not kill cancerous cells directly, but repress angiogenesis in cells surrounding the tumor.

On the other hand, Shyur said, the compounds extracted from crassocephalum crepidioides and anoectochilus formosanus hayata have proven effective in eliminating cancer cells. "Melanoma tumors of subject mice were reduced in size after being injected with the compounds," she added.
The team's results have been published by the renowned medical journal Cancer Research. The team is also applying for patents in Taiwan and the United States, another team member reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: 86-year-old judo master promoted to ninth dan

TEXT.P: Eighty-six-year-old judo master Chen Tsai-chi has been awarded a ninth dan -- a rare honor -- in recognition of his life-time pursuit of the martial art discipline and 53 years of dedication in teaching judo to schoolchildren.

The Chinese Taipei Judo Association presented Chen with a ninth dan certification, along with a red belt, Sunday during a ceremony at his dojo in Wuchi township, Taichung County. The ceremony was witnessed by Legislator Hung Chi-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
A congratulatory message from Japan's judo governing body was also presented to the silver-haired judo master at the ceremony.
Chen is now the only ninth dan holder in Taiwan and one of only a few judo masters in the world ever awarded the ninth dan, the second highest honor in judo.
Chen began to learn judo when he was 15 and has been practicing the sport ever since then.

In 1953, he opened his own dojo in his hometown. He won a gold medal in judo at the 1958 Asian Games held in Tokyo. The gold medal was the first honor ever won by a judoka from Taiwan at the Asian Games.

Chen obtained his eighth dan, represented by a red and white striped belt, more than 30 years ago. In the past 32 years, he has been teaching schoolchildren judo and organizing annual invitational judo matches between elementary schools in Taiwan and Japan.
His dedication in teaching the martial art has earned him the nickname "Judo Textbook."

DOC.HEADLINE: New Year's Eve concert climaxes international band festival

TEXT.P: The Chiayi city government in southern Taiwan will hold a New Year's Eve celebration concert featuring performances by local and foreign bands, officials of the city's Culture Affairs Bureau said Monday.
The concert is part of the southern city's International Band Festival, which kicked off Dec. 22, and will run through Jan. 1, 2008, the bureau officials said.
The city government will invite members of bands from South Korea, Singapore, and Thailand to perform during the countdown to welcome the year 2008, the officials noted.

In addition, a band from Hai-Shan High School in the northern county of Taipei will put on a special performance by having some of its 90 members perform on stage in sync with other members who will be performing in the audience, the officials went on.
Popular singers will also be invited to the concert, which will include a fireworks display, according to the officials.
The 10-day festival features 75 musical performances staged by a total of 70 local and seven foreign bands, the officials said.

During the festival, the city government also organized a carnival parade Dec. 22, showcasing band music and colorfully dressed marching bands, which received applause and cheers from onlookers, the officials said.

Italian Premier Romano Prodi said Sunday that there will be new concerted measures for assisting lower-income families. "We can do these because we have made public accounts more healthier."
