Only a fifth of doctors believe that a national electronic system for storing patientsrecords will be secure, a poll for The Times has shown.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to decide next month whether to keep freezing gasoline prices

TEXT.P: A decision will be made at the end of January on whether or not to maintain the current price levels for domestic gasoline through February, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen said Monday.

Gasoline prices have been frozen since Nov. 2 when they were adjusted upwards using a floating pricing mechanism, with the prices of all grades of the state- run CPC Corp., Taiwan's unleaded gasoline rising to over NT$30 per liter.

Chen noted in response to media inquiries that a decision on whether or not to adjust prices for February will be arrived at after the government conducts an overall review of fluctuating commodity prices, the country's economic situation, social justice, as well as international crude oil price fluctuations.

Asked how the CPC will be affected if gasoline prices are frozen at the current level, Chen indicated that the state-operated company's operational income recorded a decline of NT$5 billion in December compared with the previous month.
Despite the drop, he went on, the company still enjoyed an operating surplus for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry to set up special accounts for needy students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education announced Monday anew initiative to help students from low-income families as more and more children are reporting difficulties paying school bills.
The School Education Savings Accounts, to be officially opened Jan. 1, will enable 2,114 elementary, junior high and high schools and their individual students to receive aid from donors.
On the outset, the accounts will share a lump sum of NT$200 million (US$6.15 million) provided by the Ministry of Education, said Minister Tu Cheng-sheng.
The new measure is aimed at helping over 50,000 students each year from the 6th to the 12th grades whose families cannot afford the basic tuition and school lunches.
These include students from low to lower- middle income families and those whose families have suffered financially due to unforeseen circumstances.

The measure will add to the current help being provided to those underprivileged students, Tu said. For the last few years, the ministry has subsidized school meals for those who have applied as long as the application comes with a teacher's approval.

The basic fees excluding lunch for each semester is about NT$1,100 for a child enrolled in a public junior high school, and NT$1,300 for an elementary school student. In addition, textbook fees range from NT$300 for a 1st or 2nd grader to about NT$660 for a 12th grader per semester.
School lunches cost about an extra NT$2,750 for each semester.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 50% of Taiwan people unhappy with 2007 incomes

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people responding to a recent poll said they were not satisfied with their income in 2007, according to the results of a survey released by Global Views Monthly magazine Monday.

The survey, conducted between Nov. 30 and Dec. 5, elicited information from an effective sample of 1,007 people. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points 19 times out of 20.
The results show that 42.8 percent of respondents believe that Taiwan's economy will deteriorate further in 2008.

Their pessimism is due to a series of factors, including the government's ambiguous policies, confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties, politicians paying only lip service to the economy, the reluctance of foreign investors to invest in Taiwan and the delayed realization of the three direct links in transport, trade and postal services between Taiwan and China.
Only 29 percent of interviewees are optimistic that the economy will improve in 2008.

The survey also found that 34 percent of those polled said the stand-off between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang is the foremost issue to be resolved as soon as possible, followed by economic development, education, unemployment and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall to re-open Tuesday

TEXT.P: A special exhibition will open at the main hall of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall Tuesday to mark the completion of its renovation, a spokesman for the hall said Monday.

President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony, during which he will open the main entrance to the hall where a giant bronze statue of the late President Chiang Kai-shek will remain in place, said Tseng Kun-ti, the hall's curator.

The main hall has been shut since its name plaque and an inscription on the arch gateway to the memorial hall complex were replaced earlier this month to get rid of all references to the late president who has been branded by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as a dictator and the main perpetrator of the tragic 228 Incident of 1947.

President Chen said last weekend while stumping for a DPP legislative candidate that Chiang's statue will stay put, but the walls of the hall will be decorated with posters featuring the names, photos and life accounts of those who were wrongly killed or persecuted during Chiang's authoritarian rule of Taiwan until his death in 1975.
Tseng said that the exhibition has been planned by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation and that he does not know the content of the exhibition.
Tseng made the remarks while explaining the itinerary of the exhibition's opening ceremony at a press conference.
The opening ceremony will open with a song performed by the National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra and the National Experimental Chorus, Tseng said.
Afterwards, a group of 100 people will sing four more tunes before Chen opens the hall gate, Tseng went on.

After visiting the special exhibition at the main hall on the second floor of the building, Chen will pay a visit to two exhibitions on the ground floor featuring the government's lifting of a ban on the launch of new newspapers and the country's human rights promotion efforts, respectively, Tseng noted.

For safety concern, areas close to the memorial hall will be closed to public access from 2: 00 a.m. to noon Tuesday, Tseng said, adding that the exhibition at the hall will be open to the public from Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peaceful transition of power a must: KMT candidate

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou will issue a New Year's message Tuesday in which he will call for the government to assure that there will be a peaceful transition of power May 20, 2008 regardless of the results of the March 22 presidential election.

According to a pre-released copy of his New Year's message made available to the media Monday evening, Ma describes 2008 as a critical year that will determine Taiwan's destiny and its democratic future.

Noting that the 2008 presidential election will decide whether Taiwan's young democracy will continue to prosper and whether clean politics can be achieved, Ma's New Year's message says that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration should be required to ensure smooth and orderly proceeding of the election in an open and fair manner.
And regardless of the electoral outcome, the statement says the DPP administration is obligated to guarantee a peaceful transition of power without any chaos or upheaval.
Ma will deliver his new year's message after attending a flag-raising ceremony in front of the Presidential Office Tuesday morning.
